I was buying these wonderful almonds via Amazon's Subscribe & Save program quite frequently. Then all of a sudden they were no longer available that way. THEN when they reappeared on Amazon, they were off the S&S option and the price had more than doubled. Well, our economic system allows that but it doesn't make loyal buyers happy.I do notice that in the past Amazon seemed to be getting them directly from the producer and now another retailer appears to be in the middle.The cellophane-like material used to package these is brittle and rips quite easily after opening. I quickly learned to have another container ready when I opened the bag because the material was unsatisfactory.Whatever the price and packaging issues, these are excellent almonds. I am hoping the Maisie Jane people decide to sell directly through Amazon again.

Walked by my fridge with it during the installation process and it tried to take the fridge along. Well! This speaks to the strength of the magnet. Nope, considered trying it on the fridge but had a nice place with studs by my workbench. Only thing was I had to find longer screws than those supplied. But I suppose if the manufacturer supplied longer screws, the customers would be saying they had to go out and buy shorter ones. Figure you can't win.Anyway, this is now most conveniently holding tools that heretofore had wanted to hide from me, especially those needle-nose pliers. You know how needle-nose pliers are.

This is a (mostly) gentle, thoughtful story of the lives of a few people in a not-so-gentle time. Perhaps when human relationships are incomprehensible, nature is a better focus and the sharing of that can be beautiful.Differences, often-ironic circumstances, mistakes and how we muddle through... nicely written and eminently readable. Recommended.

They say there are as many different recoveries as there are those in recovery. Therefore, an approach that works for one person may not work for another, and a diversity of approaches is good. If this book and the author's ideas save even one person from the misery of addiction, the publication is so worth it.Tommy Rosen talks at length about his multiple addictions and what led to them. While he does at times seem to be "blaming" (not encouraged in 12-step programs), it is what it is and everyone's story is helpful to someone else out there. It is said, just wait and you will hear your story from others in the (12-step) rooms, even if only in parts here and there. I found Rosen's story good reading although at times appalling. (About things that you didn't do when "out there", you hear that those are your "not yets" - the depths to which you might sink if you "go back out" or relapse. Thus it is good to hear about what is called "low bottom".)Rosen gives piece after piece of wisdom, speaking from his own experience, strength and hope.Then he gets into moving beyond the "program" as we know it. At that point I feel he is doing what is not encouraged - he uses the program in a commercial way. Sure this goes beyond the traditional 12-step approach but it definitely uses it. You see, we soon realize that he is promoting a business he has set up. Sure, he may help some types of people a great deal as there are always those with the money who will benefit from following a guru.

This is a relatively elegant solution to an inelegant problem. While I have forced myself to deal with the reality of trapping and disposing of the inevitable rodents, it is always a challenge to my sensibilities. But I live in the country on a river and my supply is constantly replenished after I get rid of what wants my warmth and food supply. Hmm.Another positive aspect is that with the full housing, there is far less danger of getting fingers or kitty paws or whatever damaged accidentally as we forget where we've set traps when going about daily business.So they're more expensive if you have to throw them out with just one use. It's still worth it. Just set these up where mice will run, notably along walls, and wait. You can catch a fairly good-sized rodent with these. Then *poof* out with the garbage, preferably sooner than later.Both of mine have already gone away with problem solved.

There actually is a very slight smell of a component, similar to the way window cleaner smells, but thankfully no heavy-duty odor like the Pine-Sol that I have been using for years. What is useful about the heavy-duty cleaner smell is that if you want to mask something you can't get rid of, that just may do it. Temporarily, anyway, as most folks associate the strong odor with cleaning. Trouble is, what if someone who has to be there is allergic to that odoriferous ingredient or just can't stand it. I've had that happen. That's where this Nonsense comes in. First you have to realize that we associate strong masking odors with cleaners and then realize that is not necessary and may even be a problem. Just CLEAN is a good odor in the long run.Next question: How does it clean? Now obviously that is hard to quantify so I gave it a good test, using it spritzed full-strength right from the bottle, used it on a nasty situation, you know the kind of thing where you get used to the built-up paw prints on a refrigerator door. Well, I had such a mess to be cleaned. It was a combination of smears from food-covered hands and dirt and grease from people working on machinery projects grabbing something to drink without going to all the trouble of washing up. Sounds awful but life happens. So I went to work on it and this formulation cut right through that combination of foods and tough greases. No problem. Pretty good. Fridge clean.Plus I like that for general cleaning I can dilute this product so it will go much farther when cleaning lighter jobs.

It's a good idea to put some research into the project of buying an outdoor padlock that will be exposed to the elements, especially where any water that gets into the works will freeze and make it impossible to open the lock, at least until you've found your extension cords and hairdryer.So the issues are:- how does the lock's design prevent water from entering?- how thick is the shank? (too thick and it won't enter a narrower existing hasp)- the other normal lock questions like resistance to bolt cutters etc.This lock has the thick plastic drape on top but of course water can still enter where the shank slides so I put vaseline there to help even more. Time will tell. I was careful with the vaseline as I know that excess lubrication then attracts dust and dirt which over time gums up the mechanism. There is also a plastic cover on the bottom, that snaps into the keyhole. It is attached to the bottom of the lock and swivels. When it snaps all the way into the keyhole, it is difficult to snap out and requires something like a flat screwdriver blade to jimmy it loose - fingernails won't do it, not mine anyway. So be prepared for that.I measure the shank thickness of this as just under 5/16" or 8mm. It was a relief when it fit into the metal loop, or staple, of my existing hasp. Some of the other locks I saw had coatings on their shanks that would have prevented this. This shank is thicker than my previous, rusted lock but luckily not much.This is the only lock I've found that meets my needs so I bought it in spite of the bright yellow color of the body which in my neighborhood is like waving a red flag to malicious vandals. ("Oh, lookie, she thinks she's got her barn locked. We'll show her!") I fixed that, though, with some black electrical tape wound carefully around the yellow body. That won't stay forever in our hot/cold climate but can easily be replaced.Not only is the lock sturdy and water resistant, but the keys are far more substantial than those that come with your average padlock. The lock is large - I measure 1 7/8" wide and 3 1/2" long when in locked configuration, and heavy. It must weigh a pound although I haven't put it on a scale.

These shorter insoles that provide dense foam protection for the heel as it strikes, support around the heel's edges plus arch support are a good choice when the fit of the shoe doesn't leave room in the toe area for a full-length insole. I have largish female feet but choose the men's version of these Profoot orthotics because the arch is somewhat longer, which happens to be how my foot is.I got a bunch of these at Walmart back when they carried them and wish I'd bought them out because of course they disappeared. I like to be able to leave them in the various pairs of shoes that need them, so need lots. I have yet to wear these out so I think they are constructed of good stuff. I was really happy to find them on Amazon - they weren't here when I first looked.

I very much enjoyed this picture of contemporary Mormon life, the main thrust of the novel which is written in the first person voice of a feisty, impetuous woman, the wife of a bishop. The writing is straightforward and clear and contains many apt descriptions and observations of human nature. The author throws in a reasonable amount of LDS history for those who may not know it.The author deals with the issue of male dominance in a situation where there is not sufficient sanction for misbehavior, and how this can make monsters - shown in the ability of sociopaths to create false impressions of sainthood while covering their guilt, their grievous crimes. This, of course, is true in many settings, not just LDS. There is another theme of philosophical/religious rigidity, again a universal problem.In addition to all this, there are mysteries and heart-rendingly difficult emotional situations. But overall, this novel is about lives and is written with a great deal of warmth.

My old Kenmore cannister vac takes 5055 bags so I am happy to have these. They install just fine and are functioning well although they seem a bit thinner than the bags I've bought over many years at Sears. I've always been a little slow to change the bag and must resolve not to let them get so full, as I do worry that one day I will wind up tearing one, especially these thinner ones.Now on the topic of odor, which has always been something I've noticed when I first turn on the vacuum with a partially-filled bag in it - I'd say these do control that musty, dirty odor better. I have some very dusty cleanup to do so am happy with these and now am aware that I can order these, the price of which is lower, directly from Amazon rather than making a 75-mile round trip to the nearest Sears store.

Couldn't wait to get this quality soundbar with wireless sub hooked up to my TV. What a difference! I've always known Klipsch makes good stuff and this proves it. My previous soundbar was a tremendous improvement over the tinny TV sound but this one blows it out of the water with outstanding sound reproduction throughout the range - I can't detect any weak spots which are normally lower mid-range. And certainly the highs are gorgeous and precise, never too forward either.All I had to do was decide where the components would go. I chose to set the soundbar in front of the TV console which works because it is not too high. Then I put the subwoofer in a corner more or less behind a chair which also seems to work because the corner helps bounce the lows back into the room and those do not seem to require directionality but are more diffuse. The Bluetooth connection seemed to click right into place.When I think of the prices of high quality TV sound components just a few years ago it makes me even more impressed. It is my opinion that this Klipsch set is a real winner, especially in the price to quality ratio.

Cecelia Ekb√§ck's writing is spare and evocative, with an unerring instinct for presentation of character flaws and natural human fears. Wolf Winter is filled with beautifully handled symbolism - the church bells whose sounds bedevil a priest with a secret, plus I especially enjoyed "crayfish" for carcinoma, a delightful use of metonymy - and the supernatural elements are maybe, maybe not, which is to say that they could be a dead man stalking or they could be the product of fear in the everlasting night. Or mental derangement.The author takes us 'way north to Lapland where a few settlers dare live in the shadow and seemingly malevolent influence of BlackÂsen, the mountain that takes the blame for the actions of men. She weaves into the story Swedish political history as well as social: the juxtaposition of old superstitions and the Christianity that forbids (or replaces) them. She writes, via story narrative, a powerful treatise about the role of guilty secrets and false accusations which in a small, righteous population cause the accused to be painfully, even fatally shunned and punished by church or law, the same thing in days of yore.This novel deserves a prize.

I feel this early, long-lost work gives me more of a psychological portrait of the author as a young man than anything else. Which is not to say that it is not an insightful view of the inhabitants of an urban Portuguese apartment building.But the focus seems on interactions of couples as well as sexuality. The women tend to be strong and domineering while the men acquiesce in order to keep the peace. Not all follow that pattern, mind you, but it is the trend. I kept getting the insight of that pattern in the author's mind. In addition I kept getting the feeling that the writer was an introverted young man struggling with a youthful search for life's meaning, and no doubt one who was intimidated and probably captivated by the opposite sex. I kept thinking his mother must have run things.I did keep in mind that this was written by a not-yet-published writer who hadn't the supposed advantage of being "taught" to write. (Don't get me started on that whole business. I believe all the expensive writers' workshops in the world won't fix those who can't write, and those who can will do it quite on their own.) I also kept in mind that it was written more than sixty years ago and that styles have changed. Nonetheless the writing jumps around enough that I finally had to make a chart of the characters. It does give a good feel for that society in that time.This newly published translation is prefaced by a well-written foreword.

Smooth as whipped cream tho texture is more dense, very soothing and fully emulsified. Perhaps a very slight odor of one or more ingredients but nothing to trigger allergies. I mean almost no odor. It may be packaged for kids but it is fine for everyone. My skin was dry when I was young and is worse now, red and flaking - I guess you call that eczema. This is definitely a huge help and not greasy; it absorbs easily. It does contain an "extremely mild antibacterial", which frankly a skin cream in a jar needs due to the high probability of contamination when dipping in even with just-washed hands.And to think that I almost didn't try this because the product description was so over-the-top and repetitive, making the customer suspicious. Suggestions would include getting someone with editorial skills to assist with rewriting that description, and considering packaging this superior product in a squeeze tube which would lessen the danger of bacterial growth before the product is used up.Meanwhile, thanks for a real keeper.

It's a character, that tree, holding the Waverly women hostage in their swirling emotions until its out-of-season, weirdly prolific bloom, having thrown, yes, its dangerous fruit at anyone suspicious. Come to think of it, the old Waverly house is a character too. Such is the stuff this novel is made of. Some of it never does get explained but is wisely left to the reader. But along the way Sarah Addison Allen treats us to humor and wisdom and warmth and enjoyable characters. And a truckload of analogies. All along we know SOMETHING is going to happen and hope our friends, the Waverly women, survive snubs, barrenness, abandonment and treachery. By the end, though, everything is tied up in neat little bows.First Frost stands on its own despite having a predecessor, Garden Spells.Most who choose to read this genre expect the inclusion of somewhat wacky magical happenings but I found those included here, while sometimes apt and fun, are too often juvenile and a bit tired.

This is really quite good. Realize it is a specific genre - I'd call it historical mystery/romance. The story is captivating although it takes a bit before it warms up, just a warning. The author weaves a love of food into the narrative both by starting most chapters with old recipes and by the story, as the main character is a cook or "undercook" - it is her position and her passion - then with another character who is a chef, a food artist, and joins forces near the end.Meanwhile the scene in 18th century England and as the entourage makes its way through France and the Alps into Italy is most likely authentic, with regional speech and old-fashioned terms. The author goes all out to use language as it might have been and at times I found both this and the food aspect a bit cloying. Also there was just a little too much of what we now call TMI - too much information - which is to say some of the gory scenes seem unnecessary.Still, these are minor complaints as the plot is good with twists and turns and plenty of description, good dialog as we get the picture of how it was with servants, marriages driven by money and people who make mistakes and then pay for them. I really like that in the end this novel is an "upper" and that is the case all the way along with enjoyable characters who rise above the daily grind.

This historical romance gives us a lovely picture of English class structure as well as an effective set of World War One scenes that makes the horror quite clear. The author is skilled at dialog that includes the British "stiff upper lip" way of using the language and regional and class-related speech patterns. She does a simply masterful job with scene and character development; the novel is a charm to read, and while it deals with unpleasantness, is basically upbeat.This is the second in a series but the competent writing allows it to stand alone.If you're like me and find that the figure on the cover with her botoxed lips hanging stupidly (and perhaps provocatively) suggests that the novel is trash, don't worry, it is most assuredly not, anything but. The main female character is intelligent and morally upstanding, very much so.  I don't know who chooses the cover art that doesn't match the contents.

This beautiful little book is a perfect gift for the Updike fan or for anyone who likes literature and the best of writing. Even if you find some of Updike's later work tedious and/or filled with strange recitations of everything popular at a given time or evidence of his sexual addiction, you needn't worry with this small collection - it is his best work. And there IS a reason Updike gets a lot of attention in the literary world: he is or can be a fabulous, magical writer. If you want to read talented prose, here it is.It is beautifully bound with mustard-colored cloth pasted to its boards. It lies flat without any encouragement and has a classy bookmark ribbon. The dust jacket, as you can see, sports eye-candy colors. I love it.

A product that kills bacteria and viruses can be useful in any household, probably more so where there are members who tend to bring home germs from outside. This kills most stuff and while it may not eliminate every single encapsulated bacterium or spore etc., it can reduce their numbers so that the immune system has a better chance of dealing with them.My only complaint is that I feel these products should be unscented due to remarkably common sensitivities to scents. I sprayed this and my boyfriend acted as though I were trying to kill him. I couldn't do anything about what was already in the air and secretly thought he over-reacted but I do get the point and know he has chemical sensitivities. So do I, frankly.

The heat is gentle but effective. The fan is so quiet that I forget it's running. I like it so much that I'll keep it even though it wound up being an extra this year. (I do have a theory with space heaters that one can never have too many when there are many spaces.)It looks as though the fan has variable speed but actually as you turn the dial, at a certain point it clicks into its higher speed and that's it - two speeds. There do seem to be three different heat levels. And one for fan alone, which produces a pleasantly gentle fan effect even on the higher setting, rather than one of those that blows all the paper off the desk.But do watch the price - I got mine for half what the retailers are asking here, at a certain ubiquitous W place.

Protein sources low in fat are always sought and welcomed here. This one is particularly interesting because the protein sources are vegetable, and there are no questionable chemical additives.The second ingredient is what the manufacturer is calling "SaviSeed", better known as Sacha Inchi: Plukenetia volubis, which is a perennial native to much of tropical South America and some Caribbean islands. It is historically cultivated by indigenous peoples. It is a member of the Euphorbia family so should be approached with a bit of caution as many members of that family possess chemical structures poisonous to humans. However Sachi Inchi is not known for that; there could be individuals susceptible to its components. The dried seeds of Sacha Inchi have high protein (27%) and oil (35-60%) content and are rich in Omegas 3&6 as well as iodine and Vitamins A&E. Their amino acid profile makes their protein particularly usable by humans. Sacha Inchi is currently gaining favor as a "superfood".Alfalfa, the third ingredient, is in the pea family; a legume whose roots contain nitrogen-fixing bacteria and improve soil, especially in crop rotation. Thus there is a high legume content in this supplement, with the prime ingredient being pea protein. Some people do experience bloating and gas with legume consumption, especially when unaccustomed.So far I have found this supplement to have a strange and vaguely bitter taste when mixed with water per directions. I decided to add it to some low acid Greek-style yogurt and it still gave me the same somewhat bitter result which I improved with the addition of a small amount of dark brown sugar which of course makes it less healthy. It was initially gritty in the yogurt but fully hydrated after six hours.I am continuing to think outside the box re how to fold it into my diet. My boyfriend said he thought I would eat hay if I thought it was good for me.UPDATE: I've tried and tried to like this stuff. I realize that an important factor in what is palatable is being used to a given taste; in addition some specific taste perceptions are inherited. Those qualifiers given, I simply have to say that to me this tastes awful. I've always been a good eater, not picky at all even as a child, and I do like many foods that are bitter. But this just has an off taste that ruins everything I put it in - it's more than bitter, there's something that I not only can't describe but I also don't know what causes it. I've tried to think of it as a "space food" that provides my body with nutrition but it's not working. I guess if I were really, really, really hungry...

Functional and fun; THE gift this year for the football fan in your life. Or an indulgence for your man cave if they don't get it for you. Mine is in my girl cave, ha, and it's a good thing there are two heat settings because it really puts it out.Infrared quartz is the technology experts are recommending as both effective and more energy efficient than other kinds of space heaters. Indeed, many businesses here in the frigid northeast have gone to heating large offices with this technology. I mean there's oil backup but it's the infrared quartz that keeps the place toasty. So I was delighted to try this.It's a really large yellow ball and I consider the color both safe due to visibility, and fun. The fan is, as it says, quiet, 'way quieter than my dehumidifier, unobtrusive. The filter is washable, and I mentioned the practical two heat settings.

Because I generally buy jewelry in person, I find shopping for it online difficult. Mainly that is because even with the dimensions carefully given, I find it hard to visualize actual size.This is a substantial piece. The stones are impressive and the setting both surrounds these stones and has two levels so that the faceted gems are held away from the wearer and thus reflect light effectively. The chain, however, is miniscule.The stones are both cut so that there is a flat surface on most of the top but the sides and bottom are where the facets are. This cut reflects light through the top surface. I would say that the facets are fairly large and not particularly complex, but they are very even. I do have some almost amusing observations about the colors of the stones. The smaller stone is a smoky quartz but my example shows no smokiness. Rather it is slightly pinkish, which is odd because the amethyst, which is described as a pink amethyst (most commonly they are in purple hues), is in fact brown. The one I have is quite saturated and although I can see no inclusions in either stone, the amethyst is sufficiently dark that I cannot see through it. Regardless of the descriptions, both stones are very pleasing and attractive and the light plays through them prettily.On jewelry that gets a lot of wear, plating can be a problem. But on a necklace - I mean the ornament - it normally is just fine. Gold plating on sterling silver is industry standard, that is GOOD industry standard. The chain is presumably also plated, and there it can be less satisfactory. However, I will quickly replace this chain with a far heavier one I already have. I am happy to report that the chain hoop at the top of the dangle has a good 1/8" clearance so getting a better chain through it will not be a problem.

Thomas Pierce examines our little lives and en route adds tongue-in-cheek zaniness. He gently exposes societal foibles - I mean have you ever wondered about the effect on the victims whose goofs and awkwardness are caught on film, then endlessly ridiculed by TV and online broadcast? If so, read "Videos of People Falling Down". Pierce intertwines their lives to the point that you need a chart to follow the connections. "We of the Present Age" explores the hoax. Think Cardiff Man redux.And so it goes - what happens when you helplessly let your lover make a graphic video? And when you're the object of scorn from the mouth of the father of a foolish former girlfriend whom you unwittingly impregnated then responsibly parented the resulting child? Pierce doesn't answer these questions, oh no, he just points them out, wraps sometimes surreal scenes around them.I like the themes and the added absurdity but the characters hardly seem to have feelings; rather they just go through the motions of their lives. Maybe that woodenness adds to the intended absurdity.

These have the excellent taste of dates and oatmeal plus the pick-me-up of chocolate. Ever since I discovered L√§rabars, I have been sold on energy bars made of dates. These ZonePerfects seem to have a lower proportion of date although that is the leading ingredient. But they do not appear to have a lot of chemicals, just natural ingredients. I find them very tasty although somewhat too sweet. Another thing I REALLY like is that they are formulated to be soft enough that they do not threaten dental work like some brands of bars do.Generally speaking, although I love chocolate, especially unsweetened dark, I find bars with chocolate chips to be 'way too sicky-sweet. That, of course, is due to the inclusion of excessive sugars. These too are a little too sweet for my taste but not as bad as others I've had. Of course these by the manufacturer's admission contain both "evaporated cane syrup" (which is a way of saying "sugar" when there is a desire to camouflage the fact) and chocolate chips, one of whose ingredients is also the tricky evaporated cane syrup. Since that adds up to more sugar than I want or need, I use these Protein Bars for specific times when I need the instant energy of sugar plus want the lift of the small amount of caffeine in chocolate.One would notice that the fat content is high - 8% - with 10% of that being saturated fat.However they are basically gluten free although the disclaimer mentions that they are made in a facility that does process wheat. For the majority of us who must avoid gluten, tiny trace amounts are not a problem, so for my purposes these are gluten free. Some celiac sufferers, however, cannot eat oats, but those people would hardly choose these.

Before using, I washed the cover and aired out the foam portion. I knew as soon as I opened the box that I would be sensitive to its odor. So far I have not been able to remedy the odor problem enough to actually put my head there for sleeping, but I do have a history of sensitivity to scents. However, I didn't know when I ordered it, that this was made in China which gives me pause due to documented problems with items manufactured there. Thing is, I am not sure it is wise to be breathing whatever it is for the length of time I am sleeping even if I am able to eliminate the odor.I generally use down pillows and grew up with chicken feather ones, and never had a problem with allergy to those. This is my first attempt to use a contoured memory foam pillow, and I was excited to do so although I do own and use regular foam ones. However so far I have not been able to test the contour aspect but did want to warn others who may have sensitivities.

And in many of the recipes that have glutinous ingredients, substitutions are offered. If you're gluten free like me you wouldn't order a cookbook if you couldn't use a large percentage of the recipes. No worry here, I'm happy to assure you.As a teenager, I used to simply take the round carton of oatmeal to my room after school and eat the stuff dry. That's how much I like oatmeal. The other kids were off having various sweets and I was chowing down on oatmeal.That enjoyment never changed and cold mornings are still warmed with my gourmet bowl. Yes, gourmet. Some guy on the (amateur) radio once gave me instructions - I thought it was so funny that a disembodied male voice was telling a woman whose cooking skills he didn't know how to make "gourmet oatmeal". Seemed like an oxymoron. But I followed his instructions, which were simply to heat the (salted) water nearly to boiling in the microwave before adding the oatmeal, then zap it again til it does that rolling-boiling thing. Allow to cool, add milk. Of course make it with raisins if you like. Still making it that way here. Don't have to use those little supermarket packets that contain all sorts of chemicals and too much sugar.So now an inventive cookbook author puts her imagination to work and comes up with all sorts of new ways to use a grain I already like, and even includes gluten free ways to make things I really want, like Indian roti (flatbread) and fat-free pumpkin raisin granola.In addition to the great ideas, the book is bound in such a way that the pages flatten out in use.

One might well be fascinated with anyone, especially female, who begins a remarkable career at sixty. Penelope Fitzgerald is a writer appreciated by the cognoscenti and not a household name. If a completist among us wants to know every detail of her life, this biography will provide - ah - even more than you wanted.Biographer Hermione Lee's writing is fussy but thorough with parentheticals, asides, qualifiers, ponderous details often ad nauseum. The biography is entertaining but confusing: it is not easy to keep details of Ms. Fitzgerald's life straight from the beginning. Luckily a genealogical chart is provided but even that is hard to read (and I am an experienced although amateur genealogist).Lee takes Penelope Fitzgerald's life from her forebears through her early years that involve an edifice described as Old Castle to living with her brood on a not-so-gently-retired barge moored on the Thames, through the years when she turns her life experience into her intelligent, admirable literary works.This dense, considerable work is best suited to readers who are either for some reason fascinated with every possible facet of the writer's life, or doing research.

Absurd. Gritty. Well chosen from the memorabilia around black American painter Jean-Michel Basquiat who was of Haitian and Puerto Rican descent and his relationship with Canadian runaway Suzanne Mallouk whose father was an Arab. Well, their ethnicities seem to figure importantly in this small book. What is this fascination with supposedly famous people, anyway?This piece is not just about the drug-addled (and/or possibly mentally ill) artist and his strange, pliable young girlfriend, but about the 1980s New York City scene; it is existential - you really get the feeling of that life. Actually, this is one part of life in The City, as so many of its denizens still lived as they always had - their small, conservative lives confined by a few blocks of neighborhood while ignoring adjacent craziness and alternative life styles.I had moved young and alone from a small rural village 200 miles north, to NYC a decade or so earlier, so I know what an intense, unsettling, iconoclastic, avant-garde place it can be - a place where anonymity confers sudden freedom and new alliances are magic.To put aspects of it into words? Well, this does and in a non-judgmental, spare manner.

Haven't you always wanted to know what goes on inside teenage brains? Well, this Survival Guide will supply you with more information than you actually hoped for. It is both practical and highly technical. To absorb everything, I will keep going back to it.I had an optional class in adolescent psych back in my teacher training days - college - and think I've always wondered what makes teenagers tick. Well to be honest, I wonder about some memories of my own antics. We never gave full credence to the concept that the stages of development had importance. We knew that in our fairly recent history, by the time a boy was 13 or so he could and would do a man's work, and that often by 15 a girl was married and bearing children. Has something changed? True, there has to be societal influence and that has changed rapidly over the past 200 years, certainly in the Western world. But just maybe the wiring is and always has been, different, more different than we thought.If you have questions, and/or are dealing with adolescents as so many of us are, read Dr. Jensen's thoughtful and scientific take on what's happening inside the teenage cranium.

O Africa: Hilarious, hip writing that takes us romping irreverently through ethnic Manhattan (and the boroughs) and then to the Dark Continent in the company of twin brothers Micah and Izzy, boy wonders of the film world.We read intently not only about the making of moving pictures and the inevitable march of progress, but also about life in Africa of that time. We are quite exhausted by the end, but we have been entertained by a talented, vigorous writer.

You can make guitar strings out of anything you want as long as the acoustical properties and longevity are there. These strings are described as having aluminum added for corrosion resistance compared to all-bronze strings. I cannot comment yet on the corrosion resistance, but do like the crispness of sound on my venerable Guild classical/folk guitar. I am experiencing clarity along with power, and it might be my imagination, but it seems that the finger action is a little easier.

This highly-illustrated coffee table book is top quality, beautiful and weighs a good five pounds. It thoroughly explores railway and locomotive history and includes technical information suitable to hold the interest of young people with an engineering bent. It also serves as memorabilia for those of us who remember the day (Grandpa was a D&H station agent and Uncle an author of railway history books) and as an informative source for history buffs. Stories and wonderful photographs of trains world-wide are offered, along with biographical information on those who invented and developed them. Quality all the way. Recommended.

For most people's needs, this will suffice. If you are a highly-experienced or professional user, you would do well to acquire the professional version of CorelDRAW. And to check your system against this product's requirements before buying. It may seem stingy of a company to put out a version like this, that is not fully-featured and not professionally usable, but that's the way it is. And Corel, in the world of "paint" software, is a leader.I personally am finding this more than adequate for my limited use, which involves photo enhancement and occasionally a foray into morphing pictures just for fun. One aspect I particularly appreciate is the 3-user capability. It isn't that I want to give it to lots of people, it is simply that computers die all the time, taking their expensive software with them. And I use two computers, one at home and a laptop on the road, so right there is the need for two copies.

This wonderfully transporting novel reminds us again of the passion of creativity and the plight of females who in bygone times happened to possess it. It is poetically written and in its own way uplifting. Although scenes of difficulty are written, this novel is not filled with horror or violence but rather with light, life and color. Speaking of which, the young woman, Guilia, hears the musical voices of paints in much the same way that many of us see letters and words as having specific colors. It is charming.This is the second book in a series, the first being "Passion Blue", which I have not read but intend to. It was obvious throughout that there was a backstory that would have allowed me greater enjoyment, but having read the first book was not essential as it was sufficiently explained.My only criticism, and certainly not enough to detract from a 5-star book, is that I wish writers who are including musical allusions would check with a well-educated musician before stumbling. Frankly, an editor should have caught this - Ms. Strauss refers to one color as having the voice of a silver flute, which was an instrument not in existence until the mid-nineteenth century. The book, of course, is set in the fifteenth.

Stories that bring alive parts of history - to me especially history in the arts world - are always appreciated. This novel about Picasso and his women does so, and presents Paris of that time with all the usual suspects including of course Gertrude Stein, worked in.But throughout the writing kept striking me as amateurish, sometimes even clunky, as if written for children. Even while enjoying the somewhat clich√©d Paris scene, Moulin Rouge and all, I kept forgetting my initial impression and being struck all over again that the writing plods when it could fly.Nonetheless, I did enjoy this presentation of Picasso's life and those of his women, and the surrounding often bohemian and exciting Paris scene.

As I toddled through early childhood, the Nazi scourge was in full flower. Adults did their best to keep me from learning to read when in 1945 the newspapers were filled with accounts of the shocking truth. At the same time my stepfather, an Italian-American Army Major and medical officer, was conducting investigations as Allies entered the conquered concentration camps. He much later told me he had never believed the assertions of German civilians that they didn't know what was going on in their back yards.Be that as it may, it is important to remember that in any society gone awry, many upstanding citizens continue their life work according to their firmly-held righteous convictions. The man whose work is discussed in this book, Josef Hartinger, a Munich prosecutor, is such a man. And in the end his records of his interviews and those of his medical examiner, Dr. Moritz Flamm, were incalculably valuable in bringing Nazi perpetrators to justice via the Nuremberg Trials. I applaud Timothy Ryback for his research and writing that bring us this man's story, and as an important side issue, continue to keep the reality of the Nazi years alive so that we may never forget them and may continue to know that only by vigilance and sacrifice will their repetition be prevented.Think the stories of Nazi horror are made up? There are legions who will tell you that Hitler's tyranny never happened. I only fully learned of it myself when as a small-town sophomore in 1955, I found a book about Hitler's Third Reich in my high school library. I had thought we lived in an age of civilization. Guess again. I was shocked. And learned what the world was trying to forget. It had JUST HAPPENED.Thanks to writers like Rybeck, there is some hope of education. No, this is not fun reading. But it is well researched and well written and one more important book on the table that keeps alive the memories of those millions who died and those who did their best against a seemingly unstoppable world-domination machine.

My husband has to take fish oil for an eye condition. I take it for general health reasons. These 'soft gels', while large, are pretty easy to swallow. No GI complaints from either of us. Best of all they do not have a childproof cap and we can open the top with our arthritic hands! Families with young children should be aware of that but it's great for us.

We have a wrought iron ornament tree and get a dated ornament every year. We've never had a Lenox one before. This is a large, showy ornament that looks like a finial. It is liberally outlined in gold and has very nice illustrations on the side. The "2015" is on the top on a tiny gold tag.The ornament is made in China. My preference would be for a larger display of the year. However this is quite pretty and will represent 2015 quite well!

These batting gloves in large are a perfect fit for my husband who traditionally has a difficult time with gloves. He has used them in his baseball league at work as well as cycling. I can also see these as useful in active outdoors activities or snowblowing.He has done arthritis in his hands and particularly noticed how supportive and forgiving these gloves are at the joints. Most of all, the fit was primary. Well made, superior all round active wear gloves. A very enthusiastic 5 stars here.

I really love this butter keeper. I hate cold butter but if we leave it out it gets rancid. This solves that problem and eliminates the various plates cups and dishes that my husband parks partial sticks of butter.I live in an area that does not sell premium cube butter so we use traditional sticks. You do need to "rearrange" each stick to fit the mold. The video seems a bit condescending on that point but we buy local and here that = stick butter. That aside I love this container; it has the warm heft of stoneware and does what I need it to do.

This 20% urea cream is marketed for dry itchy skin, specifically hands, knees, elbows and feet. It has no scent and a smooth, easy to apply texture. It definitely worked well on my heels, helping to eliminate the chronic dry flaky skin. Unfortunately, the results on my hands were unappealing. The cream left a chalky, tacky feel to them that was really unpleasant. I disliked it so much that I now wear gloves to apply this product to my feet in order to avoid contact.This was a decent balm to some eczema I have on my elbow and it reduced the itch quite a bit. Overall, I think there are other products I'd use for my heels and eczema before I'd purchase this. The deal breaker for me is how it felt on my hands. I could not wait to wash it off.

We get a very high volume of Halloween traffic at our house. We have a shrub by our sidewalk that blocks the view of our front door. I bought these to wrap that shrub and alert people to the fact that yes we are home and participating in Halloween. It worked better than I could have hoped. I heard people using the lights as a rendezvous point. The kids just loved them. I had at least a dozen inquiries about where to buy them. There are really waterproof....it was raining all night and they were unfazed.Just FYI....this one string did a perfect job covering one shrub. If you are covering more real estate you are going to need a whole lot of batteries. For me one of the selling points was not having to run power from the house. I put the powerpack in a ziploc bag and tucked it into the branches. The one string could outline windows or a bannister. Just keep your overall needs in mind. A wonderful product, thanks so much.

I've used other Xen-Tan products in the last but not this mousse. I have very pale legs and like a bit of color in them for yoga/capris. This mousse goes on very easily with the optional mitt (sold separately). I recommend duty mitt: I've done this with disposable gloves and the mitt gives more even, streak free coverage. The scent is quite pleasant, a warm vanilla fragrance.With this product you need to leave it on for 3 hours before washing off. The good news is that it dries fairly quickly and then you can dress (dark clothes advised). It is a big cold here in WI to sit around undressed waiting 3 hours to take a shower.There is probably enough in the one container to do my legs 3 or 4 times. The results are quite dark on me but very even. The color lasts about a week. My only criticism is the 3 hour wait. I pretty much have to plan my day around it. Otherwise, good stuff.

These easy to clean placemats have a high sheen and look nice on a picnic table or outdoor setting. They are a bit plastic for use in your house or for family dinners. I like them most for going under centerpieces or candles. Stray wax cleans off quickly without staining.They are better looking at a distance; close up they look a bit cheap. For me, 3 stars.

This is a box of 8 packs of 250 multi fold paper towels. The top of the box is pre-scored to tear away to provide handy access to the packs. These towels are of good quality. These are dense enough to clean without falling apart. I have not had one shred on my while using them to clean my house.These really come into their own in our main floor bathroom. I can't keep a hand towel clean there for more than an hour. I have a free standing multi-towel dispenser and these fit perfectly. No more nasty towels to wash. These towels are a standard size and will fit in any multi-fold towel dispenser. Great for cold and flu season.

I'm of the slide rule generation and although I conduct my work with computers every day, I know little about how they function. This is an interactive toy that teaches in a logical manner and walks you through interactive tasks that build on the prior knowledge. Of course it is meant for children but I have found it engaging and delightful. I like how it is both instructive and intuitive. This robot and Wonder App program use light sound and fun to propel the user to more challenging levels of thought and function.The Wonder App was easy to install and utilize. The colors and icon movements are smooth and supportive of success. As fun as this is for me at 60, I think it is a brilliant choice for kids as a learning exercise to build upon.

I am an adult woman and these in the PG size fit me really well. I am not a skier but living in WI I am subjected to daily snow challenges, usually from November to March ( ar least). That includes snowblowing and shoveling as well as daily walks into town. Very comfortable fit and very clear vision. Nicely made, very impressive. I will get a lot of use out of these.

This pendant is a gorgeous champagne color which I chose to wear with a favorite outfit. I had not interpreted the photos correctly and thought this was a smoother, tumbled piece. While the back surface is smooth ( against your skin) the right side is raw and craggy. However, what that does is to allow the fire of the stone to shine from many more facets. It looks very sparkly on.The pendant is set on the chain and does not slide up and down, which I appreciate. I also like that I could pick a 16" length which is just right for me. The stone is very nicely wrapped in silver wire and fashioned into a bail. It is secure.  Overall the piece has wonderful color, shine and texture.If you like a natural look in what you wear this could well be for you. Keep in mind this artist ships from Canada which can cause a slight delay if you are in the US.

This game ....which I call bean bag toss but my Midwestern neighbors call 'cornhole'....is almost an addiction where I live. People play it in the office, at tailgates...anywhere. When I set this up in the backyard a neighbor invited himself over to play. We played for a couple hours until it got too dark to see.The angle of the boards is just right to thwart an easy score. The bean bags have a nice enough heft. I can't go 5 stars because the " locking mechanism" is a Velcro strip and carrying this game by the handle is awkward at best. This game is made in China and I just do not see the retail or sale price reflected in the materials. I live in a wet climate and people do play this in the snow; this set would not last long in wet weather. Maybe in Arizona but not WI.That said, this is a lot of fun and we'll use it until it falls apart. My husband loves it and we now have a better relationship with our neighbor. 4 stars.

This is a light, kind of tinny medallion on a very light chain. It doesn't have any shine or substance to it. I tried for a while to think of circumstances in which I'd wear this; maybe yoga or swimming or some activity that might put better jewelry at risk. I think this might be fine for a child who wants to wear a necklace. It just doesn't have much appeal in person. I think it is kind of a misfire. I'd be more likely to wear no necklace than this. 2 stars is as high as I can go.

This is a marvelous up to the minute guide to Paris. I'd recommend it to anyone contemplating a trip there or even interested in reading about it. The maps are first rate and the regional sections on shopping, sightseeing and food are all terrific. You absolutely cannot go wrong with this book. This is exclusive to Paris so plan on picking up a companion guide to France.5 stars from me since I cannot find anything to criticize about this guide. The full pull out map and the Metro guide are the best I have seen. Buy and read this guide BEFORE your trip to get the most out of your stay. Paris is a city which can mesmerize and a firm understanding of your priorities ahead of time will maximize your enjoyment.

This may look like a classic denim jacket but once you touch the fabric you'll know different. It is a thinnish blend of cotton (62%), polyester, rayon and spandex. It is quite stretchy. The stitching and seam work are excellent. I found this jacket close fitting in the shoulder, long in the sleeves and not even close in the chest. I normally wear a 12 and have a 34G chest. This jacket is not made for me. If you are busty, definitely size up. Unless I get a breast reduction, there is no way I can wear this closed. The shoulder fit is good ( and I am narrow shouldered) so I'd think about wearing this open. It looks really nice on a hanger.I couldn't get beyond the feel of the fabric. Too plastic for me.

My husband is an enthusiastic home chef but not so much on cleaning. I love these bags as they really deliver great meals with minimal oven clean up There are just 2 of us so a whole meal can go in one whether we use our small convection oven or our larger gas oven. I've never had one leak. They are especially useful with large "roast the meal with the vegetable" projects.At the price of over 1$ a pouch we don't use these every day but they are quite useful for holidays and Sunday dinners. We don't grill out but I can see how versatile these would be for that. Handy product.

This is a really sweet, warm guide to Brooklyn with marvelous graphics. It makes you feel at home just paging through it. I covers the geographic sections of Brooklyn well. There is no traditional fold out map here but cartoon like street guides to each section. The visual images make the borough seem home-like. I have family there and this book definitely gives you the flavor of Brooklyn.Do not think this is a comprehensive guide to Brooklyn but rather suggested highlights. The one place people want me to take them when I go to Brooklyn is Brooklyn Denim in Williamsburg. It has been around for 5 years so an odd omission. It is a destination for a lot of out of towners and I was surprised to see it not included.This is a cheerful guide with valid, accurate information. A decent start for anyone traveling there.

I really like Clorox crystals for cleaning so this just seemed like the same in a pod format. I don't use bleach in the laundry so this is strictly for kitchen and bathroom cleaning. The pods are easy to handle. I found it took them quite a while to dissolve. I now drop them into the toilets or bucket water before I plan to clean to give them a head start.I have a hard time opening the containers; there is a squeeze /turn mechanism that isn't oppositional. With arthritic hands I find it challenging to open the lid. It was so annoying I transferred the pods to an empty Tide pod container. There are no children or pets in my home so this is safe and much easier for me.I like these a lot; they prevent accidental spills and ruined clothes. I'd probably buy the crystals if they were less expensive.

I had gone to a jewelry store in search of  Tanzanite 6 mm earrings. I saw a pair I liked but the price (500$) was beyond my budget. When I checked the listings on Amazon I saw these and decided that these were for me.The stones are lovely, filled with light and fire. While they look light and pale in the box, they take on their full character once worn. In my ears they are a rich medium bluish purple. The stones match very well.I was disappointed in the findings/settings. They are a bit light and thin for this price range. The backings are also very light. I like the stones so much I may have them reset in more substantial findings. That's the only thing keeping these from 5 stars. I am happy with the stones and they are equal to the 500$ ones in the jewelry store. If you like the special qualities of Tanzanite, these are a nice buy.

I hand wash all my dishes and have sensitive, dermatitis prone hands. These are excellent dishwashing gloves. They come up higher on the wrist than the regular nitrile gloves (cover my watch). They are extremely water and puncture resistant. I normall wear a small but got these in a medium. That makes them looser but easier on/off. These are so sturdy I can reuse them day after day. Very impressive durability.Plan to order your correct size for a close fit.

My glove preference is latex. They have been hard to find over the years in a powder free form in a small size. These fit my hands perfectly ( I normally wear a size 6 glove) and are very good for lightweight tasks. I'd want a heavier weight glove if punctures were a possibility. Even though these are specifically non-medical, I could easily start an IV with these gloves; the feel is excellent.If you know you do not have a latex sensitivity, these are high quality gloves for a strong fine motor capacity. If you are at risk for punctures, try the heavy duty latex gloves.

Think of this like dehydrated bleach and you'll get a sense of the product. I'd never heard of it before receiving it. For me it is an excellent addition to my housecleaning arsenal. I also am someone who has ruined way too many items of clothing over the years with accidental bleach spills. I especially like this for toilet, sink and bathtub cleaning.For me this did not work well with my front loader when I wanted to do a load of whites. The dispenser really isn't designed for this. If I have to reconstitute the product I might as well use liquid bleach. I am saving it for household cleaning and for me, it is excellent for that.

These basic nitrile gloves are functional with a good fit ( small for me fits well, I wear a size 6 glove). I am curious as to what is so extreme about them as they seem very ordinary in every other aspect. This particular variety is intended for general industrial use, not medical. They will be fine for housework but not heavy enough to prevent punctures. Okay gloves, not memorable for anything other than good fit.

Here in WI you generally need to bring everything indoors for the winter or kiss it goodbye. We lack the storage space to house everything so second best is a very durable cover. Many of the lightweight nylon variety just can't stand up to WI winters. This cover however is extremely rugged and weather/wind resistant. It is tailored for an excellent fit. I anticipate getting many seasons from this cover. Durable, great color, can cinch in for a custom fit against wind, rain and snow. Highly recommended.

We check out tablets from work when we are on the road and I recently have been working with a 10"  Samsung. My primary rave about this is the color scheme. The 2 pinks make this very pretty to my design eye. The case works well to protect the tablet. It is somewhat limited in positioning (swivel would be 5 stars) which makes it less helpful at the lectern. Overall design, weight and degree of protection is very good. The magnetized closure never opens up in my work tote no matter how jostled. The colorway makes me smile every time I see it.

For 30 years I have worn Jockey Elance in a size 7. I was offered these in an 8/9 so I thought I'd try them thinking they'd fit if they ran small. They ended up being too big for me...wearable but a bit baggy. That's my fault not the underwear.These are a very stretchy full seat underwear. They (on me) come up to my natural waist. They do not bind or bite in the waist or the leg. My only concern is that they are perhaps too lightweight to last very long. I am tempted to buy these in my actual size; they are very comfortable.

I was surprised at how lovely these earrings were upon opening the box. The stones are deep in color and filled with fire and light. The settings are nice and set off the stones well. These have rapidly become my favorite go to earrings for day or evening wear. One thing that makes these so versatile is thAt they combine silver and gold making them a perfect complement for either. Highly recommended, come with backs and rubbery stoppers.

I have a long history of contact dermatitis from talc powdered gloves ( I am an RN) so I have often stayed away from talc based products. I did not know when selecting this that talc was the primary ingredient. I went ahead and tried it anyway and am very pleased with the results.The container has a sliding top and you shake out the powder into wet hands. Make the lather before you apply to your wet face (if you don't it really doesn't work as well). This product cleans thoroughly and rinses easily. It has left me with very smooth soft skin. So far I have not had any skin reactions from use.Last night I tested this on a full face of wedding makeup and it worked perfectly. The sliding cap works very well for me and I have not had any spillage or cap failures. If it did open up it could be quite a mess so the recommendations to secure this in transit are wise.

This product has dosing instructions for adults and children. I find it calming over the long run. For me the calming extends to mouth and gum irritation. Maybe I just mind canker sores and gum inflammation less. This is an easy to take sublingual tablet that is sweet but with no other aftertaste.This doesn't work for me for severe mouth sores but does seem to relieve mild irritation. I've added it to my oral care arsenal.

I recently bought this Glock Mag Loader and it works really great!  At first I had it backwards and was having trouble with it, but finally figured out I was using it wrong and man, what a difference.  It is heads and tails above the Glock Loader.  The bullets go in so easy and I reloaded a 31 bullet clip for 40 cal and the job was so quick!  Who ever invented this loader is a genius!

The Pro Hand Saw is outstanding!  I received it the other day and promptly gave it to my wife.  She is the gardener in this family and promptly took the saw and opened it.  She and I are sorely impressed.  It is very well made and extremely strong and sharp.I took it outside and cut a 1 inch branch off a tree.  It went through the branch like butter.  I tried it on a bigger 2 inch branch with the same results.  Finally I tried it on a big branch of 3 inches and the saw works really good.  It is stable and cuts really well and it clawed through that 3 inch branch like nothing.The saw works fantastic and it is really neat in that it folds in half.  It is much safer and easier to carry that way and occupies very little space too.  I could not be happier, and ordered a second one for my Sister.

What really impressed me about the Ultra Bright LED Lantern was how bright the light is!  It takes three AA batteries and the light has no switches or controls on it.  Just pull the top out with the handles and the light comes on.  There is no switch to try to find in the dark, and that is a good thing.  All you have to do to turn the light on is pull the top out of the bottom.The LEDs brighten the room immensely and being LEDs, the battery drain is very low, allowing the light to be used for a long period without depleting the batteries.  It is very simple and does not weigh much or take up much space.It is so easy to set the light on a shelf in the room and when and if the power goes out, just get the light and pull the top out of the bottom and you are set.  I had an instance a week ago in which the power went out.  I was watching TV and all sudden, the room was dark!  Fortunately I knew where I had set the Ultra Bright LED Lantern and was able to find it through feeling in the dark.  I pulled out the top and the light came on instantly.  The light being so simple to use is one thing that makes it so great.  The lights came back on about 3 hours later and the LED lantern was still glowing strongly when that happened.  I just compressed the top to the bottom and the light went out.I put the lantern back on the shelf, where it is ready for the next weather event in which I lose my power and lights.  The lantern is very simple to use, uses a small amount of power and is always there on standby for the next time you lose the lights.  It would be good to have one in every room in the house!

The Venstar Wireless Bluetooth Speaker is outstanding!.  What impressed me about it is it was really quick and easy to connect to my smart phone Bluetooth.  Several things surprised me about the speaker.  One was the sound.  The sound was really nice and crisp and the bass really stood out.  I held my hand near the speaker and could feel the powerful sound waves coming out of it.  The bass was just exploding out of the speakers and when I picked the speaker up it really surprised me how strong the bass was.  It felt like it was going to blow up in my hand, the bass was so powerful!  The speakers sound great, even at a high volume level.Most speakers start distorting as the volume level is increased.  Not this Venstar Speaker!  The volume at max on my smart phone sounded crystal clear and the bass was so sharp and clear.  It sounded like someone had a drum set right next to me.I really put the speaker through its paces and played music on it for over 4 hours.  The batteries on the speaker held up magnificently!  Just for fun, I turned the Bluetooth Off on my smart phone and connected the speaker through the headphone jack with the supplied cord.  The sound and volume were just as loud and the sound sharpness was just as good that way as it was through Bluetooth.  The speaker does not distort, even at max volume!I found that connecting the speaker either through the supplied cord or through Bluetooth worked great in listening to the speaker fairly close by at a lower volume level, but also worked great at max volume from across the room.  I listened to the speaker in the room and it sounds great even 15 to 20 feet away.  The sound filled the room nicely

The first thing that impressed me with this air vent universal car mount holder is the way it is made.  It is pretty and well built and sturdy, and holds the smart phone either horizontally or vertically.  I have a Moto E, and it works perfectly in the mount.  The mount should work with just about any smart phone made.I just clipped the holders into the air vents of the car and that was it.  The clips are adjustable and easy to position for proper fitting.  The mount has a knob and to change from vertical to horizontal, just loosen the screw and turn the smart phone and tighten it back down.The mount holds the smart phone in firmly and I like the green colors of the holder.  What else is there to say?  It works perfectly, is very strong and easy to adjust, and is easy to get back off.  I really like the mount.  Great job Vansky!

Nice tool!  I was sent one for a review on Amazon, and after checking it out, I ordered two more, one for each vehicle.  This  DBPower 9 in 1 has a Digital Pressure Gauge and has many other tools that really rock.  It has a pair of scissors for cutting a safety belt, a flashlight with a clear and a red lens, a pair of pliers, a flat tip and Phillips screwdriver, and a serrated knife.  The knife could easily cut a safety belt as well.One other thing this 9 in 1 tool has that is really cool is the Window Breaker.  Just push the button and the Window Breaker pops out.  It is really heavy duty and has a point on it.  You just smack the window with the pointed end and it breaks right out.  It is the perfect tool for a vehicle to be kept in the glove compartment, or somewhere close in case of an emergency.The pressure gauge is great too, and it comes on with the press of a button near the gauge window.  To turn it off, just press and hold the same button for a second or so.The tool is very sturdy, and is very strong.The 9 in 1 has a switch on top.  Pressing the switch forward turns on a bright clear LED torch in the front of the tool, and the pressing the switch back turns on the bright Red LED.  In the center is off.The DBPower 9 in 1 tool is very well made and well thought out.  The layout is great and the tools are easy to get in and out.  It is an excellent item to have in your vehicle.In the case of your auto landing in water, just press the button on the Window Breaker and break out the side window to get out of the car.  It could mean the difference between drowning in the car or getting out to safety.  For that reason alone it is well worth the small price to have one in every vehicle.

These Bluetooth QY8 headphones are awesome!  They sound incredibly great and the bass just jumps out at you.  The problem I have with Bluetooth headphones is a lot of times they sound good, but are not loud enough.  That is not the case for the EasyBest QY8 headphones.  They are cranking loud, and the sound is fantastic!The headphone comes with different ear adapters for different sized ear canals, and that is a good thing as my ear canals are somewhat small.I promptly connected the earphones to my computer through the USB port, and they charged fairly quickly.  It was easy to pair (connect) to my smart phone.  I used the earphones while I was walking on a treadmill with a big fan blowing on me and could easily hear the music.  There was plenty of volume to overcome the noise in the background.  They sound really great as well.

I must say that this is the Foneso is the best Selfie Stick that have ever used, or seen for that matter.  .  It is different from the rest in quite a few ways.  For one thing, the shutter release button is attached to a piece of Velcro and can be mounted on the Selfie Stick, or it can be held in the hand.  More on that later.The Foneso Selfie Stick is plenty strong enough to hold my smart phone and the bracket that holds the smart phone folds up when not needed.  The legs come out easily, and lock in place by twisting them to the left.  Once locked, they hold firmly and will not move in or out.  The screw that holds the bracket from swiveling works really well and the lock is made as a lever, and not a knob, so it is easy to apply firm pressure.  The swivel will fold forward for taking normal pictures and can be swiveled backwards for selfie shots.What makes this Foneso Selfie Stick stand out is it comes with a tripod mount.  The tripod mount has three legs that fold in when not needed.  I have found the tripod is easy to carry with the stick all the time with the legs folded in.  it adds some length to the Selfie Stick, and gives more leverage to hold the stick steady when fully extended.If you need a group shot and want to use the tripod mount, it is a piece of cake.  Just extend the legs on the tripod and aim the camera at the target.  The shutter button can then be removed from the stick and attached to a finger.  Once the subject is properly framed, it is just a matter of pressing the shutter button and the camera will take a shot.  When in the video mode, pressing the shutter button will take a shot while the smart phone is taking the video.If you are taking a group shot and want to be included in the group, it is just as easy.  Just put the smart phone on the tripod and frame the shot.  Then move yourself into the photo and press the shutter button, which you are holding in your hand, and the camera will take the shot.  I tried this feature at about 20 feet, and the camera took a shot every time the shutter button was pressed.  According to the directions in the box, the range is about 30 feet, which is more than enough range to get the shot you need to take.No other Selfie Stick I have seen or checked out has the feature of the shutter button not permanently attached to the stick.  This is the only Selfie Stick where the shutter button can be moved and carried in the hand for remote triggering of the camera.  Also no other Selfie Stick that I have found has a tripod stand that can be attached or left off the Selfie Stick.  That is fantastic and a really smart idea on Foneso's part.  For these reasons I am highly endorsing the Foreso Selfie Stick!

I received this product in exchange for an honest review.  This is that review.My first impressions?  This flash is really solidly built and has tight tolerances.  It clicks when moving the flash up and has clicks in moving the flash side to side.  The flash feels good to the hand in that it has about the right amount of weight too.  Even the battery compartment is cool.  There is a diagram under the battery compartment door and it shows how to insert the batteries.  The door is well made and does not have that flimsy feel.The speedlite has a GN of 60, and that is very powerful.  A GN of 60 means that the flash will provide enough light to take a photo at a ISO setting of 100 at a distance of 60 meters, or 195 feet.  That is a pretty powerful flash!I would like to say that Pixel is the first company that I have bought a speedlite from that has included a plastic diffuser cap with the flash.  Yes!  In all the other flashes I have gotten no plastic diffuser cap was included and I had to buy one for around another $20.  The diffuser cap is easy to get on and off the camera too, and fits perfectly.The plastic diffuser cap is special too. Usually the diffuser caps are a cloudy plastic material.  This one also has the cloudy plastic material, but on the inside is a cut diffuser in the plastic.  This does a ton when it comes to dispersing the light.  Great job Pixel!Also included is a really wide flash stand that sits on a flat surface or attaches to a tripod.  I looked at the flash stand and saw that the tripod hole is plastic.  At first I did not like that and felt it should be metal for more strength.  I then looked at all the flash holders I have and half of them are plastic and half of them are metal.  I looked at the flash holder included with the Pixel Speedlite again, and decided it is fine.  It is made of plastic, but there are 8 plastic supports holding the threaded part in place and that should be plenty to securely hold the flash on a tripod.  The flash stand  is much longer and wider than all the rest of my flash stands, and that is good too, as it gives it more stability on a flat surface.The case is of a soft material with room inside for the flash and flash stand.  With the diffuser cap attached to the flash it will still fit inside the case, but the Velcro fastener will not connect.  Most will carry the speed lite with the diffuser cap stored in a camera bag, but not me.  It fits into the case and I can't fasten the Velcro, but it is fine to me that way.  It is worth it to be able to carry the flash and diffuser together, as most of my flash is for fill flash during the day and I want the diffuser to spread the light better and wider.The best part of the case is that it has both vertical and horizontal belt loops, so the speed lite can be worn on the belt or could be attached to the camera bag straps.The flash covers has from 20mm (wide angle) to 200mm (Max Zoom).  I have a bunch of flash units and none of them go beyond 105mm, so this flash zooming to 200mm is fantastic!  The zoom is easy to control, by pressing the -/+ button (second from the left on top), and rotating the Select Dial to the desired setting.  To go up, turn the wheel to the right and to the left to go down.  Once the setting reaches 20mm, by continuing to turn the wheel to the left causes the flash to jump up to 105mm.Once the on board flash diffuser is pulled out from the front of the flash and dropped down, the flash zoom automatically goes to WP (Wide Panel) mode.  This is as wide as the flash will disperse.  When the flash diffuser is pulled forward and dropped down, it also shows the white Reflector Catch Card.  That card is left up in the bounce position to throw some catch lights to the eyes for the person you are shooting.  It gives the eyes the sparkle we are all looking for.The power of the flash is adjustable from 1/128 to 1/1 power in 1/3 EV steps, with the Dial Selector Wheel.The flash goes down to -7 and up to 90 degrees.  The flash also moves left 180 degrees and right 180 degrees.On the power switch is a Lock position that locks the flash settings so no accidental movement of the buttons occurs.The flash remembers the last settings used and comes back to that when turned on.The locations of all the buttons are very well marked and easy to find.  The flash comes with a manual but it is pretty small.  I found the speedlite very easy to use and operate without the manual.  Everything just kind of fits and it is easy to manipulate.The unit has a battery level icon in the top right of the display.  It works great!The flash display is a High Definition Dot Matrix Screen.The start up time for the flash unit is about 2 to 3 seconds.The florescent tube is Ultra Long Life.The External Interface ‚Äì Hot Shoe, PC Port, USB port (for firmware upgrades), and External Power Port.Sync Modes ‚Äì High Speed Sync, 1st curtain sync, and 2nd curtain sync.Wireless Flash ‚Äì Optical transmission, supports Master/Slave S1 and S2.There are three modes, ETTL, Manual, and Multi, and they are all set by the Mode Button.ETTL -  the camera talks to the flash unit to control the zoom and the power from the flash.  It can be overridden by pressing the -/+ button (top row of buttons, second from left).  After the press, the flash will highlight to the left of the EV and can be adjusted by turning the Select Dial on the back of the flash.The Zoom can also be overridden by pressing the Zoom button on the top row (third on from left).MANUAL MODE ‚Äì The zoom and the power from the flash must be adjusted in the manual mode.The power of the flash can be set by pressing the -/+ button (2nd from left on top).  Rotating the Select Dial to the right the power goes up and to the left the power goes down.  As the wheel is turned, the flash power goes up or goes down in 1/3 EV steps.  The power is from 1/128 to 1/1 power.I took some shots inside my house today and with just 1/16 power the flash put out more than enough light to properly expose a photo in manual.  The camera was set to max aperture and ISO 80.  That tells me this flash has tons of power.The Zoom is controlled by pressing the Zoom button (3rd button from left) and turning the Select Dial to the right or left, depending on the amount of zoom required.MULTI MODE ‚Äì It is easy to set the number of times (0 to 100), and the time of duration (1 to 500 Hz) by pressing  and holding the Mult*FN button (top right button on the flash).  I tried using this mode and it works perfectly.  I set the amount of flashes to 8 and the duration to 1 and every second for 8 seconds the flash went off.  I could not check this on my camera as it does not support this function.Sound is enabled out of the box, and once the flash has charged and is ready the unit will beep.I did some testing of the charge refresh rates, and at 1/1 full power it takes the unit 2.5 seconds to charge on a fresh set of batteries.  At Ω power it takes about 1 second to recharge the flash. At any speed of ¬º power or less, the flash will charge as fast as your camera can take the photos.  If you press the shutter 10 times it will charge and flash 10 times as fast as you can press the shutter.Standby Time ‚Äì Set to 5 minutes.  It can be adjusted from 5 minutes to 2 hours or to a Non Sleep Mode.The Sound, Display Timer, AF/On/Off and the Sleeper Timer are all programmable.  To do this press and hold the Sync*FN button (top right button).  Let the button go and press it again.There are 4 settings set with the Snyc*FN button.  Press the Sync*FN button and hold it.  The top Tone feature will highlight.  Release the button.TONE - On and Off. Rotate the Select Dial to the desired setting.  Press the Sync*FN button to advance to the next setting.DISPLAY LIGHT TIMER -  There are 4 settings.  5 Seconds, 10 Seconds, ON, and OFF.  Set it to the one needed by turning the Select Dial.  Press the Sync*FN button again.AF ‚Äì On and Off.  Again, rotate the Select Dial to the desired setting. Press the Sync*FN button again.SLEEPER TIMER ‚Äì rotate the Select Dial to the desired setting.  The settings available are 5 minute, 10 minute, 30 minute, 1 hour, 2 hour, and No Timer.Press the OK button to exit the module.Wireless Flash Control.  Supports the optical transmission flash control.  The flash transmits an optical pulse to control firing remotely.  The speedlite on the camera should be set as Master and the off camera flash set to Slave.These modes are set up by the continuous pressing of the Set*Rmot button (top left button).  They are set up similar to the ones on the flash sleeper timer modes.The flash is extremely easy to use and easy to set up.  It does come with a small manual but the buttons are well marked and easy to understand.  This flash is one of the easiest I have ever used.  It has tons of power and in ETTL it talks to the camera and takes all the work out of using a flash.  I highly recommend this product!  I really really like the fact that it zooms to 200mm.  That is awesome when you are trying to get the light way out there.I used this flash in my Canon Camera in ETTL, and used the flash on my Panasonic Camera in Manual.  It works great on both cameras.
