Think of this vacuum as a battery-powered handheld vacuum that comes with a floor vacuum shell--you attach the handheld vacuum to the floor vacuum shell when you want to vacuum floors.* The vacuum (I have the Deep Blue one) has a stylish, modern design.* The vacuum does not require vacuum bags.CON:* Emptying the debris cup is a little fiddly. You have to remove the cup from the vacuum, then separate the filter funnel from the debris cup, then empty the debris cup, then scrape off debris from the filter funnel, then put everything back together.* The battery life is shorter than I expected--I usually can only vacuum about three small rooms before the battery dies.* The handle is a little short. If you are taller than about 5' 10", you'll likely have to stoop to use the vacuum.* Because of the bulbous debris cavity section, you might have difficulty vacuuming under furniture.* The vacuum has a brush roll, but it does not work well with carpet tassels.* The handheld vacuum comes with an attachable extension nozzle, but there is no way to store the nozzle on the vacuum when not in use, which means it is easy to lose and is likely not going to be near you when you actually need to use the handheld vacuum.* The charging brick does not store with the vacuum, which means you must always walk back with the vacuum to wherever you have the charging brick in order to charge the battery.All in all this is a good vacuum, though not perfect. This it is more of a spot vacuum for light duty work rather than a heavy duty vacuum. That said, it is great for wood or non-carpeted floors. It is also very light in weight and very maneuverable. The removable handheld vacuum design is an added bonus. The vacuum works very well for me when I need to quickly do some light-duty vacuuming, saving me the hassle of bringing out and hooking up our main, more powerful vacuum.

I really like this keyboard and case for my iPad Air 2, and it is better than all my previous keyboard cases.1. It has a clamshell design that protects my iPad Air 2 from all sides. Moreover, this design allows me to use my iPad wherever I am and how I am sitting -- previous cases would flop over or collapse if I tried using the case while sitting on the couch or curled up in bed. Since I often use my iPad while not seated at a desk, this design is a winner.I also like the velvet feel of the case--there is a velvetty plastic coating that allows me to grip the case, which is important when carrying the iPad, pulling it out of my bag, etc. Note however that this coating will wear off over time after heavy use, especially along the edges of the case--at least it has on mine.2. The keyboard is very usable. While yes, it is a smaller scale than my MacBook Pro's keyboard, all the keys are in the right position, so I can touch type with ease. Previous keyboards I've used moved certain keys around in order to fit the smaller width of the iPad, which caused much frustration. Since I use my keyboard a lot with my iPad Air 2, having a useful one is a must, and so this keyboard is a winner.3. The case cutouts allow for access to all ports and buttons on the iPad Air, so no problems taking pictures, charging, changing volume, or waking the iPad.4. The lid swivels around, allowing you to convert the case so that the keyboard is hidden completely underneath the iPad. You can also just turn the display to the side, which I've used for example when my wife wants to see what I'm typing. I've liked the swivel feature more than I thought I would. So far the swivel itself has held up well and seems more robust than I thought it would be. The swivel hinge allows me to open the lid to any angle I want, which is so much more convenient than previous cases where you only had up to three angle choices.5. Just as a side note, this case works great with my iPad holder for my music stand, which allows me to use my iPad while playing guitar. I could take the iPad out of the case, of course, but being able to use the case helps protect the case in case the music stand or mic stand gets knocked over while rocking out.So, all in all this is my new favorite keyboard case for my iPad Air 2. I hope you found this review helpful!

I had grown really tired of those shower curtain rings we had that were just metal hooks that sit on top of the shower curtain rod. The hooks did not glide smoothly across the rod, and they kept jumping off the rod now and then, which was annoying. These roller curtain rings solved both of these issues.These rings feel very robust in the hand--I'm pleased with the build quality. Each ring has five metal rollerballs, which ensure that the rings glide smoothly across the shower curtain rod. There are also metal stoppers on the rings that prevent the rollerballs from coming off, so you don't have to worry about that when attaching the rings to the rod.The ring closure stays closed when it is supposed to -- I've had closures in the past would not stay closed after some use. However, these roller rings are easy to open, add to the rod, and then thread through the shower curtain ring holes.I've been using these for a while now and there is no sign of rust or wear.In all, I think these shower curtain rings look stylish, glide along the shower curtain rod very smoothly, and are a simple, quality product that will enhance your shower experience.

Pullups are one of the best exercises you can do, and so having a good pull-up bar is important.There are quite a few things I like about this Ultimate Body Press Ergonomic Joist Mount Bar:* The construction of the pull-up bar is professionally done -- the weld joints are smooth and there are no sharp edges.* I like the thickness of the bar -- it feels good in the hand.* While straight pull-up bars aren't bad, the angled portions of the bar allow for a variety of hand positions for your pull-ups and chin-ups, which allow you to work different muscles in your pull-up chain.* You do have to install this pull-up bar, but the instructions were clear and I had no trouble.* I liked that the bar had long enough risers that I could easily clear my head over the bar when doing a pull-up.* I also have a pair of gymnastics rings, and hanging these from the pull-up bar worked perfectly.* I like how wide the bar is -- you can do wide grip, normal grip, and narrow grip pull-ups.The only thing to be aware of is that the bar is totally smooth -- I've used some pull-up bars with a gritty texture on the angled portions of the bar. I prefer a smooth bar, since the grit feels uncomfortable on my fingers when I am sweaty, but the smooth bar can be slippery then too, so if that bothers you, you could get exercise gloves or lifting chalk.So all in all, this is a quality, heavy-duty pull-up bar and I'm going to get a lot of use out of it.I hope you found this review helpful!

This is a review of the Toshiba Satellite S55T-B5150 15.6-Inch Touchscreen Laptop.Before I get into the review, I first wanted to itemize several of the laptop's key technical specifications:* Intel Core i7-4710HQ 3.6 GHz Processor* 12 GB RAM* 256 GB Solid-State Drive* 15.6-Inch Screen, Mobile Intel HD graphics* Windows 8.1* Weight: about 4.75 pounds* Dimensions: 10.2" x 14.96" x .93"* 4K Ultra HD (3840 x 2160) HDMI output* 1 ethernet port* 1 SD card port* 1 headphone jack* 3 USB ports (2 are USB 3.0)* 801.11 AC wirelessThere are several things that I liked about this laptop.The big feature of this laptop is that it has a built-in touchscreen--you get a similar touch performance using this screen as you get from your iPad, though not all touch options on the iPad are available on the Toshiba. But touching the screen now is such an automatic and natural way to interface with a computer that this is a welcome feature for this laptop. This laptop's touch interface is responsive and effective. You can even right-click on the task-bar | Properties | toolbars tab | check "Touch keyboard" and use the touch screen and touch keyboard for everything.The large 15.6" display is clear and works great for watching movies, especially when combined with the built-in Harman Kardon speaker/sound-bar that runs across the width of the laptop, right above the keyboard.The hardware specs are good: i7 3.6GHz CPU, 12GB of RAM, and a 250GB SSD drive.  The laptop boots quickly, and I was able to download and install 108 Windows patches in about 40 minutes--during this time the laptop did not overheat, though the fans did turn on. I could easily touch the back of the laptop (it was sitting on my lap) while the fans were running.The keyboard was pleasant to use and I found the keys very responsive. The keyboard even has a full numeric keypad on the right, which is especially useful for folks balancing their checkbooks.I was able to change the power settings so that it sleeps when the lid is closed, hibernates after a certain sleep period, and powers down when the power button is pressed.  Exactly what I wanted!I like the brushed aluminum finish on some of the surfaces -- the bottom for example is plastic, so don't expect metal everywhere -- but the aluminum additions give stability and robustness to the laptop.There were also some things I found aggravating about the laptop, although I should point out that with some effort I was able to resolve these issues to my satisfaction.The most aggravating issue I had with this laptop was with the touchpad.  I could not figure out how to tweak its settings so that the touchpad worked well, but maybe I am spoiled from using Apple's touchpad. This laptop's touchpad had a rough texture, I found the control over the mouse to be spotty and clunky, and clicking the touchpad required too much pressure. I had also expected the touchpad to be centered in the middle of the laptop, but it is positioned off-center, directly under the spacebar, which is left-shifted because of the added numeric keypad on the right. In the end, I found that the best thing to do was disable the touchpad and attach an external mouse, which was easy to do using the Control Panel.The second aggravating issue was with the backlit keyboard. The laptop defaulted to lighting when touched and then turning off when you remove your hands from the keyboard. But the on/off control was too fast, and so if you work in a low-light situation, you get this weird strobe lighting effect as you work, which is distracting. The only way to keep the backlighting on all the time was by entering BIOS, which is not for the faint-of-heart. Once I fixed the BIOS setting I was pleased with the backlighting.The third aggravation was with the included anti-virus application. Being Windows, having anti-virus software is needed, but the included application has a 30-day trial installed by default, and it pops up asking you to purchase it every time you log in to your computer.  I understand the need for anti-virus protection, considering the amount of downloads and clicky-click that most kids do, but I found the frequent purchase reminders bothersome. I also found it weird that the steps to uninstall McAffee included removing it from the Control Panel | Programs and Features (so far so good) and running a downloaded tool to remove its registry settings (this is an abnormal step).I should also note that Toshiba included applications in addition to the applications that come with Windows. These extra applications include various games, several different online shops, some streaming music apps, a third-party music player, a photo editing tool, and a video editing tool.  The only app they installed which I wanted was Skype.  None of these extra apps were "bad" in as much as they were not popping up constant ads or doing anything malicious, but they were definitely targeted at the home market, and I don't really care to have my PC vendor selecting my apps for me.  This is a pet peeve that Toshiba can be forgiven for, since all the PC vendors do it.  I can remove these extra apps using Control Panel | Programs and Features, so it will be fine.The charger brick is not too big and the cable is long, which are nice features. The minor complaint is that you are stuck with having to carry a long cable even if you don't need it -- there is no short cable option for travel. Again, Apple has me spoiled.The laptop comes with Windows 8.1, which can be a mixed bag, depending on what operating systems you are used to using. To me, Windows 8.1 seems like a transitional operating system for Microsoft, as some of the included applications, like the calendar app, are "in the cloud" and require you to have a Microsoft account before you can even see a calendar. Other apps, like the alarm, run locally on the machine and can be used right away without any hassle. And there are even two versions of the same app in some cases, which can be confusing. For example, there are two calculator apps--one runs in a window normally, while the other runs full-size--it takes over the entire screen. One version is intended for laptops, and the other for tablets.And of course you can tweak some of the default choices in Windows. For example, if you don't like using the Bing search engine, you can change it by going into Internet Explorer | setting icon | Manage add-ons | Search providers.  I setup Google as my primary search, and also added Yahoo and YouTube as alternatives. As another example, I wanted to be able to find my programs without going through that new bizarre Windows GUI. The steps to adding back the traditional Windows Start Button to Windows 8 can be found online.There is an Office365 link off the Program menu. Office365 is like Google Docs in that it's an online office application suite. When I click the link, I get three options:  try, buy, and activate. My preference is to download and use Libre Office instead.And finally, note that this laptop does not come with a DVD drive.In summary, all things considered, I would say that if you can get this this discounted from the laptop's $999 list price, and if you need a Windows laptop, the laptop's large display with touchscreen support, fast SSD drive and CPU, 12GB RAM, and usable keyboard make this Toshiba Satellite S55T-B5150 15.6-Inch Touchscreen Laptop a solid choice.

4:52 Mins These Rabbit Freezable Whiskey Glasses aim to allow you to enjoy a chilled beverage without having to use ice, which would then melt and dilute your drink.In the box you get two eight-ounce glasses.The idea is that you put the glasses in your freezer until the chilling liquid freezes. When you pour in your favorite beverage, the chilling liquid helps keep your drink cool without having to deal with melting ice. The silicone coating on the base of the glass helps keep your fingers from getting cold.In the video I show details about the glasses, demonstrate their use, and point out pluses and minuses.After using these glasses for a bit,On the positive side:1.) Your drink does stay cool and you don't have to worry about ice melt.2.) The silicone base is cool to the touch, but your fingers don't get cold.On the negative side:1.) When you put the glasses into the freezer, you are instructed to place them upside down. The instructions say it only takes an hour for them to freeze, but I found this not to be the case. I'd give the glasses a couple of hours before they are ready.2.) That said, one of my glasses would never freeze! Even after leaving the glass in the freezer for a week, the chilling liquid never froze. So there seems to be some quality control issues going on.3.) The instructions say that the silicone base acts as an insulation and coaster, preventing condensation from running down the sides of the glass onto your table. My glass had lots of condensation running down it and I would definitely still need a separate coaster before I set this on a nice table. The silicone only seems to prevent you from getting frosty fingers.4.) The product ad copy says the glass will instantly chill your beverage to 10 degrees Fahrenheit. While my drink was cool, it was not 22 degrees below freezing. In other words, if you pour water into your glass, it won't instantly become a block of ice.So, all in all this is a great idea for a product, though its execution is slightly less than perfect. That said, I'll continue to use and enjoy these glasses.Cheers, and I hope this review has been helpful.

3:58 Mins So this is a pretty nifty and useful collapsible crate.As crates tend to be, this crate is a convenient way to store or carry your stuff, whether you are running errands, going camping, organizing your closets, or de-cluttering your garage. It's made from recyclable materials, is lightweight, and can be cleaned when it gets dirty.Moreover, this crate is collapsible, so it can be more conveniently stored.In the video I go through the features of the crate, show how to collapse and restore the crate, and also give a few pointers about using it.All in all, I'm very happy with this crate. While I might not carry around heavy, previous items in it, it will be perfect in my car to keep stuff from rolling around. And when I'm done, I can collapse the crate and store it under the car seat.So it's, um, quite the clever crate.

If you are at least tangentially involved in processing, analyzing, and learning from data, then you are probably familiar with the free statistical programming language and software environment known as R. But R can do a lot more than plot data and perform hypothesis tests--the new book Introduction to Scientific Programming and Simulation Using R, Second Edition, by Owen Jones, Robert Maillardet, and Andrew Robinson, is your guide for using R to tackle problems in computational statistics, simulation, optimization, operations research, and scientific programming.The book is divided into four parts. Part One covers programming--the basics of writing your own functions and algorithms with R. Part Two covers using the programming concepts from Part One to solve problems like root-finding and numerical integration. Part Three covers the basics of probability, distributions, and discrete and continuous random variables. Part Four covers stochastic modeling and simulation.Here are the chapter titles:1: Setting Up2: R as a Calculating Environment3: Basic Programming4: I/O: Input and Output5: Programming with Functions6: Sophisticated Data Structures7: Better Graphics8: Pointers to Further Programming Techniques9: Numerical Accuracy and Program Efficiency10: Root-Finding11: Numerical Integration12: Optimisation13: Systems of Ordinary Differential Equations14: Probability15: Random Variables16: Discrete Random Variables17: Continuous Random Variables18: Parameter Estimation19: Markov Chains20: Simulation21: Monte Carlo Integration22: Variance Reduction23: Case Studies24: Student ProjectsThis book covers a lot of ground, but it does so in enough depth to provide a good grounding in the topics covered. Also, end of chapter exercises provide opportunities for further study and exploration, and an R package is available that contains most of the code and data used in the book.I really like that this book focuses on teaching you not only how to program, but also how to think algorithmically and numerically to solve problems. R is a very powerful language, but some books just show you how to use R's built-in functions--functions that are already created and available for you. This book however goes beyond and teaches you how to use R to create your own tools, which allows you to solve much more complex and interesting problems.This book assumes calculus knowledge, but no prior knowledge of programming or probability is really necessary.So all in all I really like this book and I think it is a great introduction to scientific programming, simulation, and modeling in R--skills that are extremely valuable in our increasingly digital and data-driven world!

4:41 MinsFinally, I've found a stylish way to store my shoes.OK, you do have to do a little work first though--the cabinet comes unassembled. If you are familiar with Ikea furniture, then you know what to expect. If you don't know what to expect, then be sure to watch my video--I show what comes in the box and I walk you through the steps in assembling the cabinet. It took me about an hour and 15 minutes to put it together by myself, though it would be easier with two people and would probably be faster as well.In all, this is a solid and modern piece of furniture that will keep my shoes stored out of the way and protected from pets and dust. The only trouble was that my wife now wants one for her shoes.So if you don't mind putting in a little time and effort in putting all the pieces together--everything is well labeled, though the instructions are a little sparse--and if you don't mind possibly having to buy a second one for your spouse, then I think you'll like this product.

5:55 MinsIf you have carpets or rugs or upholstery furniture and you want to give them a deep cleaning, you should take a look at the Rug Doctor Deep Carpet Cleaner.In the video I show in detail what comes in the box, how to put everything together, how to clean the carpet, how to attach the upholstery cleaner, and how to empty everything when you are done.While I found the cleaner to be very robust and easy to use--the clean and waste water tanks are super simple to empty and put back into place, the unit has an adjustable handle, and there is even a "Super Boost" spray for really dirty areas--the fact that the cleaner found a lot of dirt on a carpet that I has thought was already clean convinced me that this cleaner is the real deal.Final verdict: I'm happy that I no longer need to bother with the hassle and expense of hiring carpet cleaner companies to clean my carpets. Now I can be sure everything will *really* be clean. This is the real deal--the Rug Doctor Deep Carpet Cleaner will help you keep your rugs, carpets, and upholstery clean with ease.

1:14 MinsA great pair of utility shears is hard to beat.This pair from Scotts has a lot to like.The handles are bright green and are made from 70% recycled content. The blades are serrated and are bonded with titanium, making them stay sharper longer. Moreover, the blades also separate to allow for easy cleaning.In the hand they feel very comfortable and sturdy.In use they work very well, and can easily cut through small garden leaves and branches. I also like to use them inside the house to open up boxes and other packages.Though it makes the shears no less useful, I should point out that while the shears are advertised as coming with a nylon sheath, my shears did not come with a sheath.In the video I show how easy it is to separate the blades, among other things.So all in all, this is a great pair of garden and utility shears. I expect them to last a very long time, and I know I'll get a lot of use out of them.

With the explosion of the amount of data available, the need for stronger data analysis tools than Excel has grown. Fortunately one of the best data analysis tools, R, is also free. This book, A Handbook of Statistical Analyses using R, Third Edition, by Torsten Hothorn and Brian Everitt, provides a handy primer for using R to perform standard statistical data analysis.As suggested by the title, the book is not meant to teach you data analysis. Rather, it is a *handbook* of methods of data analysis using R. After an introductory chapter for those completely unfamiliar with R, each chapter focuses on applying a specific statistical technique to data using R.Each chapter has a similar structure, and the teaching method uses a data-first approach. The Analysis of Variance chapter, for example, begins with a sample dataset and a short case study to give context. A brief summary of the analysis of variance statistical technique is given, followed by the commands for how to perform analysis of variance in R using the case study data. For each R command, expected outputs are given so that you can verify what you are doing if you are following along on your own computer. A summary of the analysis findings are given (i.e., how to interpret the data), along with final comments. End of chapter exercises are also given so the reader can explore further.The list of chapter titles are:1 An Introduction to R2 Data Analysis Using Graphical Displays3 Simple Inference4 Conditional Inference5 Analysis of Variance6 Simple and Multiple Linear Regression7 Logistic Regression and Generalized Linear Models8 Density Estimation9 Recursive Partitioning10 Scatterplot Smoothers and Additive Models11 Survival Analysis12 Quantile Regression13 Analyzing Longitudinal Data I14 Analyzing Longitudinal Data II15 Simultaneous Inference and Multiple Comparisons16 Missing Values17 Meta-Analysis18 Bayesian Inference19 Principle Component Analysis20 Multidimensional Scaling21 Cluster AnalysisNote that every example, graphic, dataset, and output in the book can be reproduced using a free R package the user can download.Who's this book for? It's not meant to teach you statistics, so it's best if you are already familiar with statistical data analysis approaches. You don't have to be an expert though--the short theory section for each statistical method covered in the book gives you the main points, and you can learn main concepts by working through the case study and seeing the R commands used in the context of the given case study problem. Note however that there is a lot more to R than is covered in this book, so don't expect this to be a comprehensive book on how to use R.So, students, analysts, professors, and scientists: if you are looking to add R to your toolkit for analyzing data statistically, then this book will get you there.

4:52 Mins These Rabbit Freezable Whiskey Glasses aim to allow you to enjoy a chilled beverage without having to use ice, which would then melt and dilute your drink.In the box you get two eight-ounce glasses.The idea is that you put the glasses in your freezer until the chilling liquid freezes. When you pour in your favorite beverage, the chilling liquid helps keep your drink cool without having to deal with melting ice. The silicone coating on the base of the glass helps keep your fingers from getting cold.In the video I show details about the glasses, demonstrate their use, and point out pluses and minuses.After using these glasses for a bit,On the positive side:1.) Your drink does stay cool and you don't have to worry about ice melt.2.) The silicone base is cool to the touch, but your fingers don't get cold.On the negative side:1.) When you put the glasses into the freezer, you are instructed to place them upside down. The instructions say it only takes an hour for them to freeze, but I found this not to be the case. I'd give the glasses a couple of hours before they are ready.2.) That said, one of my glasses would never freeze! Even after leaving the glass in the freezer for a week, the chilling liquid never froze. So there seems to be some quality control issues going on.3.) The instructions say that the silicone base acts as an insulation and coaster, preventing condensation from running down the sides of the glass onto your table. My glass had lots of condensation running down it and I would definitely still need a separate coaster before I set this on a nice table. The silicone only seems to prevent you from getting frosty fingers.4.) The product ad copy says the glass will instantly chill your beverage to 10 degrees Fahrenheit. While my drink was cool, it was not 22 degrees below freezing. In other words, if you pour water into your glass, it won't instantly become a block of ice.So, all in all this is a great idea for a product, though its execution is slightly less than perfect. That said, I'll continue to use and enjoy these glasses.Cheers, and I hope this review has been helpful.

If you need help deciphering your vehicle's "Check Engine Light" or keeping tabs on your vehicle's health and performance, you may want to check out Innova's Quicklink OBD2 vehicle diagnostic tool.Here's the basic idea: The Quicklink hooks up to your vehicle's OBD (on-board diagnostics) port, and the free quicklink app on your mobile device links to the quicklink device via bluetooth and displays performance and diagnostic information from your vehicle's computer.The app shows diagnostic reports if it detects something wrong with your vehicle. It also shows realtime visual feedback of certain performance characteristics, such as engine RPM, Torque, miles per gallon, etc.HOWEVER, you should be aware of a few things before using the device:1.) You have to create an account on the company's website and you must create a profile for your car--including providing your car's VIN before you can check your car's performance--this requires Internet access.2.) You are provided a basic diagnostic report for free, and the company provides a more detailed report for a fee.3.) You do not need Internet access (after creating the account and creating your car's profile as in 1.) to get realtime performance statistics.4.) Compared to mobile app performance and interfaces you might be used to on your iOS or Android devices, the Innova software can feel rather clunky. Moreover, the software crashed multiple times when I was using it. It was frustrating to use.All in all, the Innova Quicklink is an OK way for vehicle owners to monitor for themselves the health and performance of their vehicles. Until car makers make better car interfaces, the Quicklink seems a reasonable way to go, though improving the software would really help the user's experience and satisfaction with the device.

4:55 MinsWhen the stuff hits the fan, whether that's a simple power outage or a full-out zombie apocalypse, having a rechargeable radio is critical for receiving timely and relevant information. The Eton All-Purpose Weather Alert Radio is a rugged emergency radio that provides a lot of features useful in an emergency.In the video I step through the radio's features, which include:* Three radio bands: NOAA Wather Broadcasts, FM, and AM* LED flashlight and emergency beacon* 5V 1A USB port for charging your cell phone* Four ways to charge the 1000 mAh Lithium battery:1.) 3 AAA batteries2.) Solar panel (charges in about 5-6 hours)3.) Micro-USB port (charges in a couple of hours)4.) Hand crank (cranking for 4 minutes gives about 1 minute of talk time or 10-15 minutes of radio time)The radio even has a weatherband alert feature -- if the alert is set, the radio audio will activate when a NOAA alert is issued.Those are a lot of features in one emergency radio! The radio is rugged, lightweight, and will definitely come in handy during an emergency--it's a keeper.

5:26 MinsIf you want to help protect your new tablet, one way is to apply a screen protector--a clear, removable film applied to your tablet's glass display to help protect it from fingerprints, smudges, and light scratches. But not all screen protectors are created equal--some interfere with the touchscreen interface, some leave bubbles of air between the film and the glass, and some are not meant to be reapplied multiple times. So today I want to take a look at the iVisor XT No-Bubble Screen Protector for the Kindle Fire HD.I go into more detail in the video, including how to modify the visor for use with the Kindle Fire HDX in case you accidentally bought the wrong version, but in summary, I found that with this screen protector:* I was able to apply the protector to my Kindle with no air bubbles* The touch interface on my Kindle worked just as smoothly with the screen protector as without* I was able to remove the screen protector and reapply it as often as I needed.I feel like my Kindle is a little safer and healthier while wearing this protector!

Overwhelmed with the number of cables, adapters, and chargers that you must haul around to keep all your cell phones, tablets, and other devices happy and healthy? If you have Apple devices, you know you must carry along cables and chargers that only work with Apple products. The latest Apple mobile devices use the Lightning adapter, something proprietary to Apple. So if you want an alternate way to charge and sync your Apple products, or if you want to eliminate having to carry around cables and chargers just for your Apple devices, then you might be interested in the AmazonBasics Lightning Compatible to Micro USB Adapter.As you can see, it's a really tiny adapter, with a male Lightning interface on one end, and a female micro USB interface on the other end.Using it is very simple: plug in your micro USB cable that you use to connect to all your non-Apple devices, and you can now use that same cable also with your Apple products (at least the ones with the Lightning port).I use it with my iPad Air so I don't have to also carry around my Lightning USB cable along with the micro USB cable I need for my other non-Apple devices. Using this adapter and micro USB cable I can sync and charge my iPad Air with no problem. I'm also relieved having an alternate way to interface to my iPad Air--I've got lots of micro USB cables, but only one Lightning USB cable.For what it is, this adapter seems a little pricey, but it does what it's supposed to do--convert a micro USB cable into a Lightning USB cable. Because it helps eliminate cable clutter and makes syncing/charging my Apple devices easier, the adapter now goes everywhere I go.

If you are looking for a stylish, portable USB mic with great sound quality, you might want to consider the Samson Meteor Mic.The Samson Meteor Mic is a USB condenser microphone with a large diaphragm and a cardioid pickup pattern.It also has a relatively flat frequency response, which is good, but only records CD quality audio, which could be better. However, for the price, the audio quality you get is great.Also, I love the look of the mic's retro design.With its leg's extended, the mic stands about 6 inches tall, and the mic's body is metal with a chrome finish.Especially because the mic can stand by itself, and due to its smart design, this mic is very portable, and it's is now my goto travel usb mic.  When not in use, the mic's legs fold up and fit with its included USB cable into the included carry pouch.On the back of the mic there is a USB port and an 1/8" headphone jack. To connect the mic to your computer, simply attach the USB cable between your computer and your mic. No install CDs or drivers were needed to connect the mic to my MacBook air.Once your mic is connected, you'll see a blue indicator LED. You can turn the ring to adjust the volume level of your monitor headphones, and pressing the button in the middle of the ring mutes the microphone, turning the LED amber. When the input sound is clipping, the LED light will flash red.Installation on my MacBook Air was trivial -- I plugged in the mic and was able to select the mic in my recording software, GarageBand.In summary, I think the Samson Meteor Mic is a stylish, portable, and durable mic that's great for your audio needs, whether you are recording instruments, voiceovers, or podcasts, or just want to sound crisp and clear on your conference calls.

5:28 MinsSometimes you need a pot of coffee, and so I wanted to take a look at the BELLA Dots Collection Programmable Coffee Maker.In the box you get the coffee maker itself -- note that they come in happy colors, so you can match your kitchen decor, or maybe even your iPhone. There is also a 12-cup glass carafe, a measuring spoon, and this is a wonderful idea -- a permanent coffee filter, a removable filter basket, and an instruction manual.The controls are fairly intuitive, though note that the Start button acts as power. You can select between three different coffee brewing strengths, and of course you can program the coffee maker to brew coffee at a future time, or right away.The unit also as a deep-clean feature and an autoshutoff of the hotplate after 2 hours.Making coffee is straightforward--fill reservoir with water, put the filter into the basket, put coffee into the filter, select your brewing strength, and push start.If I had to complain about anything, I'd say that because it takes about 10 minutes to brew a full pot of coffee, I'd sure like a beep or something to let me know when it's done.That nitpick is counterbalanced though by the fact that after there about two cups of coffee have been brewed, you can pull the carafe out, pour yourself some coffee, and put the carafe back to finish brewing the rest of the pot.That's a winner in my book.In the video review you can see the coffee maker and how to use it in more detail.Thanks for reading and watching!

I've always wanted to learn to play the drums, but grew frustrated with my early efforts--toy drums and rockband-type video games just aren't the real thing. But while I don't have the space in my home for an entire analog drum kit, I decided on this Alesis electronic drum set and have been very happy with it.The kit was easy to put together, and contains a rack to hold all the equipment, 3 toms, 1 snare, 1 kick drum, 3 cymbals, a foot control for the high-hat, wire ties to keep your cabling neat, 1 pair of practice drum sticks, and the electronic control center. I was surprised at the high quality of the components. The only thing you need to add is a stool to sit on and either speakers or headphones so you can hear what you are playing.You use the electronic control center to select from the many included drum kit sounds, or you can model your own drum kit and save your settings. You can play along with included rhythms and record your own playing. I also found the metronome very useful while learning.In the first episode of the new show The Tim Ferriss Experiment, Tim tried to conquer learning to play rock and roll drums, and at the end of the episode he actually got to play with the rock group Foreigner on stage for a song. I might not ever get to play on stage with Foreigner, but I know I'm going to have fun playing drums on this electronic drum set.

4:11 MinsLet's take a look at the tablet that many say gives you the most bang for the buck, the Kindle Fire HDX 7‚Ä≥.Here's what's in the box:* Kindle Fire HDX 7‚Ä≥ tablet computer* Micro USB charging cable* AC adapter* Quick-start guideMy Kindle powered up right away out of the box, and after entering password information for my firewall and a few other simple admin steps, I was online and ready to go.In fact, the Kindle Fire HDX immediately populated the Books, Videos, and Music tabs with items I had previously purchased on Amazon. All I had to do was tap the icon for the James Bond: The Authorised Biography, by John Pearson, or the album cover for the new Black Sabbath album 13 and, after a brief download, I was reading and rocking, respectively.Aside from the ease of getting online and using the device without a lot of hassle, I enjoyed several welcome features:* The Kindle felt good in the hand: the dimensions of the unit are 7.3‚Ä≥ x 5.0‚Ä≥ x .35‚Ä≥, and at 303 grams in weight (lighter than the Apple iPad Mini 2), it was easy for me to hold with one hand.*  The display was absolutely brilliant: at 1920◊1200 pixels, the 7‚Ä≥ screen clocks in at 323 Pixels Per Inch (PPI), which is up there with the best of the tablets. The text was crisp, the images gorgeous, and the videos seamless. As a writer and Computer Scientist, I'm accutely aware of technology getting in the way of what John Gardner calls the "vivid and continuous dream" enjoyed when immersed in a compelling story. This display, along with the quad-core CPU and user inteface supplied by the Kindle Fire OS 3.0 "Mojito", does not get in the way of what you are reading or seeing.* After a couple days use, I'm still using the device as I got it right from the box. The rated battery life is 11 hours of mixed use, and 17 hours when reading.* The dual Dolby audio stereo speakers crank out adequate volume, though the 3.5mm stereo headphone jack helps me really tune out the world when I'm listening to an audio book or movie or Black Sabbath.* The front-facing camera and built-in microphone are useful especially for Skype calls.* The unit's Bluetooth support and video streaming capabilities are helping me get in shape, since I can watch movies and crank the volume with an external Bluetooth speaker when running on a treadmill.* The unit came with lots of built-in apps that allowed me to be productive and entertained right out of the box, with more available on Amazon.Note that I haven't yet used the Mayday button, which is supposed to connect you, if you need help, to an Amazon expert 24√ó7, but it's a nice feature to have in my back pocket.Also, I was already a Prime member, which gives me free 2-day shipping when shopping on Amazon, the ability to stream or download Prime Instant videos, and a free ebook a month, so the 30 days of free Prime membership with the purchase of the Kindle Fire HDX was lost on me, but I did start downloading some movies so that I can watch them offline for on an upcoming trip--being able to tune out your surroundings by diving into a movie is wonderful when stuck in those cramped airline seats.My video shows the unboxing and the Kindle Fire HDX in action.So to me, this tablet provides a big bang for your buck.

4:18 MinsHere's what comes with this Hamilton Beach coffeemaker:* coffee maker* 12-cup carafe* basket that takes cupcake-style coffee filters for ground coffee* tray for making individual servings of coffee with two inserts: one insert is used for ground coffee or coffee "pods", the second insert is for K-Cup coffee packs* manual and quick-start guideNote that the individual travel coffee mug shown in the picture on the box is not included.This coffeemaker allows you to make coffee how you like it--a full pot or just an individual cup. And you can use coffee grounds or K-Cups or coffee "pods". Also, when making a pot of coffee you can program the time you want the coffee to be made.In the video I show the various options and features of this Hamilton Beach coffeemaker, as well as demonstrate making a cup of coffee.After using this coffeemaker for a while, I'm happy with it, as it gives me more flexibility than my previous coffeemaker, which only brewed a carafe at a time. Also, I've been wanting to try one of those K-Cup coffeemakers, and so this unit gives me the best of both worlds.

5:26 MinsIf you want to help protect your new tablet, one way is to apply a screen protector--a clear, removable film applied to your tablet's glass display to help protect it from fingerprints, smudges, and light scratches. But not all screen protectors are created equal--some interfere with the touchscreen interface, some leave bubbles of air between the film and the glass, and some are not meant to be reapplied multiple times. So today I want to take a look at the iVisor XT No-Bubble Screen Protector for the Kindle Fire HD.I go into more detail in the video, including how to modify the visor for use with the Kindle Fire HDX in case you accidentally bought the wrong version, but in summary, I found that with this screen protector:* I was able to apply the protector to my Kindle with no air bubbles* The touch interface on my Kindle worked just as smoothly with the screen protector as without* I was able to remove the screen protector and reapply it as often as I needed.I feel like my Kindle is a little safer and healthier while wearing this protector!

4:45 MinsIf you have the new iPad Air, you know what a great device it is, from a solid and diverse app ecosystem and fast performance to a physical design that gets just about everything right.But there are two things that can make the iPad Air even more useful--a protective case and an external keyboard. The Logitech Ultrathin Keyboard Folio combines a protective case and keyboard into one product, and just might be the best accessory you can buy for your iPad Air.The Logitech Ultrathin Keyboard Folio for iPad Air comes with the Folio itself as well as a USB charging cable.After using this Folio extensively with my iPad Air, here's what I like:* The Folio is lightweight. The iPad Air and the Folio weigh 2 pounds, about a pound less than my MacBook Air laptop.* I appreciate the long battery life of the keyboard--you can use the Folio for about 3 months on just one charge. The Folio is also easy to charge using the included USB cable.* Quality: The Folio feels solid and durable in the hand, and the keyboard is a pleasure to type on. The Folio holds the iPad securely, yet also allows the iPad Air to easily be removed when needed.* Bluetooth pairing: Easily pairs the keyboard with the iPad Air--no extra cables or connectors needed.* Magnets: The magnets in the Folio keep the cover closed when the iPad Air is not in use, and also keeps the tablet in a secure, upright position when using the Folio as a tablet stand.* The Folio folds so that you can use the iPad Air without the Folio keyboard, if you want to.There were two minor annoyances with the Folio however:* The number keys are smaller than the letter keys, which means some of the numbers will not be in familiar positions for touch-typists. The "1" key is fully to the right of the "Q" key on the Folio, whereas it is to the left of the "Q" key on my MacBook Air laptop. This means I consistently munge typing some of the numbers.* The Folio sometimes does not turn off the Ipad Air when the cover is closed--you have to manually put the iPad Air to sleep. Auto-wakeup is also not consistent.In the video I go into more detail about the Folio.Though there are a couple annoyances with this Folio, I think this case is one of the best I've seen for any tablet. In fact, I view it more as a natural extension to my iPad Air rather than a separate accessory. The Folio allows me to be more productive with my iPad Air, and when my tablet is in the Folio, I don't worry about it being damaged.You can't lose by pairing the Logitech Ultrathin Keyboard Folio with your iPad Air.

5:12 MinsIf you want to take the quality of your videos to the next level, or if you want a portable, high quality audio recorder, then you might want to consider this TASCAM DR-60D Linear PCM Recorder.I found this piece of audio gear to greatly improve the sound quality of video captured using my DSLR camera and my GoPro Hero 3+ camera.In the video I show what comes in the TASCAM DR-60D box, give an example comparing video with audio from my camera's built-in mic and video with audio captured using the TASCAM DR-60D, and even show how you can use the unit with a Rode Video Mic and GoPro Hero 3+.Though it takes work in post-production to synchronize the audio from the TASCAM to your video and you have to deal with the extra bulk of the unit when filming, especially if you can mount the unit and camera on a tripod, I find that the improvement in audio quality--and therefore resulting movie quality--is worth the effort.There are a lot of features and functions in this unit, making the TASCAM DR-60D very powerful and flexible. So if you are looking to boost the quality of your movies and audio recordings, then this unit is a good choice.

Edward Young was the wartime commander of HMS Storm - a British S Type Submarine. Speaking as one who has visited one of that vessel's many sister ships (HMS Stubborn - deliberately sunk off Malta in 1946 as an Asdic target), I know a little (albeit very little) of the excitement these ships are able to generate. This book vividly brings to life the work and experiences of those who took part in WW2 in such craft and it is the very combination of that war, that type of submarine and the daily events of routine, danger, deprivation and even fun, which is something at which we who enjoy the freedom for which they fought can only marvel.This is a well written book which tells a story. Though centred on the wartime life of the author, it is not a book which is just about him and his ship. It is about the people and the events which he encountered along the way. Theirs is a story which forms part, perhaps only a small part, of the huge jigsaw which was World War Two. Nevertheless, their contribution still remains a vital part of the overall war effort made all the more interesting by the way in which it is told.At over 300 pages of well written dialogue with the addition of just the right amount of photographic plates and maps, this book represents real value for money and reads better than any novel.NM

I first learned to dive in the mid-1970s and within 4 years had amassed some of the top qualifications any British diver might aspire to achieve. Now, after more than 30 years of active diving at the sharp end, I have had to admit that, in my case, ordinary scuba diving techniques are no longer enough. Don‚Äôt get me wrong, those skills are fine for the vast majority of divers and have served me well for over 30 years. For anyone who wishes to progress to even longer and much deeper objectives, however, technical diving is the next logical step forward. And, if you are now at the stage where you are simply thinking about it, you could do a lot worse than reading this book before making up you mind.Kevin Gurr is a diver whose reputation in the field of technical diving precedes him. That, however, meant that, in reviewing this book, I set out to be extremely critical. In other words, it was because of his reputation that I automatically expected far more from any book written by him than I would have accepted from others with a lesser reputation. I found nothing lacking in this work and there is nothing which will disappoint the reader.I would have liked to list the chapter headings in order to give the reader a feel for the different areas of the overall subject covered but I cannot do so because there are far too many such headings and the coverage is complete. Which is great - because it helps me to go to exactly the right part of the book I need to study at any one time. Of course, my own conversion to technical diver is of no interest to anyone else, except that I am a diver of considerable experience who understands the subject - if not all the new techniques (yet!). This product is a valuable addition to my own further training and has helped me through a considerable learning curve. Furthermore, I have yet to raise any question which is not answered by this book.In short, if you are thinking about taking up scuba diving, this is ‚Äúnot‚Äù the book for you. If, however, you are seriously thinking about extending your existing diving skills to technical diving, this book will probably be the best investment you could make. At first sight, it may appear expensive, but when one considers the wealth of information contained within, I think it will come to be regarded - over many years, as probably the best item of technical diving equipment you ever purchased.NM

As British influence and colonial power throughout the Middle East diminished in the 1960s, the strategic military base of Aden soon became a battle ground at the centre of a bloody war that no side could possibly win outright.Jonathan Walker is a member of the British Commission for Military History and an Honorary Research Associate at the University of Birmingham‚Äôs Centre for First World War Studies who has a number of acclaimed works to his credit. He is, therefore, well qualified to write a book about Britain‚Äôs last colonial conflict and, all things considered, appears to have produced a most thorough job of work.Commencing with an all-important explanation of the Kingdom of Sheba, the author steers the reader quite expertly through the cause, condition and eventual outcome of the conflict in a book containing almost 300 pages of narrative plus those equally important explanations and further detail found in the appendices at the end.Personally, I was just as pleased to find a full and frank account of that well known, though often misunderstood and misquoted, contribution made by Lt. Colonel Colin Mitchell and the Argyll and Sutherland Highlanders as I was to discover some of the horrific injuries and assassinations visited upon British civilian staff and their families.The text is supported with a carefully chosen and relevant selection of photographs found together in the middle of the book and, altogether, this product should please most readers for its factual accuracy and clarity of delivery.NMBritish army major (retired)

Edward Young was the wartime commander of HMS Storm - a British S Type Submarine. Speaking as one who has visited one of that vessel's many sister ships (HMS Stubborn - deliberately sunk off Malta in 1946 as an Asdic target), I know a little (albeit very little) of the excitement these ships are able to generate. This book vividly brings to life the work and experiences of those who took part in WW2 in such craft and it is the very combination of that war, that type of submarine and the daily events of routine, danger, deprivation and even fun, which is something at which we who enjoy the freedom for which they fought can only marvel.This is a well written book which tells a story. Though centred on the wartime life of the author, it is not a book which is just about him and his ship. It is about the people and the events which he encountered along the way. Theirs is a story which forms part, perhaps only a small part, of the huge jigsaw which was World War Two. Nevertheless, their contribution still remains a vital part of the overall war effort made all the more interesting by the way in which it is told.At over 300 pages of well written dialogue with the addition of just the right amount of photographic plates and maps, this book represents real value for money and reads better than any novel.NM
