It was interesting to see which ships were noted for whatever aspect we now take for granted.From this point onwards each of the three vessels is laid bare from every conceivable angle and description. Whatever detail you are seeking to study is very likely to be found here. Each of the three ships is afforded a deck-by-deck plan alongside everything from the way in which the ingress of natural daylight was considered as part of the planning process to the double-skinned partitions used in Canberra‚Äôs construction. All of which are mentioned in order to underline the way in which this work is so complete.Although there are several pages with no images at all, the entire work is lavishly supported with historic photographs, line-drawings and plans.When it comes to books about ships and the sea, Conway Maritime are a leading authority. Even so, this particular book is exceptional for the detail, research and those profound insights into the history of passenger/cruise travel in the mid 1950s and of the thinking that went into the production of three such magnificent vessels.NM

On 7 October 1985, a small group of Palestinians seized control of the cruise-liner Achille Lauro off Egypt‚Äôs Mediterranean coast. Taking the passengers and crew hostage, they were demanding the release of fifty Palestinians held in Israeli jails. Having ordered the ship to Syria, they were refused entry into the port of Tartus. After two days of negotiations, the hijackers agreed to leave the liner in return for safe passage to Tunisia. The only casualty had been US passenger Leon Klinghoffer who had been killed by one of their number. Their aircraft, however, was forced to land in Sicily where the group were arrested, tried and various jail sentences imposed. Although unrelated, on 2 December 1994, the ship caught fire off the coast of Somalia during a cruise and sank.As mentioned elsewhere, I am currently engaged in a huge project concerning passenger and cruise ships throughout history. It is a daunting venture. To date, my studies have taken me far and wide in addition to having obtained a number of relevant books. Sadly, far too many of these suffer from an increasingly common malaise whereby wannabe authors look no further than the Internet as the all-singing, all-dancing source of information. Apart from an overall lack of accuracy, the only skills displayed are an ability to tell the difference between a right and left ‚Äòclick of the mouse.‚ÄôI mention this in the hope of clearly demonstrating how good this book really is. It is an important account for which the author deserves great credit. It is as exceptional for the detailed research as it is for being a darned good read. The fact that it was Michael Bohn‚Äôs his first-ever book is also worthy of equal praise. By producing such a high-quality page turner, we are finally provided with a complete account of what really happened - including all the political intrigue of the day. Alongside that ‚Äòdepth of understanding‚Äô of the subject itself, we also find an author who fully appreciates the complexities of research - seemingly having accessed just about every conceivable source. And that is no mean feat!Research is hard work. It is a lonely, laborious task requiring the identification of all sources of relevant information in additional to possessing a working knowledge of whatever filing/index systems are employed by the many museums, libraries, archives, records offices and private collections which may exist. Little wonder, therefore, that those without either the skills or the inclination are incapable of matching works such as this for sheer quality and readability.Put simply, if you want to know what happened in 1985, look no further. And, if you want a darned good read into the bargain - treat yourself. You will not be disappointed!NM

On 26 September 2002, the Senegal-government ferry ‚ÄòLe Joola‚Äô capsized to become the second-worst civilian matitime disaster of all time. The ship was only 12 years old - although she had been undergoing repairs to one of her two engines. Classified as a roll-on roll-off ferry, she displaced 2,087 grt, was 79.5m long and had a carrying capacity of 35 cars plus cargo in addition to 536 passengers and 44 crew. Instead of there being anything up to that limit of 580 persons on board, however, the estimated number of people was actually in excess of 1,900 - perhaps even 2,000!The ship departed Ziguinchor about 1330 hrs for Dakar. By 2200 hrs radio reports suggested all was well but one hour later she encountered an atrocious storm which caused her to list momentarily - perhaps as a result of shifting cargo, and then continue to roll until she was upside down in the water. The entire capsize was over within a matter of moments with no time for anyone to react and no distress signal was sent. Without the prospect of immediate rescue and with no boats launched, many of those who did find themselves in the sea died that night.The following morning, local fishermen arrived ahead of the main rescue effort. One survivor explained how people were trapped alive in air-pockets but unable to get out of the upturned ship. This was confirmed by tapping and even shouting and screaming being heard from inside the hull. Before they could be helped, however, the ferry suddenly sank in very deep water. After much investigation, the official death toll was put at 1,863. Of the more than 600 women on board, there was only one amongst the 64 survivors. Poor maintenance of the ship is now widely regarded as being a major contributory factor in the loss.This work, however, seeks to add additional dimensions bordering on the fictional. In attempting to create such wholly unnecessary examples of invention, mystery and intrigue Wiley draws on that age-old (and very tired!) parallel with the Titanic for which he earns a triple yawn for being both predictable and far too late. Such a comparison (with the only other shipwreck he has ever heard of) is a clear outward sign of a desperate need to find a new angle where none exist. In so doing he displays a complete lack of understanding of the subjects of research, ships, shipwrecks and what is already written on the subject. I have no idea how many lost ships are openly billed as being this country‚Äôs or region‚Äôs Titanic - because they are countless. Describing Le Joola as ‚ÄúAfrica‚Äôs Titanic‚Äù is so amateurish and unoriginal it almost smacks of plagiarism. I can name at least three ships which are already so described plus many more from countries as far apart as Australia and Canada. In one instance, the epithet is even ascribed to a sunken Tugboat! Such claims are used in books in the hope that the very word ‚ÄòTitanic‚Äô will catch the eye of the masses when an improved text coupled with detailed research is always the preferred option.As printed on the back cover, we are asked to consider the following outrageous questions; What caused this disaster which was worse than the Titanic? Why weren‚Äôt the lifeboats or life rafts launched? Why was it late the following day before rescue craft arrived? Curiously the answers are found in Mr Wiley‚Äôs brief biopic which appears towards the end of this lamentable nonsense. It is here that we learn how this so-called author has studied creative writing. Creative writing is a gift - it allows a good writer to describe anything from fact to fiction in an interesting, readable and hard-to-put-down manner. Creative writing is not, however, the same as creative accounting - where facts and figures are falsified! Perhaps he should try fiction - but certainly not book-keeping!NM

On 10 November 1928, the 10,000 ton cargo-liner Vestris departed New York for Barbados and Buenos Aires. Under command of Captain W. J. Carey, she had 128 passengers and 197 crew on board. Within 24 hours, the ship encountered the heaviest possible weather and at about 1930 hrs 11 November was struck by two waves of incredible size in quick succession. Two lifeboats were washed away and part of the cargo and bunker coal shifted causing a severe permanent list. The ship now began to take on water at such a rate the pumps were unable to cope. By daybreak, Captain Carey recognised his ship was in poor shape but refused to send out an SOS message until 0945 hrs. Almost immediately, his work force of firemen (stokers) came on deck and refused to return to their posts. Whereas the engineers attempted to carry out the requisite tasks, the list continued to increase and they too had to stop as well. Without power, Carey had no option but to abandon ship - shortly after which the Vestris rolled over and sank.On arrival, the rescue ships had great difficulty in finding the lifeboats due to the reduced visibility and high sea sate. Eventually, however, a small number of vessels, including the USS Wyoming, rescued 215 persons between them. The remaining 110 were all lost.This particular account of the loss of the Vestris suffers from three main problems. Firstly, in a work first published in 2013 (85 years after the event), there is little or nothing which might be described as ‚Äònew‚Äô information. Secondly, the writing style gets bogged down with trivia - especially when it comes to numbers, and would have benefitted considerably from a professional publisher‚Äôs input. Finally, the text is reproduced on poor quality paper which, although fine for words is wholly unsuitable for images and the B&W pictures, such as they are, appear amongst that text on the same quality paper.Altogether, therefore, the fact that the book is self-published screams from every page and, in so doing, fails to support all the effort which must have been put into the work in the first instance - in much the same way as the most smartly dressed soldier on parade will always be let down by dirty boots. Whenever that happens, he might just as well not have bothered with all the rest!NM

The passenger liner Royal Edward was built in Glasgow in 1906 and employed between Bristol and Canada until the outbreak of WW1. On 13 August 1915, the ship was acting as an auxiliary troop transport during the Gallipoli campaign when she was torpedoed and sunk by U15 under command of Lt. von Heimburg. Of all the records this ship had accumulated and might have gone on to achieve during her lifetime, she became the first troopship lost to enemy action in the 20th Century.Lt. von Heimburg remained on site and viewed the sinking and subsequent rescue via periscope and, unlike some of his fellow commanders made no attempt to interfere. Fewer than 500 of the 1,366 troops and 220 crew who were on board the ship survived.Richard Oliff‚Äôs great uncle was one of those casualties and it is from the book‚Äôs dedication we first learn how it was his grandmother who inspired the research which led to this work.Throughout the 20th Century many of the world‚Äôs greatest ships (and many more which were not so great) were lost in times of war and peace. Tracing the history of each vessel to come under the microscope of serious research is often such a difficult and onerous task it leads to much being published which either true or false. Happily, in this instance, Oliff deserves much credit for the way in which he has tackled the subject matter and I have learned much that I did not previously know about this ship.Most important of all, perhaps, the style of writing turns almost every little ‚Äòaside‚Äô into another interesting element of the entire story. As an example, after the ship has departed on her final journey, he writes; ‚ÄúCoincidentally, the day after the Royal Edward was spotted rounding the most western point of England, my father was born in the village of Great Burstead‚Ä¶.‚ÄùFully supported with an equally fascinating collection of historic images of people, places and, of course, ships, this is as complete a work on a single ship as one might hope to find.NM

This photo-led work is an excellent compilation of images from John Brown‚Äôs shipyard on Clydebank. Whereas I never tire of looking at such historic photos, there are ships and there are ships and those depicted in this book rank amongst some of the greatest warships ever built. The five Battlecruisers built by John Brown‚Äôs are detailed in the order; Inflexible (24 pages), Australia (26), Tiger (28), Repulse (32) and the Mighty Hood (56). These are followed by an overview of the G3 contract which was cancelled in 1922. The book then concludes with 10 Appendices, Sources & Bibliography and Index.Taking the Inflexible as an example of the way in which each subject vessel is tackled, we find the complete story of this ship in between images of the highest possible calibre. Bearing in mind the book‚Äôs full title, these photographs show almost every conceivable angle and feature. Four triple-blade propellers, twin rudders, stem, hull and so much more are shown in a series of pre-launch pictures which even include one of her steam launch. After her launch, we find photographs which include; deck views, amidships, aft section, stem, boat stowage, workmen taking a break on the foc‚Äôsle deck, bridge, turrets, the two starboard 125 cwt Wasteney Smith stockless anchors close up to the hawse pipes, upper control platforms, weapons, aft funnel, boat deck, steam siren, searchlight, ratings asleep below decks, refrigeration plant, Admiral‚Äôs cabin and a number of ship portraits both steaming at full power, stopped in the water. The other vessels mentioned are given the same treatment with even more images per ship.From this selection of previously unpublished images one begins to gain an appreciation of the amount of work which went into the three year building and fitting-out process for such weapons of war. That detail is then made all the more interesting by the inclusion of sufficient text to whet the appetite and, although not exhaustive, answer most of the questions one might have.Altogether, this is an excellent product where many of the images simply leap from the page.NM

It was the First World War - known at that time as "The Great War" which changed Britain and Europe forever. As the Generals on both sides sent millions of men to their deaths in the carnage which they regarded as warfare, there came about a change in the psyche of the British male - a change which would herald a complete alteration in the way he thought and acted towards those of the upper, ruling classes. No longer would that British male be so quick to use such words as "M'Lord" or even "Sir." No longer would he doff his cap as a mark of respect, no longer would the ordinary police Constable be so quick to "arrest that man" just because a well dressed person had ordered him so to do.That change in British Society continues to this day and is easily traced back to the feelings of loss and despair which came with the realisation that far too many young men had died "at the front" - even though the war itself had been won and mainland Britain had escaped unscathed.In this epic tale, author Robert Massie delves deep into why that war occurred in the first place. Every single aspect of argument and behaviour on both sides (both military and political) is exposed and analysed. As the title of the book would suggest, the theme is the world's first great arms race. When Britain produced the first Dreadnought Battleship it rendered all other battleships obsolete at a stroke (including the remainder of the British Fleet!). From that moment onwards it was always a question of who could produce the most new Dreadnoughts in the quickest possible time. Set against this wish by both Britain and Germany to be seen as the world's supreme masters of the seas was a political intrigue which few have been able to commit to print in such a masterly fashion as is found in this book.In short, this is one of the greatest books of our time. It is also a damn fine read.NM

Throughout my work as a shipwreck historian (it‚Äôs what I do!), I find many gaps in published material. The ferries which ply the English Channel and other short routes around Britain, for example, are often overlooked in favour of more glamorous vessels. This work seeks to redress that balance and is another excellent publication from Seaforth Publishing in which we find some 300 images of the ferries of yesterday. I never tire of looking at photos of historic ships and I now have a whole new selection to study at my leisure. With 2 or 3 B&W images on almost every pages, this is a book which takes the reader on a journey through time to the early 1970s in which it explains the cross-channel steamer and ferry in marvellous detail.Leaving the ‚ÄòIntroduction‚Äô until last, the book is thoughtfully divided into 10 chapters which take the reader from the earliest vessels right through to 1971 - where the book completes its journey. The chapter headings are self-explanatory as follows; (1) Early Paddle Steamers and Experimental Vessels, (2) Screw begins to Challenger Paddle, (3)  From Paddle to Triple Expansion Engines, (4) Improved Steamers, (5) The Turbine Revolution, (6) Geared Turbines and WW1, (7) Diesel Debut, (8) The 1930s, (9) WW2 and Fleet Reconstruction and (10) The Final Years. Each of these commences with its own short preamble after which we find vessels listed by year - each with its own image and explanatory text.It is, however, in the ‚ÄòIntroduction‚Äô where the entire subject is displayed in excellent fashion. The very concept of a ‚ÄòCross-channel steamer‚Äô is one which was born out of the geographical location of the UK and its close proximity to mainland Europe. Just as Mississippi riverboats are special to that river and Great Lakes steamers were developed for the conditions found there, each style of ship is different for very good reasons. Having explained the origins of the type of ship in question, we are then introduced to the many developments and variants which came about; railways, paddles, screws, turbines, WW1, hospital ships, armed boarding-ships, auxiliary mine-layers, mine-sweepers & net-layers, seaplane carriers, the inter-war period, motor-ships, WW2, troopships, hospital ships (another war!), infantry landing-ships, anti-aircraft ships, Axis-requisitioned ships, post-war reconstructions, final deliveries, last survivors, Wm Denny & Brothers and notes on ship design. And all that from 14 pages of Introduction.The paddles - as mounted onto the sides of a ship, were complex items and the two engines required to turn those wheels required far more space than the single engine required for a propeller. As those original steam engines gave way to turbines and then diesel, we find an explanation of that process of evolution and further development put into the context of how, where and when it all happened. This allows the book to take on a whole new meaning and, therefore, importance, because of the ongoing additional educational element. In other words, there is a lot more here than just British ferries!Whereas I was already aware of the significant changes in nautical propulsion systems - nowhere have I found the subject better explained than in this work and that makes it rather special!NM

For some time now, I have been studying the history of passenger-ships as part of a large project with which I am currently involved. Researching ships and shipwrecks is what I do and this was one of a number of books purchased for that reason. Each new acquisition comes to the top of the pile in no particular order and, having just finished a wretchedly appalling so-called history of P&O Cruises (which was nothing more than blatant advertising for Carnival Cruises!), I was still a little angry when I picked up this book which just happened to be next. Almost immediately, my faith was restored.Created in 1878, the Orient Line soon became the preferred shipping company for European travel to Australia and the Far East. With a reputation for comfort and quality, the company operated 31 vessels before merging with P&O in 1960.In this carefully and skilfully produced work, the very history of the Orient Line is told through those ships, including the hardships of two world wars. Appearing in date order, each vessel is described with all the technical data and full career narrative. The Ophir of 1891, for example, spent part of her time as the official `Royal Yacht' - although it might seem almost impossible that such a relatively low-profile ship had sufficient room for that huge and very beautiful first-class dining saloon. Elsewhere, a photograph of the Otranto signed by the entire Australian cricket team of the day adds another dimension to the life-time of a ship which had two serious collisions before settling down to complete over 30 years loyal service. My own favourite, however, will always remain the Orcades - but then I did have a model of that ship when I was a boy.Not only is this an excellent work, it is also a clear demonstration of how the history of any shipping line should be written and reproduced. The author has an engaging style of writing and the entire product is lavishly illustrated with B&W historic images. One can ask for no more!NM

As a shipwreck historian (it‚Äôs what I do) I study ships of all types and sizes. Currently engaged on a huge project involving the history of passenger-ships, my never-ending quest for information in recent years has favoured that particular genre. Although published in 1992, I came to this work because of the sub-title which reads; ‚ÄúFrom the golden era of ocean liners to the luxury cruise ships of today‚Äù in the expectation of finding an historical treatise on the subject. It is no such thing.This is the third work by Maxtone-Graham to cross my desk recently and each of these informs the reader he is the quintessential expert, the fount of all knowledge, the very sage itself - when it comes to the subject of big passenger-ships. Instead of learning anything of real value, however, his writing might easily be described as the perfunctory outpourings of those back-room people who are paid to produce promotional literature. The sort of people who are employed to make a company look good, make defeat look like a victory and annihilation like a temporary setback. In this particular book, we are subjected to a no-holds-barred view through the rosiest of tinted spectacles of how good cruising is and nothing else.Whereas he does occasionally mention yesterday, he does so in a style which does not seek to teach the reader of the historical context or of the technology of the day. Instead it centres on the hardships and privations of the steerage-class passenger which is then used as a platform for returning to his self-appointed theme of how good it is today. Were he selling the product it would amount to subliminal advertising.There is a lot which is right with cruising and cruise-ships and much that is very wrong. From this work, however, we are subjected to an annoyingly sycophantic repetition of preaching from the pulpit of big ship travel in which the author extols the benefits of how good cruising is now when compared to how bad it was then. It is a message which almost demands the reader partake in a modern cruise just so that their ancestors may now rest easy‚Ä¶I am mindful of the publication date of 1992 when providing the following statistics - which I have readily to hand. Similar figures for the 26 years to 1992 would take far too long to produce. Nevertheless, the message is clear.What you will not learn from this book is anything similar to the following: Between 1985 and 2010 (26 years inclusive), 177 cruise-liners are listed as having ‚Äòretired‚Äô from active cruising and you may judge the associated statistics for yourself. 107 of these ships were broken up (i.e. scrapped) at the end of their lives. These were all in poor shape and could not be used at sea any more and yet, had all recently been carrying hundreds of passengers. 18 of the remainder were lost because they sank. Another 19 were lost to fire - with three of those also sinking. Two ran aground, one capsized, one broke in two at anchor, one was abandoned, two are shown as ‚Äòfate unknown‚Äô and 26 are recorded as having changed their role. Of the latter, two became floating hotels but most of the remainder became freighters, passenger-ships or ferries - mostly in third world countries where the requisite safety regulations are not so strict. That‚Äôs OK then! A swift analysis reveals: An average of 7 ships every year ceased operating as cruise-ships. Of these, 23.7% (almost one in four!!!) came to an unfortunate end through sinking, fire or simply falling apart. Although there were four years in which no vessel was lost to accident or misfortune, there were seven when at least three met a very tragic end.These statistics are deliberately included in order to redress the extremely biased, one-sided, pleasant-dreamy-eyed view of cruising in this lengthy piece of promotional blurb.NM

Whereas I never tire of looking at such historic photos, there are ships and there are ships and those depicted in this book rank amongst some of the greatest warships ever built. The five Battlecruisers built by John Brown‚Äôs are detailed in the order; Inflexible (24 pages), Australia (26), Tiger (28), Repulse (32) and the Mighty Hood (56). The book then concludes with 10 Appendices, Sources & Bibliography and Index.Taking the Inflexible as an example of the way in which each subject vessel is tackled, we find the complete story of this ship in between images of the highest possible calibre. The ‚ÄòShips in Focus‚Äô series of books are an excellent resource for any serious researcher and this one is no exception. The foreword describes the content as ‚Äúthe most thorough photographic presentation yet attempted on the Blue Funnel Line‚Äù and I can confirm the images are truly outstanding and a joy to study. Whereas the work is photo-led, everything is supported with brief details of each vessel.Alfred Holt‚Äôs Blue Funnel Line had a reputation for being the greatest cargo-liner company and the greatest Liverpool shipping company. Whereas such descriptions are, of course, subjective, there is no doubt this company was an important player within the industry for over 100 years and, throughout that time, operated some equally important vessels.Beginning with the earliest ships, turning the pages to study each successive image provides the reader with a slow march through time as the book skilfully progresses year by year throughout that century and more of ship design. In a work of almost 200 pages (approx A4 size), there are 2-4 B&W images on almost every page and all are of the highest possible quality. Only the final 18 are in colour.I never tire of looking at historic images of ships and this collection is easily one of the best in my possession.NM

The Discovery was designed especially for Antarctic waters. She was not a naval vessel and did not, therefore, fly the white ensign even though a serving RN officer was given command. She was instead given the prefix RRS (Royal Research Ship). Constructed at Dundee and launched in 1901, she was the last traditional wooden three-master built in Britain and on page 11 there is a remarkable photograph of the ship‚Äôs frames on the stocks - looking like the carcass of a huge whale, opposite to which are the builder‚Äôs profile, decks plans and sail configuration.The ship‚Äôs first mission was to carry Scott and Shackleton in the 1901-1904 National Antarctic Expedition. This later became known as the ‚ÄòDiscovery Expedition‚Äô after which the ship was sold to the Hudson Bay Company and used to carry cargo. Discovery did not take part in Scott‚Äôs ill-fated expedition to the South Pole in 1912. It is, therefore, with some irony that the outcome of that particular mission made Scott a national hero and created a level of fame for his original ship which might not otherwise have occurred.Nevertheless, the ship is a very special vessel with a fascinating history of over 100 years afloat and this book tells that complete story. The work is divided into six parts with each containing subordinate chapters (22 altogether). Part One is headed ‚ÄòThe National Antarctic Expedition 1901-04‚Äô and includes details of South Polar exploration of the time, the building of the ship, first voyage, winter quarters, sledging, relief expedition and the journey home. It is a complete description of that expedition which is particularly well written.Parts 2-6 are headed; Voyages to Hudson Bay 1905-11, WW1 and its Aftermath 1915-20, The Oceanographic Expeditions 1925-27, The Banzare 1929-31 and Sea Scouts & After 1932-2001.Today, the ship is one of the main visitor attractions in Dundee. Fittingly, therefore, the very last chapter is headed ‚ÄòHome to Dundee‚Äô in which her return to that port is fully described. This is followed by an Appendix detailing her ‚ÄòRestoration and Display.‚ÄôThe text is fully supported with plenty of historic photographs (mostly B&W) and other images. Most important of all, author Ann Savours has fully researched her subject and turned all that information into the most interesting account of this fabulous ship.NM

It is because I am currently engaged on a huge project involving passenger-ship travel through the ages that I am currently studying a large number of books which although `new to me' may not be new to others. This particular offering from a seemingly well known writer on the subject of passenger-liners, however, has left me rather bemused. Published in 1985 to great acclaim, I found it difficult to match that praise with the reality of the product. This is a thick book (almost 500 pages) which would easily have benefitted from a larger format and the inclusion of glossy photographs as opposed to reproducing the 250 or so B&W images on the same poor quality paper as the over-laborious text. It really is hard-going.In trying to describe any book, I sometimes repeat the chapter headings in order to demonstrate the content. In this case there are 10 chapters as follows; Cruise Lines, Newbuilding, Class Distinctions, Cruises Past, Tropical Rig, Cabin Fever, Backstage, Dark Nights, Cruises Present and Cruises to Come - none of which do anything to suggest what the reader might find within.In a work which seeks to explain the whole culture of the cruise liner - past, present and future, the passengers of old and the passengers of today, the ships, the personalities and just about everything else you might consider relevant to such a work, I found it outstanding for being so boring. Ships are exciting places, they all have the most remarkable histories, the next port of call is always different from the last and who knows who or what might be encountered around that next corner or over that next wave - but we find none of that here. Instead we dwell upon the trivia of the non-descript - almost as though it were the very cruise ship owners who had commissioned the work to show them in a good light. In short, it is memorable for its complete emptiness!Only this morning I read an unrelated book review in which the reviewer explained from personal experience the difference between the wrought-iron rivet and the steel rivet. In just a few words, I learned something of importance which was also fascinating - about a RIVET! In the almost 500 pages from this work, I made no notes for my own future use  because there was nothing of significance to be learned.I was not previously aware of John Maxtone-Graham whose previous roles in life include Broadway stage manager and film producer. Perhaps he moved on to the subject of cruise liners because he also imbued those former careers with equally forgettable performances. Having just learned he is now writing a "new book about the Titanic" (aren't they all `new' books when they first appear?), his predictability becomes complete. So much fact and fiction about the Titanic has already been provided in book form and on screen that, whatever may be written in the future, however factual or farcical, will always have some who firmly believe in what has been written - and that is always a good fall-back position for any author seeking a subject.NM

Conway's are a leading British publisher of maritime subjects and internationally recognised for the quality of the works they produce. It says much for this particular series that there are many devotees who can't wait for the next edition and, once again, are not likely to be disappointed. That said, the brief title `Warship 2014' may give the impression of only the latest ships and technology being included. Not so! My own particular area of interest stems from shipwrecks and requires me to study historic vessels of all types and I found a great deal of interest here.Whereas those vessels that never got beyond the drawing board, rarely grab my attention, the splendid account of the Royal Navy aircraft carrier cancelled in 1966 was particularly fascinating. Other features include; Amiral Charner class cruisers, German battleships Braunschweig & Deutschland, the Japanese armoured cruisers which fought at Tsushima, the new Italian aircraft carrier Cavour, Admiral Lazarev & Admiral Spiridov class frigates, the IJN light carrier Ry˚j√¥, Post-WW2 fire control in the Royal Navy and the incredible story of the escape from St. Nazaire during WW2 of the incomplete French battleship Jean Bart. The work then concludes with `Warship Notes' (a selection of short articles), Book reviews and Warship Gallery - with the latter being an amazing series of photographs depicting the building of the French battleship Libert√© (laid down 1903, completed 1908) at St Nazaire.Clearly, therefore, this book has something for everyone but there is also another dimension which sets it apart from anything else. Each of the contributing authors is an acknowledged expert in his own right - with many, if not all, having several publications to their own name. Each of these talents has produced one of the aforementioned chapters - all of which have been skilfully brought together under the equally expert editorship of John Jordan.The entire work is lavishly illustrated with countless B&W images of the highest calibre showing ships and the many features and equipment they carried. These are supported by artwork which includes; general arrangements, line drawing (profiles, sections and inboard configurations) side-view and deck plans of various vessels and weapon systems.If I could suggest a simple improvement (and none more are needed) it would be to provide larger scale plans and profiles in `pull-out' format - although I did not encounter any serious problems with the size of material provided.Altogether, therefore, we have a product from a leading publisher in which the specific detail is provided by a highly qualified and experienced team of writers you know you can trust. For some, the technical information will be invaluable. For others, the quality of the `read' is most important. Just as soon as I settled down to study the content, I became fascinated and found myself treating each separate chapter like a short story - some of which are as exciting as any novel.NM

I am currently studying passenger-ships as part of an extensive project with which I am involved and, as with all intensive research, the quest is the acquisition of trustworthy information. Sadly there are not enough quality products available. This one, however, stands mast and funnel above the rest because everyone involved with the book knows their subject - and that subject is the Liner.'Conway Maritime Marine' are a leading British publisher of maritime subjects and it says much for author Philip Dawson that they have published several of his works. With a foreword written by Stephen Payne - the Chief naval architect for the Queen Mary 2, everything about this scholarly work exudes value, class, knowledge and detail in every respect. Of all the books I have on the subject, this one belongs in a class of its own. And if that is not enough, it is also well written and, therefore, a fascinating read.There are so many separate elements to the work it is impossible to mention them all. The design features of various ships are included - with a large section devoted to the Queen Mary 2. The fact that certain features from the design of one ship were then used in another or to overcome problems elsewhere is utterly intriguing. This is not, however, all about modern ships. The beginning of passenger travel across the oceans - especially across the North Atlantic, is also covered in refreshing detail. Here is an author who not only knows his subject and is, therefore, able to put his own gloss onto the topic, he also delves into history and provides a writing style which leaves the reader eager to learn more.Many works devoted to transatlantic passenger travel over the years have been accused of being pro-British or pro-European because of the number of ships from that side of the `pond' being featured. Whereas there is no place for such nationalistic nonsense in any serious study (and certainly none here!), it was the overwhelming numbers of emigrant passengers which dominated the industry for many years. As such, the passenger traffic was very one-sided with people seeking a new life in America and not vice versa. As with any trade which originates on one side of the Atlantic, the response will always come from that same side.Nevertheless, before all that traffic really got underway, it was the American paddle-steamer (side-wheeler) `Savannah' which crossed the Atlantic in 1819 to prove steam-powered vessels were capable of making such a journey. In this rather complete work, therefore, we find many of the greatest ships ever to embark on that particular crossing. With images of the early Cunard paddle-steamer Britannia arriving in Boston in 1840, through the years to the latest vessels, it would be easy to provide the reader with a list of famous names - all of which are mentioned here somewhere. Instead, another reason why this work sits apart from all others is that vessels such as the Orcades (always a personal favourite), Dominion Monarch, L'Atlantique, Europa, Bremen, Orion and Baltic (and many more) - which were never household names, are also included.The most important point of all, however, is that this work is not about any particular shipping company or any number of ships, people or places. It is the complete story of transatlantic travel - all of it, from the very beginning to modern times. It is a lengthy story, involving many people, shipping lines, inventions, modifications, two world wars and millions of passengers. It is a story I would have thought could not be told in a single book. Now it is!NM

In between the `bookends' of a Preface written by the current MD of P&O Cruises and a Foreword by the chief executive of Carnival UK (both right at the beginning) and a Conclusion at the very end provided by the chairman and chief executive, Carnival Corporation Plc, this is such a sympathetic view of P&O Cruises it amounts to nothing more than over-lengthy promotional literature. With the exception of those taken of the Canberra during the Falklands War of 1982, all images are clearly sanitised, photo-shopped or posed.Because the work has no Index, anyone wanting to check a particular vessel or see how many of the fleet from the past 175 years are mentioned, will have to plod their way through a succession of promotional outbursts (all produced in a manner which suggests they were written by the very people who fashion such advertising blurb - and not by `real' authors at all!) in order to make their utter disappointment complete. Were it an interesting read, it would be a pleasure so to do - but it is not and most of those magnificent ships from history are not mentioned anyway.The Peninsular and Oriental Steam Navigation Company has a place is maritime history which is unequalled elsewhere. On reading this quite awful and repetitive outpouring of `look at us aren't we good' it also seems to have been in existence long before the clich√© was ever invented - something which these so-called authors now seek to remedy with a passion. Take, for example, the originality of the heading for Chapter 1; "The sun never sets on a P&O ship 1837-1919." If that were true - none would ever have been scrapped!A brief look at the remaining headings reveals nothing more than a product intended to appeal to pensioners and over-aged swingers in the hope they will consider a suitable alternative to their mixed-couples Jacuzzi-party holiday in Latvia next year. It really is over-sized pamphleture at its gaudiest where the parent company seeks to promote-themselves, promote-themselves and then even promote-themselves - a little more. Other chapter headings are; From liners to cruise ships, Operation Corporate, Full ahead on passage, A new dawn, What's in a name, Southampton - a place to call home, What defines P&O-ness (I never made that up - honest!), Every meal a banquet, Going ashore, Entertainment and activities, Upstairs-Downstairs and 2012 and beyond (see what I mean about clich√©s!).In a work supposedly about the 175 year history of P&O (their words - not mine), by Chapter 3 it has already arrived at 1982 when the Falkland Islands were retaken by British forces (Op. Corporate). The previous 145 years of the history of this once-fabulous company is, therefore, condensed to such a degree it not only fails to live up to the book's title it also fails to conceal that continual underlying theme of telling the world how good they are in the hope of gaining your custom. The only item of remote interest is the way in which they demand reflected glory from that time of 1982. They do not, however, mention how the company is so structured their ships can never be called upon again. How patriotic is that!Truth is, P&O is now an afterthought within Carnival Cruises, just like `White Star' is nothing more than afternoon tea on a Cunard ship. They have gone, they are no more, they have ceased to be...Whereas the master of a super-tanker or aircraft carrier, for example, has to acquire additional skills pertinent to the type of ship he is commanding, nowhere in this work does it mention the appropriate additional expertise required of those who command a modern cruise liner. The largest cruise ships in the world currently weigh-in at 225,282 grt, measure 1,187 feet (362m) and have a carrying capacity of 8,690 people (6,296 passengers and 2,394 crew) with even bigger vessels under construction. Ships can sink (it's what they occasionally do!) and I would have preferred to know something of the specialist crisis-management training such masters undergo in the event of the unthinkable. Assuming, of course, they do?

Prior to 1932, Italian ships lacked some vital quality until the Rex was completed and all that changed. During WW2, however, Italy lost so many ships she needed to do something to capture the world‚Äôs imagination. Building the two sister-ships - Andrea Doria and Cristoforo Colombo, enabled the country to demonstrate the very best of Italian luxury and design. The Andrea Doria was launched on 16 June 1951 and was the first ship ever to have 3 swimming pools - one for each class of passenger. On 26 July 1956, she was in collision with the Stockholm and sank with the loss of 51 lives from both vessels.I mention the foregoing as an example of what is missing from this child‚Äôs scrapbook of photographs. Firstly, the Andrea Doria was an important ship and was on her 101st crossing of the Atlantic when she was lost. She is not, however, included in this book and is only mentioned in passing on page 152 as part of the briefest possible (100 words) description of the Cristoforo Colombo. Furthermore, the abysmal photograph of that latter ship is taken in a busy harbour at an odd angle in a manner which fails to demonstrate the ship‚Äôs lines. That image takes up a full half page. Of the remainder, about one third is taken up with the aforementioned text and, in keeping with almost every other page, the rest is left blank. Yes, huge white spaces on almost every page. In publishing terms it amounts to padding without any padding.With so many blank spaces to catch the eye, it soon becomes apparent how little or no time was expended on the text. The Himalaya is described in just 25 words, the Conte Biancamano in 22 and the Oronsay in only twelve! In short, you could read this book from start to finish in the time it takes to wait your turn to see your doctor (assuming they are not running late).As a shipwreck historian (it‚Äôs what I do) I study ships of all types, sizes and nationalities. In so doing, I never tire of looking at good photographs (especially historic images) of ships. In a work which boasts of being a photographic record, I can honestly say IT IS NO SUCH THING! A single obscure photograph of one ship is nothing more than a single image of a particular subject. That is not a photographic record of anything at all. As for the images themselves, I had already seen most, if not all, elsewhere and the book holds no secrets or surprises in that regard.In reality, all we have is an odd selection of historic photographs thrown together in a manner reminiscent of a child‚Äôs scrapbook with very poor captions covering some (not all) of those ships described by the title. As such, I am hugely disappointed and will probably consign this and the sister-work to the bin.NM

When one thinks of ‚ÄòGreat‚Äô cruise ships and ocean liners all those famous names and even more famous tragedies spring easily to mind. When put into the context of 1954 to 1986 (far too specific when fifties to eighties would have been far more comfortable) one has to pause and think of which ships fit that period. One of these was the last-ever four funnelled ship still afloat - the Arundel Castle which, although reduced to two funnels in 1937, is worthy of her rightful place in history.In December 1958, the Arundel Castle was finally taken out of service and scrapped the following year. She is not, however, included here - although her only sister ship is mentioned on page 75. That vessel was the Windsor Castle which was lost to aerial torpedo on 23 March 1943 - a full 11 years prior to the period covered by this book. But that is not the only oddity found here!Whereas my comments might appear very ‚Äòpicky-picky,‚Äô the inclusion of such ships as; the African Endeavour, African Enterprise, Alco Cavalier discharging a cargo of Bauxite at Mobile, Gothic, Exeter, Brasil Star, Santa Monica, State of Madras and so many, many more are worthy of mention for very good reasons. None would have sprung to the minds of anyone who was applying the word ‚ÄòGreat‚Äô to any type of passenger ship and they certainly do not even remotely fit the title of this book.Of those which were amongst the good and great, the Andrea Doria tragedy is told in 230 words - a feat of brevity which will forever become enshrined in the annuls of maritime history, if only because it can‚Äôt be done! That particular entry also comes with two well-worn pictures - one of the sinking ship and another of the damaged Stockholm in New York (yawn!). Nobody bothered to mention that, after several changes of names, the Stockholm is still in service to this day - as we approach the 59th anniversary of that disaster.I am currently studying passenger-ships as part of a huge project which has been ongoing for some time. Part of my research includes the purchase of all manner of books and other documents relating to those ships. Not all great ships were famous and not all famous ships were great. In a work which is full of tired photographs and the briefest possible captions to accompany those images we have a book which proclaims itself to be about the ‚ÄòGreat‚Äô whilst barely managing to include a few from that category. Saddest of all, of those which are included - none afforded true justice!NM

I use these for Aikido training (you are on your knees a lot).  Knee pads are a great help.  Open back pads are essential because of time spent in formal Japanese sitting position, where you need flexibility to completely fold your knees.  These pads are lightweight and seem quite durable.  I've used them over the years and they even seem to stand up to being laundered with a little bit of bleach.  (Knee pads are sweat catchers for sure, and need to be washed frequently.)I used the Adams size guide when I first bought a pair, and when I first put them on I thought they were too tight.  However after use I realized if they are too loose they will slide around and you'll constantly be pulling them up.  Even with the size recommended it is occasionally necessary to move them back into place.  Their size chart is accurate and you should follow it.

I have been a loyal TurboTax customer since sometime in the 90's (I threw away the floppy disks a long time ago, and I don't  recall the earliest date, but it's been a long time.)  I am angry about the deliberate disabling of critical features in TurboTax Deluxe.  No Schedules C, D, or E.  In the past, the product was functional, even though the "Premier" version provided more help and guidance.  That was extra functionality and if you needed it you could buy it.  But in Deluxe you got the forms, the basic help info, the IRS docs, the final review checking, printing, and e-filing.  So if you knew what a schedule C or D was (it's not that hard) you could file your taxes.Now in the name of "consistency" this has been taken away, and if I want to file my taxes using TurboTax I need to buy something much more expensive.  I have read the words about how Intuit labored over the vital need to be "consistent" and yes indeed after their stressful labors they did indeed cripple the product and they will try to force people to buy the much more expensive version.  Please be honest -- just step up and say you decided to charge a lot more money.  Instead the official Intuit response sounds like we're supposed to feel sorry for how difficult it was for them to decide to raise the price.Raising the price is something I would object to but it's just a price increase.  It's the disingenuous explanation that shows such contempt for the intelligence of customers which prompts me to give a one star rating, only because it's not possible to give zero stars.Intuit used to be known for making products that pleased customers and surprised them -- in a positive way.  It's sad to see the company's current attitude.I already gave a 1-star review to the new crippled "Deluxe" program. But I do need to use something and I at least considered the Premier version.  Even in this high-priced Premier version, Schedule C is crippled -- limited to $100 of deductions in a couple of expense categories.  I.e. only good for a tiny hobby business, and maybe not even that.  So now having forced me to Premier, even this high priced product is useless to me.  Intuit, what is wrong with you people?Everyone who reads this:  Maybe you will have to buy the product in order to avoid the trouble of converting to another product.  But even if you decide to buy it, please take the time to register a negative review here or at other product review sties.  You don't have to write as long a review as I did -- just a couple of sentences and click on 1-star.  Even if you have a rational reason for giving in to Intuit's extortion, maybe the negative reviews will cause other customers to choose other products.  Maybe someday Intuit will be forced to care about customers.

So I bit my lip and looked at ordering the Premier version.  Even in the high-priced Premier version, Schedule C is crippled -- limited to $100 of deductions in a couple of expense categories.
