The Asphalt pair is far too snug and going up to 9M is what's needed.I'm dying to wear the black pair with tights in the fall, but I still have not decided whether to keep. They are comfortable on, largely due to the material used for the heel & sole. However, arch support is lacking ... and that is not something I require a lot of. I don't have a high arch by any means but something seems just a bit "off" for me. Will attempt with inserts. Otherwise they will not be keepers. Pity.

This is a great vest for the money & the colors are bright and vibrant. However, watch for flaws.First I ordered 2 (green, pink) and both had stains, so I returned them and reordered 1 in a darker color (purple). The material is more plush than usual for Columbia, something more like fabric you'd find in loungewear rather than outwear. I like them but I just don't believe they are first quality. So watch for stains and flaws.Sizing is not generous in my opinion. A Medium worked for me (I'm a 10) but it's a slim fit in my opinion. However, the fit is typical for Columbia, at least for me.

The amaryllis color is bright & sunny -- a nice change from typical jacket colors. The jacket is nice but size-wise is a slim fit. If you are between sizes, definitely order up. I'm a 10-12 on top: The medium is too snug and going back.I did purchase the white in large from another seller. I would say that the large fits like a 12-14. The white is nice and versatile for me, but it has a wee bit of a yellow cast to it. If I was to do it over again, I would get the amaryllis. The jacket is a bit too big for me in the large -- I have narrow shoulders and a smallish bust -- but I can make this work with layers, and that's probably best for my climate anyway. Not a great fit for me, but the versatility & price of this jacket could not be matched, so I kept it.Basically, a great rain-proof and wind-proof jacket if you like a slim fit and are big busted.

This Belkin sleeve is super ... for the 1st generation Surface. Wayback when, there were no sleeves specifically made for the dimensions of the Surface, and one just had to make do with sleeves which were a bit too wide or too long. This sleeve is neither, and it fits the Surface with a type cover just perfectly. Unfortunately, this sleeve does not fit the Surface with a padfolio. If the neoprene was just a wee bit more forgiving, it just might fit a Surface with padfolio. In that case, it would be a 5* product. Not being able to add a padfolio makes it 4*.However, the sleeve is very snug for the Surface 3 Pro, so much so that I don't consider it usable. The dimensions are different between generations.

I love V-8, I love greens, I love carrots, apples & pineapple too. I should love V-8 Healthy Greens, right? Wrong.Once you get past the color, which is a brownish green, you need to prepare yourself for the taste. I don't taste greens. Instead, I taste apple & pineapples. One quick check of the ingredients reveals apples & pineapples, as well as carrots. These fruits, coupled with the carrot, contribute to relatively high sugar content (11g per serving).If the only way you can get your greens is by drinking them in apple-pineapple juice, then this product is for YOU! I suspect that most people interested in this product are like me: I wanted V-8 Healthy Greens to be a Green juice, perhaps a V-8 with greens. It's not. As such, this product is most certainly NOT for me or for those like me!

I own a pair of these best-selling earrings: 14k Yellow & White Crossover Hoops. The 14k earrings are fabulous but run about $250 here at Amazon.This pair of 18k gold-plated earrings is a terrific substitute at an amazing price. The pair come in a lovely presentation box, and they have a "bird cage" look on my ear. I love them and am happy to have them.They look like much more than the price here. At the current price (about 1/2 of stated retail), it would be hard to match the quality & price locally.Go ahead. Get them.
Malfunctioned out of the package. Was worth a shot but this thing is going back. It's perpetually "on" with all lights alit. I hold it out and it locates air! Does a great job of that too.
Was worth a shot but this thing is going back. It's perpetually "on" with all lights alit. I hold it out and it locates air! Does a great job of that too.

Very cute french terry casual jacket that's unlined and washable. The details on this jacket are very nice. The sleeves can be rolled up, and there's a tab with snap for this.The fit is large for this brand & on me. The large seemed to be sized as a 14-16. It was especially large through the bust. I would have kept it if sizing wasn't a problem.

This is a very nice, fitted hoodie from Columbia. The princess details and slim fit are feminine, and it's definitely not a boxy fit that's sometime more typical. I find the sizing to be consistent with other items from this brand, which for me means that a medium fits well on top but tight on bottom (I'm a pear-shaped 10 top, 12 bottom). I'd swim in a large but free returns meant this item was worth taking a chance in a medium. I returned it.There are two things which I do not like about this hoodie & are the reasons for the 3* rating. (1) The fleece is not a traditional polartec fleece but instead a more plush, loungewear-like fleece. For me personally, this would be fine as activewear or loungewear but not something I'd go to the store in or run errands in because it feels like pajamas to the touch. (2) The seams on the inside of the garment are not taped or finished off. I found this irritating and I would not have kept the hoodie even if it did fit.Overall, worth a try ... especially at this price.

Yes, it's pricey, even on sale, BUT this is a gorgeous necklace with a lot of natural turquoise! The colors are slightly brighter in person than shown. It's a comfortable necklace that will be stunning in winter with a black, wine or chocolate turtleneck, in spring or summer with a crisp, white shirt, would compliment a leather or leather look jacket and is a casual piece with all season potential. I like the length. The plus (for me) is it's made in the U.S. using recycled sterling silver plus all U.S. mined gemstones and offers a lifetime guarantee. There are so many shades of turquoise, it will be easy to match earrings or a cuff bracelet with the necklace. If you love Southwestern style, this is a good buy.

My clothing style is "classic", because well made garments can (with care) last me several years. I also like to be able to have clothes that can be casual or dressed up with accessories as needed. That said, this is an excellent choice for my wardrobe. I bought it in navy, plum, gray and tan. Depending on the style/cut or manufacturer, I can wear anything from a size XL to 2X. This sweater is 100% cotton; in the past I've found all cotton sweaters often shrink a bit when machine washed and dried... even using a cold wash cycle and low heat setting on the dryer. Therefore, I bought 2X and am glad I did. Out of the bag, they fit a little loose, which is perfect for layering. No measurements are given on the product page. The bust of the 2X measures 50", the hip 52", shoulder to hem is 28", and sleeve length is 24". Cable knit means the sweater drapes nicely (not boxy), but also doesn't cling. They're very well made. On me--and I'm short--the neckline doesn't come as low as pictured. No cleavage shows. Against my skin, the sweater is super soft and comfortable. I can wear them with jeans and sterling silver jewelry, or slacks and pearls. Please note it isn't a heavy weight sweater, but in my coastal CA area, it will be ideal for 3 season wear.UPDATE: After machine washing in cold water and drying on delicate/low heat, the measurements for the size 2X are: bust 45", hip 42", shoulder to hem 25", and sleeve length 22". I'm very glad to have ordered the 2X, as the shrinkage was what I'd expected and a smaller size would then have been too tight.

With the holidays fast approaching, I absolutely LOVE these non-stick baking pans! Yes, I could go to Dollar Tree for cheaper aluminum pans (and have in the past), but they aren't anywhere near as hefty as these pans, and the non-stick feature is fantastic for many sweet treats. You won't need to grease or line them with parchment paper to make gift-able fudge. Using one prepackaged cake mix and one tub of frosting, you can split the batter up for two single layer cakes to give to neighbors, co-workers, delivery drivers or friends who are single. Us them to bring stuffing or sweet potatoes to holiday potluck gatherings. Substitute these in place of loaf pans to gift banana, cranberry, pumpkin or zucchini bread. What about Rice Krispy treats? With care, they can be washed and reused. I'll definitely be purchasing a small stash for the pantry.

If you want an inexpensive little splurge, this rhodium plated sterling silver black & white CZ ring could be a good choice, especially if you're thinking of pairing it with another ring (or more) on the same finger. Be aware, it's tiny; the height and depth is just a hair over 2mm and each stone is not much bigger than pencil point size, but it's solidly made. Rhodium plating means the ring shouldn't tarnish. I paired it with a platinum plated CZ ring I own, and the look is nice. Understated. You could buy 2 and wear them as guard rings for a single stone or 3 stone ring. Bottom line? This ring is a good quality, nicer looking fashion jewelry piece. To protect the rhodium plating, I suggest taking it off to wash your hands, shower, do dishes, etc. It will arrive in a very nice box that's suitable for gift giving.

My oldest son (28) is starting a new job that requires a suit every day, so when I saw this as a lightening deal in the size he normally wears, I ordered it. The suit arrived quickly and in good shape on a suit hangar under plastic. Fit varies, of course, from one man to another. He's short with an average build, and this suit had an odd fit. The jacket shoulders extended well beyond his natural shoulders, the sleeves were 1/2 inch too long, but the waist fit fine. The pants, however, were tight in his waist and pant legs were baggy. The pants arrive unfinished, so hemming is required. A good six inches would have had to have been cut from these for my son, who usually buys 32/28. The QUALITY of the suit, overall, seems to be good, but I'm returning this to Amazon as a tailor told us today the jacket can't be altered to fit him better due to its construction. I've ordered another suit from Amazon in a different brand and am crossing fingers & toes for a better fit.

Having loved "Plum Tree" by Ellen Marie Wiseman, I was happy to receive a (free) advanced uncorrected proof of her new novel, "Coal River" to review. This book does have heavy subject matter, being about life at Coal Mines in the early 1900s; Wiseman did an excellent job with it, although serious history buffs might balk at some creative changes in the actual time line to better fit the story line.Emma Malloy is 19 when she arrives back in Coal River, Pennsylvania as the lesser of two bad options available to her. The townspeople consider her cursed and view her as an omen of bad luck. Years earlier, when she was staying at her aunt and uncle's home with her younger brother, a tragic accident happened. Her brother fell through the ice and drowned. Now she's been orphaned following her parents' demise in a fire. On the day she arrives, the train she's been travelling on also brings a number of immigrants looking for work at the coal mine. This upsets families who have been working the mines for generations.Emma's Uncle Otis is a supervisor at the mine; he and her Aunt Ida make it clear that while they're willing to take her in, they intend for her to work both at home and in the mine company's general store with her cousin, Percy, to earn her keep. All of her earnings will go to them. Emma doesn't have any means to escape her circumstances. She's horrified by the conditions the miners and their families must endure. The mine owner, Mr. Flint, is clearly written as the villain in this story, but many of the townspeople are also cast in a dark light. The miners live in a small, run down community partially up the mountain... away from town. When she recognizes their struggles, particularly the fact that so many young boys are also working at the mine under dangerous conditions, Emma does her best to help them in ways which aren't strictly legal. In doing so, she befriends Clayton Nash, a leader in the mining community who hopes to establish a union of the mine workers.I don't want to give away too much of the story. It's steadily paced and I was able to read the novel in one day. Most of the characters are well developed and the plot is interesting. My only disappointment--no spoilers--is how the story ends. In this reader's opinion, the twist is almost along the lines of a fairy tale. For that reason, I'm rating the book 4 stars. Your impression might vary. I do look forward to other novels by this author.

My sons (who are both in their 20s) love all things Star Wars and enjoy games, so when I had the opportunity to receive Star Wars:The Force Awakens X-Wing Miniatures game from Amazon and Fantasy Flight Publishing for review, I knew they'd be able to provide information for other fans. Here's what they had to say:"Having played the tutorial game it seems to be a solid, relatively easy to learn game. I had trouble following the order that the tutorial  in the Learn to Play booklet was laid out in, especially as we were playing the first two rounds while looking at the Learn to Play booklet. Beyond that, it is a much easier game to pick up than Armada: Whereas it took me several games of Armada to get a full grasp on the rules, it only took two turns for my brother and I to get to the same level of understanding with X-Wing.The materials in the game are top-quality. The tokens are perfectly aligned and well punched. The tokens and cards are well laminated and feature great, unique artwork. The ships are high quality miniatures with excellent paint jobs; it's hard not to swoosh them around before and after a game.The game itself is well balanced in a game-design perspective. You can make complex maneuvers, but are then disabled from using any special actions like Focusing and Evading, and have to do simple maneuvers to be able to take those actions again. The X-Wing is bulkier and has heavy firepower while the TIE Fighters are light, nimble, and evasive. The game is definitely skill-based: it requires you to know what your ships can and can't do and to plan ahead.Overall, it is a fun game that is easy to pick up and play. I wish the tutorial was laid out a little better in the Learn to Play booklet, but going through the booklet before playing will help with this."--A well-balanced, fun game--Helps you feel like a fighter pilot in the Star Wars Universe--Rules are easy to understand once you learn them--Variety of play styles--Challenging, as it makes you and your opponent secretly decide on your moves simultaneously and execute them simultaneously. This forces you to predict your opponent's move as you plan your own.--Game pieces are well-made and durable, but there are LOTS of pieces, including many small pieces that might be choking hazards for small children or might be lost or forgotten when putting the game away--Two rule books: a "How To Play" (that is confusing and hard to follow) and a "Rules Reference" (that contains more advanced and detailed rules for experienced players). This, combined with the number of pieces, is very intimidating for new players--Base set only comes with three miniatures, which is great for just learning the game but also means that you have to buy extra miniatures and expansion sets to play more advanced matches. If you want to turn this into a regular hobby, expect a huge hit to the wallet.In summary, it's probably not a game for young children and you will need to plan on purchasing extra miniatures... potentially a lot of them... to enjoy it fully. This could, of course, mean you have an endless list for gifts to expand the game for a fan, which isn't a bad thing. Just keep in mind it could prove expensive overall. If that's not a problem, it's a great starter gift!

Since my early 40s, I've had mild rosacea and increasingly sensitive skin. Anti-aging products often burn or I get a rash. Anything too moisturizing (anything with added oils) causes break outs, and nothing looks worse than wrinkles and pimples on the same face. I switched to Clinique brand a few years ago, trying their CC cream, BB cream and foundations (several varieties), but they felt like a mask on my face and at the end of a day, I couldn't wait to wash them off. Also, they did nothing for the mild rosacea. Based on reviews, I tried the Lumene Time Freeze CC Cream... first in light as I'm pale, then in medium (a better match for me)... and I can honestly say no product or brand has been better for my skin's appearance. This CC cream acts as a light foundation for me, with just enough moisturizing on its own that I can skip that step in the morning. My skin doesn't look or feel "made up", has a subtle glow, and fine lines are less noticeable. Women of a certain age will understand most foundations and concealers collect in the fine lines around eyes to actually draw attention to them. Not so this CC cream, which also allows me to skip concealer. I can also skip an eye shadow primer, as this is gentle enough to use on my lids and makes a nice base. Plus, my dark circles have faded a shade or two. What's been even more of a benefit is over time my mild rosacea has cleared up enough that my skin looks evenly toned and healthy when I'm NOT wearing makeup! At 53, I know nothing will erase my wrinkles completely, but Lumene Time Freeze CC Cream has helped bring a few compliments of my "lovely skin", which is something I never expected to hear at this stage of life. It's a product I really don't want to be without.

We don't drink a lot of soda in our house anymore, preferring water, coffee or tea, but sometimes we'll buy diet soft drinks. My experience with Stevia sweeteners is that they're sweeter tasting than sugar, so I was surprised that this Black Cherry soda tastes more like unsweetened, natural cherry juice with carbonation. It's not a bad taste at all. Cherry lovers will like it. My husband (a diabetic) thought it was okay, and our sons also thought it was alright. I like that it's not got any food coloring (the soda is clear) or saccharine in it. The reason I'm giving three stars instead of four is the cost; Zevia is more expensive than other, comparable brands of "natural" sodas like Hansen's (which is sweetened with Splenda). I'm also waiting for longer term studies of Stevia as a sweetener. Many think of it as a natural, less "processed" sugar substitute, but it starts out green leaves and becomes white granules, so... ?? As for the soda itself, I might buy it if on sale. Please remember tastes vary. You could love it enough to buy a six pack on a weekly basis.

We love the Brookside Dark Chocolate fruit candies, so I was happy to give these fruit & nut bars a try. They taste much like the candy, but (of course) with nuts, seeds, more substantial dried fruits and grains added. They're chewy like a soft granola bar, but crunchy, too, because of the plentiful fiber. My husband is diabetic, so I always read labels to keep check on total carbohydrates *and* how many of the carbs are sugar. These bars are just on the edge for him to have a snack while hiking; protein in the nuts and seeds helps to slow sugar metabolizing/blood sugar spikes. The bars really are a yummy treat, but I suppose that's to be expected from Hershey company. This is something we'll probably buy on sale.

I'm a BIG fan of Maggie Smith, will watch any move she's in and (especially) love her as the Dowager Countess in Downton Abbey, so I was thrilled to be able to get a pre-publication copy of this biography by Michael Coveney to review. In fact, I was anxious to start reading as soon as it arrived. I'd expected it to be a biography about her life. Meaning a book that might shine a light on the woman, Maggie Smith. I'd hoped to read more about her. This isn't that kind of biography. Think of it instead as an encyclopedia of her acting career or a textbook about the history of theater and acting with Maggie Smith as the focus. There's precious little information here of any personal nature.Coveney begins by discussing her acting style, what might make it so, and comparisons to other female actors from England in her general age group... as well as how they differ. The first chapters deal with her childhood and specifically what he feels laid the foundation for her unique style of acting. The focus quickly becomes about where she went to school, what influences in theater were the initial building blocks, and details about every performance she's ever given... including who was there, where it was, what it was and anything ever said or written about the performance. The author goes on, then, into her professional career and its details border the minutia. From plays, to theaters, to other actors in the plays (and how they did or related to her role), written reviews about her performances and on and on. There are very occasional paragraphs about her relationship with her first husband both before and after they were married, as well as the births of her sons, but those are shared mainly in how they connected to her career. As in, what she was doing onstage at the time, or what projects were in the works, how she and her first husband did performing together in the same venue (and how others described/reviewed those performances), where they were, who the other actors were, etc.The remainder of the "biography" continues in the same vein. I wound up skimming a few chapters to get to her later roles, and again, learned next to nothing about Maggie Smith's personal life off-stage. If you're a serious theater lover who enjoys in-depth, comprehensive studies--or you're an actor looking into the career history of an icon--this might be an enjoyable book. However if you're a mainstream reader who's a fan of Maggie Smith, hoping to find an entertaining biography that includes her actual personal life, Michael Coveney's book may be disappointing. Hopefully, there'll be another biography one day aimed at average fans.

Every year our area holds an Annual Bird Festival in January; we're listed as a national estuary. For the past 5 years, my husband has led groups of bird enthusiasts on bird walks for the local Audubon chapter throughout the year and during the festival. He carefully looked over "Birding for the Curious" and feels that if you've already decided to take up birding, it's a great book. There's a lot of information in this book and much good advice about how to get started. Each chapter offers an activity to get you started, and the chapters include:Why Birds? (a little over a page plus activity)Your Field Guide to Field Guides (with short blurbs about 5 recommended field guides)Binocularia (finding a good pair of binoculars or other lenses)How to ID What You SeeBirding Is Better With FriendsBringing the Birds Home (attracting birds to your yard)Birding as Giving: Citizen Science (how to provide valuable data to Audubon, for example)Field Craft: Tips for Finding Birds in the FieldThe Birder's YearWhy Birds? A ReduxGoing Beyond Your Back YardThe book is easy to read. Chapters are short, informational, and nicely illustrated in watercolors. I'm not going to go into the information here, because the chapters are short enough I feel I'd be giving too much away. Suggested activities will help the reader get started birding and become more confident. Overall "Birding for the Curious" would make a great gift for someone who is looking at taking up birding as a hobby.

My older son does videography, has a laptop, smart phone and tablet, as well as a camcorder, so I asked him to test the SanDisk Ultra 32GB Ultra Micro SDHC adapter and memory card. He was able to move video files quickly and without any problems. Video quality seemed preserved well from one device to another. The adapter worked just fine. The biggest drawback in his mind was this doesn't come with a case to protect the components, and while that's common, there are some SD cards that are packed within a tiny plastic case for protection.

At super low prices on Amazon's End of Season sale, I purchased this pendant in blue topaz, amethyst, citrine and peridot, with the garnet coming. I'd already ordered each of the colors in the matching earrings to put away in my gift stash for friends and family (see my other reviews); the pendants make very pretty sets with the earrings. Each pendant measures 3/4 inch long from the top of the bale by just over 1/2 inch wide, and they're nice. I will say the chain is far too thin and delicate to be useful for most gals. It should be replaced with a better chain, a thin leather or satin cord, or even a ribbon cord if you plan to get a lot of wear. The bale opening is about 4mm, so be sure a clasp isn't larger than that when replacing the chain. Being rhodium plated means the bright, white silver shouldn't tarnish. Each pendant appears to be well made. Here's a breakdown of each, color by color:Blue Topaz -- a clear, crisp, icy blue as shown on the product page, it matches the earrings for colorAmethyst -- fully saturated, it isn't pale, but is also not dark; it's more of a grape jelly tone and also matches the earringsPeridot -- the center stone is light and clear, not cloudy as the earrings were, but it's very paleCitrine -- a bit darker than the earrings, it's still a pale yellow stone that's more of a cool tone than one normally sees in citrineGarnet -- will edit to add the information when the pendant arrives, but if it's at all like the earrings, will be the most striking of the colorsEach pendant comes in a gift box, but in a plastic bag tucked into the gift box, so you'll want to remove it from the plastic bag and arrange it before giving as a gift. Again, I recommend replacing the chain. At the deeply discounted sale price, they're worth picking up. It's a nice, inexpensive piece for everyday wear... simple and understated... appropriate for nurses, school teachers, chefs, office workers, teens, moms, grandmas, etc.

First and foremost--all due respect to other reviewers--these gemstone earrings don't look like cheap, costume jewelry. Rhodium plating means the bright, white metal won't tarnish. To many women that's a plus. A lot of gals also like lever back earrings, because you're not going to loose the backings as with studs or post styles. That said, I shop year round for holiday and birthday gifts in order to get the best prices. When I saw these at a very low price, I first ordered the blue topaz for myself, and then placed an order for each of the other colors to use as gifts. Here's a breakdown color by color:Blue topaz - the topaz stones are a very light, ice blue and are clear with no visible inclusionsAmethyst - the pair I received are clear, clean, and a much darker purple than pictured on Amazon's product page, more like the product page picture of the matching necklaceGarnet - a deep, rich, clear, almost Zinfandel red, these are probably the most impressive of all the gemstone options and will be perfect for holiday outfitsPeridot - these stones were a little disappointing in that they were pale and cloudyCitrine - although so pale they're almost clear, there are no inclusions in the earrings I receivedThe created white sapphire stones are bright and clear; they're small enough to give a diamond look without the diamond price. Each pair of earrings appears to be well made. Durable. Amazon's packaging makes them ideal for gift giving, whether as stocking stuffers or a small gift with a lot of bang for the buck. I'd recommend the blue topaz, amethyst and garnet versions. You might receive a better peridot pair than I did, and your citrine pair might have more depth of color without losing any clarity, but I can't personally recommend those. It's a matter of taste. The earrings aren't large, but they *are* noticeable. They measure just over 1/2 inch in length (not including wires) by just under 1/2 inch in width. She could wear these to work. I can report they're not heavy weight. They're comfortable. I'm hoping this helps shoppers make an informed choice.

When I had the opportunity to read and review a pre-publication copy of Beatriz Williams' "Along the Infinite Sea", I knew it would be best to read the first two books in the Schuyler Sisters trilogy beforehand, so I did. For readers not aware, the series begins with "The Secret Life of Violet Grant" (involving Vivian Schuyler), which is followed by "Tiny Little Thing" (Christina Schuyler Hardcastle). We get to know more about Pepper Schuyler in "Along the Infinite Sea", which I feel is the best book of the three. More on that in a minute.It's the autumn of 1966, and Pepper Schuyler is in Florida to sell a completely restored, rare 1936 Special Roadster Mercedes to a mystery buyer willing to pay $300,000 for it. Pepper needs the money to carve a new life for herself and the baby she's carrying... the unwanted baby of a married Senator she had an affair with. In fact, Pepper is on the run from him and his powerful family. What she doesn't yet know is the buyer, Annabelle Dommerick, is intimately acquainted with the gleaming black car. And she has secrets of her own. Deep, powerful secrets. Uncovering them will change each woman's life.I was unaware that this series is written--at least in part--with a first person narrative and regular shifts in time from the 1930s in Europe to the 1960s in America. This style of writing has become a bit tedious for me, as far too many books are currently written in that style. However, Beatriz Williams is among the handful or so of authors with the ability to pull it off well. Each of the characters in "Along the Infinite Sea" is exceptionally well developed, and the shifts from one time period to another are very neatly done. In other words, it isn't a chore for the reader to get through this novel. Only Annabelle's portions are told in first person narrative, which is also refreshing; her story in particular kept me turning pages. While I felt no well-bred, old family money, upper class woman in the 1960s would have been as flippant or (at times) outrageous as Pepper, I did like her character. I liked the way the two women interacted. I was also intrigued by the mystery involved in the novel. Readers will also laugh out loud in some sections. Especially those involving Pepper and Annabelle's son, Florian.There are far fewer explicit sex scenes or sexual references in "Along the Infinite Sea" than in the first book of the series, which was a relief to this reader. There were also far fewer f-bombs or other coarse dialog. That's an important note to some readers. The story line is far more intriguing and interesting than in the second book of the series, with far less politics... also an important note to some readers. Overall, Williams' final installment is my hands down favorite, and I think it could be enjoyed as a stand alone novel for those who have not yet read the first two books.

This review is based on a pre-publication copy of "The Last Summer at Chelsea Beach" by Pam Jenoff. Your impressions may well be different than mine. That said, "The Last Summer at Chelsea Beach" follows a current fad of novels written in first person narrative with regular time shifts. Of the nearly dozen books I've read in the past 3-4 months, nearly all have been written in this style, and as a reader, I've come to the conclusion it takes a great deal of skill both in writing and editing to make it work. I won't fault the author for problems with those shifts in time throughout this novel. Several editors go over the final manuscript before the book is released and problems should be caught there.We're introduced to Adelia Monteforte in the prologue as she's driving to a beach house on the shore with a great deal of trepidation. It's a place from her past, and she's nervous about returning to it. Chapter one shifts to eleven months earlier in Washington D.C. when Adelia runs into a former love interest, Charlie Connally. She's working for The Washington Post. It's an awkward and uncomfortable surprise to see Charlie. There's a troubled history between them which is yet to be revealed. But Chapter two shifts to two years earlier, when Adelia arrives on a boat from Italy shortly before her 17th birthday. An only child, her mother unexpectedly put her on the ship to get her out of facist Italy and into the safety of her Aunt Bess and Uncle Meyer's home in America. Almost immediately after she arrives, Aunt Bess takes Adelia to an apartment on the shore for a quiet summer.There she meets the Connally family, a boisterous group with four sons. Charlie is the oldest. Adelia is immediately attracted to him. There are also the twins, Jack, a gentle, bookish adolescent, and Liam, who is prickly. Finally, there's young Robbie. The next several chapters generally relate to this time period, but there are awkward shifts within chapters (or even pages) when Adelia is reminiscing about earlier events. The big questions I had (as a reader) were why her aunt and uncle--among other characters--weren't more fully developed, and why Adelia didn't think about home (Italy) very much... not just her parents and grandmother, but school friends, teachers, neighbors? Normal childhood memories. It's as if none of it ever existed. Instead she's absorbed into the Connally family,and much of the focus is on her infatuation with Charlie, who seems not to notice her. At least initially.No spoilers here, but by Chapter ten, the novel has backtracked a bit before placing Adelia in England during World War II. She's working as an assistant to a high level journalist in war torn London. There are shifts back in time to her brief romance with Charlie, the tragedy that strikes the Connally family, her impulsive move to Washington D.C., and the circumstances leading to her abrupt job change. In London, she befriends Claire Churchill, the PM's niece. At this point the novel is steadily paced, but as a reader I just don't like Adelia. When Charlie comes back on the scene a key element is that they were childhood friends and grew up together in the U.S., but Adelia was nearly 17 when she arrived, met Charlie and became involved with the Connallys. She grew up in Italy. Any good editor should have caught that.If it all sounds confusing, it's because I found it a very confusing read. This will not be a popular rating, I'm sure, but I've got to give the novel 2.5 stars. I'm rounding up instead of down, because the concept was good, and the author clearly did her research. There were just too many problems for me. Of course, top selling authors highly rated "The Last Summer at Chelsea Beach", so you might find it brilliant.

It's often difficult to shop for clothing online if you haven't purchased the brand before. Since I've never tried on anything from Knits by Hampshire, I wasn't sure what size to order when taking advantage of the sale price with additional percent off on Amazon. I can range anywhere from a size XL to a 2X, depending on the brand. Therefore, I purchased this sweater in both colors in 1X and 2X... the 1X is a good fit without being too snug in the bust, back, waist or hips. It's a relaxed fit. The stripes aren't unflattering as many of us plus sized gals fear. I like the nautical look of them. Using the zoom feature on the product page, you can see there are two "stripes" of open knit; one across the upper chest, and one near the hem. I will say the yarn used isn't top quality, but for the price I didn't expect it to be. The sweater is casual for weekend wear, around the house or running errands, and will be ideal with jeans or white pants. I recommend machine washing on the gentle cycle in cold water and laying flat to dry.

These rings will vary from one to another, yet my new sparkler doesn't look cheap at all. No, it isn't "little blue box" boutique caliber--although it does come in a lovely blue box--and it's done in .925 sterling silver of substantial weight vs. 14k white gold or platinum, but the design is lovely. While the tiny round white diamonds appear cloudy under a loupe, they still twinkle. The baquette diamonds are surprisingly clear. The workmanship also surprised me in its quality. The face of the ring measures 3/4 inch from top to bottom, and 5/8 inch from side to side. The shoulders (which also have prong set rounds and channel set baguettes) taper from 3/8 inch wide to about 3 millimeters at the shank. Its under gallery is fully finished to be sturdy, smooth and comfortable to wear against your skin. Fit is true to size.My size 7 order was priced at 90% off list. Very honestly, there's enough silver to make the metal alone a great deal, not to mention the diamonds, careful workmanship and bold, vintage, elegant design. A few department stores have similarly styled diamond rings in 10K white gold selling for $800-900 or more "on sale"; the grade of diamonds in those rings compares to the diamonds in this ring. I'll probably get it rhodium plated to help prevent tarnishing.I think this would make a fantastic gift for a BFF to show off during girls' night out, but think also grandmothers, sisters, or simply as a treat for yourself! No one will guess you paid so little for such a pretty, glittering bauble.

When this AA Quality Akoya Pearl Necklace was offered on a Gold Box flash sale, I decided to take a chance and (impulsively) order it. My experience with ordering Akoya Pearls online has been mixed. I wasn't expecting much and even thought it might wind up returned. It's important to state I'm something of a pearl snob, having taken the GIA pearl course as well as studying about pearls for more than a decade. This necklace doesn't come with a certificate of authenticity or an appraisal, so if you're new to pearls or pearl buying, you might not understand its value. I'm thrilled with my purchase!Each smooth, very round, lustrous pearl measures at or near 8 mm; they are well matched for color showing pink and blue overtones with a subtle orient that's considered highest quality or "Hanadama". Nacre thickness is substantial. That's rare among almost perfectly round and smooth Akoyas, which increases the value. For those who aren't aware, and Akoya mollusk can only produce one pearl at a time, laying nacre down slowly and evenly in cold salt water environments. Freshwater mollusks can produce 40 or more pearls at a time, and in warm fresh water, the layers of nacre are formed much faster. The structure of the nacre in Akoyas makes them more lustrous (overall) than freshwater pearls. Top quality Akoya pearl necklaces in sizes over 6.5-7mm per pearl can run $1000 easily for princess length (16-18 inch). They are the gold standard for pearls. This is such a necklace. We're going to have it formally appraised by a jeweler who specializes in pearls, but I'd estimate its value in the $1800-$2000 range.Under a loupe, there are very minimal, tiny imperfection on less than a handful of the pearls which aren't noticeable to the naked eye. At the drill holes, there's NO evidence of bleaching or dying--techniques acceptable in the pearl industry. Again, nacre thickness is substantial. The pearls are evenly drilled and the make of the necklace is exquisite. I ordered earrings at the same time which are a near perfect match: http://www.amazon.com/Akoya-Cultured-Quality-Earrings-8-8-5mm/dp/B00SH2H8CG/ref=cm_cr-mr-title (see my other reviews).This is the finest Akoya necklace I (now) own! It's absolutely heirloom quality and will be my 54th Birthday gift. I highly recommend buying it for a wedding, anniversary or special event to be enjoyed and handed down throughout generations. Buying fine jewelry online can be risky and/or disappointing. This buy was amazing! I'd rate it 10 stars!

For readers who loved "The Language of Flowers" by Vanessa Diffenbaugh... readers who have been anxiously awaiting another novel from the author... you might want to skip my review of "We Never Asked For Wings". I received an advanced reader's (paperback) edition, and really wanted to love this book. While I won't say I hate it, there are a few too many problems (for me) with this novel about a struggling, single mom and daughter of illegal immigrants from Mexico. If I had to nutshell, I'd say it's both believable and completely unbelievable. There are clear stereotypes with a twist. The story is, at times, all over the map. Pun intended.Readers meet Letty Espinosa as she's racing in her car to catch up with her mother before she crosses the Mexican border to bring her back to take care of teenage Alex and six year old Luna. Children left alone in a run down apartment in a partially abandoned building. Children who don't yet know they've been left to fend for themselves by their half-drunk, panicked mother who's unable to be the kind of mother they need. Letty was a teenager when Alex was born and his father never knew about him; Letty's mom has been raising him since he was an infant. Luna has a different father (of course) and Letty doesn't even seem to be sure who he is. Now Letty's parents believe it's time for her to learn to be a mother to her own children. Maria Elena and Enrique are homesick for their family home in Mexico: they were in the US illegally since before Letty was born. The characters are developed, but seem almost two dimensional... with the exception of Alex. I loved his character.This is where the author started to lose me as too many things didn't add up. Or were simply impossible. I don't want to give too much away, but why weren't there steep medical bills after Letty's accident? The car is totaled and abandoned. No insurance? She's introduced as working three jobs, vanishes for a few weeks, comes back and then seems to be working one job on a night shift. Suddenly she's bringing her daughter to work on the day shift? Cutting her pay/tips, but there's never mention of rent, utilities, etc. (she has little money for food), and yet she can send money to her parents in Mexico? How? Simultaneously, she's saving her tips to move into a better apartment in a better school district. It just doesn't add up. And I'm sorry, but you can't rent a pet carrier in San Francisco's Mission district for "a couple hundred" a month.Throughout all of this, a wealthy doctor (father of one child) comes onto the scene, Alex gets involved with a girl, goes to a new school, then gets excited about a science project, plus the reader learns gobs of information about migrating birds/bird feathers, various mixed drinks and immigration law. Do you see what I mean? The story spins all over the place. Then there are the miraculous resolutions to money problems. I was glad, at least, that other problems weren't so neatly resolved, because life doesn't work that way. However, I really did like some of the characters, including Alex's crush, Yesenia and Letty's love interest, Rick. The writing itself is generally good.I'd rate "We Never Asked For Wings" a solid 3 to 3-1/2 stars overall. It's not a bad read. Parts are very enjoyable. You may absolutely love it. I sincerely hope you do!

This is a very basic tablecloth in a year-round neutral color. The fabric is somewhat thin, but washes up well, needs no ironing (if removed promptly from the dryer) and coordinates with just about any dinnerware or serve ware. We use a tablecloth every day. Our table is on its 3rd generation of use and it shows. Some recent purchases from department and discount stores have netted poor quality fabrics that have started to fall apart after a few washings, so I'm happy this seems to be better quality at a similar price point. It's good, not great, but I like it and will use it. I have quilted placemats to co-ordinate with more colorful patterns.I received a free tablecloth in exchange for an honest review. Your mileage may vary, and I'll update if this doesn't hold up to regular use.

Not sure this razor is worth the (steep) price. There are three men in our household--my husband and two adult sons--and each has either a mustache or chin only beard and mustache, so I asked them to test this Norelco system. Each uses an electric razor; two also use an electric beard trimmer. My oldest son set up the S7720/90 7700 shaver and had this to say:--Opening the box wasn't that hard, but the packaging wasn't intuitive and I had to hunt for some things.--The cleaner-charger dock (called the SmartClean system) is fairly intuitive to use, but it is sometimes hard to get the razor plugged into the thing.The razor itself, once charged, is easy to use and feels comfortable on my skin.--However, the razor does not dry-shave well. I had to go over the same spots over and over again. It got all the thick hairs but left behind all the thin ones; it just would not cut some areas on my face, such as the sides of my chin or low on my neck. Eventually, I gave up and switched to my normal razor.--When cleaning, the SmartClean system is a bit on the noisy side. The SmartClean actually got the razor really clean, I'm impressed. However, it did leave the blades wet and soapy, so I had to take them out, rinse them and dry them.My husband was next up, and he felt the S7720/90 7700 razor did no better job than his older (and cheaper) Norelco. My youngest son conferred, and said he prefers the Norelco Go Styler FS9185/42 G as a trimmer/shaper. No one in my household likes the idea of a cumbersome cleaning cup and charger combo sitting on the bathroom counter, which seems to be necessary with this shaving set since the cleaning fluid is an added expense to replace every day (if dumped out after each use).

Having a less than ideal experience with a different pair of Akoya pearl stud earrings, I was happy to see the quality of this pair, which was more expensive and worth it. The pearls are top grade--sometimes referred to as Hanadama quality--and nearly perfect when viewed with a loupe. Each pearl is smooth, luminous, and displays prized orient. This is indicative of very thick nacre. Also, the mountings are secure. Earring backs are quite snug, so you might need to wear these earrings several times before you can get them on and off with ease; this also means the backs aren't likely to slip off while you're wearing them. Each pearl is white with strong pink and blue overtones, which is considered the most valuable color in Japanese Akoyas.I'd considered removing one star for rating because the box mine came in was actually a ring box instead of an earring box, and the pair doesn't come with any certificate of authenticity. I'm rating them five stars, though, because I've studied pearls (GIA) and know they're at least AA if not AAA in quality. Very happy with this purchase, and would highly recommend these earrings.

The necklace I ordered and received was 24 inches long with a white gold, ball clasp. Whether or not this Akoya strand is worth owning depends on the current Amazon price, if it's a gift vs. for your own enjoyment, and with an understanding that it will probably not be an heirloom piece to pass down over generations. I paid just under $80 for what was apparently the last one in that size in white gold. Having studied pearls in depth, I louped it right away under good light. Every pearl is off round (rather than round) has surface flaws and very thin nacre... so thin that on a handful of the pearls in the strand, the nacre has peeled away from the drill hole. Looking at the drill holes, the pearls have been dyed with a very pale pink tint. That's an acceptable practice, as is bleaching the pearls, but it lowers the grade. The thin nacre means with regular wear, over time, the pearls will flake and chip off of the bead nucleus. They are, however, well matched for color, and the "make" of the necklace is good. The pearls are firmly knotted on double silk thread with french wire at the clasp to protect the string from wearing and breaking.Why am I rating it 3 stars instead of 1? Because while I can't recommend it as a gift--and only if you can buy it at a low price--it should hold up to occasional wear for up to a decade. These are NOT AA quality Akoyas, but that grade for this size of pearls would run quite a chunk of change. Think $800 or more retail pricing. Particularly if they're Japanese Akoyas. This necklace almost certainly has Akoyas from China, where the pearls are harvested in as little as 6 months vs. up to 2 years; thus the very thin nacre. I have a few very fine Japanese Akoya pearl necklaces that I intend to hand down. This is one I'd wear out to dinner with my husband and not have to worry about getting a spot of salad dressing on it (which can ruin pearls).Edited to add: I ultimately decided to return this necklace, even though it was purchased at a very low price, because too many of the pearls had nacre peeling at the drill holes. My husband didn't feel it was a good buy at any price.

This is a beautiful set of towels, but I think more appropriate as hand towels in the bathroom than as kitchen towels. The design is lovely. The colors are rich and classic neutrals. The towels appear to be well constructed. They are, however, quite thin and not terribly absorbent. For some reason, they seem masculine to me, and so I'd think the set is suitable to tuck into a gift bag or basket with a bar of sandalwood soap as a housewarming gift for a guy... but you might come up with other ideas. Kitchen towels need to be thicker and more absorbent than these are.

Yes, you can buy French soaps for less at discount stores, but I've got to say this very large bar of shea enriched, wonderfully scented soap is a luxurious splurge for yourself or as a gift. When I opened the box, the fragrance perfumed the entire room! And what a lovely box it is! I'm thinking with such a powerful aroma it wouldn't be appropriate for those with sensitive skin, but you could tuck it into a linen closet or sweater drawer as a super long lasting sachet. When using it as intended, the lather is thick and wonderful... it feels a treat. Which is why I think this would be nice tucked into a gift bag or basket with a few pretty washcloths or hand towels as a birthday, hostess or "just because" gift. You could also gift it with a unique, large soap dish. But why not treat yourself? The size of this bar means it should last several months.

I agree with the 1st reviewer that this lightweight luggage set isn't worth the stated value of $400+. My in-laws asked me to shop for a college graduation gift for our son, and I was happy to see the set as a gold box deal for $145 on Amazon. The larger of the cases is 21 inches long by 17-1/4 inches wide and 11-1/4 inches deep; it's big enough to hold a week's worth of clothing and toiletries. The smaller case is ideal for carry on limits of most airlines. Construction of both is very good. They seem solid, well made, and offer the options of carrying from a top handle, a side handle, or with the pull-out, telescoping pull handle. It's a set that should last my son for years. Bear in mind that "lightweight" for the two is debatable... together they're at least 40 pounds.

I'm an experienced seamstress, and have owned (in the past) high end, computerized machines that did everything from embroidery and smocking to quilting and beyond. Those machines can rack up significant costs in maintenance and repair. What I need now is something small (for easy storage in a closet) and basic that can handle simple jobs like hemming and clothing alterations. We're all tough to fit sizes in my family; namely, we're short. A local dry cleaner does alterations, but those costs add up, too. We recently spent more than $60 to have two pairs of suit slacks hemmed and the jacket sleeves shortened for our oldest son. This Singer 1304 Start Basic Everyday Free Arm machine is a small, sturdy, no frills model that's ideal for my needs. It's easy to set up on a kitchen table, and it's very easy to use. If you're not planning to tackle huge jobs like sofa slipcovers, pinched pleated drapes or embroidered wedding gowns, this machine will do the trick... whether or not you have a lot of experience. I'd recommend it, in fact, for women *and* men who'd like to save money on clothing alterations or repairs.

My family put this cleaner to the test. It's a very effective, easy, safe product for all wood and plastic outdoor furniture, for painted surfaces and metal. It quickly cleans BBQ grills, too. It isn't limited, though, to outdoor cleaning projects. My sons' bathroom is a challenge to keep clean, in part because the tub and shower are old. We've tried everything from bleach cleaners to Lime Away, from "scrubbing bubbles" to Soft Scrub cleanser... using sponges and even brushes. I've spent plenty of money on mold & mildew cleaners, as well as mixing up my own non-chemical cleaners using citrus peels soaked in vinegar. We tried Scotts Outdoor Cleaner Plus OxiClean on the bathtub and shower in their bathroom, and I can state unequivocally that it is far superior to anything else we've ever used. Spray, let sit a few minutes and wipe off with a cleaning rag. It's that simple. Mildew, rust, lime and soap scum came right off. So while it's excellent for outdoor use, this is a terrific product for all of your tough cleaning jobs.

Who would have thought a novel based on the subject of cancer would have you smiling at page six and laughing periodically throughout its chapters? As other reviewers have stated, I laughed, I cried, and I wanted a doughnut. This is Fausto Brizzi's first novel. I hope he writes many more! '100 Days of Happiness' was a completely unexpected delight for me, and a novel that left me thinking for weeks before feeling ready to write a review. I'm going to hang onto my pre-publication copy and buy copies for friends and family, because while I don't agree with one part of the storyline (sorry, no spoilers), I think it's beneficial for each of us to consider what really matters most in this life. '100 Days of Happiness' gently forces the reader to do so... with humor.Lucio Battistini is somewhat disappointed in the way his life has turned out as we're introduced to him in the first chapters. Raised by his grandparents, once an Olympic hopeful, now married with two children and working at mediocre gym as a personal trainer and coach of a less-than-stellar water polo team, his life takes a downturn when his wife catches him in an affair. She throws him out. His father-in-law invites him to stay in a back room of his bakery, and it's while he's there that Lucio finds out he has liver cancer. That has metastasized. The doctors are very clear it's terminal. Lucio calculates he has roughly 100 days before the disease reaches its final stages, where pain medication will dull his ability to participate any further in what's left of his life. And so, he considers what he wants to accomplish in those 100 days. What's most important to him? What does he hope to leave behind? The author softens such sharp edged questions and issues from the very first page. Readers find themselves cheering Lucio on.The only reason I'm not rating this 5 stars is that although the book is exceptionally well written--again, Brizzi is an author to watch--the novel is written in the hottest publishing trend of first person narrative with periodic shifts in time. Thankfully, he does a good job of it. But so very many novels now are written that way it feels a bit tedious. Also, as stated, I didn't agree with the ending. Which is personal and subjective. Your mileage may vary. I would absolutely recommend the book either way. Love it or not, it'll get you to think. And that's often the mark of a good novel.

There have been many good reviews written about this Chill Bag chair, but I haven't seen anyone mention safety and care tips, so thought I'd add those. It's definitely an improvement over the 1970s/1980s bean bag chairs in that it's not filled with Styrofoam pellets. That said, it's both HUGE (which can be a plus) and filled with shredded foam. Meaning children under the age of 3  and young pets shouldn't be allowed to play on it unsupervised, because there's a risk of suffocation. It's a good idea to spray the chair lightly with Scotch Guard and let it air dry in an open, ventilated area. Microfiber cloth stains easily. The cloth is also slippery on hard surfaces--and even some carpets--so placing a trimmed square or circle of non slip carpet liner beneath it will help prevent accidents when someone plops down or dives onto it. A hand held vacuum or attachment can be used to remove pet hair or crumbs. Note that if you use a steam cleaner for spots, mildew can happen, because the foam bits will hold the moisture. A better idea would be to spot clean with a damp (not wet) cloth. Fluff it periodically. As with originally setting it up, fluffing will be a two person job. Did I mention it's HUGE? It measures in at about 5 ft. diameter. With care, though, it should last for years.

This white gold, blue and white diamond Halo ring is a lovely, well made addition to any woman's jewelry collection who appreciates a sturdy, feminine style. It is NOT a bold ring; if you're into serious bling, there are other (more expensive) higher carat weight options on Amazon. Measuring approximately 8 mm across the circle design, the blue and white diamonds combined have enough presence to be noticeable for everyday wear. Under a loupe, they're the clarity listed (I2-I3) for the white diamonds, which means they're somewhat cloudy, but still sparkle. The blue diamonds appear to be clearer viewed with a loupe (I1); they're well matched in color. There's a substantial amount of white gold in the shank, making the ring very sturdy. Being crafted of 10k gold means it's durable. I always take my rings off when I'm cooking, cleaning, washing dishes, etc., but if you don't, the stones are exceptionally well set and secure. Overall I think it's a great value and would recommend it provided you're fine with less than VS or S clarity. It's a pretty ring for the price. Amazon's packaging makes it ideal for gift giving... just add a bow.

While these sheets are very attractive--as well as properly sized for a deep mattress--they are microfiber. This means they're super soft, wrinkle resistant and won't require ironing, but it also means you shouldn't expect the durability of cotton. In my experience, microfiber sheets have an expected life span of about 2-3 years of regular use before they begin to thin and tear. That said, if you're looking for affordable guest bedroom sheets, this set is an affordable choice. If you're buying for a bed that's slept in every night, and you wash your sheets frequently, they won't last as long. Remember to NEVER use chlorine bleach on microfiber cloth, as it will seriously discolor them (turning either yellow or pink toned), and will speed the breaking down of fibers. Machine wash in cold or warm water with mild detergent and tumble dry on low for best results.

This Au Gratin dish is of high quality in a simple, classic design that will coordinate with many kinds of table settings. All specifications listed on the product page are correct. It's dishwasher safe and cleans up quickly whether washing by that method or by hand. No soaking required. The shape and design make it useful for many recipes, including meats and sides. You could even use it as a platter. It arrives very well packaged. My mom loves to entertain and is very happy with this baking dish... consider giving it as a gift!

Very easy to use, intuitive and worked like a charm, according to the men in my household. No problems whatsoever. They liked that it cut cleanly at their selected length (using the spacers) without tugging or pulling on facial hair. It cleans easily as well.

We have three cats with different needs. Our indoor cat (a rescue adoption) is old with a very sensitive system, and two outdoor cats (sisters that adopted us when their feral mom abandoned them in our yard) are younger and heartier. The indoor cat has had many digestive problems including throwing up and bloody diarrhea, so we buy him Purina One for sensitive systems. We buy basic Purina Cat Chow for the outdoor cats. I have to say I'm VERY happy with Purina Pro Plan's True Nature cat food. Not only do all three cats love it, but more important, our indoor cat hasn't had digestive problems in the few days he's been eating it. Time will tell, and I'll update my review if a problem arises. I'd happily spend a little more on cat food if one large bag can be bought to feed them all. I like, too, that there aren't any unpleasant fillers and the protein content is high. Purina is a brand I trust. True Nature appears to be a healthy option all of our cats approve of.

If you have fine hair that's straight or just a little wavy, and you don't wash and blow dry it every day, Revlon's Curl Collection Heated Styling Brush might be a very good option to achieve a smooth, face flattering look. Medium textured hair might do well, too. Please keep in mind there's a reason a heat protecting glove is included, especially if you're trying for more curl to your style! Unlike a traditional curling iron, the brush grips individual hairs, so if you turn it under (or over) and wrap it to curl, it might NOT want to let go, and you'll need that glove to untangle your hair from the very hot brush. OUCH! I'd think those with thick or curly hair would have even more issue with this. My hair is fine, and while the heated styling brush works well to simply brush through it slowly for smoothing with a slight turn under at the ends, I ripped out a few hairs trying to untangle it when I tried to make more of a wave or curl. My hair is currently shoulder length and blunt cut, so perhaps shorter or layered styles would be easier? It's also possible I'm just a klutz when it comes to hair styling. My usual routine is wash and air dry, or at the most a low heat blow dry with a round brush to smooth any frizz. I'll probably use this styling tool only occasionally on seriously bad hair days when I have limited time to get out-the-door... but I'll always have the glove on in case my hair gets tangled in it again.

Upfront, I need to say I've loved some of Delinsky's earlier novels (especially Three Wishes and Coast Road), so am a fan-of-sorts and was happy to receive a pre-publication copy of 'Blueprints' for review. My Dad was a general contractor; Delinsky obviously did research for her new novel. As a 50ish woman, I'm also happy to see a main character in my age bracket that isn't stereo-typed, and it's rare to find such a book. Particularly as a heroine in a romance. Those points are made, because I may be a bit biased.Caroline MacAfee and her daughter, Jamie, are part of a large, well established family construction company and have each been stars on a local television station's home remodel show, "Gut It". Jamie has great aspirations as an architect. She's engaged to a member of their company's legal team. Caroline... Caro to her friends... has found her job as host of the show a comfortable easing towards less physically demanding work in her chosen profession of construction. The novel opens with things seemingly going well for both women. Then Caroline's ex (Jamie's dad) presses his daughter for a private meeting. With his approval, the producer of "Gut It" has decided Caroline is too old to be the host of the show and plans to replace her with Jamie. The news is to be delivered the day before Caro's 56th birthday. Jamie doesn't want to replace her mother as host, and doesn't want anyone spoiling her birthday, so volunteers to be the bearer of the bad news while silently scrambling to find a way out. Predictably, the news is broken by someone other than Jamie. Her mom feels betrayed. Their relationship is strained.The next curve ball catapults both women into unknown territory and each must adjust to the changes more independently of each other than ever before. It's a true turning point in each of their lives. Both women will discover surprising strengths as well as new paths and new loves. They're also able to see each other beyond mother/daughter roles. 'Blueprints' is a book that kept me engaged as a reader, and overall I think it's a good book. I'd expect nothing less of the author.A few twists in the story knocked this down from 5 to 3.5 stars for me, but I'm rounding up. No spoilers here. Let's just say I'd have preferred the romances played out differently in the final 3rd or so of the book. Jamie's choices seemed too impulsive and not in character at all. Caroline's left me feeling a wee bit cheated. 'Blueprints' is still a good book but in my opinion, it's just not Delinsky's best.

Labradorite is a popular stone on our strip of coastline, as it's of the same stone family as moonstone and the blue flash it gives off when light hits is reminiscent of the ocean. Like all stones of this kind, no two are alike. Labradorite has a greenish-gray base color and some stones look more brownish-gray with varying tones from deep to light, but all good quality stones flash blue. I say all of this because the Relios Enhancer I received holds a very high quality stone with good color play that's perfectly suited to its mixed metal design. The brass really makes the stone pop in a substantial sterling silver setting. I'm most pleased that this enhancer is a size that's very noticeable without being gaudy, and like all Carolyn Pollack pieces is manufactured in the US using recycled materials. It's very well made and versatile. You can wear it on a leather cord or chain, clip it onto a beaded necklace or pearls, slide it onto an omega, and the stone goes with just about any wardrobe color. The nice thing about its mixed metal design is you can also wear it with yellow gold... you aren't limited to sterling silver. In fact, it even looks nice on a long stainless steel chain I own. If you're on the fence about it (and it's still at a sale price), I suggest you get it home and see. Relios jewelry comes with a limited lifetime warranty. Amazon has a great return policy, too, but I doubt you'll return it.

If you like coconut, this trail mix might be a good choice. Although it contains dried fruits, nuts and dark chocolate chips, it's mostly big flakes of coconut. My guys thought it was alright... sweet... as a snack at home, but wouldn't be likely to take it along hiking or birding or for outdoor activities, because the chocolate could melt. To be fair, we make our own trail mix assortments using M&Ms, which don't melt. Also, we don't overwhelm a mix with any one ingredient. At the price point, if you're creative in the kitchen, you'll ultimately save money by using dried fruits and berries, salted nuts, mini pretzels, coconut flakes and/or covered candies for your own mixes that keep in airtight storage in the pantry for several weeks. As a quick snack from a convenience store, this "Peeled Snacks" brand works.In exchange for a free product, I'm required to provide an honest review. Your preferences may differ.

My husband is the computer expert in our household... quite literally, as it's what he's done for a living more than three decades. I asked him to install the TP-LINK Archer C5 AC1200 unit and to note what he feels relevant. Here's what he has to say:Setup: Quick and easy, though the actual setup and the guide had some very slight differences.Speed: Definitely appears good; faster than our previous modem (a lower end Netgear model).Management Console: One very good thing is that there‚Äôs a side panel on every screen that explains what each control does, and what all the techy terms mean. This is a definite plus for the those that want to understand a little more about what‚Äôs going on. I DEFINITELY recommend changing the default administrator password. This took a little bit of poking around to find, but once found, it was easy to change.Features: Full featured modem, with 2.4 and 5 GHz bands that can be managed separately.supports a ‚Äúguest‚Äù access interface ‚Äì this is nice for when you have guests, but don‚Äôt want to give away your password.Includes parental controls, and time controls so you can limit children‚Äôs computers, tablets and phones to only have wifi access when you‚Äôd like.Includes bandwidth control in case you have a limited or expensive ISP, you can keep your bill down.Supports attaching a USB disk drive for shared network storage. This can be good for backing up your computers.Also supports several advanced features such as interfacing with a dynamic DNS server (allows you to host websites, without an expensive static address from your ISP), and working with a Radius server for WPA/ WPA2 security.Coverage: Unit has 3 external and 3 internal antennas that provide good signal strength and coverage throughout our home.I hope that helps anyone shopping for a new modem and considering this option.

If you enjoy novels that are dark or disturbing--and a reader who appreciates what's often termed "new" or "fresh" approaches to literature--you'll probably want to skip this review. I in no way wish to offend the author, publisher, or the folks who've enjoyed "My Sunshine Away" by M.O. Walsh. In exchange for a free, pre-publication copy of the novel, I'm required to give an honest review based on my own opinions. Your mileage may vary.We're introduced to the narrator/main character as he's looking back upon his adolescence and, especially, the girl across the street and two doors down that he's had a crush on since elementary school. More accurately, it seems like a typical school boy crush. As his story unfolds, however, it becomes painfully clear that it's much more obsession... a creepy obsession at best, and a dangerous, disturbing one that can't have escaped the adults in his life. Lindy, his paramour, was brutally raped the summer he was 14, and although Walsh writes the narrator's thoughts and feelings as naive and mostly innocent, his near-total focus on both the girl and all things sexual didn't quite add up to me. I have two now-adult sons. I was well aware of their awkward, awakening sexuality in their early teens. It wasn't, however, a 24/7 focus. Had it been--had they not had other interests, hobbies, etc.--I would have been very concerned.Granted, there were other deep, painful issues going on in the narrator's life in his youth, as the story slowly exposes. Oddly, there are also a number of rabbit trails and seemingly disconnected thoughts or events that had me feeling lost while reading... as if I'd somehow turned the wrong page. Hurricane Katrina is mentioned, which happened long after the 1989-1991 time frame of most of the novel. Why was that there? I wasn't sure, and am still not. There's also a mystery throughout the chapters. Namely, who raped Lindy that summer? After hanging in there until the last chapters, I was truly let down by how that question is answered, and especially the way in which it was delivered. Pages and chapters of lead up for something that felt rushed and almost brushed off like crumbs on a tablecloth.I don't know. Other readers find "My Sunshine Away" to be a brilliant work of fiction. The novel is written in a currently popular style combining first person with shifts in time and/or focus, lots of sex or sexual subject matter thrown in for good measure, and a dismissal of old fashioned high school English grammar. Therefore, I might just be an old fuddy duddy. You might really like the novel. I hope you do! It's not one I'd personally recommend.

For anyone shopping and unsure... I'm a curvy gal (40DD bra, size 1X pants on average with a bit of a tummy), and I ordered this in Ocean Blue, Mulberry and Ivory. Because I loved the Cashmerlon cardigan sweaters from Sag Harbor, I ordered the same size (2X), and was worried they'd be too large in this tunic. If anything, they run a bit small in the waist and upper arm. I could not layer, say, a polo shirt or blouse underneath as I could easily do with the cardigan. Oddly, the bust and hip aren't tight at all; those are generally my problem areas. That said, I still do adore the fabric. It's exceedingly soft! And they don't look "bad" on me by themselves. I just couldn't layer sleeved tops with them.As mentioned in my review for the cardigan of the same brand, the Cashmerlon fabric can generate static. When this happens I wipe them down lightly with a dryer sheet; I've also hung them in the bathroom when taking a shower (steam can reduce static). The fabric can also pill, but a simple lint roller keeps the sweater looking nice.

This fun and educational game (almost a twist on trivial pursuit) is the perfect small gift to tuck into a stocking or wrap up for a friend. It comes in a tin box, as shown. It's easy to imagine many family game nights or informal parties for yourself, a family member or friend... even co-workers will enjoy testing their knowledge of history while having a great time. Suitable for older children as well as adults; young children might have a struggle.

My order arrived just in time for Thanksgiving, and I decided to give our traditional green bean casserole some oomph using the Savory Portobello Mushroom soup. WOW! It was fantastic. I used one 14.5 ounce container with 2 lbs. of green beans and only 2 tablespoons of butter, making the recipe lower fat. The results were creamy, perfectly seasoned vegetables with the usual crunchy onion topping. Each container of the soup also includes recipe ideas for meals... I'm anxious to try them.

Juice Beauty SPF 30 Sport Moisturizer is a great year-round product that tucks easily into a backpack or fanny pack. There isn't a strong or overpowering scent, and it's made using many natural ingredients (important for anyone with sensitive skin, mild eczema, etc.). I like that it isn't greasy and can be used by men or women. My husband is an avid bird watcher; often he'll get mild sunburn on his face and neck even in January. With this product, he can tuck it into his vest or pack to reapply as needed during a long day of birding. Being a relatively small tube, it won't be cumbersome to carry with him.

**this review is based upon an uncorrected, pre-publication proof of the novel**As a few other reviewers have written, this would be a great movie. As a novel, it gets off to a slow start--at least in my opinion--but just like a commuter train, it picks up pace as the story continues. The main character, Rachel, is initially a woman difficult for most of us to relate to, in that she has more than her fair share of demons. In the first chapters, I didn't like her at all. Yet, haven't we all at some time peered into the windows of a strangers home and wondered about who lived there? Rachel does more than that. She makes up an entirely fictional story about a couple she sees on her daily commute. Then reality creeps in. I'll just say that once you get into "The Girl on the Train", you'll be taken on a thrilling ride. To say too much more would be to spoil the surprises along the way.I'm rating this four stars instead of five, because I wanted the main characters to be a bit less exaggerated. The novel, itself, is good.

This small can of spray antiperspirant has a light, fresh scent and goes on if not totally dry, definitely drier than "old time" antiperspirant sprays. Marketed to men, it offers 48 hour protection against wetness and odor. I'm thinking it could also be sprayed lightly onto the soles of his feet before putting on socks and shoes/boots during winter months to prevent foot odor, as well as using it under his arms. It's more of a light mist than a thick spray when applied; even though the can is small, it should last a month or more. Nice product.

Thinking of other dried fruit and nut salad toppers, I was surprised to find Mrs. Mays brand Cranberry Almond version is actually small, crunchy, chewy squares of what has the consistency of cut up chewy granola bars. Good alone as a quick snack by the palm full, they'd be hard to spear with a salad fork. It would be terrific, however, stirred into cooked, hot cereal, added to a long grain & wild rice blend during the last minutes of cooking, or (as I plan to use it) in a holiday stuffing side dish. You might even sprinkle some over the top of a sweet potato casserole. They are tasty. It's a personal preference, of course, but I like more traditional dried fruit and nut blends--or simply granola--over ice cream, yogurt or fruit, which is what is shown on the package and appears to be the intent for this topper.

Got these for three bathrooms' worth of cabinets and drawers. Excellent value and finish. Solid metal. The sheer number of handles necessary for a bunch of cabinets in multiple rooms really adds up. You can spend a fortune on handles!They come with two 8-32 screws designed for 3/4" thick doors. If you have fronts mounted on drawer boxes, you'll need to purchase extra 1-1/2" 8-32 screws.Buying the handles 10 at a time really saves money, even if you have extras left over. We used these on the doors and larger drawers and paired them with 5101-PC-10 GlideRite Polished Chrome Square Cabinet Knob (Pack of 10) for the smaller drawers.

Great medium sized switch. Has both Normally Open and Normally Closed capability. I needed it in NO config as I used it to turn on a closet light when the door opened. It's about 2" x 1" x 3/4" with a long flexible arm and roller.Two through-holes allow it to be mounted to a surface.The electrical contact screws are 8-32 I believe and long enough that you can fit 14-ga solid wire under the heads.

First, be aware this beast is more than 14 feet long and about 9 feet wide when unfolded and assembled. It does move in the wind. It doesn't weigh that much, but with so many elements forming such a large device it becomes a sail.I mounted it on a 10' length of 1-1/4" electrical conduit held to a tall garage wall using Channel Master CM-9025 3-Inch Heavy-Duty Wall Mount for TV Antenna Masts. The antenna is about 23 feet in the air.The HD8200U has a very high-gain, directional Yagi UHF antenna on the front and a full VHF antenna on the rear. I really don't think I need the VHF section and may retire this antenna and opt for a more compact UHF Yagi if the high winds we occasionally experience cause trouble. After assembly, the two sections feed into an electronics box using 1/8" aluminum rods from each section. You then mechanically attach a top plate to the box that connects to all four aluminum leads. The coax connector is in this top plate. A weather boot is supplied to seal the connection.The HD8200U does bring in the signal like a champ. My stations are at least 19 miles and 68 miles away. It's very directional. If I aimed 30 degrees off, I got zero channels. Check where your stations are broadcast from using www.antennaweb.org (antennaweb dot org) which provides distance and direction in degrees from magnetic north using your zip code. Very handy.

I received the Amcrest ProHD 1080p IP PT "WiFi" camera yesterday, 10/30/15.I downloaded the Amcrest Lite iPhone app. Followed instructions. It would not connect via Wi-Fi using my router's password. Tried again and again. I have a TP-Link C9 dual band wireless router with both 5gHz and 2.4gHz transmission.
