The Amcrest website says in an obscure forum post that the camera operates only in the 2.4gHz band. I changed my iPhone6 (iOS 9.0.2) from 5G to 2.4G. Still could connect via Wi-Fi.So I plugged the camera directly into the router via ethernet, completely defeating the purpose for the initial purchase. It finally connected. I saw the picture for about 30 seconds, trying to get the camera to full screen, I clicked around on the mysterious icons. Nothing seemed to work. I clicked on the "X" box. The camera disappeared. I tried to reconnect. It came back with "USER LOCKED." I went to their website to search for an answer. They said (at least for their DVR line -- virtually nothing was about this camera) "users are locked out after two failed logon attempts and that I must wait 30 minutes for the reset." I waited. Still USER LOCKED. No camera. I don't even recall trying to log in. I was in the app, trying to reconnect the camera.I created my Amcrest user account and received their confirming email. I created a user and password for Amcrest.com. The account is actually for something called amcrest.Zendesk and Accumed.zendesk and Foscamhelp.zendesk. I then tried to log in at Amcrest.com. It won't take my log-on credentials. "Invalid Logon or Password." How many user names and passwords does it take to plug in a camera?Trying to start over, I deleted the app and rebooted the camera. Still USER LOCKED.Finally, I found that if you push and hold in the little LED network-activity-indicator button on the back of the camera for 10 seconds, the camera will reset to factory. Deleted the app again, set my phone to operate in the 2.4gHz band. Still won't connect via WiFi. Plugged in via ethernet, then used my router's password and it connected.  Per the prompt, I then created a new secure password, replacing the default "admin/admin". Finally, I can see and control the camera. So, I have a WiFi camera that won't WiFi. The camera needs to connect to the router at 2.4gHz band (and in my case, via an ethernet cable) but after getting it set, the phone can go back to the 5G if desired.They claim their products are "Simple, Reliable, Secure." Not quite. They fail to hook to Wi-Fi and then lock me out. Their website won't let me log on even with a user and password.I downloaded the camera's big PDF user manual to find what the icons mean. The document looks nothing like the camera's icons. They went into great detail...about a previous firmware version, then changed the firmware to look very differently.The camera works, eventually, and only via ethernet in some cases, but getting there is a real test of patience.

0:33 MinsI've had this 20-volt trimmer/blower pair since May 2014...about a year and a half. Used both about six times.The blower motor bearings are already shot. Screams like a banshee. See the video for audio proof. No obvious dirt buildup. I hardly used either tool. Very disappointed. Blower ran maybe a half hour total.Black and Decker once had such a good name in tools. Not anymore. Would never buy the brand again.

This is a terrific double stick, industrial-duty tape. It's about 1/16" thick. It's designed to hold automotive trim on permanently for years, in all kinds of weather. Good stuff.I bought to add some rubber non-slip pads to some polyethylene cases I had bought that were so slippery that I couldn't stack them on top of each other on a cart without them sliding off each other. This tape will stick to polyethylene. Not much else does.I also wanted to affix some 6" grills over my open-speaker JBL studio monitor to protect the very exposed speaker. At first I was going to screw the grills onto the speakers, then realized that even little slivers of this tape would hold the lightweight grills on forever. Worked like a charm with zero damage to the speakers.This roll comes raw -- it's not even in a package -- and is 1.5" wide. After I bought this (and had to pay for shipping) I noticed the local big box hardware store carries this tape, though in a narrower width. Could have gotten it faster and for less. But I wanted the 1.5" stuff.VBH stands for Very High Bond. It's permanent and strong. Not the thinnest, but it really holds.

For a Victorinox edged tool, this Channel Knife leaves a lot to be desired.The cutting vee was, to be blunt, really blunt. I have to drag it with great difficulty through a lemon rind. I actually took it to the garage, held it in my bench vise and took a fine file to the edge until it felt sharper. Still doesn't glide through the rind. It's stainless steel, but it's pretty soft. It filed easily -- not the best sign for knife steel.The handle is comfortable and it does cut a nice twist, but takes more effort than I expected and should be sharper from the get-go.

These Jockeys last for years and years! Very comfortable waistband. Moving to a slightly larger size as I have, um, grown, over the years is even better. I've tried others and keep coming back. Best underwear ever.

These shirts are not for working. They are lightweight knit fabric and constantly snag. Velcro grabs it, any rough surface catches it. I have a horizontal run/snag on the front right now. Wore it only a couple of times and it looks terrible already. Not durable. Disappointed.

This Lutron DVWCL-153PH-WH Diva Dimmable CFL/LED Dimmer with Wallplate, White works well with the Great Eagle (6-pack) LED BR30 3000K Dimmable Bulb. 13 Watt (65W 75W 90W) UL Listed Bright White Light for Recessed and Track Lighting Fixtures - USA Seller.I have the dimmer controlling four of the Great Eagle LEDs in a 3-way (two switches) configuration.Be aware that that is a secondary dimmer "trimmer" slider accessible from the front of the dimmer before you install the switch plate.This secondary trimmer adjusts the minimum voltage delivered to the lamps. You turn the lights on, run the main dimmer slider to minimum, then slide the tiny trimmer slider to get minimum light output that still can turn the lamps on. With the trimmer set to minimum, only three of the four Great Eagles lit when I turned them off and back on while at minimum dim. I simply slid the trimmer up a tad until all four turned on. That's now my new minimum dim position. Very easy.The Great Eagles do not flicker or emit an audible buzz (although they are 10 feet in the air outdoors in a patio cover, so they may be buzzing ever so slightly, but if they are I can't hear them.The spec says the dimmer can handle up to 150 watts of LEDs. The four 13-watt bulbs I'm controlling are obviously only 46 watts total, so I'm well within limits.One note: verify the color of your existing switches and plates. I thought my plates were white, so I ordered the white dimmer. Turn out my switchplate color is "light almond." Almost white, but not. And you can select from four colors.Easy to install. Came with four large yellow wirenuts and a smaller black wirenut. Also two 6-32 x 1" installation screws to attach to the box. Be aware there are no wire attachment post/screws for you to wrap existing wire around. Four stranded, pre-stripped wires come out of the back of the unit. Black, Red (the traveler), White/Red stripe and Green (ground). It's up to you to figure the wiring of your existing system. I had to reverse the Black and White/Red stripe to get the system to function. But it works fine. Just know that you will have to wirenut this device to the existing wiring. Make sure the wirenuts secure the stranded device wires tightly to the solid 12 or 14 ga existing wires.I used my old switchplate so it would match the others and did not need the modern, clean 2-part hidden-fastener plate that came with the dimmer. Full instructions also included.

For reaching 10' ceilings, this is perfect. The platform is 45" from the floor. That puts the top of my head (6' tall) at 117", three inches below the 120" ceiling height. For lower ceilings, stand on a lower step. My wife can easily carry and deploy the ladder. What's nice is how easily it can be carried through the house without hitting things.The ladder weighs only 12.5 lbs, folds and unfolds in a flash, stores compactly. It has a built-in carrying handle perfectly positioned for easy, comfortable carrying. The handle is in the platform so when you reach to fold up the ladder, you grab the handle and pull up. The ladder folds and you have your hand on the carry handle. You carry the ladder vertically, not horizontally. That's why it's more controllable when you carry it. It's tall, not long.The ladder is very stable and reasonably priced.Arrived in perfect condition.

These Dreat Eagle BR30 65watt equiv lamps are excellent. The bulbs they replaced were 130v 65watt models that were dimmer than designed as they ran on 120v. The 3000 K color temp is just right. Not too warm, not too blue.The are really bright and fill the space with quality light. The bulb design is actually more attractive than the old incandescent both when on and off.I am concerned that the plastic face of the lamp will yellow with age but when new are beautiful.They come packed extremely well. The six lamps are in a single box inserted into a blow molded clear plastic separator that holds the lamps securely for shipping and provides an efficient storage option for the old bulbs which in my case are new and can be used elsewhere should I ever want to go back to old incandescent technology.Six old lamps at 65w were using 390 watts. Now I'm burning 90 watts and the light is still warm but brighter.The problem I see with LED technology is the antiquated dependency on 120v line power. LEDs naturally run on low voltage. So each lamp has to have a power supply that transforms 120v to something like 12v. This adds to complexity, RF noise and unnecessary expense. Building codes need to allow 12v lighting circuits. The lamps could then dispense with the individual power supplies. The cost would drop dramatically. Lamps could also be much smaller and shallower. So, sadly, we are stuck with expensive unnecessarily complicated lamps as long as we insist on 120v circuits.More light, more useful and pleasing light, longer life, dimmable, less power consumption and less heat generated that the AC needs to pull out of the house. What's not to like?UPDATE: I wanted to dim four of these on the outdoor patio and selected the Lutron DVWCL-153PH-WH Diva Dimmable CFL/LED Dimmer with Wallplate, White. It works well, even in a 3-way configuration. It has a trimmer slider on it that adjusts the minimum voltage so the Great Eagles will turn on and not flicker at minimum dim. Works great.

This clip is really slick. Great design. Easily holds an iPhone 6 Plus, although I need to position it carefully or the spring clip will press the volume or sleep/wake buttons. Once the phone's in, it's very securely held.The mount that attaches to the Feiyu Tech gimbal handle is adjustable to a much smaller diameter if you want to mount this to a smaller rod diameter. With the red molded rubber jaw adapters installed, it's closes to about 1/2". With the jaw adapters removed, it opens to about 1.4". The jaw adapters fit well and don't fall off easily, but are easily removed if desired. They are bright red so you can see them if they're off and bouncing around your gear bag or on the floor.Mounted to the gimbal, this holder allows me to attach my phone, then wirelessly monitor and control the GoPro 3 Black (WiFi enabled). Be aware that there is a serious time lag. It's not close to real time viewing -- like 2 seconds or more. But it's great for framing and starting and stopping the camera without touching the camera. The GoPro app gives you full access to the camera in a much easier format to make changes like inverting the image during recording if you suddenly decide to invert the rig for low angle shots, sync the camera to the phone's date and time and every other menu item on the camera.The ball mount allows you to adjust the phone's angle for easy viewing. It easily removes and stores fairly compactly in my hard case, a Cases By Source B14105 Blow Molded Empty Carry Case, 14.99 x 10.5 x 5.125, InteriorBest of all, my gimbal rig is all one-handed now, still very light and compact and gives full remote control of the camera while safely holding the phone in perfect position.

These blow molded polyethylene cases are terrific. I have several in different sizes to hold photo gear. They come with nothing inside -- no formfitting premolded shapes -- just an open area.I line them with white 1/2" polyethylene foam walls and form compartments by attaching the foam to itself and the case using hot melt glue, which is about the only stuff that sticks to polyethylene.The only downside is that if you stack them on top of each other in transport on a cart, they are so slippery that they simply cannot stay stacked. I solved this problem by purchasing a sheet of 24"x36"x1/8" thick very "grippy" neoprene rubber by Shop Fox on Amazon designed to absorb vibration. I also bought a small roll of 3M VHB (Very High Bond) double sticky tape (1-1/2" wide x 9' long). I stuck the tape to one edge of the neoprene sheet and cut off the rubber following the 1-1/2" tape. This gave me a strip of rubber 24" x 1-1/2" with tape on it. I cut that into 1-1/2" squares and attached four of them to the bottom the each case. Now hey really grip the surface it sits upon and each other if stacked.They do not have shoulder straps or provisions for them -- a single, folding handle only. Lid locks are flexible polyethylene that hold securely. Hinge is a hidden pin of some sort, not a thinned molded part anything that can wear out and fail. Lid folds almost all the way back. Small molded approx 3/16" hole for a padlock.

Great idea, but overpriced.I'll tie one end of a string or strong thread to the USB cable and the other end around the LIghtning adapter, then secure the string to the adapter with a drop of hot melt glue.

This is a great little heater. Lights easily and has three heat levels. Burns a long time on a large cylinder of gas.You can't aim the head: it comes with a fixed angle. But if you put it on the floor and you are seated, it shoots the heat up toward you just right.Perfect for the patio on cool nights. Really like it.
Good, useful length but worked only for a few weeks before breaking. The Lightning tip is just too small and fragile with extremely fine wires. If you buy this, treat it very gently.

Precision made Bowens-type adapter ring that fits exactly into the Calumet Quickring Speedring.Very smooth metal with a stainless steel feel. The three Bowens lugs are a molded aluminum ring that is very tightly attached to the steel adapter.

This is an excellent, heavy duty angle bracket/umbrella holder.It is very similar -- and superior -- to the Manfrotto 026 Swivel Lite-Tite Umbrella Adapter, for one third the cost.It comes with two threaded 5/8" spuds that can be attached to almost anything. One spud has female threads -- 1/4-20 on one end and 3/8-16 on the other. The other spud has male threads on both ends -- 1/4-20 and 3/8-16. Very handy.The very best feature is the ratcheted spline employed to hold the bracket at a given angle. When you set the angle and tighten the large handle, the bracket will stay at that angle. The 026 with its friction system simply cannot hold the angle if the load is too heavy.The main locking handle is spring loaded and adjustable. If the handle gets in the way, you pull it out and readjust it.Heavy items are placed in the 5/8" receiver on top but a smaller hole is cast into the upper section that holds a 5/16" umbrella shaft. There's a locking screw to hold the umbrella in place.The whole thing is made of cast metal. Overall, a very nice design at a terrific price.

It's a great looking power supply with good features, but I'll never know how it works as it will not fit my HP Envy TouchSmart 15 Notebook PC, Model 15-j023cl.The right angle plug fits the outside diameter, but the original AC adapter has a little blue ring around the tip (this one is yellow) and a very tiny pin in the middle called a "smart pin," whatever that means. It's the weirdest connector I've ever seen.I need a replacement for p/n 709985-003. Or, as it says on the OEM power supply, "replace with HP Spare 710412-001. Confusing enough? So do you order the first, original number or the second "spare" number?Had to send it back.

Got this model B751 to hold a bunch of drill bits, screwdriver tips, nut drivers and a few fasteners so I can organize the tool bag that came with my Makita screwdriver/impact driver kit. The slim box is very durable and rugged. Can't rust. Doesn't hermetically seal, but closes well and nothing can escape. Good hinge and a single latch.

The two mats fit our cooking pans perfectly, no trimming. They measure 16-1/2" x 11-11/16" and lay perfectly flat. They are less than 1/8" thick and are made with fiberglass fabric molded inside silicon. Can roll them up for storage.Great product at a good price. Very pleased.

Fotodiox makes a good line of precision step up and step down rings. Some brands I've purchased to save a couple of bucks just don't work. A ring that's slightly off (either bad threads or out of round) can jam onto the lens making it very difficult to attach or remove and possibly damaging the fine threads of the lens or filter.So far, every Fotodiox ring I have has worked flawlessly.

Works well with the TASCAM DR-70D recorder, which requires a wired remote.This is actually an IR unit that slips into a holder. The holder has the belt clip on it. Its bottom hinges open, allowing the IR unit to slip in and the hinge snaps closed to secure the IR unit inside.The IR unit is powered by its own CR2025 battery. The belt clip adapter has some kind of IR receiver inside that converts the IR to hardwired impulses. The converter gets its power down the wire from the DR-70D's 3/32" stereo mini plug's socket. Cable is about 9 feet long.
Great for slicing bagels and English muffins. Very safe and gets the job done. Takes even large bagels, though you need to stuff them in sometimes. Sits next to the toaster. Very heavy duty.

These cases are just terrific and come in a large variety of sizes. They are very strong, lightweight, rustproof and have good hinges, handle and latches. They are not sealed, however, so don't expect them to fall into the ocean and not get water inside. They take up a lot less room than Pelican-style cases. On the other hand, they are not shipping cases either. Excellent for keeping multiple pieces of a system together.I wish they offered a foam interior as an option. Interior dimensions as listed are true.

Not exactly sure what all the hoopla is about this device. They make it sound like it's the best thing since sliced bread, but it's pretty limited in my view. I wanted to be able to display pictures and video from my PC laptop onto my TV wirelessly. So far, the only thing I can put up on the TV is YouTube, and then only if I view it from Google's Chrome browser and then only after remembering how to use it and waiting for all the connections to hook.I guess there are other things it can do, but it's not that intuitive. My Roku is clearly superior, but also cannot view my PC's content. Still looking for that perfect device.

Great little cable that works exactly as pictured. My Sony TV has an HDMI in and right next to it is the USB socket that can supply power to the Chromecast. Very clean installation of my Chromecast unit. The angles of the plugs are perfect -- the cable ends plug in without any twisting and nothing gets stressed. One end is standard USB; the other is micro-USB.
Durable, strong bag with zippered top. It's not super heavy duty, but very strong. The zipper is on the lightweight side, but works. Holds a bunch.

These handy fittings used to be sold locally at Mr. BigBox but, alas, no more. Good to see them at Amazon.I have used them to add a 1/2" branch line to an existing 3/4" sprinkler system. I used the 3/4" x 1/2" model.Once the PVC main line is buried, and you want to add a line, it's very difficult to cut the main line and insert a tee. As I recall, I dug the new trench and exposed enough of the existing line to allow me access around it. I cleaned and primed both the main line and the saddle part of this fitting. I then coated both pipe and fitting with a generous amount of PVC cement and snapped the saddle over the main line, wiggling it a bit to make sure the plastics welded and positioning it where I wanted it within the few seconds you have before the cement starts to set.After being sure it was firmly set, I then drilled the hole through the side fitting into the main line. Drilling the hole before attaching the saddle is tricky and you may miss. Drilling it afterwards guarantees a good aim. If you want, start with a small pilot drill, then open the hole with a 1/2" drill. Most of the chips will be pulled upwards out of the hole, so you don't need to worry about clogging the main line, but it's a good idea to flush the line after this kind of work regardless.I would not use this saddle on a continuously pressurized line, but that's just me. Why ask for trouble? For that, the Sharkbite tees are terrific. For sprinkler systems that are under minimal pressure or off altogether, they work great and make a hard job much easier.

One star because the device that arrived looks NOTHING like the picture. The pictured unit has eight large rod holes. My device's "ring" is square and has only four 4mm rod holes on the corners. It won't fit a single softbox I own. The Adorama part number on the box is "FPSRBF."If I want to employ this ring, I'll have to drill out the tiny 4mm holes to 9 or 10mm and even then it's only good for square boxes.It's a sturdy universal ring, although the thread tolerances are very loose on the tightening screws. They will work, but build quality is less than spectacular. This unit appears to be identical to the Novatron N7301 Universal Speedring #1

These durable blow-molded polyethylene cases are terrific. Pretty much indestructible. Only cons are that they aren't strictly waterproof as there's no real seal between the two halves. They aren't hermetically sealed. But they cost one third or better of the premium cases and are way less bulky and way less weight.The hinge is a true plastic pin hinge that will last a long time, not a molded thin film that can fail with use. The locks are secure but could be better. Totally adequate however. Holes for a padlock if desired. Folding carry handle.They arrive completely empty. I'd give them five stars if they came with a pick 'n pluck foam insert, lid foam and a base foam. Or at least offer it as an option.Great cases in a large variety of sizes.

This softbox comes with two diffusers, a fabric grid, a speedring and a case. The four rods are 1/8" spring steel with ends that make them larger to fit into 8mm holes in the speedring.The fabric is stiff, with an aluminumized interior and black exterior. Two small heat vents are cut into the long sides (most likely the upper and lower sides) with little velcro doors so you can open or close them as required depending on how hot your modelling lights are.The speedring comes with a removable Alien Bees steel insert. The insert has an outer diameter of 5.967" (151.5mm). The inner hole is 3.44" (87.5mm). (You'd think there would be some sort of standard diameter for speedrings so a variety of inner adapters could be interchanged with various speedrings. No such luck. Apparently their diameters and adapters are all over the place.)Softboxes can be floppy things when broken down. Rods can separate and get lost. I have found it's good to sew the rod ends into their pockets at the diffuser end of the box. That way the rods don't fall out in transport and handling. Nothing slows you down like having to re-seat the rod in its little pocket.When collapsed, the lightweight nylon carrying case is roughly 8"x23"x3". The case has a velcro flap to keep everything inside and a convenient carrying handle.The main reason I purchased this light is for its grid that controls the light spill. The grid really helps to keep the back light off the background and out of the lens to control flare.The only problem is that my strobes do not fit the Alien Bees flange adapter. It would be nice if they offered different speedring options.

This is a very well-designed and well-made ring. It's different from the picture in that it does not come with the actual adapter that attaches to the strobe head and it's not black -- it's nicely finished sandblasted cast aluminum with no sharp edges anywhere.Each part is high quality: the four brass thumbscrews that secure the adapter into the ring are spring-loaded and have rubber washers to help lock the rotation of the adapter when the thumbscrews are tightened. Over-engineered compared to other rings I've purchased.There are six 9.9mm (.390") rod holes around the perimeter, not eight. (These holes are a bit larger than most rings as my rods are about 7mm, so they fit very loosely in the holes.) Four are at 90 degrees to each other and the other two holes allow an "X" shape for a 4-rod narrow rectangle softbox. As is, the ring cannot be used with an octagon softbox unless you drill out the other two positions. The two positions where the 7th and 8th rod holes would be are threaded 1/4-20 and 3/8-16 mounting holes. This allows flexibility in mounting to a stand directly if desired. Very cool. They even etched the thread markings into the casting. Details.The "C" half-ring that hinges loose to release one or two rods locks in place via a spring-loaded brass bolt that looks like a miniature door latch. Another unnecessary but nice detail: the thumb trigger you pull back to release the bolt is rubber covered for comfort.The recess that holds the desired adapter (that you have to buy separately to fit your particular strobe head) is 5-1/2" in diameter.This ring is impressive and a terrific value. And it makes assembling and breakdown of softboxes -- especially smaller ones that put a lot of stress on the rods -- MUCH easier and faster. Highly recommended.

Has 1/8" spring steel rods with 8mm ends that fit normal speedrings well. The other end of the rods have smaller ends if your ring has smaller holes.My unit came with heat vents on the horizontal sides but not on the vertical sides. In other words, it will vent heat better when positioned horizontally. I think this is for higher-wattage modeling lights, but I've seen some boxes made of a very similar fabric that are suitable for hot lights if mounted very carefully and vented properly. This box is so large, I think I can get away with a hot quartz video light.The Bowens speedring is well made and has 12 holes in it for various shaped softboxes. At first, as the box is 31"x47" rectangular, I attached the rods in its ring at the less-than-90-degree (X) position, but found the rods did not lay in the seams properly. Refitting the rods in the holes that are 90-degrees apart (so the rods are in a perfect + shape) caused the rods to lay in the seams of the box perfectly.Interior is bright silver. I find if I sew the rod ends into their pockets it's a lot easier to assemble and the rods can't come out and get lost.Grids and speedrings alone usually cost twice as much or more than the whole price of this box, which has two diffusers, a grid, rods, vents and a Bowens-type speedring. Fabulous value.The only thing that would improve any of these softboxes -- expensive or not -- is a speedring that would help you assemble and especially disassemble the box. The nature of softboxes is that you can get the rods into the holes on the speedring fairly easily but getting the rods out to break the box down is a real pain. The Calumet Quickring Speedring folds in half and locks. I believe the Calumet ring will do the trick. Undo the lock and all the tension will relax. Chimera makes a quick-release ring too, but it's $87 for the ring alone.

This cable is just what I was looking for. I had purchased another coiled cable earlier, but it was more like a CB or police radio mic cable (stiff, heavy and thick). This cable is just 3mm (.119") and when retracted is about the length of my hand. Just right for supplying 5V USB power from an Anker external battery pack to my TASCAM DR-70D recorder that positively eats its internal batteries when phantom powering microphones.It's ideal in my application because it stays out of the way while allowing flexibility. If I were to snag it, the cable won't pull out during recording and it doesn't hang down flopping all over the place. Also, because it's so light, it's not putting side pressure on the tiny micro end of the cable. It's only USB 2.0, but that's fine for my purposes.It stretches to much greater length if needed, but that's asking for problems. I want it to be its compact self, store easily without kinking and splaying everywhere.The connectors seem well made and attach firmly both at the large and micro ends.

High quality Step Down ring that allows me to screw this into a lens that takes a 77mm filter and reduce the threads to 62mm so I can mount a specialty lens adapter that's only 62mm onto the larger lens. This is not often a desirable direction to go as the smaller filter will probably cause vignetting, but in this case I wanted to mount an Anamorphot 1.33:1 anamorphic adapter onto a Veydra Mini-Prime lens on a Panasonic GH4.So to be clear, the outside of this ring has 77mm male threads and screws into a lens like a filter. The inner hole has 62mm female threads.Did exactly what I wanted it to do. The adapter works nicely as long as I don't select a lens wider than 18mm.The ring is well made, works smoothly and is well finished. And the price can't be beat.

This S-Type Bracket is simply brilliant. It has no arms or parts to lose and packs flat. It's all plastic but is very sturdy. It has an umbrella port if you want it to shoot into an umbrella as is or it can be attached to a softbox as long as your speedring has a Bowen three-lug adapter on it. This is the part I didn't understand before I bought it. I thought I'd have to bolt the large round black flange into a speed ring. But it's easier than that.That large 6" black ring/flange that surrounds the flash port is actually a socket that receives the Bowen ring. The ring pushes into the flange and twists to lock in place. The tolerances are loose and the speedring moves about a bit after it's locked in place, but it's not a big deal. It's just holding a softbox. You spin and aim it and then never touch it again. Besides, the loose tolerances allow the ring to mount and unmount easily and quickly. There is a sliding lock button on the back of the flange that securely holds the Bowen ring in.The reason the flange is so big (6" diameter) and doesn't seem to be needed is because it's designed to hold the Neewer 24"x24" softbox and replace the L-shaped strobe holder that comes with that unit. Neewer¬Æ 24"x24"/60cmx60cm Professional Protable Foldable Off-Camera Flash Photography Studio, Portrait Soft Box with L-shaped bracket & flash Ring, Outer Diffuser and Carrying Case for Nikon SB900 SB800 SB600, Canon 580EXII 580EX 430EXII 430EX, Neewer T... That very popular box does not need the Bowen adapter to attach to this S-Type bracket.Fits on standard 5/8" baby spud light stands. The large plastic tightening handle is spring-loaded so you can pull outward and reposition the handle as needed if it hits anything.A shoe-mount flash like a Nikon SB-800 or similar on-camera flash is gently but securely held in place in vise-like padded jaws. This means you're not trusting a tiny cold-shoe to hold your $400 strobe up in the air. It's elegant in its simplicity and function. Treat this right and it'll do the job for years.

Sturdy, all-metal construction. My unit has 8, 8.7mm holes to accept the softbox rod ends. One of the holes is designed to assist getting smaller, more-difficult softboxes like the hair light softbox to assemble and disassemble easier.The cast aluminum Bowens inner adapter has an inner diameter of 3-3/4" (3.743" actually) and it tapers just slightly -- the edge with the lugs is slightly smaller in diameter than the "front" part of the ring. The outside diameter of the adapter is 144mm (5.678"). The three cast metal lugs are 9.6mm x 10.4mm.While the outer ring appears to be round, my unit actually has 16 flats on the outer edge. The ring's outer diameter is 7-3/8" measured across the flats.I give these specs because I'm trying to fit a ring to an ancient Photogenic Medalight Model PG-4001-ML Studio Strobe monolight. They don't really have a secure way to mount speedrings or other accessories and I was hoping I could adapt this Bowens. This ring will not fit if I attempt to put it on correctly (that is, with the lug-side facing the strobe) because of the slight tapering of both the ring and the molded plastic of the Medalight. But if I reverse the ring (lugs out) it friction fits to the strobe perfectly. See the pictures. Almost like it was made for it.Speedrings used to be very, very expensive and still are from certain manufacturers. How this quality of ring can be custom cast, nuts and bolts and thumbscrews added, packaged, shipped and delivered for such a low cost is simply amazing. Very pleased.

The unit I received was not like the picture at all, though it was marked as an N7301.First, it it much larger than expected. The description says it can take a maximum diameter light of 4-3/4". This unit can take 5-1/2". It closes down to about 2-3/4".Second, the four holes to receive the softbox rods are only 1/8" in diameter. All my softbox rods are much larger and will not fit. I could drill the holes out, but it's just too big and heavy for what I want to do.The unit is very sturdy -- made of cast metal. The screws are about 5/16" in diameter (possibly metric) and are not tiny flimsy things. The rubber tips are strong and secure. The two rings can rotate against each other for turning the softbox after mounting and there's a locking thumbscrew to secure them from moving after positioning.This ring would be fine if: 1) your rods are 1/8" in diameter and 2) your light is in the 5" diameter range.My old Medalight monolights are 3-3/4" in diameter. Technically, this ring could fit, but would be screwed almost all the way to min diameter. The biggest problem is that the holes don't fit my flexrods.

This tape is terrible. It's completely unreadable. Complete waste of money. It is simply awful.Might be able to use it to seal a package, but I doubt its adhesive is any better than its image quality.That Amazon even sells this execrable product reflects very poorly on them.The image on the tape, whether small or large (see the photo) is inconsistently garbled. Most disappointing product I ever bought from Amazon.

This unit comes with almost everything you need to ---- charge your LiPo's rapidly-- balance charge your LiPo's so each cell has the same voltage-- discharge your LiPo's if they're fully charged but you want to store them-- charge your LiPo's to storage voltage levels for long term storage-- plug your charger into AC wall powerThe adapter cable fits a large variety of cell terminal plugs.There is a balance port that receives the included balance plug adapter that can connect to anything up to 8S batteries.This particular kit comes with an AC power supply like those that come with computers. The charger is really designed to hook to a car battery or other 12VDC high amperage source. This AC supply lets you plug it in at home easily and reliably. It comes with the right plug to fit perfectly.The only things that could be added are extension cables on the balance connector to make it easier to charge the cells by making all the wires about the same length. JST JST-XH 3S Balance Wire Extention 20cm adapter 11.1v LiPo Battery Cable Li-Po This also allows you to put the cells into a fireproof bag during charging. Bluecell Black Medium Size Lipo Battery Guard Sleeve/Bag for Charge & StorageOne other accessory that really helps is a compact voltage indicator Integy C23212 Lipo Voltage Checker/Warning Buzzer that you plug into the balance port on the battery. Not strictly needed for recharging, but is very useful to monitor voltage after charging.You'll need to consult YouTube for useful instructions on how to manipulate the four buttons and why, unless you want to read the manual. And who reads manuals anymore when a good ten minute video is clearer and simpler?

This cable is delightfully flexible and light. I use it to connect an HDMI monitor to the HDMI camera output while the camera in in a gimbal mount. The thicker, stiffer cables just don't cooperate with the gimbal and fight the motors.As shown, this cable is so thin you can tie it in a knot. It flexes easily and can be coiled up on my rig to get the extra out of the way.

They say LiPo's can burst into flame if mischarged. So I got this Battery Guard bag. It can easily hold two 3-cell LiPo's for charging or storage. It's made of what looks like fiberglass on the inside and a black smooth coating on the outside. Sturdy velcro closure. Is totally flat when empty. Measures 7-1/4" wide by 9" long. Cheap insurance.
As the former official shirt of the Obama Administration, I simply do not understand why he's no longer astride this mythical beast. I won't wear a shirt without Obama on it.

2:33 MinsExcellent little device that keeps you informed about each cell's voltage. Dimensions: 1.383" long (not counting pins; 1.62" to end of pins) by 1.017" wide by .448 thick.Covered in a clear shrinktube. Not waterproof but fairly well protected.Can read any LiPo/Li-Ion/Li-Mn/Li-Fe battery with up to eight cells.Adjustable low voltage warning beeper between 2.7 and 3.8 volts. Default low voltage is 3.3v.  Very loud beeper. Put a piece of scotch tape over the horn holes to make it quieter.See my video review for closeup of information on the back and how it attaches to the balance connector of your LiPo.Took about two weeks to get here from China, but for $3.11, I'm not complaining. Great little device.

I got a couple of these right angle Micro-to-Normal HDMI adapters to fit my Panasonic GH4. I also built a bottom-mounted aluminum bracket that securely holds the adapter into the camera (see picture) so that the stress of plugging and unplugging and any pulling of the cord would not wear out the camera's port. The adapter also sends the HDMI cable toward the front of the camera instead of straight out the side.With this setup if the adapter wears out I simply replace the adapter and the camera's port is protected from very-expensive damage.An added plus, of course, is that I don't have to buy non-standard cords with a micro HDMI on one end and a Standard HDMI on the other. This allows a much greater selection of cables, including extremely thin, extremely flexible HDMI cables that simply don't exist as Micro/Normal.

The price is reasonable, the pen is comfortable enough to hold and use and the split tip is pretty easy to employ as a stylus, but there's one major failing: the molded shirt clip simply doesn't clip onto the shirt pocket very well. The pen falls out if I lean over.
I wear a 60/7-1/4 hat size. The Large/XLarge is too small for me. I'd estimate the Large/XLarge at 7 or 7-1/8 at best.Also took 20 days to arrive.Not a total loss. My wife can wear it and likes it.

My shower valve was getting very difficult to operate. This design was old when I installed it 30 years ago, but Moen still makes a replacement and it works like a dream.The new ceramic valves are the way to go these days but if you have a Moen valve in the wall, short of changing the valve, this is the best solution. Put one in for my mother-in-law, too.To do it right, get a Danco valve puller Danco Perfect Match 86712 Cartridge Puller. Makes the job 100% easier. Getting the cartridge out of the valve after it's set itself in there for ten years can be a real pain. The puller makes the job easy.Now, every time I take a shower it's a joy to operate my like-new valve.

Smallrig rod accessories are very well made and should last a very long time. They look good, have no sharp edges and come in a large variety of sizes and uses.And when you tighten them to the rod, they really grip. Not going anywhere.One of their best features is the adjustable thumbscrew. It gives you excellent leverage, but if it runs into anything you can pull up the spring-loaded handle and reposition the handle to clear obstacles.Machining is uniformly excellent and precise. Threaded holes are in logical places and allow a lot of flexibility in mounting.This particular mount works very well holding my 4" HDMI monitor. It allows me to angle it at any position. The large-diameter knurled thumbwheel allows secure tightening.I've bought a lot from SmallRig and will probably buy more.

Durable, semi-transparent bags with small lanyard loop and small carabiner. They appear to be nylon-reinforced clear PVC that is much stronger than a Ziplock bag. You can see what you have in there, and it offers a good deal of protection.

This auxiliary lens support is superb and works extraordinarily well.If you want to put a long lens on your DSLR or Panasonic GH4, and you have a 15mm rod system, this is indispensable if you want to achieve a solid rig, especially during focusing or zooming.Pros:- Solid machined aluminum with hard black anodizing- No parts can escape; it's cleverly assembled as a unit- Thin profile (about 5/16" thin); it fits under the lens, supports and doesn't take too much room- Quick disconnect from the 60mm-spaced 15mm rods, but attaches firmly- Adjustable height- Locking knobs are easily accessible, not under the lens; no tools or pesky allen wrench required- One knob locks the device to the rods, the other locks height- The height locking knob bites into a machined groove so as the aluminum becomes nicked by the lock, it still allows for smooth movement up and down. This is good engineering.- The brilliantly-designed rubber hold-down strap is about 3/8" wide and adjusts to any size up to my 4-3/8" diameter Rokinon 800M-B-AI 800mm F8.0 Mirror Lens for Nikon (Black)...which really needs this support at that focal length.- Mounts faster under the lens than fiddling with a bridge and 1/4-20 bolt, should the lens have an aux tripod shoe, which many lenses do not. Much faster to mount my 70-200mm Nikon lens that if I bolt it down via its tripod foot.- Works with any lens as long as there is a part of the lens that doesn't rotate that you can wrap the rubber strap over; you obviously cannot strap this to the focus or zoom rings- Is amazingly stable; the rubber strap really holds, even though it's flexible- Goes on and off in a flash- Stores compactly- Light weight and simpleCons:- The rubber strap, I fear, will only last so long, and will eventually rot or harden and crack. It is a molded strap that is attached to the device at one end via a hinge pin that doesn't appear to be removable. Even then, I'm sure a small bungee or something else could be pressed into duty. And if I keep it sealed in a ziplock poly bag away from UV and ozone, it should last years and years. Also, don't keep it under tension; let the rubber relax between jobs.- A bit pricy in absolute terms, but in relative terms compared to other supports I shopped for out there, this is a bargain. Some are hundreds of dollars. And Amazon got it here in two days.Bottom line, this firms up the lens, especially when equipped with a follow focus unit, eases downward pressure on the camera flange and allows steady tracking when using a good tripod and head.Couldn't be happier.

This unit supplies adequate wattage at the proper voltage to power my Nikon D800 when fitted with the expensive Nikon EP-5B power adapter battery eliminator Nikon EP-5B Power Supply Connector. The EB-5B has a very custom 4-pin connector on it that I didn't want to cut off. This Kapaxen EH-5 EH-5A power supply comes with the mating connector that fits perfectly. They snap together very firmly and are not likely to disconnect easily.If you want to save half the Nikon's cost buy the Kapaxen version of the EP-5B EP-5B Replacement Power Supply Connector for Nikon 1 V1, D7000, D800 and D600 Digital Cameras or buy the power supply and EP-5B together Kapaxen EH-5 Plus EP-5B AC Power Adapter Kit for Nikon 1 V1, D7000, D800 and D600 Digital Cameras.If you have long video shoots or time lapse jobs, this will keep the D800 going at a reasonable price.

If you simply want a digital tuner that can receive off-air (OTA) digital antenna TV transmission and deliver free HD television from local stations to virtually any TV new or old, this is it.If you want to record programming off the air via antenna, this is a possible candidate, if you add a small portable hard drive.Pros:1. HDMI output for modern TVs2. Component (YRB) and composite RCA connectors output for older analog TVs obsoleted by the new transmission standards3. Left/right (white/red) RCA connectors analog audio4. Coax RCA Dolby Digital audio output to send surround audio to your Dolby amp5. Really inexpensive6. USB output for recording to a hard drive7. Antenna can loop through the unit so the TV's tuner (if it has one) still works8. Lightweight and small size: 8-5/8" wide, 1-5/8" tall, 6" deep (not counting connectors sticking out)Cons:1. There really isn't a channel guide2. You can set the timer to record, but you have to do it one at a time and it doesn't remember. IOW, you can't set it so it records a show at the same time every week.3. Recording is essentially, "Record channel X from this time to that time" not "Record 'Dancing With The Stars' whenever it's on"4. When you want to play back, all you see is, "Recording 1." No information as to title, channel or anything. If you have multiple shows recorded, you can't tell which is which.5. No partial playback. If you stop the playback and come back later to finish, you start over again and fast forward to resume.6. Remote is lame and not very responsive. No jump forward or jump back capability7. It's nothing like the cable-company DVR you have grown to like but are tired of paying through the nose forYes, it records, but it's really not worth it. They need to spend more time on the interface to add capabilities we all want.You also need to keep the tuner tuned to that channel during recording. So to record, it'sa. turn on the tvb. tune the unit to the desired channelc. tell it when to recordd. turn off the tvThe unit is fine as a digital tuner but it's really not a good DVR.

These batteries charge either with the included charger or the Panasonic factory charger. They seem to last the same amount of time in the camera. Fit and finish are fine. Excellent backup power for the Panasonic GH4.

Initially, this was a terrific accessory for the Panasonic GH4's light weight and electronic viewfinder.The promise to be able to remotely trigger the autofocus and then with a full press of the trigger either take the picture or begin video recording was attractive.In practice, however, the system causes the camera to take pictures or go into record (based on what mode you're in) virtually uncommanded. Not sure why. It's very annoying to carry the camera, look into the viewfinder to frame the shot, only to discover it's already been in Record for who knows how long.Secondly, the adapter cable has only one right angle connector.  Both ends are micro-phono plugs -- smaller than 1/8" headphone size. The right angled end has a tip/ring/ring/sleeve plug. The straight end has a normal tip/ring/sleeve "stereo audio" configuration. The instructions are very unclear as to which end goes where. I tried both and it seems that the right angled end goes into the camera. That leaves the straight end sticking out the side of the pistol grip.I like the coiled cord: it doesn't get in the way but reaches fine. It just puts a lot of pressure on the straight end connector. It would be way better if both ends were right angle.It has a 1/4-20 mounting socket on the bottom so you can add a wrist strap for security. Would have been nice if one were included. It's a lot of value on this grip and a strap would add a little peace of mind.In operation, it's like holding an old 8mm film camera, especially looking through the GH4's electronic eyepiece viewfinder. It adds comfort and stability. As the GH4 with 12-35mm lens weighs only 1.91 lbs (865 grams) you really don't need a monster shoulder rig.I was able to walk down a hallway at the 12mm position and Optical Image Stabilization engaged and the video came was pretty smooth -- easily as smooth as a shoulder mount.I just wish the trigger worked properly.

The table insert exactly like that that came with my Powermatic Model 66 original fit just fine. Over the years, it became increasingly tight, as if either the potmetal plate was getting bigger (somehow expanding) or the hole in the cast iron top was shrinking.It got so I had to tap it to get the plate to go into the hole and removing it was quite difficult. I often needed to pry it out to change blades.Eventually, I built a zero-clearance wood insert and put the original potmetal version away.I recently pulled out the old plate with an intention of sanding its edges down on my disc sander until it fit. I started removing material a bit at a time where it looked like it was rubbing.I inserted the plate into the hole, tapped it home and then tried to remove it. It was as if it had been swaged in place. Try as I might, I could not remove the plate. I attempted to pry it out with a block and long screwdriver though one of the finger holes, and, SNAP!, it broke in half.Like I said, strange indeed. Something changed size. Either the table hole or the insert.I'd like to use the insert, but I seriously don't believe it's worth $56, especially if it doesn't fit my table's hole anymore and I'll have to machine it down to get it to fit.Pretty disappointed....
Be aware that the picture showing this AC Adapter is not of the GH3 or GH4 battery shape. It is a DCC8 shape and will not fit. Hopefully, they send the correct DMW-DCC12 battery shape.

No assembly required. Keeps wood off the ground and easily accessible.Highly recommended.

I received a sample for review and here are my thoughts:Meh, this is an ok MP3 player, sound is fine but I didn't really like the controls.  Not at all intuitive. You would think the center button is the select button, it's not.  The built in games are fun, but hard to play due to the odd way the button layout works.  I down-sampled a video and it played it fine, this would be useful for the kiddos.  If you down sample vid to 400x240 you can fit a lot of movies on the device and keep the kids entertained on road trips, although the battery isn't the best so you'll need an auto adapter handy.I guess for the price it's an ok value, but I think you can get much better performance out of a cheap Android phone (can pick a used one up for about the same cost as this).

I received a sample for review and here are my thoughts:Overall: Comfortable, light weight, good sound and a great battery.The headset is easily light enough to wear without the ear-clip (easily removed).  If you're running or being very active you will want the clip though, while the headset stays in place without the clip it will fall off if you're moving your head a lot.The call sound is great and it has a good range.  I've been able to get about two days of use with moderate call time (few hours each day).The one button design is easy to get used to.  Long press to pair, short press to answer/end calls and to activate Google voice/Siri.  Sound quality is ok for music but this headset is tuned for voice calls so music sound a little light on the bass.Overall I would recommend.  Please feel free to ask any questions you may have in the comments below.

I was provided a sample for review and here are my thoughts:The are some of the best sounding hard-wired in-ear buds I've tried.  I would say they're even on par with the Bose IE headphones.  The Bose have a better dynamic range, but only an audiophile would notice the difference.  These produce deep bass without distortion, clear highs and smooth mids.  They do a great job of sealing outside noise as well.They're very comfortable to wear and I like the removable cord design.  This is going to do a great job of preventing shorts and if a short does happen, you can replace just the cable. The only con I can find is the end of the cables that plug into the earbuds have a stiff wire in them and it needs to be adjusted for total comfort.  I suppose this is there to prevent shorts from occurring though and is only a slight inconvenience.All-in-all great earbuds, great sound, very comfortable.

I was provided a sample for review and here are my thoughts:I have a few BT headsets like this, simple design with parts that go in your ear, and a wire around your neck.  This one is by FAR the best in this genre I've tried.  Sound is VERY good, call functions work as they should and it's VERY, VERY comfortable to wear.Like I said, it has really good sound for it's design and price point (MUCH better than a pair of LG Tone headphones I have that cost twice as much).  The fit is also very comfortable and they do a great job of blocking ambient noise, they really seal out outside sound.  Great bass, clear highs, smooth mids.  No distortion even at full volume.The only con I can see is the battery isn't the best I've seen.  I've been able to get about 2 hours of talk time AND about 2 hours of vid/music out of a charge.  NOT bad, but the LG's do last a little longer.  Personally, I think the MUCH better sound is worth the loss in power life.When they're paired to your phone and clipped together via the magnet, all you have to do is separate them to answer an incoming call - clip them back together to end the call, this is convenient.If you have any questions please feel free to ask.

I received a sample for review and here are my thoughts:I've actually received a few items from Eceen for review, and like the others, this is a great piece of tech.  The thing I notice most about Eceen products is the build quality, it's always great.  This speaker is no different.  I do have to admit I'm a bit of an Eceen fanboy, but it's with due cause, their products are are very well made.This speaker is great, not so much for the sound quality (it sounds good, but it's no Bose), but for the fit and finish, it's design and price point.  It has a beast of a battery, last forever.  Has a handy storage compartment to stash you phone (small iPhone will fit) or headphones, extra cables, batteries, etc.  Built in carabine/clip is very handy, I have mine attached to a shoulder sling on my chest and it works very well in this configuration.It's waterproof to IPX5 (can take a splash, but not submersion), the sound is slightly better than other $30 BT speakers (but unlike most inexpensive BT speakers, this one is actually stereo with two speakers), and I really like the design.  Eceen sent me a bike speaker just like this but with a mount attached to the bottom, at the time I wished it was a clip on design as I didn't need the mount, this fits the bill perfectly for a pack mounted speaker.It's plenty loud, no distortion, not much bass though.  If you want better sound you're going to have to spend more.  For the price this is a good speaker and with the added waterproofness, storage and build quality, it a great buy.  This speaker will be attached to my pack for the foreseeable future.If you have any questions please feel free to ask in the comment below.  Thanks.

I received a sample for review and here are my thoughts:I've tested and reviewed many solar chargers. Ranging from 7W-28W and have to say this is without a doubt the best bang for your buck.  It puts out the most power of all I've tried (including the 28W model when charging a 5V USB device).There are two USB out ports. a 2.1A and a 1A (see pic attached).  Using a Drok USB volt meter running from the charger (2.1A port) to a high capacity/high draw external battery pack, the charger was able to produce 10.2W (5.14V @ 1.99A).  I went to snap a picture and the power dropped slightly as I moved the charger to get a better angle for the shot (the picture attached is of 9.82W, 4.96V @ 1.98A).  This was done at 3PM, a couple hours past the optimum time to test a solar charger.  This is fantastic performance.  I'm quite sure it could do better too, but the battery attached was simply at max draw.The solar panels are of the monocrystalline variety.  They are flexible and you don't need to worry about dropping the charger and having a panel crack.The build quality is nice and robust with solid stitching and material around (it's all nylon).  It has two fold out legs to position it toward the sun (see picture attached) and four loops to hang it from whatever.  It also includes two small caribiners.  The mesh storage compartment is large enough to easily fit a 20,000mAh battery, the biners, and a USB cable (interestingly enough one was not included).All-in-all its a fantastic value for the money.  Less than two years ago this charger would of been a couple hundred bucks.There are plenty of pictures attached for reference, and please feel free to ask any questions you may have in the comment below.

I received a sample for review and here are my thoughts:1st off you need to realize these microfiber towels are much different than a regular terrycloth towel.  It's a thin, yet very absorbent material that also dries way faster than a regular towel. And unlike a regular towel will dry you even when wet.  Just ring it out and it's good to go.I have a few microfiber towels and this one is by far the largest and is the only one that arrived colorfast (it didn't bleed at all, the others I've tried bled terribly at first).The stitching on the edges seems good and the included case is well built too.  You will want to wash it before first use as it does leave some fuzzies on you if you don't.  Cold wash, hang to dry.If you're looking for a towel for the gym, traveling, camping, etc this is the one you'll want. Packs small and light while being plenty large enough to cover your body.  I love microfiber towels and this is the best I've seen so far.  The included hand towel was a nice addition too.If you have any questions please feel free to ask in the comments below.  Thanks!

5:41 Mins I received a sample for review and here are my thoughts:The folks that are leaving bad reviews really need to lower their expectations. This is after all, only a $100 projector. If you're expecting a full 1080 resolution with a lot of bells-and-whistles, then you're going to need to pony up the dough for a high-end projector. If you're looking for an inexpensive projector for the kids or backyard movie night then this is a great solution.I paired it with a inexpensive screen (http://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B00M6JXPHS) and built the frame for less than $30 out of PVC. Complete setup (projector, screen and frame) costs under $160The resolution on this projector is the same (but in a wide-screen format) as old school TV's. Imagine what an 80" tube TV would look like, that's exactly what this projector produces - and I love it. Setting it up in the backyard really reminds me of going to the drive-in as a kiddo. Pair it with a nice speaker and its a great experience.1000 lumens is plenty bright in a dark environment (it isn't too bad in a very dimly lit area either). It would be nice if it was a bit brighter, but for the money its totally acceptable.I paired it with a Chromecast and it works perfectly. Streams all the content on my laptop great and streaming Netflix from the Chrome browser works seamlessly too.Check the video review to see it in action and for more details.If you have any questions please feel free to ask in the comments below.

3:42 Mins I received a sample for review and here are my thoughts:This is a handy little endoscope.  Comes with three attachments: 1 magnet, 1 hook, and 1 mirror (the mirror one is useless).  The magnet is powerful and is very useful for finding and retrieving lost screw/nut/bolts and other light-med weight ferrous objects.  The hook is ok, haven't really had a use for it yet.  All three are kind of hard to attach to the scope - this is the only downside to the setup.I received the 1 meter version and it works really well.  This picture is bright (and the screen has auto exposure, if it's too bright it will dim to the right level), the LED's on the end of the scope are bright and very adjustable, and the image quality is very clear.  You can flip the image by holding down the + key.There's already a very detailed video review posted, just thought I'd throw my $.02 in.All-in-all it's a handy little device I'm sure I'll get plenty of use out of.  If you have any questions please feel free to ask.  Thanks!

All-in-all fantastic little charger that I would highly recommend.

3:19 Mins I was provided a sample for review and here are my thoughts:First off, this is a great little table. It's light, sturdy, unpacks & folds up easily and seems to be well made. Bare in mind its a light weight portable camping table and won't support a ton of weight (i.e. don't sit on it). There's no wiggle and everything fits together perfectly.I found two small drawbacks: 1) there are two "ribs" running across the table for support and they make the surface a little uneven. 2) the nylon surface is a little soft and anything with a small footprint might not be super stable. These are only very slight issues though and I don't see anyway around them without adding weight or making it harder to attach the tabletop to the frame.See the video to see what I'm talking about.  NOTE: I call the product by the wrong name by mistake in the video.The measurement are:16.5" wide x 22" long x 15" tallWeighs 34.6ozAll in all its an awesome table and I'm sure I'll get a lot of use out of it (I actually edited this video review while outside using the table!).Please feel free to ask any questions you may have in the comments below. Thanks!

4:22 Mins I was provided a sample for review and here are my thoughts:First off I have to say I was pleasantly surprised with the sound quality.  Compared to the Beat solo BT headphones these sound just as good, tuned a little less bass heavy though.  Crisp highs, full mids and mild bass, nothing sounds muddy.  Volume goes high enough you'll damage your hearing if you blast them for an extended period.  Padding is very comfortable, both on the ears and at the top of the head.The build quality is very nice and I think they look really sharp.  Fit and finish is great, the glossy black and matte red look great together.  The simi-hard case they come with a decent, but nothing to write home about.  Does the trick to protect the headphones while in your backpack or so on.Pairing was a snap and they can pair with two devices simultaneously.  Listen to a movie on your tablet and take calls on your phone at the same time (movie pauses when a call comes in and resumes once the call is ended).I've gotten about 6-8 hours of play time out of them (3-4 a day for a couple days) and have yet to have to recharge them.  Good battery life.All-in-all I think these are a great value for the price ($49.99 as of this review).  If you have any questions please feel free to ask in the comment below.  Thanks!

4:18 Mins I was provided a sample for review and here are my thoughts:I've actually received several Eceen products to review and have become a bit of a fan.  All their products so far have been outstanding.  They really pay attention to quality, both in terms of build quality and quality control.  This speaker is no exception.One thing that isn't mentioned in the listing (and I forgot to mention it in the vid) is that this is rated as IPx5 waterproof (can be subjected to direct low pressure sprays of water).  It's not meant to be submersed but it can withstand a shower or hard rain.  After I shot the video I wanted to test the waterproof-ness of it and put it in the shower, let it play for like 10 minutes and it came out fine.  It wasn't directly under the jets, but was getting a good bit of residual splash and it held up and continued to play and sound fine.  The interior stayed dry too (although the outside was fairly drenched, the material does soak up the watter a bit).  Unless you're in an insane typhoon or submerse it in water, I'm sure it'll work fine and keep the contents dry too.The overall build quality, like all Eceen products I've tested, is great.  Everything is put together nicely, no loose stitches, and it really feels substantial in the hand.The sound quality is good, nothing an audiophile would write home about.  But for the price, and the fact it's waterproof, and it's also a 4000mAh power bank, I was pretty impressed.  It's plenty loud, great mids and highs, a little weak with the base, but you really can't expect much more from something in this form factor.  It definitely loud enough you could use it on a moped or other small motorized device and still hear fine.Pairing is easy as expected.  Turn it on the first time, look for it with your phone and then connect.  It just works.  One note about the BT: In your device list it will show up as "K-95".  Woulda been nice if they actually named it Eceen Bike Speaker or something like that.  Oh well, just change the name as soon as you pair it to find it easily again later (although, you probably don't have like 100 devices attached to your phone like I do - lol)Regarding the power bank; it will charge my note 4 from 0% to 80% in about 60 minutes.  That's pretty impressive.All-in-all I love this speaker. Great build, good sound, looks sharp and is super versatile.  Check the video review to see it in action.If you have any questions please feel free to ask in the comment below.  Thanks.

4:38 Mins I was provided a sample for review and here are my thoughts:The video shows it in action if you want to get a feel for the sound.  It has a nice range although could use a little more base (can't really expect it to boom in such a small form factor though).  I love the look and the build quality is great too.Pairing is a snap using the NFC (not in the video but I did try it and it works quite smoothly). I REALLY like it's clear in your bluetooth list what it is, clearly labeled "VENSTAR taco".  Many of these Chinese speakers are simply labeled something like "C27" or "ABC1" or something like that, makes it hard to identify the speaker you're trying to pair.  Nice touch clearly labeling this in the device list.Getting to the charging and aux port is a little challenging but once you figure it out, it's easy.  See the video to see what I mean.All-in-all it's a nice little speaker.  Has decent sound, a great battery, very good build quality, useful case (includes carabiner)  and looks really sharp.

4:23 Mins I was provided a sample for review and here are my thoughts:This is a nice little rechargeable lantern.  The fit and finish is great, adjustments from "warm" to "cool" light works very well, and the capacitive "buttons" are awesome (they're not physical "buttons", you just touch your finger to them and they work - like your cell phone screen). It really reminds me of something from the movie Wall-E.I've been testing this light for the last few days and so far, I'm a big fan.  It goes from nice and dim (medium night-light) to pretty bright (light up a medium sized room well or a tent blindingly).As of now I've only had to charge it once initially. I've used it for about 5-6 hours and it's still kicking.  I've been using it to navigate around the house at night and as a bedside light to read by, and I love it.  The only caveat I have is that is uses a mini USB port and not a micro.  Not a huge deal, but limits the cables (I already have tons of) that can be used with it. It does come with a nice long mini UBS cable though.Check out the video review to see it in action.  Super versatile light that looks very cool, works even better, and is actually fun to play with.Please feel free to let me know if you have any questions in the comments below and I'll do my best to help. Thanks!

I received a sample for review and here are my thoughts:If you're looking for a THIN case with a kickstand this is probably the one you'll want.  There really aren't very many options for skin type cases that also have the kickstand functionality, in fact, this is the first I've seen.The case isn't going to protect well against drops but will do a great job protecting the back and sides from scratches. It is a thin but very well formed plastic case and fits the phone like a glove.The icing on the cake is the kickstand is also a clever micro USB cable.  Micro is standard type but the full size end is kind of like 1/2 a regular USB plug. You just plug it into the side of the port that has the larger opening, with the contact face down and it works great.  I was a little skeptical, but found it makes a great connection.  Can wiggle and move it and it stays put great.The case is a little gimmicky, but it is the only really thin type case I've seen that has the kickstand and the USB cable is very functional.  It's not going to provide much protection, but if you just want a thin type case with a kickstand this will serve your needs perfectly.  The USB cable is a great little bonus.

I received a sample for review and here are my thoughts:This is by far the smallest headset I've ever tried and it works quite well.  Range is decent, sound is good on both ends of calls, and the ability to plug in the other ear is great.It came with a plethora of ear pieces of different sizes and styles and several ear hooks if you don't like using just the ear piece (I found it works best with the swivel hook).The call quality is good (almost on par with my Bose in-ear headset), but the stereo is a little lackluster.  It isn't bad per se, just a little tinny and lacks punch.  I wasn't really expecting more though from such small headphones.I think the ability to convert them to stereo is what really sets them apart.  If you're looking for a single ear BT headset you can quickly convert to stereo for music and videos this is a great solution.
