I'm using these in a fan that normally takes 4 x 1.2V NmHi rechargeable batteries and the added 1.6v really upped the power.  The fan is also rated to take standard 1.5V alkaline batteries so it's just .4V over it's rated load, the fan's motor handles the extra power just fine. I wanted a way to have the higher power without having to constantly replace alkaline batteries and these do the trick well.I haven't had the chance to test their claimed capacity but it seems a little shy of 2500mAh for sure.  The run about half as long as the NmHi, but put out like 50% more airflow, still, if there were 2500mAh they should last about as long as similarly rated NmHi batteries.Other than that they seem to be quality cells and do put out considerably more power than standard HmHi rechargeable batteries.They do take a while to charge and can ONLY be charged with a charged meant for NiZn chemistry.

6:46 Mins I received a sample for review and here are my thoughts:First off, the design of this chair is ingenious.  It's basically a clone of the Big Agnes Helinox chair so we have to give them credit for that.  It's essentially built out of tent poles configured in a way that the chair supports your weight like a hammock stand.  The weight of your body is directed directly down into the poles, there's no lateral forces trying to bend them.  it's really a smart design.The chair is also light, very light.  It weighs 35.5OZ with the case. When you see the size of the chair the lightness is even more impressive.One feature this chair has that the Big Agnes Helinox doesn't, is the adjustable legs.  This allows you to raise or lower the chair and to also make adjustments for uneven or sloped ground.  Nice improvement over the Big A chair.All the materials have a nice fit and finish and the corners where the poles attached are robustly reinforced.  The poles aren't poking through this material anytime soon.  The poles are quite ridged, very little flex, and everything fits together very well.  The main material of the chair surface is the only thing I would worry about, just thin nylon and if there's a failure, this is where it's going to be.I do think you'll want to be gentle with it to keep the material from tearing or the poles from buckling though.  Shouldn't be a problem as long as you don't just slam yourself into it, treat it like an ultralight piece of gear.I've clocked several hours in it and so far I love it. I'm 180lbs and it holds me just fine with no flex.  The chair is also VERY comfortable.  You can recline or sit up straight.The best way to really get a feel for how the chair works, is put together and the material, is to check the video.I love chair and its definitely going to be my new go-to event and camping chair (and I have a LOT of camping chairs).  Just so light, comfy, clever and portable.  I dig it.If you have any questions please feel free to ask in the comment below.

3:34 Mins This is a sweet little sports camera.  While it only shoots in 720HD it produces great video at a fraction of the cost of a GoPro.The audio could be a little better (although in the video review I say it's worse than it actually is, I noticed it was better than I first thought when I was editing the review together).  Not great audio, but close to what you'd get on a cell phone video.The waterproof case it comes with is rock solid.  I tested it in a couple feet of water, squeezing/twisting/pushing all the buttons and it didn't leak a drop.  It feels very robust in the hand and the closing mechanism is solid.The camera has several modes of operation and options:Videos: 720P 480PPictures: 1MP, 2MP, 3MP and 5MPBurst photos (takes rapid fire pics as long as you're holding down the shutter button)Photo timer (2 or 10 second delay - they call this "time lapse" for some reason)Time Lapse in 1, 2, 5 10 and 30 second delays between shots (they call this "continuous lapse", but it is time lapse).  You'll need to stitch the images together in a program like PowerDirector to make the time lapse but the end result is really cool (and actually really easy to do).Looping video - this is great if you plan on using this as a dash-cam. Deletes the old as it records newExposure adjustment (+/- 2EV)Auto screen off (even while recording) in 30 second, 1 min, 3 min or offAuto power off in 1 min, 3 min or 5 minDate and time stamp on or offCan format the SD card from the camera but from what I can tell you can't delete individual vids or pics.Check the video to see the camera in action and hear the audio it produces.All-in-all for $35 you can't beat the deal on this camera.  Like all Chinese products the quality control can be hit or miss.  If you get a bad unit just exchange it for a new one.  It's worth the money savings in my opinion.I was provided as sample for review.

This is a great little mount.  The suction cup part is not only a suction cup, but also has a adhesive back that makes it insanely sticky.  It's the type of adhesive that you can wash if it loses it's stick to rejuvenate it.  It's pretty impressive.The magnet part works well, but I found I had to use the large metal sticker piece that is meant to go between your phone and a case on the outside of the case.  It worked ok in between the case and the phone, but I'm using it on a Note 4 with a large case and it just didn't provide enough oomph.  I tried sticking it to the outside of the case and it worked great.  Phone sticks to the magnet great.  I've attached a picture to see what the metal sticker looks like on the phone case.The mount does take a little getting used to.  While the phone does stick well, you have to remember you can't just hit the home key hard or the phone will come off.  Just takes a day or so and it become second nature to be a little more gentle with it.I love the convenience of it.  Just set the phone on it and go.  Don't need to open a clamp, just set it where you want it and boom, good to go.All-in-all I like the mount, the convenience and the super sticky suction cup are awesome.I was provided a sample for review.

There are plenty of rave reviews on this already, this review is basically just to reiterate that is a a great little charger.  All 4 ports put out up to 2.4A and it appeared to charge 4 devices simultaneously without problem and as fast as a wall charger (Note 4, S4, S5 and a Galaxy tab4).The fit and finish is splendid, the black looks great and the touch of chrome really makes it look high-end. It wasn't loose nor too tight in the cigarette adapter and the USB ports are perfect.  Everything plugged in nicely and nothing felt loose or was too hard to plug in.All-in-all this is a great charger, performs as advertised, looks great and is well built.I was provided a sample for review.

I received a sample for review and here are my thoughts:I'm a big fan of this fan, it puts out a nice volume of air and is also very versatile.  It can be used free standing and is nice a stable but the best part is the clip on the bottom.  I use it on our 4 month old daughter's car seat, stroller and high chair. I've also used it clipped on a beach/camping chair for myself and I love it.  It can be positioned at any angle you need, it rotates 360 degrees on two axises meaning you can position it to face any direction (front/back/up/down - it will face any direction while clipped to something).  The clip has rubber pads and is sticky and opens to around 3".It has an infinitely variable power dial, meaning 0-100% power and every step in between. Charges via micro USB (includes a cable) and uses 18650 battery (2200mAh battery included).If you're going to be using it with an unattended child I would highly recommend getting a better battery.  The included battery is what's called "unprotected", meaning there's no overcharge or short-circuit protection and these cheap Li-Ion battery have been know to leak or catch fire.  There's a VERY small chance this is going to happen but better safe than sorry.  A protected cell is a little harder to fit in the fan as they're a tad longer (the microchip built into the battery makes it longer).  You can pick up better batteries on Amazon for like $10 for a pair and they'll come with an external charger that will charge way faster too.  You'll want an extra battery anyway, if you're like us you'll use it a lot and it's nice to have a spare or three around.I tried to test charging time using the built in micro USB port and it took a long time, I fell asleep before it was done so I didn't get the time.  My best guess is 6-8 hours to fully charge it.  This is a non-issue for me though as I wouldn't expect an item like this to even charge the battery in the first place (icing on the cake I guess).  When using USB to power the fan it's not as powerful for some reason, even with a fully charged battery.Other than the cheap battery I love this fan.  The amount of air it moves and the versatility of it is great.  I would highly recommend it to anyone looking for a rechargeable, portable, clippable, small, freestanding, powerful fan.

This is a great charger, much better in my experience than the Samsung brand version.  The Samsung original charger (that cost substantially more) constantly had issues, would charge ok, then it wouldn't  - was very unreliable.  The cord that came with the Samsung charger was a dud too (although this doesn't come with a cable).This charger so far (three weeks) has worked perfectly.  The battery fits slightly better in this one too (nice snug fit, the Samsung was a tad loose).This is a great external charger, and as the description states it works well with an external battery pack to charge too.  I would highly recommend this charger - MUCH better value than the Samsung original.I was provided a sample for review (I asked for one as I was having issues with the Samsung brand charger) and am pleased LEMFO provided one to me.

3:21 Mins I was provided a sample for review and here are my thoughts:This is a very nice little dash cam for the price.  Look around Amazon and you'll see plenty of them that get well above $100 and for $37 (at the time of this review) this will do the job just fine.The video I recorded was good, but I only tested it in 720 mode and not 1080 (I only had a 2gb micro SD card and was worried about storage space on the card).  I imagine using it in full HD mode would produce better results (and you can see the video it captured in this video review).The menu isn't hard to figure out once you play with it a bit and the instructions are helpful (but typical of instructions that are translated from Chinese to English).  It has plenty of recording options (always record if the vehicle is on, start once it detects motion, capture still shots) and you can set it to record in low-def (240P) all the way up to 1080P.The only real gripe I had was with the audio quality - it's horrendous.  You can make out words and sounds but it's not clear at all.  For the purpose this camera serves I don't think it's a deal breaker though, this thing is made to capture video.  This is the reason I only gave it four stars.Check the video review to see it in action and for more details.Overall I'm pleased with the device and it has found a new home on my dashboard (there's been a million times I've wished I had a dash-cam and now I do).If you have any quesitons please feel free to ask in the comment below.  Thanks!

3:17 Mins I was provided a sample for review and here are my thoughts:When I first opened the packaging I was a little disappointed as the fan was smaller than I had thought it was going to be (although I don't know why I thought it was going to be larger).  The disappointment soon subsided once I charged the battery, popped it in and turned the fan on - it really kicks air for it's size.The battery it comes with is a very simple 18650 battery at 2200mAh (came almost fully charged). I charged it fully using an external battery charger I already had and then proceeded to test the longevity - it lasted right around two hours on high.  Not too shabby.  The fan must use a digital controller because it just stopped working when the battery died, didn't start slowing down/get weaker/etc.  Just up and stopped.  At first I thought there was a problem with the fan, but nope, popped in another battery and it was up and running again.There are three settings - high, medium and low.  Pretty standard really.  One thing the listing or other reviews don't mention is that there's also a small built in flashlight.  not terribly bright but perfect for finding your way around a tent or similar application.See the video to get an idea of size, see how it works and for complete details.All-in-all I'm very pleased with the little fan and know I'll get a ton of use out of it!  It really blew me away... (had to get that pun in here somewhere lol).  If you have any questions please feel free to ask.

I was provided a sample for review and these are my findings:First off, I found this to be a tough cable.  The nylon braiding makes for a cable that can be yanked, pulled on, so on and should resist shorts very well.  It's longer than your standard cable (twice the length), and the glowing feature is kind of cool.Like all glowing things (other than tritium), this needs exposure to light for it to glow.  It does glow brightly when exposed to light and it glows for a fair amount of time.  I've attached a picture of it in a dark room right after shining a flashlight on it and then in a well lit room about ten minutes later - it was still visibly glowing.Outside of the gimmicky glowing feature (that could be useful in a large dark gear bag), the cable performs very well.  Makes a great connection, has gold plated plugs, and is VERY durable.  Definitely replacing a similarly sized cable I keep in my gear bag, much better than your standard plastic cables no doubt.

At the time of this review this item cost $7, so totally worth the price.  I'm using it to mount a monitor to a rig I have set up.  I've attached a couple photos of it.It holds the monitor no problem, it would likely hold twice the weight easily.  The spring is robust and holds the clamp quite well, the rubber on it provides a nice grip too.The listing says it has a 1/4" and 3/8" mount, this is incorrect, its only a 3/8".  You can pick up an adapter for a couple bucks though.I'll be picking up a couple more of these as there's a million uses and the price is right.

I was offered a sample for review and wasn't sure what I would think about this battery, I'm usually a fan of larger capacity batteries.I read a review that said something to the effect of not enough power, well, it's only a 2600 mAh battery - it's not meant to charge an ipad, or even a smart phones fully.  What it is made for is an emergency top off and it does this very well.I tested it using a USB voltmeter (see the picture attached) and it PUMPED out power.  It put out 1.15Ah at 5.0V producing an impressive 5.75Watts.  This is 15% more than the rated output.  It charged my Samsung Note 4 from 50% to 90% in roughly 70 minutes.  Not bad for such a small form factor.  You have to bare in mind there is going to be loss and inefficiencies charging one battery with another, the smaller the battery, the more noticeable.  Charging my Note 4 40% would equal 1288mAh of usable power at 5V.  You'll also have to keep in mind when a battery is rated at a given mAh it's usually at 3.7V (the cells native voltage), more volts (i.e. 5V) equals less mAh.  This battery seemed to perform as rated for capacity and it over performed in terms of current.  Watts are always the best way to rate power (watts = volts x amps).There are no instructions.  Comes with a small USB cable.  LED blinks 1 time for low, 2 for med, 3 high.  This is true for both charging it, and while it's charging something else.Beside charging phones, this would be an ideal battery to charge things like Bluetooth headsets/speakers and other low capacity devices as it charges very fast.All-in-all I would recommend it for anyone looking for a super portable emergency battery.

I received a discounted product to review and these are my thoughts.First off, it's a great pack!  Well built, excellent stitching, lots or room, the large molle pack at the bottom can be removed and used as a waist pack.  It's a very nice pack overall.The reason it only gets 4 stars is when it arrived it had an atrocious smell to it.  Very chemical smell.  Monkey packs was more than helpful though, immediately sent a replacement. Alas, it too had a funky smell.  Not as bad but I did have to leave it outside for a couple days to air it out.I would recommend the pack, just know you may need to let it air out.

I was provided a sample for evaluation and here are my thoughts:I've tested a couple selfie sticks and at fist I didn't think I would find any use for one, I was wrong.  Turns out they can be pretty handy and add some creative freedom to your selfies.Of the three I've tested I like this one the best for a couple reasons.  First being it folds up compactly (the camera mount folds nicely back over the stick itself).  The second is it's fairly rigid.  One of the selfies I tried had a tendency to want to turn left or right from the weight of the phone.  Kinda a pain to use.  The other, while it had a better locking extension system (worked like a shower curtain rod, twist to lock, wouldn't rotate from the weight of the phone, but also got stuck and was hard to unlock sometimes), was very bulky, wasn't wireless and just didn't pack down well - no point in having a selfie stick if it's a pain in the arse to take with you.  This model also opens the widest to 3.5", fits my note 4 in a bulky case no prob.This selfie stick is does have some rotation from the weight of the phone, but it's not much and very manageable (like a 1/16 of a rotation, the other would turn 1/4 of the way around, very annoying).  It folds up very nicely and is by far the most portable of the three I've tried.It's a snap to pair to your phone, just hold down the power button for 3 seconds, it turns on and goes into pairing mode, find it with your phone and connect.  Takes 30 seconds (if that).  Charges via micro USB port at the bottom of the stick.The only down side is that it doesn't have a zoom function, this would be handy, but none in this price point I've tried do.  You also need to be sure to turn it off after each use or the battery will die - it doesn't have an auto off feature, bummer.All-in-all I would recommend it to anyone looking for an inexpensive selfie stick that it truly portable.

This is a VERY clever case.  It transforms from a small flat case into a case that is considerably larger.  Check out my video review of the whole Platypod Pro Deluxe Kit to see it in action.American ingenuity at it's finest!

Let the Earth Hear His Voice asks two questions of vital interest to preachers: (1) What is preaching? (2) How can we preach more effectively? The book provides answers to both questions that are biblically grounded, theologically sound, and proven by experience.Greg Scharf is a scholar-practitioner. He pastored three congregations in three countries, and now serves as chair of the practical theology department and professor of homiletics at Trinity Evangelical Divinity School in Deerfield, Illinois. He authored or contributed to several books on preaching, including the revision and abridgment of John Stott‚Äôs classic book, Between Two Worlds: The Challenge of Preaching Today, which was published as The Challenge of Preaching.In the Introduction, Scharf cites J. I. Packer‚Äôs definition of preaching as his point of departure: ‚ÄúChristian preaching is the event of God himself bringing to an audience a Bible-based, Christ-related, life-impacting message of instruction and direction through the words of a spokesperson‚Äù (emphasis in original). Elsewhere, he describes preaching this way: ‚ÄúGod speaks to people through people.‚Äù Chapter 1 provides a biblical and theological rationale for this lofty understanding of preaching.The remainder of the book ‚Äî Chapters 2 through 10 ‚Äî identifies eight bottlenecks that ‚Äúkeep God‚Äôs voice from being heard‚Äù in the sermon and then identifies strategies for overcoming them. The bottlenecks are:1. Unbelief (Chapter 3)2. Unqualified or disqualified preachers (Chapter 4)3. Faulty text selection (Chapter 5)4. Inadequate understanding of the preaching passage (Chapter 6)5. Inadequate contextualization to the preaching situation (Chapter 7)6. Faulty organization (Chapter 8)7. Inadequate or overused illustration (Chapter 9)8. Flawed delivery (Chapter 10)The first two bottlenecks remind us that ineffective preaching does not always occur because of deficiencies in what might be called the mechanics of preaching, e.g., sermon organization and delivery. Sometimes, preaching is ineffective because of the spiritual, theological, and moral deficiencies of the preacher. In other words, sometimes we ‚Äî because of little faith, no spiritual gift, or moral failure ‚Äî are the bottlenecks hindering God speaking to others through us. That is a sobering thought, and preachers would be well advised to think it.Still, for those called and empowered to preach, it is imperative that we hone our craft and become the best preachers we can be. Effective preaching cannot be reduced to considerations of text selection, organization, illustration, application, and the like, but it cannot be separated from them either. Scharf provides valuable advice about how to write and deliver sermons that deliver God‚Äôs Word to our congregations.I should note, in closing, that Scharf is writing out of the Reformed or Calvinistic tradition. (P&R Publishing is also Reformed.) I recognize that the Calvinist doctrine of salvation is a controversial topic in Pentecostal and charismatic circles, whose doctrine has been shaped by Arminian and Wesleyan understandings of salvation. That said, Let the Earth Hear His Voice is nonetheless a worthwhile read because it articulates a definition of preaching that is the common inheritance of all evangelicals, not just our Reformed friends. No Christian fellowship has a corner on all truth, so it behooves us to read and listen to those outside our own theological tradition. As Scripture says, ‚ÄúIron sharpens iron‚Äù (Proverbs 27:17). This book certainly sharpened me, and I believe it will sharpen you too.

A stylish, lightweight business card holder. Very affordable compared to similar products. The only downside I experienced was the long wait for delivery. (It came from China.) That's the only reason why I'm giving this a 4-star rating.

These sunglasses are well-made, stylish, and affordable. Comparable sunglasses at a local "hipster" store sell for three times more, so the price point is especially nice. The ear pieces are hinged, and the lenses are polarized. The only downsize I experienced was the color of the lenses. They are literally rose-colored glasses (hence the 4-star rating). Regardless,  Irecently wore them all day for 5 hours of driving in a bright sun, and my eyes felt rested the entire time. No squinting or eye strain.

The LUMINTOP TD16 is an excellent flashlight. Constructed of an anodized aluminum, it feels sturdy without being heavy. A button on the bottom turns it on and off, and a button on the side switches between its six modes: high-, medium-, and low-beam; strobe; flash and low flash. What's really amazing about this flashlight is how bright and far it shines. The price point puts it out of range for ordinary, household uses. I received a discount on mine and plan to use it for camping. The product details say it is designed for tactical use with firearms, but I can't speak to how well it does that. On the whole, I am very pleased with this flashlight.

To be honest, I‚Äôm not the kind of guy who reads books like The Key to Everything. For one thing, I prefer reading ‚Äútheory‚Äù books to ‚Äúpractice‚Äù books. For another thing, I am wary of authors who promise simple answers to complex questions, let alone the key to everything.Simplicity comes in at least two kinds, however. The first kind is synonymous with foolishness. In this sense, a simple person‚Äîa simpleton‚Äîlacks knowledge or expertise. The second kind pertains to science. In this sense, a simple formula can explain complex phenomena. Think of E=mc2 as an example.Matt Keller‚Äôs book is simple in the second sense. He believes that teachability is the key to everything. ‚ÄúWithout teachability,‚Äù he writes, ‚Äúyou and I will never reach our full potential or leave a mark on the world as we all desire to do.‚Äù He doesn‚Äôt discount the roles intelligence, hard work, or native genius play in achieving success, by the way. He writes: ‚Äúall the right stuff minus teachability equals the loss of tremendous potential.‚ÄùWhat is teachability? Keller borrows Roger Seip‚Äôs formula from Train Your Brain for Success: ‚ÄúDesire to learn times willingness to change equals our level of teachability.‚Äù If you desire to learn but are not willing to change, or if you are willing to change but don‚Äôt desire to learn, you have a low ‚Äúteachability index.‚Äù The goal is to have a high one.After defining teachability, Keller outlines common roadblocks to teachability: pride, fear, insecurity, pain, and pace. Keller uses the negative example of King Saul from the Old Testament to illustrate these roadblocks. He then goes on to use the apostle Paul from the New Testament to illustrate characteristics of teachability:‚Ä¢ insatiable desire to learn and grow‚Ä¢ appropriate view of success‚Ä¢ openness to feedback‚Ä¢ flexible approach to life‚Ä¢ ability to handle failure wellKeller concludes his book with guidance about how to develop a lifestyle of teachability. ‚ÄúTeachability is not something we can develop from a single session or a simple intention. It doesn‚Äôt develop in spurts and starts.‚Äù Rather, he writes: ‚ÄúTrue teachability is a lifestyle‚Äîand it takes practice.‚ÄùMatt Keller is a Christian pastor and leadership coach, so most of his readers will be fellow pastors or leaders of parachurch ministries. Though his book refers to the Bible, Christian business professionals can safely use it as a coaching tool in a secular business environment too.The Key to Everything is a short, easy read. Don‚Äôt let those characteristics fool you, however. Keller is on to something. Whether teachability is the key to everything, I still can‚Äôt say. But it is the key to quite a lot. As Proverbs 4:7 puts it: ‚ÄúThe beginning of wisdom is this: Get wisdom. Though it cost you all, get understanding.‚Äù

Although the majority of Americans continues to self-identify as Christian, American culture is increasingly post-Christian. Evangelical Christians could once assume the broader culture agreed with them about the existence of God, the shape of moral living, and the usefulness of religious organizations. They can no longer do so. The urgent question evangelicals need to ask and answer is how to minister the gospel in this new cultural environment.Timothy Keller outlines an answer to that question in Center Church. Keller is founder and pastor of Redeemer Presbyterian Church in New York City, and a New York Times bestselling author. Through Redeemer City to City, he mentors young urban church planters and pastors. Keller is also cofounder of The Gospel Coalition, a movement associated with the New Calvinism and the resurgence of a complementarian understanding of gender roles. As a Pentecostal, I disagree with both his Calvinism and complementarianism, though I hasten to add he doesn‚Äôt make them points of contentions in his book. Regardless, I believe that Center Church offers a theological vision of gospel ministry that repays careful consideration by ministers across the evangelical spectrum.Books about church tend to fall into two categories: what to believe (doctrine) and what to do (ministry). Center Church brings the two together in fruitful dialogue, resulting in ‚Äútheological vision.‚Äù Keller writes: ‚Äúa theological vision is a vision for what you are going to do with your doctrine in a particular time and place.‚Äù It develops ‚Äúfrom deep reflection on the Bible itself, but it also depends a great deal on what you think of the culture around you.‚ÄùKeller organizes his theological vision for ministry around three commitments: gospel, city, and movement. ‚ÄúBoth the Bible and church history show us that it is possible to hold all the correct individual biblical doctrines and yet functionally lose our grasp on the gospel,‚Äù he writes. ‚ÄúIt is critical, therefore, in every new generation and setting to find ways to communicate the gospel clearly and strikingly, distinguishing it from its opposites and counterfeits‚Äù (emphasis in original). Keller takes up this task in Parts 1 and 2, which focus on ‚ÄúGospel Theology‚Äù and ‚ÄúGospel Renewal‚Äù (or ‚ÄúRevival‚Äù), respectively.Parts 3, 4, and 5 focus on ‚ÄúGospel Contextualization,‚Äù ‚ÄúCity Vision,‚Äù and ‚ÄúCultural Engagement,‚Äù respectively. Keller writes: ‚ÄúAll churches must understand, love, and identify with their local community and social setting, and yet at the same time be able and willing to critique and challenge it.‚Äù These chapters are, in my opinion, the best in a very good book. We often think of missiology as the study of missions internationally‚Äîacross national, cultural, and linguistic boundaries. What Keller demonstrates is that missiological thinking is relevant intranationally‚Äîwithin our own culture. Evangelicals should not assume, as we have done for so long, that America is a Christian nation. We should rather approach it as a mission field and think of ourselves as missionaries to it.Finally, Parts 6, 7, and 8 focus on ‚ÄúMissional Community,‚Äù ‚ÄúIntegrative Ministry,‚Äù and ‚ÄúMovement Dynamics,‚Äù respectively. This last topic ‚Äúhas to do with your church‚Äôs relationships‚Äù (emphasis in original). ‚ÄúSome churches are highly institutional,‚Äù Keller writes, ‚Äúwith a strong emphasis on their own past, while others are anti-institutional, fluid, and marked by constant innovation and change.‚Äù Keller advocates a balanced position between tradition and innovation, drawing on the best of both.Indeed, balanced is a useful way to describe Keller‚Äôs theological vision throughout the book. Keller speaks of ‚Äúthe balance of three axes.‚Äù On the gospel axis, the Church must balance between legalism and antinomianism. ‚ÄúWe are saved by faith and grace alone, but not by a faith that remains alone,‚Äù he writes. ‚ÄúTrue grace always results in changed lives of holiness and justice.‚Äù On the city axis, the Church must balance between only challenging the culture and only appreciating it. ‚ÄúThis is based on the biblical teaching that all cultures have God‚Äôs grace and natural revelation in them, yet they are also in rebellious idolatry.‚Äù On the movement axis, the Church must balance between being an organization (focused on tradition and authority) and an organism (focused on cooperation and unity). ‚Äú[A] church at either extreme will stifle the development of leadership and strangle the health of the church as a corporate body, as a community,‚Äù Keller writes. ‚ÄúThe more that ministry comes ‚Äòfrom the center‚Äô of all the axes, the more dynamism and fruitfulness it will have.‚ÄùCenter Church is not a quick read. It is a 400-page, two-columned textbook. If you‚Äôre looking for easy answers or quick fixes, this is not the book to read. On the other hand, if you‚Äôre willing to put in the time and effort, reading this book will change the way you think about gospel ministry in a post-Christian era.

Preaching is not the only thing pastors do, but it is one of the most important things‚Äîif not the most important thing. Pastors thus need to work at perfecting their craft through constant attention to proper exegesis and hermeneutics, effective introductions and conclusions, and helpful outlines and illustrations. Because it is so useful in all these regards, John Stott‚Äôs The Challenge of Preaching should find a prominent place in every pastor‚Äôs library.First published in 1982 as Between Two Worlds, The Challenge of Preaching now appears in a third edition, abridged and updated by Greg Scharf, and published by Eerdmans. In many ways, it is a primer on preaching, an introduction to the craft. But like the best primers, it is a touchstone that helps experienced preachers test the quality of their preaching.Chapter 1 identifies three challenges to preaching: ‚ÄúDistrust of authority makes people unwilling to listen,‚Äù Stott writes. ‚ÄúElectronic advances have changed the expectations of both listeners and preachers. The atmosphere of doubt makes many preachers too tentative.‚Äù Despite these challenges, Stott believes preaching is a theologically necessary task, and in Chapter 2, he outlines its theological foundations focusing on God‚Äôs revelation, Scripture‚Äôs authority, the Church‚Äôs need of biblical renewal, the pastoral role of teaching and preaching, and preaching‚Äôs expository character.Chapter 3 identifies the essential task of preaching as building a bridge between ‚Äúthe biblical world and the modern world.‚Äù Theological conservatives typically focus on the former, while theological liberals on the latter, but Stott insists we must keep eyes on both. ‚ÄúWe must struggle to relate God‚Äôs unchanging word to our ever-changing world without sacrificing truth or despising relevance.‚ÄùStott next turns to how preachers prepare themselves through personal study (Chapter 4) and their sermons through careful organization (Chapter 5). Chapter 4 struck me with particular force. It is easy for many activities to fill pastors‚Äô calendars. Time for study becomes a luxury. If preaching is as important as Stott says it is, however‚Äîand I believe he‚Äôs on track biblically‚Äîfailing to schedule regular time for reading and reflection is failing to do one‚Äôs job with adequate preparation. In the short term, this can be managed, but in the long term, one‚Äôs ministry becomes spiritually, emotionally, and intellectually weak.Chapter 5 talks about writing one‚Äôs sermon. This is a nuts-and-bolts chapter that focuses on selecting the text, isolating the main thought, arranging your material, adding your conclusion, and then‚Äîwhen everything is in place‚Äîplanning an introduction that draws the congregation in and prepares them to hear the Word of God.Preaching cannot be reduced to the mechanics of sermon-writing, however. Who preaches is as important as what is preached. In short, the pastor‚Äôs life itself preaches the gospel and gives credibility to the sermon. Chapter 6 focuses on sincerity and earnestness. Stott writes: ‚ÄúTo be sincere is to mean what we say and to do what we say; to be earnest is also to feel what we say.‚ÄùChapter 7 focuses on courage and humility. ‚ÄúPreachers, like prophets, believe they bring a word from God, and are not free to change it,‚Äù Stott notes. ‚ÄúTherefore all preachers have at various times to choose between truth with unpopularity and falsehood with popularity.‚Äù This requires courage. But speaking unpopular truths can render us ‚Äústubborn or arrogant.‚Äù Like Elijah, we can complain, ‚ÄúI alone am left.‚Äù The antidote to this arrogance is ‚Äúa humble mind, humble motives, and humble dependence.‚ÄùThe Challenge of Preaching is a short book: 102 pages in the main body and another 23 pages in the appendices. It can be read in a single sitting. I highly recommend it to new pastors because it covers the whole range of preaching topics quickly and memorably. However, I also recommend it to veteran pastors. It has a diagnostic simplicity that will help them identify and correct bad habits they have developed.I conclude with one final quote that warmed my Pentecostal heart: ‚ÄúAt the same time [that we are studying] we should be praying, crying humbly to God for light from the Spirit of truth. Like Moses, we must beg him to show us his glory (Ex. 33:18). Study is no substitute for prayer; prayer is no substitute for study. We must do both. It may help to study on our knees, because this attitude reminds us that we worship the God who reveals himself in the Bible, and we are humble before him.‚ÄùAmen to that!

The Last Coyote is the third installment in Michael Connelly‚Äôs series of crime novels featuring LAPD homicide detective Harry Bosch. It begins with Bosch in a psychologist‚Äôs office, placed on involuntary stress leave for throwing his lieutenant, Harvey ‚ÄúNinety Eight‚Äù Pounds, through an interior office window. Until Bosch deals with his issues, his ‚Äúshrink‚Äù won‚Äôt recommend he be reassigned to the homicide table.Bosch‚Äôs issues begin with and center on the murder of his mother in November 1961, a crime never solved. In his spare time, he digs into the case and discovers that powerful forces in the City of Angels wanted the case to go unsolved. The more he digs, the more he uncovers, and the more he endangers himself and those around him.The pacing of The Last Coyote is a bit slower than the previous two books, which can be dangerous in a crime novel. However, in a long-running series (as the Harry Bosch novels have turned out to be), it is important to get into the lead character‚Äôs head in order to understand his personality and motivation. The Last Coyote succeeds brilliantly in this regard, giving us insight into Bosch‚Äôs cynicism, loneliness, and commitment to justice. The fact that the solution to the mystery follows a twisting path‚Äîwith an especially hard turn at the end‚Äîonly makes the introspection that much more interesting.

The Black Ice is Michael Connelly‚Äôs second novel feature LAPD homicide detective Hieronymous ‚ÄúHarry‚Äù Bosch. In it, Det. Bosch investigates the apparent suicide of a veteran narcotics officer named Calexico Moore. As Bosch delves deeper into the case, he is drawn across the border to Mexicali, where he uncovers layers of corruption and deception that shine an unpitying light on Moore‚Äôs apparent suicide as well as three other unsolved murders.One of the benefits of reading series novels rather than one-offs is that we get to discover what makes the leading character tick. Here, we begin to see the roots of the loneliness and cynicism that stem from Bosch‚Äôs tragic family history. We also begin to see how those very same experiences push to uncover the truth and find the killer no matter what.‚ÄúI found out who I was.‚Äù That‚Äôs what Moore‚Äôs suicide note said. The Black Ice will show you who he was‚Ä¶and who Bosch is.

The LORD by wisdom founded the earth,by understanding he established the heavens;by his knowledge the deeps broke open,and the clouds drop down the dew.Proverbs 3:19‚Äì20 express the who, what, and how of creation. Who? The Creator is ‚ÄúThe LORD,‚Äù that is, Yahweh, the God of Abraham, Isaac, and Jacob. What? He created ‚Äúthe earth,‚Äù ‚Äúthe heavens,‚Äù ‚Äúthe deeps,‚Äù and the ‚Äúclouds.‚Äù And he did so expertly, with ‚Äúwisdom,‚Äù ‚Äúunderstanding,‚Äù and ‚Äúknowledge.‚ÄùThese verses also express an ancient Near Eastern cosmology. Israel shared with its Egyptian, Syrian, and Mesopotamian neighbors a three-storied universe consisting of heaven, earth, and seas. Though there were variations in the details of these culture‚Äôs cosmologies, the basic three-tiered structure was the same.Modern people hold a very different cosmology than the ancients. We know, for example, that the earth revolves around the sun, not vice versa as the ancients believed. We know that the sun and the moon are not planets, as the ancients believed, and that there are more planets and planetary moons than the ancients could observe with the naked eye. Moreover, we know that our solar system is one among many in the Milky Way galaxy, which itself is one among many galaxies in an expanding universe.The differences between ancient Near Eastern and modern cosmologies raise questions in the minds of Christians about ‚Äúreading the Bible faithfully.‚Äù Kyle Greenwood outlines both questions and answers in Scripture and Cosmology: Reading the Bible Between the Ancient World and Modern Science. Greenwood is associate professor of Old Testament and Hebrew language at Colorado Christian University, whose Statement of Faith makes this declaration regarding the Bible: ‚ÄúWe Believe the Bible to be the inspired, the only infallible, authoritative Word of God.‚Äù Though readers of all perspectives will find Greenwood‚Äôs presentation informative, Christian readers with a high view of Scripture will find it most helpful.Scripture and Cosmology opens with a chapter about the importance of reading Scripture in context. In it, he states his book‚Äôs thesis: ‚Äúa high view of Scripture employs a hermeneutic that accommodates the biblical writers‚Äô immersion in their ancient, pre-Enlightenment cultural context. Therefore, as with other cultural matters, such as social customs and language, the biblical texts reflect that worldview in their written communications.‚ÄùPart One consists of three chapters that outline the similarities (and differences) between the cosmologies of the ancient Near East (specifically Egypt, Syria, Mesopotamia) and of Israel. Greenwood argues that both ANE and biblical texts assume a three-tiered universe consisting of the earth, the heavens, and the sea. He also contends that this three-tiered understanding of the cosmos serves as a better ‚Äúguiding principle‚Äù for the Old Testament various creation accounts than does Genesis 1‚Äôs seven-day formula.Part Two consists of two chapters that describe how the Christian church dealt with the challenges to this three-tiered biblical cosmology posed by first Aristotelian cosmology and then Copernican cosmology. Whereas ancient Near East cosmology depicted the earth as ‚Äúsmall, flat and round‚Äù‚Äîa disk, in other words, Aristotelian cosmology pictured it as a sphere. And whereas Ptolemaic cosmology put Earth at the center of the universe, with the sun, moon, and heavenly bodies revolving around it; Copernican cosmology put the sun at the center, with the heavenly bodies, including Earth, revolving around it. (Contemporary cosmologies understand that the cosmos is acentric; neither the sun nor the earth is the center.) What Greenwood writes about the Aristotelian challenge might be equally applied to Copernican challenge: ‚ÄúThe most notable trait we see among the Aristotelian-era interpreters is the willingness to adapt their interpretation of Scripture in light of new understandings of the physical universe.‚ÄùPart Three offers a theological rationale for this adaptation. Terming it ‚Äúthe doctrine of divine accommodation,‚Äù Greenwood explains the rationale this way: ‚ÄúGod condescends his language to the language of humanity. This is not to say that God is condescending but that he speaks down to the cognitive ability of his human audience.‚Äù He offers this example: ‚ÄúJust as a father uses simple vocabulary and analogical language to communicate complex ideas to his children, so the heavenly Father accommodates his language to his children by speaking to his audience‚Äôs mother tongue and also employing analogical language.‚Äù Applied to biblical cosmology, accommodation entails that God speaks to Israel and its surrounding culture in terms of a three-tiered universe because that is what it believed. Were God revealing himself to our culture, he would accommodate himself to our cosmological speculations.Over the centuries, accommodation has proved to be a fruitful line of thinking for Christians wrestling with the issues raised by a better scientific understanding of the physical universe. That doesn‚Äôt mean it is problem free. One wag has defined accommodation as ‚Äúthe theory which states that God goes along with the commonly accepted story even though he really doesn‚Äôt believe it.‚Äù Accommodation presupposes that we can neatly distinguish between what culture assumes about a given topic and what Scripture teaches about it. Christians largely agree that accommodation is a good strategy when the Copernican Revolution is on the table, but Christians vehemently disagree when evolution is. Perhaps this indicates that while accommodation is a good interpretive strategy, it doesn‚Äôt necessarily decide all scientific cases.Regardless, I commend Scripture and Cosmology for its in-depth look at the specific issue of biblical cosmology. It is well versed in the Bible and the texts of the ancient Near East, as well as cognizant of Scripture-science discussions throughout church history. And it is a thoughtful, irenic presentation of how to navigate the tensions between ancient cosmology and modern science.

Freedom of speech is a bedrock American principle. It is enshrined in the First Amendment to the U.S. Constitution, but it cannot be reduced to that amendment. Instead, as Greg Lukianoff points out in this Encounter Broadside, it reflects ‚Äúcultural values‚Äù and ‚Äúintellectual habits,‚Äù such as"giving the other side a fair hearing, reserving judgment, tolerating opinions that offend or anger us, believing that everyone is entitled to his or her own opinion, and recognizing that even people whose points of view we find repugnant might be (at least partially) right. At the heart of these values is epistemic humility‚Äîa fancy way of saying that we must always keep in mind that we could be wrong or, at least, that we can always learn something from listening to the other side."Lukianoff contends that these values and habits are under assault in America today, and he points to numerous examples to establish the point.The assault on freedom of speech cannot be dismissed simply as ‚Äúacademia‚Äôs fault,‚Äù the result of ‚Äúliberal groupthink‚Äù and ‚Äúpolitical correctness.‚Äù (Academia does play a crucial role, however, as Lukianoff‚Äôs Unlearning Liberty details at length. So does the political Left.) Instead, the assault reflects a social trend that can be seen worldwide:"people all over the globe are coming to expect emotional and intellectual comfort as though it were a right. This is precisely what you would expect when you train a generation to believe that they have a right not to be offended. Eventually, they stop demanding freedom of speech and start demanding freedom from speech."The problem with expecting comfort as a right is that‚Ä¶well, the real world doesn‚Äôt work that way. Even assuming that everyone is acting on their best behavior, diversity ensures that there will be disagreement in society about what is true, good, and beautiful. Far from helping resolve those disagreements, social rules and cultural norms that promote ‚Äúfreedom from speech‚Äù hinder reasonable resolutions of those conflicts‚Äîand even the agreement to disagree. Instead, freedom from speech requires power‚Äîuniversity administrators, government regulators, etc.‚Äîto impose a version of truth, goodness, and beauty on a diverse society that literally does not have a say about it.Far from promoting a tolerant, comfortable society, then, the right to comfort ironically creates victims and transmogrifies conflicts about fundamental principles into zero-sum conflicts about who wields power. In such a situation, reason loses and force wins. That‚Äôs not a good situation for democratic societies to find themselves in. Far better to allow Socratic gadflies to ask uncomfortable, even embarrassing, questions and to dialogue the way to reasonable answers. Unfortunately, that‚Äôs not the path contemporary American society is taking.

‚ÄúWithout careful attention, faith-based organizations will inevitably drift from their founding mission.‚Äù So write Peter Greer and Chris Horst in Mission Drift. The most obvious form of such drift is the outright secularization of the organization. But secularization doesn‚Äôt happen overnight. It is preceded by small compromises that, when put together, lead to fundamental changes in the organization.The purpose of Mission Drift is to help faith-based organizations avoid drift by paying careful attention to the practices of ‚ÄúMission True‚Äù organizations. Those practices include the following:‚Ä¢ Mission True organizations believe the gospel is their most precious asset.‚Ä¢ They make hard decisions to protect and propel their mission.‚Ä¢ Mission True leaders assume they will face drift and build safeguards against it.‚Ä¢ Mission True organizations have clarity about their mission.‚Ä¢ Mission True board members understand their top priority.‚Ä¢ Mission True leaders set the cultural tone for the organization.‚Ä¢ Mission True organizations hire first and foremost for heart and character.‚Ä¢ They partner with donors who believe in their full mission.‚Ä¢ They track metrics reflective of their full mission.‚Ä¢ They understand the gospel demands excellence in their work.‚Ä¢ They are fanatics about rituals and practices.‚Ä¢ They boldly proclaim their core tenets to protect themselves from drift.‚Ä¢ And they recognize that the local church is the anchor to a thriving mission.Greer and Horst devote a chapter each to these principles, illustrating them with both positive examples of Mission True organizations and negative examples of organizations that have drifted from their founding mission.‚ÄúNot all change is drift,‚Äù the authors acknowledge. Indeed, they argue, ‚Äúremaining Mission True will demand you change to continue to fulfill your mission.‚Äù Thus, faith-based organizations need to ‚Äú[d]ifferentiate means from mission.‚Äù The former change; the latter stays the same in a Mission True organization.I recommend this well-written, clearly argued book to the leaders of churches, denominations, and faith-based charities, both paid staff and volunteer board members. It will help them keep the gospel central to their organization‚Äôs reason for being, sharpen its missional focus, and help them keep it Mission True.

James Runcie, Sidney Chambers and the Forgiveness of Sins (London: Bloomsbury, 2015). Hardcover | Paperback | KindleI am an ordained minister with a penchant for reading mystery novels. It is not entirely surprising, then, that I so thoroughly enjoy The Grantchester Mysteries, which narrate the exploits of Sidney Chambers, a priest in the Church of England and an amateur sleuth. Sidney Chambers and the Forgiveness of Sins is the fourth installment in James Runcie‚Äôs series, and in my opinion, the best. (All of them are good, however.)Set in Grantchester, a village near Cambridge, The Grantchester Mysteries begin in the early 1950s, with Chambers as an unmarried priest. Forgiveness of Sins is set in the mid-1960s, and Chambers has married and fathered a young daughter. In addition to telling Chambers‚Äô story, the novels chart the tremendous social changes taking place in England in the Cold War period.As for the mysteries themselves, Forgiveness of Sins includes a man who thinks he has murdered his wife (but hasn‚Äôt), a physically abusive aristocrat who comes to a bad end, a Cambridge professor killed (accidentally?) by a falling piano, an engaged friend receiving death threats unless she calls off the wedding, an explosion at a public school‚Äôs chemistry lab that reveals the school‚Äôs dirty secrets, and an art theft in which Chambers finds himself the accused.The Grantchester Mysteries are gracefully written, character studies, not police procedurals. They are, as the series‚Äô website puts it, ‚Äúmoral fables in the tradition of G.K. Chesterton's Father Brown mixing crime, comedy and social history.‚Äù Although a crime is solved in each story, the emphasis is less on the how than the who. In other words, there is a focus on the moral character of the antagonists rather than on the methodology of their crimes. If you like hard-boiled detective stories, in other words, The Grantchester Mysteries are not for you. (They also deviate significantly from Grantchester, the Masterpiece Mystery series on PBS that was inspired by them.)Personally, I am ecumenical in my taste for mystery. I like character studies and police procedurals‚ÄîSidney Chambers and Harry Bosch. Each of those detectives, and the series written about them, are worth reading, even though they are entirely different ways of writing about crime.As I said, I think each installment in The Grantchester Mysteries is good, but Sidney Chambers and the Forgiveness of Sins is the best one yet. If you want to read it for yourself, however, don‚Äôt start with it. Start with the first book of the series, Sidney Chambers and the Shadow of Death. Then you can trace the arc of character development and understand why the characters relate to one another as they do.

According to a May 2015 report from Pew Research Center, ‚ÄúThe Christian share of the U.S. population is declining, while the number of U.S. adults who do not identify with any organized religion is growing.‚Äù Sociologists refer to this latter group as nones. When asked to state their religious affiliation‚Äîe.g., Protestant, Catholic, Jewish, Muslim, etc.‚Äîthey choose ‚ÄúNone of the above.‚ÄùNones constitute a rapidly growing segment of the U.S. population. According to data from the 2008 American Religious Identification Survey, nones nearly doubled between 1990 and 2008, from 8.1 to 15 percent. Pew‚Äôs own data indicate that the share of nones grew by nearly 42 percent between 2007 and 2014, from 16.1 percent of the U.S. population to 22.8 percent.For Christians committed to obeying the Great Commission (Matt. 28:16‚Äì20), nones are a new people group to be reached with the gospel. The question is how. In The Rise of the Nones, James Emery White provides an ‚Äúanalysis‚Äù of this demographic (Part 1) that explains ‚Äúa revolution of mindset and strategy‚Äù which the church needs to effectively evangelize them (Part 2).White has a good handle on both the intellectual and practical aspects of Christian ministry in an increasingly secular culture. He is founding senior pastor of Mecklenburg Community Church in Charlotte, North Carolina, 70 percent of whose total growth has come from nones. And he has a Ph.D. from The Southern Baptist Theological Seminary in Louisville, Kentucky.According to White, ‚ÄúThe real mark of a none is not the rejection of God but the rejection of any specific religion‚Äù (p. 23). In that sense, they are ‚Äúspiritual but not religious.‚Äù This spirituality does not turn them into ‚Äúseekers,‚Äù however. Rather, it is consistent with what Jonathan Rauch describes as ‚Äúa disinclination to care all that much about one‚Äôs own religion, and even stronger disinclination to care about other people‚Äôs‚Äù (p. 27).White analyzes the causes of this rejection of religion, and the worldview that results from it, in Part 1‚Äîan analysis that need not detain us here. Rather, I‚Äôd like to focus on the advice for reaching nones that he outlines in Part 2. White notes that most churches‚Äô outreach strategies ‚Äúrest on a single, deeply flawed premise that people want what you have to offer‚Äù (emphasis in original). In the very next sentence, however, he writes: ‚ÄúMore often than not, they don‚Äôt‚Äù (p. 89).Like Jonathan Rauch, many‚Äîif not most‚Äînones simply don‚Äôt care about religion. When churches send out slick mailers promising a church experience with a casual atmosphere, contemporary music, relevant messages, and good coffee, nones chuck them in the trash because they already have those things‚Ä¶without organized religion.What is needed is a new mindset, a mindset that is willing to change the way we do things in order to effectively reach a post-religious generation. Unfortunately, too many churches cater to the spiritual consumerism of existing Christians, even as they vocalize a desire to reach the lost. White doesn‚Äôt mince words: ‚Äúwe say we want them [i.e., the nones] in heaven‚Äîbut we act like they can go to hell‚Äù (p. 84).To reach nones, we need to think of evangelism as both a process and an event. ‚ÄúThe goal is not simply knowing how to articulate the means of coming to Christ,‚Äù White writes in reference to the conversion event. Rather, he continues with reference to the process of conversion, ‚Äúit is learning how to facilitate and enable the person to progress‚Ä¶[to] where he or she is able to even consider accepting Christ‚Äù (p. 93).The process of evangelism looks very different in a nominally Christian culture than in a post-religious society. In the mid-twentieth century, when Christian influence was at its peak and churches could assume most Americans identified with and had a basic understanding of Christianity, the process looked like this:Unchurched ‚áí Christ ‚áí Community ‚áí CauseIn other words, first unchurched people accepted the gospel, then joined the church, then starting supporting the church‚Äôs mission.To reach Baby Boomers, who had been raised in church but left it out of disillusionment in young adulthood, churches tried a different evangelistic process, which looked like this:Unchurched ‚áí Community ‚áí Christ ‚áí CauseIn other words, unchurched Baby Boomers needed to trust the church again before they could express commitment to Christ and support the church‚Äôs mission.White argues that the nones require yet another change in the evangelistic process, which looks like this:Nones ‚áí Cause ‚áí Community ‚áí Christ‚ÄúToday,‚Äù White writes, ‚Äúit is cause that arrests the attention of the world‚Äù (p. 101). Nones are interested in the common good, not personal conversion. Some Christians seem to be interested in conversion rather than the common good. Jesus was interested in both. ‚ÄúJesus wed mission and message together seamlessly,‚Äù White says, ‚Äúproclaiming the kingdom that had come while healing the leper and feeding the hungry. He mandated concern for the widow and orphan, the homeless and naked, the imprisoned and hungry while speaking of the bread of life and a home in heaven‚Äù (p. 102). If Jesus, so the church; we should be interested in both conversion and the common good too.Notice that White has not discarded the event of evangelism, namely, a call to repentance and faith. The strategy he outlines pertains to the process whereby nones see that conversion to Christ makes sense. ‚ÄúEven if it takes a while to get to talking about Christ,‚Äù he argues, based on ministry experience, ‚Äú[nones] get there‚Äù (p. 108).White‚Äôs discussion of mindset and strategy includes far more than I‚Äôve outlined in this review. To get that, you‚Äôll need to read the book. And I worry that a focus on cause may become as unattractive to nones as slick mailers advertising a ‚Äúcasual atmosphere‚Äù and ‚Äúgood coffee.‚Äù Nones don‚Äôt need to go to church to get coffee; do they need to go to church to get a cause? A church not committed to the common good is not representing Jesus well, but nones won‚Äôt necessarily come to Christ just because the church pursues it.Regardless, I recommend The Rise of the Nones for its thought-provoking analysis and guidance regarding mindset and strategy. I haven‚Äôt touched on all the points White makes, but I hope this review has given you a better understanding of the challenge of and a strategy for reaching nones. They‚Äôre not interested in religion‚Äîyours or their own. To get them to Christ, you must start with what interests them and draw them‚Äîslowly, patiently‚Äîto Jesus.

Like many people, I became aware of Craig Johnson‚Äôs Walt Longmire mysteries through Longmire on A&E. (Netflix has acquired the show and will air its fourth season). The TV show is a different beast than the books. While I enjoy both, I still prefer the latter.The mystery at the heart of Dead Bones is the death of Danny Lone Elk. Lone Elk owns a ranch on which a large, complete Tyrannosaurus rex skeleton has just been unearthed. The find is worth millions to whoever owns it. But Lone Elk‚Äôs ownership is contested among the federal government, the Cheyenne reservation, and the Lone Elk family. And then, of course, there‚Äôs the question of whether Lone Elk died naturally or was murdered.Longmire works through these questions in his characteristic Absaroka County way. There‚Äôs the patient questioning of witnesses, the mystical experiences, the encounters with a nature indifferent to human wellbeing, and the sly sense of humor.One of my favorite gags in this book is the stoically raised fist and incantation of the words, ‚ÄúSave Jen.‚Äù (Jen is the name of the T-rex whom the Absaroka residents want to keep at the local dinosaur museum.) Trust me, it gets funnier as the book goes along.I‚Äôm a huge Longmire fan. As much as I enjoyed this book‚Äîand I enjoyed it a lot and read it in one evening‚ÄîI didn‚Äôt think this was the best installment in the series. It‚Äôs not bad, mind you. (I can‚Äôt imagine a bad story by Craig Johnson.) It‚Äôs just not the best.Even so, if you like the other Longmire books, I know you‚Äôll like this one.

The American men‚Äôs relay team is an Olympics powerhouse. Since 1920, it has won gold medals at 15 of 21 Olympics. It did not do so in the 4x100 relay at the 2008 Beijing Olympics, however. Rather, it disqualified when Darvis Patton and Tyson Gay dropped the baton as they headed into the fourth leg of the race.When it comes to transitions between pastors and their successors, a lot of churches drop the baton. The reasons for this are various: lack of planning, poor choice of successor, the inability of a predecessor to let go of the ministry, unforeseen crises, etc. Whatever the reasons, Tom Mullins thinks churches can a better job of passing the leadership baton. In this book, he coaches pastors how to lead their churches through their own transitions.Mullins‚Äô advice can be summarized in eight action steps:‚Ä¢ Lead through transition.‚Ä¢ Keep the right perspective.‚Ä¢ Prepare for the win.‚Ä¢ Select and prepare your successor.‚Ä¢ Position yourself for success.‚Ä¢ Position others for success.‚Ä¢ Lead through crisis-driven transitions.‚Ä¢ Create a legacy.Mullins devotes a chapter to each action item. His advice is practical, experience-derived, and simply and winsomely written. Throughout the book, he reflects on how he transitioned leadership of Christ Fellowship, a multisite church in Florida, to his son Todd. He also cites the experiences‚Äîboth positive and negative‚Äîof other churches and Christian ministries.Near the end of the book, he captures the proper spirit in which church leadership transitions should take place: ‚ÄúTransition really comes down to being an issue of humility and surrender, if you think about it. All the practical things we‚Äôve discussed in this book have hopefully been helpful to you as you plan with intentionality and troubleshoot inevitable issues along the way to your own transition in leadership. But the most important thing to consider is the fact God‚Äôs work is for God‚Äôs sake‚Äînot your own‚Ä¶ When that is your realization, it forces you to a place of humility and surrender in the transition process because He alone is the priority, and His plans for His church are what matters above anything else.‚ÄùI highly recommend this book to pastors and their boards. It will be of immediate help to older ministers who are preparing to transition into retirement or other ministries in a few years. But younger ministers can benefit from reading it too. ‚ÄúTransition is not the only greatest test of your leadership,‚Äù Mullins writes; ‚Äúit is your legacy. Transition well.‚Äù

‚ÄúIf you‚Äôre leading, you‚Äôre bleeding,‚Äù writes Samuel R. Chand in his new book, Leadership Pain.That five-word sentence captures a crucial truth about leadership in general, and pastoral leadership in particular. Leadership is hard work. Rather than avoiding that hard work, Chand urges ministry leaders to embrace it.Pain comes in many forms. Chand writes: ‚Äúsome of our pain is self-inflicted, the accumulation of unrelieved stress. Some is the result of external challenges, and we suffer heartaches and headaches because we‚Äôre trying to grow and fulfill God‚Äôs purposes for our churches.‚ÄùConsequently, he goes on to say, ‚ÄúThe goal, then, is sometimes to avoid pain, sometimes to relieve pain, sometimes to create the pain of growth, but always to learn the lessons God has for us in the midst of our pain.‚ÄùLeadership Pain shifts back and forth between these two emphases, between identifying the form of pain and naming the goal in responding to it.Two lessons in the book stood out in particular to me, or rather, two quotations: The first comes at the beginning of the book, in which Chand offers this hypothetical syllogism:Growth = ChangeChange = LossLoss = PainThus, Growth = PainThe second comes at the end, when Chand writes: ‚ÄúDon‚Äôt run from your pain. Don‚Äôt deny that it exists. It‚Äôs the most effective leadership development tool the world has ever known. You‚Äôll only grow to the threshold of your pain, so raise it!‚ÄùThere‚Äôs a lot of wisdom in those two observations, as well as in the intervening pages of this book.

On February 25, 1956, Nikita Khrushchev delivered a speech to a closed session of the 20th Party Congress of the Communist Party of the Soviet Union. The speech, which was formally titled ‚ÄúOn the Cult of Personality and Its Consequences,‚Äù criticized Josef Stalin, his prosecution of the Great Patriotic War (World War II), his multiple purges of the armed forces and party leadership, and other politically driven crimes against the Soviet people.Tom Rob Smith uses Khrushchev‚Äôs speech as his point of departure in The Secret Speech, the second volume in his Child 44 trilogy. The question it ponders is this: When the State becomes criminal, can criminals exact justice? As always, Leo Demidov is at the center of the action, traveling from Moscow to Kolyma to Budapest to uncover the truth and protect himself and his family in the process. As with Smith‚Äôs other volumes in this series, the pacing is swift and the plot twists are sharp.Highly recommended, but read the books in order of the series!

A serial killer haunts the western Soviet Union in 1953. According to Communist Party doctrine, such a crime cannot exist in a socialist country, where the State has eliminated inequality and poverty and hence the crimes that arise from them. To assert that a serial killer exists‚Äîlet alone to track him down and seek his punishment‚Äîis thus a counterrevolutionary act, a crime that the State takes seriously and punishes severely.Leo Stepanovich Demidov is a decorated hero of the Great Patriotic War and a loyal soldier of the MGB (predecessor of the KGB). Married, and with a promising career before him, he must confront a colleague and friend whose child is the forty-fourth victim of a serial killer whose very existence the State denies. Caught between his loyalty to the State and the evidence plain to anyone with eyes to see, Demidov dares to follow the truth and pursue a killer who must be stopped, In the process, he reveals a horrifying truth about Soviet history that explains the killer‚Äôs actions.In Child 44, Tom Rob Smith captures the contradictions, paranoia, and massive evil of the Soviet Union during Stalin‚Äôs final year. It is a riveting page-turner of a mystery, not to mention a complex meditation on what it mean to pursue justice in a fundamentally unjust society. This is the first volume in a trilogy‚ÄîThe Secret Speech and Agent 6 are the succeeding volumes‚Äîall of which are highly recommended.

Agent 6 is the third book in Tom Rob Smith‚Äôs Child 44 Trilogy. It follows ex-KGB officer Leo Demidov over three decades and across three continents as he seeks to unravel a conspiracy and avenge the murder of a loved one. Usually, when I read a series that features a central character, I try to read the books in order. I didn‚Äôt do that with Agent 6 because it arrived before the other two, and I wanted to crack it open immediately. I‚Äôm not sure if I missed any necessary backstory; I‚Äôll find that out when I read the Child 44 and The Secret Speech. What I‚Äôm sure of is this: This was an engrossing read. I picked it up and couldn‚Äôt put it down until I finished it. For me, that‚Äôs the mark of a good mystery: It grabs you and won‚Äôt let you go until you see the solution. I look forward to reading Smith‚Äôs other books.

When his sister Ruthie died, Rod Dreher found himself drawn back to his hometown of Starhill, Lousiana. He appreciated Ruthie‚Äôs ‚Äúlittle way‚Äù‚Äîher life of close-knit family, down-home neighbors, and ordinary kindness that, though not garnering headlines, was nevertheless rich in love. While happily married with children, Dreher felt that Ruthie‚Äôs ‚Äúlittle way‚Äù supplied was lacking in his and his family‚Äôs urban existence; so, they moved to Starhill.The problem was that Dreher had left Starhill for a reason: The inability of his family‚Äîespecially his father, but even Ruthie herself‚Äîto understand any way that wasn‚Äôt their way. The family had stayed put; Dreher had traveled abroad. They were Methodist; he was Methodist-turned-agnostic-turned-Catholic-turned-Orthodox. They did stuff; he read books and wrote articles.Ruthie‚Äôs death didn‚Äôt resolve the conflicts that arose from their mutual incomprehension; it only exacerbated them. Soon after returning home, Dreher was diagnosed with Epstein-Barr virus, one of the leading symptoms of which is stress-induced fatigue. In Starhill, Dreher was constantly stressed and chronically fatigued. ‚ÄúWell,‚Äù his rheumatologist told him, ‚Äúyou have a choice. Leave Lousiana, or resign yourself to destroying your health.‚ÄùDreher felt that wasn‚Äôt a choice. There must be a way to stay put and find inner peace. While browsing a book store not long after the conversation with his doctor, Dreher chanced upon Dante‚Äôs Inferno, the first of three volumes in The Divine Comedy. How Dante Can Save Your Life is the story of how Dante saved his.The Divine Comedy‚Äîif you remember‚Äîis the story of how Dante makes a pilgrimage through Hell and Purgatory until he reaches Heaven. But as Dreher points out, ‚ÄúTo read Dante literally is to misunderstand him.‚Äù Dante is not writing a travelogue of the afterlife; he is drawing a map of the inner life. ‚ÄúThe Commedia is written as an allegory of the soul‚Äôs journey through life,‚Äù Dreher points out; it is ‚Äúabout avoiding hell and gaining heaven.‚Äù He continues: ‚ÄúTo be saved is not to be saved from the consequences of sin but to be freed from the desire to sin‚Äîthat is, from the desire for our own will over God‚Äôs.‚ÄùThis desire for self-will over God‚Äôs loving will, Dreher realized, was the cause of his family‚Äôs estrangement and the source of his own sickness. Dreher the Orthodox Christian did not agree with all the details of Dante the Catholic poet‚Äôs theology‚Äînor do I the Pentecostal reader, but that disagreement doesn‚Äôt mean discounting Dante‚Äôs brilliant spiritual insights into ‚Äúthe Love that moves the sun and all the other stars.‚Äù And in finding that godly love, Dreher found himself whole.Those looking for an introduction or running commentary on The Divine Comedy should look elsewhere than this book. It‚Äôs not for them. Those looking for a self-help book that doesn‚Äôt rely on the structure and reasoning of a 700-year-old poem also should look elsewhere. But those who believe that great books have therapeutic value if read insightfully and personally will be delighted by Dreher‚Äôs testimony and the gentle nudge he presses on readers to follow in Dante‚Äôs path.

‚ÄúWhat we want is not more little books about Christianity,‚Äù C. S. Lewis once said in an address on Christian apologetics, ‚Äúbut more little books by Christians on other subjects‚Äîwith their Christianity latent.‚ÄùI thought of Lewis‚Äôs remarks as I read Joel C. Rosenberg‚Äôs new thriller, The Third Target. The plot centers on New York Times reporter J. B. Collins, whose sources have informed him that ISIS has captured a cache of chemical weapons from the Syrian government. As Collins pursues this story across three continents, he and his friends are drawn deeper into the violent clash between Islamic terrorists and the civilized world.What makes Collins‚Äô investigation even more pressing is that King Abdullah II of Jordan‚ÄîCollins uses the real monarch as a heroic character in his plot‚Äîhas somehow managed to broker a peace deal between the Israelis and Palestinians. There is a real chance that ISIS might use its captured Syrian WMDs to scuttle the peace deal and prosecute war inside the moderate Hashemite kingdom.It‚Äôs difficult to summarize the plot of The Third Target in a way that both reveals how gripping a read it is while leaving the cover on its plot twists and turns. Perhaps it is enough to say that I enjoy thrillers that involve a desperate race against time, found the book‚Äôs plot believable and pace exciting, and was stunned by the book‚Äôs ending.But here‚Äôs where Lewis‚Äôs quote comes into play. Rosenberg is an evangelical Christian, and Tyndale is an evangelical Christian publishing house. Rather than making his Christian faith latent, Rosenberg has chosen to make it patent, and this patency detracts from the value of the story he tells.J. B. Collins, we learn, is nonreligious. His mother and brother aren‚Äôt, however. They are evangelical Christians. Indeed, his brother Matthew is a professor of theology at Gordon-Conwell Theological Seminary in Hamilton, Massachusetts‚Äîa school I myself briefly attended. Rosenberg uses Matthew to give voice to two evangelical interests: biblical evangelism and personal prophecy. In a long conversation with his brother, Matthew explains the contemporary relevance of biblical prophecies concerning the territories that constitute modern-day Jordan. Additionally, Matthew repeatedly presses J. B. to come to Jesus before it‚Äôs too late.Of these two interests, the latter‚Äîthe concern for religious conversion‚Äîcould‚Äôve been presented in a way that felt more integral to the plot. Faced with the death of people on every side, J. B. begins to ponder his own fate. Is he ready to die? Is there life after death? Psychologically, these are natural questions for people to ask themselves when death comes calling. My complaint is not that Rosenberg included the matter of religious conversion in the plot, but that he did so in such a ham-fisted way.His treatment of biblical prophecy is what annoyed me most, however. The Hashemite Kingdom of Jordan encompasses territory that in Bible times belonged to Moab, Ammon, and Edom (moving from north to south). These kingdoms are mentioned throughout the Old Testament in the Law, the Prophets, and the Writings. Rosenberg believes prophetic references to these kingdoms have contemporary relevance. By placing such prophetic interpretations in the mouth of a Gordon-Conwell professor, he gives them a patina of academic respectability. To be honest, however, I‚Äôm not sure any scholar at that institution would treat the prophecies as he has done. In other words, his use of biblical prophecy does not seem credible and‚Äîmore importantly in a work of literature‚Äîdoes not move the plot forward. In a race-against-time thriller, such slowing down is a cardinal sin.Now, I recognize that my fellow evangelicals will shake their heads and tut-tut at my review for expressing online my reservations about the prophetic and evangelistic elements of the book. But here‚Äôs the deal: The secret of good novel writing is showing rather than telling. The good parts of Rosenberg‚Äôs book show; the parts that slow him down tell. The Third Target would‚Äôve been a much better book had Rosenberg integrated the comfort of faith in the face of death into his plot in a more integral way and left out the Bible prophecy material entirely.Rosenberg is a terrific writer. But next time, he should steal a page from Lewis.

William J. Bennett and Robert A. White, Going to Pot: Why the Rush to Legalize Marijuana Is Harming America (New York: Center Street, 2015). Hardcover | Kindle‚ÄúWe are at a curious, as well as critical, moment in our country,‚Äù write William J. Bennett and Robert A. White in their new book, Going to Pot. ‚ÄúWe are spending money and political capital on strengthening the health, education, and productivity of our populace, yet society believes it appropriate to push for greater availability of a drug that hinders, and negatively affects (perhaps dramatically), those very efforts.‚Äù That drug is marijuana.Americans‚Äô sea change of opinion on marijuana legalization has been slow but dramatic. In 1969, when Gallup began polling the issue, 84 percent of Americans opposed legalization, 12 percent supported it. By 2013, however, 58 percent supported it, 39 percent opposed. Support fell back to 51 percent in 2014, but the overall trendline is clear: Americans support marijuana legalization. Given that younger adults (ages 18 to 29) overwhelmingly support legalization‚Äîat 67 percent‚Äîproponents of continued marijuana prohibition face an uphill battle both in public opinion and at the polls.Bennett and White‚Äôs main goal in writing Going to Pot is ‚Äúto stop the juggernaut of legalization.‚Äù Their argument against it focuses on raising public awareness of two issues: ‚Äúthe higher potency of today‚Äôs marijuana‚Äù and ‚Äúthe ever-increasing body of scientific evidence documenting the many adverse consequences of smoking marijuana.‚ÄùRegarding potency, Bennett and White write: ‚ÄúThe average amount of THC in marijuana today, the primary psychoactive ingredient in the drug, is about 9.6 to 13 percent, more than double the potency of marijuana in 1983, which was more than double what it was the decade before.‚Äù Researchers at the University of Mississippi have identified strains with THC levels of 37 percent.Increased potency levels entail that ‚Äúthere really are two different conversations taking place,‚Äù the authors write. ‚ÄúOne is based on a frame of reference of marijuana that was experienced in the past, was weaker, and does not exist today.‚Äù This is the pro-legalization argument used by Baby Boomers who smoked joints back in the 1960s. ‚ÄúThe other is based on the reality of marijuana that is grown, processed, and sold today.‚ÄùRegarding the use of higher potency marijuana, Bennett and White cite a number of medical and scientific studies to document its adverse health effects. They include a 2014 study from The New England Journal of Medicine (NEJM) at the end of the book because its results typify what the other studies show.Titled, ‚ÄúAdverse Health Effects of Marijuana Use,‚Äù the study concludes, ‚ÄúMarijuana use has been associated with substantial adverse effects, some of which can be determined with a high level of confidence.‚Äù It goes on to say, ‚ÄúMarijuana, like other drugs of abuse, can result in addiction. During intoxication, marijuana can interfere with cognitive function (e.g., memory and perception of time) and motor function (e.g., coordination), and these effectives can have detrimental consequences (e.g., motor-vehicle accidents). Repeated marijuana use during adolescence may result in long-lasting changes in brain function that can jeopardize educational, professional, and social achievements.‚Äù (The mention of adolescent marijuana use should remind us that while legalization is intended for adult use, the unintended consequence is increased use by minors. They are legalization‚Äôs primary victims.)The authors acknowledge that THC has legitimate medical uses, such as ‚Äúcachexia, multiple sclerosis spasticity, and vomiting [associated with chemotherapy],‚Äù among others.
