The Vachanamrut is to Hinduism somewhat like the Book of Mormon is to Christianity.This is a good book to read from anyone looking to better understand fundamental Hinduism, and is absolutely essential for any person seeking to understand the Swaminarayan Sampraday, particularly the popular and influential Bochasanwasi Shri Akshar Purushottam Swaminarayan Sanstha (BAPS).

Fodor has been doing a guide like this for a long time, and it's a well refined product.  The coverage is exhaustive but, more than anything, the balance of content between details about the cruise lines, points of embarkation and ports of call is just about perfect.  There's no one area that gets deep, detailed coverage, and that type of content is really not appropriate for a cruise anyway.  This book is written with the knowledge that your time spent at any given location is going to be relatively short, so it covers the highlights only.But what a wide swath of the world it includes!  Everywhere from Galveston, Texas to Bermuda, all the way down to Cartagena and up to New York.  It's all got a place in this book.  Then there's the coverage of the cruise ships themselves.  This book will really help you select a cruise that is to your taste and budget.  There's enormous variety.  Keep in mind that this book is really about cruising, so there is a lot of practical information about how to select and plan a cruise.  If glossy color content is what you're looking for, this is NOT your book.We've found that on our two cruises with Disney this guide was spot on, and that shows a real working knowledge of the region and its cruise operators.  This is not simply a compilation of material available on the Internet.

Virginia is so smothered in important and beautiful historic architecture that any survey of the state's buildings is summary by definition.  So, what you get here are the highlights, but that does not diminish the quality of the volume.  The sample of structures is absolutely representative, if not exhaustive, and covers most of the major landmarks you're going to expect.  I am particularly pleased with the relatively comprehensive treatment of three very important towns - Staunton, Lynchburg and Petersburg.The format is carried over from earlier volumes in this series, and is arranged geographically by county.  About one out of every four entries includes a small black & white photograph.  These books are NOT intended to be picture books, but are directories of buildings written in a style similar to an AIA guide.  Entries are accompanied by a short descriptive paragraph of the structures' architectural history and features.  Each chapter is introduced with a paragraph which places the towns and sites within larger historical context.  These written pieces contribute significantly to the interpretation of the architecture and should not be skipped.  Sometimes, additional sites appear within the written material rather than as separate entries.Coverage of the Valley is probably most complete, and coverage of the Southwest is thinnest.  That's really too bad because Washington County alone has so many lovely Federal buildings that need to be surveyed and cataloged.  These regions are particularly interesting because they form a large part of the first colonial frontier, with a built environment more pragmatic and vernacular than the high-style examples of the Tidewater.These books are expensive, but they require an enormous amount of research and editing.  Really, they are a labor of love for their authors, and the quality of each volume is a direct reflection of the contributors' enthusiasm for this subject.  I would highly recommend the book to architects, architectural historians, craftsmen, local historians, and serious heritage tourists with an interest in this part of Virginia.

I live in Houston and I'm constantly looking for things to do that don't require me to buy an airplane ticket.  I've found a solution in this book.Austin and San Antonio don't really need introduction, but Hill Country is the beautiful rural surroundings of these two urban gems featuring beautiful limestone landscapes, lovely German villages, and wineries and restaurants to satisfy any sophisticated foodie.This is not a large book, but the quality is very high.  The author has a gift for concise and engaging language that makes the most of its brevity.  The lodging and dining listings are comprehensive and right up to date.  Activities included are diverse, from interesting music venues to outdoor activities.  The book even includes coverage of the new Circuit of the Americas race track.  Sprinkle all this together with interesting sidebars like "Unusual Things You'll Notice" and you've got a fantastic guidebook.I would say that the coverage of Austin is most complete, while San Antonio and Hill Country are only slightly less so.  The Hill Country, with its beautiful rolling low mountains, fields of wildflowers and live oaks perhaps deserves a bit more attention, but the attraction of the land and its small villages doesn't lend itself easily to capture in a guidebook of "sights."  Otherwise, the recommendations are well thought through and reflect an honest working knowledge of this region and its unique character.I especially recommend this guide to visitors from abroad (or from a different part of North America) who may maintain certain stereotypical images of this part of the world.

These new Frommer's Easy Guides are hit and miss.  This one is a bull's eye.There are really two things that make this guide outstanding.  First, the listings are comprehensive and right up to date.  If it's new and hot, or old and classic, you can be sure it's included here.  New Orleans is absolutely crammed with superb dining, lodging, shopping, and hopping options, and the sample included here is selected for quality and authenticity.  Second, the physical, geographic coverage is exhaustive.  Sure, the French Quarter is well represented, but so are other interesting locations.  There are separate sections for Mardi Gras and Jazz Fest, so this is a good guide for planning trips to those festivals.It includes excursions to River Road plantations and to Cajun Country without diluting its coverage of New Orleans proper.Despite its modest price and a couple factual errors (LSU is most definitely not in Lafayette), this is the best New Orleans guide I've used to date.

Jim Morekis knows this area, and his insights display an enthusiastic authenticity.  His writing style is both engaging and witty, making this guide a pleasure to read.  Jim understands that, though these deeply historic Southern "capitals" share some physical similarities, they are sprung from different mothers:  Savannah is an English colonial city, formal and planned, while Charleston is a Caribbean city, organic and more akin to Nassau or Bridgetown.This is the best guide currently available for Charleston and Savannah, though I believe it is still too brief.  Brevity aside, Jim's recommendations are spot on, and the listings he has chosen are sure to provide travelers with an exciting, authentic experience.  There is coverage of sights, activities and listings for a variety of tastes and budgets, from the historian to the party animal.  There are many sidebars and special interest sections (Literary Lark, African-American history, Civil War, etc...) that add diversity to the guide and make it more than a directory of tourist sights.The chapter on Savannah is particularly good, since this is the place where Jim is most in his element.  The side trip to Beaufort is a nice addition, and Beaufort is a beautiful town well worth your time, but it consumes space in the guide that should be allocated to more from Charleston and Savannah.

This is not a bad book, it's just too small.Charleston and Savannah are such lovely destinations that they deserve 1) a guide completely independent of other area destinations such as Hilton Head, Myrtle Beach and Beaufort, and 2) a book comprehensive enough that prospective visitors get a feel for the real diversity and historical authenticity of the respective cities.This book, unfortunately, does neither of those things.  Sure, at least it's got the facts right, and the author is obviously both informed and enthusiastic, but where's the beef?  It's the same old tourist destinations written with the same old tepid recommendations.  In two cities where historic architecture is a major, MAJOR draw, a book like this should feature at least 20 sites from each, minimum.  Listings of hotels should be as comprehensive as possible.  I've yet to find a Charleston travel guide that mentions the best small boutique hotel in the city, Zero George, anywhere within its pages.  A listing of Charleston restaurants that fails to mention Slightly North of Broad is, quite simply, incomplete.So I'll get off my soapbox.  This book is not going to steer you wrong, but it's not going to give you the tools to appreciate the full scope of Charleston and Savannah attractions either.

No, no, no.  While the author's intention is good, I just can't help but cringe every time I read something like "Hurricane Hugo devastated the city, destroying three-quarters of the homes in the Historic District."  Then he continues, "urban renewal in the 20th century leveled many landmark structures."  These statements may seem dramatic, but they are simply false.  Charleston is known world wide for its amazing state of preservation, for the fact that urban renewal did NOT level many landmark structures.Hurricane Hugo caused a mess, no doubt, but it came nothing close to destroying 75% of the homes in the "Historic District."  First of all, Charleston has many, not one, historic districts.  And few, if any, buildings of record were destroyed by the hurricane.He constantly refers to St. Augustine as "reconstructed," which is a serious misrepresentation.  One gets the image of Disney or of an outdoor museum, when St. Augustine is a living, working city with many original structures intact.The sights and listings are good enough, and the itineraries are pretty thorough, but I have to question the credibility of a book that makes these kind of sweeping, dramatic statements.  Otherwise, I would say that the recommendations are pretty good, leaning more toward what I would call "touristy" rather than more profoundly authentic.One last thing, and something that is a problem common to many Charleston/Savannah travel guides.  These guides spread Charleston and Savannah, two cities that deserve a separate travel guide EACH, far too thin by adding coverage of places like Hilton Head and Myrtle Beach.  Perhaps that sells more books.  Perhaps not, because a good guide to Charleston could fill 300 pages alone.  Same with Savannah.My recommendation is that you buy the Moon Guide by Jim Morekis.

This book tells the story of how New Orleans fits into the greater Caribbean Creole world that spreads from Haiti to Cartagena, with colonial tentacles as far away as Chile, Argentina and Reunion.  It's a fascinating historical and architectural analysis, told with beautiful color photography and insightful narrative.This volume is not strictly a "coffee table" book, and is as much a sociological analysis as it is an architectural portrait.  The architecture portrayed is not limited to high style examples, and includes many images of decayed vernacular buildings.  The purpose is to illustrate how the Creole culture sprung from French and Spanish colonial settlement maintained a surprisingly uniform depth independent of its geographic location.In the places explored in these pages, French, Spanish, African and Indigenous populations have mixed to form a local culture as rich as gumbo from Treme.

Here's yet another iteration of the "fit vs. brand" movement in the American college admissions game.I don't like these books, mostly because I believe I'm going to find one with a truly rigorous methodology, but they're all pretty much the same.  This book, like so many others, claims to offer insights into quality that are perhaps undiscovered by the general public.  While that may, in fact, describe some of the entries in this book, I believe it's just coincidence, since the author lays out a very simple formula for inclusion in the book that any serious parent or rising freshman could have derived.  There's nothing new here.  The book exaggerates the selectivity of the best colleges in order to make average colleges seem distinguished.While books like this claim to chip away at elitism in American higher education, what they really do is further support it by solidifying the exalted status of the most reputable institutions.  So, if you've read Loren Pope's book, you'll find little new here.Don't get me wrong.  I'm not claiming that there's no quality in the institutions presented here, but quite the contrary.  I believe that relegating colleges and universities into an artificial subclass defeats the very purpose it claims to solve.  There's just no need to recognize colleges and universities that are "slightly less" than distinguished.  And it's patronizing to students and parents to try and convince them that "brand" isn't that important.  We all know better.

These destinations are mostly about white sand beaches, palm trees, and crystal-clear blue water.  This guide covers those things, and the various resorts, hotels and restaurants that complement those things, very well.  But there's more.If you're interested in the history and culture of the islands, this book has you covered in that department too.  Actually, it is this quality that makes the guide so good.  You get a complete picture of the islands, and the book constantly reminds you that there's more to do here than lay on the beach.  This is particularly true in sophisticated little Reunion, which is a fully-integrated legal department of France.Coverage is absolutely exhaustive, both geographically and for listings of hotels and restaurants.  Recommendations are surprisingly candid, and critical where appropriate.  That's a refreshing escape from travel guides that fill the "everything is good in its own way" formula.Tie all this up with nice historical and cultural contexts, and a section of practical matters that is perhaps a wee bit thin, and you've got a pretty darn good guide.

I just love the Rough Guide to Germany, and here's why.Rough Guides appeal to a specific type of traveler.  I would say that a Rough Guide is the opposite of a Rick Steves guide.  These books are intended to be absolutely encyclopedic in their geographic coverage, and they present the widest possible range of dining and lodging options.  They are also quite detailed regarding historical and cultural contexts.  Travelers looking for a practical, quick-and-dirty guide that prioritizes sights and makes recommendations will be disappointed with the Rough Guide.  I would call this book a "country handbook" that is most appropriate for heritage tourists, history buffs and university students.Rough Guides have been slow to adopt some of the more popular trends in travel guides, namely, color content, author recommendations, suggested itineraries, fewer maps, etc...  Instead, what you get is the entire country presented in a rather dry format.  I really like knowing that I've got the whole country in my hand when I lug one of these books around, even if reading them is sometimes an academic exercise.  Think of a Rough Guide as similar to a Michelin Green Guide without the stars.I like the fact that the Rough Guide includes so many maps.  It includes maps of all kinds.  City maps, regional maps, topographic maps, etc...  Another thing that stands out is that the travel recommendations are frequently thematic (visit a Christmas Market, Dine in a Ratskeller) rather than geographic (Nuremberg, Berlin).  Those types of recommendations increase the authenticity of your trip.  The color photography which IS included is beautiful, and will pique your interest in that location or activity.So, Rough Guides will probably continue to be most popular with solo heritage tourists who have an interest in places that are sometimes off the beaten path.  This book will almost always cover a city or small town that other guides pass over.

Rick Steves guides are always excellent, but there is a major caveat.  You have to appreciate Rick's approach to travel to really enjoy these guides.  There are three characteristics that set these books apart from other travel guides.First, they are NOT encyclopedic, but are selective surveys of the countries they cover.  Rick does not attempt to cover the country in an exhaustive, comprehensive way.  He selects sights, hotels, restaurants, and other attractions based on the things he believes most travelers will want to visit, and prioritizes them.  For example, this guide recommends a trip to Nuremburg, but not to Bamberg.  He recommends enormously popular Rothenburg, but not lesser-known but equally lovely Quedlinburg.  All this adds up to make Rick's book very much an "on the beaten path" guide.  Rick believes that if something is popular, there must be a reason.  To really enjoy a guide like this, you have to trust that Rick's recommendations are made based on a thorough working knowledge of the country, and you must be able to accept his judgements of certain popular destinations (such as Heidelberg) as not worth your time.  I do find it odd that Rick dismisses Heidelberg as "too commercial and too popular," but provides feature coverage of over-the-top commercialized Salzburg, and it's not even in Germany.Second, Rick makes hotel and restaurant recommendations based on authenticity and value.  He doesn't just offer listings with little or no evaluation.  He actually considers whether a hotel will enhance your feeling and appreciation of the local culture, and whether it provides excellent services and facilities for its price.  Don't misunderstand.  This is not a listing of locations for travelers on a shoestring budget, but it IS a listing of places that offer a lot for guests, proportional to price.  The same philosophy applies to restaurants and other attractions.  This is what Rick calls his "back door" philosophy.Finally, this is a guide that really stands out regarding travel practicalities, and in concise historical and cultural contexts.  The practicalities are very good, with suggestions for everything from how to rent a car, to what trains to use, to when is the best time of day to visit an otherwise overwhelmingly popular attraction.  For example, most of us will understand quickly that daytime crowds in Rothenburg are going to be enormous.  Want to enjoy this gem of a town without the daytime crowds?  Stay overnight, in one of Rick's recommended lodgings, and you'll be sure to have a rewarding and authentic experience.Historical and cultural contexts are bare bones, and cut right to the pertinent issues a traveler will want to know.  This is not textbook-style dreary history.  Rick tells us when this or that cathedral was built, and why that's important to know, all very concisely and with a lively, witty writing style that keeps the reader engaged.  While the book pays due respect to history where appropriate, Rick makes sure we understand that his guides are not simply about history and the historical.  There are many modern attractions in Germany, particularly in the former East, that are very well covered.  The chapters on Berlin and Dresden are excellent.Listings are right up to date, and maintained that way through Rick's network of writers and reporters.  Plus, he spends over three months per year revisiting many of these locations to update.  Maps are very basic, but they are surprisingly easy to use and always spot-on accurate.  Rick knows the frustration of a bad map, especially for someone in unfamiliar territory.Bottom line is this:  These are selective travel guides designed to be practical and concise.  They are, more than anything, designed to make your trip authentic and valuable.  If you are looking for a truly encyclopedic country guide, there are better books.

Most people think of Austria as a southern extension of Germany, but nothing could be further from the truth.Crossing from Germany into Austria, heading southeast from Munich, the traveler crosses a frontier at Salzburg.  Many things change once we cross the Salzach River.  Any remains of the Teutonic aesthetic from further north are gone, and the Gothic gradually starts to blend with the Romantic Baroque more profoundly.  The geography shifts from fertile foothills to mountains and lakes almost immediately.  Yes, we have certainly left the lands of the Hohenzollern and found the lands of the Hapsburg.I like this book for recognizing that though these countries share a language, they are from different mothers.  What you get here is a guide that includes comprehensive coverage of this little country so immediately dependent on tourism for its economic well-being.  The coverage is not only comprehensive in a geographic sense, but also in diversity of interest.  Austria has many wonderful cultural attractions, but it also has an extraordinary number of outdoor attractions too.  This guide covers them well.  The balance between cultural and outdoor attractions is just about perfect.Unlike many travel guides that are abandoning these chapters, the historical and cultural contexts in the back of the book are very good and will enhance the authenticity of your trip.  Maps are very basic but are accurate and reliable.Listings of hotels and restaurants aren't ENTIRELY comprehensive, but they DO include the best and recommended options.Suggested itineraries are excellent, if a bit long.  You're going to need at least two weeks to give Austria a fair shake.  Because the country can really be overrun with tourists, and can be overrun with tourist traps (think Mozart, The Sound of Music, etc...), you need to take your time and get off the beaten track a bit.  Let it soak in over a longer period of time rather than trying to "power visit" as many sights as possible.  That's the approach this guide recommends.Despite some negative reviews I've seen here (?), I believe this is the best single-volume guide to Austria you can buy.

Want comprehensive, critical coverage of the entire country?  This is your guide.  There are others out there, but none of them is going to give you the combination of encyclopedic coverage and critical insight that this guide does.  The authors have been refining this volume over many editions and it shows.Listings are numerous, and there are suggestions for a wide range of budgets and tastes.  Recommended sights and itineraries reveal a profound knowledge of the country, its history, and its culture.  There's a terrific chapter on Berlin and its many attractions.  Actually, I'm a crazy historic architecture fan, and Berlin, Dresden, Leipzig and Nuremberg, being largely reconstructed cities, were always a hard sell for me.  This guide lays is out for you:  If you come to Germany and you miss these places, big mistake.  Take the recommendations seriously and you'll be guaranteed an authentic, rewarding experience.The maps are numerous, but they can be confusing, cluttered up with all those points and numbers.I would say that this guide has a slightly more cultural bent than is typical for Lonely Planet.  Outdoor attractions aren't ignored, but they do seem to be concentrated around winter and lake resorts and river tours.  There's not as much focus on eco-touring as some travelers might want.  It's easy to completely overdose on churches and castles, and if that's your thing, by all means.  I'd like a guide to offer some balance, some way to escape what can be cultural sensory overload.  This guide could do it better.Minor quibbles aside, I think this is the best single-volume travel guide to the country currently published.

This is a good, solid comprehensive guide that gives the former East its proper due.  Actually, the chapter on Berlin is very good, up to date and complete.  Since Germany is such an awesome country, with more for a curious traveler than one volume could possibly capture, some of the guide to the provinces and smaller towns is quite summary.  That makes the book very much an "on the beaten path" type of guide.Listings of hotels and restaurants are good for the major tourist centers, but are very thin for more hidden treasures such as Bamberg, Goslar, and Regensburg, for example.  Actually, there are also very few maps included, and the book really feels more like a chunky guide to sites, listings, and itineraries.This is a good comprehensive guide to the major tourist sites.  If you're looking for more encyclopedic coverage, Lonely Planet is a better choice.  Ironically enough, Lonely Planet is better known for its coverage of outdoor activities, but it is actually THIS guide that is the better of the two for eco-tourism.

Finally, a major publisher has released a good, comprehensive, UP-TO-DATE guide to this awesome South American country.  It always seemed that you could get one thing or the other in all the other books - good photography, comprehensive coverage, up-to-date listings, good eco-tourist recommendations - but no single guide offered all of these things.  Peru, in particular, has inspired a lot of mediocre guidebooks, but Avalon's Moon series has emerged as a serious and excellent addition to the other regulars, and in many ways, it's better.This is a very nice, chunky book.  There's a perfect blend of lovely color images and informative text, but what's really impressive about this book is its comprehensive scope.  Geographic coverage is absolutely exhaustive, and there is a special emphasis on interesting indigenous and ecological sites and events.  Recommended itineraries and listings are based on a real working knowledge of the country.  There's a real sense of authenticity that runs through the book and its narrative that is just not possible to extract from simple collections of listings on Trip Advisor or Expedia.  That's why we still buy travel guides.  Also, Moon hasn't abandoned historical and cultural contexts the way some other guides have.  You still get exposed to the pertinent history and culture of the place you're visiting.My only real complaint is relatively minor:  In an intentional effort to remain concise, the listings of hotels and restaurants can sometimes be a little thin.  The book will usually have the best options covered, but every now and then one slips through the cracks, such as the Palacio Nazarenas in Cusco, for example.  The listings really appeal more to independent and adventurous travelers than luxury seekers.

The only thing that recommends this edition above previous editions is the fact that the listings and some of the narrative sections are updated.  Otherwise, I'd have to say that the 89th edition (2013) is still the best.For this edition, the chapters of historical and cultural contexts have been removed entirely, replaced by a vague reference to online material.  Coverage is still good, and is generally comprehensive.  There aren't going to be many places on this vast continent that this guide doesn't cover.  As you might expect, the major tourist draws get the most attention, so this is not really an "off the beaten track" guide.  The recommended itineraries in the front are well designed, provided you have at least a month to dedicate to your travel.  Actually, the guide frequently mentions the fact that a real comprehensive tour of the continent is going to take a long, long time.  Three months, minimum.  This is a guide that can be easily used for a focussed tour, though it is really designed for a long-term journey.Footprint and author Ben Box have been at this for a long time, so they have this guide down to a well-designed handbook to the continent.  There's nothing really comparable out there.  The major destinations - Rio de Janeiro, Buenos Aires, Cartagena, Cusco, Salvador - are right up to date and well documented.  There are nice guides to the frequently overlooked countries, and the coverage of Bolivia is particularly good.  The guide includes good coverage of important natural attractions as well.  It's only when you escape into the provinces and the true hinterlands that you'll find this guide leaves you behind.Maps are very, very basic but are accurate.One thing I have noticed with Footprint guides lately is that they frequently come damaged.  Bent pages, creased spines, bent covers, water damage, mis-cut pages.  These are not things that happen during shipping, but happen at the printer.  Footprint needs to seriously look at quality control.

I love this aircraft.  I had a chance to fly in it on a transatlantic from Washington DC to Moscow back when Aeroflot was still flying these.  It's relatively small, a bit like going abroad in a DC-9!This is a decent model, decent enough for a 400 scale.  Personally, I'd like a bit more detail on the wing and around the engines because it is exactly these features that make the Il-62 outstanding.  This particular airline is also defunct, but the Il-62 was the mainstay of its long-haul routes while it operated.Take the plunge and try a model of an aircraft that breaks the mould!  You will learn about the specific and mission-focussed genius of Soviet aeronautical engineering.

Fine representation of Charlotte's first direct flight to London.  Piedmont - North Carolina's flag carrier until a merger with Allegheny created USAir - used these first of their widebody fleet on long-haul flights to the west coast and to London.  This model is well constructed and has real historical value.

This book equally emphasizes the two subjects of its title:  Alaska and Cruise.Part traditional travel encyclopedia, and part pragmatic "how to" cruise guide, if it has to do with cruising in Alaska, it's probably here.  That said, there is an awful lot of information in this book, which means that it can stretch very thin in certain places.  This is not a traditional travel guide with listings of hotels, restaurants and sights, but is a travel narrative that describes each destination and related physical features.The practical information is comprehensive.  Coverage of the lower ports of call is extensive, as is coverage of geography and wildlife.  Historical and cultural contexts are concise and interesting.  Coverage of upper and central destinations (Anchorage, Fairbanks, Kenai, Seward) is thinner, but is still satisfactory.  Readers should keep in mind that this is not a detailed guide to the cruise operators or cruise ships themselves, so there are better resources for people looking for that information.The real standout features of the book are its comprehensiveness, its many color photographs, and its dependable information which has been refined over eight editions.The pull-out, mile-by-mile map is excellent, and adds an additional level of enjoyment when planning or taking your cruise.  Altogether, it's a very good, high-quality publication that is indispensable for Alaska cruisies.

This is a magazine dedicated to motorcycle road racing (i.e. no motocross) and track days only.  There are no articles, comparisons, ride reviews, etc... for street or dirt motorcycles.For what it is, it's a good magazine.

I'm a fan of Rick Steves' "Back Door" travel philosophy, but I was surprised at how selective this guide is.When you buy a Rick Steves' guide, you know you're going to get well refined content that has been organized and prioritized to allow for an authentic travel experience.  Some places will be included and some won't.  Rick does not intend to make his books encyclopedic or entirely comprehensive in their coverage, but his choice of locations (or, rather, his exclusion of locations) in this book can leave a traveler scratching his head.Almost the entire western part of the country, and particularly locations on Lake Geneva, are ignored.  Basel and Geneva are completely absent.  The French-speaking part of the country is very poorly represented.His selection of Alpine villages is also a bit odd, choosing to include Murten and Zermatt which, though lovely, are so small that they can only accommodate a very small number of tourists at any given time.  Authentic?  Certainly.  Practical?  Feasible?  Questionable.  And Rick falling for the touristy glitz of mountain resorts like St. Moritz seems very, well, un-Steves-like!  His chapter on scenic rail journeys is good, and certainly represents are high quality attraction that should not be missed.You certainly get Rick's signature selectivity in this guide, but if his tastes aren't compatible with yours you may find this guide lacking in coverage.

Portugal makes me wax lyrical.  It is hard to overstate what an incredibly gorgeous country this is.  So many people think of Switzerland, or Austria, or Italy, or Spain.  Sit down with this excellent book and let the skilled writers of Lonely Planet introduce you to lovely, lovely Portugal.First, let's talk briefly about the country.  Portugal is blessed with diverse geography, rich culture, and a history that has not been obscured by war or diluted by decades of consumerism.  Authenticity is one of the prime reasons people visit Portugal.  While so many other destinations is western Europe can feel like preserved museum pieces, Portugal is the real deal.This book is dedicated to capturing that authenticity and presenting it to the traveler.  From Faro to seafood, from the beaches to the mountains, from quaint Obidos to mighty Lisbon, there's something here for every taste.  The guide is arranged with typical Lonely Planet completeness.  It includes well thought through recommendations and itineraries that are genuine, and not just constructed randomly.  There are themes that give each of these travel devices continuity, which all adds up to give the reader an authentic experience.This book is the most comprehensive travel guide to Portugal now in print.  I was surprised at how broad and encyclopedic the coverage of the country is.  The listings are complete and concise, and all are subject to Lonely Planet's subjective recommendations.  I have found these recommendations to be spot on, and using them allows the traveler to prioritize.  The writing is concise enough that this book can be used on the fly, as you're engaged in your travel, rather than just a reference to pour over while having breakfast and coffee in your hotel.Historical and cultural contexts add just enough information to be interesting without bogging down into textbook style.  Portuguese history, cuisine, literature and architecture are distinct from any other country in Europe.  They are particularly unique and local in their quality, and this book captures that uniqueness.  Pragmatic information is absolutely complete, and remember that Portuguese is NOT Spanish.If you've not planned a trip to Portugal, make it a priority to do so.  Then make use of this guide, the best of the bunch, to add direction and meaning to your travel.  What makes this guide stand out from the others?  The critical and comprehensive listings and recommendations of a huge network of writers far surpass the resources of any other publisher.  This one sets the standard.

Frommer's is introducing the Easy Guide series in 2014, and this particular example proves that this travel guide publisher is back from near obscurity.Frommer's came late to the full-color party and almost disappeared as mainstream publishers like DK Eyewitness, Lonely Planet, Fodor and Rough Guide introduced flashy new color formats.  What those publishers did NOT do, however, is introduce a fresh way of presenting travel content.  Underneath all the gloss, those books offer the same "what to see, where to stay, where to eat" encyclopedic format.This book does essentially the same thing, but the content here is far more genuine, organized and accessible.  All travel guides are trying harder to give their readers better, more substantial and critical content.  Rick Steves', for example, makes this a priority in his books, and these Easy Guides feel similar in presentation to the Rick Steves' guides.Don't expect glossy color content.  The name of the game here is simplicity.  The material is purposefully filtered and selective, and the entries are concise and right up to date.  There's a cautiously irreverent tone to the book that let's you know that the writers have done their homework.  This book is better organized and prioritized than any other New Orleans guide I've seen.Though something of a cliche, this book really IS like having a local tour guide in your pocket.  While it is a decidedly classical "on the beaten track" guide, the reviews are as insightful as they are selective.  This is a very, very good guide for first-time AND many-time visitors.  There's excellent material dedicated to the important festivals of New Orleans, including Mardi Gras and Jazz Fest.

I love this book because I love Russia.  All of it.Every other travel guide to Russia available today will cover Moscow, St. Petersburg, and probably the Golden Ring, but that's all you'll get.  The rest of the country, literally 90 percent of it, will be ignored.This book is different.  You get good, comprehensive coverage of Russia from coast to coast, across all nine time zones.  Moscow and St. Petersburg, obviously, are feature attractions and get major chapters, but so do the cities along the Volga River and fascinating cities along the trans-Siberian.  Want a good introduction to the lovely capital of Tatarstan, the city of Kazan?  You'll get it here.  Want to understand why the Siberian cities of Tomsk and Irkutsk are worth a journey?  You'll find those reasons, and the practical information you'll need to get there, in this book.  I've spent a lot of time in the Russian cities of Ulyanovsk and Bryansk, both of which are included in this book.  Most people will have never heard of these cities.  This guide brings you the Russia of the provinces.I bought the Lonely Planet guide to the USSR way back when I first traveled to Russia not long after the fall of Communism, and I've been using Lonely Planet in Russia ever since.  You're simply not going to find a guide that combines the breadth of coverage with a depth cultivated by decades of refinement.Another thing that helps distinguish this guide is its relatively irreverent treatment of the sometimes surly Russian service attitude.  While the situation is improving, it's nice to know where old Soviet-style service practices linger on so you can steer clear of those establishments.If there's a weak point to this guide, it's the relative lack of discussion of Russia's enormously diverse geography.  There are landscapes in Russia so beautiful that they have inspired poets for centuries.  From the Caucasus mountains to the rolling central steppes to the great eastern rivers, there's more here than can possibly be covered in one book, or in one lifetime.  And though the coverage of the geography is a bit thin, the book DOES mention that an overnight trip on a Russian train is a must.  This experience will give you hours of time to stand at the window and take it all in - the vast Russian land where you'll see not a single man-made object for miles.Russia is a country that a traveler simply can not appreciate without SOME history, because Russia's history is so immensely important to, and indicative of its rich culture.  This book will give you that overview, to enrich your experience while you learn about one of the most fascinating and important countries on earth.

If this is your kind of thing (you know who you are), this is a book you're going to like.It is a comprehensive encyclopedia of submarine boats and their respective armaments.  The coverage is excellent, and includes every military boat from all the major navies worldwide, since 1940.  Each entry includes an nice color plate, a general specification, and a short essay detailing the history of the design.  There is a good introductory chapter about the history of submarine technology.All this fits in a neat, compact book that fits easily in one hand.  The only real gripe I have is minor:  I wish the color plates were drawn to the same scale so we could get an idea of each boat's relative size.  Otherwise, this book is exactly what I wanted, for less than ten bucks.  Can't beat that.

Hooked on the sound of a Japanese inline four at 16,000 rpm, or the roar of a Ducati V-twin or the wispy smoke of a hot two-stroke?  Does the idea of a 14:1 compression ratio get your heart racing?  Want to learn about the historical foundations of modern engine technology, about who invented what and why it was important?  This is your book.Kevin Cameron is both a master engineer and a fine, skilled journalist.  He brings highly technical material to the general reader and interested enthusiast.  The best part of this book is that it teaches you the technical material without deteriorating into textbook arcane.  It makes you FEEL like a skilled engineer when you read it.  Cameron has the skill to pull this off.The book features detailed chapters about the historical and technical backgrounds of 53 important motorcycle engines.  It's a varied mix of configurations, from the Harley XR to the Honda NR to the modern Yamaha inline fours.  Most of these engines were race only designs, but more than a few were eventually configured for street use, such as the Suzuki GSX-R.The color photographs and few technical graphics which are included are from archival sources, and were not commissioned specifically for this book.  Generally, the feature of this book is the text, and the illustrations serve to enhance the text.More of a motorsports history book than a technical manual, the book nevertheless includes enough wizardry to keep even the most fanatical engineers engaged.

I bought this book for several reasons.  I'm a committed amateur architectural historian, and I have a specific interest in the sociological elements of high-style architecture from the deep South.  This book is a good study of the sociological elements that came together to form the great houses we know today.Next, the illustrations include floor plans for each of the houses studied, which is a feature that exists in no other book, at least for these particular sites.  And finally, this book includes a few houses that were important examples of their respective style and time, that no longer stand either because they were neglected or wantonly demolished, such as Mount Brilliant in Kentucky.So those are the reasons for reading this book, but there is a major caveat:  The author is racist.  The text itself runs from merely irritating in places to downright deplorable in others.  The racist slant of the writing may be a product of the times, but that does not excuse its vanity and insensitivity.  As it is, understanding the sociological elements of the book requires a somewhat dry, clinical approach in order to avoid offense.  The chapter about the technical elements of design are really quite good, and tend to be free of racist allusions.This is not a coffee table book or a casual browse of sites.  It's not a tourist or travel guide.  It is something of a dry academic treatment of architecture from the deep South.  I say the "deep South" because the sites featured in the book are from what we would call the Old Southwest - Tennessee, Alabama, Mississippi, Louisiana - and not from the more ancient eastern states like Virginia and South Carolina.  It is really a study of the Federal style as it developed on the frontier, and of the Greek Revival style.  There is no discussion of Colonial.This book will find most interest from architectural historians and local historians, but will be of limited interest to the casual reader.

The plantations of Louisiana are beloved historic monuments, and books dedicated to their preservation abound.  Here is yet another.  Those of you familiar with Sexton's book "Vestiges of Grandeur" know that you're in for a treat in this book.  Here, the author's pen and photographer's lens are pointed at Pointe Coupee, north of Baton Rouge.This book brings the same kind of excellence in photography that has so frequently been applied to the River Road up north to the equally stunning Pointe Coupee Parish.  The book is organized as an architectural catalog of about 50 well-chosen sites, grouped by geographical area within the Parish.  The photography, which is mostly external, is simply outstanding.  While architecture is very much the feature attraction, the author and photographer have decorated the entire essay with shots from everyday life.  Portraits and still life give the book an intimacy that makes it more than simply a catalog of buildings.  The text serves to frame the photography, and is not intended to be an academic study of the region's architecture or history.This is a book that made me want to plan a journey.  Very much a book intended for informal browsing, it will not serve the more academic interests of architects or architectural historians.  I would recommend this book to anyone with an casual interest in architectural history or local history.

Very realistic, heavy and seems to be design wonderfully,  Both openings are designed very realistically,I had no issues with particles coming off onto me, however it is covered in an oily substance and does have that plastic smell,  I am sure this is to preserve it and to make it realistic, however it does take away for me, and the reason I am giving 4 stars instead of 5.I received this item at a discount to write an honest unbiased opinion.

This is a great wallet and case for your cell phone.  First and foremost I love the hot pink color.  So pretty, This works by putting the magnetic cell phone case on your phone,  The case hugs your cell phone and it still allows you to have all access to your buttons along with being able to charge your phone while it is in the case.  It then sits by magnet in the wallet,  by sitting I mean the magnet is VERY strong, It even has a hole cut out of it for the camera so you are still able to take pictures while it is in the wallet.  The card holder is secured by a snap closure button and it seems to be a very firm snap button.  This has plenty of card holders, in fact if you fill this wallet up with cards you need to get rid of some cards.  That is my opinion.  This has a clear open spot for your photo ID,  and all the slots are adequate sizing to get the cards in and out of.  The whole case is secure again with a magnet flap closure,  This magnet isnt near as strong but it still holds unless you are rough with the case and then it will pop open.  The strap is a nice added feature however I had issues getting mine on,  It took me several tries before I finally got it secured properly.  Overall I dont have anything negative to say about this case, I would purchase again,I received this case at a discount for testing and reviewing purposes,  this is my honest unbiased opinion and have come to this by using this wallet on a daily basis.

This tablet has many features,  hard to go over them all,  The key major selling points for me would be the case that comes included with the tablet.  Its not the heavy duty type of case but a soft silicone one.  Still offers protection for minor drops.  It has Childrens World already installed on it so you can limit what your children have access to.  I also LOVE the feature of the time limit,  no arguing with your child that its time to get off, it just happens.This is a 7 inch tablet with 8GB of internal memory,  which was plenty for the games we installed on it, however if you require more storage, you do have the option of adding more memory by installing an sd card,  I believe it will accept a card up to 32GB of data.  This is an Android based tablet so its a great tablet and works very well.Tablet is not one of those cheapy feeling type of tablets,  This has a good feel and appearance so it looks high end.  When the tablet is out of the case it is also yellow based.  Not a problem for me as yellow is gender neutral.Overall I personally can't think of any thing negative to say about this tablet, it functions great and appearance is outstanding.I received this product for free for testing and reviewing purposes.  This is my honest unbiased opinion and have come to this conclusion by testing and playing with this tablet myself and allowing my children to play on it to.

This is a great set of headphones,  They fold up for easy storage and packing.  The sound is great, clear, crisp and has quite a bit of bass.  love the braided cord.  They last longer than the rubber cords.  Great padding on the ear pieces,  Was able to wear for some time and my ears never got sore,  Just hot.  These are easy to adjust just pull on the ear piece and they extend for larger heads or push back in for smaller heads.  These were able to fit my head and also my daughters head.  Great headphones, I have nothing negative to say about these headphones.I received these headphones at a discount for testing and reviewing purposes.  This is my honest unbiased opinion and have come to it by using the headphones myself.

Love the idea of this being reversible gives me more options for coloring in my living room.  This is a quilted design and cover, could be a bit thicker but it gets the job done.  It fits my couch well and covers what needs to be covered. It has protected my couch from my kids and my dog well.  Stitching is durable and should hold up over time.  This will be easy to clean just throw in the wash.  I am happy with this cover and have nothing negative to say about it..I received a discount for testing and reviewing purposes.  This is my honest unbiased opinion and have come to it by using the cover myself.

This is a good cover seems to be made of fairly durable material, I am sure it could be a little more sturdier.  this cover is quilted and fits my couch well.  So far it has protected against my dog being on my couch and from my kids who are destructive critters.  This fits well and covers the whole couch how it is supposed to.  If you have a large couch it may not fit your couch  Overall I am happy with this cover it is quilted and does what it is supposed to do.  Wish it was a little thicker.I received this furniture cover at a discount for testing and reviewing purposes.  This is my honest unbiased review and have come to this conclusion by using the cover myself

These are great tweezers, they are very pointy which work great for getting those stragler hairs,  they work well for pulling out splinters and glass.  They are stainless steel and very durable.  They are very strong and have a very strong grip.  They are easy to hold.  and have a nice base to grip with.I am happy with these tweezers,  They do what they are expected of.I received these tweezers at a discount for testing and reviewing purposes  This is my honest unbiased opinion and have come to it by using the tweezers myself.

I was not familiar with this brand of bedding,  I am not your typical person who buys things cause of a name.  Anyways this bedding is so cute, very soft and has a decent amount of stretch.  This comes with a toddler pillow, pillow case, flat + fitted sheet combo & a toddler blanket.  The design is super cute with a little dog wearing a mask and cape.  Super cute.I found no flaws in the material or the design.  I found no flaws in the stitching and even after washing it held up even after the wash cycle.Overall I am very pleased with this set.  I am loving this material,  it is super soft.I received this bed in bag set for free for testing and reviewing purposes. We love this,  this was a hit with my daughters sleep over party,  We melted chocolate and had a chocolate dipping station.  Heated the chocolate perfect, didnt scorch the chocolate and had adjusters.  Seems to be made of great materials and very durable.  Great melting pot.  love how the little pans come out for easy dipping and being able to pass around for others to get what they need or want out of the pans.I am very pleased with this melting pot.  It fit my needs and has worked well and I could not ask for anything better.I received this item at a discount for testing and reviewing purposes. This game is a lot of laughs and a lot of fun.  I tried playing this with my children who are 11 and 8 but they had a hard time with the songs.  They didnt know many of them.  I did decide to play this game with a group of friends and we had a blast.  Of course I am the most tone deaf person on the face of this earth, it doesn't matter with this game..  We all had fun and played for quite some time.  Overall I am pleased with this game, I wouldn't list this for any children to play as they may not know the songs which makes playing the game impossible and just being sore loosers.  However get a group of adults who feel comfortable with each other and the tears will be rolling off your face from laughter.Great game. I received this game for free for testing and reviewing purposes.  This is my honest unbiased opinion and have come to it by playing the game myself.

This is an absolutely beautiful table cloth.  It has a floral jacquard design in the cloth and it really is something to look at.  Looks very high end quality.  I found no flaws in the hem with the stitching, and no imperfections in the material or in the jacquard design.  There is no lining sewn in this tablecloth so its not really waterproof,  It is machine washable in cold water.  You can even throw this in the dryer on a low heat setting.  You can iron as needed.  What a fantastic table cloth.My only complaint I have is that the package insert lists material as Polyester, cotton, PVC, EVA.  However the sewn in label states it is 100% polyester.  I believe the sewn in tag as the material feels like polyester.  I believe package insert is a typo.Overall this is a beautiful table cloth and looks fantastic on the table.  Beautiful.I received this table cloth for free for testing and reviewing purposes.  This is my honest unbiased opinion and have come to it by using the table cloth myself.

Very impressed with these brushes.  There are 6 brushes to the pack,  Each brush has a very long handle and the perfect thickness to the handle.  Bristles are of high quality and glide very smoothly with acrylic paint.  When you first get these brushes you will have to wash the glue out of them and reshape them.  That is expected with any high quality brushes.  I am very impressed with these brushes.  They are very high quality and the bristles are fantastic.I received a discount for testing and reviewing purposes.  This is my honest unbiased opinion and have come to this conclusion by using the brushes myself.

If you don't drink tea on a daily basis this probably isn''t for you.  This tea has a different flavor.  You can not add any sweetner cause it takes away the effect of the tea.  Make sure you can drink unsweetned tea before you get this. This is my reason for 4 stars.This tea did give me energy and seemed to curb my appetite.  You have to drink 2-4 cups of this a day in order to see slimming effects from  this tea.  This bag contains 30 bags and will last 7 days if drinking 4 cups a day.  I didnt see a weight loss however I havent drank it long enough for long term effects. I have nothing negative to say.I received this tea for free for testing and reviewing purposes.  This is my honest unbiased opinion and have come to it by drinking the tea myself.

This is  neat mask.  Love the light up feature.  I got the blue mask and where there is blue there is light.  The mask fit my face well and there was a lot of give to the elastic strap.  It did not bother my face at all while wearing and I really stood out as I was the only one with a lighted mask.  The overall quality of the mask is decent I am giving 4 stars because when the mask is turned on it has a very loud humming noise coming from the battery pack.  It actually coincides with the light feature, constant on = constant hum  blinking = a repeated tone to match the blinking.I like the idea of the different features of the light.  3 modes to choose from, constant light, slow blinking and fast blinking.  Cod is very long and is easily hidden.  I tucked the cord behind my ear and fed it down my shirt.I am pleased with this mask.  Nice quality.I received this mask at a discount for testing and reviewing purposes.  This is my honest unbiased opinion and have come to it by using the mask myself.

Lovely set of 5 christmas socks.  Love the natural colors!  Design is super cute.  These socks are soft and fit well.  Stitching is very durable, and held up during wash. This wireless doorbell is great. It is easy to set up, easy to mount and works perfectly out of the box. This is a nice little thermos to take to along to my sons baseball game when I want to keep my coffee warm.
