Length: Print, 426 pages; Audible audiobook, 10 hours 55 minutes.Feel free to leave a comment at the end of the review or to search my profile for more good books or my email contact information.This Action-Adventure fiction is targeted to people who love a good story that ties in elements of ancient history with modern technological suspense and political intrigue. It is part of a series referred to as the NUMA Files.The setting and technique used as a foundation for this story is not so different from a series I recently have reviewed by author Inge H. Borg, in that the prologue is set in ancient Egypt (17th year in the reign of Akhenaten) and then leaps forward to present day. Unlike Borg‚Äôs storyline, though, the reference to Ancient Egypt is a mere prologue, contrasting greatly from the book Khamsin. Other differences would be that Pharaoh‚Äôs Secret consolidates the story into one book and has less of a romance bent to it than do Borg‚Äôs sequels to Khamsin.Early on in the book there is also a brief description of interest to folks interested in the brief period during Napolean‚Äôs expedition to Egypt‚Äôs Mediterranean Coast that helps flavor the story.Despite the general similarities, Cussler‚Äôs work, as well as Borg‚Äôs, makes for a delightful immersion, provided you are able to suspend disbelief.What was the Amazon Rank on the date this review was published? 256.Is this a book that I can read without having to read others first? Yes, but reading the other books remains an interesting endeavor.Are there other books by this author that might also be helpful? Yes, this can be read without first reading any of the other books in the series.Are there a lot of typos/misspellings, grammatical errors or other editing failures? This is professionally edited.Is it a quick, easy read and is the writer enthusiastic in his/her approach? This would be more of a curl up in bed or in one‚Äôs recliner. At 426 pages, there is ample time for character development and for bringing several related stories together in the typical Cussler manner.What sort of language does this writer use to amplify the points made? General spoken English, even among the Egyptians portrayed. It is interesting to note, the harshest cussing in this book is one occasion in which the d-word is used, and a few uses of the h-word. Surprisingly, I did not come across a single f-bomb. I say surprising, because I've not read or listened to a Cussler novel in several years.My biggest pleasure or disappointment was an error at the beginning of Chapter 13. Reference is made to the, ‚ÄúWhite Desert of Egypt, seven miles west of the Pyramids 1130 hours‚Äù.- Cussler, Clive; Brown, Graham (2015-11-17). The Pharaoh's Secret (NUMA Files series) (p. 89). Penguin Publishing Group. Kindle Edition.My difficulty with this stems from my several years working and living in Egypt. At least thrice weekly I drove through the area mentioned and, although this was indeed once desert, it has been increasingly developed and, alas, for the last decade, has not been desert. I mention this not as a severe flaw. Rather, I just want to show that suspending my disbelief at this point was challenged. I did get over it and was able to kick back and enjoy an otherwise terrific yarn set in one of my favorite genres.At the same time, the story relates a determination for a comeback by the nucleus of the foundation, or supporters, of the previous Mubarak regime. In that this is entirely logical and may indeed be the critical factor in turning back the recent Arab Spring in Egypt, it is not quite so difficult to suspend that disbelief. Having so stated, though, the premise surrounding their methods is a bit far-fetched. Note: I will not disclose here because I don‚Äôt want to spoil the story upon which that is so key to this story.The below excerpt relates a key point in the novel that explains more about the psyche of a villain and his determination to win in this diabolical contest between east and west.EXCERPT:‚ÄúA report came in from Malta,‚Äù Shakir said. ‚ÄúHagen and two members of your handpicked team were tasked with eliminating the Americans. One of them was killed, Hagen was captured and one escaped. I‚Äôm sure you understand why it is imperative that none of our operatives be captured.‚Äù‚ÄúOf course I do,‚Äù Hassan replied. ‚ÄúFor that reason, I sent‚Äî‚Äù‚ÄúYou sent a candidate who failed me,‚Äù Shakir boomed. ‚ÄúOne who I was led to believe had died in the desert three days ago.‚Äù‚ÄúI never suggested he was dead.‚Äù‚ÄúYou kept his survival from me,‚Äù Shakir said. ‚ÄúOne and the same transgression.‚Äù‚ÄúNo,‚Äù Hassan insisted. ‚ÄúHe survived. You didn‚Äôt inquire. I took it upon myself to execute your offer, which was that any of those who made it back to the checkpoint would be given another chance.‚ÄùShakir despised having his own words used against him. ‚ÄúExcept that it‚Äôs not possible for anyone to have survived the march back to the checkpoint. Not thirty miles, across the desert, in the blazing sun, without any water or shade. Not after weeks of draining competition with little sleep.‚Äù‚ÄúI tell you, he made it,‚Äù Hassan said. ‚ÄúAnd without help. Look at his face. Look at his hands. He burrowed into the sand when he thought he was going to die. He hid there until dusk. Then dug his way out and continued on.‚ÄùShakir had seen the scars. Smart, he thought. Resourceful. ‚ÄúWhy wasn‚Äôt this reported by the men?‚Äù‚ÄúThe checkpoint was deserted when he arrived,‚Äù Hassan insisted. ‚ÄúThe men had left assuming, like you, that no one would live to finish the trek. Number four broke in and made contact with me. Seeing his strength and determination, I decided he would be the perfect choice to watch our own men. He was there without their knowledge. Should they falter, his orders were to eliminate them and keep us from being exposed.‚ÄùShakir was the unquestioned leader of Osiris, but he wasn‚Äôt afraid to admit his mistakes. If Hassan was telling the truth, then number four was indeed the one candidate worthy of being honored with a position‚Äî and, just as important, a name.Ordering Hassan to keep silent, Shakir unmuted the satellite link and questioned number four. The answers were close enough without being identical. Shakir felt he was hearing the truth, as opposed to a practiced story.He glanced at the guards behind Hassan. ‚ÄúLet him up.‚Äù The guards pulled back and Hassan stood. Shakir turned to number four.‚ÄúLet me tell you a story,‚Äù he began. ‚ÄúWhen I was a child, my family lived on the outskirts of Cairo. My father scavenged metal from the trash heaps to sell. That is how we survived. One day, a large scorpion came into our house. It stung me. I was about to smash it with a brick when my father stayed my hand.‚ÄúHe said he would teach me a lesson. So we put the scorpion in a jar and tried to drown it, first with cold water and then with hot. Then we left it out in the sun, beneath the clear glass, for days. Then we poured rubbing alcohol over it. It tried to swim but couldn‚Äôt and eventually settled to the bottom. The next day, we drained the alcohol and dumped the scorpion out onto the dirt beside our house. Not only was it still alive, it immediately turned to attack us. Before it could get me, my father flicked it into the distance with a broom. The scorpion is our brother, he said to me. Stubborn, poisonous and hard to kill. The scorpion is noble.On-screen, number four nodded slightly.‚ÄúYou‚Äôve proved your worth,‚Äù Shakir said. ‚ÄúYou‚Äôre one of us now. A brother. Your code name shall be Scorpion for you have proven to be stubborn, hard to kill and, yes, even noble. You did not beg me for mercy in the desert. You did not give in to fear. For this, I commend you.‚ÄùOn-screen, the man with the newly bestowed title bowed his head.‚ÄúWear those scars proudly,‚Äù Shakir said.‚ÄúI shall.‚Äù‚ÄúWhat are your orders?‚Äù Hassan asked, trying to get back into the conversation but mostly just thankful to be alive.‚ÄúThey remain as before,‚Äù he said. ‚ÄúGet the artifacts before they‚Äôre made public and erase all record of them within the museum. This time, you will go and supervise personally.‚ÄùCussler, Clive; Brown, Graham (2015-11-17). The Pharaoh's Secret (NUMA Files series) (pp. 155-157). Penguin Publishing Group. Kindle Edition.Critics beware: On two occasions, the author commits one of Elmore Leonard‚Äôs pet peeve number six: never use the phrase ‚Äúall hell broke loose.‚ÄùBottom line: Despite some fanciful stretches, this is an enjoyable intrigue of politics and secrecy that should keep many readers up late in night. I, at least, had great difficulty in stopping at the end of any chapter. In part, because these chapters are quite short and each ends on a note that had me only too eager to flip the page for just a little look-see as to what was about to happen next. This is probably the fastest I‚Äôve ever raced through a 400-page book.

Length: Print, 254 pages; not yet available in audio format at Audible.Feel free to leave a comment at the end of this review.Amazon Kindle Sales Rank when this review was posted: 180.This nonfiction history of the Indian Wars is a terrific overview for each of the more significant campaign exerted against the various groupings of aboriginal peoples of what would become the United States.Written in standard English, this is clearly intended as an objective discussion of the general causes of each military campaign.Although some detail is evident regarding the differing attitudes by the contestants, in just 254 pages it is impossible to even mention a number of the significant skirmishes and battles. Although I'd have preferred much more depth to the main battles and at least some mention of the lesser fights that occurred during each campaign, this was a good summary that can foster a great curiosity among those who do give this work a once over.But, there is far more worthwhile reading than one might expect from a text of only 254 pages. Therefore, I'm rating this a five star book.I'm unable to include any experts tonight, so will update this review when I am able.

Length: Print, 50 pages; not yet available at Audible.Please feel free to leave a comment below and to let me know if this review helps you decide whether to buy The Last Level Project.Amazon Kindle Sales Rank when this review was posted: 102 free.This nonfiction how-to booklet is focused on informing people on a model for setting up a network. It differs from other similar books on networking and includes a link to a free eCourse to further detail the methods touched upon in this introduction.Unlike most of his other guides, this booklet is absent any f-bombs and only has two cuss words, one each of sh&$ and da@?. For a Buck Flogging book, this has to be some sort of record.But, trust me, absence of swearing does not mean his brand of humor is lacking. He eloquently, and with only one very minor editing snafu, presents a solid case for a method he claims can help many people succeed more effortlessly than is generally believed.Of course, there are many questions remaining to be answered before I am persuaded to go hog wild into networking, but, as will many readers, I have signed up for his eCourse.Insofar as the quality of writing and editing, though, this is an extremely interesting and intriguing booklet that I purchased while it is free.EXCERPT: if you're still reading this review, I'm thinking you're unfamiliar with Matt Stone's writing style. His style and flow are a hybrid of sarcasm and Andrew Carnegie. Sometimes inspirational and sometimes raucous but always more fun to read than anything even your most interesting professor ever lectured you on in class. Stone (or Buck Flogging) just plain knows how to communicate.What is network marketing? Network marketing is a system in which independent ‚Äúdistributors‚Äù are compensated by a company to sell a product or line of products. That part of it makes it identical to the traditional sales rep type model that many companies follow and that everyone is familiar with. With network marketing however, the real money for a distributor is not in selling retail products, but in signing up other distributors who sign up more distributors who sign up more distributors. This enables the distributor at the top to earn a commission for every product sold by hundreds, thousands, and even hundreds of thousands of other people.It‚Äôs pretty ingenious really. A company creates products and then, without having to provide much training or take on any financial risk, a massive, viral distribution network forms over time. The company only pays these sales distributors when a sale is made. They don‚Äôt have to worry about ‚Äúemployees‚Äù and tons of overhead and other things.A massive, viral distribution network forms because when one person signs up two distributors, and those two distributors do the same, and so on, you see logarithmic growth. 1 gets 2, those 2 get 4, those 4 get 8, those 8 get 16, those 16 get 32, those 32 get 64, those 64 get 128, those 128 get 256, and before you know it there are hundreds of thousands of distributors out there buying and selling products and trying to make a buck.What‚Äôs even more ingenious about it is that, unlike with typical storefront items, which are bought and sold because people are seeking to use those products, network marketing adds a secondary motivation to buy products: making money.That‚Äôs right. Networking marketing uses people‚Äôs desire to make money, and make that money from home no less (a higher echelon of financial freedom), as a motivating force to sell their products.You can make money in network marketing by running around telling everybody how awesome the products are no doubt. And you will inevitably do some of that once you become educated about the company‚Äôs products. But that‚Äôs hard work, you have to be skilled to do it effectively, the products are usually less than exceptional which makes selling them harder, you‚Äôll be exchanging hours of your time for dollars, and you‚Äôre unlikely to actually achieve last level status and truly passive income.It‚Äôs best to think of network marketing as a slightly bizarre way to get people to buy products. Most of the products are bought by distributors that are forced to buy a certain amount each month in order to receive commissions. The amount of products bought usually far exceeds what any normal person would actually want or need. The price of those products is usually priced way above the true market value of those products as well, but none of that matters. Distributors buy however much they need to perpetuate their business. Extra is typically given away to friends and family...The foregoing review and the excerpt above should not be construed as an endorsement of his proposal. Each reader must exercise due diligence. But, I love this book and am rating it as a five star.

Setting up the keyboard was easy, when following the clear instructions in the supplied quick-start guide, but you need to download the specified Lenovo Y Gaming Mechanical switch keyboard. This driver is necessary for the keyboa d to be able to capture, (to record), macro for the G 1-6 keys.Now it was time to plug in the peripherals and headsets.The keyboard works flawlessly and is extremely touch-sensitive. Using Windows 10, you may need to tweak the sound drivers, but be patient and the results will come.This large keyboard might be too bulky for some, but might be perfect for guys with larger hands and fingers.Aside from the size, the only serious drawback is the price. Other keyboards that work just about as well are available for under $70, so, in this case, price is a serious drawback.Feel free to leave a comment. I hope this review is helpful.

Fate of the UnionLength: Print, 320 pages, Audible, 8 hours 21 minutes.Amazon Kindle Sales Rank when this review was posted: 122.This is an intriguing fictional political suspense novel, the second in a series featuring Joe Reeder and Patti Rogers.When you read that it is a political suspense novel, you can probably figure that the story arc is going to include a hard-edged military anti-establishment character and that the language will be seedy, (what my mother always referred to as mule skinner language). If the f-bomb annoys you, look for a different story.Although this stereotype has been around in print for a couple generations, it seems it will last for much longer. Certainly, it still works with this PI, as brought to life in this great story by Max Allan Collins and Matthew V. Clemens.Although this is a series, I did not read the first book and don't believe I enjoyed this story any the less. Also, there is no cliffhanger ending, although there clearly we are left aware that follow on work related the this story is coming, someday.Note: I discovered this book through Audible and got into it so fully, I added the Kindle version a short while ago. What astounds me most is that until this book, I was not aware of Max Allan Collins, despite his great success with Private Eye books, and a score of TV credits that includes Mike Hammer, CSI, etc.EXCERPT: The below excerpt should provide a good feel for the pace and flow of this story:‚ÄúThen . . . then we showed up.‚Äù"If he recognized me as we drove past‚Äîthis was likely our blond perp‚Äîhe knew he‚Äôd scored a bonus round. If you and I hadn‚Äôt chatted a while in the car, we‚Äôd have already been inside when he hit the detonator.‚Äù"We . . . we‚Äôd have been . . . scattered all over this parking lot . . . with the rest of the debris.‚ÄùSirens sang their distant song. This was the boonies, but somebody had seen the flames rising into the sky, and/ or heard the big boom.Their breathing slowing, the air clearing some, the smoke on its upward trajectory, the two got up and had a look at their rescued corpse. Only the figure‚Äôs back was charred black, the front of him appearing relatively normal‚Äîhis expression almost serene, as if he‚Äôd slept through the other side of him getting cooked."Dead before the explosion,‚Äù Rogers said.Reeder pointed out the two punctures in the blackened back of his neck‚Äîbarely visible but the indentations were there, all right."Double-tapped,‚Äù Rogers said.Reeder nodded and looked back toward the trees on the other side of which was the service road. Just then flames illuminated something over that way, and glass winked and blinked at him.A sniper scope."Gun!‚Äù he said, and then came the muzzle flash.They both hit the snowy cement, sending up puffs of white, then each scrambled around behind the car, Reeder around front, Rogers around back. The shooter had seen that action through his scope, because two more rounds slammed into the car, and then another took the back left tire, which hissed as if a villain had come on stage, and hadn‚Äôt he?Each sat with their backs to the passenger side of the Fusion. Breathing hard again, Reeder said, ‚ÄúYou got extra magazines?‚Äù"Yeah. Two.‚Äù ‚Äú"Good. Keep him busy.‚Äù"What do you mean, keep him busy?‚Äù"Do it.‚Äù From around the rear of the car, Rogers threw shots into the line of trees. She had a handgun and the shooter had a rifle and the advantage of firepower and distance were his. But she kept it up, the sharp cracks of her Glock rising over the rumbling murmur of the burning buildings.She was shooting as Reeder took off, very low, right toward the facing fires, running between them and skirting around the building at left and staying parallel to it. He couldn‚Äôt remember the last time he‚Äôd run on snow. He was trying to be careful in the dark, trying not to trip over any chunks of debris, and was grateful for the minimal moonlight and even fire glow, assuming it didn‚Äôt give him away.As he reached where the building ended and concrete parking lot yawned to a strip of snowy landscape with the line of trees waiting, he climbed out of his Burberry and left it behind, his dark suit better suited for his purpose.With the night alternating pops of the Glock and resonant reports from the rifle, Reeder headed over to where the service road curved around behind the buildings, the line of trees ending where that curve began. As the shooter exchanged shots with Rogers, the rifle‚Äôs scope would not be swung way the hell over here. Or so Reeder told himself as he kept very low on the asphalt, as low as possible and still run.Any other Tuesday night, this industrial park would be all but silent. An occasional car would thrum by, the odd owl might hoot, tree leaves might rustle with wind; but tonight was a cacophony of howling flames, screaming sirens, crunching snow, all punctuated by the bellows of his own labored breathing.Overall, despite the thin premise of the story so reliant on a worn stereotype, this is a terrific story worth reading, hearing, or reading and hearing.

Bearing in mind that, as an older American, my hearing may not be able to discern the full range of sounds by the likes of Elmer Bernstein and of the City of Prague Philharmonic Orchestra, but I am happy with these speakers.Imagine have speakers that will connect via Auxiliary stereo cable or Bluetooth or WIFI; via house current or using batteries (6 AA batteries for each speaker).Another great, unsung feature is the sound volume of these Wolverine Portable speakers.

My Egyptian-born and raised Yorkshire Terrier, Buddy, loves this stew. Even I am tempted to give it a try.The large chunks of chicken and beef (liver and meat), immersed is a thick, creamy gravy, looks to be a passable stew for people.The cost, at just over $1.60 per can is a bit rich for my budget, if I depended on it as the only source of food for my 12-year-old dog. If it is augmented on a 50-50 basis, though, with dry food, I will use about half a can per day. Still not cheap, but manageable.I am rating it only four stars because of the price and because it is 8.5 percent protein. I would expect more protein from a meaty dish such as a stew.Overall, since Buddy loves this and since I trust what I see, and Eukxanuba, that's good enough for me.

Book Review YouTube: Building Your YouTube AudienceLength: Print, 68 pages. Not available as an audio book.Feel free to leave a comment at the end of the review or to search my profile for more good books or my email contact information.This nonfiction book is targeted to people wanting to attract viewers to their videos posted on YouTube so they can make a solid income.What was the Amazon Rank on the date this review was published? 248,706.Questions that might come to mind are: Will this book actually teach me something I didn't already know by surfing the internet? Possibly, if you can meander through errors of spelling, grammar, punctuation and a difficult formatting method with too frequent bolding/highlighting and so forth.Is this a book that I can read without having to read others first? Yes.Are there other books by this author that might also be helpful? Yes.Are there a lot of typos/misspellings, grammatical errors or other editing failures? Lots of them.Is it a quick, easy read and is the writer enthusiastic in his/her approach? It could be, with good editing.What sort of language does this writer use to amplify the points made? English language. No swear words that I recall.The one fact I am most pleased by is that I borrowed this through my Kindle Unlimited account.The excerpt below fairly accurately sums my points regarding this writer‚Äôs spelling, punctuation and grammar, or typos and layout challenges that interfered with my ability to consume the content he provides.If you don‚Äôt do this yet I highly recommend you do. I found that it dramatically increased my daily productivity when I started doing it about 3 years ago.WMT Forum Case StudyAs mentioned before I do a huge amount of work daily in this field and many relevant fields, it becomes very easy to get lost in trying out new techniques or strategies, in fact I‚Äôd say its one of the biggest threats to your success beyond inaction, that being wrong action. Now there will not always be the perfect strategy that you can always rely on the internet and YouTube changes rapidly and you have to adapt to that change by keeping up to date with your field, the easiest thing to do however is to start doing things you think will work on impulse without considering them in relation to your principles. So, a topical case study. I mentioned before we have a forum over at WebMoneyTutor.com that has a very active section devoted to YouTube. A member of the forum was highly concerned that he had ‚Äòtried everything‚Äô and yet his visibility was low, his channel was barely growing at all and he hadn‚Äôt had a video that peaked over 1000 views. His Channel was a Gaming Commentary Channel. To be fair to this member he had tried a lot of things, he was very ‚Äòbusy‚Äô. He was doing lots of sporadic activities that on paper sounded like good ideas, endlessly requesting for collaborations with big Channels. Endless spamming of his videos on semi-relevant forums and Facebook groups. He was definitely not lacking on the ‚Äòeffort‚Äô front but as myself and a few other forum members began to investigate his Channel and see what he was missing we realised straight away he was just stabbing around in the dark. He had no clear strategy set-up and was doing lots of activities that had no direction, nor did he even understand why he was doing some of them. So we went back to square one, made him look at those basic principles and begin using methodologies that actually had a clearly defined point.Silver, Daniel (2015-01-20). YouTube: Building Your YouTube Audience (Kindle Locations 240-256).  . Kindle Edition.With YouTube: Building Your YouTube Audience, the content is not so bad, perhaps. Rather, it is the manner and method of delivering that content that gets in the way.
