Length: 67 pages.Feel free to leave a comment at the end of the review or to search my profile for more good books or my email contact information.This nonfiction book is unique in that it is a summary and analysis of a debut novel. As such, it provides a bit more depth in terms of what one might expect from a review.What was the Amazon Rank on the date this review was published? 285,202.I bought this book for reasons exceeding the customary buyer. I wanted first to understand why someone would post a review for sale, especially for $2.99. Secondly, I wanted to understand another, more professional perspective on writing reviews. I mean, am I missing an opportunity to be genuinely helpful with my reviews and, just as important, am I missing an opportunity to turn a hobby into a revenue producer.Further, what might I do different if I were to explore the financial option?Yes, one could read this book without reading another, but, that might be missing the full value, at least insofar as I am concerned. So, of course, using my Kindle Unlimited account, I got the actual book, My Sister‚Äôs Grave, in  Kindle format with audio. If I do enjoy it as much as I expect, I will go ahead and purchase the book by Robert Dugoni. Which, I hasten to note, makes for a somewhat costly excursion to buy the debut novel that is the subject of this analysis and summary, (buying the summary plus buying the book plus buying the audio version is what I am meaning, is a good deal more costly than simply buying Dugoni‚Äôs original book.I discovered no typos, misspellings or grammatical errors in this brief work.Is it a quick, easy read and is the writer enthusiastic in his/her approach? This is an easy, fast, thought-provoking read, worth my time and, for my purposes, cash outlay. It is written in straight forward English with no numor.This excerpt not only gives a feel for the tempo and pace of the summary and analysis of My Sister‚Äôs Grave, it is an interesting, intriguing, synopsis of what special value can be inserted into a top notch book review:BOOK REVIEW Robert Dugoni‚Äôs My Sister‚Äôs Grave, follows Tracy Crosswhite as she puts to rest the case of her sister‚Äôs disappearance some twenty years after the fact. Through her efforts, the improper conviction of Edmund House is overturned and appropriate justice enacted upon the person who had abducted, raped and killed Sarah Crosswhite, Tracy‚Äôs sister, in the early 1990s. Along the way, the small town of Cedar Grove, Washington, is afforded final closure, and Tracy is able to set aside a decades-long obsession and live in the present once again.As with any work, My Sister‚Äôs Grave suffers problems. One that attracts particular attention is inconsistency within the work. For example, at one point, Tracy remarks on not being able to exercise sufficiently well to overcome the problems of the working police diet. Later in the novel, she explicitly notes working out ‚Äúfour times a week,‚Äù a disjunction that suggests authorial or editorial inattention. Also, the unfortunate coincidence of George Bovine‚Äôs name and racial identity (as well as his interaction with some dogs) and the comment that stereotypes are usually true come off as insensitive choices on the part of the author, not a mark in his favor.That said, there is much to recommend the novel. It is an easy read, presenting little in the way of challenge for a general audience and thereby facilitating the entry of the text into the prevailing consciousness of mainstream readership. Chapters are short, making the book easier to read in odd moments of free time, and the unresolved endings of most chapters promote continued engagement with the work. The shift late in the text serves to distance the work just enough from the tropes of the genre to defy a blatantly obvious supposition, helping to draw the reader along. In addition, narration of action is tight, and many of the secondary characters are admirably fleshed-out; they feel consonant with the setting and plot, which does much to enhance the literary effect Robert Dugoni‚Äôs 2014 novel, My Sister‚Äôs Grave, produces.Book*Sense (2014-11-05). My Sister's Grave: by Robert Dugoni | Summary & Analysis (Kindle Locations 150-164).  . Kindle Edition.If you had told me that I would, essentially, post a review of what amounts to another review, I would have chuckled and scoffed at such a moronic thought. Then again, in this world, anything and everything is beginning to look to be reasonably possible. What‚Äôs more, I actually enjoyed the analysis of the major character and found more value than I honestly expected to find.Still, paying $2.99 to read a review, even a good review that includes psycho analysis such as this work does, might exceed the disposable income of many folks. For my purposes, though, it was worth a couple of dollars.

Length: Print, 196 pages; Audio, 2 hours 27 minutes.To give you a hint as to how I value this work of history, while preparing to post this review I noticed it is available as an audio book at Audible. Consequently, I purchased an audio version so I can be reminded, from time to time, of the value of good, honest reporting.Feel free to leave a comment at the end of the review or to search my profile for more good books or my email contact information.Amazon Kindle Sales Rank at the time this review was posted: 4,450.NOTE: Because this work is of such vital interest for so many reasons, I am including two brief excerpts.Possibly the greatest value of this book consists of the reprinting of the initial reports so one can experience the story as if it were taking place these days. The included copies of print photos and newspaper headlines is immensely helpful.In this stunning reminder of a time now referred to as Yellow Journalism, huge errors, even outright fabrications, were printed in the major newspapers regarding the Titanic accident: [Excerpt 1]The New York World wasn‚Äôt the only newspaper to run with the errors mixed with the conjured and fabricated news stories.The Washington Post reported in a banner headline which reached the full width of its front page: ‚ÄúTitanic‚Äôs 1,470 Passengers Are Now Being Transferred in Lifeboats to Cunard Liner‚Äù.The Christian Science Monitor also ran with the story that all passengers were safe and had been transferred to another ship while the Titanic was under tow.An English newspaper reported that the Titanic would have to be towed back to Britain as there were no shipyards in America large enough to work on the Titanic.The New York World printed even more details about the Titanic, reporting that the ship‚Äôs bow had been ‚ÄúCrumpled by Collision with Iceberg‚Äù.Not only witness testimony by the crew at the official inquiries on both sides of the Atlantic revealed that the ship had not hit the iceberg head-on but had brushed by it on the starboard side with an underwater protrusion ripping open the hull like a can opener.The New York World staff must have been in a real frenzy conjuring up more details. The newspaper reported that the Allan Liner Virginian was towing the Titanic, which was in ‚Äòbad shape‚Äô to Halifax.The many notable passengers were reported by the New York World to have been transferred from the Titanic to the Carpathia and the Parisian. In reality, the Carpathia actually did pick up all of the survivors while the Parisian didn‚Äôt find anyone alive.The London Daily Mail also reported in early coverage that ‚ÄúNO LIVES LOST. COLLISION WITH AN ICEBERG. 2,358 LIVES IN PERIL. RUSH OF LINERS TO THE RESCUE. ALL PASSENGERSRossignol, Ken (2012-03-27). Titanic 1912: The original news reporting of the sinking of the Titanic (pp. 5-6).  . Kindle Edition.Titanic 1912 is a reminder, regardless of the contempt one might have for modern media, that there was a time when sloppy journalism (and propaganda and even outright lies to sell newspapers) were the rule, rather than the exception.One learns first hand the just how critical it is that one get the facts straight, as regards the early accounts, since proven false and, even, as fabrications conjured up by the writers of the day provided false hope to people following the most important disaster of the lives up to that point in time.There are a few typos, but not a great number. This is pretty well written and edited and is a quick, interesting read that is essential for historians and useful to members of present day media.What sort of language does this writer use to amplify the points made? Clean, everyday, spoken, English.As the below excerpt shows, greed is not restricted to present day society: [Excerpt 2]Chapter Sixteen ‚Äì Shut Up, Big Money!The controversy over whether or not the news of the Titanic disaster was intentionally held back as a result of payoffs of the New York Times to Marconi officials was fully examined by a competitor of the Times, the New York Herald.New York Herald, April 21, 1912, page 1:'Keep Your Mouth Shut; Big Money for You,' Was Message to Hide NewsHold Story for 'Four Figures,' Marconi Official Also Warned the Carpathia Operator,While Anxious World Waited Details of Disaster. While the world was waiting three days for information concerning the fate of the Titanic, for part of the time at least, details concerning the disaster were being withheld by the wireless operator of the steamship Carpathia under specific orders from T. W. Sammis, chief engineer of the Marconi Wireless Company of America, who had arranged the sale of the story.This was admitted yesterday by Mr. Sammis, who defended his action. He said he was justified for getting for the wireless operators the largest amount he could for the details of the sinking of the ship, the rescue of the passengers and the other information the world had waited for.Rossignol, Ken (2012-03-27). Titanic 1912: The original news reporting of the sinking of the Titanic (pp. 69-70).  . Kindle Edition.All in all, Titanic 1912 is a valuable not merely for the quality of writing and editing. It is a valuable resource for historians and for those with occupations related to journalism and public relations. As such, I enthusiastically rate this as a Five Star history.

Length: Print, 408 pages, Audio, 9 hours, 11 minutes.Amazon Kindle Sales Rank when this review was posted: 154.I've not read any of the other Robert Crais novels, although there are several top hits.Feel free to leave a comment at the end of this review.Language: A gritty street language English, consistent with the characters and the environment they inhabit. This writer is similar to Elmore Leonard in tempo and language, albeit, Crais is more circumspect than Leonard. There, of course, are f-bombs sprinkled in the colorful language.The best part about this novel is the pace and tone. Description of the scenes and characters is sufficient to paint a picture that the reader can still color according to his/her desires and imagination. This is what I find most appealing in a good novel.Also, as in most any good, modern novel, there is character development that is more than mere filler material. There probably would be more, except this is a series of novels.Speaking of a series, despite this being one story within a series, I found it a fun read despite never having read any other of the stories. It is not necessary to read the others, but I certainly will now go back and order the other titles in audio book format through Audible.That reminds me, although this is a good read, I think audio would be a better way to digest this story, as the pace and flow, built on dialogue, is especially good in spoken word books.The below excerpt should help readers gain a better feel for this can't miss best seller:‚ÄúThe people you work for listen.‚Äù"I‚Äôm home two days, bro. What are you talking about?‚Äù"Stolen ordnance in Echo Park. RPGs and forty-millimeter grenades. Cole‚Äôs trying to find a woman. He thinks she‚Äôs with the dealer.‚ÄùNow Jon was pissed. After thirteen years in the Army, the last six with Delta, Jon Stone had jumped the shark to become a private military contractor. He sold his services and the services of others to various clients, one said other being this very Joe Pike, who, by the way, commanded top dollar, which meant a top commission if Pike let Jon set a contract, which he wouldn‚Äôt, because Pike wasted his time with Elvis Cole, a low-rent peeper without two twenties to wipe his butt."What the hell, Pike? I don‚Äôt care about Cole and his problems. Tell me you didn‚Äôt pull me away from those women without serious cash on the table.‚Äù"If the woman‚Äôs with him, he probably sells to al-Qaeda.‚ÄùStopped Jon cold. Jon Stone‚Äôs primary client was the United States of America, with most of his work being directed against various terrorist factions and the governments, corporations, and individuals who supported them. Off the books, and deep in the black. When Jon Stone told the French chicks he was a professional warrior, he wasn‚Äôt lying.Jon glanced at his bedroom again. Nothing moved within the black rectangle framed by the doors."Al-Qaeda.‚ÄùPike nodded."Listen, so you know, just because some idiot sells this crap doesn‚Äôt mean it‚Äôs going to terrorists. All-American morons turn grenades into paperweights, and RPGs into lamps.‚Äù"The woman doesn‚Äôt care about morons. She‚Äôs been trying to contact an FTO.‚ÄùFTO. Foreign terrorist organization.Jon was totally disgusted."This is why I hate you wasting your time with Cole, bulls*** like this. What are we talking about here, a crazy person, or some kind of anti-American lunatic?‚Äù"They killed her son.‚ÄùAlthough there is a teaser at the end, leading into the next story, this is a solid novel worthy of my time and money, despite a somewhat high price.

Length: Print, 33 pages; Not available in audio.Amazon Kindle Sales Rank: 233,749.Readers should be aware that there is one instance in which a swear word is used. Since Amazon does not allow swear words in reviews, I will simply state the word rhymes with pitload. Mind you, I'm not personally offended, but some readers might be.The author might consider producing this as an audio book, much as did Rob Archangel and Buck Flogging advised in their book, How to Create an Audiobook for Audible.This booklet has more typos than I would expect. Also, the formatting does not begin chapters on a new page. Although this is not always necessary, it is customary.Aside from those issues, the advice provided is sound, and includes screen shots to help readers understand the points made.EXCERPTThe excerpt below is provided to demonstrate the author's pace and tempo. It is presented just as it appears in the booklet, typos and format.NOTE: This template is for information marketers or those whos sell some kind of coaching and consulting services, if you are a local business, then don‚Äôt worry, I‚Äôm going to teach you how you can apply this into your kind of business.1. IntroTell them your name and say the # 1 benefit they could take away from watching your video.2. More reasonsAfter that, tell them more reasons why they should watch this video and how long would it take them to watch it. I know that the video length is already given but it would be nice to reiterate that it will be short and you won‚Äôt waste their time.3. Teach themGive them what you promise you will tell them. Give them some actionable content if you are teaching some kind of step by step process.4. RecapSimply state your main points and summarize your content. Give them some key takeaways and some action to take5. Call to actionThanks them for watching the video and tell them about a special offer or a free offer. Tell them the exact steps that they need to take in order to get that offer. That‚Äôs it. _________________________________________________________________________If you are a local business owner, say you are a plumber, what I want you to do is to educate instead of sell.So instead of telling them how awesome your business is, teach them instead. Help them make an educated decision.You can teach them how to choose the best plumber. In that video, tell them the qualities that a plumber must have to be effective and worth the price.At the end of the video, always ask for an action.Never, ever end the video without asking for some kind of action. Whether it is to click the link, call us, visit us, whatever. Always ask for an action.Chapter 5 -The All Important Video Uploading ProcessHere are the simple but important guidelines for uploading your videos.File NameChange the name of your file to the keywords that you are targeting.PropertiesChange the TAG of your video, right click on your video and click details. Then add your keywords on the TAG part.Although I would have hoped the writer would have more properly edited this work, it is okay and, for 99 cents, I'm rating it a weak Four Star.

Length: 79 pages.Amazon Kindle rank at the time this review was posted: 990,793.This is a remarkably written and edited biography of Old Blood And Guts, George Patton.This quote of Patton, at the lead-in th Chapter 6, speaks volumes:‚ÄúIt is foolish and wrong to mourn the men who died. Rather we should thank God that such men lived.‚Äù ‚ÄìGeorge S. Patton.Before I go further in this review, I just have to comment on one of the video clips.Less than a month ago I chanced upon an interview with a local unsung hero. He came to our local American Legion post on his 60th Anniversary. I snapped a pic of him with the Post Commander and got some of his information to post in the local newspaper. Thereupon learning that he was under the command of Patton, I was so intrigued that I decided to conduct an in-depth interview.That's when I learned he had opted to traverse the last 80 miles, or so, n a Piper Cub enroute to a battle at Minsk. It seemed to Ervin Longnecker a no-brainier - 80 miles in a two-seater Piper Cub or jostling back and forth, up and down, in a convoy troop truck. Little did he then know that his greatest nightmare was yet to come...At the end of the flight, he was ordered to greet none other than General Dwight D. Eisenhower. Longnecker told me, "I was scared to death, shaking in my boots, certain I was going to make a mistake. Ike told me 'At ease, son, we're at war."Eisenhower even shook Longnecker's hand to calm the young unsung hero of Little Branford's hand.I included the foregoing after viewing a short video clip in this Interactive Biography of George Patton that, I believe, may include Ervin Longnecker standing before the Supreme Allied Commander. I will show the video to Longnecker to confirm, if possible. Bear in mind, though, Longnecker is now nearly 97 years old.Okay, back to the review...I did not come across any editing snafus - no typos, no spelling errors and none of the mistakes typical of failed proofing or editing.There are a number of quality black and white photographs and video clips, and even at least one full color photo.All considered, possibly because of my own slight personal tie-in, I confess, I believe this is the best interactive volume Charles River Editors has thus far published.Certainly, this book deserves a place in every military historian's Kindle library. I also hope it is included as an audiobook for audible.com in the future.By the way, although Longncker was aware of the slapping incident, he was quick to inform me that all, or certainly the vast majority of soldiers under Patton's command, "Loved and respected Old Blood and Guts."

Length: 30 pages.Rank at the time of this review: 158,099.The writing and editing are pretty good. I found one or two typos or misspellings, but nothing too severe, other than a price range of £7,000 to $70,000 which probably was meant to read $7,000 to $70,000. Oh, and right at the beginning the author states, "The world is literally your oyster." This error is common, but begs to be corrected. Literal means truly, which implies fact. The correct word to use is figuratively, since, as we all know, the world is not in fact an oyster.I know it sounds like I'm being picky, but a good copy editor would tell the author the same.Aside from the above minor points, although this booklet is well written and certainly a terrific inspiration, it falls short of the implied promise to show people how to live debt-free and stress-free.Having stated that it falls short, though, I do believe it succeeds in inspirational advice to stimulate readers into getting motivated into living an RV lifestyle for long term living. In that sense, I love this book, despite the shortcomings and occasional typo.

Length: 88 pages.I have mixed emotions regarding this interactive biography.On the one hand, it does an excellent job highlighting he great military leader's splendid accomplishments, not the least of which was his becoming the first son of a Congressional Medal of Honor winner to also be so awarded. MacArthur was unquestionably a brave warrior and great strategist.I also appreciated the candid appraisal of the man's blunders during WW II and, especially, at Korea.My misgivings are two-fold:There are more typos and editing snafus in this book than I have seen in almost any other CRE book. A stray 4 and a stray 6 early in the book, and some typos here and there, plus a word missing in the last paragraph of chapter 10: the word "years" is missing after 36, making it read 36 after instead of 36 years after...The sloppy editing, though, is not the only concern. The video clips don't seem to properly amplify the points, for me, and, hence, just don't add the value that I expected. Also, the clip of his address to congress seems shorter than intended, but, perhaps I am spoiled by so many other great CRE interactive presentations.I do feel that an opportunity to present the heart and soul of this great leader was missed. On the other hand, I am grateful to CREfor being able to see how the ever growing ego of this leader whose errors came mostly after his prominence seemed to lead him to believe he was invincible.I also want to mention, there are several nice photographs plus on fantastic color picture of MacArthur surrounded by fellow troops on a beachfront.I liked this book, but didn't love it. Not certain why, though, aside from the above mentioned points.

Length: 70 pages.This is a fun read. Usually we think of gold diggers being women on the prowl for a rich fool who, let's face it, simply wants a trophy to escort him to parties and country clubs.Of course, there are at least as many men trying to con rich women with their suave, sophisticated accents. Usually, the accents are British, as, for some reason, many women conjure up fantasies pertaining to princes and earls of the British Isles.Edward is the one of the more talented cons you ever shall encounter. But, he is a scoundrel who will have you wishing you could tear his eyes out one moment. The next, you will be guffawing in anticipation of his nerve.The stories were delightful, smooth, and painted quite clearly by the author. I like how she presented this con man with a light touch, not going over the top, so to say. What I mean is that she could have been quite brutal with this fiend. In some manner, I think Inge H. Borg dreamed up a character she wanted to despise. Then, somewhere along the way, she grew attached to his inner soul and could not so easily dispatch him.Edward is clearly the scumbag every woman wants to meet so she can be swept off her feet, but, in the end, they are instead cleaned of their worldly possessions, their honor and their own self respect. And, sometimes, these women, truth be known, are open for yet another Edward to come into their lives.Well written, well edited, with no serious typos or grammatical errors. Worth the buck and a quarter, many times over.

Length: 124 pages.This nonfiction book about Amazon's newest device is well-written and well edited.The only editing snafu I found was at 43 percent through the book, where it is written to go, instead of go to. In other words, the two words are flip-flopped, which is a not uncommon error when a writer is thinking faster than they type. At any rate, his small error is not sufficient to weaken the value of the book.What is confusing however, is the discussion regarding having Alexa read your audiobooks. I own approximately 900 Audible programs. Most are full length books, but many are old time radio plays, and a few are some contemporary productions by Colonial Radio Theatre On the Air. My confusion is, why would I have Alexa read these productions when I've already paid a good some for the professional narrators and voice actors?At first, I was intrigued that Alexa would read my books, but, if Alexa won't read my Kindle books, this feature is unimportant to me. Further, if the speaker won't simply serve as a speaker via Bluetooth to play my audible.com books in the voices I paid for, then Alexa is a minus, in my case.Of course, had I not read this book, I might have purchased an Alexa only to be disappointed, so I am quite pleased to have read this through my kindle Unlimited account.McKinnon writes in a smooth, business English manner. He had many natural opportunities to slip in a joke or a goofy statement, but elected not to play cute. I greatly respect that.I was able to read this book in one setting, which says much for a 124 page book.

Length: 229 pages.Feel free to leave a comment at the end of the review or to search my profile for more good books or my email contact information.This nonfiction book is targeted to people, young or old, interested in learning about generals who led Americans into battle against one another in the Civil War.What was the Amazon Rank on the date this review was published? 676,866.I found this a good, pretty quick, easy-to-read resource that, while not extensive, was well-steeped in information about each of the leaders discussed. Sometimes, reading a large volume will nourish my hunger for information, and the civil war is just such a topic. Other times, though, especially while commuting, reading quick histories (or listening to Kindle read them to me) is a nice way to learn, or refresh one‚Äôs memory of that which was previously learned.Having stated that, I want to point out that this book by Charles River Editors is, possibly, the largest page count I have yet read by CRE.Are there other books by this author that might also be helpful? Charles River Editors has more than 1,000 inexpensive books posted at Amazone.com and a few at audible.com, my favorite source for audiobooks since 2002.Are there a lot of typos/misspellings, grammatical errors or other editing failures? I didn‚Äôt detect any.What sort of language does this writer use to amplify the points made? Common, clean, everyday English.Is this better to read, or is it better to listen to? Audio would be nice, but reading is fine.Unlike most other CRE books I‚Äôve read, this is laced with excellent modern photographs and illustrations. I mean, they are not just historical in pics. One in particular is a present-day photo of Grant‚Äôs birthplace. Better yet, the front cover illustration used for the book is among the best Kindle covers I‚Äôve seen. It depicts a battle in progress. Another is of William Tecumseh Sherman‚Äôs boyhood home in Ohio. There also is a photograph showing the location where Stonewall Jackson was shot and one of his tomb. Just as with Grant and Sherman, there is a modern photograph of home that is presently preserved in Arlington National Cemetery.Aside from the above photographs, there are color illustrations that depict the battle plans and troop movements, as well as authentic black and white photographs taken at battlegrounds during and/or after battles.Although this volume is not extensive in its coverage of the war, it is a well-written, well-edited volume that should be in every historian‚Äôs Kindle library. It ranks as one of my favorite CRE books that is not interactive. I would expect that is primarily because the war pre-dated video, obviously. Still, it could benefit with some video clips taken at several of the battlegrounds and shrines that exist today.I do want to note that the legacies of Stonewall and Lee are included, as well as some treatment regarding the post-war lives of the Yankee generals, especially the man who went on to serve as President, the general known as Unconditional Surrender Grant.

Length: 33 pages.Feel free to leave a comment at the end of the review or to search my profile for more good books or my email contact information.This nonfiction book is targeted to kids or to adults who wish to spend some quality time with their children or grandchildren using a smart phone or a tablet computer.What was the Amazon Rank on the date this review was published? 1,880,580.Questions that might come to mind are: Will this book actually teach me something I didn't already know by surfing the internet? Yes. At least it will be an easier, smoother experience and can be controlled.Are there other books by this author that might also be helpful? Charles River Editors has more than 1,000 inexpensive books posted at Amazone.com and a few at audible.com, my favorite source for audiobooks since 2002.Are there a lot of typos/misspellings, grammatical errors or other editing failures? I didn‚Äôt detect any.As a youth I watched a great Tony Curtis movie based on the life of Houdini. Although that movie was excellent and actually stayed much closer to the true story than most films in recent years that are labeled, ‚ÄúBased on a True Story,‚Äù this book did inform me of some things I don‚Äôt recall from the movie.This is a well-written and well-edited book that deals with most of the key points of Houdini‚Äôs life. The video clips were a nice touch that helped drive the story home and embed it into my memory banks.That and Houdini‚Äôs last words: I would print them here, except that it might be construed as a spoiler and, I abhor spoilers.What sort of language does this writer use to amplify the points made? Straight forward, English, with neither bias nor prejudice. In other words, it is straight reporting.Is this better to read, or is it better to listen to? Since it contains video, I don‚Äôt think there would be any special advantage for it to be available in audiobook format, but for some, especially those unable to read for one reason or another, audio would be a nice move.I was thoroughly entertained and can see how this would be a terrific way for me to spend quality time with my grandchildren. Oh, just recalled, I don‚Äôt have any grandchildren. So, I suppose I shall just have to visit with a family or two from Church come Christmas Vacation‚Ä¶

Length: 109 pages.Feel free to leave a comment at the end of the review or to search my profile for more good books or my email contact information.This nonfiction book is targeted to kids or to adults who wish to spend some quality time with their children or grandchildren using a smart phone or a tablet computer. Let‚Äôs face it, to reach kids these days, it simply will not do to work so hard to pry them away from their electronic media and then expect them to enjoy you reading to them using some old book. Yes, when you can‚Äôt beat ‚Äòem, you can join them in their natural habitat.What was the Amazon Rank on the date this review was published? 2,466,814.Questions that might come to mind are: Will this book actually teach me something I didn't already know by surfing the internet? For all intents and purposes, yes. At least it will be an easier, smoother experience and can be controlled.Is this a book that I can read without having to read others first? Yes, but it likely will spur you and the kids on to other terrific, quick, educational, fun reads. That is perhaps its greatest value.Are there other books by this author that might also be helpful? Charles River Editors has more than 1,000 inexpensive books posted at Amazone.com and a few at audible.com, my favorite source for audiobooks since 2002.Are there a lot of typos/misspellings, grammatical errors or other editing failures? I didn‚Äôt detect any.You could say this is three books in one. One book each covering President John F. Kennedy, Robert F. Kennedy and Ted Kennedy.This is a well-written and well-edited book that deals with most of the important observations and issues affecting each man, plus a bit of history of the Kennedy family and of Joseph, the eldest brother who died at age 29 while on a mission during World War II.What sort of language does this writer use to amplify the points made? Straight forward, English, with neither bias nor prejudice. In other words, it is straight reporting.Is this better to read, or is it better to listen to? Since it contains video, I don‚Äôt think there would be any special advantage for it to be available as an audiobook, but for some, especially those unable to read for one reason or another, audio would be a nice move.I was but a third grade student when JFK was shot, so I have little memory of him except for the assassination and, one minor point. My family was camping one summer, possibly 1962 or 1963, at Big Bear in California‚Äôs San Bernardino Mountains. While Dad was driving, looking for a campsite I think, we saw a small shop or store with a sign posted. The sign read, as I recall, Closed Until That Catholic Traitor Kennedy is Removed From Office. I recollected Mom‚Äôs shock that somebody could be so hateful.I recall a bit more about Robert. I criticized Mom for becoming a volunteer in his 1968 campaign, teling her, ‚ÄúYou know he‚Äôs just going to get shot.‚Äù Only years later would I come to realize how wrong I was about the country‚Äôs need for RFK and how much we lost by his assassination. While I doubt Sirhan Sirhan had assistance, I wish he had been prevented from so hurting our nation.Ted Kennedy, though, I have many memories of. I know for certain, through a shipmate who‚Äôs uncle was Mayor Bradley in Los Angeles that Ted had chosen not to challenge Carter. Then, news leaked that Carter had told someone that he would kick Kennedy‚Äôs &$$ if Ted entered the race. I phoned my contact and learned that Ted Kennedy was reconsidering. Might have been a nice touch to have included this tidbit in the book, but, probably, nobody would have cared to know.I also was a volunteer in the 1980 campaign for Kennedy. Even worked for a few days with a nephew of his, a 19-year-old named William Kennedy Smith, in New Hampshire. Working in Maine, I even met Ted one weekend, while I was escorting some senior citizens to caucus for him. I was stunned at how much Ted looked like my own father, save for my father being bald and just a little older than Ted Kennedy.Okay, I did include a little of my life into this review. If that bothers you, please accept my apology. Regarding An Interactive Biography of the Kennedy Brothers, though, this is a remarkable, if all too brief, history that young and old should find interesting and educational. With the included video clips, it should also entertain youngsters while roping them into an educational experience. A Win-Win.I feel quite fortunate to have found this booklet available while it was a free download, but would have willingly parted with the small asking price if I had not been so fortunate.

Length: 40 pages.Feel free to leave a comment at the end of the review or to search my profile for more good books or my email contact information.This nonfiction book is targeted to youngsters who might find learning more pleasurable when interspersed with video content. The video works best on smarthphones and tablet computers.What was the Amazon Rank on the date this review was published? 416,551.Questions that might come to mind are: Will this book actually teach me something I didn't already know by surfing the internet? Yes. At least, it will be an easier, quicker resource to use.Most readers, including adults, may be surprised to learn that Edison was first an entrepreneur, becoming the first to publish newspapers aboard locomotives.Of course, it was his technological creations that most stunned the world and paved the way for the Gates, Wozniak and Jobs that would come a century later. To name just three: Phonograph; Light Bulb; Moving Pictures.Whether it is the Sioux Ghost Dance, the Sisters Boxing, or the Mock Battle at the 1901 Expo, I am certain kids, and parents, will be enthralled by the video clips in this interactive booklet.I love the Edison Quote at the heading of Chapter 2:‚ÄúOpportunity is missed by most people because it is dressed in overalls and looks like work.‚Äù ‚Äì Thomas EdisonIs this a book that I can read without having to read others first? Yes, but it may instill a curiosity to youths who may go on to educate themselves more intensely.Are there other books by this author that might also be helpful? Charles River Editors (CRE) has published more than 1,000 other booklets, several of which are interactive histories or biographies especially targeted towards youngsters.Are there a lot of typos/misspellings, grammatical errors or other editing failures? I did not come across any, which is a bit unusual for CRE booklets.Is it a quick, easy read and is the writer enthusiastic in his/her approach? Yes, a quick tempo that most children should find interesting.Is there humor? Is it wry, laugh-out-loud funny? Is it moronic? A light touch, yes. Humor, as such, no. Still, I cannot help but note the irony in the second paragraph of Chapter 2, in which a vote counting machine was Edison‚Äôs first patentable invention. Of course, I am recollecting the debacle in Florida in the 2000 Presidential Election. Excerpt:In 1869, Thomas Edison was awarded his first patent by the United States government. This meant that nobody else could make the product he had invented. His invention was an electronic way to count votes.  No one wanted to use it.  The only people who could really use it were politicians. But Congressmen didn‚Äôt even want it. They didn‚Äôt trust a machine to record their votes.Charles River Editors (2013-05-16). An Interactive Biography of Thomas Edison for Kids (Kindle Locations 106-109). Charles River Editors. Kindle Edition.What sort of language does this writer use to amplify the points made? A version of English that is a little simpler for youngster to understand than that normally used in everyday English.I found An Interactive Biography of Thomas Edison for Kids to be quite educational and entertaining, even inspirational due to the quotes for the first four chapters.Probably, though, the greatest value derives from the short, stimulating videos; one of which is of the Sioux Ghost Dance. The Ghost Dance was at the time this video appears to have been recorded, was at the height of controversy ‚Äì a time when whites feared attacks and a renewal of the Indian Wars of then recent history.

An Interactive History of the Space RaceLength: 66 pages.Feel free to leave a comment at the end of the review or to search my profile for more good books or my email contact information.This nonfiction book is targeted to people interested in understanding the essential points in the early history of space exploration. It is especially dedicated towards the youth, whose likely interest will be enhanced by the eight videos.What was the Amazon Rank on the date this review was published? 1,260,223.Questions that might come to mind are: Will this book actually teach me something I didn't already know or would not have gleaned by surfing the internet? Probably not, but it is a more interesting and enjoyable read than can be obtained through surfing and hunting for video and data of interest.Is this a book that I can read without having to read others first? Absolutely.Are there other books by this author that might also be helpful? Charles River Editors has provided more than 1,000 booklets at Amazon. A few of them also are available as audiobooks at audible.com and, as is this book, are enjoyable, easy, quick reads for the curious folks around the globe.Are there a lot of typos/misspellings, grammatical errors or other editing failures? There are a few, but none of them is bothersome.Is it a quick, easy read and is the writer enthusiastic in his/her approach? Yes, it is quick and easy, but the writing is more straight to the fact, rather than enthusiastic.What sort of language does this writer use to amplify the points made? Common, everyday English, that most people familiar with English will find easy to understand.Is this, or should this, be available on audible.com? No, it is not and probably would not benefit by becoming an audio book.Is this better to read, or is it better to listen to?Trivia Quiz question one:What was the first living organism to travel into outer space?A - a monkeyB ‚Äì a human beingC ‚Äì a dogD ‚Äì fruit fliesIf you chose A, B, or C, you have not yet read An Interactive History of the Space Race.Trivia Quiz question two:The first mammal to enter outer space was a dog. What was the dog‚Äôs name and whatever became of it? Was it paraded as a hero or was its fate celebrated by anybody?A ‚Äì Yes, Laika was a dog owned by a famous German-American scientist interested in promoting animal welfare.B ‚Äì Yes, Laika was a dog from the Soviet Union that Premier Kruschev championed as proof of the superiority of dogs raised in the USSR.C ‚Äì No, a stray dog from Moscow named Laika died in space with little fanfare or concern for what many people regard as man‚Äôs best friend.D ‚Äì No, Laika did not survive the trip but was heralded by both America and by the Soviets as a heroic volunteer in humanity‚Äôs space exploration.For details, you can read the booklet or read the excerpt below, which may be the first time Laika was singled out in print. Air Bud, Lassie, and Rin Tin Tin all would have been disappointed to learn the dog‚Äôs fate‚Ä¶Excerpt:As a stray dog from Moscow, Laika seemed an unusual candidate to make history as the first living thing to orbit around the Earth. At that time, however, nobody was sure what effects space travel might have on the human body, and the Soviets weren‚Äôt confident enough in their launching technology to risk their cosmonauts‚Äô lives. Thus, Laika and two other dogs trained for the Sputnik-2 mission, which included isolating the dogs and forcing them to live in cramped compartments.Laika was the winner, but that didn‚Äôt make her a lucky winner. Unbeknownst to the poor dog, she was given a suicide mission. In 1957, the Soviets had no clue how to de-orbit a spacecraft through reentry into the Earth‚Äôs atmosphere, and they had no intention of trying to figure it out for a stray dog. It is still not entirely clear when or how the dog died during the mission; the Soviets later claimed she lived for days, either euthanized with poisoned food or dying when the oxygen onboard ran out, but it‚Äôs now believed she died within hours from an overheated cabin.Charles River Editors (2013-02-06). An Interactive History of the Space Race (Kindle Locations 177-184). Waxkeep Publishing. Kindle Edition.Overall, I believe An Interactive History of the Space Race is a good tool to use by parents and educators alike to foster an interest in history and science. I consider it a good choice for any parent or grandparent to consider as a gift for stocking, figuratively, in a Christmas Stocking. What I mean is, buying a kindle, or having the free Kindle App loaded onto a child‚Äôs smartphone or tablet computer, and then ‚Äògifting‚Äô them a copy of this inexpensive booklet could make for a quality gift that entertains while it educates.Why a smartphone or tablet? The interactive media (video)  works on smartphones or tablet computers, but not on the kindle app available for laptops or desktops. Note: I do not have access to a Microsoft Surface, so perhaps someone who uses a Surface can check to see if it works on one. I have not yet checked to see if the video works on my Kindle Fire HD or on my Paperwhite, but I will check and add my observations as soon as possible.

When I first saw this was available for testing, I declined , because several years ago I bought what was then said to be a state-of-the-art ASUS Desktop Computer.I had so many troubles with that one, I didn't know who to blame, so I blamed ASUS & Microsoft for its BSOD issues.Mind you, that was in Egypt and that was 12 years ago. So, just in case I was missing out on a good opportunity, I discussed the specs for this desktop with my IT guy at work. He thought I was making a big mistake, so I went ahead and ordered it through Amazon Vine,Hey, it is a jewel for its price. Loaded with Windows 10, it seems Microsoft just might be recovering some lost ground.First though, let's discuss the hardware:I took everything out of the box. Hooked up the mouse and keyboard into the USB Ports in the back. Hooked up the HDMI cable to the back. Plugged in the power cable and....Everything worked. I let it install updates and the took the quick tour. Then, I immediately downloaded Google Chrome and made that my default browser, since it is superior to all other browsers, in my opinion.I didn't spend a lot of time testing the DVD player today, but will test it in coming days. Regarding the other hardware:The computer has good speed with the i5 processor.Keyboard, about average. There is a decent spring back feel to the keys, but it doesn't feel as good as most quality keyboards. Also, I'm a little harder on keyboards than many, so I expect keys to break soon with this. Also, the labeling on the keys appears less than optimum - my experience tells me the I'd will wear off quite soon. I will definitely replace this with a better keyboard. I will probably opt for a wireless keyboard similar to the one I bought for my Mac Mini.The mouse works quite well. It isn't the best I've used, and it isn't wireless, but, I am pleased with it and expect to keep it.I was actually quite pleased with how easily and quickly I was able to get up and running.Although my preference remains the Mac Mini, which I now have updated to elCapitan operating system, I can definitely see where other geeks would enjoy using Windows 10 on an ASUS M32Cd Desktop.Unlike a Mac, this computer does not come equipped with iTunes, Photos, and the other freebies that are loaded on a Mac. That lack, though, is not the fault of ASUS, so it is unfair to hold that against them. Then, too. ASUS costs a lot less than a Mac...Judging this computer, as supplied, hardware and software, for the selling price, I rate as a five star. If my siblings or in-laws were to ask my appraisal, I'd give the ASUS M32CD an enthusiastic thumbs up.

Length: print, 209 pages; audio, 3 hours, 3 minutes.This is book two in a series for young adults looking for good action-adventure stories hat pit kids in a desperate search for survival with little more than their own wits as tools.The series, inspired by Jeff Probst's reality TV series, Survivor, is set in a clean English that no parent should find objectionable but that is truer to life for kids brought together as one family comprised of the kids from two families.In other words, these four kids, aged 13 and under, experience as great a challenge with one another as from the weather, food shortage, or wild boars. To survive, they need to form a team. Will they succeed?Unfortunately, this is not a series that can be read out of order. To fully appreciate book two, you Ned to read book one first.My wife and I enjoyed the series primarily while driving, so I bout the audio version. I highly recommend buying the kindle version, but, at the same time, purchasing the audio version as a Whispersync - this saves you $3.49 and the narrator does an excellent job, reading it slow enough so you can hear each PD well enough to avaoid hitting the 30-second replay button too often.i enjoyed Trial by Fire and plan to listen to book three tomorrow..

Length: 280 pages. This is not yet available at audible.com for some reason.I note this author, and this series, is a huge hit on Amazon. Having said that, I have read none of the previous books, so, bear with me. My eyes are a fresh look at this monster hit series.This is a combination war storie, science-fiction action-adventure. In other words, this book will best address the cravings guys have for hot and dirty get-in-your face action with no, uh, politically correct niceties.Put another way, this is not a story we ever are likely to view on Hallmark Channel. For me, that is great, for I read it in parallel with a book that is perfect for Hallmark. I needed to offset that other excellent literary work with something that, if not a literary masterpiece of mainstream prose, would appeal to my John Wayne/Clint Eastwood cravings.Okay, I admit it, I am an old geezer. I love gritty shoot-em-ups and football.Even so, I also sometimes abhor stories of war guys loving the action shooting enemies whom they don't acknowledge as also being human. Navy Seals with Charlie Sheen was, for me, a total waste of time, even though I usually love his flicks.So, that should let you see why I was so late in discovering this great series of stories that, despite not being great literary works and despite not working towards character development. I have been trying to avoid stories that feel too similar to Navy Seals.By the way, lest I forget, the language is the sort we all have come to expect from military heroes. It is coarse, but, the language is perfectly consistent with that I would expect to hear in situations similar to those in which these guys find themselves. Certainly it sounds more believable than the artificial cussing I came across in a recent sci-fi, Dark Space.One quote, in particular, has won a place in my lexicon. Until this book, I often found myself quoting a friend who liked to find something more interesting that that offered to him. He'd quip, "I think I'd rather pick fleas off my dead dog."My new favorite quip goes something like,(paraphrasing) "You boys look about as confused as my cat trying to bury his leavings on a frozen pond in the Dakotas."Granted, it is far funnier the way the author puts it, but Amazon doesn't permit such language on its review pages.I loved this book as a great relief from other recent stories. It is intense and studded with action throughout.Two observations that are not pertinent to the story:Too much of the front matter consists of promoting other books in the series. I prefer to delve straight into the reason I spent my hard earned money for.The back matter that ordinarily is promotion, though, is terrific. The author explains where and how he was inspired to show certain key points. I have not seen other writers do this so well and with so much class.As stated at the start, I can't believe it took me so long to find this series. Though I read book 10, it felt as good to me as a book one. Perhaps I shall feel different after I read the previous books, but right now I am a huge fan.Also, I don't know why this is not yet available at Audible, but, you can be sure I will be among the first to but the audio version.I can't wait for the movies.

Length: 304 pages.This is a novel more about the struggles married couples encounter while trying to muddle through life in the 21st Century.In that sense, this was less about the dog than I anticipated. I should have realized that when I read the whiz bang opening paragraph.I would summarize this as a romantic comedy especially appealing to professional women in modern society. Except it's more literary and laced with several layers of doubt and self doubt.Before I forget, it is important that in one instance, the f-bomb is uttered. In today's society, though, I would have expected such an expletive to be uttered in exactly the same situation in which it pierces the air, even by some of the older ladies I know here in North Dakota, so it should not deter anybody from buying. However, I have known a few people who would want to know, so I do mention it.As I mentioned earlier, I bought this expecting a story more about the dog and the birth of an unexpected baby. After all, although I do have two (adult) sons, but my current wife, though previously married, has no children. Not long after we married, we took in a Yorkie while living in my wife's native home in Cairo, Egypt. I therefore expected to be able to immediately relate to this story, in an abstract way, if, at least, we were able to bear a child.Still, even though the dog was not central to the story, and even though this was far more literary than I normally read, this did grab me and hold me from beginning to end. I did experience frustration with the back and forth hot-and-cold romantic goings on, but that is what makes romantic comedy entertaining.The writing and editing is superb and professional throughout. Further, written in first person, this sort of story is more difficult to write and keep interesting than one might expect.Character development for the husband and wife was good, but, honestly, it was a little difficult for me to fully identify with either person. Not sure why, though, so it may only be that I am older and am a guy. At any rate, this is a superb story for the Hallmark Channel that I am certain my wife will love.

Length: 111 pages.I am camping at Lake Sakakawea in North Dakota and am forced to write this review using an iPhone. My fingers are clumsy so please excuse an typos that escape my notice due to vision failures.This is, generally, as well written of a guide on the topic of writing for Kindle that I've yet read.The only error I found, grammatically, was in regards two two alternatives. He should have used the singular 'is' instead of 'are' but such a distinction is nitpicking. This book has excellent editing.There is mild profanity. I found one instance in which hel/ and one in which da$& was used. The are numerous times in which the three-letter word as$ was used as kick-as$ but otherwise there is no serious profanity.The language is quick, snappy and, well, written in common everyday spoken English.Although most of the book is useful, it is Chapter 9 that is outstanding when he talks about rewriting.Overall, this is a terrific guide for any self publisher.

Length: Print format: 119 pages. Audio format, 1 hour 57 minutes.Before I begin this review, I want to pay tribute to a fellow Amazon Reviewer who recently passed away ‚Äì Harriet Klausner. She published more than 30,000 reviews on Amazon until, on October 15, 2015, she went to the great library in the sky to join another recently deceased Amazon Reviewer, Hall-of-Fame member, Peter Durward Harris.Although I never communicated with Klausner, I feel a certain kinship with her, primarily because we both started reviewing about the same time and because we both were born in 1952.Mr. Harris and I did share an email or two and he did provide some reviewing tips to me once or twice.Because of my sudden realization that reviewing might well be the most lasting mark I make on this world (pitiful as that may sound to a few of you), I have decided to take this craft a bit more seriously now. I am going to experiment with a new structure, in an effort to provide more useful information in my reviews, but, as I have always strived, to avoid rambling so much about the contents that I burn out the readers desire to read the book.Further, I will continue to avoid spoiling the ending or critical points of the book. Especially with fiction, I want my review readers to get a good feel for the quality of writing; the tempo of the story and a general understanding so they can make a better, informed judgement, as to whether the book is something they will find useful and/or entertaining.In short, my reviews are not intended to be used for book reports for school.Feel free to leave a comment at the end of the review or to search my profile for more good books or my email contact information.This nonfiction book is targeted to indie writers in search of how-to books that show them the most efficient steps to market their books.Q - Is this a get-rich scheme or is it good, fundamental advice?This is good, fundamental advice that, if followed, will not merely help you sell more books, but will help you provide better written and better edited books that people will find useful or entertaining.Q - What was the Amazon Rank on the date this review was published?Selling rank on date of this review was 280,733, which is exceptional for a book originally published two years ago, on September 6, 2013. That means this book has superior staying power to most books in its class.Q: Will this book actually teach me something I didn't already know by surfing the internet?Yes, it probably will teach you several points that, if they are indeed on the internet already, are certainly not too easy to ferret out.Q - Is this a book that I can read without having to read others first?Yes, but, as with most similar books, this writer has published a series of complimentary titles that you will want to check out.Q - Are there other books by this author that might also be helpful?Yes. Several.Q - Are there a lot of typos/misspellings, grammatical errors or other editing failures?I did not come across any. At least not worthy of mention. Probably, because he has had professional editing done.Q - Is it a quick, easy read and is the writer enthusiastic in his/her approach?Yes. Rogan writes in an engaging, enthusiastic style that you will want to read or listen to quickly, then go back to the points that most resonate with you.Q - Is there humor? Is it wry, laugh-out-loud funny? Is it moronic?Light humor, not laugh out loud or moronic, but a more of the humor suitable for young and mature audiences.Q - What sort of language does this writer use to amplify the points made?Pretty much the same sort of language your college professor might use in a lecture, provided he/she is not trying to impress you with seven-letter words. What I mean is, the language is good, crisp, everyday English that will not require access to a dictionary for high school graduates or most high school drop-outs.Q - Is this, or should this, be available on audible.com?Yes, it is available on audible.com. In fact, if you purchase the whispersync at the same time you buy the Kindle version, you can save $3.00.Q - Is this better to read, or is it better to listen to?You will want a Kindle version so you can refer back (or bookmark) to key points, but, I immensely enjoyed listening to an outstanding narration by Greg Zarcone. In fact, at just 1 hour 57 minutes, I will certainly listen to this book another time or two so I can embed the information so that, when I finally do publish a book, I can make it the best seller it can be.Note: if you buy the whispersync version at the same time you purchase it on Kindle, instead of buying it later at audible.com, you can add save three dollars.Q - To what degree or percentage does this book succeed in its goal?I would judge that it fully met its goal. Still, there is one tip he gives regarding acquiring reviewers that I found does not ring quite true. Speaking for myself and, I believe, many fellow Amazon Reviewers, I never open attachments from unsolicited emails. I am almost certain to never review any eBook that is not in Kindle format.Further, concerning complimentary reviews upon request, I only review print format, or Kindle format that are gifted to me through Amazon‚Äôs outstanding KDP program. Otherwise, I review only books that I purchase myself.Q ‚Äì Overall satisfaction derived from this production?As hinted above, I found this to be a valuable addition to my library and plan to put its principles into action, if and when I ever actually do start producing books about my several entrepreneurial endeavors or about my expat residency in Egypt (before and during the revolution and counter-revolution), Libya during Moammar Gaddafi or in Southern Africa as Nelson Mandela commenced his drive to take power.I hope you find this review helpful and even that you leave a comment. We reviewers, just as most writers, love to learn if our work is useful and why. Until then, good day.

Length: 50 pages.Unlike some of the other interactive biographies recently published by Charles River Editors, the video clips do not include sound. If they do, the audio did not work with my iPhone, even with auxiliary speakers hooked up. That reduces, slightly, the value of the interactive nature.Also, there are only two clips included. A parade in her honor and a very short clip, the last known clip, of her before her ill-fated trek in an attempt to circumnavigate Planet Earth.This is a pretty good, if short, biography. I found three very minor typos: One is merely a repeated word early in the booklet. I went back looking for it for this review, but couldn't find it; 2nd error was at location 143, second paragraph, where it reads, 'first record as a s female...' Obviously, the a and the s are not needed; The third, and last typo I found was substitution of the word Here instead of Her, at location 392, referring to "...Her last entry..."I believe, as does the other reviewer, that this could be useful in bringing to life an historical point so a young audience can learn about a most important female who pioneered the way for equality in employment free of sexual discrimination. Considering how enduring that battle has been, the early 21st Century needs to grapple with all forms of discrimination.But, just as electing a Black American President has not eliminated racial discrimination, it also is likely true that electing a woman President is not likely to herald wage equality. Accomplishing either goal requires each of us Americans to recognize the root of the problems and to deal with those causes.The feeling that any particular group is more qualified or capable or more in favor with God is outdated.Okay, I know I am pontificating, but, if educational books can not stimulate inward thinking and foster change, then what use is education?

Length: 546 pages.Target audience is Young Adult, but even , a senior citizen, found this an engaging science fiction story, with the right blend of romance, action, and fantasy (time travel). And, yes, even though it is the third (conclusion) book in a trilogy, it is the first of the three (plus two novellas) that I have read.I note that, even to I am sure I missed some of the meaning by starting with the third, it is certainly a stand alone that will bring pleasure to most every reader.This author has, apparently, grown into the Kindle publishing business. I say this, because she put all the skippable information at the back of the book. Very smart and very smooth. Just as many of my friends, I prefer to jump right into the story, especially with Kindle, and not be bothered with what I call the fluff, or skippable information.Also, even though, unlike writing instructors (I think it was Elmore Leonard) I will read prologues, but prefer not to. In Time's Divide there is no prologue.An other sin most new authors commit is the opening scene: they love to open with a statement regarding the weather. Again, this writer does not. Fantastic.Usually, I am the type of reader that Leonard claimed to write for. I tend to skip scenes such as romance and excess description. Partly because I am in a hurry to get the main story without wading through all the obligatory stuff that I love to skip over. In fact, until recently, I tended not to purchase books that exceeded the thickness that would fit into my back pocket. Then, I got a Kindle. And, then I read some of Stephen King's books that required half of the Cascade Mountain Range forests for printing.You see, on Kindle, number of pages is inconsequential to my lugging the book to and from work. Well, when I read The Stand, at some 1,400 pages, I realized I was missing out on some great stories. That marked my change as a reader. Now, I am far more willing to read 400 and 500 page books.That is not only fortunate for me, it is a good thing for Rysa Walker. At 526 pages, were this in paperback, I would have never tried it. Then again, perhaps it is I who is fortunate.I can visualize, with some adaptation, the conversion of this book into a future Star Trek motion picture. If that occurs, I'd love to attend the opening. One other Time-Travel Action Adventure book pleased me as much as did Time's Divide: that is Dinosaur Four. However, Time's Divide is, honestly, written by a more seasoned author who has been developing a terrific following.

Length: 256 pages.I'm a sucker for trivia, especially quizzes, so, of course, I like this.Learning through trivia games can be fun, but the way this one is setup is less enjoyable than I expected. Also, as alluded to by another reviewer,you cannot afford to make mistakes.Furthermore, I expected this to be a book to read while answering nature's call - similar to a series of books referred to as The Bathroom Reader. Alas, Bathroom Reader remains authentic and stays at the top of the, uh, no, not THAT pile, the top of the pile of books on the water closet.Misgivings aside, I did still like this book, even if I only got to the January 5 test the first night.If you're looking for something to read, this probably will not interest. If, though, you're in preparation for Jeopardy, this is one resource that might help, so long as you don't bet everything in Final Jeopardy based solely on the answers provided here. Alex Trebek will scold you for sure.I do wish they had more than just three questions per day. Ten, at minimum, would be better, while 25 would be acceptable to a real trivia nut like me.

I got one of these free, in exchange for an honest review. I also got two USB 4-Port 3.0 hubs.Until I hooked up this hub, I was quite pleased with the other two hubs (one silver and one gray).I can't say yet whether data transfer speed actually is 10 times faster using this 3.1, but I can say it is a lot faster.Since my Desktop has only two 3.1 slots and four 3.0 slots, I remain pleased with the other hubs. But, this one will always be my preference and it is only five dollars more.

1:15 MinsA fabulous set of lights that is completely solar powered.  I let this set sit under a normal indoor light for overnight. The next morning they are fully lit and functional.These are bright and seem to have a nice blue tint to them. There is a solar panel that has two buttons on the back. One is the power button and the other is the 8 modes.  Now if you turn them on, you will likely get the steady mode first. But press the Mode button once and the lights will cycle through all 8 cycles for a continuous light display. You can also press the button repeatedly to have it move to the next design but it will always cycle through the different patterns, you can;t pick a favorite.For the price and the quality and the fact that the are solar - it's a no brainer "Yes"."I was given a free sample for my review an evaluation."

Essentially this Conair does what it says it does but the problem with a lot of the written explanations seem more like  hyperbole than fact. For instance:  It's called a 2-in 1 Clipper and detailer. Uh, okay, so it has the clippers and you can unscrew those and put on the thiner detailer  (something most of the ones I've gotten can do) it gets to be counted as 2 in 1.  Then there is the "NEW Comb Technology"  they are red and supposed to cut around your ears.  Nine combs that feel like cheap plastic.So if you can get past the hype, it's a fine trimmer, really pretty quiet and some nice (albeit cheap) accessories. Don't try to figure out the "special technology" words just expect a trimmer and you won't be disappointed.

1:50 MinsI have been looking for an occupancy switch for my dim hallway with an inconvenient location for the on/off switch.This switch is using the combined PIR (Passive Infrared) and Ultrasonic technologies to help avoid false triggers.  I had my electrician install it because of the grounding requirements, etc.The directions provided are outstanding. They are about as clear and I've ever seen, especially when involving any technology!To get to the brains of the switch, you pull out the bottom plate which reveals 7 dip switches which you can mix and match to determine, how long the lights will stay on after the trigger and other tweaks.You can adjust the sensitivity of the Ultrasonic Feature and determine whether the lights should avoid turning on if enough daylight is detected. And the bottom switch allows you to turn the whole thing off,  have it turn on and off automatically with motion and have it only turn off automatically once you have manually turned it on.This is a feature rich light switch. The ONLY thing I would want is a way to have the lights auto dim if there is enough light or to just have a dimmer switch included in the built. These particular lights are glaring.***I received this product free - in exchange for my evaluation and review.

I bought the bronze expandable towel holder from a brick and mortar store locally (for more than Amazon is selling them for). They are an incredibly helpful solution to a seemingly ubiquitous problem: where to put the kitchen towels.  We have been storing them on the refriderator handle but it not only looked messy but it was inconvenient for us. We use kitchen towels for two functions, 1. to dry dishes,  2. To dry hands.  And we like to keep them solely for that specific job (can't use dish towels for hands and vice versa).We also used the dishwasher and oven handles but the towel would have to brush along the floor every time either appliance was opened - unacceptable.The expandable towel bar was a welcome addition. There isn't much to the installation but if you don't mind putting two tiny screw holes into your cabinet, they do come with pre drilled holes in the back that allow you to secure it to the cabinet door.  Perfect solution.The hooks on top are lined with a nonstick grip to help it stay on the door. We initially installed them to the top DRAWER for ease but realized the towels would hang over the cabinet. Yep, I'm not the brightest crayon in the box for DIY things so I keep a lot of spackling and glue and duct tape nearby.  I took a star off for the lack of direction, suggestions, additional foam for making them more secure and two tiny screws for installation.

At first glance, I was pretty excited about this Belkin Charger. It is heavier than it looks and my 6plus fit in perfectly without a case. I ordered a very thin case for this phone and felt assured after a scant perusal that there would be no problem fitting with the case.  Even the side of the box gave me some assurance that it is "Compatible with open base cases".NOT!I've dropped some pictures here to illustrate the point. I was thinking if Belkin didn't claim it was to fit open base cases then I need to rank the product according to its ability to charge my phone, the ease of fitting it into the base, and overall quality -  Which to me are fantastic.  But the problem is the promise to fit open base cases (and mine is really slim) isn't true. These days, we ALL have a case to protect our phones so designing something that expects a disrobing every time you want to charge it is - ill conceived.

I ordered these because the other kind of double-walled glasses keep losing their little plug that prevents water from getting in there - so they eventually just get ruined. But this set indicates that they can be put into the dishwasher and they are right!  Remember these are only 8oz and it's hard to get a perspective by picture but they are great for small cups of tea, juice and the perfect size to keep your coffee consumption under control.

I'm giving the Zero Water filters 5-stars because they do exactly what they say - take just about everything out of the water and last for about 3 months. The opening of the filters is a little wider than the other brands but I think that allows more water to filter through. This compensates for the slower processing these filters have. If you want zero water (i. e. no minerals or salts, etc)  these are the filters to buy.

1:15 MinsA fabulous set of lights that is completely solar powered.  I let this set sit under a normal indoor light for overnight. The next morning they are fully lit and functional.These are bright and seem to have a nice blue tint to them. There is a solar panel that has two buttons on the back. One is the power button and the other is the 8 modes.  Now if you turn them on, you will likely get the steady mode first. But press the Mode button once and the lights will cycle through all 8 cycles for a continuous light display.
