Ok, this isn't the most exciting thing in the world,and I can't add much to what other reviewers have shared, but it helped expand my Samsung Galaxy Reverb's memory. Just wish I could say the same for mine.

It's clear that U.K. writer Peter Moffat knows what he's writing about in his depiction of working-class village life at the turn of the previous century. His Scottish grandfather and great-grandfather were shepherds ("Doctor Who" fans, he is unrelated to Steven Moffat). An enormous feature of "The Village" series is its topography. Cinematographer David Odd captures a landscape where nothing is straight. The stone walls are the bones of the land, green with lichen and moss, seemingly holding the land together under a vast cloud-driven sky. Absolutely beautiful. Moffat's wonderful narrator, Old Bert Middleton (David Ryall), begins this story as the 2nd oldest man in Britain (and by episode 3, the 1st oldest dies-off). Vivid writing and a fine cast create an utterly believable world.The summer of 1914 was the first time ever a bus came to Bert's Derbyshire village, no one expected anyone to actually get off. Young Bert Middleton (exquisitely played by Bill Jones) was only 12 years old, but he fell in love immediately with new arrival, young Martha Lane (Charlie Murphy). He still loves her 100 years later. Bert's older brother Joe (perfectly portrayed by Manchester native Nico Mirallegro), is a servant in the Big House and he also falls for Martha. Both boys are afraid of their tormented father John, a drunken Peak District farmer (the always remarkable John Simm, catch the Manchester drama Life On Mars (U.K.)). For context, Simm himself researched what the life of his struggling-against-the elements farmer would have been, reading local history in Milk, Muck and Memories: Farming Lives Collected by Margaret Wombwell. Maxine Peake is mesmerizing in her powerful performance as the long-suffering boy's mother, Grace Middleton (see her in Moffat's Criminal Justice). Grace is a ballast for her family.Old Bert is asked what his childhood was like. His answer: "Short." What made it short? Wryly, he says, "Being poor and being hungry." This first collection covers the period from 1914 to 1920, with the harrowing fallout from World War I, with tragic consequences to the Middleton family, the entire village, and Bert's gentle schoolteacher Mr. Eyre (Matt Stokoe), who protects him from a bullying colleague. Eyre gifts the teenaged Bert (Alfie Stewart) with a camera, and we are thus treated to "historic" photos of a lost time. A menacing character is Detective Stephen Bairstow, darkly played by Joe Armstrong (we noticed an uncanny resemblance to another great U.K. actor, Alun Armstrong, and later discovered why).Thankfully, there is a second series in the works for 2014; this will progress the series into the 1920s. There is speculation that future series may also be created, to cover World War II, and possibly post-war Britain. We look forward to more!354 Minutes on 2 Disks, English subtitles provided.

This film is exquisitely written, by Vaughan Sivell. I appreciate strong narrative, and "Third Star" delivers in spades.I immensely relate to the film. During a tumultuous move to an arctic environment, a huge lump popped out of my neck. This, after a back injury from falling on ice (which still limits me). Weak, ill, and losing weight, I had no idea what was going on with my health. Even my insurance got lost in transition due to bureaucratic incompetence. Turns out I had a fast growing tumor, and by the time I could finally have surgery arranged, it was the size of a golf ball. I lived with months of struggle, not knowing if the thing was malignant or not. This time it was not, but can it can recur and then be cancerous.Benedict Cumberbatch is simply superb as James, terminally ill, who knows he won't live past his 29th birthday. He sets off on a mystical visit to  Barafundle Bay, on the Pembrokeshire coast with his three best friends, Davy, Bill and Miles. Hugh Bonneville does an exquisite turn as a beach nutter, can't be missed! There are moments of poetry, as in the opening scene with the ocean flowing backwards, and in James' dream with the tunnel of light. There is a grim humor that I can relate to, having walked the shores of a wintery sea, on a lonely boardwalk along the ice. "The Third Star" shows the anger of living with death, the searing honesty when one feels that there is no time to lie about anything - the sharp edge of reality. Death can be a vivid, an immensely alive time as well, pathos, pain, forgiveness, and love all searingly brought to life in this film.

The Brits are a dab hand at portraying their ironic and difficult post-war years ("George Gently"), where materialistic plenty seeps into society, and corruption spreads even to the refined environs of Oxford. The score and narrative music of Barrington Pheloung's compositions deepen the experience, and are the connective narrative tissue between this series and the beloved, classic "Inspector Morse" with John Thaw. This new set of chapters in Morse's life is absolutely compelling. Shaun Evans' acting is a work of art, each nuance knitting the new/old Morse together, from brittle self-doubt, to stubborn intelligence. Even the origin of Morse's limp is woven into the story...After leaving Oxford without obtaining a degree, Endeavour (Shaun Evans) serves as a cipher in the Royal Corps of Signals, and then joins the police. In mid 1960s, he is transferred to Oxford. Roger Allam is wonderful as D.I. Thursday, Morse's caring mentor who has a few skeletons in the closet. The wounds of WWII run deep; in the third mystery, people wear the traditional red poppies pinned for Remembrance Sunday, a traditional that vividly continues in the U.K. Bonfires, smoke and ashes, an evocative and painful time of year underscores Thurday's turmoil. We meet the ambitious P.C. Strange, and see how it is he advances faster than Morse, while becoming a Freemason with Oxford's subversive elite. Anton Lesser as Reginald Bright, Police Chief Superintendent (PCS), is absolutely superb, a perfect foil for Morse and Thursday, his voice and manner straight out of that post-war era, where past values clash with progress. The writing is remarkable, the cast impeccable. When young Morse visits his difficult, dying father, the man lying on the bed could be John Thaw.

Set in Cobh, County Cork, Ireland, Ivan McCullough's magnificent cinematography brings this evocative film, written and directed by Conor McPherson, to life. I was surprised at what a good movie this is, not exactly horror, more subtle than that. Ciar√°n Hinds, always excellent, evokes quiet loneliness as Michael Farr, a recently widowed father of two children. At night, he secretly writes in his attic office, while during the day he teaches shop. A high-point for him is volunteering at the town's annual literary festival. The lovely seaside town is a perfect backdrop for the mysterious elements that begin to overtake Michael. His angry, aged father-in-law lies near death in a nursing home, yet Micheal glimpses his figure roaming the house at night.Extremely unpretentious, Michael is assigned to chauffeur and help out an acclaimed writer of ghost stories, Lena (Iben Hjejle). The quality of her writing and honest narrative causes Michael to incrementally confide in her. Meanwhile, a famous writer (Aidan Quinn), pesters Lena to get back together, despite his being married. There is a lovely scene when Michael drives off, leaving his daughter to open the shutters in the blueish light of dawn. One has the impression she is aware something peculiar is going on. Irish spirituality is hinted at in the old graveyard Michael and Lena visit, in the statuary of the nursing home, and around the large church prominently arising from the town like a castle. One has the impression of an ancient faith, still functioning, like a bulky ship plowing through the sea. Yet, despite repeatedly filming religious paraphernalia, the threshold remains uncrossed. One of the best moments is when Aiden Quinn's drunk character accuses Michael of being a hanger-on, a wanna-be writer. In reality, Hinds has more talent than anyone realizes. The film would have been stronger if there had been a more overt, less painterly narrative, especially regarding Michael's spiritual/personal journey, and depiction of real contact with Lena after some good news.The film's strength is how it quietly shows how a shy, hidden writer struggles to resolve his personal and real ghosts, and get on with life.

Set in Galway and Dublin, this Irish mystery series features tormented detective Jack Taylor; Iain Glen deeply inhabits this character. Art and pathos combine, with an overflow of booze, in this finely nuanced set of stories. The best mysteries ask questions about life's struggles, and the quest for truth. This second collection further deepens the narrative. While Glen is superb in "Game of Thrones," in "Jack Taylor" he stretches his acting-chops to a harrowing degree. Reminiscent of the great film noirs of the 40s and 50s, Raymond Chandler, stained with whisky, smoke, and sea. Jack Taylor wonders, "Why is it that family can push our buttons so effectively? It's because they installed them." I don't know why this series isn't more widely known! The writing is clever, incisive, and atmospheric - not to be missed! We just wish there were more to come.

After months of pain and illness, I had extremely serious surgery to remove a large tumor from my neck area. The procedure left an extensive, painful, pronounced-raised scar. After a month, the scar remained protruding, red, and painful. We had bought a smaller jar of this aromatic, delicious Nutiva coconut oil for other nutritious health purposes, but just out of curiosity I decided to apply a bit to the scar. Within the first day of applying Nutiva's pure coconut oil to the scar, it flattened-out and the pain decreased! After two days of application, the appearance and pain further improved. The scar now looks completely different. I would never have believed it, unless this actually happened, and hadn't expected such a positive result! So now I'm using this as an unguent for hair and skin, as well as a supplement. Amazing! Nutiva's coconut oil must have anti-inflammatory properties when applied topically; it did far more than simply sooth, it went deep and helped traumatized scarring heal way faster than normal. Highly recommended. Other brands don't taste or smell as good. Good luck!

"If there's one thing I have learned, it's not that time passes. We pass." - Jack Taylor, Series 1. Iain Glen deeply inhabits this role; art and pathos combine in this finely nuanced Irish-noir. While Glen is superb in "Game of Thrones," in "Jack Taylor" he stretches his acting-chops to a harrowing degree. Reminiscent of the great film noirs of the 40s and 50s, Raymond Chandler, stained with whisky, smoke, and sea... Another Jack Taylor rumination: "Why is it that family can push our buttons so effectively? It's because they installed them." I don't know why this series isn't more widely known! The writing is clever, incisive, and atmospheric - not to be missed!

Authenticity is rare as duck's teeth, and worth its weight in gold. The Season 5 finale is really special, featuring Jase and Missy's wonderful, beautiful little girl, Mia, born with a cleft palate. She is an inspiration, a true Robertson. That girl can do anything! With a strong spirit, Mia has undergone multiple surgeries with courage, faith, and family. Missy's singing, in the song that accompanies the end-segment, is angelic. You also don't want to miss more of the playful John Godwin, blessed with a hankering for "ham samiches," and a unique voice that would be great for cartoon bears and other fuzzy creatures. Talent scouts should pay attention! Sassy little Miss Kay is a delightful character all on her own, a gentlewoman, and cook of many talents. Hungry folks will find many tasty victuals in her Miss Kay's Duck Commander Kitchen: Faith, Family, and Food - Bringing Our Home to Your Table. She also has a special way with her rat terriers - perhaps there could be a "Miss Kay the Dog Whisperer" special episode someday? She wonders if beloved BoBo and JJ might need middle names, and describes how they enjoy snacking on lizards. This is uplifting, wholesome, eccentric-American fun. Generations of the Robertson clan enjoy the fruits of the land, from frogs to delectable Duck-Wraps.I'm with Phil, the Duck Dynasty Godfather, on men who duck hunt in pink; we prefer The Jason Bourne Trilogy. Likely Phil was goaded into the unfortunate incident with GQ. We all get irritated and say things in bold-type that we regret later. It's not easy being a fierce man these days. A true individual, Phil overcame tribulations and vividly shares his story in Happy, Happy, Happy: My Life and Legacy as the Duck Commander.And goofy Uncle Si can dance and sing, Jack! Check out his Si-cology 1: Tales and Wisdom from Duck Dynasty's Favorite Uncle. Thank you Robertson clan for sharing with us. This series is an inspiration to kick back and worry less. Enjoy!

These handsome and jazzy black Crocs are not only super-comfy, they are cool and suave. Black Crocs resemble an accoutrement concocted out of a shiny spare-tire, all dark rubber and functional charm. You just can't go wrong with these. So when life throws another rock or nasty bug at your virtual windshield, at least soften the blow by letting your feet shelter in these handsome Crocs. Enjoy!

Many early filers of 2013 returns who used Turbo Tax experienced a delay on refunds this year. For those who filed early and expect a refund, and were "Accepted," there has been slow progress. According to TT user Nikki Torscha (TT blog), there was a glitch "processing for returns accepted 1/26-1/28 ... This is what I have been seeing ... WMR [IRS Where's My Return] reset some of the Refund Statuses back to the beginning... as if it was just submitted. Spoke with IRS and IRS confirmed that DDD for those individuals would be 2/12 - Wednesday..." Our thanks to this TT user for the alert. It does look like things are moving along now, that all this will be resolved shortly; TT has performed well for us in the past. Good luck!

This luxurious comforter set is far beyond our expectations! This cost far less than at department stores; after trying less expensive brands, I learned that you indeed get what you pay for. We have a difficult situation dressing up a loft-space where the bed is all too visible. I spent hours searching for a viable option, but the others were too brassy, too bright, or simply garish. But this exceptionally classy Lenox comforter dresses up the room without being too frilly. The classic design's pattern and color scheme are wonderfully man-friendly and gender-neutral. The rich, gleaming, tapestry-like comforter, shams, and bed-skirt are even more attractive than they appear in the photo. The reverse side is a soft, gleaming gold. And along with the beauty, the function is superb, providing delicious warmth too. Highly recommended!!

Instead of what we ordered, king-size was delivered. Yet under product page, it's been tabbed in as if I ordered King on Amazon. I double and triple checked when placing the order. There is a weird lack of information on the order's product description when you place the order, as it won't list the color or size you choose in your order summary. It seems like others have experienced this same issue as well. So beware!

This Theramed Universal Dual-Temp Cold Pack is the highest quality we could find. An essential core of FYI has been through years of disabling, chronic back/neck pain, underwent disk removal/fusion surgery, and has a titanium plate embedded -  on an x-ray it looks like a human ate the hinge off a barn door. Thankfully, with years of working at it, some of the old pain subsided, but occasionally comes roaring back. This Theramed cold pack works wonders, it actually stays cold and retains the chill for a long time. Good luck, good healing - you may want to try this excellent, well designed cold-therapy pack.

After years of using ugly rubber dishracks, I've moved on to Lipper's elegant bamboo dishrack, and this Norpro dish-drying mat is perfect underneath. It's non-intrusive, and adds to the simple attractiveness of our new dish-drying system. This is a well-made, excellent product, highly recommended!

This little gadget works beautifully with Lipper's Bamboo dishrack, and looks great! It's a vast improvement on our old white plastic dishrack. I prefer to wash our few utensils by hand, rather than waste time and water with the dishwasher. This ftatwear holder makes the job a bit more fun and rewarding. Highly recommended!

Beautiful design and color; a vast improvement on our old plastic dishrack. I dislike using the dishwasher for small loads, and this makes a basic chore more appealing by providing an elegant, useful place for dishes to dry. For utensils, get the Lipper  2-Compartment Bamboo Flatware Holder with Metal Clips. For non-intrusive water absorption underneath, try the Norpro 16 by 18-Inch Microfiber Dish Drying Mat (in Cream). Highly recommended!

This adds a nice touch of greenery to our shower, and looks quite classy. The material passes as "real" fabric, and the design and the earthy, natural looking colors in gold and soft shades of green are super nice. We're trying to fix our place up, and this does the trick! Highly recommended!

This looks large, warm, and welcoming in the photograph. But in real life, this flimsy comforter can not weigh 8 lbs., the sizing is small, and it looks depressingly cheap. Normally, items look how they are advertized here on Amazon, which is really reliable. But not in this case. I've seen nicer at Walmart. This resembles a Big Lots item. You get what you pay for!

Martin Shaw is superb as a deeply intelligent and ethical police detective who has become fed-up with corruption at London's Met. Complex, honest, and stalwart, Inspector George Gently (Martin Shaw) is a veteran of World War II who had happily married his lovely Italian bride. After witnessing her murder in "Series One," the grieving Gently seeks refuge in the North East. Shaw is masterful, powerfully depicting a man with deep integrity and convictions, and a talent for boxing. Those of you who enjoy Vera are in for a treat. Filmed in England's starkly beautiful North Country, and historic city of Durham, this vivid series boasts high-production values, and authentically recreates the ambiguous, and at times disturbing, era of the late 1960s.Series Five ended on a disturbing note, a cliffhanger, where the fate of our main characters was unsure. Veteran cop George Gently mentors Detective Sergeant John Bacchus (Lee Ingleby), a young fellow whose morals run adrift amidst the swirling social turmoil of the 1960s. As Gently's ambitious sidekick, Ingleby inhabits his character perfectly. You may recall Ingleby's inimitable turn in Harry Potter and the Prisoner of Azkaban , as the Knight Bus conductor, Stan Shunpike. Blessed with abundant talent and a memorable voice, Ingleby is incisive as the menacing Vic Tyler in the highly regarded 1970s police/time-travel hit Life On Mars: The Complete Collection (U.K.). A fine constant is PC Taylor (Simon Hubbard), who grumblingly serves many a cuppa of PG Tips Black Tea with plates of biscuits.Series Six resumes in 1969, several months after Gently and Bacchus were brutally shot admit the majestic Durham Cathedral. This encounter nearly claimed their lives, and both suffer post-traumatic stress, along with physical scars. Poor Bacchus is still recuperating in a police convalescent homeEach mystery is feature-length at 89 minutes. Thankfully, there are English subtitles, for those of who do not want to miss one word. For a three-dimensional taste experience, you may want to indulge in some Northumberland style bangers & mash, with a classic Newcastle Nut Brown Ale (a favorite of Bacchus') to top it off. Enjoy!"Gently Between the Lines"Gently is shocked to receive Bacchus's resignation, as the sergeant is suffering PTSD after the shooting (in the last season). Although Gently seems to accept the young man's notice, he insists that Bacchus help with another murder investigation. After rioters were arrested after Newcastle police tried to clear a poor neighborhood out, prior to demolition and redevelopment, one of the protesters is found dead in the cells the next morning. The case causes both Gently and Bacchus to examine their role as police officers, during a time when law enforcement changed from being seen as locally based, to being thuggish agents of the state. Young policewoman Rachel Coles (Lisa Mcgrillis) is wrongly fired from the force - just wait and see what our George makes of that! Written by Tim Prager; cast includes: Robert Pugh, Steve Evets, Ruth Gemmell, Matt Stokoe and Caroline O'Neill."Blue for Bluebird"This mystery is written by Jess Williams, of the marvelous series "Call The Midwife." Personally, I tend to dislike mysteries set in coastal holiday camps, and this one features dreadful clown faces. A beautiful young "Bluebird" from the camp washes ashore. Under all the camp's revelry and playful permissiveness, Gently and Bacchus expose a web of greed and jealousy. PC Rachel Coles (Lisa Mcgrillis) assists the team, while Bacchus fights to see more of his daughter. Guest stars include: Lee Boardman, and Pixie Lott."Gently From the Cold"As often is the case in murder investigations, cases connect in ways not anticipated. From a murder in a sauna, the case moves Gently to investigate the possibility of military abuse. He finds himself actually facing a wall of silence and Cold War conspiracy. Written by Jess Williams; guest stars include: Jemma Redgrave and Helen Coverdale."Gently Going Under"The best mystery of the lot, with wonderful developments in the relationships between Gently, Bacchus, and newcomer Coles (Lisa Mcgrillis). During the late 1960s, massive economic shifts pressure communities in the North. As Northumberland's coal mining industry suffers, stress grows in tightly knit mining communities. In Burnsend, a body is found in the mine, and Gently and Bacchus must unearth the truth beneath the community's tensions. In this beleaguered community, schisms and ill-feelings there date back to World War II. Though WWII may seem distant now, in 1969, it had only been over 24 years. To make a contemporary comparison, many of us recall the 1980s up to 1990 quite vividly. Time is relative, and memory collapses intervening years quite effectively. Written by Mike Cullen (the great Scottish series "Taggart"); guest stars include: Grant Crookes, Neil Eddy, and Poppy Lee Friar.While you wait for more George, there is another wonderful mystery series set in Northumbria, worth savoring. Based upon novels by Ann Cleeves (Crow Trap), the series features the great Brenda Blethyn as caustic DCI Vera Stanhope: Vera, Vera: Set 2, Vera, Set 3 (to be released). Be sure to have plenty of hot, strong tea and Carr's Ginger Lemon Creme Cookies on hand.

Some of us are blessed to know real minions, and they need the jolly reinforcement of seeing their brethren gathered en-mass in this film! The details of the art and film are overwhelmingly amazing, from the curly hairs on creature-dog Kyle's chin, to the underwater and jam sequences, the colors are delicious! There is even a love story here, quite delightfully done, along with mocking hideous, superficial puffed-up fake fish lips too prevalent in the plastic world today, anti-bullying, plus, pro-baldness, as there's nothin' wrong with less hair! And thank goodness for Minionese, we can't get enough of the little yellow guys. Good-hearted Gru and his girls Agnes, Edith, and Margo are a lovely family, and Anti-Villain League operative Lucy Wild is a treat. Only missed the Eminem song "Without Me" which we enjoyed in the previews. Pollito is a great touch - having been attacked by evil chickens, I know the truth. And you haven't lived until you see the minions bouncing around to Mungo Jerry's "In the Summertime," or the Village People's "YMCA!" We can't wait till "Despicable Me 3"! Pierre Coffin is a genius.

The Swedish artist and writer Elsa Beskow, 1874-1953, remains that country's most popular children's illustrator; a century later, her books continue to provide pleasure worldwide, to children young and old. Her exquisite illustrations portray the wonder of nature and changing seasons; this book is a classic.The pleasures of youth can be cherished by those of any age. As Roger Rosenblatt writes in in his memoir The Boy Detective: A New York Childhood, child and adult are linked together. "...I do not believe in time. How could I if I feel the presence of the boy as completely as I do the man, in many ways, more completely since the boy is more completely realized. He who existed in me over half a century ago walks with me today." So explore your imagination, and take a walk in the woods with your grandchildren, or on your own, in the delightful "Children of the Forest."

Wonderfully narrated by Denholm Elliott, this beautiful film, "A Child's Christmas in Wales," delves into the richness of Dylan Thomas' prose. Gorgeous cinematography of the coastal Welsh village and surrounding landscape vividly brings to life this classic Christmas tale. Dylan Thomas' 1955 poem, originally written for radio, is meant to be savored on a chill winter's night, and nostalgically portrays a simpler time, with a child's special imagination. On Christmas Eve, kindly grandfather "Old Geraint" (Elliott) shares stories about his Christmas past with his beloved grandson, Thomas (a perfectly elfin Mathonwy Reeves). The narrative poetry will pull you in: "All the Christmases roll down toward the two-tongued sea, like a cold and headlong moon bundling down the sky that was our street; and they stop at the rim of the ice-edged, fish-freezing waves, and I plunge my hand in the snow and bring out whatever I can find. In goes my hand into that wool-white bell-tongued ball of holidays resting on the rim of the carol-singing sea..."True to Thomas' story, the film delightfully describes a Useless Present: "a celluloid duck that made, when you pressed it, a most unducklike sound, a mewing moo that an ambitious cat might make who wished to be a cow..." I have heard black and white cow-cats like that, who poke around the ground with their little faces, eating grass and moo-mewing.This film can enrich and inspire your family traditions during the holidays. To further savor the story, we also have the book, A Child's Christmas in Wales. You also might want to try another lyrical film: The Secret of Roan Inish. Enjoy!

This inimitable series continues amidst Midsomer's deceptively bucolic hills and dales, whilst denizens inflict numerous creative demises upon one another. Three new, feature-length Midsomer mysteries are a welcome arrival. Of a fond and generous heart towards Midsomer, this would merit five-stars, but for the first episode and a fine cast of actors coping with material that is occasionally too contemporary, with less humorous banter between the main characters. These issues get ironed out. DCI John Barnaby is wonderfully played by Neil Dudgeon, while Jason Hughes has been given too little to work with as DI Ben Jones. On a musical note, loyal fans loved Midsomer's iconic score, composed by Jim Parker, and performed on the appropriately weird musical instrument, the theremin. Ears perked at Midsomer's spooky, inimitable opening notes. Unfortunately, a decision was made to replace the eerie theremin with a violin, resulting in a loss of continuity. There needs to be a return to charming but deadly places like Badger's Drift, with peculiar, humorous puzzles. Like a lace doily blotched with tea, Midsomer's coziness has a sinister stain, darkness seeps in at the edges.The running time of "Midsomer Murders, Set 23" is approximately 278 minutes; subtitles are available; Extras: audio commentary for "The Dark Rider" with Neil Dudgeon and director Alex Pillai, and a behind-the-scenes featurette for "Death and the Divas.""The Dark Rider"Written by Michael Aitkens, who antagonized loyal fans with the abominable "Death in the Slow Lane," in Midsomer Murders, Set 21. Barnaby and Jones investigate a series of untimely deaths linked to sightings of a headless horseman. While Midsomer County sports a spectrum of deviant behaviors, this particular offering is overly preposterous and oddly paced, with a number of unsympathetic characters. The mystery revolves around the gentrified DeQuettevilles, who stage an historic battle re-enactment every year. There is silly competition with grating and obnoxious neighbors. At least there are bits about Barnaby, his wife (Fiona Dolman), and Sykes settling into Midsomer."Murder of Innocence"Written by Elizabeth-Anne Wheal, this moody Midsomer mystery inveigles DCI John Barnaby (Neil Dudgeon) and DS Ben Jones (Jason Hughes) with the protection a hated offender. Momentarily, the beginning is a bit off; Midsomer fans prefer views of chocolate-box villages, hedge rows, and tree-lined lanes, as compared to bleak bus stations. Hang in there. Released from jail, the parolee, guarded against angry villagers by Barnaby and Jones, lodges in a super-dismal cottage. Past and present collide, and a local barrister dies in suspicious circumstances. The accused culprit claims to be innocent of the crime he was locked up for in the first place, as well as the barrister's death. The suspense and body-count builds; layers of the past must be peeled back, while previous events ripple into the present.Death and the DivasThis is a standout episode, classic, quirky, Midsomer, wacky and weird; thanks to writers Rachel Cuperman and Sally Griffiths, who satisfy the macabre appetites of loyal Midsomer fans. The Midsomer Langley Film Festival is underway, and it turns out our Barnaby is a fan of the lead actress and her campy, gothic oeuvre. During the festivities, a writer is murdered whilst a campy horror classic plays on the telly. The murder is ghoulishly like one that occurred in a cult 1960s horror film. This being Midsomer, further murders ensue, each one reenacting a cult-film classic. Harriet Walter Dorothy L. Sayers Mysteries does a fine turn as an obnoxiously successful actress, returning home to Midsomer to upstage her sister, who happens to be the film-festival's star. Well done, in the spirit of the long-running series!You may want to try a wonderful mystery series, set in the U.K.'s blustery, beautiful Northumbria, based on novels by Ann Cleeves (Crow Trap). The series features the great Brenda Blethyn as caustic DCI Vera Stanhope: Vera, Vera: Set 2, Vera, Set 3 (to be released). Be sure to have plenty of hot, strong tea and Carr's Ginger Lemon Creme Cookies on hand.The U.K. boasts numerous fine and often underrated actors; catch Neil Dudgeon's unforgettable performance in a superb story in the BAFTA Award winning series The Street, (1st Season, Episode 3). He plays Brian Peterson, a teacher accused of being a flasher, whose wife waivers in her loyalty to him. When Peterson gazes out of a taxi window passing fogbound streets, we see that each street is full of stories, lives with moments of mystery. "The Street" is gritty and harrowing, unlike Midsomer's macabre villages.Enjoy!
Not as loud as I expected from the hype but gets the job done. Absolutely so much better than the factory horn that sounded like a squeaky toy. I might try the truck version for my other car.
Fits several oil filter sizes and shapes. I particularly like it on the small Fram 7317 as it does not block your scope.
They work

All of the connectors are way too small for the 12 gauge wire. The 12 gauge wire was 4 inches too short to reach my battery and I have a small Japanese car. You can buy the connectors (3 kinds) at your local auto parts store for $9 and ten foot of wire (12 gauge THHN) from your local Home depot for $3. So $12 vs $15 and you will probably have to buy the new connectors anyway. Save yourself the aggravation and just buy the wire and connectors locally.
If you can, get the audio version of the entire series read by Marguerite Gavin. She is awesome and really brings the stories to life!

This thing cools like crazy. Its amazingly quiet. We really like it a LOT and now I'm considering a 3 stage unit for my mother-in-law's house.The only two problems that I had with it are:1-The manual covers three models on each page and is very confusing. Come on Pioneer -- its a PDF file. It costs nothing to make one specifically for each model. The manual does not cover the things you need to consider BEFORE YOU START installation -- like where is the drain going to go. This caused a LOT of problems when we discovered what was necessary AFTER it was on the wall with the pipes connected.2- The drain for the inside unit. OMG! This was the biggest pain in the butt. In the manual they keep saying "be sure the drain is lower than the pipes". Well, BE SURE THE DRAIN IS LOWER THAN THE PIPES. The slightest upward curve in the drain will cause a flood in your room. There was no mention of the second drain hole on the left of the indoor unit. THAT would have saved hours of pain. You MUST determine the hole through the wall based on the drain, not the pipes or you will have a LOT of extra work. The drain must be connected, re-connected, or plugged BEFORE you mount the indoor unit on the wall and it should go straight out of the unit out the wall -- not across the bottom of the unit as it is shipped. The drain tubing seems flimsy and is short. I could not find any way to extend it (like 1/2" or 3/8" pipe). Also found out the hard way that putting in a drain trap at the end caused the water to back up and flood the room. Still haven't figured out how that could possibly happen, but it does. Does this defy gravity?This was not a real problem but be sure you find the tube of sealant for the flared ends. Its very small and was lose in the giant box.
Love these things. The wings don't hold up too great but it sure makes it easy to find your car in the mall parking lot.
Had to cut through 8 inches of solid concrete. Not like a hot knife through butter but definitely got the job done quickly. No complaints whatsoever.
Had to cut through 8 inches of solid concrete. Not like a hot knife through butter but definitely got the job done. No complaints whatsoever.

I was able to get one hole drilled before the set screws stripped out. Tried to get replacement screws at the local box store but all replacements stripped out immediately. This does not seem to fit the shaft of the arbor very well at all. Seems much too large.

The computer itself works great. Every problem I've encountered has been operating system related. It comes with Windows 8 which ate up most of the 500g hard drive so you will probably either need to get Windows 7 or a larger hard drive for it. I did both.
The suction/adhesive part works very well. Unfortunately, the plastic hangers that hold the soap rack to the suction plate broke off after just a few weeks.
Easy to mount, looks good. The hangers are sized, one for the butt and one for the barrel. Looks good with my 10/22.

This holster works great. I usually don't even know its on my ankle. If someone should see it (like when I sit down and my pant-leg raises up) people just think its an ankle brace. The left / right thing is kind of confusing. I'm right-handed and with a right-handed ankle holster its very awkward to get to the pistol unless you wear it on the outside of your leg. With this one (left) on my inside left ankle, the pistol handle faces forward and easy to get a hold of with my right hand. I like the holster on the inside because its almost invisible. It just seems to "print" when its on the outside of my leg. Maybe its just me. Regardless, this is a very comfortable holster for my CW380.
We have small dogs that don't jump. This works very well to keep them in the kitchen while I'm at work. Its attractive and light weight.
Used it three times now. Very simple with great results. It doesn't get much easier than this. Clean up has been simple so far. No problems.

Changed over from TurboTax this year because of all the bad press that Turbo Tax is getting (undisclosed fees, etc). WOW! Wish I had changed over years ago. This is MUCH easier to use. It seem much more complete and asks more relevant questions. For me, it is much more enjoyable to use than TurboTax.

Got this to replace a stock scope on my Ruger. This is MUCH better. It gets a LOT more light and is much easier to see the target. The adjustment knobs seem a bit flimsy and don't feel quite right when adjusting but once it zeroed in, you rarely touch them again.
More like sawdust than chips. Half the order was Oak, that was disappointing. Tried it in a Master Electric Smoker and had to keep replenishing every half hour to keep smoke up.
Attractive and works. What more can you say?

Sennheiser, what do you expect? Sound quality is excellent. Extremely comfortable. I've worn them for up to 5 hours straight and no sweat, no pressure, still comfortable. Great for movies, music, and audio books. Extremely clear with no distortion.

Been using these now for almost a month while I'm working around they house. They are extremely comfortable and sound great. I always have trouble keeping ear buds in my ears and these also work their way out but not nearly as often or as fast as other buds I have tried. The range is limited (about 15 feet from source before they start breaking up) but I don't know if that's the headphones or my phone.UPDATE: It has now been 9 months and they are still working fantastic. I work a lot in my yard and have caught the earbuds on limbs and about everything else that sticks out and they are still intact. Still have great sound and the battery is still good and fairly long-lasting after many recharges and drains :) . When (if) these die I will surely get another pair.

Love these scissors. The notch in the blade really holds whatever you are trying to cut. They are VERY sharp. They are advertised as gardening shears but I use them almost exclusively in the kitchen. They make life so much easier.

What I really like about this switch is its size. Its a little smaller than a pack of cigarettes.It fits inconspicuously behind my TV connecting my Tivo, TV, and Asus Media Player (PC). So far it runs cool and efficient. Very nice. I'll probably get an additional 8 port unit for my home network surveillance system.

I got the Alpine 149BT last week as a gift (it was on my wish list).Let me start off saying that if you really care about the sound quality of your music, you just can‚Äôt beat Alpine. I don‚Äôt know how they do it, but Alpine units just SOUND amazing. Having said that, that seems to be Alpine‚Äôs only strength. I got the 149BT to replace an older Alpine head unit that was almost exactly the same but without BlueTooth and HD radio. I really enjoyed that radio except the CD player was not so great (sound-wise excellent, mechanically not-so-much), nor the iPod playing capability (sound quality excellent but plays out of order - sometimes/often), nor the fact that every add-on (HD radio, BT) cost almost as much os the radio itself.This seems to be a recurring theme with the new 149BT. It SOUNDS fantastic. But every time I turn it on I feel insulted that Alpine does not think I know if I‚Äôm listening to radio, iPod, or USB because there is a HUGE 1‚Äù by 1‚Äù animated radio antenna on the left side of the display when it is on radio or HUGE USB symbol, or HUGE iPod. Or if I have the display set for TIME, they must think that I might be confused as to which planet I‚Äôm on because there is a HUGE 1‚Äù x 1‚Äù spinning globe of the Earth on the left. Did I mention that this is on the DISPLAY? And that it is animated? In a car -- where you should not be watching your radio? That‚Äôs right, you lose the entire left one inch of the display, top to bottom, that could be used to show additional info like the title of the song, or artist, or some type of IMPORTANT info like radio signal strength. At the bottom of the display are three teeny, tiny icons that show if your phone has connected through BlueTooth, its battery level, and how many bars signal strength it has. THAT could be blown up in that one inch space and it would be very important to know -- but no, its so minuscule that you can barely see it.As I said before, the engineers at Alpine truly get it when it comes to sound, but that‚Äôs the beginning and end of their expertise. They have no clue when it comes to the user interface or experience. That‚Äôs why I had to give this a 4 out of 5 rating.

This review relates to the TV being used as a computer monitor - ONLY.As with everything there is good and bad.The Good:The screen is incredibly bright. So much so that my students don't like looking at it. I know, I know, you can turn the brightness  down but just a heads up. It is also has razor sharp images. Every little detail is immediately apparent. It automatically connects to the computer through the HDMI port -- no problems what-so-ever. The aspect ratio, at least to me, is much more preferable than that of Dell Monitors (I bought this to replace a 21" Dell). You can  easily see two pages  side-by-side on the screen at 100% size with a little room left  over all the way around. It draws almost no power -- according to the Energy Label, only $5 / YEAR.The Bad:There is on ON button but no OFF button. You have to use the remote to turn it off. There is a sleep mode but if you have it turned on then its a constant hassle while you are using your computer. Eventually you will turn off the sleep mode so you don't go crazy and then you have to turn the TV off with the remote when you are finished for the day. DON'T lose the remote.The screen is HIGHLY glossy. It reflects light from everywhere. This is probably the main difference, and drawback, vs a computer monitor. I would HIGHLY recommend an articulating arm to mount this TV so you can adjust it for minimal glare. Speaking of movement, naturally it does not raise or lower or tilt like my Dell monitor did -- after all, its a TV, right?. I find this quite annoying and will fix it with a VESA articulating arm.Overall, I like this TV as a monitor. However, the glare is a real problem. If Vizio makes a matte screen TV in the future, I will definitely consider that for my next monitor.
Got this to replace a Samsung chip in a  Foscam camera. The Samsung just never worked right. This one is excellent. Works better than expected.
You would think that the wings would tear off but they don't. This is my second one (first was stolen) and the previous one lasted almost a year. I have high expectations for this one too.
Cable just keeps on working. I have had others that would stop charging after a few weeks but this one keeps going. Must have heavier wires than others. My phone charges at 2+ amps.

Got this to replace a hard drive with an SSD. the cables to the drive were way to short to reach the new drive because the adapter mounts the 2.5" drive in the middle of the mount instead of at one end. If your cables can reach the extra 1.5" then this should work well for you.
IF you have not read the Odd Thomas series, you are missing a LOT of fun.
Present for my wife.She is crazy about it.Loves the little smiley face mirror stickers.
When it comes to hot beverages, you can't beat this product. Sweeter than sugar but not that weird aftertaste of some products. Love it.

I have purchased several of these thermometers.What do I like? They are about TEMPERATURE and HUMIDITY, not time.WHY do so many thermometers have a HUGE clock? Go buy a clock if that's what you need.You can easily see these from across a room. Set up four side by side and they all read the same temp and humidity over 24 hours. Great consistency.
I really like the non-slip material this is made of. VERY thin and almost no weight. Its hard to tell you have it on the phone except your grip is MUCH improved.

I'm really becoming a fan of BlueRigger.I have purchased several of their cables (different types) and they all seem to be of very high quality.Never had any connection problem -- which I have had with other brands.

These little speakers are amazing. I take them to conferences for computer output -- they fill a typical conference room fine and take up almost no space. My daughter always takes them to the beach and I have a hard time getting it back. Check out a YouTube comparison of the different brands -- i thought this one was best and have been very pleased.
Low cost and made of a non-slip material.You can't beat it for the price.

These cases are great. I have purchased several and recommended them to my friends who have also ended up purchasing them. They are thin, unobtrusive, made of a non-slip material (EXTREMELY important) that has saved my laptops many times. The only caveat is that you need to take them off the computer a couple times a year to clean under the case -- stuff gets in there.
Got these for the computers in my lab and they work well for the price.I have definitely had much worse for about the same price.I will be buying these again when I need new speakers.

It holds my Note 3 fine but the straps are a little short if you have arms larger than about 14-15". Tried strapping it to my wrist but its too big for that, kept getting in the way. Gets a bit hot and sweaty but that's not unusual for any phone strap. Just wish the velcro strap would have been about 1 inch longer or it would have an extension strap.

Wasn't sure about this little device but it works great.The red part is made of a non-slip plastic (or maybe rubber) that keeps the pills from slipping around when it comes time to cut.The little "box" to the right of the cutter catches the pills nicely.Definitely recommend.

I was very pleasantly surprised at how comfortable these gloves are.I have a very hard time finding gloves that are large enough and these fit fantastic.I almost feel bad about doing my gardening with them they are so nice.

I wear these for any time that I don't want to disturb my wife (TV, elliptical, etc.).The sound is great for the price.The range seems to be about 15-20 yards and that's through one concrete and one glass wall.Sync very easily to my Note 3.

Got these for my mother-in-law to have around the house if the power goes out. They really light a room up and they are easy to find in minimal light. The magnet on the back makes it easy to attach one to the fridge.
It seems to display the correct temperature but it is slow to get to it. Takes 5+ minutes to get from 78 to 325 degrees when the oven is already preheated.
Moisturizes hands and cuticles. Totally not greasy. Blends in completely. Not sticky. And I really like the aroma.
The legs were about 3 inches longer than normal. Better too long than too short. Saved enough on the price to get them taken up at the tailor's. Other than that they fit great.
This camera is huge. Its like cameras from the 1960s. I was hoping it would be about 2" long and 1" high but its about 6" long and 4" high. Definitely not for covert placement.
This is a very nice divider. I didn't use the shelves because I just needed a room divider but they are also very nice. I'll probably use them someplace else.

I absolutely love this shampoo. I wasn't thinking that I would be impressed about a shampoo, but this one is so moisturizing and made my hair feel silky smooth. Amazingly you might not even need conditioner, that is how amazing this leaves my hair feeling. This shampoo comes in an extra large bottle with a pump. You only need about 1 pump of product and I have extra long hair down to my lower back. For a shampoo that is sulfate free it suds up nicely and almost immediately you can feel the softness while washing. I would definitely recommend this shampoo if you would love a softening and moisturizing shampoo or if you do not like to use conditioners. I was sent this for review, however it does not effect mt thoughts or opinions.

Bergamont essential oil is one of my favorite essential oils to use in my diffuser. This particular vial is extra large and is perfect if you are like me and like to use it on a daily basis. The scent is strong and lasts in the diffuser without frequent redropping needed. There is also an additional dropper that you can place in the bottle permanently. I purchased this at a discount, however it does not effect my thought, opinions or experiences.

This HSI Professional Flat iron is great for my hair for straigt or curled styles. It comes in a sturdy box and a silky bag to storage it after use and one glove to protect your hand if you need to use it. It heats up quickly and the heat is adjustable to be as warm 140 degrees or hot up to 410 degrees. I personally use it at a cooler temp than most since I have thin hair that does not require a high temperature. I would like for the temperature gauge to have a few more temperature settings noted on the dial. The paddle glides right over my hair with ease and the additional bonus of the argan oil is great to use in my hair as well. There is a spring in the flat iron that opens the flat iron and you do not have to use much force to close the flat iron and "squish" your hair in it. The cord is long with a velcro strap to manage the cord when not in use and has a rotating base to prevent twisting of the cord. I purchased this at a discount, however it does not effect my thoughts or opinions.

These Curved Eyebrow scissors are actually a great shape and thickness to use for trimming my brows. I like that they come in a reuseable pouch so I can maintain my scissors fitting and protected. I had another pair that never trimmed well and would not cut more than seemed like one hair at a time which was really annoying. These I can comb my brows and trim with ease. They are also made will and feel comfortable to hold in the hand. I was sent this for review, however it does not effect my thoughts or opinions.

I really appreciate that this brush set comes in a solid case, that locks in place and will not pop open until you open it. It actually reminds me of another high end set that I own. It is great for travel or if you would like to keep an extra set of brushes either in your boyfriends place or at work. They are all kept nice and neat and you will have your basic brushes that you need to do your makeup look. I would love to have a fuller flat top kabuki brush since that is my preferred brush to apply my foundation. The blush/powder and contour does a great application job.The 3 eye brushes will give you a simple eye look, but there is space to add a couple additional small brushes in this set. All the brushes are soft and easy to use. The quality is very nice and I think this is also a great starter set to gift to someone who is starting out or just needs some extra brushes on hand. I purchased this at a discount, however it does not effect my thoughts or opinions.

I have been using us for a few weeks now. I use it daily after my shower as directed. I put the amount in the dropper into the roots of my hair towards the front of my scalp which is where I feel I need it the most. I have a ton of new girls towards the front of my hairline I have noticed when I'm doing my hair I have all these baby ears that stick out. You're definitely not going to know if this is working in just a few days it is going to take a couple of weeks for you to notice any type of hair growth. The solution does not burn nor does it have an odor which is very nice. It does at times leave some areas of my ear a bit crunchy after application, but that is easily fixed by just running your fingers through your hair. These close sticks are superbright. It comes in a pack of 100 glow sticks with adapters to connect them to each other to make bracelets or necklaces. They're a lot of fun for the kids to use is perfect for the upcoming Halloween event approaching. When you crack them to light them up they begin glowing extremely bright upon the first crack and continue to shine brightly for hours. Your child can even light up these glow sticks on their own. This is perfect for me to use at work. I'm a nurse and having a pulse ox is a great tool to have. It has given me no problems and reads the pulse and oxygenation of the blood simply. The numbers are easy to read and the device shuts off automatically after use. It comes with a strap that you can keep and attach your pulse ox to. it takes two AAA batteries which are not included. This is a great device to have in your home even if you're not a nurse if you just want to know how your pulses or if you have a history of respiratory problems and would like to know what your oxygenation and your blood is this is definitely a great tool to have for your own personal use as well. This is a very nice backpack it's made of Denon and has really cute white in matching blue floral design on it. The straps are adjustable and my daughter who is five years old uses this to pack her things to go to her grandmothers house. The main compartment is very large and there is a smaller zippered pouch in the front. The shoulder straps have padding And some tan leather details throughout the bag which is a nice touch. The material is very strong denim and it doesn't feel like it will rip overtime. I was sent this by review, however it does not affect my thoughts opinions or experiences.

This is a rechargeable nightlight that turns on with motion. Initially I couldn't figure out how to charge the light, it has a cover on the bottom that slides open. Under the removable panel is the charging port. The package will come with th light and charging cable. You will have to do lug the charger into a USB compatible plug. The light is a soft light that does not bother your eye when it turns on. It shuts off automatically as well. The design is unique and looks nice. It has double stick tape that you can attach the light to the wall if you wanted. I was sent this for review however it does not effect my thoughts or opinions.

This Concealer/contour palette has 6 large powder shades going from the brightest white to a medium to dark brown. While this says it is a concealer, contour and foundation palette. I would use this as a foundation since it would give a very light coverage. There is no scent, each powder is a very large circle which is perfect to use a large fluffy brush if you wish to. The palette is a generic black plastic case. I think this powder palette is great for light to medium skin tones. I have been using the second to the lightest shade and skin toned shade under the eyes. The peach shade I have used as a blush and it gave a very nice peachy tone to my cheeks.The two darkest shades I have use as a contour and using a fluffy brush so I won't have it get patchy. I have had no issues with blending this out with a fluffy brush. Each shade can also be used on the eyes as well and they are all matte in my opinions and does not give you a cake face. I haven't used the white shade much due to I rarely use that shade for any reason in general. I was sent this for review, however it does not effect my thoughts or opinions.

This brush set is a great set, especially if you are needing your first set of brushes. It comes in a plastic bag and each brush is covered in an individual bag which is disposable. This is a great starter set. You can try different designs and sizes so you can see which type of brush or brushes you decide is best for you to work with while applying your makeup. The brushes are dense and very soft. The multiple large brushes are great for uses for foundation, blush, all over face powder or blending out concealer. The brushes are very soft and dense. The brush handles have some weight to them and are attached well to the ferrules. They washed and dried without any issues. I use slightly warm water when washing and to dry the brushes hanging downward to be sure as to not have too much water or soap to ruin the adhesive in the brushes. I purchased this at a discount, however it does not effect my thoughts or opinions.

I love the look of this bracelet The style is beautiful, it fits like a bangle, but opens and slides over your hands with ease. The floral design is what locks this bracelet on your wrist. I was so much happier with this piece than I expected. I knew I loved the design and look, but in person it was even better than I hoped. I think this is a great piece to wear on any special occasion to give that extra elegance to your outfit. I was sent this for review, however it does not effect my thoughts or opinions.

This is a great quality and large bottle of tea tree oil. I do with it had a dropper that can be used permanently with the bottle. It comes with a soft pliable dropper, but can not be left in the bottle. This is a bit of a pain since you will have to wash it out after each use. In case you wanted to know a few of the things tea tree oil is good for here are a few.psoriasisgetting rid of ticks, place on skin and they should unlatch and gomaking cleansersacne treatment (fav)helps with asthma (in diffuser)heals skin infectionsrid ringwormsThose are just a few, there are so many more things. This is a great toilet paper and was a great value. This is one of my go to toilet paper brands to use. What more can I say, It does it's job.

I love these nail clips. I can now paint my nails with my oh so ignored glitter nail polishes. I hated having to use the foil method to remove my nail polish. This is so much easier to have my finger soaking as well as just being comfortable to have on. It is easy to check how the status of the removing is going without trying to re tighten the foil on and not tightening enough.

It's really pretty and shiny, and comes in a lovely gift box. My only concern is that it seems somewhat lightweight. It's probably fine; I put a heavy pot on it and it did its job. I just was thinking it would be a little more substantial, since I think of a trivet as doing some heavy lifting on the table, and for gifting it seems more impressive if it's not thin and lightweight. However, for what it is---a shiny trinket to make a Christmas table more festive---it's pretty much right on the mark.

This is just what I'd hoped it would be. It was easy to set up and SO fast. I've been using it for about a month now with no problems at all, and it has been perfect for moving videos (and other large files) around. It has a small profile; amazing that so much storage comes in such a small box. It's super quiet, too. Basically it has made my life better and the only downside I can see is the price. Great product!

I love the feel and effect of this lotion. It goes on very light and smooth, and absorbs instantly. My skin feels moisturized, but not oily. There's a light rose scent (reminiscent of Nivea) and no yucky sunscreen feel or smell. It doesn't erase wrinkles, alas, but my face does look brighter and smoother after application. It doesn't take a whole lot of this product in order to cover my whole face, so even though the tube is relatively small, it will last a decent amount of time. I test a bunch of lotions for Amazon, and this one is my favorite so far. I like it even more than the Dr. Brandt Do Not Age Serum pearls, which costs over double the cost of this one and had been my favorite before this one. This one is a keeper!

Ugh, where to start. First off, it does not look like the picture. The background in the photo looks iridescent, with gleaming mother-of-pearl. Mine looks like white plastic. The lines that you can see radiating out of the center are completely invisible in my watch.  It's enormous: far too big for my wrist, and I think it would probably overpower most women's wrists, unless a woman wants to have a clunky and huge watch. It literally spans almost the entire area of the top of my wrist. What's more, it's barely water-resistant. It says that it's resistant to 165 feet, which is about 50m.  Don't think about using this for water sports, in other words.  Worst, it's incredibly hard to get off without help. I have been wearing a watch with a similar clasp for years, so I'm familiar with how they work. It's usually a quick, one-handed operation and boom! the watch slides off. I was literally trapped in this watch until I could get a friend to reach underneath and release me from it. Who needs that? I have a Citizen eco-drive watch, and I guess I'll be sticking with that one for a while longer.

This is absolutely superior chocolate. It's smooth and milky, with a slight crunch from the hazelnuts. It is totally authentic Swiss chocolate. I have spent over 4 months in Switzerland, and while I was there I ate plenty of chocolate. This bar brings me right back. It's delicious!

The plate itself is beautiful quality. The pattern seems a little more impressionist and a little less precise than my other Lenox Christmas pattern, but it's still lovely and exudes warmth and cheer and Christmas festivity. It's heavier than expected, much like stoneware, and not light and delicate like porcelain.My disappointment and dinging of one star is that the plate came with no presentation box; it is simply wrapped up in bubble wrap and sent alone. I think an accent piece like this would make a lovely gift for someone, but it needs a box.  My other Lenox Christmas pieces came in beautiful red boxes, so if someone wanted to give them as a present (teacher gift, etc), they are perfectly set up for that. This one, not so much. You wouldn't even know it was new if you tried to wrap it up; it just looks like a plate.

These pants are SO COOL, but run VERY big. My 9.5 year old son was very disappointed that they are too big, because he loved them at first sight. It took a lot of convincing to get him to fold them up and put them away until he grows a little bit.  But the fading and styling is perfect; just like his dad's jeans, and details like the metal hawk on the back pocket really add to the overall look.  I actually bought another pair of these in a size 8 (we started with size 10), and my son is STILL swimming in them.  He's not a huge kid, but he's not tiny, either. I'm not sure how they sized these jeans, but they don't seem in touch with the reality of my kid, at least.

This is very cute and quite unusual.  It would be adorable for hot chocolate with peppermint stirrers, or coffee with cookie straw stirrers, etc. For ordinary use, however, it is a bit strange. But the colors really pop and the mug has a good heft to it. I was expecting something more like fine china, but it's really thicker like stoneware.  That's not a bad thing, but it's not exactly what I was expecting. I would give these as a perfect teacher gift.

This is perfect! It is hefty for even baking and a sense of "weight" to even a simple dish, and perfect from oven to table. The colors and designs really pop from the dish, and they are so beautifully painted, it makes it look more expensive than it is. And even better, it comes in a beautiful box that would work for gift-giving if you wanted to give it as a gift.  An utterly beautiful piece that I'm so happy to have!

One of the most important things about hand lotion has to be that it absorb quickly and not make me leave a sticky, yucky residue all over everything I touch until it dries. This hand cream did just that. At first it did feel a little sticky right after I applied it, but within just a few minutes it had absorbed and my hands were dry and normal to the touch. In a way, it worked too well this way, as my hands don't feel particularly moisturized, and I'm feeling now that I need to reapply, even though it's been only a few minutes since I put it on.  But I'm hopeful that the moisturizing effects are more than "skin deep" and that my hands will be protected from chapping and other damage from the cold air.  There's no scent to this lotion, so it won't conflict with other scents you might be wearing.  Basically, it seems like a good lotion, other than just not quite leaving my hands feeling saturated and soft when I've applied it.

This is definitely a lovely deodorant. I was concerned when first applying, because it does not go on dry like a solid. It goes on wet, but it dries quickly and then has a great scent. I wore it to a workout and though it didn't stop my sweat, it did stop the stink.  It's shockingly expensive, and for a similar product, I like Nature de France solid deodorants (no aluminum in those either).  But other than price, this is a great product.

This is a beautiful little dish.  I mean, it's tiny! But it's perfect for serving a small dish of candies, or maybe a European-style butter round, or individual servings of a dessert if you got one for everyone. It's light and delicate, and the Lenox quality is clear. The printed picture is luminous, and the gold glows on the edge of the dish. It's definitely fine porcelain, and will grace any Christmas table with elegance.

These are good little cloths. People complain that they are cheaply made, but what do they expect? These cost next to nothing! They are nice to grab to clean up quick messes, and have a little grip to them to pick up dried-on food. Think "paper towels on steroids, that don't kill trees." True, they are not good hand cloths, because they feel yucky and scratchy on your hand. Use them on the counter or for dishes, and you're all set. Plus if they get nasty eventually, just throw them away. At this price, that makes sense.

This is an absorbing game that's perfect for 8+. I often think the suggested age ranges are too conservative, but I think in this one, it's about right. So I won't be playing it with my 6.5 year old for a while, or if I do attempt it with her, I'm going to have to expect a good deal of confusion at first until she gets the hang of the game play.It's been often compared to Ticket to Ride, but I think a comparison to Blokus (with a dash of Carcassonne) is more fair. There's some planning strategy in the manner of Blokus, but there are also little people you put down to claim territories, much like in Carcassonne.  The strategy is built on a lack of resources (needing the correct color tile, not having enough laborers to play, or having buildings in the way of where you'd like to build), and it feels a little like a double-solitaire game than a truly interactive game.  However, you can definitely make decisions specifically designed to mess up your opponent, so it can be more or less interactive depending on how you choose to play.  It's one of those games that builds in intensity as you get closer to the end, and it's a good idea to watch the size of the draw pile (and the player's building pile) so you can plan and not got caught unawares as the end of the game sneaks up on you.  It's a fast-playing game, and I like having a game that's fairly simple to set up and then can be effectively played by 2 players in about 30 minutes (once you know the game rules). There is very little luck involved: although you do depend on having the correct color come up to make specific builds, there are enough possible decisions and build-spots that strategy can overcome nearly the entire element of chance in the game.  I think the game pieces are fine quality. It's true that wooden pieces would have been a bonus, but the plastic ones are okay and the cards used are nice and thick with high-quality printing.So to me, this is a valuable new game to add to my collection for all these reasons. It's a little too simple for me to truly gush about it and it's not going to displace my current favorite games (Agricola & Cosmic Encounters) any time soon, but it's a good choice for a quick strategy game to play with a child.

This is a beautiful citrus-y, summery scent; very light and youthful. I really love this. It goes on light and bright, and has good staying power. I think as the afternoon wore on it mellowed into a slightly more mature scent, but nothing heavy or overly sexy. It reminds me of the Colors by Benneton scent, but a little brighter.  The bottle is classy and stable, and my one caveat was that it arrived to me from Amazon with a dented box. It was obviously just tossed in a cardboard box where it had room to slide around and get dented. Since perfume is often given as a gift, I thought I would bring that up, since it doesn't look as great for gift-giving as it would if you bought it from a brick-and-mortar store where it would presumably be more carefully handled. Still, a lovely scent and great product. I would wear this and give it as a gift.

This glides on smoothly, and I can see some effect on the fine lines, but almost no effect on the puffiness or shadowiness of my undereye area that's been the plague of my 40s.  I have fair skin and the Sand color is a good match. When I did a trial with using this under one eye but not the other, it was rather difficult to tell which eye I had "concealed" and which was au naturel.  So I think this product is fine for use within a regime of foundations, concealers, and powders, but it will not work miracles by itself.

These really have amazing sound, like the kind I get in my full-size headphones. Just beautiful for listening to music.  Connectivity was super easy with my iphone; they popped right up on my Bluetooth screen, I tapped it, and I was on.  The use is very intuitive and the buttons are easy to reach and use. My main concern is just that they are so small and light, they seem exactly like the kind of headphones that get lost or broken around my house. I also suspect that the rubber cover for the charging dock is not long for this world. The carrying case is suitably protective, but not much above what I keep much cheaper headphones in.  Basically, the same lightness and smallness that make them nice headphones make me worry that they will be fragile. Only time will tell, I guess, but at this price, they are something to take good care of.

My little princess is not always crazy about new food offerings, but this one she accepted without a problem.  I mostly like the ingredients list, too: most of the ingredients are ones that I would eat myself, or else they are vitamins or probiotics.  There are a few kinds of "meal" in the ingredients, which probably indicates low-quality food (meal can include entire carcasses of old animals, but it could also include just the meat portion of the animal). No added corn, wheat, soy, artificial preservatives, artificial flavors, or sugar.  "Natural flavor" in the ingredients list probably means MSG, but good luck finding a dog food without that. I've been looking for years and haven't found one.  And since I only have to feed my Cavalier King Charles Spaniel about 3/4 c per day of this food, the bag will last quite a while. So it becomes fairly economical. I think this is a good choice of dog food.

If I face facts, my older golden lab is not as active as he used to be. It's important to me to keep his weight down. This food is exactly right. It's not one of those which has only like five ingredients, but when I look at it I feel that ingredients in there are mostly foods that I would eat myself, or vitamins. Also for the weight of my dog, this requires a full cup of food less per day than the food I normally use. That is a great sign, because it means that this food has fewer fillers in it. Less fillers, less poop!  Not to mention which it means that this little bag will last longer. In fact, if I had one complaint about this, it would be the price. It is kind of steep if you figure that a 4 pound bag is only enough for a couple of days for my big guy.  But if you have a very high budget for dog food, or a very small dog, this could be a great choice for you. No corn added, no weed or so I added, no artificial preservatives or flavors or sugar‚Ä¶ This is a winner for me. Oh, and my dog likes it too. But he likes absolutely everything, so you can't put a whole lot of stock in that. :-)

This is ALMOST a five-star product.  I've gotten my son a bunch of Lego products, but we've always been biased against Mega Bloks.  I thought they wouldn't snap together as well, and that there was a fundamental difference in quality between the two.  This project definitely proved me wrong about that. These snap together very securely, and the final product is a very stable truck. Some of the pieces were almost too hard to snap together, when fitting in tight places!  These problems are par for the course in building with little plastic bricks, though, so I'm not going to ding it for that. What I will ding it for is the absolute lack of organization of the pieces in the initial bags.  Other (ahem) companies will put their plastic bricks in meaningful bags. Bag 1 is full of what you need for the first steps, Bag 2 for the next batch of steps, etc. This kit just puts everything in random bags, so you really have to open up all the bags right from the start.  That's both messier and makes it difficult to find the pieces you need. Spending that extra time in the beginning to sort the pieces is key.  Expect there to be a few extra pieces.Another thing to note is that obviously almost all of the pieces are similar colors. I think my son dragged a bit in completing this project because it was not the most exciting to put together (it's not a Death Star or anything), but that's the kind of thing you can predict before buying it. If your child is psyched about making this truck, it's a good choice at a reasonable price.

This is a smooth, light-to-medium roast coffee. I find it's necessary to select the smallest cup size when brewing with this one, in order to get it close to the level of richness I want. If I try brewing a larger cup it's too weak and light. Still, it does have a good flavor, not bitter, and brews a decent cup of coffee.

I've been using this and don't see any particular benefit. It goes on slimy and very runny, so it's hard to apply. I have to drip some on my face and then hurry to rub it in before it drips all over. My face does feel more or less moisturized when it is applied so it's not a terrible product, but I like others in this Burt's Bees line more, especially the night cream, which works during the day too, and goes on smoothly, smells great, moisturizes well, and doesn't smell like sunscreen (like the day cream in this line).

This is pretty expensive for what you get: the $15 bag I received is enough to feed my lab for a couple of days at most (at his weight he's supposed to get over 6 cups per day of this!).  But he likes it, I can't complain about the ingredients, and he hasn't had any tummy upset since I've introduced it to him.  Personally I'd recommend shopping around for the best price among the premium brands of grain-free if that's what you want, but this one works for my dog and could be a good choice for others, too.

I'm not seeing any shockingly wonderful results with this, but it does moisturize. One pump is enough to cover both under-eye areas thoroughly with a little left over. The feel is a bit waxy, and I like it better as a nighttime cream than a daytime one. I don't think it works really well under make-up and I think it has been making my eye-makeup run.  I have been fighting typical 40-year old under-eye issues (dark circles, sagginess) but can see no improvement from this. But I keep using it, and hope it will at least maintain the status quo and delay the onset of 50-year old problems!

Strong, lightweight, cute, and they hold a lot.  They won't hold up to crazy abuse, but basically it's a good strong cup for parties or occasional disposable use.  Also sharpie shows up really well on them if you want to write people's names on them.

This is good. Fizzy, sweet, a little bit of bite. Personally, I would have liked a sharper ginger to my ginger ale, and even though the stevia is natural, it doesn't taste the same as sugar. There's something subtly not quite right about the taste.  I also wonder if it has MSG--I get suspicious whenever I see "natural flavor" on an ingredients label.  On the other hand, it IS calorie-free, and it does taste like a soda, and not like a fizzy water.  So I would choose this over other sodas for sure.

I rarely use cookbooks any more. I can make fruit pies from scratch without a recipe (including homemade crust), I bake muffins/sweet breads weekly, and I can make pizza crust and bread in my sleep.  I HATE cookbooks that give too much detail or assume I know nothing about cooking, and the cooking blogs that take a picture of every.single.step.  This book is the kind of book I can actually use; actually, the kind of book I dream of.This book focuses on pastry dough, the next step for someone like me: puff pastries, croissants, pains au chocolat, phyllo dough (!), danishes...I'm so excited.  It doesn't cover pasta dough or bread dough. It breaks down the steps into an appropriate level of detail, explains the keys to success for the type of dough, and gives both a traditional ingredients list and a ratio for more advanced cooks.  I use ratios a lot, so I know how helpful they can be. For example, with muffins, the quantity I can make depends on how many zucchinis I have (or whatever). One thing that jumped out at me is that the ingredients are listed in terms of weight, not volume, which is definitely a departure from the way most recipes are written. A kitchen scale will be vital to use these.So how are the results? I tried an apple-pie recipe, because I know how to make apple pies and I wanted to make sure whatever result I got was not due simply to lack of experience.  I followed the recipe exactly to make sure I was getting as close as possible to the results intended by the author.  So, the pie ended up looking and tasting wonderful; definitely the best apple pie I've ever made. But there were some surprises. First, for some reason I ended up with waaaay too much apple filling, even though I weighed the apples as directed and used a 9" pie pan as directed.  I also ended up with some extra pie dough (possibly I rolled it too thin?), though, so I just made a second pie with only a top crust in a smaller pan. I'm definitely not complaining, but it was mystifying. I was suspicious when I was peeling the apples: I used about 18 apples to get 6 lb for the filling.  Still, it was cool to learn how to make a neat edge to the pie (never tried that before) and it really was delicious. Oh, and it did not take that long. The pie crust only took me a couple minutes (plus cooling time); max 10 minutes total mixing and rolling time.  The filling took longer, about 30 min because of peeling the apples, but still not too daunting. So not EVERYTHING in here is going to be an all-day project.So the upshot is that this is a serious book. Pretty much everything in here can be bought ready-made, but if you want to learn to make your own, this is what you want. Forget searching the Internet for this stuff; just get this book.

I was surprised by the slimy feel of the strip, but otherwise I have no problem with these. The handle is nice and grippy, for good control, and everything is angled well for effective use. I dropped it and the head didn't pop off the handle like sometimes happens, and it was as sharp you would expect.  I never understand why razors need to be gendered, but these work great for a woman as well as for a man.

This is wonderfully thick and creamy and enriching.
