It does make the feet a little slimy, so it's best before bed (don't plan on putting this on before wearing shoes, at least without socks), but it has a great moisturizing effect and I think I can see some improvement after a few days of use. The smell is light and not overwhelming, and when you're done with your feet, just rub whatever's left on your hands for a deep moisturizing. I've seen other foot lotions (like the Burt's Bees peppermint one) that require you to wash your hands after applying, which to me always feels like a waste. My only complaint about this lotion is that the bottle is small for the price, so it's definitely a budget-buster for most people. But for a "luxury" beauty product, it's a nice one.

Blech. I really tried to like this, but nope. It doesn't mix well (including when I put it in a shaker bottle) and it has a really unpleasant taste that I can't get over. It has stevia, so that could be some of the artificial taste of it (yes I know stevia is natural, but to me, it tastes strange and artificial), but whatever it is, it's an unpleasant combination of ingredients. I give it 2 stars because I like the theory of this powder, because the ingredients (except stevia) are impressive and just what I want. I'll keep trying to sneak this into smoothies and similar foods, but there's no way I'm going to simply mix it and drink it straight.

This is just what I look for in a mask! It applied smoothly and evenly, and I didn't need much of the tube for an application. It will last a long time! When I rinsed it off my skin felt firm yet soft, and I swear it glowed.  Maybe it's my imagination or wishful thinking, but I felt like I looked 10 years younger immediately after applying it.  I definitely felt beautiful. This is a great product!

My dog had no digestive problems at all with this food.  No tummy upsets or diarrhea. He also likes the taste (but then, he likes poop, so I'm not sure if he can be trusted).  I am happy with the ingredients list, and I'm pretty picky. It does have MSG ("Natural Flavor") but in all the dog foods I've reviewed (and there have been many!) every single one of them has that ingredient.  Another reviewer complains about the presence of lamb, and I think there should be some defense of that meat.  First of all, lamb is the name of the meat product that comes from sheep. You will not find "sheep" on an ingredients list.  "Lamb" on the list is not like "veal" and an indication that a baby animal was used in the food.  Also, for people concerned about animal welfare of their meat food, lamb is one of those animals which is less frequently factory-farmed than, say, beef, pork, or chicken.  So I think if you're planning to feed your dog a meat product (which I think you need to for them to be healthy!), lamb is a good choice.

I appreciate the focus on strategy on this game.  Game-play is much like Go or Othello, where regions can swap hands based on strategic destruction and rebuilding of bridges.  Unlike Go, though, there is an element of luck in this game, so you have to wait until you get the card you need.  I'd say it's about 90% strategy, 10% luck.  I disagree that the game is decided by the end of the first round. For example, at the end of the first round, I stomped my opponent with 6 islands in my control, to 3 in his control. By the last round, we were tied in terms of island control.  I still won the game, but I did not feel that my position was secure through all 3 rounds. (I think I just played better that game.)The rules are very easy to learn and assimilate. One quick read-through of the rules was enough for me, and it took me about 3 minutes to explain it to my 9 year old son.  He plays a lot of games, so may not be typical in terms of picking up on it, but any habitual game player will find it easy enough to learn.I don't think it's quite worth 5 stars because I almost feel that if you're going to have a game that is that strategic, why introduce luck at all?  I know I'll play this again with my son, but I sort of would rather play Go and dispense with the luck and stick with the basics.  It's a decent variation, though.

This is everything I hoped it would be. It is VERY high density, providing the firmness I needed for yoga applications. It is a little slick and "rolly" but I found it was able to mostly stay where I needed it to. The sizes were true to the description, and the outside of the roller is tough enough that I think it will last a good long time.

This is a cute game that is simple and very easy to learn, but still strategic and at least somewhat skill-based (but luck does play a factor). The instructions are so simple that they take up a single double-sided sheet of paper, and anyone can be taught the rules in under 5 minutes.  My 6 year old was able to grasp game play and join the fun.  We enjoy much more complex games as a family, and this one will NOT be a hit with my teenager (for whom Agricola is too easy), but for the younger set (6-13) it will be popular.  I'm always looking for games I can play with my 6 and 9 yo which will not make me want to claw out my eyes, and this is a good one.  I can't really imagine adults or adults and teens sitting down to play this without the presence of children, but to each his own. In my book, it's a good one to play WITH the kids.One of the things I like about this is that it is not a clone of any other game I know of.  It sort of reminds me of Karma (the card game) or even Solitaire (since cards can only be put on equal or lower cards), and reminded my son a bit of Ticket to Ride (probably because of the color cards and collection factor).  A little hand-management, a little risk-taking, a little strategy--it's a good game that I'm glad to add to our collection.  It's so easy to learn that a visiting friend could easily be brought into the game play, which is not always true for the more complicated games that seem so baffling to non gamers.  Mage Wars, for example, would not be good to play with a non-gamer guest; but this could.By the way, in response to the other reviewer who complained that the rules are unclear about whether other players get the Victory points on the piece left behind...of course they do.  If they didn't, it would make more sense for the "discoverer" of the VP token to simply take it until the end of the expedition.  It's true that the rules didn't explicitly say this (and they probably should), but context makes it clear.

I love this style of cat scratcher, and so does my kitty.  My old one was a frayed mess, littering the floor with little bits of rope hair constantly. I'm glad for a new one, but be warned that these do have a lifespan, and they don't look new for very long.  Maybe a few months.  If you put it in a corner, you can rotate it to try to make it last longer, but ultimately your cat will do a number on it, and you'll have to figure out how to get rid of it if your town has pay-per-throw bags or something similar.  My last one lasted a couple years, but only because I've put up with it looking incredibly beat up and was willing to vacuum up all the rope threads regularly.  For my sanity I should have gotten rid of it after a year at most.  Now that you're warned about that, I can tell you that although the scratcher gets beat up, my curtains, walls, and furniture look scratch-free, and my cat's claws are in good shape.  Totally a good trade-off.  Because they call this a "tall" post I was expecting something huge, but it's not more than a yard high--which is fine, because only a monster cat would be able to stretch much higher than this to scratch anyway.  As long as you know about the life-span and don't expect this to be the last scratch post you ever buy, you'll be happy with this product.

It gets rid of the frizz, but my hair feels heavy and greasy  where I focused the product.  Especially this summer, I'm finding my hair is frizzing out all over the place with the humidity, but it's particularly noticeable up by my part. (I have naturally wavy hair that can conceal a lot of frizz.)  So when I used this product following the vague directions (use a "small amount" on towel-dried hair) I was careful to apply especially to the part that is frizziest.  Well, now that part feels kind of gross, like I need to shower.  Hmph.  Other products work the same way without that heaviness (I like Paul Mitchell's Skinny Serum), so I wouldn't recommend this one too highly.  It's not awful; just somewhere between 3 and 4 stars.

I can't fault this with anything. It smells nice, goes on thick and creamy, and tames my dry hair into something smooth. I do have wavy hair and this was not so heavy as to make the waves fall out; they just dried nice and "undone."  Check out the sea salt spray from the Perfectly unDone line--it's my favorite new product.  This whole line of products, in fact, is awesome for naturally wavy hair.  Recommended!

This is perfect! It has everything I could want, and many features it never occurred to me to want. The alarm starts very quietly and then gets louder, so if you wake up quickly you don't have to suffer the onslaught of a loud noise. The display is very easily dimmable, which I so appreciate because I hate bright alarm clocks in the bedroom.  There is a "nap" feature, where with the touch of a button you can take a nap of set lengths from just a few minutes to an hour and half.  You can change the length of the snooze alarm.  The charging docks, backup battery, easy-to-operate alarm setting, and manual backup time set (for if/when the auto-set feature fails, like it's failed on my last 6 auto-set clocks).  If only the auto-set feature lasts as long as the rest of the clock, it will be truly the most wonderful clock ever.  Time will tell. (Get it?)The one thing I can point to as a possible problem has to do with the charging cord. I've never seen an alarm clock that doesn't have the power cord permanently attached to the clock, so there is a possibility that an over-zealous snoozer could yank the clock out of its power charge cable.  Also, the end of the cord is not an ordinary 2 or 3 prong plug, but has a large transformer attached, that would need to be plugged into the bottom of the 2 outlets or you'd lose the outlet underneath the transformer. In my bedroom, the outlets next to the bed (where I would plug in an alarm clock) are half wired to the wall switch, (so you could turn out a bedside light at the wall), and it's no good to plug an alarm clock into the wall-switch outlet.  Luckily, in my case the wall-switch outlets are the top outlet of the 2, but if they were on the bottom, I'd lose that plug since I'd be forced to plug the alarm in the top outlet and it extends down far enough to cover the other plug.  So if that might apply to your situation, caveat emptor.

I can't, for the life of me, get my cat interested in the blinky ball that goes around the track. And when you take that away, this is just an overpriced cardboard scratch-pad.  I have sprinkled it with the catnip that comes with it to "train" her, I've tried tempting her with the ball when she's sitting nearby, I've rolled it around when I found her actually sitting on the pad.  Zero, zip, nada.  And she is a fairly active cat: she is a great mouser, and she loves chasing laser pointers and fluffy balls as much as the next cat. But this ball, meh. She couldn't care less.  As a scratcher, it's fine.  She has scratched it and I'm sure she'll enjoy ripping it to shreds. But it's no big deal, and I'm not exactly excited about buying the replacement cardboard inserts when this one is destroyed.  If I had paid the purchase price for this, I'd be really disappointed.  As it is, I can just give it a lukewarm so-so rating.

Oh, this book is a treat. It dwells quite a bit more in the "real world" than I was expecting, but those scenes were part of what gives the book its depth.  Maguire has quite a bit to say about the Victorian world, adolescence, class structure, etc, and he communicates this through the third-person omniscient structure of the narrative and the scenes involving the Real World folk.  I actually found myself wanting a pencil while reading this, so that I could underline or star various passages for further musing. Lewis Carroll had much to say, as well, but without the historical perspective that a modern author can overlay.  Maguire writes in the tradition of Carroll, with depth, humor, and imagination: I loved it.This is by no means a copycat book, but Maguire certainly does know his Alice. The scenes in Wonderland, especially, are often laugh-out-loud funny; far funnier, to me, than the original scenes, but perhaps that's because the original jokes are stale since I've heard them a million times.  These scenes take us back to Wonderland with a very different girl, a clever and prosaic one, who is much less apt to be befuddled by the Wonderland characters than to outsmart them.A caveat, though: this book is written at a very high level. It is not for children, but it is less the subject matter (although the philosophical musings would bore them silly) than the language.  Children are frequently taught to assess the reading level of a book using the "five finger" test:  read a random page of a book, and if you find five words you don't know on that page, the book is too hard for you.  I suspect that many adults would fail the "five finger" test for this book.  For example, page 7 includes the words distempered, ellipsis, vatic, apidistra, benighted, and kitted out, as well as slightly easier words epiphany, marmalade, and fray (commotion).  I literally just randomly picked a page toward the beginning of the book. The whole thing is written with an SAT vocabulary.  If you are not accustomed to reading "high" language, you might just find this book boring.I think it would be a failure as a read-aloud for younger children because you'd have to stop over and over to explain vocabulary (and concepts, on many of the more philosophical chapters that detail a character's thoughts and dreams), and I know a lot of parents would be taken aback to find the word "rape" used (hyperbolically) by one of the roses or the F-word slipped in with minimal disguise in another character's thoughts.So, it's not for children.  But for educated adults who will always have a soft spot for Alice, this book is a rare find: funny, thoughtful, and utterly respectful of its predecessor. I can't recommend it highly enough.

Ew, ew, ew.  This is the most disgusting protein bar I've tried in a while. The flavor is a horrible, artificial sweetness which my daughter likened to "week-old cough syrup"  and my husband called "bubblegum and chalk."  The texture is crumbly and dry.  The box is tiny, which normally would be a matter for me to complain of, but in this case it makes me feel less bad about just throwing the rest of the them away.  I couldn't even get two sugar-crazy six-year-olds to eat this.  Just, yuck. Skip this one!

These were not at all what I expected, but I like them. For starters, the bottles are MUCH smaller than other Purell wipes I've gotten in the past.  Be aware that these are 40-count containers, not 100-count containers like you can also get.  Also, the product is different: these are NON-ALCOHOL wipes.  I'm not a scientist, so I'll have to take their word for it that Benalkonium Chloride can also kill bacteria, but these feel much gentler to skin and can, in fact, be used on the face.  I have used regular Purell wipes on my face before and the experience is not fun--overpowering, asphyxiating alcohol fumes in my nose and eyes--yuck! But these are fine; it feels like using a Wet Wipe; no fumes, and it cleaned my face. (But they do need to be kept away from eyes, so don't imagine these can double as make-up removers.)The upshot is that these are versatile wipes that will kill bacteria and be used on faces.  The smaller bottle means they're easier to stash in the car, backpack, etc.  I'm a fan!

Writing this to help balance all those 5-star reviews.  I'm not impressed with this book. The writing is immature, the dialogue laughable, the science often implausible, the characters one-dimensional, the romances ridiculous, and the plot just plain boring. The idea of a silo-world was intriguing, which kept me going for quite a while through this book, but it wasn't ultimately enough to keep my interest.  About 250 pages into the book, I'm calling it quits.  Better books await.

My biggest complaint is that it's hard to get out of the can. I had envisioned that it would be so easy: pop of the top, dump out the food, repeat. But instead, it's a production that includes multiple kitchen tools (knife, spoon, scraper) and a minute per can. The food is sticky! Imagine emptying a jar of peanut butter, quickly.  OK, maybe it's not that bad, but anything that turns feeding the dog into a bigger chore is not a good thing in my book. If only they had made the can a little bigger and added just a little more broth (or water). It seems that it would have simplified feeding.Beyond that, I do wonder about the importance of a "diet" dog food.  If I control how much he eats, why can't I feed him a little less of whatever other food I choose?  Is this more for the owners, who can't bear to feed their pet so little? Calories in, calories out = weight control.  But whatever.Also, be sure you do the math to calculate how much per day it will cost you to feed your dog with this food, if money is an issue for you.  A 100-lb dog needs 6 cans of this a day for weight maintenance (4 for weight loss), so that cost adds up really fast.My dogs both approve heartily of this food and are going to be disappointed when it runs out. Me, I'm more than happy to go back to the easy-to-scoop kibble.

I'm not sure how you could improve on these binder tabs. They are the strongest dividers I've ever seen,and it's obvious that they will last through a lot of hard wear without falling out.  Yet they remain perfectly flexible, so there usefulness is not compromised. The window is not crystal clear, but translucent enough that you can really have a preview of whatever the first page is under the divider. To combine the translucency with the colored border is genius, because you get the best of both worlds.  The extra-large tabs at the sides allow for extra-long names if necessary, and the sheet of stickers for labeling contains enough for labeling both sides of the tabs once.  If you want to reuse the dividers for another project, you'll either have to cut your own labels from unshaped sticky paper or use Sharpie directly on the tabs.  Maybe this is a potential negative, but on the other hand you could just plan to use these for a project or filing system you plan to keep around for a while.  A very long while, in fact, because I suspect these dividers will outlast all of us.

I drink my coffee black, so the flavor of the coffee is very important.  This is a smooth coffee, without an acidic bitterness that some have.  I almost want to say it seems to have a touch of sweetness and I felt like there were notes of almonds in the flavor. It is full and rich and, yes, dark enough for me. I also think it's very cool that it is sourced from a single location (Ethiopia).  Having just read Cutting for Stone, a great book set mostly in Ethiopia, I enjoy imagining myself transported to the world of that book.What I didn't like was all the packaging. Nespresso packs make me feel bad enough; all that extra plastic for every single cup! But this brand goes one step further and wraps each Nespresso pod in yet another plastic bag container. I feel like I'm throwing away a bunch of stuff for every single cup. But if you're already using Nespresso, I guess the one little extra bag per cup is not a big deal.  It's just like, why?

Some water toys can keep a group of children entertained for hours on a summer day...but this is not one of them. It's a cute gimmick, but not much more. I had a group of three children testing it out, and it took too long to set up for the entertainment value provided.  They were entertained for about 5-10 minutes, and it took maybe 5 minutes to get it all set up.  The chin strap is a pain to adjust each time, and it is overkill, I think.  It is original, I'll give it that, but sometimes it's the oldies-but-goodies that are the real summertime winners. Slip-n-slide, water guns, water tables, sprinkler attachments; these are all superior choices for water play.

There's a reason there's a picture of a small dog on the can. I was shocked when I saw the feeding guide for my lab would require me to feed about 6 cans (but up to 7) every day. 3 cans in the morning, 3-4 in the evening. If I do the math, that's about $10-$12 per day to feed my dog. Yikes!  Over $4300 per year?  Maybe not.  Even a dog with no teeth could eat dry food that's been soaked in water, which I think I would do before shelling out this kind of money.But for a smaller dog, I can see using this product. The ingredients list is very high quality and almost perfect. "Chicken Liver Flavor" is the only dubious ingredient I can identify, and I don't see any other red flags like those identified by the people at the Dog Food Project. This food is basically just real foods fortified with vitamins and minerals (plus the flavoring, which undoubtedly has MSG).Oh, I should mention that both of my dogs were thrilled with this product. Even the cat tried to get in on the fun.  So I guess it tastes good.  However, full disclosure: my dogs eat poop, so I'm not sure they can be trusted on what tastes good.I know some people make food for their dog, and I'm sure that's an even healthier option (if done with care). But short of that, this seems like a great option...just very pricey if you have a big dog.

This author/illustrator is so talented, and it's really fun to see him apply his talents to a purely whimsical topic. The same kind of elaborate illustrations that are found in his other books are here, and it's all about ice cream. My 6 year old daughter loved finding the hidden ice-cream cones in the pictures and my nine year old son was fascinated with some of the ice-cream lore and history presented through the illustrations.  Even the page with the ice-cream math was a big hit, and my kids wouldn't let me continue the story until they had solved all 4 of the problems. (3 of them were solvable by my rising first-grader, but she needed help on the last one, which involved multiplying 6x2.)  The book reminds me of Tomie da Paola's Popcorn Book, which I read over and over as a child, and taught all kinds of tidbits and factoids about popcorn.  This does for ice cream what that did for popcorn, but with better illustrations. (with apologies to Mr da Paola.)  We love this book!

This is just right for a night cream. The scent is lovely but not overpowering, and the cream is thick and substantial without feeling waxy or oily. It is definitely too much for a day cream, as my face feels heavy when I use it. But for a serious shot of moisturizing, this is a great product. This is best for dry to normal skin; oily skin would probably be overwhelmed with this product.  I'm not going to try to claim that it's going to stop my face from aging, but I do know that it is keeping my skin from looking dry and taut, and I do think that keeping one's face properly moisturized helps reduce wrinkles.

The biggest problem for me is that it wears off very fast. It's horrible right at first, but after a few hours it's barely noticeable. For best results you would need to apply maybe twice a day. But, because it's actually a nail polish, you have all the hassle of applying new polish over old polish, with result that my nails actually look worse than ever. (No mean feat: as a lifelong biter my nails are not my best feature.)  Also it stings a lot on hangnails, one of my problem areas.Also, I do not think it is a matte finish. Maybe it's not as shiny as other polishes, but it definitely shines. I was hoping my teenaged son could use this product to help with his habit, but I think he would feel stupid with shiny nails. Plus, if your nails look crappy because of being gnawed on, the last thing you want to do is make them shiny and eye-catching. I can't imagine using this on an entire thumb for thumb-suckers.But all that said, it's not a terrible product. I think it can help, if applied religiously daily or twice a day. It's more of a reminder not to bite than an actual deterrent, once the initial bitterness has faded.  I will often bite without realizing it, so this helps with that. But if I'm determined to do so, once the initial moment is past, this is not going to stop me.  It's just not strong enough.

This is why Provence, France, is famous for their soaps. What a lovely soap! It is perfect and hits all the right notes.The presentation is elegant, with a lovely wrapping and embossing on the soap itself.The color and striations on the soap are attractive. I think the light texture and visual interest are caused by shredded rose petals (although I can't be sure). They are not uniformly sized, which adds to the attractiveness of the bar.  There were faint knife scrape marks on one side of the bar, confirming its origin as touched by human hands, and not just cranked out in some factory.The feel of the soap is lush and smooth, not gritty. With use, the soap gently wears away to a slightly bumpy feel, and is not grainy or scratchy in any way.  The lather is substantial.The smell--ahh.  Just roses.  A strong, pure rose scent, unadulterated by notes of jasmine or other flowers. I love it.The bar is cured to a hard, silky touch, but not too soft: it holds its own with use and doesn't just melt away too quickly like I've seen some other premium soaps do.And, it's a purely vegetarian soap. No worries about how the animals were treated in making it.If I were to name any problems, I would point to the scary ingredient list, which has big, chemical-y sounding names.  I am not a chemist, so I don't know if those are just the official names for, I dunno, rose extract and lye (needed for soapmaking), but my guess is that if you want a purely natural soap, this one isn't going to fit the bill for you. There are a lot of ingredients, most of them unrecognizable to a layperson.But if you just love the experience of a beautiful soap and are not overly sensitive about what's in it, you will not be disappointed with this quality bar.

Where to start?  First of all, the whole thing looks cheap. The bows are tiny, and everything just looks cheap too.  Mine came with no retail box or instructions, but if you hold the bow vertically, more often than not the darts clip the heel of your thumb as they whiz by.  Ouch! Not only does that mess up their aim, it really hurts. My son figured out way to hold the bow horizontally so it doesn't hurt, but it no longer has the "archery" look and feels unnatural.  The darts fall off the board after a few seconds, so you can't shoot all your arrows and then add up your points. Somehow I thought the dartboard itself would light up or something fancy, but no, it's just a little light you can turn on or off in the arrows.  It's not like the motion of being shot or landing activates the light (which would be cool).  You just flip the switch on each dart to make it glow or not. Big deal.Basically, this toy is not awful, but it would need to be in the range of $15-20 to accurately reflect its coolness.  We have a Zing Curve Bow and it is a much better product with a more appropriate price.  The Zing Curve Bow is maybe twice the size of the Zeon bows included in this set and shoots the arrows about 3x as far.  I realize they are different products, but this one is a disappointment, whereas the other is a huge hit in this house.

I mean, this is a nice product, but it is so overpriced as to be laughable. With the same active ingredient as Clearasil, you're not going to do much better with this product at clearing your acne. I read once that doctors are more likely than other consumers to buy generic medicines, because they realize it's the drug, not the brand name and marketing costs, that does the job. If you buy this, you are not buying a more effective ingredient, you are buying expensive ads in fashion magazines, etc.  But maybe you don't care, and you don't want to have an embarrassing tube of Clearasil on your counter.  So, fine. This product smells nice, goes on smoothly, and works as well as expected.  It won't do miracles (for that you need to see a dermatologist), but I like it.  It comes out just a little at a time and feels more like a lotion than a medicinal cream. It is drying, so be careful where you use it.Bottom line:  If you don't need your money for other things and like the look of the bottle and the cachet of the brand name, then it will be a good purchase for you.

Only get this mattress if you truly like a firm sleeping surface. It is not for the faint of heart. My teenager joked that if I would like, he could get me a wood plank or stone slab to sleep on, since I liked this mattress so much.  All 5 of my children hate it (I asked them to try it so I could get a variety of opinions on it), and I suspect that most kids wouldn't like it. It's not bouncy or soft.  Each of them (and they range in age from 6 to 16) would give it one star.BUT. It allows just enough sinking in for the heavier parts of my (40-something, average-weight) body, and my legs and arms feel like they are floating. I feel that it allows my spine to stay essentially straight while I sleep on my side, since my hips sink in just a little bit more. I think I had overly high expectations for this mattress, because I still wake up with some discomfort in my back and need to stretch and loosen things up when I get up, but I do think it's better than it was on my old, softer mattress.I don't particularly love memory foam, but in this mattress, there's just a layer of memory foam on top of the springs, so I feel that it's not overkill.  I despise a full memory-foam mattress, but here it's ok.A great feature is that it reduces or eliminates the bounciness of having your partner shift position next to you, which is a big deal to me. I hate feeling bounced when someone turns over, and with this mattress, I can't feel it.One issue is that it is definitely thicker than other mattresses I've had, so I've been having some trouble keeping the sheet on. I did not use a mattress pad, but I imagine with a mattress pad, this would need some seriously specialized sheets with huge side pockets.  This is an issue I am working on.  If you have a very tall base for your mattress, you may find that your bed is higher than you are accustomed to.  Something to keep in mind.

I've had 5 babies, and I've never tried Dreft until now. Frankly, I'm not that impressed. As far as I can tell, the only thing distinguishing it from any other mainstream laundry detergent is the fragrance---which is very powerful.  The bottle seems to claim that this detergent will help your baby smell like a baby, but trust me, your baby will smell like a baby regardless.  You also have to use a ton of this detergent for a full load of laundry. Perhaps this is a good thing if you're doing teeny tiny loads of just a few baby clothes, but if you're saving your sanity and washing the baby clothes with the rest of the laundry, you need to use a huge capful even for an HE load. It's like 3 times the amount of detergent I've been using recently in other brands. There's nothing alternative, natural, or gentle about this detergent; for that you'll need to look to a more expensive brand like Seventh Generation.  The ingredients are not listed on the bottle like they are for natural detergents, so I can't comment on that.  As far as stain removal, yes, it seems to do about as well as any other detergent, and clothes come out smelling very strong in the baby scent.  (Which is another negative to the detergent, because it almost forces you to wash baby clothes separately.  I didn't, though, and we all just wore baby scented clothes!)TL; DR:  meh. Not worth it.

I would love these if the dose were not 6 gummies per day. Basically, they are just little vitamin-supplemented candies, and they are very high in sticky sugar.  It's hard for me to feel really good about taking these when I know they are little sugar bombs. On the other hand, I know my limitations, and in this house, pills that I have to swallow just don't get taken unless I'm really sick.  If you were really disciplined, you could eat your dose of these after a meal and call it dessert.  For me, though, it's just an added dose of sugar because I always take them first thing in the morning.  They are just too tempting!  Still, they do the job and deliver the vitamins, so it's a good product.

I love how it smells, and it's cool how it pumps out in a foamy mousse, but I do not think it's hydrating at all. It feels just like I used soap on my face, and my skin is parched and uncomfortable after I wash with this.  I need to follow it up ASAP with a moisturizer.  Maybe it would be good for a teenager who needs to do everything possible to combat oil on her skin, but for my forty-something skin, this is not a winner of a product.

This is a beautiful, perfectly laid out calendar. I absolutely love the balance between the monthly calendar and the daily assignment calendar part. It will work perfectly as a planner for my homeschooling needs.  I can either see the entire month's activities at a glance or see a more detailed section of assignments by the day or week.  The simple but pretty motif of the birds and the tree is feminine and somehow makes it seem less dull. This is definitely a great planner.That said, is this really a Julian calendar?  Great Britain stopped using the Julian calendar in 1752, so presumably our country has not used it since it was founded. One of the last holdouts to the Julian Calendar was Greece, which used the Julian up to 1922. So are the writers of the ad copy just uninformed?  Because this looks like a regular calendar, not some strange thing.  If you're a geek like me and  worried about not buying this because it is Julian, rest assured that it looks plenty Gregorian (the usual calendar) to me.Ahh, further research has informed me that today, the phrase "Julian dates" means that they are numbered sequentially.  So today's date, May 31, is actually day 151 in Julian terms.  I have never heard of anyone using this, but if you do, this is the calendar for you.  If you don't use it, you can just ignore the little numbers and rest assured it's also an ordinary planner.

The one thing I wasn't expecting was how shimmery most of these colors are. That's not a bad thing, but it is different.  It makes them look less natural than matte colors. They're not kidding about the nudes being blushed: most of the colors, even the brownish ones, have a pink or reddish tint.  But it's a nice effect, and the colors blend well together.  The coloring goes well with my "spring" coloring (dark blond hair, blue eyes, fair skin with pink/blue undertones). They flow on smoothly, and stay on for hours; I would reapply every 8 hours or so. I would classify this as a younger palette, and I know my teen would be very happy with these colors.  On my 40-something face, I need to be careful not to overdo the shimmer, so I'd go easy on this palette. It won't be one of my favorites, but it's still a nice set.

I usually keep a variety of different kind of dishcloths: scrubby ones for cleaning, soft cotton ones for drying, and others for wiping up small messes. Usually the ones that can scrub are terrible at drying--but not these.  These are made from a rough microfiber that is perfect for scrubbing a countertop or even dishes (they are small enough to be used for that), but are amazingly also absorbent enough to wipe up spills and other messes. It's remarkable. They really do everything. They are also attractive, although I am not crazy about the darker colored ones because I like to bleach kitchen cloths, and I'm not comfortable throwing the dark ones in with the rest of my whites. Still, other than that one minor issue, I love these. Great cloths!

My son adores animals, watches documentaries about them all the time, and LOVES games. We have dozens of games, mostly Eurogames (like this one pretends to be). He (and I) hated this game.  It really couldn't be stupider. All the cards are simply fact sheets about tons of obscure animals, and each turn involves guessing the location found, tail length, weight, and/or length/height. You get points based on how close you were. There are limited guesses, and you lose guessing tokens if you get things wrong. Only one person can guess one area/weight/etc. at a time.  So if you KNOW where an animal lives, but the other player "guessed" there first, you have to settle with putting your token in a nearby zone to get half points. It's so, so boring.  We played two turns before he begged to stop playing.There is no strategy, no suspense, no real game play, just a sorry excuse for a game that tries to be educational.  But really, the knowledge it's trying to impart is so trivial that who cares, really?  If an eight-year-old child knows the range and other statistics for a Nyala are they more likely to get into Harvard?  Is there some kind of animal habitat bee (like the geography bee) that this helps prepare for?  I honestly can't come up with any reason to keep or play this game.  Save your money.

Some people were saying that this color is too bright: nonsense! It's absolutely beautiful! And perfect for spring. I will say that the reviewer who said it was the same color as the purple dinosaur Barney was right on. Who knew that would be such a good color for nails? The polish glides on easily, dries quickly, and looks good with just one coat although I put two. Great stuff!

These are excellent razors. They shave smoothly without problems, and seem to moisturize while doing so. For me, anyway, they last a long time before needing to be changed. The head has some movement to it to allow it to go over curves and tricky areas without cutting.  They look about as nice as a razor can.

I love this bottle cooler, but I don't use it for baby bottles. As the weather gets warmer, it's very difficult to keep a bottle of water from home cool in the gym bag, especially when I have to pack it a few hours before the workout and keep it in a hot car. This pouch does the trick. Even after hours in a warm car, the water is cool and fresh for use during a workout. I use one of the largest sized Kleen Kanteens and it still fits, even with the cold pack included.  As a bonus, it provides extra insurance against a leaking water bottle drenching the stuff in the bag.  I love it!

I like this mask, but I'm not certain that it's life-changing. It goes on smoothly, and I like how you can pump out only a little bit at a time. I can use the same product over and over without having to worry about it drying out. It dries quickly and  rinses off easily. It does not have a firming feel to it when I rinse it off; if anything my face feels mushy immediately after treatment. I think this is a matter of personal preference, because I sort of like to have that sense of firming when I take off a mask. However, I  think the goals of this product are a little different, and as far as detoxifying and purifying, I think it's doing what it sets out to do. I don't think anything is actually going to stop my face from aging, but if it can look better along the way, I'm okay with that.

After having some trouble getting my cat to eat Wellness Core Air Dried Chicken/Turkey food, I was SO happy to see that she actually liked, right off the bat, this product. The other one I can only get her to eat when she's ravenous; this one she'll cheerfully chow down at regular mealtimes.  The food is a great product, with so many awful things NOT included and some good stuff in there. Note that the ingredients list is still somewhat intimidating and full of big words and chemicals, but I think a lot of those things are probiotics and vitamins. I see all kinds of real foods in the list, too, like spinach, kale, broccoli, chicken, etc. I don't like to see "Natural Flavor" since it's probably MSG, but I have yet to find a pet food without it.  An added bonus is the closing velcro of the bag, which I adore. She won't be getting into this bag behind my back!

This book is terribly disappointing after Sekret.  I truly enjoyed the first book in the series and recommended it to a few friends as a fun, off-beat alternative-history novel. The first one was exciting and intriguing, and it had such an exotic setting that it was extra interesting.  This one misses the mark. After 60 pages in I realized I couldn't care less about the characters and didn't really see where it was going. After 100 pages in, I realized I was approaching reading this book like a job instead of for pleasure.  Yulia seems weak and whiny in this one, the excitement of hidden KGB headquarters locations is replaced with boardrooms in Washington, D.C., and the descriptions of Yulia's mental pain from the scrubbers seems unending.Now, 100 pages in, a spy is on the loose (finally), there might be a mole in Yulia's unit, and guess what? I don't care.  The latest development is that Yulia might get to go to college!  Yippee! Maybe we'll get to listen in on her professors' lectures in the last 2/3 of the book.  I'm not going to force myself to finish this book. If a book can't grab me within 100 pages, something is wrong with the pacing.  This is not an English assignment, so I'm outta here.Not recommended. Read Sekret, then let your imagination fill in the rest of the story. It will probably be more exciting, and most certainly will move faster, than Skandal.

This is great, but I was surprised to see that the largest spatula is actually a stiff flipping kind of spatula, not a soft kind for scraping jars. You can't tell from the picture, but there's an angle from the flat part to the handle, like any other flipper.  Still, these are very nice. I like that they are one-piece, since my other spatulas are starting to get yucky from the place where the end slips onto the wooden handle. They have the right amount of "give" to effectively scrape jars, pans, etc, and they are heat-resistant so they can be used for cooking.  The color is strange and may not blend with many decors, but on the other hand, it does make them stand out in the drawer. A great tool.
Great cord, but the dreaded message comes up saying "this cable is not certified" using with iPad Air 2.

Picked one up last week at BestBuy, only place I could find one in stock. Their FB page said the Folio would be out on 9-25 for $79 and $99. Neither was and as oct 5th still not. I thought they looked less bulky. Then they finally arrived but raised the cheaper one to $89. It was a gift for my wife as was the mini 4. I thought it looked bulky but I got ugly anyway. She took one look at it, hefted it and said its to heavy. Took it back next day. Not going for the others as they raised the price. Waiting for the Clamcase, much better reviews and less weight, plus I had to return something a few years ago to Zagg and was put through the ringer about why I thought it was not a good product..
My wife loves this, last time was a 16 ounce bottle that's nit available. Just discovered by ingredients it contains wheat. She can't have wheat period.
This is just the light folks, not sure why green laser is included in the title.

Decent little guy, very small. Whoever stated in description it's 100% leather needs to maybe see this product for themselves, inner lining is a fabric of some sort, so it's probably around 80% leather. 3 stars for being not all leather it'll last about a quarter of what was the expected lifetime of 100% leather.
Fits iPhone 6s plus perfect and practically invisible.
Works good and practically invisible on my 6s plus. Nice round cutout for home button. There is however no noticeable rounding on edges, if it is it's too slight to be effective.
Don't care for the protectors with a "U" cut out for home button, this package in photo clearly shows the "O" cutout but product doesn't match. Minus 3 stars for wrong product. Sending back.

This is the case that finally switched me from Piel Frama after more than 10 years. Light weight, slim profile, well made, no nonsense. Camera cut out is thin enough not allow the flash issues like in the puffiier ones.  I've been using on the 6 plus since Feb '15 with not a single issue, as well as my wife on her iPhone 6. Price is a little more than it should be but I guess that's supply and demand. I'm pretty sure it'll also work on the 6s and 6s plus. I'll update on the 25th.
Easy to use and described correctly.

When I ordered, it stated "Nutriden Omega 3 Fish Oil Supplement 2000mg 400ct"Sold by: Nutriden. What's I received was directions on back "400 capsules 200 servings actually they're 400 capsules 1000 mg ea. Most misleading description I've seen to date.
Worst one I've ever owned on fears to pilling.

This thing is well built. Only thing I had to replace was foam seals available from manufacturer three dollars. Takes two hands to operate but not difficult at all. I use the sealer to seal potato chip bags etc (not vac and seal, just seal) and you can use just about any brand Amazon sells of sealer rolls with this unit. Highly recommend.
Sucrose, Mouger selling 35 dollars greed will not become you.
Bought this as a spare for a newer 2012 bdp-s7200 blu-ray player that I wound up returning. Fortunately it works just fine on my older 2010 model bdp-s570.

Been using another major brand with great success but only 16 oz. and I wanted/needed more. Read mixed reviews here. I think the people with leaks are probably microwaving them, which you cannot do to paper travel cups as that'll guarantee a leak at the seam. Blame it on the removal of chlorinated solvents from our adhesives.
4' perfect length in my opinion, small (like oem) lightning end rather than some others with ends so big you can't use them with a case. I'm buying two more, by darn it.

Easy to assemble, makes it easy to move from room to room the Honeywell document safe. Seems strong enough for the job, wheels are the light weight plastic type (4 stars on that acct) so not real excited about that.
Priced right, piece of cake to install, looks great with wooden rod, not obtrusive.

Regular run of the mill deodorant, should have read closer, thought is was more of a natural product. Maybe like talcum powder or baby powder. I'm sure there's nothing wrong with it, just not what I was looking for. Wound up throwing away.
Very good filters, small tab to separate them from each other is an appreciated touch.
Both my dogs enjoy these, there appears to be no added unnecessary ingredients or colors.

Excellent product, but what you get is a torpedo shaped bottle with either 12 or 16 ounces of oil. Why the feel they need to show a quart bottle on the main photo I have no idea, I've already brought that to the sellers attn over a month ago. Also way overpriced.
First quality and fast shipping. Excellent price as well.
Good flexibility (black ones) nice snug fit.

Very misleading use of MIMO, that acronym means 2.4 and 5.0. This has the 2.4 part only. Manufacturerers shouldn't have to deliberately mislead consumers to sell product. Didn't work any better than my 2010 model. Having issues, was advised to turn off the fast loading part (dual-core) for it to work properly, negates the purpose of buying dual core in the first place.

This thing is amazing, built an add on to deck for my 4 bbq's appx 12' x 8'. Decided to try this instead of wiring one in. This thing is amazing, and I don't use that word very often. Plenty bright, picks up movement just as I'm rounding the corner and illuminates the entire area..
Butt kicking movie, I really enjoyed it. Dolby Atmos too.
Good flexibility (black ones) nice snug fit.
The best, tried cheaper brand (Sparkle) theirs a night and day difference in the thickness, and absorbency. Little more money, but well worth it.

Sharp knives are a joy to use and a must for slicing onions, carrots and other tricky/difficult vegetables with ease. They're also essential if we want to avoid bruising items like tomatoes and delicate herbs. Yet we've all known the frustration of reaching for our favorite knife, only to find it isn't up to the task at hand. This new 3-Stage knife sharpener can help with that, within limits.It includes coarse and medium sharpening stones and a ceramic wheel for final honing. It's also small enough to remain unobtrusively on the counter next to a knife block. There are no markings to indicate which stage is which, although that is easily discerned by passing a dull knife through each slot. The innermost slot (near the center of the device) is the first or coarse grinding wheel. the center slot is the medium wheel and the outer slot contains the ceramic honing wheel. Quick tip - once your knife is sharp, if you draw it 2-3 times through this slot before each it will keep your knives ready to go.It is also lightweight and easy to use. Hold it in your hand by the side without the slots, behind the black divider and using your free hand, set your knife in a slot and draw it through. I suggest angling your knife in the slot (letting it rest against the side of the slot) and alternating sides each time you pull the knife through. This will give you the best chance of matching the angles on each side.There are 2 major drawbacks to this particular sharpener and the reason I can only give it 3 stars. Nowhere does the maker tell us to what angle the sharpening discs are set. This is crucial for cooks who own both Japanese and European style blades, because the angles for those knives are quite different. Further, the slots do nothing to control or even suggest the angle at which the blade is inserted into the slot. Given these 2 limitations, it would be all too easy to create an unintended angle on a knife. For these reasons, I cannot recommend it to anyone but the most casual cooks. If you regularly straighten your blade edges know the angle to which they're ground, look elsewhere.However, if you are, like a great many cooks, one who buys inexpensive knives and never sharpens or properly steels them, this will be a nice step up, giving your knives a much longer useful life and can go a long way to saving you money over the long term. Having it next to your knife block will encourage you to use it to keep your edges straight and sharp.**The seller provided this item in exchange for my honest review.**

This is a nice little cake decorating tool for the occasional baker, like me. It is easy to fill, easy to use, and works as advertised. It has 7 of the most commonly used decorating tips that will store right inside the unit, ensuring they don't get lost. Tips screw easily and securely onto the nozzle of the chamber, the cap clicks in place easily, too. My deviled egg filling flowed smoothly without applying undue pressure. The whole thing is easy to clean.That said, it has limitations. It holds only a small amount of icing. I used it to fill 6 deviled egg halves (3 eggs total). The filling filled it about æ full. This is not going to frost a dozen cupcakes without refilling. Still, it's easy enough to fill that this isn't a major problem, but is worth noting. Given it's small chamber size, I would have liked to see a narrow writing tip, which seems like a no-brainer in a set like this. That would increase it's usefulness to this casual, once in a while baker. It's other design flaw is at the business end, where the chamber narrows to a cone shape. The plunger cannot push all of the icing/filling out of the chamber, leaving a couple of teaspoons behind. Other models only leave frosting in the tip, this leaves some in the chamber itself.Again, these are minor irritations, but given the price of the set, I can't give it 5 stars. For occasional bakers, who don't always like to decorate their baked goods, this is a nice, space-saving, easy-to-use decorating set. Serious bakers will be frustrated by it.The seller provided a sample for me to test and review. This is my honest opinion of the product.

The problem with hard plastic fashion cases is that they're often difficult to change out. Eventually, from repeated stress, the plastic weakens to such an extent that something breaks. But it's a fashion case, so changing it goes with the territory, right?GMYLE has taken another approach, adding a hinge with a buckle at the lower left corner of the case. This allows the case to be opened for easy removal or application. It's a bit tricky to get everything lined up if you're using the backing plate, but once you do, it all just snaps into place and the buckle holds securely. The decorative backing plate can be left off if you prefer a straight bumper case. This will also make it easier to attach and remove the case.I ordered the case in Metallic Champagne Gold and Dark grey and find the gold bumper a nice match to my gold iPhone 6. The backing plate in a dark grey scroll design offers some extra silicone-type grippiness in addition to being just plain elegant, a nice touch for any hard case.The seller provided a sample for review. The above words are my honest opinion.

This is the long-awaited companion to The Food Lab series of articles on Serious Eats. It is about 900 pages and contains 300 recipes. There are something like 1000 color photos. Much of the content is recycled from The Food Lab column, but it's organized in such a clear, common-sense fashion that I think it's worth your money and shelf space. Fans of the science presented by everyone from America's Test Kitchen to Harold McGee will enjoy it immensely.Pages are glossy white with clear, well-spaced type in a readable font, making it easy to use in the kitchen. it's bound in such a way that pages will lay flat when the book is opened. This is the way cookbooks should be presented, in my opinion.Part science tome, part cooking course and part recipe book, I think it's an excellent resource cookbook, the kind that builds confidence in new cooks, and perhaps teaches more experienced cooks a few new tricks. One place it especially shines is in the charts and technique discussions that are included within the relevant chapter, presented before the recipes. For example, in the discussion of eggs and omelets, we find advice on the best way to cut a bell pepper, a common add-in and the reason it's best to add salt before cooking eggs (and let them sit for 15 minutes!). Additionally, there's an entire series of photos showing the step-by-step of both American and French omelets along with charts of common omelet add-ins. Often, some of this information would either be missing entirely from the column, or we'd have to follow a link, taking us away from the main discussion. Some people will say "C'mon, everybody knows how to slice a pepper!" I presume that these cooks were born with the knowledge, and were slicing and dicing peppers before they could walk. For new cooks who aren't so genetically blessed and for those with less-than-stellar knife skills, it's a useful, practical demonstration. After watching Pepin and Child cook French omelets (high heat, 15 seconds), I've been struggling with them for some time, and look forward to giving Kenji's technique (low heat, then covered off the heat) a try.For pasta lovers (guilty!) Kenji gives us what he's calling the "Five Italian Mother Sauces" along with several variations on each. This section is reminiscent of Mark Bittman's How To Cook Everything. I'd compare The Food Lab to that epic volume as well as to Joy of Cooking. Although the latter books include thousands of recipes, they lack the technique illustrations Kenji offers and give us zero science. They're a set of instructions (recipes), while The Food Lab is a cooking course. They're also much harder to cook from, with ivory paper and small type that can be quite frustrating at times. I've often found myself squinting to read a recipe.For new cooks who want clear and concise instruction and for more experienced cooks who want to learn to get the same result, time after time, this is a great resource. It's also a must for anyone who wants to know WHY things should be done the way they are, complete with photos showing the differences in various amounts of an ingredient. For this science geek, I've been enjoying his column for several years and became seriously hooked when I read his column on the best way to boil eggs (steam them). My eggs have been consistently better and easier to peel ever since.As I mentioned above, some of the content is already available at Serious Eats, but much of it is new. And it's organization makes it, in my opinion, a terrific companion to or replacement for the Food Lab column.

This is the One Ring of hose nozzles. Legolas could have used the jet to blast Ringwraiths from the sky (no need to reload), Gandalf could have used it to knock the Balrog off the stone bridge in the Mines of Moria without needing to get near the beast, Frodo would have liked the mister to cool off on his sweaty climb up the slopes of Mt. Doom and best of all, it doesn't taste like fish (trust me), so Gollum wouldn't have been hanging around being such a general nuisance. Back in the Shire, Samwise might like the mister and soaker to keep the gardens at Bag End looking their best. Too bad Tolkien didn't know about it, it might not have taken him 4 books to tell his tale.The details:It's made of high quality materials with a soft molded ergonomic handle that fits well in the hand. It screws onto a hose easily and tightly, with not a single leak. The spray pattern dial is easy to move yet clicks into place. The handle also locks into place, greatly reducing hand stress while operating it.Here's how we've used it in some of the positions:Jet - cleaning cracks and seams in our concrete driveway and for cleaning our curbside trash bin. It has really high pressure to blast away dirt.Flat - to clean the stucco on the exterior walls of our house, to clean the driveway and for washing the car. Instead of just moving soap or dirt around as a jet-like directed spray does, it washes it off in sheets.Soaker - for getting water to the roots of plants. There's no more need to remove the nozzle, just select the soaker pattern, lock the handle into the open position and lay the nozzle in the bed. Try to remember to turn it off later. Setting a timer on your cell phone or in your kitchen will help with this. Not that I'd ever forget to turn the water off, but *he* might. Just saying, a timer is a good idea.Mister - for rinsing dirt off foliage. Turn the pressure at the hose bib to low and you'll be able to rinse even delicate leaves. Rinsing foliage allows more sunlight to penetrate to the leaf's photosynthetic factories (chloroplasts), increasing the plant's ability to turn sunlight into fuel for growth. It has the added benefit of making plants look better without a layer of dust muting the beauty of the leaves. Good for us, good for them.Shower - This one is good for general watering of plants and lawns, not too high pressure even with the hose bib faucet wide open.We haven't tried all of the spray patterns, but you're getting the idea. This a very versatile hose nozzle, performing more functions and performing them better than any other nozzle we've owned. And in some 35 years of home ownership in 8 homes across 4 states, we've purchased our share of hose nozzles. The Amzdeal is the best. That's just the plain truth. If only they'd introduced it in Tolkien's lifetime.The seller provided a sample for us to test and review. This review is my honest opinion.

This is really nice spice grinder for herbs like thyme, oregano and rosemary, anything woody and dry. Made of excellent tough aircraft grade aluminum, it's teeth align perfectly and are plenty sharp enough to do the job but won't cut your fingers. Nice trick, that. It made quick work of thyme and oregano, although some of the rosemary leaves were left whole. It captures dust in a lower screen. All the parts are very easy to clean, and the grinder itself is simplicity to use with a few twists of the lid.It is somewhat limited, not suited to fragile herbs like parsley, cilantro and basil. It bruised the leaves and left me with some pretty ragged pieces. The holes could be just a little smaller for my taste, but overall, it does a good job on woody herbs.The seller provided a sample for test and review. This review represents my honest opinion of the product.

If Wishes Were Husbands is a little bit modern-day fairy tale, a little bit comedy, and a little bit cautionary tale about single girls and tangled webs. Mostly though, it's a fun read with characters I'd like to share a drink with. I raced through it in a weekend, chuckling often, and just flat out enjoying the yarn. It's light, breezy and thoroughly enjoyable.Like all good fairy tales, it's got a damsel in distress, although her distress stems from being asked again and again (ad nauseum) when she's getting married. Her handsome prince shows up to rescue her (of course) and almost gets arrested for the effort. I know that's not how fairy tales are supposed to go, but this is a thoroughly modern fairy tale, deal with it. To say more would be to reveal too much, so I'll just recommend that if you enjoy modern romantic comedy and wish there were more magic in the world, If Wishes Were Husbands is right up your alley.

These molds work very well, turning out small tortilla bowls from 6-10 inch tortillas with ease and consistency. Within about 15 minutes at 375 degrees, I'm able to produce very good, crispy bowls from flour tortillas. Let them cool about 5 minutes. These molds produce better bowls than any of the kitchen hacks I've used in the past, like an inverted cupcake pan, or draping the tortillas over jars or bowls. They're also much easier to use. I get the best results when I preheat a baking sheet/baking stone as a base for the filled molds. This gives a crispier base.Using room temperature tortillas, the tortillas slip right into the molds perfectly. From the fridge, the tortillas should be warmed first. I use this fabulous tortilla warmer, which is superior to any other method I've used, by a wide margin. http://smile.amazon.com/MEXI-10004-Pepper-Tortilla-Warmer-12-Inch/dp/B00HWER1NG/ref=sr_1_3?s=home-garden&ie=UTF8&qid=1442509307&sr=1-3&keywords=tortilla+warmerI think for parties or lunches or for child-size portions, these are great. The base and volume are too small for use for a full-size taco salad. For a dinner, you'll want to order larger ones, as I intend to.

I've long used a knife or a mini food processor to mince herbs. I was a little surprised to find that these scissor do an excellent job at some herb cutting tasks. Although they won't cut herbs like parsley, cilantro or basil into a fine mince, they do an excellent job at turning small amounts into usable size (chopped) for many recipes, like tomato-basil bruschetta topping. Although I'll continue to use a knife to scrape and mince large amounts of parsley or cilantro, when I want to chop a little cilantro to add to our tacos (for 2 people) these will be the quickest, easiest way to get it.So they're not perfect for every herb-cutting task, but they do very well for some, like prepping small amounts of chopped herbs or slicing basil into a chiffonade. Do I need them? No, I've got some sharp knives that will do the job. But are they an easy-to-use, handy addition to my cutlery? You bet. And if your knives aren't kept really sharp or your knife skills are not the best (Hi, Mom!), they'll prove even more valuable to you.The seller provided a sample for review. This review represents my honest opinion of the product.
Great size, vivid colors, heavy fabric, very well made flag. It hangs well on our flagpole, right next to our Seahawks flag by the same maker.

I'm a big fan of extra screen protection, because let's face it, the glass is usually what breaks in a bad fall. I used to suck so badly at applying the old 1st generation plastic sheets that I'd have to ask my guy at the AT&T store to do it for me. Well, this glass from LaoHe is so easy to apply that I was able to pop it right on.The full kit comes with the glass and two cleaning cloths, one wet and one dry. The glass is encased in a padded foam envelope. The written instructions on the back of the box are clear and easy to follow. Clean your phone then position the glass over speaker. Carefully lower the top of the glass, then align the bottom circular cutout with the Home button. Drop it into place and watch as all the air is magically sucked out from between your phone and the LaoHe protector.The best thing about this glass, aside from it's ease of installation, is how it looks and feels. Touch capacitance is not affected at all, nor is your phone's appearance. All edges are smooth, not at all sharp or dangerous. At the current price of $7.99, that's a whole lot of bang for very little buck. If you have horrible memories of the way screen protectors used to be, impossible to apply cleanly, always with bubbles and easily scratched, you owe it to yourself to try this one. You won't regret it.**The seller provided a sample for test and review, but I have no prior relationship with them and no obligation beyond writing an honest review. My opinions are my own.

When we removed our over-the-range microwave-vent we needed a countertop model that still had good power. We use it almost daily to cook bacon or steam frozen vegetables. Also for popcorn. This cooks faster than any other microwave we've owned. We've had it for almost 2 years now and it's still doing very well. We paid about $79 for it.In summer, we steam corn in the husk for 3 minutes per ear and it's perfectly cooked. No need to soak it, just cut off the stem end, nuke it, then grab it by the tassel end and it slips cleanly out of the husk, leaving all the silk behind, leaving nothing but perfectly steamed corn on the cob, ready for eating.

We drink a lot of wine in my home, and at one time had over 1000 bottles in our cellar. As you can imagine, we've used almost every variety of bottle opener there is, from a simple corkscrew to the most innovative CO2 pressure models. Now I readily admit that I have almost zero skills with a classic waiter's corkscrew. My favorite opener for years was the 2-prong Butler's Friend. It was almost foolproof, but it took some strength and skill to use well. Since the introduction of the first "rabbit" style openers, I've never gone back to the Butler's Friend. A few years ago we bought our first lever-pull opener, very similar to the Peak Reserve. I loved it and haven't used anything else since. It's simply the easiest style of opener to use, bar none.Loving my all-stainless lever-pull as I do, I was a little uncertain that I'd like the Peak Reserve opener more. After all, my original is all stainless and bullet-proof. After quickly and easily opening a bottle last night, I fell hard for the Peak Reserve and banished my old stainless love to the back of the drawer. This opener has an easy-to-hold sueded grip. In addition, both the squeeze lever and the pull lever are beautiful brushed stainless, giving a softer, more elegant look and better grip than my bright stainless opener. The squeeze lever is substantial and wider than my old model, with a flare that provides a nice surface for squeezing the lever. The pull lever, used to lift the cork cleanly from the bottle, is also wider and flatter than on my old model. The cork on last night's bottle came out quickly and cleanly, as expected with a good quality lever-pull opener.To complete the picture of a quality item, the Peak Reserve opener comes in a very handsome black case, nestled deep in black felted foam shaped to fit the opener and the included 4-wheel foil cutter. This is tailor-made for elegant gifting to your wine-loving friends and family. Note to Peak Reserve - please consider softer foam, the opener is held so tightly it's almost too hard to remove it from it's case.If you're one of those fortunate folks who can open a bottle with a waiter's corkscrew in 5 seconds flat, good for you, but you should still consider the Peak Reserve because it's easier to use and faster, too. For the other 90% of wine lovers, this was made with you in mind. It's faster and easier than any butterfly or rabbit opener you've ever used and it's more comfortable to hold than the extra-heavy all-stainless lever pulls. I highly recommend it.**Peak Reserve provided a sample opener to me with no obligation.**

I was somewhat skeptical that this small battery pack would perform as well as the larger units I've tested before, but I needn't have worried, it performs every bit as well as it's much larger cousins. It charged in just a few hours, and then took my iPhone 6 from 6% power to full charge in less than 3 hours, using only about half it's charge, leaving enough power to do it all again before recharging the SuperPak. The MFI certified cable performed flawlessly, connecting easily and securely to all ports on the pack and on my iPhone.In appearance, it's very nice. At only about 1.5 inches wide by 3.5 inches long and .5 inches thick, it will fit into any pocket and will take up very minimal space in my luggage. It uses one cord to charge the battery pack and my phone, with a USB connector on one end and combined mini-USB/Lightning connector on the other. My white SuperPak is a dead match for my white iPhone and has a sueded finish that makes it easy on the eyes and easy to hang on to. One end has all the important bits, USB and mini-USB ports, along with the power button.To charge the battery, plug the USB connector into any charging device (I used a USB port on my MacBook Air) and plug the mini-USB connector into the battery. A series of 4 small lights will begin blinking to tell you it's charging and to monitor progress. When all 4 lights are solid, it's charged. To then charge your device, switch the USB connector to the battery pack and plug the mini-USB or Lightning tip into your device, push the round power button and watch the lights glow. That's it. Simple and direct.Given it's dead simple ease of use, small compact size and stylish appearance, this UnU SuperPak is my new favorite charger. I highly recommend it.**A sample (white) was provided by the seller, but I have no affiliation with them and made them no promises beyond leaving an honest review.

I've been a loyal Wine Away customer for almost 15 years. We lived near one or the other of the California and Washington wine regions for many years and over those years amassed a collection of 1000 bottles. I've no idea how much we drank. We've had to clean up a LOT of red wine spills. Wine Away is my cleaner of choice. A few weeks ago when my son his dear wife were visiting, she carried a glass of red into their bedroom. He bumped her elbow, wine went flying, and our 1-yr-old light brown carpet resembled a Jackson Pollack painting. I handed them the Wine Away and set them to work. The carpet looked brand new when they were done, with not a trace of stain remaining.Wine Away is fantastic on nylon carpets (100% effective on my many spills), tile grout, synthetic fabrics and some cottons. It is not always completely effective on white cotton, but I've never had more than a light pink or blue stain remain and a bleach pen took that out.Bottom line, if you have red wine in the house, you should also have Wine Away on hand. It's the best, especially on carpets.

Updated review: I initially left a glowing review, after my first use. The shampoo lathered well, the conditioner was easy to comb through in the shower and both rinsed out very easily. My hair was soft and easy to comb, not dry at all. I highly recommended this duo.  However, the 2nd and 3rd use were very different. My hair began to be more flyaway and prone to tangling. It was also more dry and brittle feeling. I shouldn't be surprised, as this is after all a clarifying shampoo and conditioner. But it is also advertised for all hair types.If you have dry hair, it's likely going to be fine for occasional use, if you feel you're getting some product buildup in your hair. Otherwise, stick to something that isn't so drying.**Sample provided for review**

This is one terrific little foil cutter. It ships in a very nice black gift box with a foam cradle to hold the cutter securely. The cutter itself has 4 sharp stainless steel cutting wheels and slips easily over any wine bottle. Last night we tested it on a 10-yr-old Andrew Murray Syrah (Santa Ynez) and found that it worked very well. Bottles from Andrew Murray are sort of an acid test for foil cutters because an extra ridge at the top of the neck, coupled with very thick pliable foil makes their bottles a challenge for ordinary cutters. We did need to give it 4-5 turns to cut completely through the foil, but this is nothing new for this label and more importantly, we did not need to apply much pressure on the cutter to do it. The thinner foils commonly found on most wine bottles will pose no challenges to this sharp, well designed cutter.As wine collectors, I can honestly say that we go through a lot of foil cutters and probably have at least 3 in our wine gadget drawer right now. This one is a fine addition and one I wouldn't hesitate to recommend or to give as a gift to friends and family.**Sample provided for review**

I've never replaced my own screen or digitizer, instead have always taken my phone to an authorized repair shop. Still, when DBPOWER offered to let me review this iPhone 6 screen digitizer, I had nothing to lose and perhaps much to learn.The digitizer appears to be identical to the original, although it's build quality may not be as high. Time will tell. Some of the tools are fairly cheaply made, and not up to making the replacement easier. The suggested video guide at https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=t6O-bGY_1dM is very clear and easy to follow. I'd have preferred to see written instructions included with the kit. I was happy to see that the replacement glass is already attached to the digitizer, saving that extra (and for me, scary) step.I waffled a bit between 3 and 4 stars, but in the end, had to go with 4 because of the very clear video instructions, which made the process less daunting. Bottom line, if you're comfortable making your own repairs, this kit may be a good option for you. For dolts like me, given the cost of this kit, a reputable repair shop may be the best bet.**Sample provided for review**

Love this book, it's got suggestions for hundreds of substitutions. Referring to it is much faster than going online to find just the right substitution for a recipe ingredient. This lives alongside my most-used cookbooks in my kitchen where I can easily grab it when I need it.

I bought this silicone ring to use as a second ring for my IP DUO-60 pressure cooker. I use the original ring for savory dishes, giving it a 24-hr vinegar soak about once a month. I use this ring for sweets like cheesecake and neutral foods like oatmeal when i want to make sure that no off odors get into the food. I don't mind swapping out the rings because it's so easy to do, taking about 30 seconds.Side note - I cooked 3 pounds of sliced russets for mashed potatoes a couple of nights ago using my 'savory food' ring and the ring emerged completely odor free while imparting no off odors to the potatoes. Who knew that potatoes were an odor remover?

I've had my IP for 3 months. In that time I've used it to make ribs, steel cut oats, my very first ever baked cheesecake (no cracking!), pulled pork (BBQ and Mexican), chile Colorado (wondrous), risotto (yes I did) and beef tips in gravy (so good). That's not all I've made in it, but it's a small sampling.Other reviewers have gone into great detail about it's features and functions. I'm more into telling you how it fits into my lifestyle. I'm an early retiree, living in Tampa, FL with my husband. Our son, DIL and their 4 young wolves live on the next block and we're often together on the weekends and even some weeknights. I'm a fairly accomplished home cook and cook most things from scratch because they taste better and take only a little longer. I'm all about making the process easier, faster and better. I also HATE standing over a hot stove for a long time. My Instant Pot works well, whether cooking for 2 as I usually do, or feeding the entire wolf pack (that's 8 of us when we're all together).I don't like to use my oven unless absolutely necessary. By far my most used appliance is my Breville Smart Oven (the big one). It keeps my kitchen much cooler year 'round. I consider slow cookers too hot to use indoors in summer, as running on low all day my kitchen still gets warm, even with a ceiling fan. My Instant Pot is a slow cooker, too, and it doesn't heat up my kitchen at all. It's just better insulated, but I've found that meals are so good under pressure that there's no need to use the slow cooker function. I keep meaning to, but speed always seems to prevail. I love that I can make roasts and other long-cooking things that we used to reserve for cooler months.One of my concerns was the ability to cook smaller cuts of meat and smaller volumes of other foods than the recipes indicate. I was assured by my friends at Chowhound.com that this was simple. For meats, I use the IP's rack or my steamer insert to elevate the meat above the liquid when I feel it's warranted. For other items, like rice, a pot-in-pot works well, with a heat-proof container placed on the IP rack. I use the same 1 cup of liquid in the bottom of the pot no matter whether I'm cooking one pound of meat or 4 pounds. I pushed it once with almost 5 pounds of cut-up beef and it was still perfect.This being my first pressure cooker, I had no idea how to use one, and specifically, I'm pretty clueless about cooking times because they're all over the charts, with many cookbooks (I'm looking at you, Great Big Pressure Cooker Cookbook with your 10 minute risotto) being no help at all. Or others which suggest we Increase the stovetop time by 30% for every recipe? Who thought that was the right way to go? Is it any wonder people shy away from these marvelous appliances? My best results have come from the recipes on Barbara Schieving's website, Pressurecookingtoday.com, and from the the timing charts in the back of the IP manual. Those are adapted for the IP from Laura Pazzaglia's charts at Hippressurecooking.com, another very valuable resource for ePCs. I've got 3 cookbooks for the pressure cooker. My favorite (so far) is the ATK book, Pressure Cooker Perfection. This book gets slammed by ePC cooks in the reviews, but using the timing charts mentioned above and comparing recipes to similar ones on Barbara's or Laura's website, my results have been flawless. I simply use the ATK recipe and make a timing note right in the cookbook. I like it so much because it's got a lot of my kind of food, simple, everyday, but well-seasoned and made from fresh ingredients. I've followed many recipes from Barbara's website and the ATK book (timing adjusted) to the letter and find them to be spot-on to the flavor profiles I love. With these resources at my disposal, I've quickly gained confidence.All the things I've made in it?  Chile Colorado. I served it cubed the first night, then shredded the leftovers for burritos.
