BEST BOOK I have ever read on reincarnation, simply because of all the PROOF. Doesn't involve hypnosis. Only the fact, ma'am. (I do believe in hypnosis, but not everyone does....this is more OBJECTIVE.)I found it an easy and thrilling, fascinating read. Couldn't put it down!Susan Schenck, award-winning author of The Live Food Factor, Beyond Broccoli, & Expats in Cuenca.

HIGH ART AND WISDOM ROLLED INTO ONEI have been interested in Sikhism for a long time and have read several books on the subject. But THE SINGING GURU is like no other book because it is entirely original in conception and imagination while being true to the spirit of Sikhism and its central messages. It is beautifully written, the engrossing and enchanting fiction brings alive the history, the characters are real and you can identify with their conflicts. I found such a kinship with the central character, Mardana, and his follies, and his so many relevant questions, which are answered by Guru Nanak. I have been waiting and searching for such a book on Sikhism and its founder for a long time. I am happy to have found it in THE SINGING GURU. The book is hard to put down. I read it in a few days.POSTSCRIPT: The world knows so little about Sikhism and this is an excellent introduction which allows the reader to see what a modern and relevant religion it is.Susan Schenck, award-winning author of The Live Food Factor, Beyond Broccoli, & Expats in Cuenca.

I love this jewelry hanger. It's so convenient! Things do not get tangled up as each necklace has its own pocket. You don't have to go hunting for things since the pockets are transparent. Just hang it in your closet. What a great concept!Susan Schenck, award-winning author of The Live Food Factor, Beyond Broccoli, and Expats in Cuenca.

I just LOVE this! Every single ingredient is organic, which is highly unusual. Not only does it contain the finest of ingredients, but it smells and feels exceptionally good.Susan Schenck, award-winning author of The Live Food Factor and Beyond Broccoli

Ayurvedic medicine has been around for five thousand years, standing the test of time. Yet parts of it have only recently gone mainstream. Practices such as oil pulling and gallbladder/liver cleanses have contributed to the health of millions while costing only pennies.This book is a comprehensive yet easy-to-read guide of ayurvedic medicine theory which really emphasizes balance. In other words, true health is not just about the body, but the body, mind, spirit, emotions, relationships, occupation, finances, etc. Real health involves all your life. As the author states, "It is my firm belief that most illness stems from us not living our life's purpose. Wehen we are living out of line with what we're supposed to be doing, our bodies feel it."The book includes 10 guidelines for eating awareness, an explanation for the three main body types (doshas) and their recommended diets and exercises, 12 guidelines for better sleep, a huge list of foods with their tastes (sweet, sour, salty, pungent, bitter, astringent), 10 tips for a better spiritual life, 12 traits of healthy relationships, four rules for compassionate communication, and much much more.Susan Schenck, award-winning author of The Live Food Factor and Beyond Broccoli

Hollywood really needs to make a comedy based on this book--something like the 1994 movie, On the Road to Wellville. Fat (especially saturated) became falsely vilified and it all began with one hardheaded man, Ancel Keys, Through a comedy of errors, everyone tried to fit the data to suit this theory,and when the government got on board, it became dogma. When a few voices cried that the emperor had no clothes, they were denied research grants. Food became politics. The whole situation got worse when saturated fats were replaced with toxic trans fats, and it would have been hilarious if so many senseless deaths hadn't followed.I knew about half the stuff in this book already from when I researched for my book Beyond Broccoli--nonetheless this was a very informative and entertaining read, full of surprises even for me. The author is a great sleuth.Susan Schenck, award-winning author of Beyond Broccoli

I am a health/diet author and educator. When people ask me what one simple thing they could do to be healthier, I never hesitate to reply, ‚ÄúGo gluten-free!‚Äù The simple fact is that humans are not granivores, and since the onset of agriculture, have lost six inches of height, on average, due to phytates of grains robbing our minerals. What‚Äôs worse, the human brain has shrunk 10%. I believe this is mostly due to consuming grains.Things are worse today: with wheat especially. Wheat has been so hybrid in the last 100 years that the body doesn‚Äôt recognize it as food. You may think that you are not wheat sensitive, but everyone is to some degree: especially since wheat in the USA is sprayed with the very toxic pesticide, Roundup Ready!This is a great e-book to have for fast, healthful and tasty gluten-free recipes. The recipes include breakfast, lunch, dinner and desserts.The recipes include color photos to inspire you to make the dish. Best of all, each recipe has the prep time, the number of servings, and nutritional data per serving (ie: number of calories, carbs, protein, and fat grams).Some of the recipes you find include rice noodles with sun-dried tomatoes, basil & parmesian; gluten free strawberry shortcake muffins; tomatoes stuffed with brown rice, mint and feta, and plenty more. I was glad to receive this in exchange for a review.Susan Schenck, author of The Live Food Factor and Beyond Broccoli does raw ketogenic food classes and health coaching. Another book of hers you might enjoy is Expats in Cuenca, Ecuador: The Magic & The Madness.

This book was a real labor of love to help people, inspired by the author's having lost his wife to cancer. Says Dr. Westman: "I have the nagging feeling that, if I had known in 2011 about the complementary therapies for conventional cancer treatment described in Chapter 11, Nancy would be living today."The book opens with conventional cancer treatment, and why the alleged "war on cancer" failed, and all the toxicity from conventional treatment and even the diagnostic procedures (such as mammograms and MRIs, which can actually CAUSE cancer!) It's all just a big money machine, (and finding the "cure" was never intended in my observation).In this book you will also learn the types of cancer, the stages of cancer, the history of cancer, and the culture of cancer. You will also learn about the various theories of what causes cancer.I found most interesting the suppressed information of Otto Warburg, who proved that cancer depends on an acidic environment, as well as glucose. Truly a diet rich in greens (alkaline) and very very low in carbs (ketogenic) is the route I would surely take if I got the disease that has killed most my family. Warburg concluded: "... the primary cause of cancer is the replacement of the respiration of oxygen in normal body cells by a fermentation of sugar."The author states: "It turns out that dramatically reducing the blood glucose that cancer cells so heavily rely upon both starved them and forces the body to generate new fuels from fat called ketones--a fuel source that cancer cells are unable to use ..." So, cut the carbs and starve the cancer cells! How simple is that?  Cancer is NOT the body's deficiency of chemo chemicals!This book is a great overview for those facing which direction to go with cancer treatment. I also like how each chapter is summarized at the end, so you don't have to read everything. Since it is obvious that the drug companies lost their "war on cancer" (though gained enormously in profits), I would go with the nutritional route.Susan Schenck, award-winning author of The Live Food Factor and Beyond Broccoli.

Definitely worth the money for this! It is convenient and easy to use, I took photos with an iPad without the lens and with it, to compare. I loved the ones with the lens more, as there was a wider view. This tool will give you a lot of fun and creativity!Susan Schenck, award-winning author of The Live Food Factor, Beyond Broccoli, and many other books

This is really great stuff especially since it is from food sources. This means it is more complete (as there may still be certain nutrients undiscovered as yet) and a whole lot more bioavailable.I especially like that some of the sources are superfoods like chlorophyll, wheat grass and spirulina. There is also acidophilus for gut bacteria and gota kola for energy.Synthetic vitamins are often filled with toxic fillers--they are mostly worthless. So I was glad to be given this for review!Susan Schenck, award-winning author of The Live Food Factor and Beyond Broccoli

I have read literally hundreds upon hundreds of spiritual books. I thought this would be "just another." Really, I underlined just about every other sentence!Move over Eckhard Tolle, Adyashanti, and all you teachers! Teal has a very lovely presence on youtube, and in this book she very articulately and succinctly tells you how to be blissful---which is really all we ever wanted! She discusses the law of attraction, how we help expand the universe with our desires and evolution, how bad emotions are our compass, how desire is NOT the root of unhappiness, ghosts, the practice of meditation and being present, why we should embrace the negativity in our lives, forgiveness, getting free from core beliefs and habits, and much, much more.It is really amazing that this old soul learned so many things at such a young age, things it took me 60 years to learn!

Definitely worth the money for this! It is convenient and easy to use, I took photos with an iPad without the lens and with it, to compare. I loved the ones with the lens more, as there was a wider view. This tool will give you a lot of fun and creativity!Susan Schenck, award-winning author of The Live Food Factor, Beyond Broccoli, and many other books

I have been using this for a couple of months on my under-eye area. At first it was hard to notice any difference. But now after using it awhile, I do notice that the fine lines and bags under my eyes have been significantly reduced. The ingredients are among the finest, for sure: plant stem cells, hyaluronic acid and Vitamin E. It feels good on the skin, and one thing I like about it is that I can even wear it in the daytime as it doesn't show up.This was given to me for review, and I am glad it was!Susan Schenck, award-winning author of The Live Food Factor and Beyond Broccoli and plenty of other books

I have read several books on how to market books, which includes getting reviews. As the top book seller in the world, hitting amazon is an absolute must. This book includes some tips I had never heard about. Reading this book will teach you the following: when even a five-star review hurts and even a one-star review can help; how to take control of the first reviews; where to find bloggers to review your book; how to correctly approach reviewers with an email (includes examples of poorly formulated letters and why they won't get a good response); how to set up a "newsroom" on your site which has all the book's publicity and reviews; what to tell your friends and family members so that they can write a good review ( not writing it like a high school book report); the importance of having feelings in your review; how to avoid "fake reviews" which are illegal as far as the FTC is concerned; how to make book signings work in modern times; how to handle bad reviews; the three biggest mistakes authors make when soliciting reviews; how to use social media in book promotion, and much more. I especially like the link to the Amazon top reviewers (10,000 of them!) And by the way, the book is so succinct that you can read it in one sitting!Disclosure: As a top reviewer myself, I was given this book for review, was glad to have it, and will incorporate some of these tips that were new to me.Susan Schenck, award-winning author of The Live Food Factor and Beyond Broccoli and plenty of other books

I loved this book and couldn't put it down. While I was writing Beyond Broccoli, I was in ketosis most the time. My brain was sooooo sharp that I was reading faster, and my mind could easily understand complex studies that I cited. The book's name means "clarity on the topic of keto" but it has a double entendre. It can also mean that your brain becomes VERY CLEAR when fed ketones! Unfortunately, I fell for the propoganda that this diet was meant to be only temporary.Now I have been on it again for about 6 weeks. I got some really good tips from the book that I hadn't known about, such as restricting protein. Another obstacle was coffee, which stimulates insulin. But now we have "bullet proof coffee" with butter or coconut or MCT oil. This prevents the insulin response!My energy is soaring, and my sleep is better than it has been in five years! I am sleeping deeper than ever. I was not overweight, but I have lost most my belly fat. For me, this is a DIET FOR LIFE. I am so excited about it, I got several of my friends to do it. I used to teach raw gourmet food classes, but now switched everyone over to a high raw keto diet!Jimmy, I am going to write another book on ketosis. Prepare to have me back on your show!Susan Schenck, award-winning author of The Live Food Factor  and also Beyond Broccoli: Creating a Biologically Balanced Diet when a Vegetarian Diet Doesn't Work

These taste AWESOME!But fortunately, these bars are fairly guilt-free treats. They are RAW, so include all the enzymes, making them easier to digest. They contain omega 3 fats, the really good kind, from chia seeds. They are mostly organic and contain superfoods such as maca (regulates hormones, increases testosterone), coconut (burns fat) and cinnamon (controls blood pressure). The bars are also kosher.Most important, in some ways, is that they do not contain GMOs, which are known to help cause cancer.If you are a raw food vegan, these are a real treat, and in my opinion are better than even Lara Bars.Susan Schenck, author of the two-time award-winning book, The Live Food Factor, as well as Beyond Broccoli

This stuff has great ingredients. Rose hip (Vitamin C), Vitamin E, and the 92 minerals from the ocean are great on the face. This makes the skin feel really great and clean and refreshed. . It does not contain the usual toxins that are bad for the skin.I enjoy many of the Oz skin products, but especially this one....Susan Schenck, author of the two-time award winning book, The Live Food Factor, as well as others, such as Beyond Broccoli

As the author of a couple of diet books and a life-long health enthusiast and foodie, I can attest to the  value of chocolate in one's diet. Yes, you heard that right: Chocolate is a super food, very high in nutrients. Some of the most long-lived people were chocoholics (including a French woman who lived to be 122, and a Mexican woman still alive at 125).What most people don't realize, though, is that to get the maximum benefit from chocolate, it must be DARK (at least 70% cacao, which is low in sugar) and RAW. This is not only because milk chocolate is high in sugar (which, as we know, is toxic), but also because when any food is heated, many nutrients are destroyed. That makes the Joyfuel cacao superior.Chocolate is also a mood-enhancer, an aphrodisiac (why given at Valentine's Day). Just don't eat it at night as the theobromine (similar to caffeine) might keep you awake. I use these nibs in recipes such as trail mix, chocolate chip ice cream, raw cookies, and more.Currently I am on a ketogenic diet, and since the nibs are 100% fat (the GOOD kind of fat), I can eat them to my heart's content.I live in Ecuador which is the source of much of the world's chocolate. Unfortunately, the best coffee and best chocolate is exported. So these nibs actually taste much better than the nibs here!Susan Schenck, author of The Live Food Factor and Beyond Broccoli does raw food classes and health coaching. Another book of hers you might enjoy is Expats in Cuenca, Ecuador: The Magic & The Madness.

The author is on a mission to wake everyone up about our Higher Selves. Note: that is only one of the 51 names he cites for our intuition, our inner guidance, that still small voice.He found that every culture and language describes this sixth sense. The author prefers the term "second side."He opens the book with three stunning examples of people whose lives were saved by following their intuitive guidance. One was a woman who, upon sensing that a man about to board her plane had very strong vibes, postponed her flight. It turned out that she dodged one of the 9-11 planes that was hijacked!This book is similar to Brain Weiss's classic, Through Time into Healing, in that he hypnotizes a woman and discovers an incredible esoteric secret--the inner guide we all have. He decided to contact his inner guid---and his life changed radically.What I found different from many intuition self-help books is that he personalizes the source of intuition. He encourages even giving a name to your Higher Self and engaging in dialogue with him/her/it. I have to say, I have tried this method many times while reading the book. I tend to misplace things, or not recall where I put them, and when I call upon this guidance, I usually find it within minutes!I like how the author explains how the second side works. It "isn't pushy or intrusive, and it doesn't take the lead in decision-making unless you initiate it first. Like a wise and faithful friend, our second side waits for a request for help." One exception, he claims, is a life-threatening situation, in which the second side gets bold (since keeping us alive is its main job). Most people, he says, don't ask questions, and when they do, they don't wait for the answers, not believing they have them inside. We are also very condescending towards children, who are much more in touch with their inner voice. He gives the startling example of a 16-year-old who invented something scientists had been trying to do for years.The books provides easy-to-do exercises to get in contact with your second side, including the pendulum method. Throughout the book he touts the benefits of doing so (including getting great advice, developing creativity, and finding the inner genius). He gives many examples from other people and himself as well. He even claims that being in touch with this higher guidance can be an all-the-time occurrence.Susan Schenck, author of The Live Food Factor and Beyond Broccoli does raw food classes and health coaching. Another book of hers you might enjoy is Expats in Cuenca, Ecuador: The Magic & The Madness.

I really really love this stuff! I only wish it were available in other shades, like coral. Finally there is a lipstick and lip liner I can totally trust. I think there is no excuse any more for all the toxins in cosmetics. Lead can lead to dementia-- a price not worth beauty!Susan Schenck, award-winning author of The Live Food Factor and Beyond Broccoli

I really really love this stuff! I only wish it were available in other shades, like coral. Finally there is a lipstick and lip liner I can totally trust. I think there is no excuse any more for all the toxins in cosmetics. Lead can lead to dementia-- a price not worth beauty!Susan Schenck, award-winning author of The Live Food Factor and Beyond Broccoli

I used this about a month as I got a review sample. I am not sure if this reduced my wrinkles or not. But it has made the  rosacea on my cheeks nearly vanish. The redness has greatly diminished!Susan Schenck, award-winning author of The Live Food Factor and Beyond Broccoli

I have a whole shelf of recovery books, and I can say this one definitely deserves five stars. It's revolutionary in several ways: the author challenges the concept that one should always identify as being an addict; he provides ways an atheist can deal with step 2 (believing in a greater power);  he feels that the 12 steps are a great spiritual path even for nonaddicts; and he goes  beyond simple recovery into finding  total freedom from desire for substances or any addictions--especially after he discovered kundalini yoga and meditation. I love his emphasis on nutrition and how he calls sugar the "gateway drug." He also discusses cleansing or detoxing the body with herbs and juices, which I believe are important for everyone's well being. He claims that the drugs we are really looking for are the "the infinite pharmacy within," referring to our endocrine system's workings to make us feel good.I have highlighted and underlined something on nearly every page of this book. The author includes his entire story--his childhood dysfunctional family and being a teen addict in New York City. Later he became a Deadhead (fan of the Grateful Dead) and had some spiritual insights.  After recovery, even when free from pot, liquor, and cocaine, he went on to have "the frequency of addiction" with sex and gambling. He even experienced the horror of having his sponsor relapse!This book is filled with so many original quotes that I can list only  my favorites here:  * A mother's food habits (and drug and alcohol consumption) will shape the future preferences of her child.  * Personal experience trumps all other information.  * I was not trying to have an experience; I was trying to recreate an experience. That is exactly what an addict seeks to do.  * I like to pray even though I don't know exactly what I'm praying to.  * Our suffering comes from an insistence that things be other than what they are. This is avoidable.  * I certainly have not given up getting high. I've had a massive overhaul in my methods of doing so... I have redefined, for myself, what it is to get "high"...  This book is not just for beginners. It can be used for people who have been in recovery for many years to inspire them to go further! I was happy to get a review copy.Susan Schenck, award-winning author of The Live Food Factor and Beyond Broccoli does raw food classes and health coaching. Another book of hers you might enjoy is Expats in Cuenca, Ecuador: The Magic & The Madness.

On the plus side, my male friend said my hair looked great, and this shampoo does have some nice herbal ingredients. But how can a shampoo claim to be detoxifying while it also contains toxic ingredients such as sodium laurel sulphate?I got this for a review, and was disappointed when I read the ingredients. Come on, Clairol, get with the times!Susan Schenck, award-winning author of The Live Food Factor and Beyond Broccoli

I inherited intestines that can get a bit lazy even though I eat more fiber than the vast majority of people in the USA. I can't eat any glutens or dairy at all, but nonetheless, constipation arises once or twice a month.I can vouch that these pills work to clean out the colon. I would only caution that one use this no more than 10 days in a row as at least one of the ingredients (senna leaf) can be addictive, and if abused may in some cases lead to liver or kidney issues.I love the idea of having coconut in a cleanse, as this is a real superfood and its fat content aids in weight loss. I intend to use this for occasional constipation.cSusan Schenck, award-winning author of The Live Food Factor and Beyond Broccoli

Dark chocolate is one of the foods with the highest (if not the highest) antioxidant level. It is the one sweet treat I indulge in almost daily. Some of the longest lived people on the planet were lovers of dark chocolate. (My criteria for "dark" is that it must be at least 70% cacao, or chocolate, and the higher the cacao, the lower the sugar.) Chocolate can also serve as an aphrodisiac which is why it has been traditionally given on Valentine's Day.The Funky Bars are very tasty. One thing I love about them is that they are only about an ounce. This means I don't have to exercise will power by eating, say, only a third of a three-ounce bar!Susan Schenck, award-winning author of The Live Food Factor and Beyond Broccoli

This money belt is very practical when traveling. It is RFID-proof s that thieves can't steal your credit card info. It has two main pockets for passports, cash, credit cards, etc. The larger pocket has additional pockets inside, so things can be very organized. The back side even has a pocket. Best of all, it has ventilation so the money belt doesn't cause excessive sweating -- an issue I've had with other money belts.I travel a lot through South America. In third world countries, pickpocketing is an issue. Sometimes a person watches people at ATM machines and go for the easy target. Having a money belt makes you a very difficult target--you feel really safe.Susan Schenck, award-winning author of several books, including Expats in Cuenca: The Magic and the Madness

There can be no doubt, this stuff tastes really decadent! Yet the ingredients are health-promoting.  I would just use caution with one of the sweeteners: erythritol. . I would suggest eating a teaspoon a day until you can see if it agrees with you.  High intakes of foods containing sugar alcohols can lead to abdominal gas and diarrhea, or in my case (less common) constipation. Some people can adapt to it if taken in moderate amounts.But the taste is flawless, and the ingredients are all very healthy, if your body agrees with erythritol. It is not only low carb, but high in protein.Susan Schenck, award-winning author of The Live Food Factor and Beyond Broccoli

This stuff tastes great! But as other reviewers have warned, the only ingredient that one must be weary of is erythritol. I would suggest eating a teaspoon a day until you can see if it agrees with you.  High intakes of foods containing sugar alcohols can lead to abdominal gas and diarrhea, or in my case (less common) constipation. Some people can adapt to it if taken in moderate amounts.But the taste is flawless, and the ingredients are all very healthy, if your body agrees with erythritol.Susan Schenck, award-winning author of The Live Food Factor and Beyond Broccoli

This backpack comes in very handy for carrying a laptop and other things. It's quite comfortable and has side pockets, inside pockets, and a back pocket. The only thing that could make this (and most backpacks) better would be ties in the front so a thief can't easily rip it off your back. (I spend a lot of time in South America where petty theft is a problem,)The shoulder pads make it very comfortable as well.Susan Schenck, award-winning author of The Live Food Factor and Beyond Broccoli.

I have used Nutiva oil for years so was happy to get this product for review. Coconut oil is the only safe plant oil for cooking, remaining stable at high temperatures and not turning into trans fat. The medium chain triglycerides make it ideal for weight loss. Besides, it tastes great! If you don't like the coconutty smell and flavor, this is minimized in the refined oil.Besides eating it, coconut oil can be used as a nontoxic sunscreen or sexual lubricant. It can be used as a facial moisturizer. I use it to make chocolate truffles.Susan Schenck, award-winning author of The Live Food Factor and Beyond Broccoli

What I love about this little turtle is that the instructions are so clear. In fact, pictures are used so you don't have to really even read the instructions. It tells you how long to leave it out according to how sunny or cloudy it is.There are three levels of brightness as well, though I am not convinced it is bright enough to read by, as the instructions imply. I left this out in the sun for 6 hours or so. I was so surprised to see the light work, as I had had no experience with solar power. It went on in the dark, and automatically off when it was light. I am not quite sure how the clip on top works. There is a switch on the bottom to turn it off or to keep it on autopilot.Susan Schenck, award-winning author of The Live Food Factor and Beyond Broccoli

When asked to review the Jolly Chef's high quality cheesecloth, I jumped at the chance.According to wiki, "Cheesecloth is available in at least seven different grades, from open to extra-fine weave. Grades are distinguished by the number of threads per inch in each direction." The grades vary from level 10 to level 90. So if you are straining something, this higher grade will do the job better than the lower grades.I make fermented foods so that my gut bacteria is 80% "good bacteria." This is for optimal immune system as well as weight control. Using this high grade cheesecloth helps me in making raw apple cider vinegar and kiefer.What I also enjoy about this cheesecloth is that it is unbleached --- no toxic bleaches are seeping into my food. It is also cotton, so no synthetic material contaminates my food. I have found through the decades that the fewer toxins my body is exposed to, the better health I enjoy.Susan Schenck, award-winning author of The Live Food Factor and  Beyond Broccoli

‚ÄúRadiant Rodney‚Äù strikes again with a fourth book, gracing us this time with brief essays downloaded from Source. These contemplations (generally about two-thirds a page each) can be read in any order, and include topics such as creativity, presence, thinking, intuition, emotions, nonattachment, genius, and even insomnia (which the author ‚Äúsuffers‚Äù from). They are intelligently and eloquently written, provoking pause, as usual for his writings.In spiritual circles there is a debate about desires: Do they continue after awakening? Do they ALL cause suffering, or only the ones that stem from lack or fear? Are desires ‚Äúbad‚Äù? Do they keep us from awakening? But aren‚Äôt desires what make the world go ‚Äòround?  I love how Rodney answers this question in one powerful sentence: ‚ÄúWith self-knowledge, you continue to have desires and inclinations‚Äîyou just are no longer attached to them.‚Äù Later in the book he confesses to have only two desires left: ‚ÄúApart from sex and Publix‚Äôs Black and White cookies, there are no real desires here.‚ÄùOver and over again in various creative ways, this master points us to the simplicity of the ultimate truth: that who we are is simply presence, awareness, eternal and unchanging. ‚ÄúThere is no awakening, no enlightenment, or no liberation. You are what you are and have always been, which is perpetual awareness.‚ÄùThank you, Rodney, for your eloquent simplicity. You go, guy!Susan Schenck, award-winning author of The Live Food Factor and Beyond Broccoli  and Expats in Cuenca, Ecuador: The Magic & The Madness.

Do you believe in a benevolent God/Universe/Source? Many people CLAIM they do, yet they still cling to the fear-based concepts of most religions, like ‚Äúman is a sinner in need of a savior‚Äù or ‚Äúhellfire and brimstone for eternity.‚Äù If you can read this book with an open mind, your fears will be dissolved and you can finally trust the Universe again, seeing the method behind the madness and logic behind the insanity of this planet.The book is well-written, upbeat, and often humorous (as in, ‚ÄúLeave the past for your biographers‚Äù). Each chapter ends with a fictitious letter written in cursive from someone who has passed. (I especially liked the one that begins, ‚ÄúLordy, I‚Äôve given up trying to talk‚Äîyou just keep ignoring me. So I‚Äôve decided to write.‚Äù)The book is filled with answers to questions that it took me literally four decades to figure out on my own. I would say I resonate with at least 99% of it: questions such as, why do we reincarnate if heaven is so great? How can reincarnation be true if there are so many alive today (ie: where‚Äôd the ‚Äúnew‚Äù souls come from?) How do we manifest? Do we ever reincarnate backwards in time? Do pets have life after death? Why does life seem so unfair?It is filled with author-original one-liners, such as:‚Ä¢ Withdraw the blame and forgiveness becomes a moot point.‚Ä¢ Everyone eventually learns whatever they came to learn and returns to love.‚Ä¢ Thinking the loss of a loved one was unfortunate, ill timed, sad, or an accident is to miss the gift.‚Ä¢ The only thing that people who succeed have in common is that they dreamed of their success.‚Ä¢ You are the face of God as it‚Äôs never before been seen.‚Ä¢ Your challenges are temporary while their lessons are eternal.Highly recommended, especially for the spiritual newbie or intermediate seeker!Susan Schenck, award-winning author of The Live Food Factor, Beyond Broccoli, Healing a Midlife Crisis on El Camino de Santiago, and Expats in Cuenca.

I travel a fair amount since I live in Ecuador. Often a tiny cosmetic or something goes missing. i feel much safer using this lock which only the TSA can open..Usually locks are a bit complicated to use and reset, for the technically challenged as myself. But I found the instructions for this lock to be surprisingly simple, if you follow the simple 3 steps with a visual prompt. Worked like a charm, and at the first attempt! Now I only have to worry about the TSA's sticky fingers, since they, too, have snatched a tiny thing or two!Susan Schenck, author of Expats in Cuenca, the Magic & the Madness; The Live Food Factor, The Quilotoa Loop, and Beyond Broccoli

I was given this product for review. The first time I used this, I didn't really notice anything.But then I started using it before my daily ritual of reading for an hour. I suddenly noticed I was reading much faster, and with a longer attention span. Usually I have to take a lot of breaks when I read, but this time I was more engaged.Then I recalled I had taken 3 of these pills. Why would this help me speed read, and actually enjoy a book that had been a bit boring to me previously? I believe the B vitamins help the nervous system and this includes the brain. The amino acid phenylalanine gives you that happy, romantic feeling. It is in dark chocolate, and it is believed to be why chocolates are given to lovers on Valentine's Day.Susan Schenck,award-winning author of The Live Food Factor and Beyond Broccoli

You can't go wrong with this product's money back guarantee. But why would you want to return it? It is easy to use, not demanding a strong grip like men have. It's stainless steel and dishwasher safe. It's easy to use and includes a little brush to get out that last little bit of pressed garlic! I just used it last night to make two Indian dishes, aloo gobi and chicken curry. Pressing the garlic enable the fresh garlic taste to be more evenly distributed.In addition to flavor, garlic has many medicinal properties, and some believe it was the use of garlic that enabled many to survive the Black Plague.Susan Schenck, award-winning author of The Live Food Factor and Beyond Broccoli

I was given this for review and impressed that it even came with a battery and a battery recharger, as well as a bicycle mount! I looked around and found it hard to find 100% cotton pajamas.....If found, they are usually very expensive. What a device! Seems like in our generation, people liked it when things got BIGGER. But in today's world, SMALL is the new BIG. People love small, portable gadgets. As a writer, if I interviewed people, I would carry a voice recorder just a bit bigger than a cell phone. Now all I need is this gadget, a bit smaller than a lipstick case.The recording is very clear and this gadget is handy for everything from recording Skype calls (with consent, of course), lectures, workshops, and interviews.Susan Schenck, award-winning author of The Live Food Factor and Beyond Broccoli

Chia seeds are a great superfood, and Nutrigold sure has a fine variety. What is so unique about chia seeds? First, they are one of the very few seeds that are 50% protein. Most are only 20%. While most seeds are high in Omega 6 fats, chia seeds are high in Omega 3 fats, which are good for the brain, heart, glowing skin, and reduction of belly fat.Chia seeds can be used in a myriad of ways. They can be put in smoothies, made into raw crackers (using a dehydrator), sprouted (remember the chia pets?), and baked into bread. If you put a tablespoon in water overnight, the seeds gel up and this drink is good for digestive disorders like constipation.Susan Schenck, award-winning author of The Live Food Factor and Beyond Broccoli

These sponges are excellent for cleansing the face, makeup removal, and  exfoliation. They are sturdy and can be used over and over again. The size is just perfect. The texture is a bit rough, but that assists in exfoliation or removal of dead skin, which helps with rejuvenation.Susan Schenck, award-winning author of The Live Food Factor: The Comprehensive Guide to the Ultimate Diet for Body, Mind, Spirit & PlanetandBeyond Broccoli, Creating a Biologically Balanced Diet When a Vegetarian Diet Doesn't Work

I have about two book cases filled with spiritual books that I have read over the decades. During the first 50 pages of this book I felt it would contain nothing new, but I read it as I wondered what all the fuss was about. Then as I read on, I learned that this book is an EXCELLENT how-to manual on how to become truly free from the mind, emotions, worries about anything and everything.Other books say "let go," but this one tells you HOW to let go. I really do wish I'd had it at the beginning of my spiritual journey--or at least during my last Dark Night of the Soul. It makes an excellent spiritual guide, and definitely a keeper!Susan Schenck, award-winning author of The Live Food Factor: The Comprehensive Guide to the Ultimate Diet for Body, Mind, Spirit & PlanetandBeyond Broccoli, Creating a Biologically Balanced Diet When a Vegetarian Diet Doesn't WorkandExpats in Cuenca, Ecuador: The Magic & the MadnessandHealing a Midlife Crisis on El Camino de SantiagoandThe Quilotoa Loop: Ecuador‚Äôs Hidden Treasure

I was a bit skeptical at first--not that the dog would reincarnate (I had read evidence of animal reincarnation), but that anyone would care so much about their pet coming back to them! Then I got to page 38, where the author makes a very strong case for the co-evolution of dogs and humans, which has occurred over the past 100,000 years. Dogs, she says, are the only animal that looks into our eyes the same way that humans do! I can't argue that fact. In fact, the author claims to have received 5 million hits when she put "dog reincarnation‚Äù into a search engine."There are people who say the death of an animal is less traumatic than the death of a human being. But love is love, and when you lose what you love more than anything else in the world, that loss is devastating,‚Äù states the author. She was so upset for months that she couldn‚Äôt even watch Lifetime for Women movies‚Äîthat made me laugh, as I just love those movies myself.But the author‚Äôs conviction that her beloved Bao, a Shih Tzu, would come back to her was strong. She even told people about it. ‚ÄúMy certainty that Bao was coming back to me wasn‚Äôt a delusion or a defense mechanism. It was as real as I am.‚Äù I love how the author cites Ian Stevenson, an MD who devoted his life to proving reincarnation, using the scientific method. She gives a few examples of his work in which children recall vivid details of a former life, and have them verified. I agree with the author that animals also reincarnate. Why would it be a privilege only for one species? She cites the tradition that ‚ÄúShih Tzus in particular have a tradition of returning to live out a second life with a beloved owner.‚ÄùThe book is very well written and includes an 8-week program of simple things you can do/feel/visualize in order to encourage your own pet to come back to you.Susan Schenck, award-winning author of The Live Food Factor: The Comprehensive Guide to the Ultimate Diet for Body, Mind, Spirit & PlanetandBeyond Broccoli, Creating a Biologically Balanced Diet When a Vegetarian Diet Doesn't WorkandExpats in Cuenca, Ecuador: The Magic & the MadnessandHealing a Midlife Crisis on El Camino de SantiagoandThe Quilotoa Loop: Ecuador‚Äôs Hidden Treasure

I was surprised at how good this tasted. I like to put a teaspoon in about 16 oz. of hot water, stirred it up, and drink it while reading. It makes my mind alert, but unlike coffee, it doesn't keep me awake at night if I have it after 3 PM. This is great as a source for antioxidants, too. But I love it as it gives me more energy, boosting my metabolism, while not making me edgy or increasing the insulin release the way coffee does.I received free or discounted product in exchange for providing an unbiased review.Susan Schenck, award-winning author of The Live Food Factor: The Comprehensive Guide to the Ultimate Diet for Body, Mind, Spirit & PlanetandBeyond Broccoli, Creating a Biologically Balanced Diet When a Vegetarian Diet Doesn't Work

The author of this book has the credentials of being a beauty editor and journalist. Diet is now becoming the beauty buzzword‚Äîgetting gorgeous from the inside to the outside. This book contains a lot of science though it is easy to understand for the layman, including genetic and nutritional research, as well as the latest dermatological findings.Part I includes ‚Äúbeauty betrayers,‚Äù a list of no-no foods such as alcohol, caffeine, dairy, fried foods, gluten, processed foods and more, as well as reasons to avoid them. We are also given the philosophy of nutritional beauty, as well as the building blocks of beauty with a list of vitamins, minerals, and other nutrients and how they work to make you pretty.Part II includes foods and spices to stock your kitchen with, and why they are important. There is also a chapter for each season which includes the foods to eat and recipes to use them in.Part III, ‚ÄúBeauty Beyond your Plate,‚Äù discusses the importance of proper food combining, optimal digestion, fermented foods, hormones, proper breathing, exercise, massage, sleep, stretching, and more.I have several books on eating for beauty, and this one is one of the most up-to-date and comprehensive.Susan Schenck, award-winning author of The Live Food Factor: The Comprehensive Guide to the Ultimate Diet for Body, Mind, Spirit & PlanetandBeyond Broccoli, Creating a Biologically Balanced Diet When a Vegetarian Diet Doesn't Work

The bands' length can't be adjusted, only the number of bands in use.  So this means the range of resistance is only limited ot that which is available at the fix distance between the handles.  While this may be perfectly fine for folks who are 6' and taller, for persons of shorter height, we don't get as large a range of resistance.Anyway just something to consider.  Overall though, it's a very well constructed product and it has an innovative mechanism for configuring how many bands you want to use.  It is  very easy and quick to change the configuration.  You just push up on band and unlatch both sides of the holes and then draw the band out..  To install it's the reverse.The amount of resistance offered with all three bands is incredible.  For a small person, one or two bands is more than enough for a good work out. If you are very muscular, 3 bands willl give you a very good workout.  You won't be disappoointed if your a large person.  Otherwise, YMMV.

I'm really liking Painter.  As a long time Photoshop user, I am actually quite impressed with Corel Painter.  I have used earlier versions eons ago, and have found it met only a niche market for digital painters.  Having gone back to it after so many years, I am very impressed at the massively expanded feature set.With Painter, I have been able to do everything I have been doing on Photoshop, however I admit I have not used Photoshop to it's fullest extent, and I am doubtful any user out there users every feature Photoshop has to offer.  But I would not go as far as call Photoshop a be-all-end-all solution.  Painter as many great digital painting features that Photoshop doesn't have, but it also has an extensive featureset for photomanipulation.I wont' go into too much detail as there are plenty of reviews here that do so, so I won't repeat them.  I will say that if you're like me, a person who primarily used Photoshop's most standard features for photo-retouching, Painter is perfectly great application for it as well.  It took very little time to acclimate myself to the basic navigation and brush controls.Don't get me wrong-- I still think Photoshop is never going to stop being the industry standard for recompositing, photography, and graphic design work, but Painter puts up a very good "fight" and I would bet you most seasoned photographers and graphic designers not looking for a very specific exclusive Photoshop-only feature will be perfectly comfortable with Painter.But what Painter excels at is what it has always been designed for--digital painting.  While I understand many digital painters do use Photoshop, I think it has more to do with market dominance than them actually having tried Painter and preferring Photoshop for that specific application.  If you are a digital artist, I highly recommend you give Painter a try.  You might never go back to Photoshop.

You don't know what you're missing until you start using the good stuff.  After just a few times using this vise, I realize how much time I wasted fiddling with the simple harbor freight drill press vise to get it in the exact position, and then locking it down with the bighorn vise clamp.  Jeez. This vise has made positioning my holes laughably simple.  Kind of want to kick myself for not doing a bit more research into what options there are.Given the sheer versatility of this vise, there is no reason anyone should ever settle for a fixed drill press vise.  If  you can't afford spending a few more dollars for this, just save up and get it.  This will pay for itself with the time and frustration you'll save repositioning that fixed drill press vise.  The x & y axis knobs are so nice.  The vise worked perfectly out of the box.  A great, high quality vise.  I have a couple of other YOST vises, and they are both excellent quality as well. YOST is a good brand I trust.  Anyone want my HF vise? lol

Okay, I listen to it again and was like, "Oh damn, it IS ET he's singing about!!!"  lolAnyway I love this song. Listened to it back in the 80s and it's such a nice throwback for an x-genner like me.  I listen to it every morning when I get ready for work.  Puts me in a great mood.

1:19 MinsI have a Apple silicone case installed on my iPhone 6S Plus and had no issues using this product with that  case.This will work with any iPhone case that has exposed bottom around the charge port that is at least 1 inch across.  The plug on the dock sits on a hinge which can tilt forward if needed to accommodate cases with different thicknesses.  The catch is if your case is thick, it might not slide right in. You'll have to use a finger to pull the plug forward, or tilt your device forward to line up the port with the plug, for it to go in.  In any case it's not a huge issue, and for a large majority of the folks which use thin cases, it's a non-issue.My biggest issue with this dock is that the cord is fixed permanently onto the dock.  If the cable is damaged, the entire dock has to be replaced.  I would have preferred it to accept any cable--that way you can use the exact length you need.  It's kind of silly they did that because Belkin makes a great line of MFi certified cables for the iPhone/iPad in different lengths and yet you can't use them with their own product..Anyway, overall, it's a nice looking stand and charging dock, and as long as you find a means to tuck away the excess cord, it'll look great.

I'll admit. I was turned off by the size of this thing.  About twice the large and 4 times heavier as my home made dust collector using an $80 Bostitch 8 gal shop vac paired with a 5 Gal bucket w/ woodcraft dust collection lid. Fortunately the footprint was the same, given this vertical setup over the side-by-side setup I had.  My DIY worked okay but now unjust laugh at it being so piddly underpowered by comparison to this Delta dust collector.I have been using this for an entire month now and I have completely ditched my DIY setup.  The Delta is such a pleasure to use. At first it felt like a luxury item in my workshop, as I was still convinced I would have gotten by just fine with my homemade setup.  But boy did it open my eyes.  Seriously effective dust collection left virtually no dust behind in and around my shopfox belt sander.  The power really does add up to exponentially better performance.  I am convinced now that it is not a luxury as it has become an essential part of my workshop equipment.Yes, the thing is very loud (87db to my iphone measurement), but not nearly as loud as the equipment I am using it with so its kind of a moot point.  I can see it being annoying but if you have smart switches on your power tools it is a non issue.  I have yet to fill the dust bag so I can't speak to how easy or mess free it will be.  But I promise to update my review once I do.  For now, I'm really loving this thing.The frame is very well built, with expert welds.  Not a single rattle or squeek to be heard.  Thanks to the wheels I was able to easily roll it around my workshop as I repeatedly changed where to best put it.Anyway I HIGHLY recommend this product to anyone that wants to step up to a legit powerful dust collection system, but this is is just as much a recommendation for those folks building out their workshop.  Save yourself the trouble and get the real deal, guys. I should have gotten this thing YEARS ago.  Would have saved me many hours of sweeping and wiping my equipment.

7:05 MinsQuick specs:Heater rating: 167F highest temperature setting (averaged temp), 470W, 120V 60HzMultiple modes (Fast, Raw, and Combination, and Continuous)Dimensions: 12.25"Wx14.5"Hx20"DTray dimensions: 10"x12-7/8"Headroom (distance between trays): 1"Total capacity (surface area): 1416.25 cubic inches (9.83 sqft)Maximum programmable time: 99 hours per mode, 120 hours max for continuousIMPRESSIONS:I love this unit. First of all, it's probably the nicest looking dehydrator I've seen and looks great as a permanent kitchen appliance.  But more importantly it performs great.On my test, I dehydrated 4.6lbs of beef round, cut into quarter-inch pieces, and still had two empty trays left over.  I think it would have easily handled 6lbs of meat.  The interface was intuitive and easy to use. I had no issues programming it.  The machine dried my jerky very quickly, in just under 4 hours.  The trays were surprisingly well constructed with clean welds and smoothly grinded edges, so the lack of sharp edges spared my sponges and steel wool pads when I cleaned them.  The bottom tray is a drip tray however I can swap it out with the extra drying tray provided.My jerky turned out perfect and was just awesome.  If I knew how easy it was to make beef jerky, I would have done this a long long time ago and not spend so much money on it!  If you eat lots of jerky, this thing will pay for itself in no time.Anyway, I hope this review has been helpful!

Feels like an average T.  The cut isn't ideal for showing off slim physiques.  But for the regular guy it's very comfy. Not tight, but not too loose either. Just right. It's a T-shirt for any occasion.The two tags in the neck are kind of big, so you'll want to cut them off for best comfort.Other than that, I had no issues comfort issues with interior seams or the 60% poly blend.

5:15 Mins First of all, let me say this isn't the watch for your average person. But if you like big watches, read on.This is a watch for the active person.  I chose this watch because it is something I can definitely use, worn on the outside of my ski gear.  It is definitley not something I could possibly wear on my bare wrist, and in fact most people won't because it is simply impractical.  Too large, too heavy, and really, it would look ridiculously arge (to most people) for anyone except maybe a person who is 6'5 250lbs, and even then it will appear quite large.This watch I could not pass up on. It is one of the most unique watches I've seen. Never ever saw a watch with a silicone wrapped case before.  It's bright blue and is very eye catching.  I think it definitely makes statement.  As a watch collector, I really enjoy owning a collection that is diverse and unique.  This is definitely going to be one that pops out of the lot.  Perhaps not the most valuable, but the most fun to handle and show people.BTW, the compression/conversion Amazon applies to video uploads is pretty aweful.  I have made the following video available at full resolution via my Amazon Photos library. You can view it here:https://www.amazon.com/clouddrive/share/12nemUNi9QBg35LEtpJyqOlVCFuS50KhBtWWq6RFwIy?v=grid&ref_=cd_ph_share_link_copy

I bought this for my espresso machine to ensure I use water with the proper TDS levels for the machine to operate correctly.  It turns out the sweet "bite" I get from my current filtration system was gone.  I can only describe the water as now being a bit flatter, more mellow, or neutral tasting.  I guess maybe that's what "good" water is supposed to taste like?  I didnt' like it much.  I gradually used less and less and realize my RO water worked perfectly fine in my espresso machine without any additive.  The electronic sensor doesn't need much mineral content at all (my RO filter's TDS is 20).But over all it's not a bad product. It didn't make the water taste bad. It does alter the flavor though, for better or worse will be entirely up to you.Instructions say 2-3 drops per glass of water, so to refill my espresso machines water reservoir, I needed about about 12-14 drops of this stuff.  This thing would have taken me a very long time to use all of.Now I just use it as a supplement since trace minerals are still important in one's diet.

I had a 64GB sandisk which suffered data loss when used in my Samsung Galaxy Note 2.  The data got corrupt and my pictures I had taken and apps I had moved onto the card were gone. So frustrating!  I called Sandisk and they sent me a replacement under warranty.  Unfortunately the EXACT same issue happened again with the damn replacement card 6 months later on my Galaxy Note 3.  OMFG I wanted to pull my hair out.Well, after that I bought this one instead and it's been over a year without issue.  I am now using it on my Galaxy Note 4 for the past 8 months or so and it has functioned flawlessly.I don't know what the deal is but all I know now is to avoid Sandisk memory cards in Samsung phones.This is not a knock against SanDisk-- I have owned several CF and MiniSD cards from SanDisk that performed perfectly fine in my DSLRs for many years. I dont' know what it is with their MicroSD cards or if it is some conspiracy with Samsung to destroy Sandisk cards. lolPlay it safe folks, just get a Samsung memory card for your Samsung device and they will play nicely together.

I have 6 espresso machines that run off a single GFCI breaker connected to a standard unswitched.  For some reason even though I never use more than 1 machine at a time, my GFCI breaker frequently trips, regardless of the machine I'm using.  I don't know why and have not narrowed down exactly which machine  was the culprit.  I did not want to buy a separate GFCI breaker for each machine as those things aren't cheap (at least not the good ones), and furthermore it would take multiple outlets to get them all plugged in (they aren't exactly small, they usually take up 2-3 spots on a single outlet).  So this was the perfect solution.  I now run all 6 machines on this, each with their own switch. So I just switch on the one I need and it is the only one being protected by the GFCI while the rest are essentially disconnected.  So if the GFCI does trip, I'll know exactly which machine caused it, but so far the GFCI no longer trips on ANY of the machines.  If any expert out there wants to unravel this mystery for me I'd love to understand this better.Anyway, no more ruined espresso shots by tripping the GFCI during the middle of pulling a shot.  I love this thing!

I was using a cheap pack of sand paper from harbor freight. gave me 15 sheets for the same price as this, and yet I went through all 15 sheets flattening my new Stanley handplane.  The HF stuff simply fell apart.  Frustrated, I decided to buy the "expensive" stuff and man oh man. I made more progress with a single sheet of this very high quality sand paper than I did with all 15 sheets of junk sand paper from Harbor Freight.It was a revealing lesson . Good sandpaper is indespensible and worth the extra money.

I found this tape extremely useful in quieting all sorts of things around the house. The drip tray rails on my espresso machine was rough and removing the tray always made an unnerving scraping sound.  I added a couple of strips to the rail and my oh my, so quiet! I did the same for all of my steel drawers in my tool shop.I opened my espresso machine and added a tiny sliver of this tape on microswitch lever bar and the scrapy metal-on-metal sound of the grouphead lever (it is a La Marzocc Linea Mini) completely went away.  Here's a photo of that application: http://i.imgur.com/RonsXnL.pngI love this stuff. Any tinkerer like myself will undoubtedly have endless uses for it.

2:44 Mins I chose this toy for a 4 year old (my niece) and while she loves it, I noticed she had a difficult time trying to get it to talk. Pushing didn't do it, but wrapping both her arms around and giving it a good strong squeeze finally got it to talk.  It's not a big deal as I'm sure she'll get stronger, but she is most certainly in the lower half of her growth percentile (I think? I don't have kids).It's a super cute and cuddly toy, with lots of fun details. The quality was well beyond most plush toys I have seen.  Anyway given the sound device is at the very center of the torso (the thickest part of the body), it can require a good amount of force to reach it through the batting material.  There was no way she could push on the torso to activate it.  Even for an adult it was noticeable. Also, when activating, the "tears" are candy-shaped glitter that shimmer inside the water-filled eyes.  The sound button is integrated with a pump bulb which forces a jet of water to agitate the "candy" in the eyes. The problem with this, though, is that unless the doll is squeezed hard and fast, the tears stay at the bottom of the eyes. I hope you can see what I mean in the video. It really does take some effort, and I think most kids ages 4 and 5 might not have enough strength to squeeze the doll with both hands.  And hugging it will prevent them from seeing the eyes, so it's a bit of a design flaw I think.As for the speech, they are cute phrases from the movie and not annoying loud like many toys (parents can be thankful of that!).  But unfortunately there aren't that many phrases--I think 5 or 6 different sayings/sound effects as far as I could tell.  Still it's fun for the kid and that's what matters.Anyway, overall a great gift for any kid who loves playing with plush dolls.  But again, just be aware that children in the lower (smaller) percentile might struggle to make Bing Bong talk. This was really the only real issue that you might have with it.

2:40 Mins Not much to say that the video hasn't shown already.  The glaze is really nice.This stoneware tray is perfect for hors d'oeuvres but is also suitable for entrees as well.  Did I mention how much I like the glaze?  Anyway the video doesn't show how heavy it is. It's thick and feels quite heavy, not the typical lightweight ceramic that is so prone to chipping and breaking.  The glaze is very thick which is going to add to it's resilience.  It weighs 2lbs 1.6oz.One thing I should mention-- while the p[ackaging was really great (as you saw in the video), the label was secured directly onto the tray with thick globs of rubber cement.  They didn't come off cleanly and will require you to use a solvent to remove completely (ie Goo-Gone). Gorham--if you're listening-- it's not necessary.  I would have easily seen the label if you just included it by laying it on top of the plate.Anyway I hope the video was helpful.If you want to see the details high resolution, go here:http://youtu.be/_7U_n3VKw58

As a relative beginner, I have started out my welding using a very cheap auto-darkening helmet (by Northern Tools).  I thought, "helmets are helmets", but having the opportunity to use a much higher-end helmet such as this one, I must say I am extremely impressed.  Not a single adjustment was needed during an entire session in the workshop.  I showed the helmet to some fellow artists and they all wanted to try it.  The helmets provided by the workshop weren't even auto-darkening, so I brought both helmets to loan my other one to one of the other students.Long story short, everyone took note of the brand and told me they were going to get one too.Here are some impressions I had while using the helmet:Pros:- Light yet high quality construction.- Excellent fit and comfort even after long session.- Separate modes for Grinding and Welding- Adaptive darkening offered superb clarity in all light levels at all times.- Wide viewing angleCons:- Costs several times more than other variable auto-darkening helmets.- Digital controls had a slight learning curve.

3:36 Mins I intend to give you a long-term report but I hope my video is at least helpful.  For now, here are some thoughts on the collar thus far:The collar feels about as heavy as most collars of this type, but still very light that doesn't cause any problems for the dog.  My dog is perfectly used to wearing them and this collar seemed uneventful for him.  The interface is quite easy to use (I figured it out without even havign to read the manual, although I did to ensure I understood exactly how it functions).  There are 0-9 modes.. 0 mode is training mode, and the other levels are the strength of the static.  Training mode is used when you are acclimating your dog to wearing the new device.  It only beeps and vibrates, in case the dog triggers it by accident.  Having lots of experience with collars, I've found that most of the time, it takes just beeping to train the dog.  But over time they get conditioned and will 'test' the device, when stronger correction might be needed. That's where the other modes, 1 thru 9 comes in. The higher the mode the stronger the shock. 1 is mild and 9 is described int he manual as "super strong".Unlike other collars that increase the correction strength, this one does not. This is actually a good thing.  I've owned past collars where the false positives cause the correction to be much stronger than it should, which punish the dog for no reason.  I much rather would have more control over the exact strength of the correction.  Lastly, there is a "Free bark" duration. It allows the dog to bark, and only after a certain time will kick in. This is the preferred logic. You never should try to shut your dog up completely (that would be cruel in my opinion).  But you do want to keep them from barking incessantly.Anyway I really like this collar, it feels well made and I look forward to giving you guys long term assessments every few months.UPDATE 10/20/2015:  So it's been a couple of months and Freddie and as expected Freddie is fully conditioned now to not bark when the collar is on.  In fact most of the time, I don't even need to turn it on.  As soon as I put it on he stops barking. Period  When my neighbors dogs act up, Freddie normally he barks like crazy at the door, but now the most he does is whine, which is still annoying but better than barking.  To stop his whining, I come over and console him, and move him away from the door where he hears the other dogs. Once he is reassured, he calms down and relaxes, but it takes effort.  But that's part of being a good owner.  I can't expect Freddie to improve if I don't also.

It's amazing how good this mouse is for only $10.  It track really well, and shuts off to conserve battery. So far it does not look like it's going to run out of juice any time soon, even though I've used it approximately 14 hours a day for over a week.  The button feel good with a precise click. No gummy feel like most cheap mice.There are no soft-touch paints used on this mouse,  so you can be certain in a few years it won't look like crud.  The button above the scroll wheel changes the DPI and it is plenty fast. There are I believe four or five modes;  I use the second one from the lowest  and it covers my entire screen within a 1-1.5" left-right tracking range.  The two plastic foot pads on the underside have alot of surface area and offer really smooth tracking on my laminate office cubical desk without any need for a mouse pad.Just overall an excellent mouse. And for only $10 bucks, I think you will be quite pleased with this purchase.  Cheap and good doesn't get any better than this.

UPDATE:  I marked this one star so I can capture your attention as a public notice to a hazard I (and a few other reviewers) have identified with this mat.I did not notice this before because this was in my garage however I decided to move it to my kitchen.  A few times my wife complained how slippery it was on her bare feet and I thought nothing of it, until I slipped on it and nearly hit busted my back.  Lesson: LISTEN TO YOUR WIFE! LOLThere is somethign about the surface of this mat that makes the bottom of your feet really slippery. An oil or something.  I first tried to remove it with an alcohol and soap water solution but it didn't go away once it dried.  Then used a bar of soap (Zest) on it  because I know that always leaves your skin kind of tacky.  After it dried it was a little better but within minutes it was back to being really slick.  I'm extremely disappointed in this.  While I still think it's usable so long as you wear shoes, it is quite dangerous to use with with your bare feet, especially if your feet are particularly dry.I honestly hope no one gets hurt slipping on this mat. So I just want to warn you guys of this if you're going to use it in the kitchen with bare feet to take caution.----------------------Amazingly this mat made big difference.  I am flat-footed and this mat has been a godsend folks like me.I found this mat to allow me to stand longer than my existing mats.  The mat is thicker and the upper layer is also firmer.  This extra weight and thickness of the material cups my feet better and allows me to stand longer while working at the bench.  Before I found myself shifting my feet around quite a bit because my previous mat would simply flatten as soon as I put all my weight down.  Memory foam feels good good but simply doesn't give me the support I need when standing for any significant amount of time.Anyway I also love that it is tapered to a fine edge, which seems keeps me from having to lift the mat when I'm sweeping up in the shop for debris that gets trapped underneath my previous mats.Overall, I'd say for what it is, it is quite excellent in both form and function.  I intend to buy more of them, one for each workstation I have in my workshop.

There's no cleaner showering than one that entails a full body exfoliation.My Korean girlfriend introduced me to this product, which is feels kind of like a scouring pad for the skin. It's not so rough it damages the skin but just enough to slough off the dead cells. It is something many asians use and is commonplace in public spas in asia.I like to use soap with this product however my wife uses it in the traditional way, which is without soap, after which she applies moisturizing lotion.  She says there's a satisfaction in seeing the dead skin is scoured off your body into rolleds she calls "noodles" .  I tried it and I admit it does tell you how dirty was and clean your body is when you're done.  I like to use it with soap because I'm just used my Zest smell, plus I don't get the unsightly noodles.  She says I don't do it that way I can't tell if I'm clean.  Fair enough, honey :)Anyway I HIGHLY recommend everyone buy the smaller "mittens" (which are just square pockets) for the body, and this one to scrub your back.
