I seem to have the same reaction to each of Angelopoulos' films; flawed genius. But in each film, what feels flawed and what feels masterful is different.Mild spoilers ahead...In this story of a 12 year old girl and her younger brother on a fruitless journey for their non- existent father in Germany what works is the ultimate emotional impact of the piece (it left me in tears), and (as always) the sheer poetic power of some of Angelopoulos' images.On the other hand, a key supporting character (the youthful actor Oresteis) is thinly written and exists basically as an overly-convenient plot point. Some of the dialogue and ideas feel heavy handed, and some images are lifted from other director's films. And the references to his own earlier film 'The Traveling Players' are an interesting, brave style choice, but also a bit distracting and intellectual. The young girl's acting is mostly terrific, but the young boy feels fake at times, which doesn't help.There are scenes I'll never forget. Maybe the most disturbing (yet completely hidden) rape scene I've ever seen. But other scenes feel awkward or forced.This is the kind of film that may grow on revisiting, and I certainly plan to see it again.If possible, get your hands on this now out-of-print 'New Star' DVD. The transfer was overseen by the director, and it blows away the New Yorker DVD.

So far I‚Äôve had no issues with these daubers, it was a cheap package that serves its function.  The one thing that may annoy some people is that I do not get a complete ‚Äúdaub‚Äù when using it on paper, rather a heavy inking in the middle and then some radiating outwards, almost like a bulls-eye.

This book is a tough read; I‚Äôm not going to lie. I spend a lot of time with textbooks and I have struggled a bit with it over time.  The main issue is that the religions are presented within one chapter, then the corresponding psychological theories are presented in the following chapter with theorists.  If these things were presented side by side, the format might be a bit easier to handle/read.  Otherwise, it is akin to reading a philosophy textbook where you have to keep stopping and drawing parallels with the information, taking good notes, and graphing on one‚Äôs own.  The content is great, but just know that it is on a big higher of a reading level. Chances are you‚Äôre reading this for class, so it is probably better to get the non-Kindle version so that you can annotate it as you read.

I purchased this for my mother; she seems to like it and I have purchased it a few times for her.  She let me know that it is a thinner lotion/moisturizer and it is one of her favorites to use.  It is my understanding that it is a bit thinner than Burt‚Äôs Bee‚Äôs, certainly thinner than L‚ÄôOccitane, and almost has an oily feel, but once rubbed in, causes no issue.  She‚Äôs about 70 and has a large number of liver spots on the skin and spends a significant amount of time in the sun. Although the tube is small, realistically speaking, it's cheaper than L'Occitane.

I really like this scale.  I have a Weight Watchers scale as well that cost a lot more than this scale.  I went ahead and weighed and measured a number of items side by side with this scale and found that it was almost spot on in terms of the accuracy of the weight.  This is a really easy scale to open, use, and figure out the functions.  Sometimes I can struggle with figuring out scales and gadgets, but this one was very intuitive to me to use.  That‚Äôs a huge plus.Another reviewer mentioned it, and I will mention it again, the only issue with the scale is going to be the surface/counter space it takes up.  The Weight Watchers scale I have has a bit less of a surface area, but this one is a bit bigger, as a result, you do have to be mindful of where to store it.  As Angela C mentioned in her review, it‚Äôs a lot easier to just put it on top of the fridge because you do not want to store anything on it or put it on its side.To wrap-up; it‚Äôs a really good and high quality scale.  Thinking about what this scale does in comparison to a scale that cost twice as much as it, I can‚Äôt complain.  If I have an issues with durability, I will let you know through an update.I was provided a coupon for this product in exchange for an unbiased review.

Right away I will say what the biggest con of this device is; it‚Äôs the AC ports.  Okay, now that that‚Äôs out of the way, this is an excellent product that I‚Äôm pretty in love with; it meets all the needs that I have with regards to providing the USB charging ports.  That‚Äôs really useful, and, honestly it‚Äôs the main function that a lot of the plugs are used for in my class room; charging cell phones.  So, this product gives space to do both of those things.  Man, but the AC ports, those are so annoying.  Figure that you can only use about half of them at any given time because of the spacing of the plugs.  I want to give this product five stars, I really do, but the spacing of the AC ports is problematic in getting optimal use out of this.  I‚Äôm also a huge fan of the 7 ft cable, as that is helpful as well.I was provided a coupon in exchange for an unbiased review of this product.

I‚Äôll be honest, when I put this case next to my other phone cases that I‚Äôve used and offered reviews on, this one seems to be the one that affords the least amount of protection.  It‚Äôs really thin, and really, I think it‚Äôs only usefulness is probably keeping your phone from getting scratched (the back side) in your pursue.  It‚Äôs clear, but at the same time, you can tell that it is on your phone.  Figure out what you want the purpose of your phone case to be and determine whether or not this will work for your needs.I was provided a coupon for an unbiased review of this product.

I received this transmitter in exchange for an unbiased review.  I admit, when I got it, I kind of stared at it for a bit trying to figure out how to use it.  However, when I broke it open and realized its functionality, I was able to get it up and running pretty quickly.  I‚Äôve mostly played with it using my cell phone and Amazon player to a Bose speaker I have.I also use Dragon Speak a lot and have a pair of Bluetooth microphones that I use with it.  I‚Äôve used it and have found that the distance for the microphones has increased significantly, as well as the distance to hear the microphones with audio playback.  However, there is degradation in the quality of how Dragon Speak reads my voice and there a lot more errors in the typing.  That was one of the main reasons why I wanted to play with this device.This serves the function with audio, but there is quality lost.  It somewhat serves the function with Dragon Speak, but it‚Äôs not really a good option for that product combination.I was provided a coupon in exchange for an unbiased review of this product.

I like door stoppers, I have a dog who acts like a teenager and slams doors.  I‚Äôve used a variety of door stoppers and often just go with the cheap rubber.  Sometimes my dog will eat those, so having this level of quality in a door stopper is both foreign and nice to me. This is a really solid door stop and does a great job of holding its location and works especially well for solid doors or those that may have a large rise.There‚Äôs just things that I don‚Äôt really get though‚Ä¶.mostly about the design.  The rubber portion is not adhered to the door stop itself, so it can easily become askew; mind arrived this way and I was able to push the rubber back into place, but if you‚Äôre someone who is bothered by unequal lines or the potential for them to get off, that is something to mention.  They especially go askew when you‚Äôre trying to un-prop it with your foot.  The other aspect is that the mental thing is kind of sharp; it‚Äôs the half-moon on the edge.  I bent mine up so it doesn‚Äôt just out as much as it does in the pictures, but rather faces straight up.  It‚Äôs handy in that you don‚Äôt have to bend down as far to get out the door stop, but at the same time, if you‚Äôre barefoot and not noticing it, it can whack/cut you pretty good ÔÉü personal experience.  There was blood.  It would be super, as a future improvement, possibly to put some rubber on that portion.It‚Äôs a really high quality door stopper and it is best for an office environment.  It has excellent traction, there are just a few issues that might need to be addressed in design.  I was provided a coupon in exchange for an unbiased review of this product.

I have fat hands and my hands fit in these without a problem.  ÔÉüif you‚Äôre like me and you care about that, I just wanted to give you that little bit in the review.  If you don‚Äôt have larger hands, these are still pretty functional because they won‚Äôt slide right off your hands. Oh wait, I actually just read information on these; they actually are designed not slip off your hands.  Humm, I could see that functionality.I‚Äôve enjoyed these gloves a whole lot.  I admit, I was a big skeptical about using them.  I first ran hot water and tried to determine if I could feel the ‚Äúheat‚Äù on my hands before braving an oven.  I realized that I was only feeling the pressure and not the heat itself, so moved onto the oven items.  I was really surprised, nothing.  I took out a tray of cookies and felt no heat on my hand; that‚Äôs pretty nice.  I mean, these do exactly what they say they are going to do.The only thing that should be noted is that they do not ‚Äúdisperse‚Äù heat.  So, when I went to take off the gloves, right after taking out the cookies, my gloves were very hot to the touch.  So, one needs to run them under water, or even wait a few seconds/minutes before taking off the gloves.  However, overall, bravo.  Pretty neat.I was provided a coupon in exchange for an unbiased review of this item.

I‚Äôve been very happy with this item. I admit, I haven‚Äôt really watched a lot of stuff with Leah Remini, I‚Äôm familiar with her from King of Queens, but that is about it.  My mother has indicated that she has been on a lot of the talk shows lately talking about this book.  I picked it up mostly for the insight into Scientology.  I was not disappointed, but in the process of learning a bit more about scientology, there were some really interesting insights into her childhood, as well as her experiences getting into show businesses.This is a very quick read and it starts off right away by jumping into the issue of Scientology, so, if that is the reason why you are picking up the book, I recommend it for that aspect.  I think that it is also useful to get the perspective of someone who is brought into Scientology through their family and it discusses how the appeal of the organization somewhat lured her mother into the organization and kept her persisting in it as an adult.  It‚Äôs actually a really good insight/manual into understanding psychological aspect of cults, even if it is unintentional, it provides a personal aspect to one‚Äôs reflection on the process.It actually kind of highlights an abusive relationship with the organization, one in which a person stays even when it‚Äôs clear it might not be the healthiest relationship.  Think riding a boat to the middle of nowhere and getting dumped in the water.  However, these things are told in personal narratives, which Leah at no point is trying to label or, but just tell a story.  At the same time, there are a lot of rewards that are highlighted for being a member of Scientology, especially in terms of networking within the Hollywood circles.It is also interesting to see how the fall-out and consequences for breaking with the church comes to light, in particular, Leah outlines her own humanity, pointing out areas in her life where she has messed up at the very start of the book, essentially expected to get sued by Scientology.  In reading about the processes of other people and herself, there seems to be a strong leaning towards lawsuits by Scientology (which, many are aware of).  Leah mostly keeps the story within the framework of her time directly in Scientology, with the final 10% (Kindle version) highlighting her time outside of the church and just how emotionally and socially devastating it was to her initially.Great read.  Especially for those who are interested in Scientology.  I think that the detail and first person account does a good job of at least tying it down to one person and their personal experiences.

I became a fan of RFID blocking sleeves after my sister had her credit card information stole multiple times while traveling to London.  It seemed that her cards were picked up in Heathrow pretty much as soon as she landed and by the time she‚Äôd check into the hotel there would already be charges on her card.I started getting in the habit of using RFID blocking because I had had a lot of my cards switched over to RFID/chips lately due to security elements with my cards.  I also have a card with an RFID that I use for access to my building at work.  I have had these card holders for about three weeks now and I‚Äôve been really satisfied.  First off, I have kept one in my flip wallet, which is relatively thin, and have had no problems with the durability of the RFID blocking card so far.  It has proven very durable, even after I have sat on it and pulled it in and out multiple times.  I guess my only argument might be a more neutral appearance in some of the covers.I have an access card for my office that requires the reader to use RFID to open the door.  I went through all the sleeves that were given me and tried to see if it blocked the signal.  Sure enough, it did.  In my mind, that‚Äôs proof positive it works.  Without the sleeve, the RFID can read on the door scanner through my wallet (meaning I fold it in and it‚Äôs on the other side and inside of it).  It was nice to see that the sleeve was able to block this signal, even though it is able to make short work of going through about an inch of wallet.I was given a coupon in exchange for an unbiased review for these products.

I‚Äôm in love with this item. Pro‚Äôs:-Solid feel-Design is functional/makes sense-Slightly raised lips helps protect the face/edges-Durable-Holds up when in heat/hot cars (doesn‚Äôt change shape)-Multiple colors (red is really vibrant)Con‚Äôs:-May make phone seem a bit bulkier-Medium weight-Some women may perceive as ‚Äúmasculine‚ÄùUAG cell phone cases really have been the gold standard that I compare all other cell phone cases against. As soon as I get done looking and playing with those cases for a few hours or a few days, I always go back to the UAG case, I just feel safer using it because of how sturdy it is and I‚Äôve seen it hold up already, like other times, I‚Äôve dropped my phone and accidently boot kicked it into a wall; no problems, phone held up great, no scratches or anything.The other thing that I love about this case is that it doesn‚Äôt change it shape in the heat. I‚Äôve been using the UAG case since the Note 5 came out and even when left in my car, no problems.The heat also leads to the other wonderful problem of me constantly sweating, so the grips on the case are a nice touch without me dropping the phone with my sweaty hands. All and all, a great product that I really recommend.Oh, I don‚Äôt keep my phones in my pocket, I put them on my waist, using my shorts or pants to hold up my phone. It‚Äôs not something to be proud of, but I‚Äôd been asked that once before‚Ä¶that‚Äôs why I come back to the UAG case because I feel a lot more secure knowing my case is going to help me out in this situation.

I wanted to love these, you really have no idea how badly I just wanted them to work.  We have two rugs in our house, on the tile floor, both of which we ourselves and the dogs go surfing across the kitchen floor because of their inability to stay in one place.  As another reviewer noted, there was some difficulty in understanding the instructions.Initially we adhered these to the floor and there was no issue, the carpets stuck and we thought that all of our problems/troubles were over in the world.  Then after a few hours, they ceased to hold the carpet anymore.  The adhesive portion worked well and stuck to the floor, but it just didn‚Äôt hold the carpets anymore.  What we realized, so it could entirely be our issue, is that these attracted dog hair, lots and lots of dog hair, so that when our carpets, which had dog hair, were placed on these, it made is so that it was difficult to maintain a bond because they then sucked up all the dog hair.I do also have to push back about not leaving a sticky residue.  Perhaps we installed it incorrectly, but all of them left a stick residue on our floor.  We were able to get it up, we have a Bissel steam mop, so going over it a few times with that got it up, but there was certainly some marks left behind, but again, they came up with cleaning, but it wasn‚Äôt a fell swoop and it was gone clean-up.One thing that was kind of neat though is that they would go back to their shape if you pulled them up or the carpet pulled them in a different direction.  So, our carpet was moving around, but you can see how it would hold down corners very well because if for some reason it was bunched up, or a corner folded over on its self, then it resume its original shape.Overall, they make sense and I can see them working.  However, not if you have dogs that shed a lot (we have three shedders).  Since we had dog hair already on the carpets, that‚Äôs my guess as to why it probably did not work as well as it could have.  Also, it did leave some residue on our tile where we adhered it.  I was able to get it up, but it required some persistence.

I received this bottle a few days ago and I have been playing around with it; I admit, I was initially scared of it because of the fancy packaging and the fact that it said ‚Äúfragile on it.‚Äù However, it is wrapped very well and it‚Äôs just a reminder not to launch the product across the counter.  It‚Äôs sturdy and well made.  I actually received the coral pink coral bottle and the Breast Cancer Research Foundation versions with a coupon for an unbiased review.  It‚Äôs one of those days where snazzy things have come my way and I‚Äôm happier for it.  I‚Äôm going to review both of these products in one review so you can choose which one is right for you.Both of these bottles have an infuser in them.  I washed them both by hand, then a day later shoved them in the washer machine.  I put the plastic parts on the top level of the dishwasher and did not have any issues with them.  None, there was no discoloration and on the coral pink version, there was no issue with the plastic stretching out on the bottom of the bottle.  On the Breast Cancer Research as well, the plastic cord/handle had no issues.  They both held up very well, which made me very happy.The infuser is nice, keep in mind it has the slats on it to allow for the taste to infuse the bottle.  If you have something that may have seeds, it will still get into the drink, but it prevents the cucumber slices or lime from floating up and blocking the drinking hole.  Which, if you‚Äôve used a bottle before and put slices in it, tends to be the number one problem.  The way that the bottle narrows allows whatever you put in it to stay towards the bottom of the drink.I really was skeptical that it held 17oz‚Äôs, but it does, even with cucumber or something else in it.  The measurement does take into account the infuser in the bottle, as well as the putting in a fruit that may take up minimal space.  I used a measuring cup to see how much water it actually took.Overall, they‚Äôre great products that are very high quality and are very well made.  The main distinction between the Breast Cancer Research version and the Pink Coral is that the Pink Coral has some rubber along the bottom that makes it a bit smoother when one puts it down on a counter or glass table top.  Both of them are high quality thick glass, which I did kick over on more than one occasion and there were no chips or scratches; think Pyrex type glass.  It does not contain head or cool, so if you‚Äôre in the south, the bottle will sweat, BUT the rubber handle is a nice edition that can help deal with some of this issue by allowing a grip that is dry (great thinking there).

Honestly, the book is exactly what you think it‚Äôs going to be, and, it‚Äôs still good.  It‚Äôs actually, really good, with a high readability and passes the time quickly.I will be upfront; I‚Äôve never seen a Nicholas Sparks movie, nor read a Nicholas Sparks book before; I‚Äôve been doing my best to read a variety of books this year and changed genres.  This was a pleasant read, quick, and moved fairly fast.  I‚Äôm not much of a romance type of person, but even as someone who‚Äôs not into guys, the main protagonist Colin, was kind of dreamy.  No, really, he actually was really dreamy.  As a bad boy, MMA fighter, turned good, I thought that the character was a bit over played out in the initial chapters, but as it progressed, I found that he maintained likability and still kept my attention.A piece of me wanted to dislike the whole story; knowing that it was hitting on many of the romantic elements that I had stereotyped all of Nicholas Sparks books to be, but‚Ä¶it was good.  Really good.  Even the stereotypical family friend, with a fianc√©, who embraces the bad boy, who said bad boy has a soft spot for, and vows that now harm will come to them, even they were perfectly written, well developed, and offered humor to the story in very genuine and sweet ways.  I laughed out loud at them‚Ä¶I don‚Äôt do that, but they were so cute and added a dimension to the character of Colin.The female protagonist is well developed with some levels of depth that creates a significant amount of buy-in from the reader.  I found myself rooting for her, and was happy with all of her resolutions that occurred in ways that support her character and kept rather true to who she was throughout the book.  Maria has some fleeting encounters with sexual harassment, which comes up right away in the story.  Sparks actually does a good job of mirroring oft-occurring responses, and does so in a really good way that stays away from self-blame, but also frames the emotional discomfort that (unfortunately) many women have felt in some work situations.Maria‚Äôs story is one that plays into the ‚Äúthriller‚Äù aspect of the story, but, the book isn‚Äôt a ‚Äúthriller,‚Äù it‚Äôs more like, a plot dimension with some action? I mean, it‚Äôs not really a thriller, there is foreshadowing very early on that gives background context to Maria‚Äôs past employment as a city prosecutor and some disgruntled individuals due to her work.  I‚Äôm not really giving anything away, but the reader gets a ‚Äúpool‚Äù of two/three individuals who are affiliated with the same case.  Since the case is so far removed and buy-in to the persons affiliated with the case is minimal, in my opinion, it was more so a matter of, ‚ÄúWell‚Ä¶it‚Äôs one of them‚Äù without really needing a distinction of who it was; as they all were a blur associated with the same issue.  However, the thriller aspects lets us spend more time with Colin making himself a bit dreamier and developing as a person.If I had only one piece of criticism; Colin is an MMA fighter, and it‚Äôs initially very central to his figure.  However, I actually watch and follow a lot of MMA, and there is a disconnect between some of the training components and what Colin is doing.  I had given up some hope that Nicholas Sparks really knew anything about MMA, but then he made a comment about an amateur fight sometimes getting a bit more brawl-like, which made me happy, as it‚Äôs true, but the relationships between fights and coaches and even training partners are really strong; so that aspect maybe a bit under played.  Again, that‚Äôs just me, having that familiarity.  I still liked it a lot.

I read this book; one thing that I agree with 100% is that there are a lot of elements/questions that come up when someone starts a business.  I run my own company and found myself exploring things that I thought I‚Äôd never have to deal with, especially small random things.Pro‚Äôs:I like the concept of the book, it‚Äôs good for someone who has minimal experience, comfort finding things for themselves on the web.There are lists of things that someone who is in a business or too busy to look around and stumble across may absolutely love.It‚Äôs broken up into logical sections so there is some level of ease in finding elements for the book.Con‚Äôs:Typically only one or two suggestions on options; they are more generic, often focus on Google products; which isn‚Äôt bad, but tends to be the easiest that a person can find on their own.Just lists a site, with a link, so you‚Äôre able to go their easily, but it would be nice if there was maybe a heads up if it is a pay site, or if you have to pay for the service that is being offered.It‚Äôd also be nice if there maybe a pro/con or ranking of the different items on the sites that are under specific topics.If you‚Äôre a novice person on the web, this is a great book, it has a lot of things that you may not have thought about before.  If you have a bit of familiarity that is a little bit stronger, you might want to get the book while it‚Äôs free or discounted (depending on the Amazon plan), but if it‚Äôs a little bit steeper in price, you may want to forgo it for something more comprehensive or your own Googling skills.  Overall it‚Äôs a great premise, it just has different uses for different audiences.

I‚Äôm a huge Rick Riordan fan and I‚Äôve been waiting for this book for a while, those who have been waiting as well won‚Äôt be disappointed.  I‚Äôm personally impressed; I know that the structure of the story is going to be similar to others of Riordan, but even with the structure similar, it‚Äôs still a page turner, but this time in the context of Norse mythology.  It initially appears to be a long book, but, it is an easy read that goes fast; I didn‚Äôt want to put it down and read it in one night.For those who are not familiar with Rick Riordan‚Äôs writings, this is a perfectly fine book to jump into Riordan‚Äôs fantasy world, there is no benefit gained in having read his other books that deal with heroes from Greek, Roman, or Egyptian mythology.  The characters stand alone in their identities and are all affiliated with Norse mythology.  The protagonist, Magnus, is quickly discovered in the story to have a background not quite like others, more so in his parenting and lineage; his father is a Norse god.  As a result of this lineage, there are obligations that Magnus is thrust with, and the story is a modern day interaction of Magnus through components of Norse mythology, ranging from characters to weaponry of the ancient belief system.  The story is told with humor, but also does a great job in outlining and establishing some of the belief systems of Norse mythology, such as the pantheon of the gods and goddesses.The characters have a different personality, much like those we meet out of Camp Jupiter vs. Camp Half Blood.  The story takes place in Norse mythology, which I personally do not have as strong of a familiarity with, and allowed for a new sense of novelty in the story that has the format of hero discovered, hero goes to ‚Äúcamp,‚Äù and hero goes on quest. The introduction of the new characters was nice and it created a sense of anticipation about who maybe a bit more friendly than others.  Overall, the relationship with the gods themselves is a bit more casual, even if the society itself is more regimented.A discussion board commenter alluded to the possibility of a relationship between these books and that with Camp Half-Blood, from the start of the book there is a pleasant surprise in that Magnus does have a cousin who attends Camp Half-Blood, but rather than long-term interaction with him/her, there is just a brief reference too at both the beginning and the end of the story.It‚Äôs a hard story to talk about because of the potential to give so much away about who is related to who, and familiarity with some of the Norse gods would reveal some of the plot elements.  However, a unique aspect of the Norse mythology is that the fates of the gods are much clearer, with a level of clarity and absolutism in the roles that each one knows that he/she plays, even in the final battle (Ragnok ÔÉü which isn‚Äôt the final battle in this book).Know that the structure is similar to the books in the past, the characters who are introduced throughout this book are unique in their own ways, especially Magnus‚Äôs new companions and, I especially enjoyed the history and sense of honor associated with the Valkyrie corps, especially Samirah al-Abbas, who identifies from a Muslim family.Anyway, enjoy a way!  I have some Norse mythology to learn about now that I‚Äôm curious.

Yes; this tape has been amazing.  It's held up wonderfully, even with above-average use.I used this product to wrap a cardboard cutout of the Tardis (Doctor Who's traveling device.)
