My son didn't like any of the Avent bottle nipples, but since all of our other kids started out using Avent sippy cups, we figured we'd give this trainer cup a shot.  I was expecting the spout on this one to be the same as the spout on the Avent classic+ trainer cup, but the shape is actually a bit different.  I think this one is a better shape for transitioning the baby to a regular hard spout sippy cup.  The handles on this cup are nicer than the handles on the Avent Classic+ trainer.  The downside to the natural trainer cup is the handles are not detachable (even though the description says they are).  Because the handles can't be removed, putting this cup in a bottle pouch in your diaper bag and even most stroller cup holders is going to be a challenge if not altogether impossible.  The cup is compatible with the My Penguin sippy cups so you can swap the pieces.

I've tried other Seventh Generations diapers in the past with one of my older children and while I thought they were ok, I didn't think they were great.  The Touch of Cloth Diapers are a lot nicer than the other ones that had the crinkly tea stained colored outside.  I really like that the touch of cloth diapers are completely off white and have absolutely no designs on them.  The loud cartoon designs are what I like the least about the Pampers that we usually buy for our baby.  At first, I thought that the diaper might not offer as good of a fit as the Pampers Cruisers and Swaddlers we've been using, but I was surprised at how these fit our son much better.  We were already finding that the size 3 Pampers weren't fitting him as well as we would like at just 20lbs, so we had just bumped him up to size 4.  The size 3 Seventh Generation seem like they have a more generous fit than the Pampers and he looks like he will easily be able to remain in size 3 for at least a few more months.We haven't experienced any leaks with these diapers since we started using them.  They were even great for overnight.I really like these diapers and I also like that they're a bit more environmentally friendly than the disposables we typically use.

The powdered formula dispenser is useful for more than just formula.  It doubles as a nice snack dispenser, too.  The three section insert is removable so you can fill the cup up with just one type of snack, or you can leave the divided insert in the cup and have three different snacks in there.  Items like Cheerios, Gerber puffs, and Goldfish crackers will all easily dispense from the snap shut opening on the lid.  I prefer this container for dispensing snacks over the snack trap cups because my little ones always figure out how to get all the contents to spill out of those snack trap containers after the first day or two of using it.  With this container, the opening is so small that even if your child turns it over with the lid open, you won't have all of the snack on the floor like you will with those other snack containers.

Of the different Avent gift sets that are available, I think this is the one that gives you the best value and variety.  The set has everything you find in the newborn starter set, plus the microwave steam sterilizer.  I have had one of these steam sterilizers with all four of my kids.  While I know there are plenty of people who will say you don't "need" a bottle sterilizer, it is nice to have.  It's quicker than boiling the bottles, pacifiers and pump parts in a pot of water, so for me, the convenience factor of the sterilizer makes it an essential item.This Avent infant starter set will give you a nice variety of what the Avent Classic+ line of products has to offer.  The set includes three 4oz bottles with stage 1 newborn nipples, two 9oz bottles with stage 2 slow flow nipples. Using the included soft spout sippy insert and trainer handles, you can easily convert a 4oz bottle into a training sippy cup.  The starter set also includes a powdered formula dispenser with removable divider, a newborn pacifier and a bottle brush.I've used Avent bottles for all four of my children, although my youngest baby isn't exactly the biggest fan of them and seems to prefer the Medela bottles over Avent.  The Classic+ bottles have one less piece to clean than the previous version of the Avent Classic bottle (In the 13 1/2 years that we've been using Avent bottles, they've come out with a few different versions.).  The Classic+ reminds me of the original Avent bottle minus the BPA.  The skirt of the nipple on the Classic+ is different from the old Classic design.  Avent says you can use the older style nipples with this bottle, but they recommend the Classic+ for this bottle.  The bottle brush that is included with this set is one of the best.  I tried many bottle brushes with my older children and this was my favorite hands down.  The pacifier is one that my children never particularly liked (our preference is Mam).  While my children never took to the Avent pacifiers, I did like that they come with a nice snap on cover to keep the nipple clean while it's in your diaper bag or purse.  It's a nice touch.  The soft silicone sippy spout is good for a baby who is just starting out with a cup, but I have found that the spout will leak.  It's essentially a flattened out nipple with a slit instead of holes so liquids will flow quickly through this spout.  The trainer handles are another accessory that never particularly impressed me.  My children never cared to use them, and I saw them as just another part to wash.  The handles make slipping the cup into a diaper bag bottle pouch difficult or near impossible.The powdered formula dispenser is useful for more than just formula.  It doubles as a nice snack dispenser, too.  The three section insert is removable so you can fill the cup up with just one type of snack, or you can leave the divided insert in the cup and have three different snacks in there.  Items like Cheerios, Gerber puffs, and Goldfish crackers will all easily dispense from the snap shut opening on the lid.Of the different gift sets offered by Avent, this one is my favorite because it includes the steam sterilizer.

These cups are cute, but they're not the easiest cups to drink from.  If the cup has less than three ounces of liquid in it, the baby has to tilt his head back pretty far to get anything out of it.  The cup has soft grip handles which feel a lot nicer than the handles on the Avent soft spout trainer cups.  A drawback to this cup is the handles can't be removed.  Because of the handles, you can't fit this cup in a bottle pocket in a diaper bag.  The cup comes with a snap on lid to keep the spout clean.  I would be hesitant to use this cup with milk because of the deep tiny crevices in the lid around the spout.  There's really no way to get into those spaces and clean them out well.

These breast milk storage cups are pretty nice.  They have twist on lids and can hold up to six ounces of breastmilk.  The set comes with two adaptors so you can hook it up to an Avent pump, or if you're using another brand of pump, you can use the Avent pump adaptor and hook that up to the adaptor for the storage container. I found doing that to be overkill since you wind up with a bunch of extra pieces to wash.  So I just pour out the standard bottle I use with my pump into the storage container.  If you use Avent bottles, you can use the adaptor and feed your child using either the classic or natural bottle tops.  So this storage system is pretty convenient if you use Avent bottles.  These containers are also nice for storing home made baby foods.  The screw on tops mean they won't pop open in transit.

The soft silicone sippy spout for this trainer cup is good for a baby who is just starting out with a cup, but I have found that the spout will leak a bit.  It's essentially a flattened out nipple with a slit instead of holes so liquids will flow quickly through this spout.  The trainer handles can be removed so that's a nice feature that I wish other Avent sippy cups offered. The training handles have never particularly impressed me. None of my  children have ever cared to use them.  I see them as just another part to wash.  The handles also make slipping the cup into a diaper bag bottle pouch difficult or near impossible.If your child is already using Avent Classic or Classic+ bottles you can use the sippy insert in any of your Avent bottles.  The trainer cup also comes with a stage 3 bottle nipple, so you can use this as a bottle or a sippy cup.  I like that it offers some versatility in that regard.

My nine and thirteen year olds have been playing Minecraft for more than a year now, and while I've never played it myself, I've seen all of the things the kids have made and have listened to many hours of them telling me about their Minecraft worlds.  This book is packed with information that is now allowing me to make sense of what my kids have been telling me about different things in the game.  My kids frequently go looking for tips online for how to do different things with Minecraft, so I really like that this book has a lot of the information that they typically go searching for all in one convenient book.  It's a good book if you have a Minecraft obsessed kid and you're looking to find out what they're talking about.

This laminator takes almost five minutes to heat up.  I was a bit surprised at the slow warm up time.  Other comparable laminators from Scotch and Swingline heat up in half the time.  When it comes to laminating, this one does a nice job.  Pages come out looking more clear than ones run through the Scotch laminator I have, but not as nice as the one that run through the Swingline machine.  The release for jammed sheets is very difficult.  I had a hard time getting a laminating sheet to release once the lever was depressed.  So if you're trying to reposition something, expect that the laminating sheet is going to get messed up.  The machine does a decent job and is pretty compact, but it wouldn't be my first choice for a personal home use laminator.

I got this computer for word processing and page layout, so I can't speak to using it for gaming or heavy graphics work (but you would probably want a faster computer for that). For text work, it is sufficient, but has a few foibles.- Screen.  The screen is just under 8.5" by 15", which supports having two almost-full-sized  pages side-by-side. (Two full sized 8.5x11 pages would need 8.5x22, but some of that is margin).  The screen is nice and sharp for text work. I've also watched a few SD videos, and those were ok, but don't expect to get anywhere near the claimed six-hour battery life if you're using this as a media machine (the battery is swappable however, which is a very nice feature).- Noise.  If you put the machine up to your ear you can hear the ocean. Or maybe Xiamen. (but seriously...) The fan isn't silent, but mostly just sounds like a gentle whooshing.  The noise is louder when the machine is warmer, which is to be expected, but the laptop doesn't heat up as much as I expected it to - maybe because the components aren't as tightly packed as in my smaller machine.- Keyboard.  The keyboard is a mixed blessing. On the one hand (literally), the keys have good key travel and a nice click-tactile feel (and they're full sized!).  On the other hand, there is a distracting metallic rattle while you type.  I've seen this on other machines, and it doesn't necessarily mean it's a poor quality keyboard (maybe just metal switches instead of plastic), but it's distracting. The keyboard surface also has a bit of flex to it.- Touchpad.  The touchpad is again a mixed blessing. The left and right button areas also have a nice tactile click to them, and I have no complaints about the pad itself. The laptop surface on either side of the touch pad, however, has the slightly tacky rubberized coating you sometimes find in electronics. AND, inasmuch as the machine is running Windows 8.1 (at the moment), this means a side-swipe onto the touchpad starts on a surface that's rubberized and tacky.  I HATE this. Will Windows 10 be better?  Unlikely.  Did Dell do this intentionally, as a little rumble-strip for your fingers?  Maybe. But I'm going to put some duct tape next to the touch pad.So, this is a good computer, especially for the price. But not a great one. YMMV.

I've been using the same Miele canister vacuum for almost 20 years, and buying bags for it from Amazon almost as long. As such, I was happy to get this Dyson to compare. I found the Dyson cordless to have some major advantages over the Miele, but also enough disadvantages that I can't recommend buying it as your only vacuum.Pros:- Cordless. My Miele neatly retracts its cord, but it's still tethered. You can take the Dyson cordless out to the car, or up to the attic, or wherever, and use it with a wand or without. The Dyson is much more versatile than a canister, and has much better reach than a dustbuster.- Great on stairs. The floor tool picks up dust all the way to the edges and back of the treads (though you'll need to swap to a smaller tool to get between any balusters). And, as noted, it's cordless.- No bags. The dust goes into a clear cylinder right below the handle, so you can admire your progress, and that dust container empties from the bottom when you hold it over a trash can (but more on that below).- Attachments. There are about a dozen different attachments and accessories available from Amazon and from Dyson-dot-com.Cons:- Cordless. This is really a mixed blessing. The vacuum needs 3.5 hours of charge to give you at best 20 minutes of vacuuming time (less if you use the floor tool, or "Max" suction). There is no way to swap out batteries, and no easy way to use the Dyson while plugged in.- Loud. Is it really that much louder than my Miele, or is it just that the motor is roughly two feet from my ear, instead of on the floor?  Doesn't matter - it's loud.- Not so great on furniture. There is an optional crevasse tool (aka couch tool) and a mattress tool available. But remember, when you're using those, there will be a whole vacuum body between you and what you're cleaning - not just a hose.- Dusty. The clear dust-catching cylinder leaks a tiny bit from the bottom, and some of the exhaust from the vacuum is basically pointed right at your face. If you have asthma or dust allergies, consider this before buying. The system also releases some dust when emptying - Dyson suggests putting the whole assembly in a clear plastic bag to empty it if you have dust issues. So much for not using a bag.- Unattached filter cone. The washable filter cone sits in the top of the vacuum body, but has nothing to attach it in place. When I first unpacked the vacuum I thought it must be missing some sort of cap to hold that in, but no, the instructions just say to not turn the vacuum upside down or the filter cone will fall out (along with a lot of dust). Mmm k.- No kick stand.  OK, vacuums don't typically have a kick stand. But there's no way to set this down except in its docking station or horizontally on the floor (or on the couch I guess, just don't accidentally turn it over). I'm thinking of sewing it a shoulder strap.- Lame docking station. Unlike most vacuum docking stations I've seen (two connection points, and the vacuum gently snaps in), the Dyson docking station has an elaborate spring system to hold the vacuum, and a pin-style power connector that has to be attached to the station when you first install it. (Don't screw this up, or you'll have to pry things apart again with a screwdriver).  The docking station has places for two attachments (three if you leave one attached to the vacuum body), but there's no place to store other attachments if you buy them, and you can't store two wide attachments next to each other. To remove the vacuum from the docking station with the wand and floor tool still attached, you'll need about two feet of clearance in front of the docking station for everything to swing forward - something to consider if you were going to put this in a closet.- Itchy trigger. There is no on/off switch, just a trigger. You have to hold the trigger down to run the machine, which is ok, since you didn't want to use up your 20 minutes accidentally anyway, and the trigger is really easy to pull. However, the manual has all sorts of warnings about not pressing the trigger while emptying the machine or trying to clear a blockage, and, while there's no way to lock the trigger on, there's also no way to lock the trigger OFF. It's *really* easy to accidentally press this.Meh:- I confess that Dyson has that panache thing going. They have cool ads, and the box comes with a little booklet titled "The Story of Dyson," and they're basically Apple for vacuums. (The folks at Gizmodo love the new "Fluffy" version of this device. http://gizmodo.com/stop-swiffering-1715262802  However, the folks at Gizmodo are getting paid). Whether all this really matters is up to you. Personally, I'm sticking with my Miele. Except for the stairs.

Vital Statistics:Cake Pans - approx. 7-3/4" in diameter inside, 10-1/2" to the ends of the handles outside, just under 1-1/2" deepLoaf Pan - 4-3/4" x 9" inside, 6" x 11-1/2" to the ends of the handles outside, 2-1/2" deepBaking pan - 8-3/4" x 12-3/4" inside, 10" (roughly) x 15-1/2" to the ends of the handles outside, 2" deepCookie Sheet - 10" x 14-3/4" inside, 11-1/4" x 17-3/4" to the ends of the handles outside, 1/2" deep(All measurements are at the top of the pans, which are tapered as they go down, and don't include the little divot around the rim. The pans are made in China).These pans are made from a nice heavy-gauge carbon steel (about the same weight as Granite Ware Better Browning pans), and have a fully rolled rim to add additional stability. The coating does have some thin spots where the black undercoat can be barely made out (not unusual with this kind of spray-on manufacturing), but I don't think it will effect the non-stick performance. I'm more concerned that the pans aren't dishwasher safe, something that isn't mentioned at all in the product description.The box comes with a list of tips and warnings that will be familiar to anyone who uses nonstick (no metal utensils, don't use cooking spray, etc.). One of those warnings is to not have pets or small children in the vicinity when baking - is this general advice, or are there potentially harmful fumes associated with these pans if they overheat, like there is with Teflon?  A call to the Customer Service number referred me to the Meyer website, potsandpans.com, where my research was inconclusive - http://meyer.custhelp.com/app/answers/list/kw/fumes/search/1Cake pans are vastly easier to work with if they are non-stick, and I am happy to have these. For the other pans, however, given the cleaning and fumes issues, I will probably continue to use my Granite Ware.

Anyone who uses an ultrasonic humidifier knows the glug-glug-glug.  You fill the reservoir in the sink (or shower, if your sink is too small), you turn the reservoir upside down, and the water glugs into base.  Every once in a while you get another glug, to let you know your humidifier is working.This device is glug-free.  No reservoir - the ultrasonic module floats in its bowl (or any water-filled vessel), the bowl gets filled and re-filled from the top, and, as the water level goes down, so does the ultrasonic module.  The device can be completely taken apart for cleaning, and almost everything (except the actual electronics) is washable. Why didn't someone think of this sooner?!I only have two beefs - first, while the instructions warn you to not run the module unless it's in water, there's no alarm or auto-shutoff. I usually sleep with the humidifier on if I need one, so I'm going to have to get a really big bucket to put it in.  Second, the optional control module (included, but only necessary if you want to adjust the mist volume) is nicely designed to match the form factor of the device, but the cone at the top is smooth not knurled in any way, which makes it much harder to grip and twist. The mark to indicate the setting is also very faint, and hard to see in dimmer light.  So, four stars.(Vital statistics - the cord is about 4.5 feet from the plug-in power supply to the control module, and about another five feet from the control module to the device. The device itself is very light weight, and about 8.5" in diameter and 9" tall with the nozzle. Both the power supply and the control module have a bright green LED power light).

I already get Big Tree coconut nectar at my local health food store, which also stocks Coconut Secret (both are also sold by Amazon). I expected I would be doing a comparison.  Not so.  This coconut palm syrup is bona fide SYRUP.  Not quite as thick as honey, more like agave nectar, but definitely not the thin (though equally delicious) coconut nectar I'm used to getting.The syrup is very like agave nectar in taste as well, with a slight caramel finish that's heavier than brown sugar, but not as fruity as maple. There is only one "darkness" available, which is somewhere between amber and blonde coconut nectars. The syrup will be excellent in tea where you might use honey (or in baking banana bread), but it's probably a bit much for plain coffee (though if you're one of those types who drinks hazelnut vanilla swill, go for it).The bottle is PETE, with a flip cap. There is no indication of country of origin on the bottle or website (http://wholesomesweet.com/product/organic-coconut-palm-syrup/).  WRT value, my local store sells nectar for between seven and ten dollars for a similarly sized bottle.Update: it's also really good on chocolate ice cream.

Step 1: clean your window thoroughly to remove any dirt or dust particles.Step 2: clean the room thoroughly to remove any dirt or dust particles.Step 3: you just got more dust on the window. Go back to Step 1.Step 4: spray the window glass with enough water (3M recommends Windex) to activate the adhesive, but not enough to cause the film to slide down the window.Step 5: the water (you definitely want Windex) just showed up some dust you didn't notice. Go back to Step 1.Step 6: with two hands, hold the top corners of the film steady on the window. With your third hand, squeegee out any air bubbles. If the squeegee doesn't work, you didn't use enough water. Go back to Step 4.  If the film is sliding down the window, you used too much water. Get another kit and go back to Step 1.I was quite pleased with the 3M whiteboard surface kit I got from Amazon, so I was happy to get this window film kit to review. The film does cut down glare and heat transfer (and is way cheaper than getting new low-e windows). And, oh joy, it comes with a squeegee and cutter knife (but not with the eye protection, hand protection, lint-free cloth, scotch tape, and tape measure also required). But, if you've ever tried to put on a screen protector, you know that every little bit of dust and bubble is going to show, and you need to be obsessive about controlling that. Now imagine doing this on a roughly 3x5 foot surface. With a film that's very, very thin and clingy. Vertically.If you can get this to look good it will work well. If you were planning on installing this in the rec room, with the shag carpet, the beanbag chairs, and the poodle, forget it.(Pro tip - if you do decide to install this, run an air filter for 24 hours ahead of time, then turn it off when you are about to do the actual install. Comment to 3M - If the lint-free cloth had been included, this review would have been four stars).

I have a mixed marriage - I'm PC, and hubby is Mac. So my first question when receiving this keyboard was if it worked across platforms.  Mostly it does.I was able to connect the Keys-To-Go to an iPhone 5, iPhone 6, Dell Venue tablet, HTC1 M8, and original (first generation) iPad. The alphanumeric keys worked flawlessly, and the Function, Command/Windows, Control, and Alt/Option keys worked mostly as expected for each respective OS. There is no Menu key, Esc key, or PageUp/PageDn/Home/End (on the actual Keys-To-Go Keyboard for Android and Windows those last four are mapped to the arrow keys - on the Apple version the left and right arrow are used for Select Word).The keyboard also includes iOS specific hotkeys and those got some odd responses. The complete list of hotkeys are - Home, Switch applications, Search, Switch language, Virtual keyboard (why?), Screen shot, Previous track, Play/Pause, Next track, Mute, Volume down, Volume up. All hotkeys worked as expected on the iPhone 5 and 6, though the antique iPad didn't give me screen shot. However, when I tried listening to Amazon streaming music on the Android phone, for example, volume and pause worked ok but not mute. Other stuff was similarly variable. Some of this is due to cross-platform issues, some is due to the individual program.The keyboard can only speak to one device at a time, but swapping it between devices is pretty easy -  just turn on Bluetooth on the device you want to connect to, press the Bluetooth button on the keyboard until the indicator light does fast blue flash, and then add the keyboard when it shows up on the other device's Bluetooth list (depending on settings you may also have to enter a passcode on the keyboard as a security measure). A few times I have had problem with pairing - per the Logitech knowledge base (http://support.logitech.com/product/keys-to-go-ipad), that can usually be fixed by "forgetting" the Keys-to-Go on the other device and then re-finding it, but sometimes I've had to turn everything off and on again and start over. With the Dell in particular, the pair process has timed out, which is irritating (I blame Dell).WRT to ergonomics, the keyboard does manage to be click-tactile in a very thin and slight squishy package, which is impressive. There is a bit of flex to the keyboard itself, so it's hard to type well on your lap with it without some harder backing surface. The key pitch (center-to-center) for the letter keys is less than 3/4 inch, so no this is not a full-sized keyboard. There is also only one Ctrl key (on the left), and for some reason it's really easy to hit Caps Lock accidentally. So the keyboard is not ergonomically perfect. Still pretty good, however.

I must confess - I didn't get these for incontinence. I got them because the first few days of my period are so heavy I have to get up in the middle of the night to change the "overnight" pad, or risk waking up in a puddle.  Inasmuch as I have also done patient care for non-ambulatory patients, however, I have a good sense of what works for adult diapers. These briefs are definitely not diapers, but are a step up from piddle pads, and much more convenient (if the wearer is dressing themself). As the manufacturer says, "moderate" protection.FIT and FEEL - The "fabric" has a slightly waxy, crepe-papery feel, way better than a plastic backing, but not quite as breathable as cotton underwear. A bit of powder would go a long way on a hot day to make that better. The waistband stretches from 24 inches (completely unstretched) to more than 40 inches (though that would fit like a Speedo). Because of that range of sizes, there is some fabric bunching, especially around the leg holes - not too bulky, but you probably couldn't wear these invisibly under yoga pants (despite the promo picture with the nice towels in the background). I wish there were four sizes instead of two.ABSORBENCY - Like the description says, these are "moderate." The pad is quite thin, though wider than a napkin or piddle pad, and extends to the middle of the pubic bone in front, but not quite to the bottom of the tail bone in back. The fabric of the brief itself will stop some leaks, even beyond the edges of the pad, but I wouldn't use these for someone who was fully incontinent, and they're not meant for fecal incontinence.DISCRETION - There are many nice little touches that help maintain wearer privacy. For example, the cardboard box these come in has a large "D" on it, but nowhere says "Depends," and inside the box the briefs themselves are packed in two plastic packs of 30 each that are roughly 12" x 12" by 5" - just the right size to slip into a dresser or vanity drawer.  The fabric makes a tiny bit of crinkly noise when you walk, but you would have to be in a totally silent space to really hear it.SEAM - Nothing is perfect. My one real complaint about these is the thick horizontal seam that runs across the middle of the back (you can see it in the picture with the brief inside out).  I'm moderately sensitive to seams in odd places, and can mostly ignore it.  Some people are *very* sensitive to seams in odd places, and, if that person were also non-verbal, they might wind up digging in their pants to get at it, which would result in an unpleasant interaction between the wearer and their caregiver. If this is an issue for your situation, it should be considered before buying.For my own purposes these are working well - the included pad acts as a literal backup to the overnite pad (though I wish it were about three inches longer in back), and the disposable brief lets me avoid the little pile of "to be soaked" underwear in the bathroom.  Hopefully my description will be of help in other situations.

(Note - this review is for the Fine Rasp version).  I've been a Microplane fan since way back, but I'm always happy to get another kitchen gadget, so I was thrilled to find this. As the title says, it's a good grater, but has a few foibles you should be aware of before purchasing.Pros:- Sharp!  Definitely not the dollar store version where they punch a bunch of holes in metal and hope for the best.  The teeth on this thing are actually teeth-shaped, with a sculpted blade on the end that will make short work of even fibrous stuff like ginger and coconut.- Solid.  The handle feels like solid metal, perhaps even a bit too heavy, and is knurled for a better grip (no plastic grip that will eventually break down, and I'm looking at you Oxo).  The side-rails supporting the grating surface are robust, and not going to bend any time soon.- Big. The whole device is thirteen inches long, with about six of that being useful grating surface. The rail on the end will stabilize the grater on a bowl or cutting board. All good.- V-shaped hole arrangement.  Not just a gimmick - this really does seem to make it easier to keep stuff in the middle of the grater.- Comes with a blade cover that can be reversed and used for measuring. A nice touch, though it only works on dry stuff like hard cheese, and is pointless on veggies (see picture).Cons:- Heavy.  Robust is good, but the grater is almost too heavy.  Great if you want stability, but you really need to rest it on a surface to grate, not just hold it up in your hand.- No shuttle. The downside of "Sharp!" is that it also applies to fingers as well as carrots. The demo video shows the cook wearing cut-proof glove, but a shuttle to hold the food and protect the fingers would be a whole lot easier.- Slightly confusing cover. The cover looks like it slides on over the end, but if you try to do that it goes almost all the way on and then hangs up on the end rail.  It actually snaps on from the front. Ok.- No hanging loop. A personal preference, YMMV.- Spot welded grating plate. The grating plate is not wrapped around the supports (which would make this much more expensive to manufacture), or embedded in plastic (which does create longevity issues, and I'm looking at you Microplane), but rather folded and spot welded to the inside of the support rails. This creates a pretty substantial crud trap on the backside of the grater (see picture).  In gadgets, as in life, all creation involves compromise.- The grater is, of course, made in China.Overall, I think this is a good mid-range, mid-price gadget.  I'll probably stick with my Microplane, mostly because of the shuttle issue.

I've been using a Honeywell HEPA air purifier for years (the Honeywell Long-Life Pure HEPA QuietCare Air Purifier, 17000). Inasmuch as it sounds like a jet engine, and looks like an orthopedic shoe, however, and inasmuch as the filters and pre-filters (purchased separately) aren't cheap (even on Amazon), I was thrilled to get this Frigidaire to compare.  I guess I got a bad one.The general whooshing noise is definitely quieter on the Frigidare as compared to the Honeywell, and, on the "quiet" setting is barely noticeable.  There is another noise, however, kind of a high-pitched whine, that is quite noticeable and annoying.  It's actually worse on the quiet setting, since there is no whoosh to drown it out. Turning on and off the ionization and UV didn't change this, nor did opening the device and re-seating the paper filter insert.  Nothing appears to be loose. It just whines. Did I get a bad one, or is my hearing just more sensitive?WRT to other operations, the Honeywell pushes the air out almost straight up, and sucks it in from the side. The Frigidaire pulls air in one side and pushes it out the other - hard enough that you could use it for a room fan. My general sense (given allergies and asthma) is that the Honeywell does a better job of clearing pollen and dust, but the Honeywell doesn't have the UV or ionization features, so wouldn't work as well on smaller particles. The replacement filters are also much more expensive, compared to the Frigidaire - Genuine Frigidaire 68661 Allergen and Foam Air Cleaner Filters for FRAP18K5OB and FRAP22D7OB, 1 Allergen and 1 Pre-Filter.  (They recommend you buy a new filter pack every year- consider this when comparing cost).As noted in the title, the Frigidaire is much prettier.  I am, however, sticking with the Honeywell.

My phone lives in the left side pocket of my cargo pants.  But, when I get into my car, it launches itself out of the left side pocket, and plays hide and seek on the floor of the car. As such, I was delighted to get this clip to review.The clip is actually a threefer - it works as a belt clip, with a slot that's about two inches long and a quarter inch wide, in which case you twist the phone 90 degrees to get it to release from the clip; it works as a pocket clip, since the outside of the clip opens up, in which case you pry open the very stiff clip but leave it attached to the phone; and it also works as a kickstand, propping up the phone in landscape mode, which makes up for the fact that the anchor glued to the back of your phone case means the phone will no longer lay flat.  So far so good.Nothing is perfect, however, The quick-release mechanism consists of a hard plastic square that glues to the back of your phone case (in my case, an Otterbox Commuter), and a magnetic/mechanical socket for that plastic square on the back of the clip. Good in that the clip can be attached to the phone in any of the four orientations, and can be removed with a simple twist. Bad in that this assembly sits above the surface of the phone case, which creates a second slot that catches on your belt or pocket or whatever, which then forces you to use two hands when clipping on your phone - one to hold the phone, and one to guide the fabric or belt (See picture. Orange not included).Nothing is perfect, and holding the pocket fabric while I'm attaching the phone is still better than going phone-fishing under the carseat.  But I'm looking forward to the next iteration.

I'm allergic to honey, so I'm always looking for other similar things to use as an alternative.  This stuff is just wonderful.The syrup tastes a lot like dark (grade B) maple syrup, just a bit thicker and fruitier.  It's *really* good on Greek yogurt, and it's a natural combination with tahini on pita (the middle eastern equivalent of a peanut butter and jelly sandwich).  I haven't tried making baklava with it, but given the taste I think it would work well. (Ok, I confess, sometimes I just squeeze a shot directly into my mouth.  At least it's healthier than the aerosol cheese).The squeeze bottle is a little stiff, but I keep it upside down in the fridge and so far it hasn't had a leakage problem. The price for a bottle on Amazon is quite variable, so it's worth keeping track of that for a week or two, or waiting for it to be available as an add-on. Otherwise, however, this stuff rocks.

When I get a migraine, I really just want everything to shut up and go away.  I was hoping this pillow would help - gentle calming aroma, a nice cool surface, a wide shape and dark fabric that helps shut out the light, and relatively heavy stuffing that keeps it all in place. Unfortunately, what it doesn't have is a removable and washable cover.  For regular yoga cushions I don't mind - I'm generally sitting on those.. But, migraine or laying-down-asana, this is sitting on your face. So, if you care about such things, I can't recommend this without a cover (and, if you're Gaiam's media liaison, I'm not the only one who wants this).Some other reviewers seem to have gotten a much more strongly scented pillow,  Mine has a gentle smell, not at all egregious.  And I guess I'll do what my grandmother did with similarly scented things, and leave it in my lingerie drawer as a sachet.

We're a hummus, tzatziki, and pimiento cheese eating household, so when I saw this newly released on Amazon I jumped on it. A month later it self-destructed (stalled, grinding/slipping gear noise, actual *smoke* wafting from the motor housing). I bought another one.The chopper has to be coddled:- Big chunks won't chop efficiently. My pimiento cheese recipe calls for an eight ounce brick of cheddar, and I cut that into half-inch chunks before putting it in the chopper. For tzatziki the cucumber gets cored, and then cut into quarters. I have managed to get it to chop bigger pieces, but it's not worth the time you spend scraping stuff down (see second item).- You have to scrape stuff down. The above-mentioned cheese chunks get put in the bowl with two ounces of cream cheese, and two ounces of mayo. The resulting mash really likes sticking to the clear plastic shield/lid of the chopper, or to the side of the bowl above the blades. So, after about ten seconds of processing I open the bowl and scrape the chunks back down (takes about four iterations before the cheese is chopped enough to stay put at the bottom of the bowl). The cukes have a similar problem, and so would any wet-ish vegetable.- You can't process tiny amounts. Some of the recipes in the included pamphlet call for chopping one clove of garlic. Forget it. The tips of the blades are about a quarter-inch away from the inside of the glass bowl, and the clove will get cut into roughly eight pieces, all of which will then stick to the sides. Much better to use a garlic press right into the bowl with the other ingredients. (See photo for how the blades look in the bowl).- You can't process huge amounts either.  Three cups is about max for pastes, less for liquids.- You can't process for more than about thirty seconds at a time. If you hold down one of the buttons the machine will process continuously, but the motor gets hot, and needs to rest and cool down (which is fine, since you're going to be scraping the sides down anyway).- The "safety" feature is just a cutoff in the blade assembly that keeps it from rotating unless the blade shaft is being pressed down. Putting the entire chopper together will do that, but if you leave the shield off the blades will move anyway, and, if you were so inclined, you could get the blades to rotate by just pressing up on the bottom of the shaft with your hand (DO NOT try this at home).- Not a coddle issue, but, while the bowls and lids look just like the Pyrex four-cup equivalents, they are B&D branded and apparently made in China. :-(So, why am I buying another one? Because the bowls, blade, shield, and gasket, basically everything that touches the food, can go right in the dishwasher, and the bowls come with lids and can go right in the fridge.  Also, I vastly prefer processing food in glass (though of course the blade assembly has a plastic shaft, but at least it's not polycarbonate). I sincerely hope Black & Decker will continue this line with a bigger bowl and a more powerful motor. For now, this is filling the spot in my batterie de kitchenette between the immersion blender and the mandoline, and it will stay there.-----------------------------------Pimiento cheese recipe: eight ounce brick of supermarket cheddar (chunked), two ounces of cream cheese, two ounces of mayo, teaspoon of Worcestershire sauce, shake of paprika, shake of cayenne (to taste), four whole pimiento peppers (from the jar).  Process everything but the pimientos until smooth. Add the pimientos and pulse a few times until they shred.Tzatziki: Two regular cucumbers (seeded and peeled, cut into quarters), clove of garlic (pressed), juice of a half a large lemon (or a very small one), two cups of Greek yogurt, salt to taste. Pulse the cukes, lemon juice, and pressed garlic until it looks grated, Take the lid off the chopper and mix in yogurt and salt by hand (don't process the yogurt, or you will have delicious cucumber soup).

The purple jars are very rich and pretty, almost an amethyst color. The other two colors are lighter. The green is not quite Coke-bottle color, more Mountain Dew. The blue is almost an electric blue - not what I would expect to see in a vintage jar.In shape and form these jars are about the same as regular Ball mason jars - they hold a pint, they have the Ball logo on one side (the blue one says "perfect mason," the green and purple say "perfection," and "improved" respectively"), and they have ounce and milliliter measuring marks (on two sides for the blue, and one side for the green and purple). The fourth side says  "1913-1915/100 years of American heritage/Made in USA." The jars come with canning lids and rings, and will take Ball storage caps. The plastic caps from most pint and quart sized glass mayonnaise jars also fit.We use Ball jars for drinking glasses (hot and cold) as well as storage, and I've bought a six pack every time a new color came out. They definitely add a bit of elegance to the iced tea. (I really wish the company would extend this for another year and have amber glass jars too).

PC-based graphic artists have been hit with two frustrations in recent years - Adobe's heinous new pricing scheme, and Microsoft's slightly less heinous reworking of MS Paint. I had high hopes that this program would help address the first issue. No such luck. But it's an awesome Paint program.WRT Photoshop - the program claims Photoshop compatibility, and this is true, inasmuch as it can open .psd files. It even preserves layers. What it doesn't do is bring in anything path- or object-based -- no splines, no fills, no reshaping, no manipulations that aren't bitmap/pixel rendering. If you thought the price for this as a Photoshop replacement was too good to be true, you were right.WRT Paint - this does everything you ever wanted from that toy. Layers (as mentioned above), a much less useless zoom feature, all sorts of fun brushes and effects (with stylus pressure support), pixel-based transforms, and even a better-designed color mixer. Sweet.Once I stopped expecting too much from it, the program was a lot of fun to play with, with a few annoyances. First annoyance -- the help function takes you to the help files for Painter itself, not Essentials. So, you will read about this cool feature, and then, at the bottom of the page, be presented with an apologetic "Some features described in the Help are available only in Corel Painter 2015, and are not included in Painter Essentials 5. For more information about Corel Painter 2015, visit http://www.painterartist.com/"  (which is a store link). Essentials is the teaser for the more expensive program (which does support paths), and Corel makes no attempt to hide this. Second, as with all Corel's graphics programs, this software can only be installed once. Were you planning on changing machines any time soon?  Well, unless the first machine fails catastrophically, you can't take this with you.Given the relatively low price of this package, I would still recommend it to budding artists and fingerpainting kids of all ages. It's not a professional tool, however, and doesn't really claim to be.(Note - if you're looking for a real artist tool in this price range, check out Autodesk's Sketchbook Pro. That has a much steeper learning curve, and is still bitmap-based, but does a much better job of emulating a real drawing board workflow.)

I've been using the same Cuisinart blender for a couple of decades, because it has a glass jar, and because it lets you select the speed with a slider instead of buttons. Needless to say, I was ecstatic to get this modern equivalent to compare. I am now less ecstatic.Form Factor:- The machine is about eighteen inches high, so it will fit neatly under your upper kitchen cabinets.- The non-glass parts appear to be ABS plastic, or silicone. Both are relatively innocuous plastics (unlike PVC or polycarbonate).- The glass "goblet" is a heavy beast, actually heavier than the base, which makes the blender a bit top heavy. OTOH the goblet also has a wide bottom and is stable standing on its own, which is a feature.- The goblet can be dishwasher-ed, but according to the instructions the blade assembly has to be hand washed (bummer).- There is a stirring wand that fits into the hole in the lid (usually covered by the fill cap), so that, when you're making soups or smoothies, you can stir up the blender contents while the blender is running.  I would have liked to see a holder for this on the side or back of the machine, but no such luck.Ergonomics:- Knob. When I saw the picture of the machine I was worried that the pulse function was a big button in the middle of the knob (which, given my shiny granite counters, would have left me chasing the machine all over the kitchen).  Not so. The knob gets turned counter-clockwise to pulse, and clockwise to select either "on" (which activates the program buttons), or, past that, to select a range from min to max. Nicely done. HOWEVER - the labels for these settings are not incised in any way, they're simply printed onto the rim of the knob, right where your fingers are going to grip the knob to turn it. It's not clear how long those labels are going to last.- Buttons. Once the knob is set to "on," the six program buttons light up. Once a button is pushed, that button will remain lit while the program runs its course, and the others will temporarily darken - all will turn back on again once the program is done. Since the programs stop and re-start the motor, I strongly suggest you train yourself to check the button lights to see if a program is done, not just listen to the motor noise and look at the goblet contents, lest you open the goblet prematurely and be rudely surprised.Usage:- Leakage. The motor is powerful enough to torque the machine sideways when starting up, which I thought was pretty cool, until, after about 20 minutes of putting the blender through its paces, I noticed my counter (and floor) filling with water. The motor is also powerful enough to loosen the blade assembly from the bottom of the goblet - if you are going to do several blends one after the other, I suggest you stop periodically to retighten everything. There is what appears to be a vent hole on the lower back of the base, which, it turns out, is actually a drain for the goblet socket. (Much better to have liquid pouring out the bottom of the base than potentially running into the motor). There does not appear to be any way to get into that channel to clean it, if your leak involves something other than water. I fear for what the starting jerk is going to do to the plastic chassis in the long run.- Capacity. The promo picture for this blender shows it full of neatly cracked ice. Which I'm assuming the photographer got from the ice machine down the hallway. According to the included instructions, the machine's "max. recommend capacity" for crushing ice is 200 grams, or seven ounces. This will get you one margarita. The capacity is the same for grinding nuts, spices, and coffee beans, and slightly higher (250 grams/nine ounces) for chopping vegetables. Only cold liquids can be blended at the full (more than 1.5 quart) capacity of the machine.  As a side note, the instructions are kind enough to translate the Metric grams into ounces for us Americans, but those ounces refer to weight not volume.- Performance. Other reviewers have already sung the praises of the blender when making cream soups and smoothies. Since the machine will also grind spices and coffee beans, I tried it out with some dry rice on that setting to see if I could get a coarse rice meal to make idli. The result was excellent - coarser than rice flour, but a bit finer than commercial cream of rice cereal, and very consistent. Trying to crack rice to make jook was less wonderful, inasmuch as I used the pulse function, and got lots of whole grains mixed in with the pieces. In both cases, the seven ounce limit means the process will be a tad frustrating.If this were a hundred dollar blender, I would have no qualms about giving it five stars.  For this price, however, given the machine's limitations, I can't recommend it to someone looking for a versatile kitchen appliance. If all you wanted was a really pretty smoothie maker, go for it.

It's not unusual for an anthology to span a writer's career.  Somewhat more unusual for it to start in high school. This one does, and, as the author himself admits, the early stuff is terrible. (I'm not complaining mind you - the first couple of stories are actually charming, in a teenaged author kind of way).Each story in this collection starts with a bit of commentary: sometimes a self-critique, sometimes a note about the real-world inspiration for the piece, sometimes a bit of context. Budding writers will enjoy reading about someone else's underpinnings, and misgivings. Authors are people too.The timeline of the stories runs from 1963 to 2009. Roughly the last third of the book is set in Discworld, including some previously unpublished outtakes.Cool.

We have a complicated shower - there's an Aquasana water filter attached to the showerhead, a handshower with a hose, and a border on the (fake, acrylic) tiles that sticks out a bit from the wall.  In addition, there is a Very Tall Person using the shower who really wants his shelves and such to be a bit higher than typical.  So, I was a bit concerned that this Oxo Shower Shelf wouldn't fit.It fits beautifully. There's plenty of clearance for the filter. The wire support doesn't interfere with the hose (though the filter pushes the clamp forward a bit, which also helps). And the whole thing sits a little bit away from the wall, due to the thickness of the suction cups, which is just enough to clear the tile border.The designers didn't build in any height adjustment. What we did (which seems to be working) is to snap off the hook/clamp that's supposed to be at the top, to attach to your showerhead pipe, and move it to the wire on the side. This gave us a couple of inches, though it does mean the shelf is a tad off-center.I do wish there was a real way to adjust the height, or even other versions of the shelf for higher or lower placements. So 4.5 stars. But for you average folks, this is recommended.

I adore my Kyocera Vertical Peeler, but it only has a blade on one side (Your kitchen will need a left-handed cook for carrots, and a right-handed cook for potatoes). So I was thrilled to discover that Kyocera had added this gadget to its line.Unfortunately, the peeler is a disappointment. First, because the peels themselves are quite thick, which is great for rutabagas and celery root, where you want to take off a lot of skin, but terrible for carrots and potatoes, where you wind up with half your vegetable in the sink strainer. Second, because the handle is weirdly uncomfortable. The notch for your forefinger is just a bit too far away from the blade, and the handle is at an odd angle, which makes peeling round things held in the other hand feel just a bit awkward.I adore the Kyocera blades, and I really hope they'll come out with a two-side version of the old peeler. I use this one for thick-skinned veggies, but I wouldn't buy it again.

I already have a Zojirushi Electric Skillet (purchased from Amazon about a year ago), but it's not big enough for potlucks or holidays, so I was glad to get this De'Longhi to compare.  The De'Longhi is nice and big, but has some foibles.PROS:- BIG. The inside is 3 inches deep, 11.5 inches wide, and 15 inches long (measured at the widest part of the interior, since the sides are bowed out a bit). So not only does it hold a lot of food for stews and sautes, you'll have no trouble using it as a griddle. (The exterior length is 19.5, which fits nicely front to back on a countertop).- Dial. The thermostat has a real dial you can turn, not electronic pushbuttons like some other similar models, with a red light that goes on when the skillet is heating. (However, see below under CONS).- Pretty fast. Four quarts of water fill the skillet to about halfway up, and it took just a hair over ten minutes to get that to a simmer (one bubble every few seconds, tap cold water, lid on), and just over 18 minutes to a full boil (constant bubbles).  When I turned the temperature down the water came off boil almost instantly.  There is only one heating loop, which is where the bubbles appeared first, but the pan metal is thick so the diffusion is pretty good.- Accurate.  I brought the pan to full boil with the knob set to the highest setting (400), and when I turned the knob down the thermostat light went off at about 220.- The handles can be used when the controls are in place.  It's an odd complaint, I know, but some similar skillets have a thermostat that is so close to the handle that you can't use the handle when the skillet is plugged in.CONS:- Watch your fingers. The insides of the handles don't fully cover the sides of the pot, and the sides of the pot get quite hot.  If you have long fingers it's a little too easy to accidentally touch hot metal (the instructions say to be very careful when moving a pot that's plugged in, or to avoid doing so at all, but even after the pot is unplugged the contents and surface will be hot for quite a while).- Misleading light. The thermostat light turns off when the skillet is above the set temperature (because the heating coil is not on), and turns back on again when the skillet has dropped below the set temperature (because the heating coil went on again automatically). The lowest temperature setting is "warm," not "off" - to turn the skillet fully off you have to unplug it. Inasmuch as having the light off doesn't signify that the skillet is turned off, and inasmuch as turning the dial all the way down sets the temperature to "warm" not "off" (which will turn the light and the heating coil off, but only temporarily), this might be a hazard for people unfamiliar with this kind of equipment.- Plastic inside the lid. Some people prefer not to have plastic touching their hot food, but the handle for this lid has a plastic base on the inside of the lid, right where steam will rise and condense. I think this is to support the vent built into the handle, but I would rather lose the vent and the plastic (the lid lets out more steam around the edges than from the vent anyway).- Non-magnetic cord. The cord for the skillet is detachable, but it goes deeply into the pan body when it is attached. Thus, if the skillet is plugged in and the cord is accidentally caught, or if a kid reaches up and pulls on the cord, the skillet could potentially be dragged off a table or countertop. The Zojirushi has a magnetic cord base, which will detach if the cord is yanked. Much safer if there are little ones running around.Overall, I think this is a good skillet, but not a great one.  It will be an excellent warmer for potlucks, but I'll probably keep using the Zojirushi for stewing and sauteing at home.

I was concerned, when I saw the picture of this device, that it would be a little tippy, and that it would interfere with the speakers on the iPhone. In fact, the designers did the right thing - the inside of the slot has a little raised bit that the phone rests on, so the speakers aren't blocked at all (it even has a bit of wiggle for strain relief on the connectors), and the charger is nice and hefty.My iPhone has a thin silicone skin, which fits fine in the charger, but something thick like an Otterbox clearly wouldn't fit.  My only beef is that I can't plug in headphones while the phone is charging, though apparently some other Belkin chargers do support this (I would settle for a notch so I could plug in an angle connector - since the inside of the charger has rubber cushioning, I'm tempted to cut one).UPDATE: My previous phone had an Otterbox case, and I felt naked without one, so I decided to take the plunge and see if I could get it to work. I bought an Otterbox Commuter (not the thicker Defender), and carefully cut off the tab that covers the charging port. I then carefully pared down the base of the connector inside the dock (basically just changed the rounded ends to pointed ends). It works! The slot of the dock is wide enough to fit the Commuter, and since there's a bit of play it the connector you can get it to mate properly. If you have a steady hand, and are willing to take an x-acto knife to sixty bucks worth of electronics accessories, you can in fact get this stand to work with an Otterbox.

As a long-time Prismacolor user (with occasional forays into Crayola pencils), I was happy to get these to review. They are actually made by the folks who make Derwent pencils, a well-known drawing pencil brand in its own right.On a scale of soft-and-waxy to hard-and-chalky (with Prismacolor Scholars being at the far end of wax, regular Prismacolors not far behind, Crayola somewhere in the middle, and Prismacolor Verithins being at the far end of hard) the Mead/Derwent pencils are somewhere between Crayola and Verithin.  This will work well for a drawing technique that involves laying down many light layers, either of the same or mixed colors, and also makes for a nice precise edge.  Getting solid coverage with one hard stroke is easier with a softer pencil, however, as is blending in general. (Depending on the tooth of your paper, you may wind up with a nice pointillism effect here).  Derwent makes a blender, which I don't have, but my Prismacolor blender did smooth the laydown on these somewhat, though not as well as it would have with the Prismacolors or P Scholars. (Pro-tip - you can blend regular, non-twistable, non-erasable, Crayola pencils with the sharp back edge of the pencil itself. You can't do that with these).My biggest beef with this set, however, is the included colors, which are: Cadmium Yellow, Orange, Red, Purple, Ultramarine, Light Blue, Light Green, Dark Green, Yellow Ochre, Terracotta, Burnt Umber, and Black. There is no White, which substantially diminishes what colors you can blend, as well as the ability to make highlights. The Red also is a wimpy salmon-like color, not what any other set I've ever had would call red. Crayola has a better color range for a lower price, if somewhat less panache (and Prismacolor has a better color range for a higher price ...).If you really want this set, check the price on Amazon for the Derwent equivalent - Derwent Academy Colored Pencils, 12 Pack - which appears from the Amazon listing to have white instead of Yellow Ochre, and Pink instead of Purple (though I've seen 12-packs at other stores that had the same colors as the Mead set). But I wouldn't recommend this set when there are other, better, collections.

Inasmuch as the Brother machine I have for general use is (literally) a lightweight, I was thrilled to get this Singer for heavier duty projects. It has a notable amount of power and speed, but does have some foibles that should be considered.FORM FACTOR: The machine is QUITE heavy (almost 32 pounds). This is a feature, inasmuch as it won't jump around at high speeds or when dealing with tough fabrics, but I wouldn't buy it to transport to your weekly quilting class. While the chassis is metal, the knobs are plastic or plastic-covered. (The reverse lever is plastic over a metal base - I anticipate having to eventually replace the plastic part, but the lever is usable without it). There is a longer arm than the typical home machine, which gives you a nice large throat, and a fair amount of surface area. Because of the front-loading bobbin and extended size, however, the machine can't be recessed into a standard sewing table, and it won't fit in a standard carry case.STITCHING/SPEED: As other reviewers have noted, the machine stitches very fast and very evenly, and with a fair amount of power. (I went through four layers of medium weight nylon backpack webbing with no problem). I was concerned, given the emphasis on speed, that the machine wouldn't be able to also run slowly for doing fine work.  In fact, there are three speed settings, and the pedal is also a speed controller (unlike some cheaper machines, where the pedal is only an on-off). At the slowest setting, with a light touch on the pedal, the machine is slow enough to count the stitches.THREADING AND TENSION: I had no problems threading the machine, using only the included Quick Start guide, the threading instructions on the machine itself, and a degree in mechanical engineering. The threading is very fussy compared to other machines I've used, however, with much poking of thread through tiny holes, not just around wires. A handheld needle threader will be of help here, unless you have a very steady hand. Setting the tension is a pain, involving two different knobs for the top thread, a screwdriver for the bobbin tension, and another knob for the presser foot tension. I never did get the tension right for sewing sheers. On the other hand, unlike some cheaper machines, you can in fact set the bobbin thread tension.BOBBIN: The bobbin is front-loaded/vertical, not drop-in/horizontal, which some quilters insist gives you better tension control (not quite to the level of a religious argument in crafting circles). This will make it easier to change bobbins while there is still a work piece in the machine. Unfortunately, this also means there isn't the convenient clear window and clear plastic bobbin that lets you know how much bobbin thread is left, and the machine itself has no warning light or beep. To exacerbate the problem, the bobbin itself is L-class (5/16" thick, 3/4" diameter), not M-class (3/8" thick, 1" diameter). Typical for home machines, but it doesn't hold nearly as much thread.The bobbin winder is usable while the machine is still top-threaded, thanks to the machine's two spool holders. It is operated by a button on the front of the machine, though the Quick Start guide indicates it is operated by stepping on the pedal (true for every other Singer machine I've ever used, but not this one). There is a guide on the machine itself showing you how to use the bobbin winder, but no guide on how to insert the bobbin and case, though the Quick Start guide does cover this, as does the documentation booklet.EMBROIDERY: While the machine only does straight stitches, there is a zero-length stitch setting for free-form work. When I first tried this I embroidered a nice bird's nest. However, with the correct presser foot and cover plate, and much fussing with tension, I got fine stitches and a good amount of control. Some machines let you drop the feed dogs for embroidery - this one only has a plate to raise the fabric above them. Ok. There is a very nice spring-loaded embroidery foot included. There is no hoop included, but I would recommend getting this if you are going to do anything beyond basic mending.KNEE LIFTER/CUTTER/NEEDLE THREADER:  A knee lifter is the mark of a real quilting machine, and I have no complaints about this one. It is removable if you want to get close in for fine work. The needle threader was difficult to use at first, until I figured out that I had to press my thumb to the bottom of the front tab to hold the thread in place. The cutter is push-button and spring operated, and cuts with a resounding thunk, but doesn't leave quite enough bobbin thread to pull up easily (the most annoying thing about this machine). My Brother just has what is essentially a seam ripper glued to the side of the machine, but I vastly prefer that for cutting threads.DOCUMENTATION: The machine comes with onboard diagrams for threading and bobbin winding (as noted above), though I wish these were in black, not medium grey. The Quick Start guide covers the above plus inserting the bobbin case and bringing up thread, using diagrams almost entirely. The included manual covers the same, plus how to use the various presser feet, with verbal explanations. There is a link to Singer's Youtube channel if you want videos on general sewing, but there is nothing specifically for the Singer S16 as yet. (A general search for "Singer S16" only brings up a third-party video, with a link to this Amazon page - the video is clearly click-bait).PACKAGING: The machine comes packed in Styrofoam, and there is a vinyl cover included. Given that it won't fit in a standard home machine case (sometimes called a universal, or free-arm case), and given how not-green Styrofoam and vinyl are, I *really* wish it had just shipped in a hard-sided case. I'm sure people who are investing in a machine this costly would be happy to add another 25 dollars to protect their investment.ETC: Oddly, there is no walking foot included. There is also no ability to set needle position, though the fabric guide addresses seam positioning.Overall, this is a good, but not perfect, machine for quilters who are ready to move up to the next level of investment, and it will also be useful for other applications that need a heavy-duty but not full-time machine. It is definitely not for beginners.

When I got my new HTC One M8 I immediately bought a Class 4 chip to put in it for music MP3s (from another manufacturer, whose name is French for "without disk"). When I tried to save video MP4s, however, the phone complained.This chip works with no complaints for videos taken using my HTC, including fast and slow motion, high def, and "zoe". Transferring a five minute video from the chip to my laptop using the adapter takes about 30 seconds (26 fps, 20040 total kbps, file size about 720 Meg), which is about half the 48MB/s the device claims. How much of this is my (fairly slow) Lenovo laptop, or overhead? Don't know. Most of my downloads will be via USB, not the adapter.Amazon prices for the various Samsung Micro SDHCs can vary, so it's worth checking the cost for the larger and faster chips before buying.  But as a HTC user, I have no complaints with this one.

I was a little concerned that the clamp on this tripod wouldn't be able to handle my (ginormous) HTC One M8, but it fits beautifully, and is a substantial advantage when using the phone in both stereo and camera mode. The tripod also works well with my Lumix DMC-SZ1 (an actual camera). Nothing is perfect, however.The tripod is actually three devices:* Bendy legs, which work like giant twist-ties to wrap around chair arms, bannisters, or anything else of similar diameter, and which are stiff enough to stand alone, with nice non-skid feet and little ball joints at the tops for more flexibility. There is also a large locking ball joint above the legs so you can orient your device in portrait or landscape mode.* A clamp to hold your phone, with rubbery jaws that open up to more than 3.25 inches, and another lockable ball joint at back to provide more tiltablity.* A mounting bolt and platform to attach the clamp to the legs, or to attach a camera to the legs directly. The bolt screws into the tripod socket on the bottom of your camera, or into a similar socket on the clamp. As with a full-sized professional tripod, there is a quick-release plate holding the bolt, with a tightening screw that holds the plate onto the platform. And herein lies the problem: The tightening screw is the (literally) weakest link. Not because it doesn't hold, but because it's tiny, cheap, plastic, and really hard to grip. On a full-sized tripod these are usually made of metal, with some kind of handle, and ideally spring-loaded. It looks like the designers just copied the bigger version, without thinking about size and ergonomics.  It's also not clear to me why the clamp assembly doesn't have its own plate built in.I still use and enjoy the tripod (it's a perfect accessory for the HTC). I really hope the designers will add a grippy metal screw to the next iteration.

Monster has something of a "reputation" in the audio marketplace, so I wasn't sure how much I would really like these earbuds (excuse me, "In Ear Monitors"). I found the sound to be really good for the price, but I don't think the earbuds are particularly comfortable.NOISE ISOLATION/COMFORT - as the package notes, these buds have "partial" noise isolation, which means they block out some sound but not all.  (if you want more isolation, get the iSport Victory buds instead). The speaker part sits very loosely in the ear, not as an earplug - the buds are held onto your outer ear by the little stub thingy, which you have to press down, put the buds in place, and then let up. I didn't find this to be particularly comfortable, inasmuch as the fit has to be fairly precise, and I apparently wear a small-and-a-half. There's also a little hard tab in the silicone that was pressing in a bad place on one of my ears, but not the other. YMMV. (And as a Bose user, I originally put the buds on backwards - once I figured out they were Andorian not Vulcan that was OK). If you have sweaty ears, or intend to wear these in a high-motion workout like jogging, they probably won't stay in.CORDS/MICROPHONE - The cord is 47" long, flat, and with an angled plug. It is still possible to tangle the cord, but the shape does help somewhat. The microphone is just a mic, no controls. Will it let you answer a call hands-free?  The package insert says you should go to the website to download the instructions but the manuals aren't there yet - I'll update.SOUND - I found the sound on these to be very good, not only for voice-range music like ballad and country (typical for buds), but also for things like classical and disco. My Bose SIE earbuds have a richer bass (imaging, not just volume), and the the Monster buds also have some foreground/background compression compared to the Bose, but considering the difference in price the response is quite respectable. The imaging is better at higher volumes, so will likely improve at the lower as the buds break in. I would note that most of my music is at 256k, on an iPhone, and that my definition of "high" volume is in the middle of the volume slider.EXTRAS - The buds come with three sizes of eargels (typical) and a little - but overengineered - drawstring bag. They are packed in a nice, solid- but overengineered - cardboard box (dig out the magnets before recycling this) with a recyclable plastic insert. According to the promo insert, the eargels are supposedly antimicrobial and washable. I assume you'd have to take them off the speaker part before washing, but I'm still waiting for the manual.Overall, these have a nice sound at a reasonable price, if they work for you. I'll be sticking with my old Bose MIE earbuds, however.

Any student of Architecture or Interior Design is probably familiar with Francis Ching's work. This book is a re-working of his classic Building Construction Illustrated, with the focus shifted to the EU. There is also a small final chapter on building construction in the Middle East.A lot of the text in the book is taken wholesale from the original American version - a paragraph-by-paragraph comparison of the first few chapters gave me more than 90% overlap, and the ending chapters covering HVAC and materials appear to be almost identical. There are some differences in naming - "Wood" is called "Timber," "Gypsum board is called "Plasterboard," measurements are in metrics, and so on. Much of the difference in actual content, however, arises from new green and sustainable building technology.In Chapter 1, "The Building Site," 32 sections have the same title. The EU version adds: "BREEAM," "Carbon Reduction Strategies," "The Passive House Standard," and (oddly) "Drawing Conventions." The US version adds: "The 2030 Challenge," "Regulatory Factors," and "Zoning Ordinances," as well as three sections that are addressed elsewhere in the EU book: "Slope Protection," "Retaining Walls," and "Site Description."  In Chapter 5, on "Wall Systems," the EU version has sections on Hemp and Straw Bale construction, while the US version covers Glass Block and Structural Clay tile. In Chapter 6, "Roof Systems," the EU version has a section on GluLam beam roofs not in the US version. Chapter 9, on "Special Construction," adds a section on prefab Pod Systems. And so on.Is it worth buying this book just for the divergent sections?  That question is up to the reader. Certainly the new information is interesting. I do wish the publisher had taken sustainability into account, however, and just published the upgrade.(I also wish the publisher had used a more readable font, as many other reviewers of this round of Ching's books have noted).
Not since Yoda sent Dorothy back to Kansas on the Shuttlecraft has a book had such a profound influence on my life.  And this poster is the icing on the synthahol. Nanu Nanu Uncle George.

I'm always on the lookout for excellent earbuds, so I was happy to get these to compare to the others in the household. I found them to be much superior to the cheapo ones that came with our various phones, and about on-par with various other mid-priced earbuds, but not as responsive as my Bose MIE or Polk AM4110-A buds.- EAR PIECES - The bases of the earpieces are relatively tiny and gumdrop shaped. The ear gels are three sizes of silicone bulbs (plus one foam set), and the middle size made a solid seal with my ear canal (too solid - the day I wore these with a clogged eustachian tube I wound up in horrible pain from the pressure waves). The gels wouldn't stay in your ear during any kind of exercise, though the foam might.- CORDS - the cords on the Denon are almost 55 inches long, compared to roughly 45 for the Polk and the Bose, and quite thick and stiff (more al-dente spaghetti than capellini). This would definitely help with tangle-resistance. There is an adapter included for Sony phones, which I didn't test. There is no slider. The jack is at a 90 degree angle, not straight.- CONTROLS - The controls and mic are high up on the left side, which is not what I'm used to but not a dealbreaker. There is only one button, which on my iPhone 5 gives me pause with one click, forward a track with two, and back a track with three. On my HTC One I only get pause and play. (This is typical functionality for one-button controls).- CASE - There is a very nice little zippered case included.- SOUND - The buds sound spectacular on voice-based mid-range music like opera and ballad, but don't have quite the same level of imaging for classical and instrumental music as the Bose or the Polk. I was originally underwhelmed by the bass and high-end response, but after giving them some break-in time, and switching to the small size gels, I'm revising my opinion. There is a downloadable Denon music app that I didn't test, so I may still not be giving these their full workout. As the "Studio" denotes, the buds are designed for a flat response across the audio spectrum.So, if you're looking for a tangle-resistant set of earbuds for sedentary use, and don't listen to complex music, and can find these on sale, go for it.

- The Bronze color goes nicely with our walnut (actually walnut colored Formica) bathroom cabinets- There is padding inside the hooks to keep the rack from scratching- The hooks including the padding are just a hair under 1/8-inch thick, which fits nicely between cabinet or drawer fronts- The hook interior space is about 7/8 inch, which should fit over thicker (Shaker style) doors- The rack is braised, or maybe soldered, onto the hooks, not welded, so I wouldn't put something very heavy on the rack, or use it for a grab bar.That is all.

As a science nerd from way back, the recent uptick in interest in all things technical warms my heart. This book largely fans those flames, with a few caveats for non-scientific readers.The book starts with classical mechanics, but covers a wide range of topics - matter and energy, atoms and solar systems, particles and waves (with some discussion of dual-nature implications). The writing is mostly accessible, with some topic headings that were clearly intended to appeal to a lay audience - "What does your blood pressure mean?," "What makes an atomic bomb work?" (Don't get your hopes up - the book won't help you build one.). There are lots of real-world examples used throughout, including everything from curve balls to x-rays.Lay audience notwithstanding, however, the explanations in the text refer to things like polar coordinates and partial differentials, with the assumption that the reader knows what those are, and the formulas use Greek letters freely (for readers who aren't up on their rho's and tau's, it will be helpful to print out a Greek alphabet for reference while reading, if only so you know how to pronounce the equations). As a visual thinker, I do wish there had been more diagrams, or even a video. (Maybe a companion guide viewable on a 3D device?).Looking at the book with an editor's eye, I was sad to find some typos of the type that a spell-check program would miss (including a figure reference in Chapter 4 that I'm pretty sure was off), and some odd sequencing of topics - in particular, the text discusses quantum mechanics before optics and atoms, which, among other things, meant that diffraction gratings were referred to before they were introduced. There is an index, which helps somewhat, but I wish there had also been a glossary. The chapter on quantum mechanics is one of the harder ones, and I also wound up completely confused at one point while reading it, until I realized that the "K" I was reading in the current equation meant "kinetic energy," while the previous "K" had meant "Kelvin." It helps to take frequent contemplation and comprehension breaks.Foibles notwithstanding, I found this to be an interesting and valuable work, and a bit of a brain workout (NTTAWWT).

Anyone who's been following the software market knows that Adobe shot itself in the foot with its new rent-to-not-own software pricing scheme. And anyone who's evaluated this Corel suite knows that Corel has set out to eat Adobe's lunch. Not only does the software take in Adobe files, CorelDraw offers a "workspace" that emulates the look and feel of Illustrator, and Photopaint offers a similar workspace for Photoshop, as well as some recently added path-friendly capabilities. Searching for Adobe on the Corel site turns up much advice on how to handle the transition.So, how well does the Corel suite really handle Adobe files?* ILLUSTRATOR TO CorelDRAW *I prepared a file in Illustrator (CS5) with two art boards, two main layers, and eight sub-layers (some were created on the fly as I added text).
