The most sour is the SweeTarts Sour Chews that will eat through the tooth enamel. The least is the SweeTarts gummies, which are just soft, faintly fruity and dusted with sugar.

Very high quality and absorbent. We're using it as a dish towel in a large and highly trafficked kitchen of an open floor plan contemporary home where one's eye naturally falls on the sink in the middle of that room. The colors are actually a bit softer and lovelier muted ochre yellow and stainless steel grey than in the picture, but match out kitchen decor. For some, the Moorish-Moroccan design might be a bit too busy as a complete set in a bathroom, despite its high quality.Edit: Indeed, we retuned to buy another as a spare for our kitchen and would've in a heartbeat, but the in just 2 weeks time the price had increased to nearly $15. It's a nice hand towel for $10, but $15 is a bridge too far. We'll look elsewhere for these colors. Price point is part of a review, and the illogical jacking up of the price prompted me to drop this down from 5 stars to 4. It also makes no sense, as the large bath towel is $12.
Have bought these several times over the past couple of years. Great savings and I've never seen any difference in quality than the outrageously priced Miele brand.

These soft nippled cabinet bumpers are what most homeowners have longed searched for. I'm not prone to gushing over home hardware items, however, this product is my exception. Our home came with high end kitchen cabinets - lots of them, which is fantastic. The downside was the original manufacturer bumpers quickly petered out, flattened and nothing I replaced them with did one thing to deaden the loud thunk when any where even gently closed. So very tired of the noise after 8 years and trying every other type of bumper that I figured one last hurrah might be the fix. It is. Upon arrival in the mail, I tested them on the most used and most annoyingly loud banging cabinets. Voila! I then went around removing all the useless, old replacement bumpers, replacing them with these. With a coupled left over, I attacked the bathroom vanity cabinets. And now back ordering more. I'll update later with time to see if the soft noise reducing bumpers remain soft and noise reducing. Why manufacturers don't use these on the front end is puzzling. It's not as if you're not paying enough for good cabinets or that good, soft bumpers would add much of any cost to them.
DO NOT put this in a tank with Betta - or any fish you care for. It is hard plastic, with fake hard plastic "moss" fronds that are like tiny razors. It will rip fins and kill.

It is spicy and tasty, but it's also thin and needs some beans and meat and more than just jalapenos. We use it as a base, adding our own meat and beans, sometimes veggies, as well. I cannot imagine just eating what comes in the can.
2-ply means it is 500 thread count, at best, not 1000 thread count. To be 1000 thread count, it would need to be 1-ply.

She seems like a nice woman, but this was not more than a lightweight wet kiss to those in high places she applauds for having the foresight and smarts to raise her, hire her or marry her. ;-) As a lifelong non-partisan Independent who didn't bring any political agenda to the table, I just don't think there is much in this book that will enlighten or surprise, or entertain. One of the great lines from the 1980s movie, Broadcast News, was advice Ms. Perino ought take: People who are lucky enough to stumble into high profile well-paid dream jobs - generally because of looks, not talent - should keep it to themselves. This book would've been a terrific little vanity press tome given to friends, colleagues and family in their Christmas stocking. It's also too long by about 100 redundant pages. On the plus side, it's a very quick read and dog lovers will appreciate it.
Prefer these to the wedges. Just more reliable and accurate in critical spaces - which is to say wherever someone is tiling. These were easy to rinse off afterward and can be reused.
Teen daughter loved it. The purple is more of a periwinkle, and the green is very understated.

Perfect, just what we were looking for to sit in a very expensive caddy and replace the glass drinking cup in favor of a soap dish in our powder room. It has a nice, compact shape. It fit perfectly in the existing standard 2 1/4 caddy. The frosted glass matches the frosted glass shelf over the lavatory, as well as the frosted lower 1/2 glass in the powder room window.

Nice quality. We bought the white tufted chenille sham to go with mostly white patchwork quilted bedspread for a teen moving into more sophisticated and understated all white bedroom decor. Gone is the pink/lavender gingham and butterflies bedding, but she did agree to the soft tufted chenille and diamond design.
Not too hard, not too easy. Cute when assembled. My kid and I like to do these, sometimes together and sometimes competing to see who can finish in the quickest time.

Like most Avery products, this product is great for short runs, like under 100 prints. After that, the pricing model pretty much comes undone. I do not like that I now have to register in order to download the appropriate templates for this label. I have ended up getting at least 2-3 junk mailings from Avery in the past 2 weeks since singing-up via their website. It used to be that you could just download a template for their products without registering at all. Unfortunately, that's no longer the case.

I was looking for a mouse. A cheap mouse. Something under $10. Hopefully, something that would actually last longer than the last cheap mouse I bought on Amazon (it didn't even last a month!). I have used and reviewed a lot of Belkin products in the past, usually with pretty good results. This was not literally THE cheapest mouse I could find on Amazon, but it was still under $10, so I decided to take a gamble on it.Fortunately, for what is unarguably a "cheap" (in cost) mouse, the Belkin USB Optical Mouse is surprisingly well built and works flawlessly. A couple of things impressed me with this mouse off the bat, First, it has no ridiculous, unnecessary LEDs. I have this mouse connected to a laptop in my bedroom and mice with blinking LEDs drive me nuts. They also waste electricity. I love the fact that this mouse does not light up my entire  bedroom, even when the computer is unplugged. Secondly, I was also impressed with the USB cable that the mouse uses. Most "cheap" mice sold these days use cords that are as thin as a strand of spaghetti. This is always a sign of poor construction, which leads to a very short mouse lifespan. The Belkin mouse has a pretty beefy USB 2.0 cable by today's standards. Light enough to not get in your way, but thick enough that it will probably last longer than my past few cheap mice put together.The packaging that the mouse arrived in was a very simple cardboard box. No driver disk (none necessary, for Windows at least). No confusing manual written in Chinese. No maddening blister packaging, nor any materials that can't be recycled. Kudos to Belkin for keeping things simple. It's definitely worth more than the $2-3 extra than you will pay for THE cheapest mouse you can find here on Amazon. So, do yourself a favor and give the Belkin mouse a try. I'm guessing that you will not be disappointed, either.

I have to rate this drive squarely in the middle as compared to the rest of its SSD counterparts. I ran benchmark tests on the drive alongside another solid state drive that I had bought earlier this year, made by Kingston. The results were fairly comparable, in that both fell well short of their advertised maximum read/write speeds.Disk read speeds on the OCZ Trion 100 Series (240GB) SSD were fairly average, clocking in at just a little better than 300 MB/s at its absolute fastest. That's nowhere near the advertised max speed of 550 MB/s, but at least it's in the ballpark. On disk writing speeds, benchmark tests showed the OCZ disk to not even be in the same zip code, let alone the ballpark, though. At best, I was able to eek out 100 MB/s, as compared to the advertised max write of 520 MB/s. I ran the same test 5 times in a row to assure accuracy. Disappointing? Yes. Surprising? No.Unfortunately, solid state drives not living up to their specs seems to be the norm with most manufacturers today, including OCZ. The common excuse seems to be that I just happened to get a bad one, or that I must not be testing the drive correctly. I have been building computers for myself and for my customers for 20+ years now. In other words, I know what I'm doing and how to properly test computer equipment. The benchmarks simply don't lie. Unfortunately, 90% of the drives I test these days are no better, which is why I am cutting OCZ some slack. It is not THE cheapest drive on the market (the similar Kingston 240GB drive is selling for about $10 cheaper at the moment), but it is still way cheaper than a drive that I would expect to pass benchmarks with flying colors.Bottom line, as long as you aren't actually expecting this drive to operate anywhere near it's advertised speeds, it is a pretty good deal. If you want/need a drive that actually performs to spec and is screaming fast, I would suggest something from the Intel 5XX series of solid state drives.You will pay nearly twice as much for Intel's drives, but you can always rely upon them to run at the speeds they advertise. In the end, you get what you pay for in the world of SSDs.

I must admit that I at first found the basis of this book to be intriguing. Unfortunately, the concept seemed to come unraveled rather quickly. The author's explanation of his theory seems to be an answer in search of a question, in story after story. However, some of his arguments feel way too much like trying to stuff a round peg into a square hole.While there may be some cases in the media of black vs white, in actual practice story telling is a much more of a grey area. The best stories are ones that closely reflect real life and let's face it, if real life was mostly black vs white (good vs evil) it would be infinitely easier to make decisions based upon our faith. Implying that all works of man must be inherently good because we are all made in God's image is a gross oversimplification, but that seems to be part of the general argument from what I was able to take-away from the book.While I find it a very hopeful for mankind to think that there is always some inherent good in what we do, no matter how hard it may be to see at first glance, I unfortunately have to classify this as wishful thinking. It's nice to think that every cloud has a silver lining, but at some point you have to accept that the cloud part vastly outweighs any silver lining you may eventually find. There is just too much "reading between the lines" in this book and not enough subjective reality. I admire the author's devotion to his argument, but I believe that his devotion in this case may be misplaced.

I have two cats and have subjected both of them to trying an ever-growing list of "healthy" cat foods in order to find the best balance between quality ingredients, taste and cost. This particular brand was not all that difficult to judge, but not for the reasons you might expect.First of all, I had a difficult time convincing either of my cats to actually try this particular brand and I am pretty sure that I know the reason why. Compared to every other cat food I have fed them before, Hill's Science Diet definitely has the largest kibbles. I took a picture that I will upload with this review, but suffice to say it is both wider and thicker than any cat food I can remember seeing. My cats seem to have sensitive teeth and at first avoided it, very likely for this reason.Insofar as quality ingredients go, the actual ingredients list is quite disappointing. While the #1 ingredient may be meat (chicken), it really goes downhill (no pun intended) from there. The #2 ingredient is whole grain wheat, #3 is corn gluten meal, #4 is pork fat, followed by powdered cellulose, wheat gluten, chicken liver flavor (what, just flavor, not actual chicken liver?) dried beet pulp, soybean oil, and on and on... Near the end are some other ingredients you would never expect to see in a cat food, such as apples, cranberries, carrots and broccoli. This ingredients list is something I would expect to find in a cheap-o brand cat food sold in bulk, not a supposedly "premium brand" cat food. What kind of "science" they are using to come up with these ingredients is beyond me, but it does not sound like the basis of a healthy diet for cats.Hill's premium brand also sells at a premium price, which can not be justified considering the ingredients it uses. In a rather ironic move, the bag lists the #1 ingredient as chicken and displays next to that a picture of what looks to be fried chicken. I will assume that the chicken in this cat food is not deep fried, but you never know. It does include pork fat.I will let my cats finish this one bag (if they will agree to it), but I definitely will not continue feeding it to them beyond that. Hill's makes some excellent products, but this isn't one of them.

Nutro has been around for quite awhile and at one time was one of those high-end brands that you could only seem to find at veterinarian's offices. The small company eventually ended-up being bought out by Mars, a corporation mostly known for its line of chocolate bars. Since then, Nutro has gone mainstream and you can find their products in pretty much every major supermarket chain in the country. It's price has also come down accordingly.These days, Nutro is somewhere near the middle of the pack on price/quality when it comes to "healthy" dog and cat foods. I had largely avoided the brand in the past due to its high cost, but it has gotten to the point now where it is not outrageously expensive, so I thought that I would give it a try.Both of my cats seemed to take to Nutro's "hairball formula" right away. They each seem to have rather sensitive teeth so the size and shape of this food is a definite plus. It isn't soft, but it is a lot less "crunchy" and dry than other brands that seem to have more complex shapes. The Ziplock-like resealable bag it comes in also keeps it fresh for longer.The ingredients list is impressive in some ways and disappointing in others. Unlike the really cheap cat food brands it does not contain corn, grain, artificial colors or a tremendous amount of fillers. It is also supposed to be GMO-free, although I don't know how on earth that could even be tested for. The #1 ingredient is real meat (chicken), which is something I always look for. It does have some non-meat sources of protein that cost them less to include like peas and potatoes. That seems to be the trend nowadays among most of the cat food manufacturers though. It is definitely healthier for cats than stuff like corn or grain, but not something they would probably not eat at all were it not for the majority of the flavor coming from chicken and chicken meal.I normally feed my cats Purina One Smartblend because they seem to love it so much. Nutro seems to be slightly higher quality (Purina One DOES use corn as filler material) and my cats like it almost as much, so I will probably end-up switching. The price difference between the two is justified and not all that great considering the better ingredients.

I like the larger bottles. More convenient. No problems, otherwise. Like the fact that they do not use cheap-o BPA plastics, which can break-down and get into liquids, especially after exposed to high temperatures (like dishwashers). Not much else to tell. They just work!

The cable I received did not arrive in consumer packaging, just a plastic bag, but I am assuming that it was actually manufactured by Belkin due to the fact that the Belkin name is stamped across the entire length of the actual cable. If the cable is counterfeit, the manufacturer went through an awful lot of trouble. The construction and features seem the same as other patch cables I have bought from Belkin in the past as well.Since the particular patch cable I ordered was only 3' long, there isn't really much that can/should go wrong with the product. It definitely seems up to spec. I generally buy CAT6 for most long runs, but for patch cables like this I can't imagine that there is any difference in performance between CAT6 and CAT5E that is measurable. Honestly, CAT6 has been standardized for so long now, it makes me wonder why anyone even bothers to make 5E anymore.Irregardless, Belkin has been my go to manufacturer for patch cables for quite awhile now. Their build quality is always up to spec and generally lasts longer than other brands I have tried. A definite thumbs up.

I've owned a (regular) George Foreman Grill for several years now and really like its features. When I first looked at this grill, I figured that it would keep most of the same features and characteristics of the regular GF electric grills, only it runs on liquid propane. Not really.To me, the greatest part about my electric George Foreman Electric Grill is the ability to avoid a huge mess by using the teflon cooking surfaces on both sides to contain any grease splatter. I can just throw-on a hamburger after pre-heating, and walk-away, since it includes a shut-off timer. It cooks evenly on both sides. When it's done, I just pour out the grease and throw the teflon cook surfaces in the dishwasher. The Camp and Tailgate Grill is a whole different story though.Having only a single side to the grill allows for grease to splatter, most of which sticks to the metal parts of the grill. These parts can not be put in a dishwasher and have to be cleaned by hand. Having a single side and cooking with gas also means no walking away from the grill at any time. You need to be there to both flip the food over as well as properly turn of and then disconnect the propane bottle. There is no automatic shutoff timer. Unlike the electric version there is also no way to easily determine what temperature your grill is operating at.Just opening the unit up pretty much requires reading the few instructions you will find in the manual. It is kind of clunky in that regards. The manual itself is mostly just warnings about cooking with gas in general. One thing that few other reviewers have mentioned is that the safety warnings explicitly warn you NOT to use anything but a 1 pound LP container. It doesn't give a reason, but it is VERY specific about warning you not to ever use any other sized container. It also warns you never to store LP containers indoors or store it attached to the grill. So, you basically need to store most of the grill inside and the LP bottle and regulator outside, since it also says not to store the grill itself outdoors.Insofar as its cooking abilities, although I personally prefer charcoal when cooking outside, this is what I would call a nice "emergency stove". It's something I might use on my deck if I am cooking for just myself, but I would prefer a "real" BBQ when cooking large meals for the best taste. I don't tailgate, so I don't know how convenient this would be for those occasions, but it certainly will fit into a vehicle much more easily than a traditional LP or charcoal BBQ. It would also be much more convenient for camping, as I can't imagine lugging a full-size BBQ around more than a few feet. This grill folds-up easily and has a carrying strap for easy transport. FYI, you can store the drip tray and regulator inside the grill when carrying it. They will fit under the griddle. You will have to carry the LP bottle(s) separately though.It's not quite what I expected, but still a decent and sturdy product that comes in handy if you aren't cooking at home. If you don't mind the grease splatter and cleanup it entails, as well as the constant attention needed while cooking, this might be the perfect outdoor grill for you.

This movie started out kind of slow, but very quickly picked-up its pace and started sucking at full throttle. The script is plain nonsense, the characters unlikable and performances barely serious enough to convince me that this was a spoof and not a spoof of a spoof. Don't get me wrong, I love cheesy, campy movies in general. Some of my favorite films are cult classics. This one just isn't entertaining enough for me to not regret wasting 90 minutes of my life though.About the only redeeming qualities in this film worthy of mention are the performances of Corey Feldman and The Iron Sheik (mostly the latter). Despite Feldman's awful lines, he is the one entertaining and likable character in the movie. The Iron Sheik is clearly the highlight of the film though. Although he has few lines and little screen time, all of it towards the end, he makes the difference between this film earning a "solid" one star vs zero stars (even if Amazon doesn't actually allow me to rate anything zero stars). Anyone who has seen or heard the Sheik before will recognize that he isn't even acting. He's just doing his regular schtick, albeit in costume. I seriously doubt that even half of his performance was scripted, which is what actually made it enjoyable.One scene in particular (spoiler alert!) that was off-the-charts stupid was a "chase" scene between a vehicle and the main characters who were riding a camel and a donkey, respectively. The highlight of the scene was the lead character (on a camel) screaming, "They're gaining on us!". No kidding. A vehicle with a gas engine gaining on a camel who doesn't seem to be in any particular hurry? What kind of screenwriter would be stupid enough to think that there was any way of making this scene look plausible?Oh, since no one else has mentioned it, this movie is not just a romantic comedy, but a musical as well. All of the musical numbers are original and all are cringe-worthy awful. You might enjoy the film more if you simply turn off the audio and just read the subtitles until the Iron Sheik's part comes along. You may want to leave the subtitles on even then though, if you want to understand anything he is saying. The few words he spoke that I could understand were either profanity or the word "jabrone".For an indie film, I have to say that the production values seemed good and the direction so-so. Kudos to whomever did Corey Feldman's make-up. That's about all the nice things I can say though.

I don't have a dog, but I do have a cat that seems nearly as stuffed as this pet bed. I bought him a cat bed when he was small, but these days it seems barely big enough for him to use as a pillow. So, I went ahead and ordered the Stainmaster pet bed, hoping that he will not outgrow this one. I got the large size and it certainly lives up to its name. I would absolutely agree with an earlier review here here stating that the padding is easily more than 4" thick. It's not very often that you actually get more than you pay for.Fortunately for me, my cat really did not need any coaxing to try this bed out. I was in a bit of a rush the day I received it, so I just tossed it on the couch on my way out the door. By the time I got home, my cat had already made himself comfortable on the bed and was sound asleep. He had even managed to drag a couple of his cat toys up on to the bed, which there is plenty of extra room for.The best thing about the bed (by far) is the outer cover material and the fact that it comes off for easy washing. It makes for very easy cleanup as cat hair doesn't seem to stick to the surface that easily. What hair does stick is easily wiped off by a damp cloth. The bed has not yet gotten to the point where I have needed to wash it. I suspect that it will not need to be done that often though, since the damp cloth trick and dusting it off outside seems to get the job done with little effort.

From the look of most reviews here, this toothpaste seems to be a touchy issue. I have been using this product on-and-off for about a year now. I have not had any type of allergic reaction that some here have mentioned, fortunately.I have some mixed feelings about this product insofar as to how well it works. For me, it actually seems to work a bit too well. The presence of baking soda is definitely noticeable and it seems to do a much better job at cleaning my teeth than most other toothpaste does. The baking soda in this formula is more abrasive than I have found in other brands though, which results in getting my teeth cleaner but also seems to result in wearing-away my teeth's enamel if I continue to use it more than a few days in a row. I have found myself alternating between this brand and a much milder one in order to keep my teeth clean without eroding them as a result. If I keep using this toothpaste on a prolonged basis my teeth become extremely sensitive to cold and heat, to the point of causing significant pain as well.I have no idea why this brand seems to be so much harsher than other baking soda types of toothpaste, but I would definitely not advise continued use if you can physically feel the enamel decaying-away after every brushing. I will probably end-up only using this product on an occasional basis rather than for daily brushing. It's great for an occasional deep-cleaning, but really is overkill for daily brushing in my experience.

I have had diabetes for the past 10+ years and am always on the lookout for food/snacks that taste good, yet are actually healthy for me. Glucerna's snack bars are definitely not health food by any stretch of the imagination, but if you are craving something sweet with chocolate in it this product is a much better alternative than most foods.On taste, I thought that they tasted quite good. You definitely will not mistake Glucerna for a Snickers bar, but they certainly are sweet enough to satisfy most people's chocolate cravings. The ones I received from amazon were quite moist and not at all chalky like some other reviewers have mentioned. One thing to keep in mind... If you get these from Amazon you will almost certainly receive a product that has not been sitting around in a warehouse for an extended period of time, due to the fact that Amazon sells so many of these and has a lot of turnover. If you buy these from a drug store, variety store, grocery market, etc. the product may very well have been sitting on the shelf for many months and will likely be nowhere near as fresh. So, if you find these on sale someplace, I would carefully check the expiration date. It may be that they are on sale because they are close to (or even past) the expiration date.As to being a proper food for diabetics, while these bars will definitely not make your blood sugar spike like a "real" candy bar would, it will still make it go up. You have to keep in mind that while there is quite a bit of fat, fiber and protein in these bars, they also have 20g each of carbohydrates. They have twice as many carbs as they do protein, so it isn't like you are eating health food. Glucerna bars would be best used as an occasional treat, rather than as an integral part of a "healthy" diet. They are not really "good" for diabetics, they are just much, much less "bad" than their sugar-laced counterparts. Honestly, given the near-impossible task of creating a sweet snack that is relatively harmless to most diabetics, I think that they have done an amazing job.The only real disappointment I have with these bars (outside of how expensive they are) is in the ingredients list. The ingredients list reads more like a science experiment than that of real food. It would be nice if they concentrated a little more on adding natural ingredients to their product than extending it's shelf life. I'm pretty certain that these bars are not GMO-free, organic, lactose-free, gluten-free, kosher or any other label that might sound reassuring to those of us trying to avoid overly-processed foods. I can only imagine how much more expensive they would be without using so many artificial ingredients though.As long as you are treating these as an occasional snack and have no illusions about these being a health food, I believe that they are a perfectly acceptable part of a diabetic diet. The product's relatively high cost and laundry list of artificial ingredients is the only reason I will not rate it at five stars.

First of all, if my cats were actually writing the review, they would likely give it much more than 3 stars. Then again, they also eat their own vomit. My cats seem to enjoy the "filets" or "shredded" variety as opposed to the pate, or mush as I call it. All of the different varieties seem to be combined in the reviews section though.As for me, I only really care about two things... How much it costs and how healthy is it for my cats to eat (not necessarily in that order). So far as the price goes, Friskies is a pretty good deal. With Prime membership I get 24 cans for under $11 with free two-day shipping. That's less than I pay for it at the local grocery store and a LOT less than at the pet store. Combine that with shipping right to my doorstep and it definitely comes out a winner in the price category.Insofar as to how healthy the food is for my cat to eat, I am far less impressed with Friskies. The #1 ingredient in every variety is water (or "moisture") which comprises 80% of each can. That's a lot of "moisture"! Next to that is meat and meat by-products. You don't even want to know where the by-products come from, but I assure you that you would not even feed them to your worst enemy's cat if you knew where they came from. After that comes a huge assortment of artificial coloring, artificial flavoring, wheat gluten, soy and a bunch of chemicals, some of which have vitamins in them.I'm no vet or nutritional expert, but I am pretty sure that about half of the ingredients listed aren't ones that my cat should be eating. Just check the ingredients for yourself and you will see what I mean. While my cats love this stuff, I feel guilty about feeding it to them in a similar way that I would feel guilty about feeding my kids junk food. Since they very rarely finish an entire can (or anywhere close to it) before it "goes bad" (insofar as they are concerned) I'm thinking that both my cats and conscience may be better off feeding them smaller quantities of healthier food. I haven't found one that they will eat yet, but will leave a review when I find one that they will.

The Viking Professional 5-Ply Casserole Pan is definitely a professional, high-quality product that is backed by the manufacturer with a lifetime warranty. It's surgical steel construction not only provides an extremely evenly-heated cooking surface, but also makes it the most impressive looking piece of cookware in my kitchen. The surface is as tough as it is beautiful and extremely lightweight for its size. Even the riveting is impressively done. The handles give the feel of being so solidly connected to the pan that you would think that they were welded together, if not part of the same mold.The lid and pan fit together extremely well and the weight of the lid helps to keep it very snugly in place while cooking at high temperatures. Due to how durable surgical steel is, it has not bent or warped at higher temperatures as cheap cookware seems to do. I seriously doubt that it would, short of anything less than being placed in a blast furnace.I had not used any surgical steel cookware until now and was a bit skeptical about just how non-stick it would be. It definitely exceeded my expectations in that department. The non-stick surface makes for less wasted (burned) food, less initial cleaning and great results from just popping it in an automatic dishwasher.Obviously, the price of the pan will keep a lot of people from choosing it. I think that it is best looked at as a long-term investment though. With a lifetime warranty (from a company that is not likely to disappear overnight) this is the last cooking pan you will ever have to buy. It may be the last pan that anyone in your family ever has to buy! It's versatile size also makes for less cookware you will need to buy in the end, which saves you both money and kitchen space. I would definitely recommend it.

While there is a lot about mouthwash preferences that is purely subjective (like taste), there is one major difference in TheraBreath Plus that sets it apart from the vast majority of its competitors. In a word, it's alcohol (or lack thereof). The vast majority of mouthwashes on the market include some form of alcohol. Amounts can vary greatly, but it is one of the most common ingredients you will find and what is largely responsible for the burning sensation you feel after using most brands. TheraBreath includes no alcohol, which makes it a much better product in my opinion.Alcohol is generally used in mouthwash because it is a relatively cheap ingredient that kills (through sterilization) most forms of germs and bacteria that cause bad breath almost immediately. Unfortunately, its effectiveness in stopping bad breath is extremely short-lived though as alcohol evaporates very quickly. As a side-effect, it can also cause dry mouth, which can actually make your breath worse after the initial effect has worn off.TheraBreath uses a different type of ingredient than alcohol to kill germs and bacteria called OXYD-8. While the formulation of OXYD-8 is proprietary, it most likely works similarly to hydrogen peroxide, which also kills germs but does not evaporate as quickly or have the same side effects as alcohol. By eliminating the quick evaporation effect of alcohol it makes the ingredients designed to give your mouth a minty type of odor (mostly leaf extracts) last longer. Natural oils help the product to coat your teeth and gums and provide a long-lasting effect that makes it even more effective.Besides lasting much longer, there is an even better side-benefit from leaving alcohol out of the product. You won't get the same "burning" sensation in your mouth as you will with most products like Listerine. You may get a very mild burning sensation from the Menthol, but it is quite weak in comparison. People have come to believe (for whatever reason) that the strong burning sensation that you often get after using alcohol-based antiseptics means "it's working". Unfortunately, that just isn't the case. The results you will get from TheraBreath clearly prove that.While the product is definitely priced on the high-end of the market, at least you will get what you pay for. The high price is due to the fact that it uses natural ingredients to replace more costly (and less effective) ones. The product has no artificial coloring or flavoring and is free of alcohol, gluten, sugar or GMOs. It's most likely one of the safest things you will put in your mouth all day! This product doesn't claim to be cheap, just natural and effective. In that respect, it definitely deserves five stars.

The KitchenAid Cast Iron 6-Quart Casserole Cookware is far and away the most well-constructed and versatile piece of cookware I have ever owned. It combines the durability and evenness of cast iron cooking with the benefit of having a very easy to clean and attractive enamel surface. KitchenAid certainly did not cut any corners when they built this thing. While it's price may be a bit on the high side, you tend to get what you pay for when it comes to cookware. This product definitely proves that point.If you haven't cooked with, or are not familiar with, cast iron cookware, you will probably be surprised initially by its weight. The KitchenAid weighs in at around 20 lbs, and that's without any food added to it. Fortunately, the handles on this model make it much easier to pick-up than most cast iron cookware. Most of them have a simple, single handle. The two handles on this model make it much, much easier to pick-up and work with than those types.Again, the quality construction of this item can't be stressed enough. It is most likely stronger and more durable than the material that they make black boxes on airplanes out of. About the only real downside to this is that if you are unlucky enough to drop this thing on your foot, you will almost certainly need a trip to the emergency room and be stuck in a cast for several months. Don't worry though. The cookware won't have a scratch on it.

I have had a number of cats over the years and have pretty much tested the entire spectrum of cat litter that has come on the market. I have tried everything from the ultra cheap-o store brands to the expensive, hi-tech crystals. While the crystals would probably still be my first choice based upon performance alone, Precious Cat gives you a lot more bang for your buck, so to speak.I live in a fairly rural area where everything from gas to cat litter seems to cost more than it does for people in the rest of the country. What first attracted me to Precious Cat was honestly the price. I usually buy some type of mid-range, clay cat litter here locally and a 20 lb bag usually costs somewhere around $8. With Prime membership I can have this delivered straight to my front door for roughly the same price as going out and buying it at a local store and a bag lasts twice as long. The only downside in this equation seems to be for the UPS guy, who has to lug a 40 lb box across the street. I'm not sure how he would feel if he knew that he was actually doing all that lifting to carry my cat litter. I digress, though.When it comes to performance, Precious Cat hands-down outperforms all of the generic store brands and other clay litters that I have tried thus far. The dust is absolutely minimal. I would say that 99% dust free is probably a good estimate, with the exception of the very bottom of the bag (the bottom of all all containers of cat litter seem to have more dust than the top, for obvious reasons). Odor control is excellent. It performs well enough to be scoopable, but is cheap enough that you can just throw-out the entire litter box if you don't want to bother.About the only downside to this brand is one common to all brands of clay cat litter. Cats (and in turn, people) tend to track it around the house pretty easily. Compared to crystals, you will likely spend more time sweeping your floor and brushing pebbles off your furniture. Considering the vast difference in price though, it doesn't really bother me that much. If you have unlimited financial resources, the crystal-type cat litters might be the way to go. For the 99% of the rest of us though, Precious Cat is definitely a winner.

I just recently upgraded to PowerDVD 15, due to the fact that the computer my Blu-Ray player is on was upgraded from Windows 7.0 to Windows 8.1. I already owned a previous version of PowerDVD, but it would not work under 8.1, so I had to find something new to play Blu-Ray discs on.While the last version of PowerDVD I had installed on Windows 7.0 without issues, this new version had problems. An error message told me to check the hardware compatibility list. I'd played Blu-Ray discs on the same computer before, so I knew that the specs were more than sufficient. I had to dig around on the Cyberlink website to determine what the real problem was. Apparently, the software will not run at all if you have the HyperV (virtualization) feature in Windows enabled. So, if you have this standard Windows feature activated, you will have to physically uninstall it if you want PowerDVD to work. I found it a bit annoying that I had to disable a basic feature of the operating system in order to use the software, but played along to get it working.Once installed, my CPU spiked as PowerDVD started scanning my hard drive and indexing anything it found that it was capable of playing. I don't want it cataloging files on my computer without permission, so I had to turn that feature off. I then inserted a Blu-Ray disc of The Expendables in my drive. The PowerDVD player immediately informed me that I was watching a copy of the movie The Avengers and gave me a long description of the movie that I wasn't playing. Weird.I rebooted the computer, changed some settings (most notably, I turned the option to download movie information OFF) and tried another Blu-Ray. It seemed to recognize the movie fine, but then I get some scrolling ad across the top of the screen for new movie releases. Apparently, there is no way to opt-out of having this software exchange data with (who knows) that downloads new advertisements for me to sit though. I find this lack of control over being bombarded with ads on a software title that costs a hundred bucks rather annoying. Equally annoying, I found that PowerDVD silently installs some type of background process that starts running every time you start Windows, whether you are using the player or not. There is no option to turn this program off. It has to be killed manually unless you want to tweak with your registry settings. Otherwise, it just runs 24/7, eating up memory. Doing what, I have no idea.One feature that I was eager to try out was the software's ability to play .iso files directly, without having to mount them as an extra hard drive. I have my movies stored on a disk linked to my computer network (Network Attached Storage). I use a different software program to play regular DVD .iso files across the network regularly and it works flawlessly. Unfortunately, there is no option in PowerDVD to access a networked drive. I ended up using Windows Explorer to access the drive, found the particular movie .iso file that I wanted to watch, right-clicked on the file, chose "Play with CyberLink Power DVD 15" and waited. The PowerDVD software launched, but the movie would not play. Eventually, the software froze completely and I had to kill it with Task Manager. Subsequent attempts to open networked .iso files always ended with the software crashing. This was extremely disappointing, as I have never used any type of media player that refused to play a file from a networked drive. This is really a show-stopper type of bug and I'm surprised that a piece of software could even make it to Beta testing without fixing something this basic.While I was eventually able to get the software to play Blu-Ray discs directly from the drive, the annoyances, bugs and limitations of the software are extremely frustrating. Considering the price, I really expected better.

While I found this 500GB drive to be amazingly small, lightweight and highly portable, I did not get anywhere near the speeds promised in the specs. I ran multiple benchmarks on two of my PCs and was never able to get past 100MB/s on short bursts, with averages being more like 60-70MB/s.Each was bench tested with all antivirus and antispyware temporarily disabled. Disk encryption on the drive was NOT enabled, which should have provided maximum speed. Attached are screenshots from both computers using using a variety of different USB 3.0 cables, including the one that came with the Samsung drive. All cables seemed to provide the same amount of throughput, so I am ruling out the provided cable as part of the problem. Disk was set up and formatted per Samsung instructions.Despite doing everything "by the book" multiple tests across different machines, with different cables on different versions of the Windows operating system all gave pretty much the same results.By contrast, I ran the same benchmark utility on each of my internal SSDs and they each clocked-in at between 300-450MB/s.One other item that bothered me... Samsung loads some sort of proprietary driver on my PC that stays on ALL the time, even when the external drive is disconnected. What it is doing and why it is sucking up my free RAM, I have no clue, but I don't like it.

The Tri-Lynx 12 LED Motion Sensor Light seems to fill the gap that exists in-between the line-powered outdoor motion sensor light fixture and the weaker, but more portable, solar powered, outdoor LED lights. If you have a location outside of your house that you know will need to be lit at night, there is probably already a light fixture there. If not, installing one can be a bit of an expense, but is usually well it. Alternatively, solar-powered LED lights are generally very inexpensive, but have a habit of not being terribly reliable (especially during the Winter months) or able to give off enough light to make one feel safe. This device seems to fill the in-between niche quite nicely and is definitely priced to be competitive against either solution.The range of detection this device offers seems to be a bit less than most outdoor fixtures would provide at around 8-10', but the range seems well-suited to how far away the lights themselves can illuminate. The limited range also cuts down on the sensor being set off by small objects (such as falling leaves or squirrels) which would quickly drain your batteries. The device accepts 3 standard AA batteries (batteries included!), which are non-rechargeable, but fairly inexpensive these days. You can usually find packs of them at The Dollar Tree, Dollar General or Harbor Freight for $1 or even for free on occasion. Amazon also offers them in bulk for quite a reasonable price.The unit is fairly lightweight and definitely not waterproof, so you will need to find a place to mount this that is not only well-protected from the elements, but which will not be easily dislodged from its mount. A fall to the pavement from 6'0 would almost surely destroy this device, so find a stable, steady place to mount it. It almost seems better suited to be placed indoors than out, which would be easily accomplished using its magnetic base (attach to your fridge, washing machine, water heater, etc.). For the price, you could probably afford to have a few around the house, which would come-in extremely handy during electrical outages or nights when you are too sleepy to find the light switch.

Having had diabetes for the past 10 years and been through a number of Doctors and insurance plans, I have necessarily switched between a number of different blood glucose meters. Cost aside (more on that later), the Freestyle Lite Blood Glucose monitor and kit is by far the most accurate, painless and convenient meter I have used to date.The meter's best attribute is probably its accuracy. As other reviewers have noted here, The FreeStyle Lite scored very high in a government study done on a number of different commercially sold meters. While I have found the majority of meters sold in the U.S. to be fairly accurate, there are a handful of cheap ones that provide very unreliable results. If you need absolute accuracy, the FreeStyle Lite meter is definitely the way to go.On the more practical side, its small size is definitely another big plus. The LCD display is large enough to read while keeping the layout simple and straightforward. Some of the smaller numbers (like the date) might seem a bit small if you have poor vision, but the majority of users are really only interested in one "number" and that is on the large LCD display. Another bonus is the meter's speed. Results take a fraction of the time as compared to many other meters I have tried. It may only be a few seconds' difference, but its still nice to have.FreeStyle Lite test strips let you draw the least amount of blood of any glucose meter I have seen that gives reliable results. Non-finger testing is also available, but you will still get the most accurate results from a finger poke.The last issue I will address is price. As with most brands, the meter will only give results from using the same company's test strips, which is why many times you can get a meter for free. The manufacturer knows that if you use their meter, you will have to use their test strips, which is why most test strips are so expensive. You will most likely fall into 1 of 2 categories. Insured or uninsured. If you are insured, the cost of the meter and test strips is largely immaterial. You will likely pay the same co-pay (if any) for all brands of meters and the test strips. If this is the case, definitely go with the FreeStyle Lite. If you are NOT covered by insurance and have to pay out of pocket, the FreeStyle Lite test strips are fairly expensive by most standards. They cost up to 10x what you will pay for test strips from other companies. If money is an issue, and you don't need pinpoint accuracy when it comes to results, you should probably shop around. There are other meters that are not nearly as small, accurate or fast, but give adequate enough results. If money is no issue though, this is definitely the blood glucose test meter that you want to buy.

I've read quite a number of books about spam control and network security. This is the first book I've seen thus far completely dedicated to tackling the issue of phishing though. Most books aimed at the IT industry concentrate on the technical aspects of how to stop these types of e-mails from ever getting to the inbox of users in the first place. This book concentrates not so much on the technical methods of stopping scam e-mails as it does getting inside the heads of both the phishing fraudsters as well as their potential victims.Phishing Dark Waters approaches the subject of phishing from two distinct angles. About half of the book is focused on the technical aspects of e-mail fraud while the other half delves into the psychology that goes into crafting a successful phishing campaign. Although network administration and psychology are two incredibly different subjects, the authors do an admirable job of presenting both sides of the coin while trying not to put the reader to sleep in the process. For the most part, it works. Switching back and forth between the two subjects is a bit abrupt in some places, but all of it is done in a logical manner that will not leave your head spinning.Anti-spam itself is a niche subject and phishing spam is really a niche of a niche subject, which explains the book's brevity at around 200 pages. It is by far the most complete work I have seen on the subject thus far though and belongs in the library of every network or mail administrator who takes the subject of spam control seriously. It is certainly one of the few books written for administrators I have read that is as "readable" as it is technically concise.

Powerline networking has certainly come a long way in recent years and the Netgear Powerline 1200 is the fastest, simplest and most secure powerline networking product I have seen to date.Setting up a networking connection does not get much simpler. You literally push a button on each extension a single time and that's it. You should not have to make any other adjustments to the unit. Ever. Setting up a secure, encrypted connection between extensions is similarly simple. Hold the same button down on each extension for about two seconds and you are done. No other adjustments should be needed. Ever.There have been some mentions in reviews about there not being an indicator to tell you whether or not encryption is working. That is true, but when first setting up encryption there is a different sequence of lights flashing to let you know whether or not encryption has been set up successfully (the set-up instructions describe this). So, that isn't really a factor for me, personally.Compared to setting up a typical wi-fi connection in your house, the Powerline is ridiculously simple. It is also faster and infinitely more secure. If you use a desktop or laptop and don't need the flexibility that a wireless system offers, the Powerline solution definitely seems to be the better choice. At the what this kit sells for, it is actually comparable in price to deploying a wi-fi solution as well.With the exception of limitations that are inherent with wired connections (namely, you are limited to moving any further than the reach of the outlet and cable you are connected to) I really can't find a single thing about this product to criticize. It is rare to find such complex solutions that you can just plug-in, push a button and "it just works". This happens to be one of them though.

This gift box definitely exceeded my expectations. While the picture looks nice enough, it doesn't really do it justice as compared to the actual product. The box is very solidly built and has an ultra glossy finish to it. Amazon shipping was fast and reliable and the price is definitely right. I would definitely recommend it.

This is definitely not a rickety old wagon from yesteryear, nor is it one of those tub-like contraptions that seems to have replaced it more recently. This Radio Flyer seems to be a totally new design that is more of a buggy for toddlers than a toy for hauling stuff around in. Compared to the older models, this one is probably more like riding around in a limousine for small kids.With the exception of the telescoping handle, this is one very solidly built wagon. The handle is a bit hollow and flexible to suit my taste, but it is just solid enough to be justified by the wagon's ability to easily fold-up and take-up a very limited amount of space.The canopy honestly seems to be more trouble than it is worth and doesn't protect from the sides at all for sun or rain, so I really don't see it being of much practical value. Fortunately, it is not an integral part of the wagon and can just be left off.Most of the wagon comes put together, but some assembly is definitely required. You will need a wrench, screwdriver and about 20-30 minutes of spare time. It's nowhere near as much hassle as some toys are nowadays. I've spent more time just getting some toys out of their boxes than it took me to assemble this.All in all, it is a bit pricey for something your kids will only be able to fit into for a year or two, but there are plenty of things that both kids and adults can use it for once they get bigger. Judging by the construction and sturdiness thus far, I would expect this wagon to last quite a number of years.

First, I will say that this is definitely an expensive kitchen faucet to own, but when you take a look of what the average kitchen sink faucet runs these days, the figure is really not that out of line at all.This happens to be one of the few products I have had the pleasure to review where the instructions were not only written in perfect English, but were extremely helpful, thorough and easy-to-understand as well. Bravo, Pfister! It does help to run through the installation guide WELL before you start the actual work as there are likely a variety of situations unique to your installation and you will need to take them into consideration long before you dive under the sink.The main thing to take into consideration is the nearest source of electricity. If you have a newer home with an AC outlet right under the sink, you are in luck. If not, you will need to do some planning well before you start the actual faucet installation.Whatever you do, DO NOT wire a AC connection anywhere that has a history of water being able to reach the AC outlet. That is just asking for trouble and could conceivably pose a health risk.In any event, I would make doubly sure that the cold water pipe (and sink, if metal) connected to this faucet is connected directly to a solid earth ground for maximum safety.Once you have all of the preliminary planning finished, the actual installation is a breeze. It obviously helps to have some prior plumbing experience. I have just enough from having installed a few home appliances to have made installation exceptionally simple.Although the unit has not been installed long, considering the great reputation of the brand and their famously great support. I would expect this faucet to last quite a number of years. If I have any problems in the future though, I will come back to edit this review.

I ordered one of LD's remanufactured ink cartridges (Cyan) for my Epson Workforce 7620 (you can find my review of the printer here on Amazon as well). After my printer gave me a message telling me that the original Cyan cartridge that came with the printer was no longer recognized, I figured that I didn't have much to lose going with a non-Epson brand cartridge. If it doesn't even recognize the ink cartridges that it manufactures itself, how big could the difference be?I had tried replacement ink refill kits for my older HP printers about 10 years ago. It was quite messy, labor intensive and gave mixed results, to say the least. These LD cartridges came complete and ready to use. No mess. No instructions needed. For $7.99 you really don't have much to lose. I placed my order on a Friday afternoon and the ink was delivered directly from the company on the following Monday. Essentially, I got free, overnight delivery! I live in California (where the company is located), so your results may vary.As for the ink and cartridge's quality, I had no problem getting the printer to instantly "recognize" the ink cartridge (ironic, since Epson couldn't even identify its own!). My limited experience with printing thus far has resulted in no noticeable difference in quality between the original ink and the new ink. I will try to remember to update this review in a few weeks when I have a better idea of the cartridge's long-term stability. For the moment though, these replacement cartridges would seem to be the deal of the century.

This is the second Baofeng/Pofung HT that I have owned, but all of their models seem to share two things in common: 1. They all are incredibly cheap as compared to just about every other manufacturer; and 2. Trying to figure out how to program their radios using the few instructions provided should be considered cruel and unusual punishment.After watching a ton of YouTube videos, and going against the direct advice of the manufacturer, I was able to get the Pofung BF-F9+TP working using a daily build of CHIRP software. The model is nowhere to be found in the CHIRP menu, so I just chose the closest Pofung model that was listed, which is the BF-F8-HP at the moment. You will save yourself a ton of time and trouble if you simply use the CHIRP software and choose RADIO>IMPORT FROM DATA SOURCE>REPEATER BOOK to directly import a list of local or national repeater frequencies. You can also use the RADIO menu to easily import scanning frequencies for NOAA weather broadcasts, FRS/GMRS and Marine radio. To add additional frequencies, simply use the other entries as a template and then click on RADIO>WRITE TO RADIO. Bam. Your radio is now programmed and ready to use.Of course, you will need a USB programming cable to interface the radio with your computer. A cable is NOT included with the radio. Fortunately, the same cable works with every one of their models I have tried it on thus far. I paid about $8 for mine from Amazon. Once the nightmare of programming your radio is finished you are left with a very attractive and functional (if not exactly durable) dual-band HT. It's definitely not a radio that would survive the type of punishment that a radio from Icom, Yaesu or Kenwood would take, but at the price it sells for this radio is practically disposable.For the money, there is very little to complain about insofar as the radio's performance is concerned. I have not made any contacts using simplex thus far, but from prior experience Baofengs do not seem to have a great battery life, so I would advise having more than the one battery that is included if you plan on spending any amount of time directly communicating with other handhelds.If you are thinking of using this as a FRS/GMRS radio, don't. It does not have FCC type acceptance nor does it conform with required output levels to operate on these frequencies legally. Same goes for the marine band, public service and commercial frequencies. Just don't. The radio's high 8W output power is probably offset by it's rather anemic stock antenna. The radio's SMA connection to the antenna is not compatible with most other HTs, so finding a better replacement might be difficult, at best. Economically infeasible at worst.For hitting the local repeaters now and then, this radio works well enough and is a great value. I'm definitely not ready to replace my Yaesu HT with it, but as a back-up radio you can hardly go wrong.  Van - KB6VWL

The Honeywell HPA250B is an impressive air filter on a number of levels. The most unique and useful feature of this product has to be the VOC sensor though. When tuned to the VOC mode the unit will automatically detect Volatile Organic Compounds (stink!) and ramp up its cleaning power to match the VOC level. When the air is clean and VOC levels have dropped, the unit then throttles itself down into low-power mode. This not only takes the need out of self-monitoring the air and adjusting the power level manually but greatly reduces power consumption while improving overall air quality. This is especially helpful while sleeping, as the highest setting is just loud enough to keep light sleepers awake but probably not loud enough to actually wake a person up.I have used a couple of Honeywell air filters in the past and they have all performed much better and lasted longer than competing brands in similar price ranges. The price point of this particular model is particularly good, considering the amount of square feet it can cover. I've tried quite a few different types of filters, but the combination of HEPA and charcoal pre-filters seem to work the best. A negative ion generators would be a nice addition to this model, but Honeywell has never really embraced NEG technology for some reason.Compared to my last Honeywell model, this model takes up quite a bit less space yet has equal or better air cleaning ability. The wide and tall "tower" design would seem to be ideally suited for air filtering as opposed to the short, stubby design of other Honeywell models. It also seems to result in less noise being made. The low setting is little more than a small amount of white noise from only a few feet away. The highest setting is considerably louder though and best used sparingly.The Android app is a bit of toss-up, insofar as trade-offs are concerned. The most useful part of the app simply lets you change the mode/speed of your air filter (or turn on/off). Another function allows your air filter to adjust its sped according to a timer or pollen counts for your area as determined by either entering your zip code or allowing the unit to turn on your phone's GPS (which will shorten your battery life considerably). The unit functions just as well without the app as with it, from my vantage point. The tradeoff? In order to use the app, Android users must agree to a staggering amount of control over their phone's features and can transmit a considerable amount of data about you and your phone back to Honeywell's "mothership", without your future need of approval. From a privacy standpoint, it simply is not worth the tradeoff for me. I would rather do without the app than agree to have my private information uploaded to Honeywell and sold for commercial purposes.Bluetooth issues aside, this is a very good product at a very competitive price with added bells and whistles that are actually quite useful;. Even if it cost a bit more it would probably be worth it, simply from the energy savings you can obtain from scheduling and/or use of the VOC sensor. I would have no problem recommending it.

The Panasonic Home Monitoring System not only provides an easy way to monitor your home from any location but is actually the center for an entire home automation system. Despite there being no mention of this in the product's description, you can also purchase a number of other add-on items to greatly extend the system's capabilities. For example, you can add a Smart Plug (Model KX-HNA101) to remotely turn on/off almost any electrical appliance (including lighting with an external cord) in your home via your smartphone. This device will even record the outlet's electrical consumption, so you know how much energy you are using. There is also a motion sensor unit (Model KX-HNS102) that can be used to trigger a number of camera functions or cause electrical outlets to turn off/on as well. Window/door sensors (Model KX-HNS101) can be purchased separately to trigger camera functions as well as appliances/lighting and indoor cameras (Model KX-HNC200) can be added to provide an audio intercom system and temperature sensor. Lastly, a digital/cordless phone system can be added (Model KX-HNH100) to arm/disarm the alarm system without the need for a smartphone as well as monitor system status.The overall system can be extended to four cameras, six cordless phones, four smartphones or Android-based tablets and any combination of up to 50 additional sensors or power controllers. Obviously, those devices cost extra, but the ability to easily expand the device to a quite extensive home-automation system is especially awesome.Set-up of the base system is extremely simple. The only problem I had was from another Android app switching between wireless networks automatically which initially prevented me from completing the set-up. I temporarily disabled the other app and that solved the problem permanently.Mounting the wireless cameras outside is little misleading, unfortunately. The video transmission may be wireless, but the camera and lights need electricity (provided by included power supplies). So, the cameras aren't entirely wireless. You would never know this from the picture on the product's page though, which shows someone mounting the camera on a brick wall (using wood screws!!!) and no wires. Fortunately, there is NO set-up in regards to the cameras. The phone app and hub just seems to connect to them automatically. Literally, plug and play.The camera's resolution is quite good as compared to most home monitoring systems I have seen, although I can't find the actual resolution anywhere in the documentation. The audio is also quite sensitive. Just make sure not to enable the audio monitoring via the app if you are standing close to the camera or you will trigger an audio feedback loop that will leave your ears ringing. The cameras could also be mounted indoors as well, I assume. Just make sure that you can locate a stud for use with the wood screws, because drywall alone may not support the camera/mount's weight.The central wireless hub works extremely well. I had no problem with reception or fading signal anywhere around the perimeter of my house. The DECT wireless technology they are using seems to be much stronger and more reliable than typical wi-fi systems. For maximum range, the hub should be mounted on a wall or on top of a tall object. The top of most refrigerators would probably be ideal as it would provide both height and a large metal groundplane to extend the reach of the signal.While I probably would not use this system for a large business or an installation needing extensive (more than four units) camera inputs, for the size of most small homes and apartments this system works great. The ability to extend it later on to a home automation system with temperature and electrical usage monitoring is just icing on the cake.

I purchased this 16V DC replacement power supply for a rather oddball Dell desktop computer that used an external power supply similar to a laptop. Although this is not listed as a direct replacement by the manufacturer I knew the specs that the power supply needed (output voltage, amps, plug polarity and size) and this one was a perfect fit. It also happened to be one of the cheapest OEM power supplies on amazon.Honestly, for the price this costs, I figured that I had almost nothing to lose, since the computer would not work at all without a power supply. Amazon delivered it quickly and it was exactly as pictured and completely to specs. I plugged it in and was finally able to get the computer running. After a couple of weeks of running nearly around-the-clock, the computer is still still doing well and I have had absolutely no problems.The power supply looks like any other replacement supply you will find. It does not seem to cut any corners and is solid enough that it doesn't even get warm while running. All in all, it does exactly what it is supposed to do and does it at an extremely affordable price. If I ever need a replacement power supply for my laptop in the future, I will definitely buy another one of these again.

This is a beautiful bracelet. It looks much nicer up close than you can tell by looking at it on the page. The clasp seems to be fairly sturdy and the rest of the design quite solid. I did not get in the gift packaging for my review, but amazon usually does a good job with its packaging. I do not buy a lot of jewelry, so I am pretty clueless as to how much it should cost. The price seems fairly reasonable for such a nice piece though.My only "complaint", if you can even call it that, is that it is much easier to tell exactly what jewelry is going to look like in person as opposed to seeing a picture on the web. Amazon does its best. Between pictures, descriptions and reviews you get a pretty good idea of what you are getting. There really isn't a substitute for seeing something in person as of yet though. Fortunately, in this case, the actual product was even nicer than the picture.

Cosco's new Light & Comfy car seat certainly lives up to its name in the weight department. It is extremely lightweight and easy to carry. I have no idea what type of government regulations that baby car seats come under, but I would have to assume that the product's light weight does not sacrifice protection for convenience.The first thing I noticed when I opened the box was the manual, or lack thereof. You can't really tell from the product picture, but there are stickers and sewn patches all over this thing with warnings and instructions, to the point of being a bit overboard. It kind of reminds me of NASCAR and how driver's cars are almost completely covered with stickers these days.There is no mention of what type of fabric the car seat uses, nor are there any washing instructions. It is obviously something synthetic though and not terribly soft. This is good from the standpoint of washing off messes or hosing it down, but probably not the most comfortable for baby. Since this is an infant seat only though, it probably won't be used for that long.As others have stated, there is no way of adjusting for the tilt of your particular vehicle's seat, so you will need to use something in-between to keep the car seat level. Considering the relatively cheap price this car seat sells for though, you would kind of expect it to be a no-frills type of product, which is essentially true. Whether the trade-offs are worth it depends totally upon your situation. Since you are only going to be using it for a few months before it is outgrown, the trade-offs are probably worth it though.

I will be the first to admit that I am not a gamer. However, the Turtle Beach Impact 100 Gaming Keyboard impresses me quite a bit. The first thing you notice when unboxing this product is how heavy it is. Upon inspection, the weight is not just "thrown-in" indiscriminately, the actual construction is of a very thick and high quality plastic that should survive a drop test at any height you would possibly drop a keyboard from in the real world without suffering so much as a scratch. The steel reinforcement inside definitely adds to its survivability. This is NOT anything like a "stock" or "replacement" keyboard that you will normally find in the $10-$50 range. I have literally used dozens of stock and replacement keyboards over the years and this one is by far the toughest I have ever tested. In fact, the only keyboards I have used that were even close to this product in respect to durability are ones built by IBM and HP for use in computers from the 1990's era. Those were considerably larger though and USB didn't even exist back then.The keys have a sort of depth to them that I have not seen in other keyboards before. They seem designed in an ergonomic fashion that would favor keeping your fingers on the keys and using them as "buttons" rather than something built for speed typing. Between that and the fact that it does not have the same feedback as an IBM soft-click keyboard (or clone), I would have to say that this keyboard was definitely not made for those of you who type 40+ words per minute. If you are using it for video games or are a hunt-and-peck type of typer, it will more than meet your expectations though.Some other features of the keyboard worth mentioning are the USB cable and connector. They are also of high-quality construction and should be much more durable than that of most  replacement keyboards you will find on the market. The USB plug itself is built tightly to specs and fits very snugly into any USB port you can find available. The reference to it having a braided cable refers to the braided shielding wire inside the cable. You can't actually see it, but braided shielding wire gives you a much better physical and electrical connection between the keyboard and computer. It is also greatly helpful in environments where there are high levels of RF radiation and will prevent electrical or RF interference. Most manufacturers use thin, foil shielding in their cabling these days, which may be thinner and cheaper, but is also more apt to break under any type of physical stress.I like that the shape of the keyboard does not waste space with an over-sized bezel or odd shape like many keyboards do these days. While you get a full-sized keyboard (for easier typing) you also get a keyboard that you can rest on your lap instead of only fitting on the top of a desk.The literature does not say if the keyboard is waterproof or even water resistant. That would certainly be nice to know if you are planning on using it in some sort of industrial environment. Perhaps the manufacturer will clarify this issue in the future. Overall though, it seems to be a great, sturdy keyboard that will most likely not only outlive my computer but probably me as well!

My first impression upon unboxing this new Hoover cordless vacuum was that the engineering and construction quality that went into designing and building this unit are absolutely top rate. All of the parts seem to fit together tightly and with precision. Controls are easily accessible and its design incredibly ergonomic. The vacuum swivels and tilts in such a fashion as to maximize the places that it can reach well beyond expectations. It's weight is light enough to lift and carry around with ease, yet not so lightweight as to feel cheap or flimsy.First impressions aside, once I started vacuuming it became apparent that this model has some definite strengths and weaknesses. Some of its problems are inherent with all models of cordless vacuums I have tried thus far. Compared to most other cordless vacuums, this model is by far the best I have ever used though.Compared to other cordless, upright vacuums, the Hoover is robustly powered. The two rechargeable batteries that come with the unit are a bit bulky, but simple to replace and provide enough longevity to clean the average home without worrying about running out of juice. You can maximize the life of the batteries to an even greater extent by manually switching the rotating brush on/off or using the "boost" feature to only use the maximum amount of power when you need it. Compared to corded vacuums this model is surprisingly quiet, although it does make a rather dreadful, high-pitched noise when switched into the boost mode.The vacuum seems to work best on laminate and vinyl flooring. The fibers of the rotating brush are soft enough not to scuff floors with hard surfaces, but strong enough to pick up quite a bit more dirt than you normally would by turning off the brush feature. It's small head size lets you get into tight corners and under low "bridges" that the average vacuum cleaner simply can't. If your flooring is almost entirely hard surfaces, I would say that the Hoover is strong enough to actually replace high-quality corded vacuums with.The Hoover's biggest weakness is in dealing with thick carpets and handling large amounts of hair or "fuzz" that you inevitably find in carpeting of this type. While the Hoover is definitely a huge improvement over most cordless vacuums in regards to cleaning power, it simply can not compare to high-quality, corded upright vacuums like you would expect from something like a Dyson. We've all seen the commercials where a vacuum cleaner has suction powerful enough to suspend a bowling ball in mid-air or gobble-up marbles and other small objects like a riding lawnmower cuts through grass. This is NOT one of those vacuums. The power simply is not there and while you may get a perfectly acceptable-looking cleaning done on thick carpeting, you will never achieve the type of deep cleaning that a well-built corded vacuum will provide.For what it is built to do though, the Hoover is an outstanding piece of equipment, although I would be hesitant to spend the amount of money it costs if you have any type of carpeting that you want to thoroughly clean. Besides its lack of power (as compared to corded models), about the only problem I had with this model was its regular habit of the hose being plugged-up by pet hair, lint and carpet "fuzz". There seems to be a permanent bottleneck in the hose between the cleaning head and dust compartment that requires removing the hose and physically digging out the contents until the hose is unplugged. There is about a six inch section of hose near the head that is always the first place for contents to get stuck. I'm certain that this is more of a design problem than one specific to the unit I received, since other reviewers have mentioned the same thing. If you don't mind getting your hands dirty two or three times during the course of cleaning your house, this might not be a big deal to you. It did bother me though, as having to dig through chunks of dirt to unplug the hose of an absolutely brand-new vacuum cleaner was not something I had expected to be doing.All in all, if you have rather light cleaning requirements and a combination of hard floor surfaces, the Hoover may very well be all you need for regular cleaning and dusting. It's flexibility and light weight make it almost perfect for the job. If you have any significant amount of carpeting, especially of the shag or deep-pile variety, this would definitely not be my go-to vacuum though.

This is one of the only new pet foods I have ever given to both of my cats where each of them took to it right away, Considering how picky they can be about new foods, that is really saying something. They are both used to being fed fairly high-quality dry foods, so they have been pretty much spoiled from birth. It's nice to know that there is something else that I can get them to eat.I would not have even tried to get them to switch to this brand were it not for the fact that it is 45% protein and uses real trout as it's #1 ingredient. The fact that it doesn't use corn, wheat or artificial coloring is also a big plus. Corn and wheat may be cheap fillers, but there is very little to be said for their nutritional value to cats or dogs.About the only downside to this product is the addition of soy and pea proteins. These proteins are much cheaper to use as an ingredient than meat protein is, but is much more difficult for cats to digest. You wouldn't normally see a cat munching on peas or soybeans, which is a good indicator that it is not something that their bodies will absorb all that naturally. It's a good "gimmick" to boost the protein content percentage, but not much else positive can be said for these added ingredients.
