Still, it's better for them than corn or wheat, which is what normally passes for cat food.I'm not sure if the price this is selling at for the moment is normal or not, but $36 seems a bit pricey for a 6lb bag of dry cat food. I can normally get a 16lb bag of a decent brand for $10 less than that. This seems to be a newer product though, so perhaps they are still experimenting with the price. It certainly is a decent product, but not worth what it is priced at for the moment.

The SilBlade FLX1919 Premium Beam Wipers seem to be a vast improvement over the cheap replacement wiper blades I usually buy when I get my oil changed.Despite the stupid-proof installation instructions, it took me awhile to figure out exactly how to install these. I would have to attribute this to user error rather than to anything having to do with the product though. Once attached, the blades were quite sturdy and fit well with my 2002 Ford Escape. The packaging was also in a quite minimalistic cardboard box, which I definitely prefer as compared to struggling to remove blades from some sort of plastic packaging that requires a knife to cut through.Fortunately, if you can call it that, it started raining the day after I installed these wiper blades and there hasn't been a dry day since. The curvature and construction of these blades allows me to keep up with the rain with the wipers on low, rather than having them go at full-speed. That is quite impressive. Although I haven't had these blades long enough to vouch for their durability, they have gotten quite a workout over the past week and seem to have come through fine. Definitely would recommend.

The above title pretty much sums up my experience with the Artaste 4890 Vertical Rabbit Style Corkscrew Kit with Foil Cutter. First of all, the most notable thing about this product is its complete lack of documentation. There are no instructions inside and only a picture of the unit on the outside of the box, which really doesn't help.After studying the contraption for a few minutes, I decided to try uncorking a local wine that was on sale at Safeway for $4. I didn't want to test it only anything important with no idea as to how/if it actually worked. My first attempt failed. I got the corkscrew into the cork, but the cork would not come out. It did work on the second try though. The cork was lifted up into the innards of the contraption, which made it a bit difficult to remove. It took a minute to figure out how to get the cork to more easily release.As for the foil cutter... Where is it? What does it look like? Is it part of the main product or did it go missing in transport? I have no idea, since there are no instructions and no diagram showing how any part of the device works.Compared to other "normal" wine bottle openers I have used, this device is needlessly complicated, takes up WAY too much space and for $30 you would think that it would at least include instructions. I'm pretty sure that I have never paid anywhere near this price for a corkscrew bottle opener, yet every other product I tried was simple enough to not need instructions, smaller and considerably cheaper. I really do not get what all of the fuss is about with this thing. It looks nice enough, but is hardly a "better mousetrap". If it were just a little heavier, it might make a good door stop.

As one of PBS' higher-profile original series, Frontline has had a history of producing some great reporting. Unfortunately, it also has had a habit of mixing "news" with politics and political opinion, which is a very slippery slope for a broadcaster that is being kept on life support by politicians and taxpayer's money. While I find very little of Frontline's programming politically overt, there does seem to be an unspoken undercurrent of liberal influence, which seems to be where most of PBS's political and financial allies keep camp.For this review, it was suggested that I watch the episode Frontline: Egypt in Crisis. I found it to be fairly typical of most Frontline episodes, so I will go on to review that episode here.Again, typical of most Frontline episodes, this one is the the product of literally hundreds of hours of observation, reporting and filming. It is inevitable that such a massive piece of work will eventually be whittled down to a single 60 minute segment, but that is the reality of journalism these days, unfortunately. Although there is plenty of footage and some interviews, the bulk of the show is presented as narration, supported by accompanying video. This method of news production unfortunately seems to rely heavily upon the personal interpretations of the reporter, rather than lending itself to a "just the facts" type of presentation. In essence, human reporting's greatest weakness is that reporters are humans, each filled with their own personal imperfections, biases and sometimes lack of comprehension regarding the subject being reported.In this episode, while I don't see any overt political bias, I do sense a serious lack of understanding by the main reporter in grasping the situation's "big picture" as a whole. Instead of tackling the real elephant in the room (the goals of the religion of Islam and its followers) the reporter attempts to describe the Muslim Brotherhood and its leader Mohammad Morsi as simply being part of a political movement that dates back less than 100 years. I believe that this is being done either purposefully, or unintentionally, to provide viewers with a type of political movement more easily understood by Americans. In fact, it is a gross oversimplification to paint the revolution in Egypt as being part of a political struggle. The truth is simply far too complicated to easily explain within the span of 60 minutes, so a storytelling "shortcut" is taken to make everything easier to comprehend for an American audience, but winds-up distorting the picture in the process.What the reporter in this episode seemingly fails to understand is that the Muslim Brotherhood is NOT a political organization, nor is it a humanitarian organization. It's goals are very much the same as groups like Al Queda and ISIS. That is, it's chief objective is to impose Muslim rule and Sharia law across every nation on earth. Rooted deeply in the Koran and the Islamic faith, the use of terrorism, murder and martyrs is standard practice and supported by fully 30% of the Egyptian population. Those are Morsi's supporters. That percentage is actually considerably higher in other middle eastern countries. Egypt has traditionally been a moderate in the region. The ends always justifies the means in this sort of mentality and there is no way that ANY Islamic state (like the one Morsi and the Islamic Brotherhood tried to bring to Egypt) can remain at peace as long as there are non-muslims living within their borders or near them. The Koran demands that "infidels" be killed or taken as slaves. There simply is no legitimate "middle ground" in the teachings of Mohammed. This is the elephant in the room that American reporters fear to report, lest they be accused of being politically "insensitive".Without delving into the real reasons for Islamic revolution, this Frontline episode only serves to obscure the underlying facts in favor of a politically-correct narrative that is dumbed-down to the point where people watching it THINK that they have actually learned something. Perhaps this is what the public actually wants, rather than to be confronted with the more dismal reality of the situation? Unfortunately, only a very thorough education and understanding of religious and political dynamics of the middle east will give one insight into the subject of Egypt In Crisis. I'm afraid that this episode sacrifices the complexity of truth for politically correct oversimplification.

I seem to recall Clearasil from my youth as having a lot of drying, irritating facial products in it that actually contributed to breakouts. I was shocked and pleased to receive this modern kind of Clearasil, with gentle products suitable for sensitive skin and a really effective exfoliating ingredient - the salicylic acid.I've been using these wipes longer than the time I would normally experience breakouts over facial irritants. And no problems at all! My skin looks almost radiant. My nose pores are clean and look smaller. My whole face looks more even and smoother.I will definitely be purchasing more of these wipes when I use them up. I can manage to get by with one wipe for my entire face and neck at bedtime each day, carefully using all the parts of the (admittedly) small wipe to get all the moisture off. So I can make a packet last an entire month.NOTE: This is my second round of buying these - and this time, I got a six pack! Six months of good, clear, adult skin.I realize the idea for these wipes is for on the go use, but I've already added to my nightly routine and appreciate the simplicity of a wipe. It's replaced the expensive liquid salicylic acid exfoliator that I used to apply with a cotton ball.The scent is mild and clean, and there is no burning sensation that one would associate with a formulation containing alcohol or menthol/mint compounds. There is no residue left on my face.I'm extremely pleased - and, I have to admit - I wasn't expecting much. Clearasil seems to have updated with the latest advances and research into what is actually good for skin. I follow this up with a good moisturizer with antioxidants and am good for sleep.Highly recommended.

Words cannot express how clearly I hate this bird feeder. Or rather, how much the birds hate this feeder.I'm a novice feeder. I'm pretty good at wild bird IDing...in, you know, the wild. With binoculars, while camping. I'm no good at luring the birdies to my home to watch them feed at my leisure. I was feeling particularly depressed at the time I bought this, and needed some light happy cheering up. So I read the reviews and carefully selected this one. It looked simple; it looked good. Most of all, it looked foolproof - you put it on your window, put seed in, and waited in comfort for the birds. Free food! Come and get it. EAT AT JILLY'S!You just know how this tale's going to end.First off, my feeder arrived broken. The thin, cheap plastic was cracked. Bright and chipper, like the birds I hoped to see, I used a bit of glue and a clip to hold the plastic together until it dried. Then I plopped the feeder on my window, added the seed my local ACE recommended, and waited.Weeks later, and with no birds, I tried scattering seeds nearby. Maybe the birds couldn't see the feeder and I could leave a little trail of goodies? Still no birds. At that point I was convinced they needed a stick to land on while feeding...I cleverly added a stick, and of course that didn't work. Overthinking is my specialty.I decided my entire approach was wrong, and I needed to figure out where the birds were, and move the bird feeder there. I saw that little birds liked the back window that had morning sun, and moved the little house there. No birds yet. So I scattered seeds along the ground under the window, along the window frame, and along the back yard - anything to get birds to come near the dumb bird feeder that got such nice rankings on Amazon.Finally, one morning, an actual bird hopped along the ground under the window, eating the seeds I scattered there. I was absurdly happy. Then he left, ignoring the feeder. A week later, a bird ate the seeds I scattered along the window frame.No bird ever, EVER went into the bird feeder - the seeds were piled as perfectly as the day I piled them. Until one morning when the glue popped open and all the seed spilled out, freeing the birds even from having to look at the feeder they hated so much.The seam re-breaking actually pleased me. I grabbed the feeder and a hammer and went to my potting bench, intending to smash the thing into smithereens. I even got my husband to film the event to post here on Amazon for all humans to enjoy, yet that pleasure was even denied me - the plastic refused to smash properly, and just deformed weirdly around my hammer. Screw it.SUMMARY: You're on your own with this one. Maybe it was the glue that turned off the birds and I should have just sent it right back when it arrived broken. Or maybe the feeder sucks in every way.

50 exhausting, dirty, wet minutes later, and my large Scouring Stick is a nub.Let me explain. In a normal household, with normal toilets, these things should last a good while. They arrive a good half foot long - a nice chunk's worth, oh wow! I've used tiny bit of pumice to clean the poopy rings around typical toilets before, and said rings come right off. Easy peasy.This house is an old trailer with three toilets that I doubt have been properly scrubbed since the early 70s. This isn't hyperbole. This neglected ugly trailer home has been Student Party Central for decades. I know this because I found a Time Capsule in the attic stating just that...and I also talked to dozens of enthusiastic people in town telling me of all the outrageous events they've been to here as time ticked by.Don't get me wrong. I don't dislike parties and I've been a student...but I'm also familiar with just how clean things aren't in these kinds of places, much of the time. 'Nuff said.I started with the easiest toilet - mine - the one I give a good 'swish and scrub' to (the Flylady Way) after each use. After sitting on the floor and scrubbing, and scrubbing and scrubbing, I realized just what I'd gotten into. I moved into my husband's office toilet and scrubbed so vigorously that the floor became a pond...but at some point the bowl was mostly clean. So I left the pond for him to deal with, and took my rapidly dwindling pumice stick into the worst toilet - that in the main hall.Okay. I'd been using soap each time, and doing a lot of flushing to see what still remained to be scrubbed. I also had to stick MY FACE in each toilet bowl to scrub under the rim, which is a delightful experience I recommend to everyone at every opportunity.At some point my husband walked by and asked why I wasn't wearing gloves, at which I yelled, "BECAUSE THE PUMICE KEEPS MAKING HOLES IN THEM AND IT'S USELESS AND THERE ARE NO GLOVES LEFT GO AWAY."After 50 minutes of pure scrubbing I thought my elbows would fall off and my huge pumice stick was small a round cobble. Enough. I'm saving the pumice cobble to scrub away the iron stains in my bathroom sink once I've recovered from toilet bowl hell.Not today. Time for a scalding hot bath to wash away the stink of...I'm not even going to finish this sentence.

SPOILER..........OKAY, seriously, no one in their right minds would be reading or watching this as a stand alone movie...This will make zero sense if you haven't seen the series in order, and paid a great deal of attention. Actually, it's best to watch this after a BSG series re-watch, where you can mentally slot this all into the places where it should go. This is not told in any logical fashion - it is an attempt to fill in the gaps, and is an admiral (no pun intended) attempt, truly, since everything production-wise is well and truly wrapped up by the time they pulled this little feat off. Major kudos for everyone they managed to pull back in for this, for the decent attempt at production values, for the music, for Tricia Helfer, and my gods the brain frakking effort to give the fans a treaty treat. Don't forget to watch the deleted cuts, which add to the story.I keep wanting to make an Ultimate Series Re-Watch Guide, since BSG is SO GOOD (but SO IMPENETRABLE to the dilettante). In my head, I'd put the pieces of this movie right where they need to go, from the very VERY beginning before the miniseries (or "Before the Fall", at the very last episode and OW MY BRAIN), then during the miniseries...then all along the first three seasons, during the webisodes that relate, and ending when the Cavils meet and (SPOILER SPOILER OH WHATEVER WHY ARE YOU READING) die.In Summary:The Plan is worthwhile for the rabid BSG fan, but not important if you really haven't been paying attention. It's a Love You note to the fans, and if you love BSG back, then buy it to thank everyone involved. Seriously, the gesture is important, and that's why we also bought Dr. Horrible, even though we could get it free online - to thank Joss Whedon for his Horrible Awesomeness. But The Plan really does fix a lot of dangling plot threads, shows Trica at her most versatile, explains poor Boomer, throws a lot of cute Cavil evuls at us, and gives Anders a lot more to do, with bombs! Our series would be incomplete without The Plan. It's all very 'downstairs' to the 'upstairs', which is fun by itself.

We had to return this product, and I'm normally a BIG fan of Havahart. I routinely use the larger traps to humanely catch, spay, and release feral cats, as a volunteer project elsewhere. For itty bitty mice, though, these small ones don't work without a lot of hassle. They are super tricky to set without snapping them shut on your fingers...and then the mice are STILL able to get the bait without tripping the doors. Every night. Fiddle, fiddle, fiddle. Mounting anger. Rough edges making our fingers bleed. Tripped traps, open doors, no results - unless you count my husband swearing to get poison next, and me begging to try something humane, anything else, please, please.After a lot of arguing, we ordered the highly ranked little green trap made of plastic - which worked like a dream from day one, and every day thereafter, until we caught all five mice in our pantry. We bade them live a nice life along the banks of the Swannanoa River. No more problem. It looked too simple to work, but sometimes, simple is the way to go.

Thank God for Tums. They take away the pain, they don't taste like chalk (at least these berry-flavored ones don't), and they even add Calcium to my diet. My husband prefers the minty ones, but I don't like those at all: each to their own. There are now enough varieties of Tums to make everyone happy.The bottles are study enough to reuse for craft projects or in the office - I put thumb tacks and  paper clips in them, once rinsed out. Bombproof jars with good lids/nice openings.

These are just lovely. Sometimes you want a single clip, for whatever: scarves, a purse, a pair of gloves, lingerie, things you are drying in the bathroom/laundry room. They also look good, even professional.You get three in a pack. My uses:1. I have one in the kitchen for my dishwashing gloves (this is what I bought them for - I never use the gloves if they live hidden under the sink).2. One goes over my shower curtain rod to dry hand washables.3. This leaves only one for my closet. It's holding up a freezer sized Ziplock bag containing my next holiday costume (in this case, my sparkly 4th of July outfit. I love dressing up in wacky fun for every holiday, and put everything together in a bag to get ready WEEKS beforehand).The clips are well-made with no sharp burrs or edges to catch the skin or delicate clothes, and open cleanly without needing a lot of force. They also stay closed on their own, so nothing falls out accidentally. The rubberized tips make sure nothing gets abused. I like them and want more for my closet.My only complaint is that three is a little stingy. A pack of ten would be about right.

This is an extremely well made, thoughtfully designed solar reading light. It is very lightweight but sturdy, charges in almost any amount of daylight (it even charges by the light of indoor bulbs), and has an adjustable metal stand that you can also hang the lamp by.I've used the d.light lantern while RVing, backpacking and paddling. I also use it in my own bedroom for night reading, since it uses no electricity and I get a kick out of that. It charges up right away the next morning, so I don't have the worry that I have to conserve my batteries. I can just use this, worry-free. :)It burns in a nice bright light, sufficient for reading and doing detailed tasks. The beam is nicely focused. This is not a "diffused light" area lantern; it's more like the light from a headlamp. I also own the d.light lantern-style solar light, and that one is what I use for lighting a larger area.The little metal stand adjusts for a range of positions for either collecting photons or emitting them. The directions suggest turning the solar panel to catch the light directly, but since even indirect light charges this device, it's easier to use than the directions suggest.I appreciate that the light was made for third world countries and especially jungle living - this thing can withstand my typical gear abuse.Highly recommended for anyone looking for a simple, inexpensive, durable solar task light.

I'm in love with this headlamp flashlight, and I've had a lot of them. For one thing, it's got LED bulbs in them, which are BRIGHT and last a long time. For another, it's comfortable on my head, easily adjusts to shine light where I need it, and even offers more than one light application. That I can use red bulbs or blinking options is pretty sweet.I really just use the steady white light. I camp constantly and need the light for reading, cooking at night, gathering firewood, walking around in the dark...the red is nice for the times I need to get up and not disturb others, or to retain my night vision (as in star gazing), or for leaving the eyes of the wildlife alone.I'll be doing a month long solo van camping and kayak trip down the Carolina's Outer Banks Islands, and this will be a key gear component.

This is the strangest chopstick set I've ever used. They are extraordinary light (hollow metal - aluminum?), and super slippery. I'd say they aren't for Gringo beginners, since their gripping power is zero. It's all in the technique.There are shallow circular ridges spaced evenly along the tips of the chopsticks, so, okay, the gripping power isn't exactly zero, but seriously, it's close.Another thing to note is that these are working chopsticks, intended for direct use in your kitchen drawer. There's no satin or velvety drawstring bag to pull out and impress the guests for your special Asian meal. The packaging is simply intended for delivery, not for storing, or re-use. I wouldn't give these as gifts, either.My sense is these are the real deal - the utensils used by people at home in the Orient on everyday occasions. I don't actually know anything - this is just me, guessing. They aren't the high end 'silver' versions - there's an obvious seam running the vertical length of each one. They're nice enough for everyday use. :)So I put them right in my own kitchen drawer, next to the forks. I make a point of practicing with them when I think of it. They clean easily, and there is no chance of rotting, as wooden sticks might.Received as a review sample.

This is a well sewn, 8 inch thick belt, with just the right amount of Velcro. The stitching is solid. It holds up to a full day of working out, gardening, hiking, doing projects around the house, or adding back support to whatever I need.At the end of the day, it gets a little floppy in the middle. I just do some quick, gentle hand washing (gentle, in cold water with shampoo) and let it hang overnight. It is set and ready for the next day.I like the color. It's not a teenage pink, but more like a calm, cool fuchsia.Personally, I like to wear it a bit higher than the waist, so that it holds my boobs in securely while I work out or do chores. I find it very comfortable that way. I am around a 36-38D, and I appreciate the snugginess. Really, for me, it's more for back and boob comfort, than any weight loss, and I would fully recommend it for ladies looking for something to wear around the house for tasks, gardening and anything else at home where a bit of extra comfy support would be welcome.I'd also recommend it for anyone with Autism, since it's very huggy and comfortable, and sold at a much more affordable price than most of the compression gear at Autism shops. I've found I can even wear it under shirts and it's barely noticeable.Review sample received and appreciated. Aspergirl approved!

This is a sturdy red cable that lets you view photos, videos, movies and homemade whatnot, from your phone to your television. I had some issues setting it up, since the directions that arrived were (extremely) lacking. I think Skiva assumes you know what you're doing. I'm more of an average user (not an el33t3), so I had to do some video searching.Once I figured it out (not easy), I was able to use my Samsung Galaxy Note (but not my Samsung Galaxy 3, 4 or 5) with my TV. It really is a good idea. I have a huge television, and it's neat to turn it into a camera display. I have thousands of photos on my phone, after all. No joke. Thousands of thousands of pretty nature shots to enjoy on the big screen.My suggestion: Wait for the bugs to be worked out and get something more universal, something more plug and play with all kinds of devices. This one is just too confusing. I know there's an adapter for the other size pins...but I'd have preferred said adapter to be included, and avoid asking everyone to be just so shiny about it all. I can barely remember what remote to use between the TV, DVD player, Synology...actually, our DVD player is the Game device with its weird control thing - don't make me learn all this, okay? Ow.I received this as a review sample and really should have known it would be more complicated than I was up to. STILL: IT'S A GOOD IDEA. I'd wait for a simpler version.

At first I was charmed with these spoons, and feeling so clever with myself. I have a lot of powdered supplements I take on a daily basis, and I need very small amounts. I read the reviews here and saw that people had done the work for me in measuring what exactly a TAD and DASH and so on meant. I ordered the spoons and used a Sharpie to write the actual amounts on the backs of the spoons.Clever me.Until after a few uses rubbed the amounts right off. The stainless steel is too smooth. Now I'm stuck with useless guessing again, or these choices:1. Open up Amazon and look up the amounts on the reviews (which is annoying)2. Print up the amounts and tape them in my bathroom (which is still annoying)3. Get another pair of spoons with actual amounts on them (which I did, and now I'm not annoyed at all)My POV: If you have a way to engrave these spoons with the amounts  you need (- ie - 1/16th, etc, then go ahead and bother with them). Or, order them as a gag gift for someone who might find such archaic amounts cute.HONESTLY: If the manufacturer would  - just a suggestion - put the actual amounts somewhere on these spoons, it would be a five star item. FIVE, all five, all great.

These are pretty good. I use them for quick dish washing, quick gardening chores, and yes, food handling - but for handing my OWN personal food. I don't like touching food. At all. I just don't like touching anything wet or messy.I also use them for pulling poison ivy. I put a set on, then pull my rubber poison ivy gloves over them, and get to pulling. So I end up double gloved. I keep the rubber gloves and toss the plastic 'under' gloves.I keep sets of them in my first aid kits (in my car, in my backpack and the big one under the sink). Some go in my recycling area and some go in my craft area. I think my husband took a few for his workshop.What I'd like is some way to store these in the kitchen for food prep that is more attractive than the ugly paperboard box it comes in. I'll keep looking: something will turn up, probably in a thrift store - maybe a ceramic jar. In the meantime, I got 500 of these at a cheap price, and many many uses.

We really wanted this to make perfect little Death Stars. We even brought them out on Star Wars Day (May the 4th Be With You) and our guests all exclaimed in happiness....but the being the perfectionist Siths that we are, we really were displeased with our efforts. There's no way to do this right, unless you use the Force, I guess.Our Death Star cubes came out:- Cracked- With little knobs on top- with external rings - not trenches - around the middlesSo, I wrote the manufacturer (who provided these as review samples), who suggested I was filling them too much. Well, yes, I am a Sith who can read, and the instructions clearly say not to fill them too much, since water expands. There is even a Fill Line, beyond which a Padawan should not fill the cubes. I'd paid attention to all that the first several times I tried to make Death Star Ice Spheres.In my next attempts I went really, really below the fill line. I ended up with half stations, of course, which was worse than my overfull stations with rings around the middles and knobs on top.Another thing worth mentioning is that the bottoms are impossible to remove. The tops come right off, but to get the bottoms off, we have to either:1. use the microwave2. knock the bottoms against the sink several dozen times and make the Death Stars even more cracked3. use hot water on the bottoms4. pry and pry and pry at the bottoms until our fingers are like HOTHBTW, the hot water and the microwave systems work but create melty ice spheres that look nothing like Death Stars, as one would expect.In the end, I have to assume that neither my husband or myself have very little Force skill, since there are a lot of glowing reviews here of perfect Death Stars. Lord Vader would Force-choke us both. We shall, of course, re-debouble our efforts. We want cute little spheres of cold destruction and to inspire fear in the galaxy. :(

These are okay. I'm kind of just glad there are seltzer flavors out there, but they don't taste as good as I expected (they are sort of 'flat'), and are a little messy to use. I have to keep them in the fridge, I have to keep a little 1/8 measuring spoon by them and rinse the spoon after each use (it is sticky)...and the entire little boxed operation isn't cheap.I'm actively looking for better ways to flavor my seltzer so I won't have to use this kit again.It's okay for a starter set to get going with your new Soda Stream, and that's the best I can say about it. I like the raspberry flavor best, mixed 1/8 teaspoon with 1/8 teaspoon lime.I've found a lot of things around the house that also work, like vanilla, lime juice squeezers (or lemon), a tiny bit of any juice of any kind, a tiny bit of any liquor...the key is using a small amount of something so that you get an 'essence', rather than a flavor.In any case, three stars for just getting this for the FIRST time with your Soda Stream/seltzer-maker. After that, you should be able to make your own seltzers with 1/8 - 1/4 teaspoon of any other juice, mint, lemonade, cream soda, amaretto, vanilla, Tang, tea, whatever.

These are fabulous labels. I like a lot of things about them:- big enough to write on without cribbing it- big enough to read what you wrote from a distance- sturdy enough to stick in the ground without effort- slightly textured so your Sharpie doesn't rub off (this is a big issue with a lot of the slick labels)- the texture means they won't be so shiny in the sun the reflection isn't painful to my eyes- 100 of them for the price point of 5 bucksBasically these are well thought out - actual gardeners must have been consulted. I can use both sides and there's room for instructions, even. I really like these. Not cheapie dollar tree labels that break as soon as you try to break dirt.I got these as a review freebie but would have bought them anyway. I was reusing the old ones I was getting with last year's plant starts (using whiteout and Sharpies, and finding that really annoying to do). THESE ARE GREAT!I put a rubber band around my nice, big stack and placed them on my potting bench with my Sharpie.

I was thrilled to get these as a review sample. I opened the box, slipped them in my favorite daily sandals,and kept on going. I wear a woman's size 9, and they barely made my shoes feel tighter on top. What they DID do was make them more comfortable. Loads more comfortable. What I tend to do is find a pair of shoes (from a thrift store), which I wear to death, whether or not said shoes are actually good for my feet. These make that pair better for my poor soles.So:- less sweating- less slipping in the shoe- more comfy sole-feel- very nice on the heel- cover the entire foot- gives my flat feet a bit of arch support (not a huge amount, which would bug me)- they don't stinkTo sum:I didn't have to do a thing. I opened the box and stuck them in my shoes and stuck my feet in them. Out the door I went. Nice!NOTE:I do have big feet, and I wear large hiking sandals everywhere I go, so I didn't have to cut these down. I imagine for smaller feet, that would be an issue.UPDATE 5/16/15:These things do slide around. I am constantly pulling them down, which is annoying, and I just took off a star for that. The bottoms should be tacky so this doesn't happen. I might use some sandpaper, or find some kind of light glue to apply to the bases so this stops happening. These need to be tweaked by the manufacturers.

I love and use these toe separators every day in front of the television. I use them for about ten minutes. They stretch my feet nicely, and feel really good once I remove them. Then I just rinse them with cool water under the kitchen since, let them dry on my drain board, and put them back in the drawer under my coffee table for the next evening.LOVE THEM. It's like the easiest yoga. :)NOTE: They do pick up every stray bit of dust, since they are made of sticky gel. That's why I rinse them. Rinsing cleans them right off, with very little effort.I received them as a free product sample, but I used to have something like these that I paid for previously, and would have bought again anyway. I lost the originals in a move...but these are nicer, since they mold better to my feet, having one straight side, and one side that molds to my foot contours.I also like the pretty tropical blue color. It's the little things that make me happy.

The best thing about this mouse trap is that you don't sacrifice any effectiveness in making it a "mouse safe" trap. I can't imagine that any mouse trap could be more effective than this one. We put it out six nights in a row and caught a mouse each night except for one. (I discovered that a young mouse is too light to activate the trap door so I taped a nickel to the trigger.)What we did:- We caught the parents the first two night with trap as is.- Then the trap did not trigger with the younger mice until we taped the nickel onto it.- After that we trapped all three of the rest of the family.It is also super easy to set. We tried another "mouse safe" trap first -- made of metal  (the Havahart version) -- and it was crap. It was very hard to set without triggering the trap and it never did catch a mouse even though it was triggered every night (-ie -they managed to steal the bait but we never caught a mouse).Suggestion: keep a large storage container handy to release the mouse into before taking it to the woods. The trap is very small and not a very nice place for a mouse to be trapped for a long period of time. On a few nights we caught a mouse before going to bed, so I put the trap in a storage container, with some old clothes and food, and opened the trap. At least that way the mouse had a nice place to sleep.If I had it to do over again I would have purchased a mouse habitat to keep all of the mice in as we caught them and then release the entire family together.

*Product received as a review sample*My Samsung Galaxy Note fits, tightly and securely, in this mount. I had another mount for my Samsung Galaxy S4, which worked just fine, but didn't have the stability to hold my new Note. I have a Honda CRV that doesn't have a particularly smooth ride, which caused my S4 to vibrate constantly while in the old mount. This new mount holds the Note rock steady.What is really nice is that the clamp mount swivels for either direction of phone use - horizontal or vertical. Nice touch. The suction cup is easy to mount and sticks solid. We put ours on the dashboard, but it could also work on the windshield or roof. The gel-suction is reusable if you clean it off, and the box includes a 3M sticky mount tape in case you don't have a hard surface to work with.The only thing that could make this mount better is if it were a tiny bit bigger. It's an effort to get the phone in and out of the grip, because the jaws are open just about as wide as they'll go, but I will admit the Galaxy Note is a really big phone. Our smaller Galaxies and iPhones fit in just as well. The clamp is really responsive and I'm pleased that finally my phone doesn't droop.This really is an excellent phone mount.

These are very unusual makeup brushes, at least to me. I'm used to seeing only a few larger brushes in a kit, and tons of tiny little eyeshadow art ones. This kit is specific - it's mainly for really doing foundation, concealer, and total face coverage. It's for the full-on, flawless face look.I'd call this a sort of Kabuki line - the brushes are very full, on the large size, and several of them are totally flat across the top. This is, I believe, for stippling and blending motions, rather than the sweeping motions usually used with typical American makeup brushes.Here is what the Amazon blurb suggests for their use:1.Round Blending Brush---Powder Foundation2.Angled Blending Brush---Foundation around nose and mouth3.Flat Blending Brush---Foundation around nose and mouth4.Tapered Contouring Brush---Conceal around eyes and nose5.Angled Contouring Brush---Blush and Bronzer6.Small Tapered Contouring Brush---Conceal on rounded areas like the nose7.Small Flat Blending Brush---Conceal under eyes and around your nose8.Small Round Blending Brush---eye shadow and primer9.Small Angled Contouring Brush---Contouring hollows of cheek and sides of the nose10. Small Angled Blending Brush--- Stipple conceal and blemishesNotice only one of these brushes is specifically aimed at applying eyeshadow.MY THOUGHTS:The 10 brushes themselves are wonderful: thickly packed in the ferrule without being too stiff, soft like bunnies, with pretty ombre tips, and nice pink wooden handles. The handles are a good length, too. The pink velvet drawstring case they arrive in is very feminine.I like this set for home use, for when I have the time and inclination to do a perfect face. I'm usually very lazy with foundation and concealer, rarely contour, and barely bother with a lot of blending. This set is so pretty and such a pleasure to use that it makes me slow down and pay attention to the process. It makes me more mindful. That's an interesting effect right there. It's also made me look up other makeup techniques than what I'm used to doing.RECOMMENDATION:This is a very girly, pretty and unusual brush set that works really well for at-home use, for creating really porcelain-like facial looks. If you like to get really involved with eyeshadows and liners, though, you'll need another kit. There's also no lip liner brush, or anything small enough for brows. The focus here is on foundation, concealing, blending, contouring and bronzing. If you love makeup, I think this is an excellent kit for days/nights when you want to do the whole 'flawless' deal, but you'll probably need a separate kit for small detailed eye/lip/brow brushes. Or just buy a few extra individual brushes and add them to the pink bag (there's plenty of room).[I received this set as a review sample]

I'm having a hoot with this clips. I know they're for clipping towels to lounge chairs, but they have so many other uses. I'm going around the house and yard looking for things to do with these large, sturdy, happy-looking clips.USES I'VE FOUND:- Hold those large pet food bags closed.- Hold human food bags closed (since these clips are so big, that's kind of a waste, unless your food bags are gigantic).- I used them to 'iron' my bed skirts: I sprayed them with Febrese in sections and held them flat with the clips, working around my bed skirt. As each section dried, the weight of the clip would pull it down and help it dry flat. I can totally see the section I haven't finished yet looking all wrinkly.- Hanging big, wet heavy things up to dry: bathmats, blankets, shoes, coats.- Holding open a book I'm reading so I can be hands-free while I eat.- Holding a book propped up for reference while doing other things, like cooking, or researching Internet items, or for copying notes from papers to my blog.- Holding open curtains when sunny out, or clipping curtains closed (for privacy, for blocking out the neighbors' porch lights).- Hanging linens and bedding out to air on my balcony (on sunny days).- Holding plant vines around stakes (gently, through the big curved hole).- Clipping notes to my metal desk as reminders for the day.- Clipping around the wad of wires behind my TV/entertainment center (through the curved hole), as a sort of 'corral'.- Holding art/craft projects together while the glue dries.- Emergency hair clips. I'm using one right now in my very long hair.I'll say it. These clips are both stupid and brilliant. They are just overgrown clothesline clips...but oh, so useful. And cheerful. I even Sharpied my initials to each clip, so they don't wander off into my husband's workshop. Yeah.I received a set of four for review purposes, and will probably end up buying more.

I'm really happy with this car charger on several levels. I like that I can charge three devices at once (or that three people in my car can charge one device each - no more waiting). I like the form factor - the shape is smooth and easy to pull in and out. And I like the pretty blue LED light that lets me know the charger is seated properly and working.PROS:- Seats well in outlets without jiggling around.- Easy to grab and pull from the outlet (some other chargers are hard to get in and out of the socket, or hard to grab itself).- The construction seems durable.- 3 USB ports!- Numbers by the port let me know which port to use alone (the one on the top).- No trouble recognizing either my Samsung Galaxy 5 or my iPhone 4, along with my husband's Samsung Note Edge, all at once.- The blue LED light is handy when driving in the dark. I don't have to futz around looking for the outlets.- Good price point at around $9.CONS:- No USB cords included. This isn't actually a con, since most people have their own cords, but as a few car chargers come with USB cords, I thought it was worth mentioning.- I don't actually have anything negative to report. :)I have the white one and it looks clean and sleek. The Amazon blurb suggests this won't overcharge any devices, but I've never had a problem with that and can't think of a way to test it anyway. Really, the best thing about this is that you no longer have to fight with other people in the car about who gets to charge what!

I like the new wave of ultrasound devices to eliminate household pests, but they do require a learning curve to figure out where best to place them for what rodent, insect, spider or small monster you want gone. I don't mind doing a lot of experimentation, since I'm very adverse to using toxins in my home, and I'm not big on actually killing living creatures if I don't have to.This one apparently takes a few weeks to kick in. You plug it in (lots of caveats as to where - see below), and the red LED light stays on steadily to indicate it is working. The amber and green lights blink intermittently. Amber = electromagnetic function is on. Green = ultrasound function is on.PROS:- Nice blue LED nightlight option.- No poisons or toxins! A big plus.- This doesn't actually kill any creatures. It just makes them leave. I'm good with that.- Plug and play use. You don't have to set anything at all. The only issue is finding the right outlet to do the most good.- Two prong plug is easier to use with older extension cords.- UPDATE: works on getting rid of large carpenter ants!- A NEW UPDATE: works on cockroaches!CONS:- Instructions are vague. "Do not leave doors, windows, garage or basement doors open", or "Leave a door or window open to let them escape"? I'm baffled that they would offer contradictory advice.- Instructions say to keep this away from water, flower vases and object containing water. Is that because it will inhibit the sound waves? Will it bother my fish? I could use some clarity.- Apparently, rabbits and pocket pets will be disturbed by the electromagnetic and ultrasonic action. If you want mice gone, that would be a plus. If you have pet rodents, you probably shouldn't purchase this product, or at least keep them far away from it.- It keeps clicking every few seconds, which annoys me. At first I had it by my computer, but it's going in the bathroom next. I'll explain why below, as in what vermin I want to vermoose.- The 'manual' is a poorly photocopied slip of paper with tiny print. I can read small print, but I know a lot of adults that would need a magnifying lens for this. Just FYI.- When first using the iCooker, pests are supposed to be stirred up and more active, as they try to escape. Not really a 'con', but something to be aware of. You may end up with spiders or mice scurrying around as they freak out, try to escape, whatever.- If someone has a serious pest problem, according to the instructions, one will need a bunch of these devices around the house. The area covered is small, and walls, furniture, and textiles absorb the ultrasounds. The manual actually suggests getting one for each room, and then actually says to get two for each room. So, if it works, it might be well worth investing in a ton of these. But you have to try at least one it for a few weeks -  in optimal conditions - to see if it works for your particular pests.MY THOUGHTS:I have a huge problem every summer with no-see-ums that drive me batscat insane. My real hope is that this device will give me some relief. I'm willing to put up with the clicking and the LED blinking if it will help end my torment. Since the no-see-ums don't really get bothersome until mid-June, my hope, for now, is to eliminate the giant black ants all over my bathroom. The clicking and blinking won't keep me awake in there, and the pretty blue nightlight is useful in that location. And since the bathroom is a small area, it should work to get the ants out.Remember: the directions suggest it could take 1-3 weeks to actually chase away the vermin. In the meantime, I have a nice nightlight.Device received as a review sample.UPDATE 4/29/15:I've had the iCooker in my bathroom now for about a week, and haven't seen a single ant since. I was having huge problems with large black carpenter ants everywhere. Not a one has popped up! The clicking sounds are still a bit annoying (I can hear it from my bed), but since I sleep with a fan near my face, that drowns out the soft clicks anyway. When I want to relax in a bath, I unplug the unit, and then plug it back in when  I'm done. I'm very satisfied with how it's working on ants.The next real test will be this summer with the no-see-ums.UPDATE 5/5/15:They also work on cockroaches! I do not have a big problem with roaches, but one was hiding from my machine in the bathroom by clinging to the opposite, vertical support of a wooden shelf. When I tried to pick it up with tissue, the cockroach dissolved into little bits. I've never had an insect fall to pieces like that before. The instructions do say that the device takes longer to work on roaches, and I guess that would be accurate - but it DID work. Also, sometimes a carpenter ant now pops in my bathroom, but it seems lost, and my thinking is they keep hoping I've removed the device and they can move back in. HA! I don't think so.

What's nice about this fielding trainer is that it's stiff (you can't just scoop up a ball), but not so stiff that there you don't get some of the give you find in a glove. It's the right textural combination to train players to use both hands when catching grounders.What this does is create engrams - the part of the brain that memorizes correct body positions, for unconscious play later. If you've learned how to swim, ride a bike, or drive a car, you can thank your engrams for giving you the ability to do complex maneuvers without having to think it through newly, each time. Imagine how mentally exhausting that would be. This faux-glove gives you the same kind of training for proper technique catching ground balls in the field.The construction is a little flimsy on this - it's really just a foam pad with finger slots sewn on the back with elastic - but for training purposes, it's a good place to begin. It's also good for both hands, which is thoughtful - not everyone is right-handed.

This is the nut-bar version by thinkThin that has only nuts. No fruit. No other flavors. It's pretty boring. I could just eat a handful of nuts if that's all I wanted.It's a decent trail bar though, bringing a little salt (70mg), 8 grams of protein, 4 grams of fiber and some calcium and iron. It's also dairy-free, vegetarian, gluten-free, non-GMO, has no transfats, is cholesterol-free, and contains only 4 grams of sugar.It's also only 190 calories, which is far less than the cookie type versions (the White Chocolate has 240 calories, for reference). And for some reason, it's got 10 more calories than the far more delicious nut-blueberry version.Less good: 13 grams of fat - 1.5 of which are saturated. It's also a smallish bar, and won't serve as a meal replacement. It's better as a trail snack, or something to eat after a workout.The nuts inside: peanuts, almonds and cashews, in that order. Brown rice syrup is the third ingredient, after the almonds and before the cashews.I'm just not that excited about this bar. It's nuts in a sugar base with 'soy crisps'.

Of all the "nut only' versions of the thinkThin bars, this one has the best flavor. I can actually taste the blueberries! It's a good trail bar, bringing a little salt (60mg), 8 grams of protein, 4 grams of fiber and some calcium and iron. It's also dairy-free, vegetarian, gluten-free, non-GMO, has no transfats, is cholesterol-free, and contains only 6 grams of sugar.It's also only 180 calories, which is far less than the cookie type versions (the White Chocolate has 240 calories, for reference).Less good: 11 grams of fat - 1.5 of which are saturated. It's also a smallish bar, and won't serve as a meal replacement. It's better as a trail snack, or something to eat after a workout.The nuts inside: peanuts, almonds and cashews, in that order. The fruits: currents and blueberries, with apple juice concentrate, in that order.

I like that there are two screen protectors in this package, since I'm not the most adept at placing these screen stickers on without trapping bubbles. It's a basic shield - it keeps scratches off the glass, and does a bit of overall ding protection to the entire device. The touch capacity is still present, and a little glare is reduced. You get a cleaning cloth and a little card to help press out the bubbles.I prefer the solid screen protectors myself - the stiff kind you place over the entire front - but for the price, this is a decent way to go.

This is by far the most delicious thinkThin bar flavor I've tasted, and I've been a bit scathing in my reviews of some others. The outer coating is white and creamy, and the inner cocoa layer was thick, moist, chewy and sort of like a cross between a cake and a brownie. I've had this bar almost two years before eating it, and it was still amazing.It also had 20 grams of protein, which is a LOT in a small bar like this. A typical egg has 3-6 grams of protein, for reference. There's also no added sugar, which is a bonus. Also good: it's gluten-free, and there's some calcium and some iron.This isn't a diet bar, though. It has 240 calories and is too small to act as a meal replacement. There are 25 grams of carbs, 200mg of sodium, and 9 grams of fat - three of which are saturated.RECOMMENDATION:Bring this bar on a hike as a snack - it's tasty, you get a nice wallop of protein, and some of the sodium that outdoor activities seem to make one crave. It lasts a LONG TIME in the package without going bad.

Inexpensive, lightweight protection. All the functions are accessible, and it has a slim, clean profile. This is a good case for people who don't want an obvious thick for of protection for their device, and the clear, barely there look is definitely attractive. It's just not much of anything, to me - I prefer solid ding, scratch and drop protection.

What is the point of this product? It contains 4 little packets of mostly salt. I could add salt to rice by myself, or just have Ramen noodles if I wanted a starch and salt combo. In case this was not clear, there is no rice included in Mi Arroz (which means My Rice, in Spanish).SPECS:- 4 packets, each with .42 oz of salt, an undisclosed flavor, MSG, corn starch, silicone dioxide, cellulose gum, barley extract, sugar, disodium inosinate, and partially hydrogenated soybean oil.THOUGHTS:- Way more salt per serving than is recommended in a day: the box lists 660 mg per serving. A serving, again, per the box, is 1/6 of a packet. The FDA reports that 480 mg or more of sodium per serving is high....doing the math, ONE PACKET would supply 3,960 mg of salt. That's just shy of 4k grams of salt if you add the packet to some rice and eat the whole thing.- I'm going to just pause here and reflect on the 4 thousand grams of salt.- I have no idea what the "natural and artificial flavors" are, because they don't tell you on the box or packets. The flavor might be onions and garlic, but that's a guess based on photos on the packaging. The only flavor actually indicated in words is WHITE.- MSG is a flavor enhancer. A lot of people like the taste, but some people get headaches from it. Just be aware of this. It's also a form of salt. For more information, the FDA classifies MSG as "generally safe", and the Mayo Clinic website warns against MSG symptom complex, which has a whole suite of unpleasant temporary symptoms, if you are susceptible.- Silicone dioxide is found mainly in quartz, and sand. The Wikipedia says silicone dioxide is used in foods as a 'flow agent' - this is mainly - I assume - what keeps the rice from clumping. Health dot com lists this ingredient as one of their Top 18 Sickening Food ingredients. A little sand won't hurt you, but I don't know why I'd add it to my food on purpose.- Cellulose is indigestible wood pulp, also used as a flow agent, and works as a filler. It's also on Health's article about the Top 18 Sickening Food ingredients. So now we are eating salt, sand and sawdust.- The Barley is actually an autolyzed yeast extract, according to the ingredients list, and is a flavor enhancer made from salt and barley. It makes Vegemite taste like it does. This is another kind of MSG, the Wikepedia reports, creating a savory "umami" flavor. Umami is very interesting to read about, if you have nothing else to do, but it essentially means 'savory'. It's more sodium, in any case.- Sugar. Why sugar? Why add sugar to rice? For the same reason that sugar is in catsup, I suppose. We're addicted to sugar.- Disodium inosinate - just another form of sodium, used as a flavor enhancer, often associated with MSG. The Wikipepdia says it can be sourced from meat, fish or tapioca.- Partially hydrogenated soybean oil is where I draw the line. I've eliminated transfats and partially hydrogenated fats from my diet, because it causes cancer. Unlike sand and sawdust, it is actively bad for you. The FDA is making moves to actively ban these fats from food, according to NPR's website, but there is a lot of pushback from the soybean industry and other food groups. This has to be a personal choice for everyone at this point, but transfats are not allowed in my house. I suggest you do your own Googling on this one.RECOMMENDATION:Well, this was fun. I never intended to spend so much time on this review. I don't recommend Mi Arroz to anyone, really. I'm going to save these packets for my backpacking trips, which is when I start craving massive amounts of salt and stop worrying about transfats. I decided not to eat them here in my kitchen at all.

This was a kind of fun product to play with. You can print out your own design from the computer, and then add the plastic to anything stick-like. I added it to a walking stick I found in the woods and take it hiking, and everyone is curious what exactly I did here. It really is easy to use, adds a firmer grip to pole-like things (bats, rackets, hockey sticks), and let me add a wild touch to something I use all the time anyway.Keep in mind this is smelly out of the package, so open it outdoors and let it air a bit.BTW, I made mine with a sort of Lord of the Rings theme (i got creative with my own designing), because I'm that kind of nerd. If I get another one, I'm printing it out with a BAMA logo for my footbally husband.

Super easy to cook. I received two different kinds of these Knorr sides, and cooked one on the stovetop, and one in the microwave. The taste was pretty much the same (slightly spiced rice).WHAT I HAVE:- Creamy Chiptotle Rice Sides (rice and pasta blend)- Creole Garlic Butter Rice Sides (rice and pasta blend)What you get in these is the actual rice, ready to cook, with the spices already mixed in. There are no packets to have to open. Rip the top off the bag, dump in a bowl or saucepan, add water, and go. I didn't see a need to add margarine, which was an optional choice anyway (who uses margarine anymore?). The Creamy Chipoltle one says to add milk, which adds a slightly creamier taste.You get 2.5 servings per bag. One of them I split three ways - which wasn't quite enough for each person. The other I ate all by myself as a meal, and it was only a bit larger than I'd normally eat as a meal. So the 2.5 servings (for two adult people, with a little left over for seconds) sounds about right, especially as a side meal. Alternately, each of these could be made into a decent meal for two with some nice veggies or meat added.WHAT I LIKED:- 7 minutes on the stove, or 14 minutes in the microwave, with nothing to have to do but stir it a little. For non-cooks like myself, this is a very easy do.- It lasted a good long time. I owned these packages almost two years before I cooked them, and they were fresh enough for family food.- I thought it was better than Rice A Roni, and a good contribution to the 'instant starch meal' lineup- 6 grams of protein per serving.- 2 grams of fiber per serving.- A decent amount of B vitamins: enriched with thiamine, folate and Niacin- - ZERO trans fats! Yay!- Minute saturated fat (if you keep butter or sat oils out of it). Over all, one bag has 1 gram of any fat, and the other has 1.5 grams. So this isn't bad stuff - mostly it is carbs  (around 49g per serving), and calories 230 per serving.LESS GOOD:- This isn't a health food. It's not packaged as one, so that's not a con in my book, but don't expect to live on these. There's no added veggies, although the sides are enriched, along with 700mg of sodium per serving.OVERALL:Easy to cook and not too unhealthy. Knorr did a nice job with these 'insta-food' products. It's not all that tasty (the spices are bland, unless you add your own afterwards), but it's hot and filling. I think children would eat these, and I like the idea of having a few of these on hand for lazy nights when I want some warm, quick comfort food. Since there are no transfats, these are welcome in my house.

I'm very happy with this phone case, and it fits my Samsung Galaxy 5 perfectly. I picked the blue one that looks like tropical water, and this color makes me happy every time I see it. The case leather is soft, with a textured pattern, and feels a very tiny bit padded. There are two slots for cards. Three little freebies come along with this: a blue stylus, a plastic phone cover, and a tiny cloth-like square for cleaning the phone's screen. It's a thoughtful little kit.What is ISN'T is a wallet. It's just a nice kickstand case with two card slots.PROS:- Pretty case with a nice feel to it- Magnetic closure flap works well- There's a bottom grommet on the case that I could see putting some kind of leash on- Nice little freebies, as mentioned above- Props up nicely for horizontal hands-free viewing (kickstand feature)- Between the case and the plastic cover, you get great scratch protection- All the buttons and camera lenses are perfectly accessible. Nothing is blocked.- I can plug it in to charge while closed- My phone is securely snapped in the plastic holder inside the leather caseCONS:- Only two card slots- No clear card slot- No pocket for dollar bills/receipts- There's nowhere to put the stylus that comes along with this- The 'cleaning cloth' isn't microfiber - it's more of a very loose-knit felt (but as a freebie that comes along unadvertised, this isn't really a con)- Not a lot of protection against dropping. Don't expect that.With these limitations, it really can't be substituted for a wallet. I just see it an upscale-looking/feeling phone case, with the bonus of two slots to put cards in. In one slot I placed the little screen cloth that came in the kit (folded over) and in the other I put about three business cards to have for handily handing out. Personally, I love this. I love the way it feels, how it protects my screen from everything else in my purse, and how darn pretty it looks.I really feel it would be improved with a clear card slot, a little pocket for a few dollars, or an actual place to put the stylus. I've been trying to decide whether to give this 4 or 5 stars, and wish 4.5 was an option.I received this item as a review sample.

I'm happy with it. It's not super heavy duty, but it punches holes in my projects with the loose precision I was looking for. I wouldn't choose these for a classroom of boisterous kinds, but for an adult with occasional holey needs, it's plenty good.It would be nicer if it came with the loop so many of them have inside the handle, for tying to a string, making it easy to hang.A nice point: hole puncher arrived in a little clear plastic case. I just keep it in the case, in the drawer with my misc office supplies.Also good: there's a little 'hole catcher' lip. It doesn't work to catch every hole I've punched, but it does collect most of them. I've never seen this on a hole puncher before. It needs a bit of tweaking to be a better design - sometimes when I open it, it doesn't close back to the proper position, and then I have to futz with getting it back on correctly. But since I wasn't expecting this little feature anyway, it's no big deal. I just wanted to punch holes in some cards. :)NOTE: At this time, the product is an Add-On for Prime, which I find annoying. You can't just buy it alone. It's also $1.79, which is about 79 cents more than I think it should cost.Sometimes you just need a stupid little thing, and now I have one, and I don't expect I'll ever need another. It's all good.

Very creative design for a mudflap, and nice LED light unit. I'm very pleased with this kit.A lot of people don't put mudflaps on their bikes because they 'look dorky'. Unless you live in Seattle, where people are used to seeing mudflaps on commuter cycles, people tend to endure getting a wet, slimy back. This completely solves that problem, with an interesting tensile solution: the mudflap rolls up, out of the way when not in use. You barely notice the little black roll over the front and rear tires.When pulled out, the flaps do the job of diverting water at the same rate as conventional flaps. This is really best for a road bike, commuter bike, or hybrid. I don't think the flaps will stay flat if you're mountain biking - my sense is with the right angle of knock, they'd roll back up. From my experience with hardcore mountain bikers, mud flaps aren't a consideration in the first place, anyway.Whether or not the mudflaps are out, the other neat thing is the LED tail light unit. There are five choices of lighting - red/blue/white slow flashing, red/blue/white quick flashing, white quick flashing, red flashing, blue flashing. There is only one button, so you have to press through through all five options to turn the lights off. You do have to press solidly on the button - it won't accidentally come on by itself.The LED unit is USB chargeable, and mine arrived with a full charge. The USB port is the smaller size that works with my Samsung phone. It blinks red when charging.Note that there is only the tail light in this kit; no headlights are included.The kit comes with installation hardware, but no instructions for mounting. You're on your own with that. They do include a small bike wrench, sized for their hardware.OVERALL RECOMMENDATION:Even without the mudflaps, I love this tail light, and it makes cycling safer. I'm definitely more noticeable on the road, but the lights won't blind anyone behind them in cars. I like the color and blinking choices. With the cool rollout flaps, cycling is now more comfortable, without dealing with the typical ungainly metal flanges. I'd be surprised if everyone didn't get these - creative, cool tech advance.I received this kit as a review sample.

This is kind of flimsy. I've had a lot of over the door hooks, and this one is not really up to snuff. It arrived with one of the door hooks bent to the side; I was able to fix that by just bending it back into position. Some of the white paint was also chipped in six noticeable spots, which I fixed by touching it up with WhiteOut.PROS:- Nice, dainty design, if you like that look- Five clothing hooks- The clothing hooks have balls on the end to protect the clothing- The over-the-door hooks are narrow enough in profile so that just about any door will still close- You don't have to screw anything together - just hang it over a door, right out of the boxCONS:- A bit wonky- Too cheaply made for the price point- Arrived chipped and bent- Will not stand up to heavier coats or laden purses, unless you're very careful in how you use the hooks. I wouldn't carelessly yank on these!OVERALL:For the price point, this isn't a good deal. It's too flimsy. Once in use, though, it does the job for lighter-weight clothing items. It would look very nice in a girl's room, and I can see it being useful inside a woman's closet for lingerie and scarves. I put it in my craft room and it's okay. I have much sturdier over the door hooks for my own bathroom and closet.I was provided with a sample for review.

One of the problems I've had in the past with styluses (stylii?) has been my fear of losing them. So I keep them safely in a drawer at home and forget I even have them. This affordable pack has enough stylii to encourage me to actually use them, which is the goal.PROS:- Good price point, lots of them.- Fantastic, brigh colors.- Freebie screen cleaning cloth included.- Clip on one end, plus a hole through the clip: gives choices on how to attach or leash the stylus to yourself.- The Capacitive tip works fine to press buttons, move screens, and generally act like a finger, but with more precision than a finger.- Comes in a decent resealable plastic bag that's clear in front. I put the lot in my drawer and pull out the color that looks fun for the day- If you don't like bright colors, you can choose the black, white, silver, gold, red or dark blue one. Actually, that's more than half of the colors, so everyone should be fine. My favorite is the teal. :)- Because there are so many, I feel comfortable using them all over the place - nightstand, in my desk, in my purse, in my car, in my travel bag, and clipped onto the cases of my many devices.CONS:- My husband complained he could not use the stylus as a screen 'pen' to write on his Samsung Note. This isn't that kind of stylus, so I don't see it as a con, but it's worth noting. If you're looking for something to make clear handwriting on your screen, keep looking.- The metal (?) clip on top is really rather cheap.RECOMMENDATION:Worth having if you want something more precise for your touchscreens than a bare finger. I find myself missing these when I don't have one around. Has a clip and a hole for a narrow string, if you're having issues with where exactly to put them near your devices. Love the colors.Received as a review sample.

These are some nice, well-made glasses that I'm not sure what to do with. They don't block the computer glare on my large desktop monitor, nor my husband's array of three desk monitors and one laptop. It's possible this will help me use my phone to take and see photos or read texts on sunny days? I'm going to do my nightly TV watching with these on tonite, and see if they reduce eye strain.PROS:- A really nice black canvas, solidly-built zip case is included with these computer glasses. It's a hard case with some give, and there's a nice rotating clip on one end. I've already put my own daily glasses in them and don't have to fear I might sit on them anymore. :)- The glasses themselves are a solid, pretty tortoiseshell that appears to be unisex. They look very handsome on my husband - it's Clark Kent look. We will probably save these just for the frame.- The ear pieces have a 'wood panel' look to them, which is an interesting choice with the tortoiseshell front.- These are sold as having UV protection, which would be a nice feature if I used these with my phone, out of doors.- I do wear eyeglasses for distance viewing, and these fit right over them. I won't include a photo, since I look a bit silly, but yes, they can be worn over prescription eyeglasses. Since I have a female-sized head, I asked my husband to put these on over his reading glasses, and that also fit fine.- Not bad for nerd-chic fashion statements, or as part of a costume.CONS:- They don't block glare. WTF?- Am I doing something wrong, really? All they do is lend a slightly amber overlay to the world. Very slightly.- Not polarized. How is this supposed to work?RECOMMENDATION:Since they don't block computer glare for me, I don't know how to rate these. They are nice 'nerd' frames, well made, with a truly great case. The price point for the frames and case alone are well worth it. The UV protection would be nice outside, but these aren't sunglasses - they are almost clear. At most, they 'soften' light. Maybe worn for hours at a time, they would reduce eye strain. For $13, it might be worth trying.These were provided to me as a review sample.UPDATE 4/21/15:I thought of a new use for these glasses: sneeze protection in crowded areas, like in planes. I tend to get everyone's colds on planes, unless I take a lot of precautions about not touching things. I'm placing these glasses in my carry-on bag, next to my Airborne, Clorox wipes and little cloth gloves. Yes, I know I'm a freak about it, but since I've started being so careful I haven't come down with any more travel-related flu.UPDATE 4/23/15:I like to spend a lot of time walking around a little pond near my house and text people. I get fitness, and I get some time with friends. I wore these glasses today - a bright day - and they did NOT cut the glare from the sun shining on my phone. They did nothing of the sort. If I think of a good way to use them, I'll add that here. I really don't know how a tiny bit of amber can reduce eye strain. Please let me know in the comments below if I'm missing something crucial.

This is a very lightweight phone case that doesn't do much to protect the Samsung 4. Well, it will cover the four edges from light dings, and cover the back from scratches. I wouldn't toss this across the room with my phone in it. If you're the careful type with your phone, though, this will probably be all you need. It has a slim profile, is light, milky, matte, translucent, and has a smooth, slightly grippy texture.PROS:- It's like its barely there (this will be a con for some)- A good seal around the Samsung 4- Somewhat useable for the Samsung 3 (same good seal, just minor issues with buttons lining up)- Attractive- Nice feel - smooth with a bit of grip, so it's easier to hold than the phone alone- Decent edge protection if you don't expect armor platingCONS:- It's like it's barely there (this will be a pro for some)- No rim - so there's nothing to have as a scratch 'bumper', so to speak, for the screen.NOTES:- I was able to fit my older Samsung 3 in the case just fine, but the holes do not match up exactly. It's very usable, though. If all you have is a 3, this  cover will serve for everything but the lower part of the volume button. Just FYI.- For some reason, a lot of reviews on this page are for an armband. This is just a lightweight case to cover the back from scratches and the sides from light dings.FINAL THOUGHTS:I like Belkin products, generally. I'm not sure about this case, because it just doesn't seem to DO much. It's practically invisible and the protection is light. Too light for someone like me, who's rather hard on her stuff. I expect this case is PERFECT for people who take a lot of care with their things and want a bit of extra protection that isn't obvious. The grippiness does  make it easier to hold onto the phone. Better for adults, especially adults  who are careful with their belongings.

I'm very happy with this phone case. I picked the blue one that looks like tropical water, and this color makes me happy every time I see it. The case leather is soft, with a textured pattern, and feels a very tiny bit padded. There are two slots for cards.What is ISN'T is a wallet. It's just a nice kickstand case with two card slots.PROS:- Pretty case with a nice feel to it- Magnetic closure flap works well- There's a bottom grommet on the case that I could see putting some kind of leash on- Props up nicely for horizontal hands-free viewing (kickstand feature)- Between the case and the included plastic cover, you get great scratch protection- All the buttons and camera lenses are perfectly accessible. Nothing is blocked.- I can plug it in to charge while closed- My phone is securely snapped in the plastic holder inside the leather caseCONS:- Only two card slots- No clear card slot- No pocket for dollar bills/receipts- Not a lot of protection against dropping. Don't expect that.With these limitations, it really can't be substituted for a wallet. I just see it an upscale-looking/feeling phone case, with the bonus of two slots to put cards in. In one slot I placed my business cards in those, to have for handily handing out. Personally, I love this. I love the way it feels, how it protects my screen from everything else in my purse, and how darn pretty it looks.I really feel it would be improved with a clear card slot, a little pocket for a few dollars, or a place to put a stylus.I received this item as a review sample.

This bundle of microfiber cloths is one of those things I really didn't realize how much I would need, until I had it. I've always had a few microfiber cloths here and there, but the quality of these are a step up. They feel luxurious. To my Asperger's-sensitive skin, they feel like silky clouds. And since so many are included, I've felt free to use them for all kinds of uses, instead of weirdly hoarding them in my computer desk drawer.USES I'VE TRIED AND SUGGEST:- Cleaning eyeglasses- Cleaning my phone screen- Cleaning my computer monitors and other electronic screens (good for my Kindle Paperwhite)- Cleaning my television screen- When damp, you can clean keyboards- Great household duster when damp- Cleaning windows (especially doggy nose prints left on the glass)- I've enjoyed using these as little washcloths for my face. Since they are so soft and smooth, it feels luxurious, and the microfiber drinks up moisture- Good for removing makeup when damp! I set aside one cloth just for this. The black ones show makeup stains least- They actually work fantastic to mop up the sweat from my hot flashes...now I always have some in my purse just for drying off my face and neck- Cleaning my coffee work mug. I have one just for this to remove the brown rings inside the cup, and the spots that get outside. They also remove lipstick- These also work for cleaning mirrors in the car. One now lives in the glove box of my truckYou could probably shine silver with these, but I haven't tried that yet. I'd also try them if I was going to to polish my car, if I ever bothered to do that. If I had kids, I'd keep some around to wipe off dirty little mouths and faces. :)PROS:- Extremely soft and smooth- Three colors in the package - the variety is a nice touch (blue is my favorite, then black)- Perfect size - not too tiny (I have small hands for an adult, and this covers my entire hand when laid flat on my palm)- Scalloped ends to prevent fraying- Easy to hand wash in my bathroom sink; they dry super fast- It's been fun finding off-label uses for themCONS:- The grey color isn't very exciting, and shows grime the most readilyRECOMMENDATION:For seven dollars, getting 15 of these really soft cloths is a great deal. I never realized how multifunctional these small cloths were until I had so many to play with! Highly recommended for many, many cleaning uses. I'm most impressed with the relief they help give me with menopausal hot flashes. Seriously, sheesh.I received this product as a review sample

This oil feels lovely on. It has a smooth slip, isn't greasy or waxy, soaks right into the skin, and doesn't leave any sort of residue. It is also completely scentless, to my nose.The bottle says this is an organic, unrefined, cold pressed oil. There's also a warning to keep it out of the eyes, and not to take internally.The bottle 4 fluid ounces, comes with an airtight cap and plastic seal, plus a pump top option. I removed the caps it arrived in and just use the pump.You do not have a lot of control with the pump - it's a bit squirty. Be prepared for that. More comes out with one pump than expected, but I just make sure to use any extra on the backs of my hands. Keep the airtight cap in case you want to take it traveling, since the pump cap doesn't lock.I haven't heard of using Rosehip as a carrier oil - my husband, who used to be a masseuse, always used almond oil. This oil seems clearer and cleaner, a bit. Less slippery, but I prefer that in a massage. I've been hearing about using coconut oil as a carrier, which seems messy, since coconut oil is a solid at room temps. This rosehip oil is an elegant solution.WHAT I USE IT FOR:- I've been rubbing it over a scar of mine, just to see if it does anything. It's a really old scar, so I don't expect much, but we can see.- I'm experimenting with it as a facial moisturizer. I'm very particular what I put on my sensitive skin. Almost anything with a scent makes me have a reaction. So I'm trying this two ways 1. As an all-over night-time facial moisturizer in place of my usual stuff, and 2. as a serum, placed only over the areas that lines are developing (I'm 47 with very light age lines). My normal-to-aging skin drinks it up and it feels great. I haven't had any bad skin  reactions, after a couple weeks of use.- Massage. I've added a drop of peppermint oil to it, which was a bit more revitalizing than I wanted. I want to add some other, more soothing essential oil next, like Chamomile. Since there's only 4 ounces to the bottle, this won't last long if you do a lot of body massaging. I mostly use this to massage my hands and forearms, and my feet. It's really nice to work this into my toes and let it soak into the backs of my heels.- On my nails. My cuticles in particular, since I have troublesome ones.- On the ends of my hair, as a sort of serum. Since this is a straight oil, I only use a little and keep it on the ends, so I don't get a greasy look.RECOMMENDATION:This is an elegant textured oil with a nice array of possible uses.
