I like that it's organic and contains only rosehip oil (and nothing else). With only four ounces, this will probably get used up quickly in my house. Highly recommended for personal hygiene.I received this product as a review sample.

I've been waiting over a year to review these stool softeners, and still have not had a need yet. This is one of those things that's good to have around in your first aid kit, but you don't necessarily want to use. Kind of like life insurance.So, all I can do is 1. wait until I get constipated enough to use this, or 2. review what I can see of the product without using it.Here's my information on Number 2 (no pun intended, hehehe):1. The box is pink. I think the idea here is that it won't look so scary in your cabinet. It lends a feminine air to the whole nasty proceedings.2. The bottle has a pink label.3. The pills (softgels) themselves are half pink. They are also half white. The pink half is translucent and catches the light, while the white side is opaque and seems milky.4. The one active ingredient - Docusate sodium, in 100mg per softgel - will make bowel movements within 12-17 hours. The instructions say to take 1-3 softgels daily with a glass of water, as a single or divided dose over the course of a day, for adults over age 12. The pills are considered  "stool softener laxatives", according to the package label.5. You take these by mouth. DO NOT insert them up your butt.6. Interestingly, included in the box is a little health insert, briefly mentioning "Women's Problems" like menstruation, menopause, pregnancy, and the taking of Calcium. This offers a few suggestions to prevent constipation in the first place (ie - eat more good fats, eat complex carbohydrates, take less Iron). There's a $1 off coupon for more laxatives on the back. This insert is also pink.7. 25 softgels are included in the rather small, almost discrete, little bottle.WebMD, a site I trust, has this to say: "Stool softeners such as docusate are often the first method used for preventing and treating this type of constipation. Docusate is often used when straining to have a bowel movement should be avoided (e.g., after a heart attack or surgery)."RECOMMENDATION:Since doctors say this works, I'll go with that. It seems to be the first line of defense before moving up to stronger laxatives. So, yes, this should be a suitable product for constipation. The action occurs after at least 12 hours, so don't expect immediate relief. The main thing that sets this product apart, really, is the pink PINK pinkness of everything. It won't look frightening or manly in your medicine cabinet, so, it's got that going for it.

First off - this stuff is STRONG. Like, acid for blood strong (ten points if you get the Aliens reference). I remember living in Boulder, CO, and going on a tour of Celestial Seasonings tea warehouse. They had to keep the peppermint locked in an air tight room, so it would not make every single tea in the factory taste like peppermint. When they opened the peppermint room door, with a whoosh, it would clear out your sinuses. I'm not exaggerating.That's what this stuff is like. It is pure essential oil of peppermint, and I'm surprised it hasn't melted the plastic off the stopper cap. You receive quite a small bottle of this (10ml, or .33oz), but my sense is this is enough to last a lifetime for typical home use.Once you're aware of what this is, then you can decide what to do with it. Websites abound with ideas for this oil.MY OWN EXPERIENCE:- I wanted to use it to flavor my SodaStream carbonated water. I used one drop from the tiny dropper, and it made my entire liter of water so strongly pungent that I couldn't drink it. If I was to try this again, I'd see if one drop worked suitably in a gallon.- I also used a drop in Rosehip carrier oil for massage, and it tingled. I'd call it more bracing than relaxing.- I have hopes that it can help with the inevitable no-see-um torment I get every summer - either as an insect repeller (I'd use a carrier oil and glycerin, I think, in a spray bottle).- I also have a mouse problem. I'll put some on cottonballs and see if that keeps the mouse out of my bathroom cabinets (it likes to live in there, and poop, and make nests from my extra toilet paper rolls).- Any mint can be used as a counter-irritant, so I'd think this would help with bug bites, poison ivy, or even soft tissue pain (maybe arthritis). It works on the same principle as menthol, which it's related to.MEDICAL, TOPICAL AND HOUSEHOLD USES:~ WebMD, a site I trust, suggests the following as MEDICINAL USES:"In dietary supplements, peppermint oil has been tried for a variety of digestive problems including:Irritable bowel syndromeIndigestionHeartburn"Dietary supplements containing peppermint oil are also used by some people for the following conditions, although there is no clear evidence that they are helpful:NauseaVomitingMorning sicknessCramps of the upper gastrointestinal tract and bile ductsDiarrheaBacterial overgrowth of the small intestineGasColdsCoughsInflammation of the mouth and throatSinus and respiratory infectionsMenstrual problemsLiver and gallbladder problems"Skin preparations containing peppermint oil are used by some people for the following conditions, although, again, there is no clear evidence that they are helpful:HeadacheMuscle painNerve painToothacheInflammation of the mouthJoint conditionsItchinessAllergic rashBacterial and viral infectionsRepelling mosquitoes"In addition, peppermint oil vapor is sometimes inhaled to treat symptoms of colds and coughs. Also, some doctors add peppermint oil to a barium solution to relax the colon during barium enemas."According to the National Center for Complementary and Alternative Medicine, several studies suggest that enteric-coated peppermint oil capsules -- which allow the oil to pass through the stomach so it can dissolve in the intestines -- may help relieve common symptoms of irritable bowel syndrome such as abdominal pain, bloating, and gas. Non-enteric coated forms of peppermint oil, however, actually may cause or worsen heartburn and nausea."~ Please, if you're going to ingest this oil, be really careful, and see what your doctor thinks.~ There are tons of non-medical uses. The PaleoMama blog offers 20 great ideas on peppermint oil, including ways to eliminate bad breath, eliminating bloating by rubbing on the belly, breathing it in to reduce drowsiness (this works!), repelling spiders and ants (use cottonballs or make a spray), removing ticks, adding to a diffuser to freshen air or help combat stress, adding to a foot soak, mixing with vinegar for a household cleaner, and as an odor control scent for smelly closets/lockers/shoes/whatever.~ Also, as the Amazon blurb says above, you can add this oil to crafty, homemade items such as perfumes, candles, body wash, bath salt, shampoos, conditioners, lotions, balms, and soaps.OVERALL THOUGHTS:Very strong, pure minty oil substance that could probably be used as the perfect murder weapon somehow. I'd have to think about that. You should be careful with this...but it IS the real deal. This is an excellent choice and a good value if you need pure essential oil of peppermint, and there are probably literally hundreds of ways to use this. The dropper itself is also well-made and easy to work with. Five stars for being the good stuff.I received this as a review sample.

This is a fantastic charge unit. It's one of those things I didn't realize I needed, until I had one.You know how old houses don't have enough outlets in a room? Or how hotels might or might not have enough outlets, but they are in inconvenient places? I was recently at a truly crappy rat-bag of a motel with one outlet in the room, right behind the bed. The only source of light (a table lamp) was plugged into one outlet, and the TV had the other. I unplugged the TV (I needed the light), and then spent the rest of the night juggling between my phone and tablet. Good thing it was only me that night - a couple with devices would end up out of luck.Don't ever stay at the Payless Inn in Gila Bend, AZ, BTW.Even more importantly, I can now use one outlet at any coffeeshop, or in the airport, or on a plane...and charge - guilt-free- ALL my devices. No more feeling greedy. I can even share.This just isn't an issue anymore, any of it. Where has this been all my life? Seriously.PROS:- 4 USB ports :)- Everything charges at once, and is each device is actually usable while charging. I have another charger that only allows for either charging OR using, so this is a nice feature.- Charges anything a USB takes. I've used my Samsung, iPhone, ASUS Tablet, Kindle Keyboard, Kindle Paperwhite, USB power bank, and a USB fan...no problems. Nice and speedy and reliable.- Fits in my daily purse. It's a little on the large size for daily toting, but I have a big purse. For actual travel with a backpack, it takes up very little space.- 48 watts of power, so nice for camping with an inverter.- Even with all four ports in use, the device never gets hot. Warm, yes, but not hot. This is a well made unit.CONS:- Although it looks like those cute little charging cords are included with this unit, they aren't. It's just the charging box, with 4 USB ports.- I wish there'd been a little bag for this, since I now bring it everywhere. I went to the Dollar Tree and got a little canvas zip bag for it.I do recommend investing in a few of the shorter charging cords, since when I have all my devices charging at once, my long cords look like a spaghetti factory. This isn't really a problem, just a matter of aesthetics and organization.RECOMMENDATION:Highly recommended. I think anyone with more than one device needs this. Anyone in a relationship needs this - it keeps the peace. If you travel , you need it. Well made, quiet, works!I received this product for review purposes.

Strangely enough, I find myself carrying this monopod around to use quite a bit - more than the actually superior, more upscale version made by this  company. I think I like the squishy handle for gripping (mine is the pretty green one). The aluminum telescoping 'stick' is stronger than it looks, and I really like the way the holder grips my Samsung 5. It feels safe and secure, once I tighten the directional screws down. There's plenty of room for my largish phone, even in its case.A little orange rubbery clip is included for iPhones, but I since my old iPhone 4s lives in a case, I didn't need to use that when I tested this. The newer, more narrow iPhones might need that clip for extra security, or to protect the glass, or both.PROS:- Nice black-on-black box presentation - would make a pretty gift.- The inside is also well-packaged, with all the pieces in a velvety drawstring bag.- I like the heft and feel of the grippy handle.- You can really reach up high with the telescoping arm extended - there are tons of uses for something like this, besides taking selfies. :)- The whole kit, once in it's drawstring bag, is pretty lightweight, so it's very easy to pack this in for camping, hiking,- The handle holds a charge for a long time. I was able to still use this thing after a month, without a recharge.- Charging cable is included too. :)- The green color is attractive. I like that there are several color choices with this company; these selfie sticks stand out (no pun intended) from all the boring black ones on the market.- With the phone holder unscrewed, there's a standard camera mount on the monopod, so it works with digital cameras too.CONS:- The button for taking the picture is at the upper part of the handle, which is less convenient then at the lower end. Unless you have a large hand, that cuts off a half foot of picture height. The other YOPO has this issue corrected.- The button itself is kind of 'soft' - I do prefer the actual clickey type button on the other YOPO Bluetooth Selfie Stick.- No instructions. I don't know why there isn't even a card for this. If you don't know how to operate Bluetooth features, you have to do some internet research on your own. That's kind of an oversight, in my book.OVERALL RECOMMENDATION:Sturdy BlueTooth monopod that gives you plenty of extra height, works well, holds phones securely, while looking good. :)I received this product as a review sample.

Smells lovely, is gentle on my face, and does a nice job of cleansing off dirt. It also leaves my skin feeling dewy and soft:  I'd even go so far as to call this rose water dreamy, okay? I love spraying it on my face all day long, just to refresh myself. It's like taking a gentle break from whatever stresses are going on...literally taking time to smell the roses.AS A TONER:My facial skin tends to be sensitive to fragrances, so usually my toners and spritzers are scentless.  I'm very careful with what I allow on my face. I don't feel like I have to worry with this one. Not a single breakout yet.I'm not a daily makeup wearer (only for special events, really), but my face does get grimy from all the gardening, yardwork,  and outdoor activity I do. This definitely picks up dirt, grit and sweat on my cotton rounds.FOR MENOPAUSE:Yes, at 47 I'm right about there. I've been experiencing the hot flashes and irritation that comes with peri-menopause for five years now, and I don't see that letting up any time soon. I'm already carrying this around in my purse, along with my usual microfiber washcloth, to mop up the sudden tropical monsoons I get on my face and chest. After wiping off the sweat, I spray this on, and just let it evaporate off. I feel cooler, and less irritable.DISCLAIMER:I received this product as a review sample, but will be buying it as soon as I run out. I don't want to be without it, especially as summer ramps up and  the humidity really kicks in. I'm sorry about all the superlatives, but this Rose Water is one of the nicest personal treats I've run across, ever.

Think Thin makes some hits and misses in their flavors, and I'd say this one is a miss. It's not awful-tasting, but it isn't what I'd call good, and the texture is a bit chalky. I expect more...flavor...out of something called Cookies and Cream.What's good? It's gluten-free, has a lot of protein (20 grams is significant), and comes in a convenient bar format. There isn't any added sugar, so it's low on the glycemic index.It's not low carb (11 grams), or low calorie (230), or even low fat (7 grams). It's just a way to get some more protein into your day, and to avoid spiking your blood sugar while doing it.My recommendation is to try one of the other Think Thin bar flavors. I prefer the Chocolate Covered Strawberries one, and the White Chocolate. Keep in mind that NONE of these bars are going to taste like dessert; but some are more palatable than others. Since everyone's taste buds are different, you might want to try out single versions of different varieties before you settle on an entire box of them.

This shampoo is a bit thin, and I didn't find it all that amazing to use. It cleans hair, but doesn't have any kind of elegant scent or texture, and didn't leave me feeling like I'd done much cleansing, either. My hair felt a bit heavy and limp, somehow, after using.It's light on the lather, which is actually a good thing (sudsing doesn't actually do anything to clean hair), but since I'm used to lather, it did feel a bit odd.I've also used the conditioner and oil in this line, and none of these products left me impressed.For reference, I have dark brown Causasian hair of medium texture and thickness. I don't think my hair is the target market for what this product is about.

These things work, but it's a slow process. I've used used mine over the course of a year, and noticed they work best when left in an area not often frequented by people.For example, when I put them in my daily use clothes closet, I never saw a single bug trapped in it. But when I moved them to my RV, over the course of months the entire thing filled up with moths, crawlies and grub-like things.I put one in my RV clothing wardrobe and the other in the food pantry. The food pantry one worked so very well after a few months, that I moved the  second one to the food pantry too. It also filled up. I'm very glad to not have these insects crawling around my food. I'll be buying these again for the food cabinets in my RV...this may be an off-label use, but I'm glad to have figured this out.If you have major problems with moths in your clothes (probably in an attic or some other infrequently used area), then I can verify that moths are indeed attracted to the trap, but it takes them a while to find it. This isn't the item for a quick fix. I think you'd need something stronger (ie - more toxic) for that.

Suitable hardhat with a nifty UV exposure element (because sunlight breaks down plastic). The suspension harness is comfortable, once it's in there.Which leads to my main issue with this hat: the frustration factor in assembling the suspension/strap system. The written instructions were a bit feeble - worse than Ikea's hieroglyphics.I understand that sending it out unassembled kept the price point down, but I'd rather pay a bit more and have it arrive in a ready-to-wear form. At the very least, some care and attention should be paid to making usable instructions. Perhaps most buyers are in the construction industry and already know how to put a suspension harness in a hat? Still, I feel that's no excuse. People buy products for all kinds of reasons, and not just because a brick might fall on their head. ;)I tend to retrofit my hardhats for caving use by removing the 'brim'...which required a little bit of power tool use and some sanding, but then worked fine. I also had a to buy a hardhat chin strap: those cost around $4-$7 on Amazon. This all cost less than the price of an actual caving helmet (those start at $50 and go up to over a hundred dollars), so it was a worthwhile endeavor. Note that in a cave, you don't get an awful lot of UV light, so I don't expect the sensor tag to go off-color on me anytime soon.The vent holes are a nice touch, and the design of the helmet leaves me plenty of room to strap on a headlamp.

Multiple uses! I do like the 'selfie' idea - I take enough of them, like everyone else, but I actually prefer this as a monopod for getting nature photography at angles I just can't on my own. The Bluetooth button at the base allows for me to make creatively framed shots, without having to get into crazy positions.Other uses:- Getting enough distance for group shots, without needing to mess with self-timers, or in finding stable/safe places to rest your phone.- Using to record events - meetings, classes, flash mobs, concerts, dance clubs...anywhere where you need the height.- You can actually be discreet taking people photos with this, since you're not holding it up to your face. You can hold it off to the side, or down low, over people's heads, or even around a corner. Think of the International Spy uses! :)Pros:- The mount works on real cameras - if you don't screw in the phone, there's a standard camera mount!The spring mount for the phone holds my Galaxy 5, even in its big case.- USB charging cord for handle is included.- I have to mention the lovely packaging. The black-on-black box is pretty, inside and out, with every last piece of the item set in a black foam backing. Gift quality presentation.- The velvety carry pouch is a thoughtful addition.- Solid handle with a grippy texture and good plastic button, well placed.- I ordered mine in blue. It's a very pretty blue. :)- My phone picked up the Bluetooth connection right away.- Handle keeps a charge for a long time!Cons:- Where are the instructions? If I didn't know how to set up my Bluetooth, I'd be hunting the Internet to figure this thing out. No instructions included. None. With everything else so carefully presented and included, this seems a crazy oversight.- The extension rods are a little stiff at first - they don't screw out - you pull them. Yet, once extended, you do have to be a little delicate with it. It doesn't lock into position.- The weight of my phone makes things a little awkward at the farthest end of extension. Use caution.Overall:One of the better selfie/monopods/spy devices on the market (I've tested four in the last month!). Instructions should have been included...but aside from that, this one is sturdy, the handle has a nice heft to it, the photo button is well placed, and the entire box is just so pretty. Recommended both for one's own use, or as a nicely presented gift.Disclaimer: I received a sample of this product for review purposes.

"My soul is wrapped in harsh repose,Midnight descends in raven-colored clothes,But soft... behold!A sunlight beamButting a swath of glimmering gleam.My heart expands,'tis grown a bulge in it,Inspired by your beauty...Effulgent."William isn't the world's best poet, but he's got my heart. I've got my own little Spike to adore me and defend me from a sad and crazy world. He sits next to my computer monitor, watching out for demons, loving me, guarding me, making my days happier, even if he would like a little blood from time to time. My William doesn't have a chip, or a trigger, but he does have a soul.He's even got the little eyebrow scar from the Boxer Rebellion, and the leather duster he pulled off that one Slayer during his Billy Idol days.

This isn't the best dust mop on the market, but it's a good one for the price point. I like using it - it's just so easy to get the hairs and dust and little bits of floor flotsam out the door. The blue color is also cheerful, which appeals to me.Pros:- Lightweight and pleasant to use. No lugging.- I don't have to attach something to the bottom every time I want to use it, unlike the Swiffer dust mop- To clean it off, I just take it outside and shake it. The dust flies off and into the wind.- If I want greater gripping power, I just hold a can of Pledge a foot away from the mop head and lightly spray it into the blue hairs.- The mop head bends nicely between the floor and wall.Cons:- Blue hairs come out all the time at first, making a mess. This stabilizes, though, after a bit of use.- The hairs aren't very grippy for anything larger than hair or dust. For the other little random things that end up on floors, I end up using this like a push broom. That's fine and all, but it's worth noting.Recommendation:This is a good everyday dust mop for light conditions. Heavy-duty conditions would be too much to expect...if you have a lot of foot traffic and constant floor dirt, you will need to buy something else.

I've had this cover for a year now, and it's stood me in excellent stead. I drop my phone ALL THE TIME. This case absorbs all the impacts, leaving me with a perfect, crack-free phone. The raised edges also provide a bit of a lip to prevent scratches on the glass. Seriously, I'm hard on my stuff - anything I choose to use had better be up to the task.Also love the cobalt blue color. It hasn't faced at all, although you can see a bit of oil staining from where my fingers grip my phone from my constant texting and photography. The entire look of it is rugged, and somehow makes me think of The Borg, or a Terminator.The only issue I have with the case is the useless stand. I think I used it once before it broke off. I can jiggle it around to work it back in and make it do an okay job of giving me a hands-free horizontal view of whatever I'm watching...but I can't touch it. So, if I want to do any reading where touch swiping is involved, the stand just falls back off again. It's so annoying to use that I forget it's even there.I also found it a bit hard to get on my phone, the first time. Three edges would go right in, but the last fought me for hours. I had to get someone with stronger hands to force it completely in there. Once in, it stays put. So, that's good.I won't take a star off the case for having a ridiculously weak stand, since I bought it for phone protection, period, and that's where the strength of this product lies.Overall, I love the color, the price is great, and it really is a heavy duty piece of plastic.

After a lot of use, I'm happy with this 'hobo' style lunch sack. It's cute and well-constructed.Pros:- Very cute dots and style line- Thick, solid zipper- BUILT makes good products, so I trust them- The thick neoprene protects whats inside, and adds an element of insulation for both hot and hot foods- Easy to clean by just wiping with a wet towel, or rinsing in the sink- After almost two years of use, still going strong- Solid stitcheryCons:-  Strap stretches out under too much weight - so be careful with that. Mine hasn't broken yet, or stretched too far to be useful, but I'm mindful to use this for lighter items like food, and not as a quick carry-all for heavy things like books, or beverages- Seriously, not for the heavy stuff, unless you want to ruin the strap- Not big enough for use as a beach tote - towels alone would take up the entire space and look bulgyRecommendation:Great thickness, durability, style and usefulness for lighter items like food. Thick and durable zipper. Good for picnic food, as a cute 'lunch box', or for toting small extra day items around.

I liked the taste of this bar, which surprised me, seeing all the reviews that said it tasted bad. Everyone has different taste buds, and different experiences with food bars. Suffice to say, this has a simple chocolate-strawberry flavor that I found appealing.It was soft without being overly chewy. Not crunchy - rather smooth.It didn't stick to the roof of my mouth. So, non-offensive in texture. It wasn't sweet like a candy bar, but it's not intended to be. Sometimes I think we expect too much of weight loss food bars. They're never going to be like a  Snickers!In any case, I've had far, far worse protein bars. I'd actually order and eat this particular flavor again. Seriously - so many bad bars out there: this was just a treat.Enough on the taste and texture. What about the nutrition?- Protein is the first ingredient, made mostly from whey and soy. There are 15 grams of protein in one bar. Good deal.- Malitol instead of sugar...in fact, there is no sugar listed in the Nutrition Facts.Again, I like that.- Gluten Free, if you care.-  There IS fat - 7 grams, of which 3 are saturated fat. There is no trans-fat. Keep in mind this is a protein bar, not a calorie-free one. I'd prefer less saturated fat. It's probably from the Casein (dairy protein).- 200 calories per bar, which is a reasonable for a protein bar.- 23 carbs per bar. So...not exactly low-carb!Recommendation:Not low carb, not low cal...but with 15 grams, it's very high in protein (by comparison, an egg is only 6 grams of protein). Some saturated fat (3 grams). Gluten free, and high in soy. I liked the taste, since I wasn't expecting candy-bar flavor. The texture is inoffensive, unlike Power Bars that stick to the top of your palette.  Keep in mind what your goals are...for a high protein bar that travels well and tastes good, go with this one.

I don't generally like sweet beverages, but with this packet, I could dilute it as much as I wanted, and it still carried the neat flavor of coconut and tropical fruit (called passionfuit on the label, but I honestly do not know what exactly passionfuit tastes like). I thought it was a unique and pleasant flavor. Lipton did a nice job with it this powdered Green Tea line.The best thing with this packet is that it travels very easily, and keeps well. I've held onto this little bag for a year and half, and just opened it today while at a hotel room. I wanted something to wake me up and start my day, without resorting to using the sometimes icky coffee packets left for travelers in hotel rooms.I was able to open the packet without scissors, which was nice. It has a little 'start' section for ripping it open. Scent DOES billow out when you pour it int a glass, so be aware if that sort of thing makes you sneeze.Tasted fresh, and the little clumpy parts smoothed right out when stirred slightly.Be aware the first ingredient is sugar (honey granules), plus there is sucralose and maltodextrin (more sweet enhancements). This isn't a health drink. :)It's a little unclear from the directions (in tiny font) exactly how much water to use with it. One packet makes two servings in a glass...but you can one one packet in a 17 ounce bottle of water. The key to remember is that if you put it ALL in one glass, it's pretty overpowering. I prefer the idea of using it in a water bottle and just sipping across over your day. Once in the bottle, you can also just shake it, without needing a spoon for stirring.In any case, the combo of sugar and green tea powder woke me up and put me in a good mood. I wasn't expecting a nice taste...and was happy to be wrong.Recommended for  traveling, or just being on the go. Slip a packet into your pocket, purse, suitcase...and head out.

This lovely conditioner is a thick creamy white that smells terrific while using, and leaves my hair smooth and shiny. It works better than the more expensive non-lice conditioners I've been normally using.How I use this:With my long, wavy hair, I need about three solid pumps of product. I work it into my hair, starting with an emphasis on roots, working down my hair shaft, and then applying some to my root and scalp line. I massage it on and leave it on for about five minutes, and then rinse.The result:I don't seem to have a lot lot repellent-type scent once it dries. My husband detected a faintish lemony smell from my damp hair, and I couldn't detect any scent from my long ends, once dry. So, will the scent that remains be enough to drive away the biting insects that torment me? Mostly, I follow this up with the stronger and long-lasting repellent spray this company makes, and that does the trick.Honestly, what I love this conditioner for is the soothing, healing, and smoothing effect is has on me. My scalp itches less, and my hair becomes very soft and smooth. I love it, just as it is.Product notes:The bottle is a dark plastic that keeps the vast array of essential oils and potent healing ingredients from breaking down. The pump works smoothly.This container doesn't scream "WE HAVE LICE HERE" all over it - in fact, you'd really have to read through the entire small-font blurb to even find the word lice. So if fits in on my bath shelf without any stigma. Not that I have lice...but I do have major issues with no-see-ums. As it warms up here in North Carolina, I'm hopeful this conditioner will help either 1. keep the no-see-ums away, or 2. soothe my itchy and sore scalp after any bites I do get. If it works, I'll make sure to have gallons of this stuff, and leave it on for 20 minutes at a time, maybe using it as a body lotion and even shaving my legs with it. There's nothing in the ingredients list that cannot be left on.Ingredients:The bottle has different ingredients for soothing and protecting the scalp and hair, and for insect repelling. For the former, it's loaded with helpful ingredients - Emu Oil, Olive Fruit Oil, Argan Oil, Grapeseed oil, rice protein, panthenol, and glycerine. For repellent qualities, it contains lemongrass oil, lemon oil, geranium oil, and lemon-eucalyptus oil.That last one is probably the key - the CDC released information stating that lemon-eucalyptus works to keep biting bugs away. I trust information from the CDC (Center for Disease Control).OVERALL RECOMMENDATION:Use this conditioner for the wonderful way it leaves hair - shiny and smooth - and for the soothing effects it has on scalps that have been itchy and subsequently scratched to death. It's a super pleasant product, and one I intend to keep around. For the best repellent qualities, pair it with the repellent spray they produce that spritzes on hair AND body.Note: I received this conditioner as a review sample.

This whole line is innovative and pleasant to use, but between the repellent spray, the shampoo and the conditioner, this is the item I feel works the least well for actual repellent action. As a shampoo itself, it's pretty nice. Not excellent, like the conditioner and spray, but quite nice. And it has nice soothing ingredients to counter sore, itchy spots.The texture is think, and looks mostly clear with a whitish tinge to it.Pros:- Pretty scent that I love, but apparently insects don't: lemon oil, lemongrass oil, geranium oil and lemon-eucalyptus oil - the latter of which is recommeded by the CDC to keep biting insects away.- No one would ever know, seeing the bottle resting on my tub, that it's for something 'uncooth' like lice. The bottle and label look like something you'd find in the beauty section of of health store co-op. The label has an 'all natural' look to it.- Dark plastic keeps the volatile essential oils within fresh longer.- Smooth pump action.- My hair feels super clean and super smooth. I don't know how much of that is due to the line's conditioner that I used after, but the ingredients list is wholesome, with healing ingredients like Emu Oil (not vegetarian), aloe (the main ingredient), passionfruit oil, acai oil, rice bran oil and panthenol.Pros:- Formulation is a bit runny.- Not much lather action. This isn't actually a con, since lather itself does nothing to clean hair. I just found myself using more of it on my very long hair, just in case.- Keep in mind this ins't the shampoo to use when you actually HAVE lice. That would be a totally different product - I remember from my childhood that those had a tar-like substance. This is more of a scented repellent, and a way to soothe the scalp after lice has actually been removed after using the appropriate removal products. Again, not a bad thing here, but an important distinction to be aware of.After using both the shampoo and conditioner, I didn't find the scent as clear and apparent as I was expecting. My husband could barely smell the lemonyness in my hair. I think, scentwise, it smells great in the bottle, but dissipates quickly after using. Fair enough on a shampoo, which is a beauty product mainly to put on and quickly rinse out. For a repellent, I really prefer the spray made by this company, which lasts and lasts, besides working on BOTH hair and body.Note: I can see using all three products as a way to layer the scent, and would suggest the company add a soap and body lotion/oil to the line. I want to wreathe myself in this scent! I have a huge no-see-um reaction each time it warms up outside, and would rather not use toxic DEET all over my body/hair every year.Overall:- I like this shampoo a lot for it's healing qualities and nice scent, but won't rely on this alone for keeping bitey bugs away. The scent just doesn't last much after rinsing. While the spray and conditioner will become a permanent part of my summer-time bug arsenal, I'll be sticking to my regular cheapy shampoo once this is used up. However - if I had a sore, itching scalp, I'd go right out and get this again, since I think that's where its biggest benefit lies.Disclaimer: I received this shampoo as a review sample.

Without access to instructions in English, I had to experiment with using this whole leaf, high end tea. If done right, you get a delicious and soothing cup. A little bit of the leaves go a long way, and I really recommend using a clear glass with this tea, since drinking it is only 1/3 the point of the process in Presentation Teas.As far as I can glean from my side of the globe, Presentation Teas offer three parts to the user:1. Making the tea2. Watching the leaves absorb water and sink, creating a soothing, meditative 'water feature'  in your glass3. Actually sipping the tea and and relaxing into a new day/afternoonI believe the process is intended as a sort of Firewall to stress. You're forced to slow down and be with your thoughts for a reasonable break of time. I'm not even a spiritual person, but I can absolutely see the value in this. Buy something cheaper, in tea bags, if you don't have the time to make your own 'ritual' with this tea line.Pros:- Lovely scented green tea.- The Jasmine Tea is fragrant, and easy to drink for people new to the very layered and complex luxury green teas from Asia.- Elegant leaves that look great when served in clear glass, as depicted in the Amazon blurb.- Very nice black tin, with elegant Asian characters in a raised silver design. When all the tea is used up, I'll be happy to reuse the tin in my office.- The tin has a printed safety seal, and the inner bag is vacuum sealed.- Using the tea in a loose presentation format is a slow experience, but I think that's intentional. It takes a good 10-15 minutes for all of the  whole (uncut) leaves to fully saturate and settle. In the meantime, you get some time to meditate, warm your hands around the glass, look out the window and relax, or sit convivially with friends.Cons:- The nice characters are pretty to look at, but there aren't any instructions in English. The only English I can see on my tin are the words Jasmine Tea. If you know how to brew loose tea, not having instructions won't be an issue, but if you aren't familiar with using exact steeping times, the resultant tea is a bitter brew. I had to do a bit of experimentation, and I've used loose tea before. I recommend looking around the internet for exact details.- The inner bag is not resealable, so the tea will not stay as fresh as it could be, once opened.- The not tea to use for quick mornings. You kind of have to make a ritual of it. Of course, you could put the loose leaves in a tea ball, but I think with a tea of this quality, you're missing the point of the experience. This is a 'slow food' example (ie - the opposite of fast food).Note:Green tea is a source of L-Theanine, the compound that's supposed to decrease stress levels in the brain. Green tea also contains caffeine, so I think the idea is that the L-Theanine will slow down any caffeinated jitters, but not get you so sleepy that work is impossible. Green tea was probably the world's first 'Smart Drug".Overall:Great tea in terms of taste and presentation. A nice introduction to using tea in a mindful way. Jasmine in particular is a good start for the newbie to break into the higher-end loose green teas, since Jasmine smooth and friendly-tasting, and not as complicatedly layered as other teas of this type. :)Received as a review sample.

One thing that surprised me: this book is a memoir. Based on the title and blurb, I was expecting more of a guide to handling adult-type conversations with young people.The memoir itself is a quick, light and easy read, and never goes very deep. There are amusing passages, and a couple of times I smiled to myself in appreciation. I do admire the level of honesty the author shares with her daughter, and agree that her parenting style is worth emulating. I just would have liked this to have been more of a how-to guide than a collection of essays loosely tied to the theme of 'hard questions'.There are tons of family-anecdote memoirs and mommy blogs already out there, so I'm not sure this collection is particularly new in the huge and thriving genre that's already out there. I would have appreciated if, anywhere on the front and back covers, this book was indicated as a memoir.

This was a pretty cute memoir/tale, based on the social media experiences of a young man listening in to girlish chatter, and learning a few things about life along the way. I was expecting the story to be a little mean-spirited towards the girls, but was happy to see that everything was in good fun.The whole story was pleasant and amusing. Not knee-slappingly funny, but full of interesting insights, showing a surprising amount of character growth in what could have been a one-trick pony type of story. I liked it, and look forward to seeing what else the author might publish.

This is a very nice puzzle, with solid pieces that are cut well, good colors, and a design that isn't a pain to put together. I know some people like puzzles that are hard on purpose, but I prefer one that I can put together in an evening or two, for relaxation purposes. This one has lots of clues in the picture to let you know what part you're working on.The whimsical pieces are a novel idea that adds another dimensional element to the process of putting it together.Highly recommended if you use puzzles to relax your mind, instead of testing your mind. There's a difference.

For being cheaply made little cubby bins, I really like these. The double-thickness of cardboard has stood up to my abuse now for a couple of years without ripping, fraying, bending or falling open at the bottom.What else do I like?- Although sometimes the plastic handles pop out, I can snap them right back in.- It's surprisingly attractive for, in essence, being a cardboard box.- There were two in my pack, which look nice when set up next to each other.- They were easy to assemble (they arrive flat, as cardboard boxes tend to do).I've even moved a few times, using these to store my silver plate goblets and art supplies, and the bins are still going strong.I did think they were a bit expensive, for what they are. I think at this price point, there are options that might look better on open shelves. Also, mine came with one handle per box, which makes carrying the boxes a tad awkward.

This cream is rather thick, and has a slightly stick feel to it. I have to wash it off my hands after using. The scent is also a little bizarre: it's not a bad smell, so much as not really a pretty smell. Kind of like glue?I only need a little bit of this product to tame my frizzies, curls or hair ends...too much and it starts to make my hair look dull. The formulation does work for me, but it's simply not the hair product I reach for when I need serum or control. I don't find it elegant, texture-wise, it's too easy for me to end up using too much of this, and I don't like the smell.What's interesting is that Just For Me makes another hair milk that I like and use: the Curl Smoother. I'm sure different people will prefer one over the other. It's worth experimenting.For reference, I have wavy, dark, Caucasian hair of average texture and thickness.

I like the scent and texture of this creamy white hair 'milk'. When I add it to my dry hair, it tames down the frizzies without making it sticky or greasy-looking. I can use this on both straight hair days and curly hair days.This isn't just for children - I like it just as well on my adult hair. For reference, I have dark Caucasian hair of middle texture and thickness, with a tendency for waviness.How I use it on dry hair:1. I pour a dollop into my hands, and rub my hands together.2. Starting at the ends, I work it into my hair and then work it up the hair shaft. I don't put much on top of my head. I really concentrate on the ends, and on the shorter hair pieces around my face.3. On curly hair days, I scrunch the milk into my hair.4. On straight hair days, I just smooth it around sections of my hair in pieces.I'm not thrilled with using this on wet hair - it doesn't seem to do much of anything when used that way, unless I scrunch it in and then strictly leave my hair alone when dry: any further styling removes any benefit.

As of this review this queen sized mattress costs $253.96 which I think is a fair price though I would not want to pay anymore for it.  It came in a big, tight roll inside a long, cardboard box.  I didn't know a mattress could get rolled up like that - much like you would roll up a sleeping bag.  And it was held in a tight roll by several layers of heavy-duty plastic so be careful when using scissors or a knife to cut off the plastic that you don't accidentally cut the mattress material.  We took the unwrapped mattress roll upstairs and set it on the box springs and unwrapped it there.  It quickly unrolls itself and then it is easy to adjust on the box springs.It fit our queen size box springs perfectly and we compared it to the queen sized mattress that it was replacing and both were exactly the same size.  However, the Classic Brands mattress only has one side up (the pillowtop side) and the other side is a different color and material and not meant to be slept on, so you will not be able to flip this mattress every few months or so like other mattresses.  The pillowtop adds some cush to the mattress and makes it more comfortable.  The material appears to be fairly durable, but I wouldn't expect it to last for years and years.  Although we have used this mattress to replace our nearly 20 year old former queen sized mattress, I think it would be better to use on a bed in a guest bedroom since it can't be flipped and might eventually sag.  There are no handles on the side to move the mattress but it's not too terribly heavy.We slept on it all last night without adding an extra mattress topper (foam) and it was comfortable enough, though this morning I put a foam mattress topper on it because I really like how comfortable they make any bed.  Overall, I think this is a good mattress for the money, but I haven't had it long enough to see how it holds up over time therefore only 4 stars for now.

So far, of all the tanning solutions, sprays, creams, etc....that I have tried I find this one works the best.  I get a nice, even realistic-looking tan and the only orangish areas are on the bony parts of my body (ankle bones, tops of my feet) where I neglected to wipe the tanning mousse off. So, overall it tans well and lasts me about a week before I notice it fading away.  I can even shave my legs and still keep my tan.Other reviewers have very well described in detail the application process (which should be followed exactly for a positive result), so I won't waste mine or your time talking about it.  Though the XEN-TAN Mousse is a bit pricey I think it delivers a good tan for the money.  I've tried a lot of other tanning products and some worked well but others turned me orange or didn't last past the next shower.  This one seems to hold for a while which is good.

My youngest daughter always gets a nagging cough (maybe due to allergies in the fall) and though she is no longer a baby, I gave her a double dose of this and to my surprise it stopped her coughing at least long enough for her to go to sleep.  So, I think it's worth at least 4 stars.  And she usually doesn't like the flavor of any cough syrups but didn't balk at the flavor of this one.

I guess I'm just spoiled at how easy the ketone test strips are to use.  All you have to do is pee on them, but this ketone tester is a lot more involved and I'm not really sure it's any more accurate than the strips.  Basically, when I was using the strips I just wanted to know if I was finally burning fat or not and they told me what my fat burning situation was, and for less money.  This disposable Breath Ketone Test works if you follow all the steps very carefully.  I tried too, but I don't know for sure.  I never did reach the fat burning stage according to it.  But, honestly, I really didn't totally cut out carbs so I'm not surprised.  The only times I ever tested positive for fat burn was when I was on the Atkins diet and followed it to a tee.  It really worked despite all the negative hype about it.These work, but are kind of laborious to use.

These are definitely on the cheaper side of tennis shoes but I thought I would try them out and hopefully save some money.  I can wear them if I lace them up tightly but they are a little loose.  I play tennis and really need better fitting shoes so I gave these to my husband whose feet fit them much better though he didn't like the bright orange color.  He was thinking everyone could tell he was wearing women's tennis shoes but I know he'll wear them.  I will be going back to my other shoes brand that fits much better though it costs twice as much.

I like that these contain no artificial ingredients, sugar or fillers.  They taste pretty good with a sour bite but still sweet enough.  I think these will probably sell well especially for those who love raspberries and apples.  I like both but not too fond of the raspberry seeds and I still rather just eat the fruit in it's natural state.These are puffed up like big cereal balls and could maybe used as a cereal in milk but I wasn't given enough to try that out.  My family ate my small sample before I got to it leaving me only a few of them left to try.

I've been taking glucosamine chondroitin off and on for quite awhile but have recently been more regular about it since I am much more active and I'm in my mid-fifties. Though I don't have serious joint issues, my knees do let me know they aren't exactly happy after a healthy 2 sets of furious tennis against my daughter. When I take these I notice that my knees don't scream at me nearly as much and overall I feel more flexible. I will probably continue taking these on a regular basis. I used to buy the glucosamine/chondrointin and MSM separately from SAM's club but really like having it combined into a tablet so there's fewer tablets to swallow.

These are the Cadillac of Omega 3 supplements imho.  They are very easy to swallow and I haven't noticed any fishy burps afterwards.  I'm not pregnant, nor is my husband, but these are very good for all people not just those who are pregnant.  This bottle won't last long since the directions say to take 2 pills with each meal, but it's a big bottle of 180 pills so they will last about a month or so before needing more.  I think these are a very good source of DHA Omega 3 fatty acids and there is nothing more I can add to say that the other reviewers haven't already said.

I have longed to take CoQ10 but when I see it for sale in regular stores it's just out of my price range.  I don't know what they are selling this for but when I was given the opportunity to review it I took it.  I was looking at the list of ingredients and noticed it has black pepper in it.  I can only guess that the peperin (sp?) is needed to bind with the CoQ10 to pull it into the bloodstream.  I add freshly ground pepper to my Golden Paste that I make at home for the same reason.  (Google "Golden Paste" and you will find something wonderful).I am at the age where I need all the anti-oxidants I can get and anything that will help with heart health is wanted. As another reviewer noted, I can't possibly eat enough CoQ10 in my food to get what one of these pills will easily deliver. And these pills (softgels) are very easy to swallow since they are nice and small and slick.  I feel as one grows older, if such supplements are available and found to be helpful then they should be used.  I can't say I can "feel" any improvement physically, but I rarely notice an actual physical feeling of improvement with most of the supplements I take.  That doesn't mean they don't help with health since I do feel good by far most of the time.

I'm a little confused about the ingredients labeling.  The product page says chicken is the first ingredient, but as I sit here and look at the bag I have for review, it say the first ingredient is corn meal, followed by chicken by-product meal and then chicken.  I have deducted a star because I always want to see meat listed as the first ingredient and I know corn meal is always GMO now days.That said, my dogs seem to like this food and readily eat it up.  I hope it helps with weight control of one of my pudgy poochies, but I think I should walk her more often too.

I've been taking glucosamine chondroitin off and on for quite awhile but have recently been more regular about it since I am much more active and I'm in my mid-fifties.  Though I don't have serious joint issues, my knees do let me know they aren't exactly happy after a healthy 2 sets of furious tennis against my daughter.  When I take these I notice that my knees don't scream at me nearly as much and overall I feel more flexible.  I will probably continue taking these on a regular basis.  I used to buy the glucosamine/chondrointin and MSM separately from SAM's club but really like having it combined into a tablet so there's fewer tablets to swallow.

This stuff is great for those times when you are sick.  I mean sick with a stomach bug including vomiting and diarrhea and all that loveliness involved.  This will greatly help replace lost fluids and electrolytes that are lost through the above activities. I drank this when I got food poisoning and was sick (with the above activities) for 4 days.  It helped me to not dehydrate away and eased my suffering somewhat but I could only drink it right after tossing my cookies or I'd be tossing it too.I received the dry powder which I think is even better than the pre-mixed liquid.  If you store the dry Pedialyte in a dry, dark and cool place it should last for months, possibly years before losing it's effectiveness.  I was glad to get the dry too, because it takes up practically no space compared to the big bottles.I can't say enough good things about this stuff.  I just wish I knew about it back in the day when I was bad to party.......don't really need it for that anymore but I understand it helps a lot with hangovers, so it's not just for babies and kids.  And though it doesn't taste as good as Kool-Aid it doesn't taste bad either. Definitely 5 stars.

I only have 30 days to try out this product before I have to write a review on it and I wish I had more time since taking supplements almost always takes a while before seeing any noticeable effects.  However, I will say that I frequently get a sore shoulder from playing a lot of tennis and I have not noticed my shoulder being sore in the time I have been taking this supplement.  I understand that Astaxanthin is supposedly a powerful anti-oxidant and anti-inflammatory so I think that is a good combination.  This is the first time I've ever taken Astaxanthin and so far no bad reaction but I'm not allergic to shellfish either.  Since it is derived from seafood, I would be very careful if you are allergic to fish.

Our chihuahua has always had a bad breath problem even shortly after getting her teeth cleaned about 5 months ago.  I feed her dry dog food almost exclusively and she gets a lot of dog biscuits to help keep her teeth clean.  The vet who cleaned her teeth said chihuahuas just get gunk build up much faster on their teeth than do larger dogs - hence the reason I opted to try out these breath drops.I've been putting about two squirts in her water dish at every re-fill, and though I have not intentionally gotten my nose near her face or mouth to test for how much funk she is emitting, I have not noticed it being very bad.  I think the drops are helping to a certain extent.  Apparently the taste of the water is still alright after spraying some breath drops into it since she drinks it just fine and she has always been a particular beast when it comes to flavors.  I haven't run out of the drops yet and I change out the water at least once each day.  So far I think this is helping with her chronic halitosis.

I can't really tell if this has helped with gas or not.  I think maybe a little because sometimes when I eat a lot of fibrous foods it seems I don't get gassy at all, but at others times I still do.  I take it as directed  - one with a meal and then kind of wait and see what does or does not happen.  Some people swear by this stuff and others are in the same boat I'm in.  I have to turn in this review within 30 days and I haven't always remembered to take this pill with each meal but I have taken it enough I think to determine if it's helping with legumes and other gas-producing foods and I think it helps sometimes.  I just don't know why it seems to help some times and at others it's like I'm banned to the great outdoors for a while by my family.

I should have known better than to request this product for review.  I tried a different Garcinia Cambogia product about a year ago and it gave me the most terrible bloating and belly-ache that I've had in a long time.  I really wasn't 100% sure at the time that the cause was the Garcinia Gambogia but now I am certain.  I only took one pill of this and I was in some very uncomfortable gastric distress for about two days.  Obviously, this product is not for me but not everyone reacts to it like I do.  Please read the other reviews concerning it's aid to weight loss since I cannot report back on that.  I'm not really saying it's a bad product by giving it two stars, it just doesn't agree with my digestive system.

This is really quite a nice cat tree. However, YOU MUST BUILD IT FROM THE TOP DOWN!!!.  If you build it from the bottom up like we did the first time, you get to the top tier board and there is no way to screw it down and it will be very loose and not cat-useable.  We had built it completely and got to the last step of putting on the top board and realized we would have to disassemble it and build it from the top tier down which was not an easy task because we had to keep reversing everything.  The included instructions have no writing on them whatsoever, and is just a picture diagram of the cat tree with all the parts numbered and what piece goes where.  Nothing was mentioned about the order of assembly.  So, for something that should be easy to assemble turned out to be a project for me and my husband with several curse words and insults delivered to each other.The finished product however, is quite a nice thing.  It looks really cool and is coated in a creamy colored carpet.  All the poles have a rope-like material wrapped around them which is great for cats to claw on.  Our chihuahua immediately discovered the cat resting pouch (which you can't really see in the picture) and made herself at home.  I think she might be using this more than our cat.  I hope to get a picture of both of them on it at the same time.  Overall, I really do like this cat tree.  It's not overly big and we have it against a portion of our wall in our bedroom.  The various things offered to a cat (or chihuahua) to do are numerous.  It's very steady and doesn't seem to want to tilt one way or the other and we have it sitting on carpet. The materials used seem good - the hard pieces are made from press board and the carpet though not super great, should last a while before turning into shreds.I would have given it 5 stars if it wasn't such a beast to rebuild.  The instructions should have made that clear.  If the instructions had been drawn in a way to reflect the order of building it it would have been a piece of cake since all you need is an Allen wrench which is included.  If you start from the top down it won't be very difficult - just re-orienting the parts was kind of a mental exercise.

Although these dog biscuits are aimed at large breed dogs, my little dogs could eat them just fine.  The ingredients are o.k. but not what I'd prefer for the price of these biscuits.  As of this review they cost $8.99 for a 12 ounce bag.  If meat had been the first ingredient instead of wheat flour I might would give these 5 stars.  The second ingredient is chicken by-product meal (hate to think of the innards in that) followed by dried beet pulp.My dogs seemed to like the flavor, even the finicky chihuahua.  She usually takes dog biscuits from me but buries them in the cat box for me to find later.  This time I didn't find it in the cat box so she must have eaten it.  I bit a bite off of one and it tasted like a regular dog biscuit - grainy, crunchy with a bitter back taste so I wasn't too fond of it.  It tasted a lot like Milk Bone dog biscuits.  I often taste the pet food for myself when doing reviews in order to really be more accurate about the flavor and texture of the products mine and anyone else's pets might be eating.

As far as I can tell, these are high quality vitamin C capsules.  According to the info sheet, these are non GMO because the vitamin C is derived from non-GMO corn grown in Scotland.  Whether that's actually true or not, I don't know but I'll take their word for it.  Each capsule contains 1000mg vitamin C, 25mg Rose Hips and 25 mg Citrus Bioflavonoid Peel Complex.  The label on the front of the bottle says there's 250 capsules inside, but the lid has a red sticker saying there's 50 bonus capsules so I guess there's 300 in a new bottle.  I didn't bother to count them.  If you only have to take one capsule each day, then one bottle will last nearly a year.

Chicken is listed as the first ingredient and I always want to see a meat listed as the first ingredient because it means it's the most plentiful ingredient in the dog food.  However, corn meal is the second ingredient and I'm not too fond of corn meal in my dog's food, but the rest of the ingredients look good and there are no chemicals or preservatives that I see on the list of ingredients.  I don't have a puppy right now, but I wanted to try this food on my mother's little rescue dog who appears to me, to be underweight.  I want her to eat some puppy food because of the higher calorie content and hopefully she will begin to put on some more weight.  She already loves this food (she loves all the food I've given her since I don't think she got enough to eat before) and really wolfs it down.  I'm happy with this food.  I just wish it didn't have so much corn meal in it.

I love the chocolates but I don't love the $50.56 price tag.  They are quite good and I've given each different chocolate a good tasting.  My favorite was the regular milk chocolate - super creamy and good.  The others were similar to other chocolates I've eaten such as Hershey's dark blend, and many other more fancy chocolates that you can easily buy at a grocery store.  But, these are very good, and each little chocolate is individually wrapped in a cool-looking wrapper.  The glass jar and lid is o.k. and can be re-purposed for something else after all the chocolates are gone.  This would be a great gift for that someone you just can't figure out what to give this holiday season.

These glasses have so far lasted me about 2 months and still show no signs of breaking or coming apart.  The plastic lenses are clear with no warping and I can see clearly with them.  I'm wearing a pair right now and they feel fine on my face and head and they don't make my nose sore or bother me in any way.  I like these a lot and will probably be buying more.  I haven't yet used the pair with the dark lenses but I expect them to last just as well as the others. The designs are cute and colorful too!

This mold worked better than I expected it too.  I like to make handmade soaps and I poured some cold-processed white soap batter into these and let them sit in the freezer for a couple of hours.  They un-molded nicely with a lot of snowflake detail.  I was kind of expecting them to stick or break or not have much design but I was wrong on all counts.  I will be buying a couple more of these to make soaps to give away this Christmas.  The bars (soap snowflakes) after removal weigh approximately 3.23 ounces each so they make a good sized bar.  I won't be using this mold for hot processed since the mold is very flimsy and will collapse if I press thicker batter into it.  But for a light trace CP soap batter it molds very pretty and detailed snowflakes!I paid $5.99 (including shipping).  I see they are now priced at $12.99.  I think that is asking too much for them.

One of my kids loves the scented hand sanitizers so I bought these for her.  They all smell fine (not too strong) with 2 bottles each of the same scent.  She hooks them onto her school backpack and uses them frequently.  She goes to a public school and I want her to use her hand sanitzer many times each day.  The rubbery hook on the bottom seems to keep them secure on her backpack and it looks cool as well if she has several hooked on there at one time.  I think I can refill them so I don't have to send the little bottles to the recycler/landfill which makes me feel better about buying them.

Though I ordered the white ones I got a pack of multi-colors but I like them just fine.  They fit well, and so far I have not experienced the dreaded "creeping up the crack" syndrome.  I've washed and dried them about 4 times now and they come out fine.  The lace at the top will probably fold over like they did on the ones I bought a couple of years ago but they still are comfortable to wear. These are a repeat purchase since they seem to fit well, are comfortable and stay where they need to stay.  I like these a lot!

I bought this for my daughter who just loves to create wonderful things in the kitchen.  She saw someone on a cooking show using an "offset icing knife" and begged me to get one for her.  I had never heard of one before and I used to work in gourmet cookware shop years ago and thought I knew just about every kitchen/cooking device known to man.  This one slipped past me.  I always just used a butter knife for icing a cake........BUT NOT ANYMORE!!!  This thing is great!!  The handle is higher than the blade and keeps your knuckles from dragging through the icing.  It's flat and wide enough to get any type of texture I want (usually pretty swirls) and wish I had had one of these years ago.  Wonderful invention for those who ice cakes, cookies or whatever.

I pour my "Seeds of Beauty" into a tall glass of cold filtered water and stir.  Then if I let it sit long enough all of it completely dissolves into the water.  The flavor is a weak pineapple and is alright, but not wonderful.  As far as making my skin, hair and nails appear in healthier condition I can't really attest to that.  But, I'm not saying this product won't help with that - it just takes a LONG time to see results.  I only have 30 days with which to try out the product and review it so that is not enough time to tell if my skin, hair and nails are getting better or not.  I think after about 6 months to a year I would see some results.I think that if you are patient, and drink this daily, you should see some improvement in those areas it is supposed to help with.  The flavor is tolerable and it will make you drink more water daily which is always good for your skin and other bodily functions.  At this time I really can't say if it's worth 5 or 1 stars so I give it 3.

These chips are salty, seaweedy and crunchy.  If you like the flavor of seaweed with some salt and a hint of sweet then you will love these.  I find them alright but nothing to really write home about.  My Asian foreign exchange student couldn't get enough of them but she eats dried seaweed by the bag full anyway.

I like this concealer/cover stick, but I don't like it well enough to pay $28.00 for it.  I'll keep using my other, much less expensive brands that seem to do basically the same thing as this one.  The lipstick style container is attractive, and it seems to operate smoothly.  The make-up stick itself is very easy to apply.  I received the 'Opal" tinted stick and though I am Caucasian, I am not as white as a red-head.  My skin is fair in complexion but the opal color was a little bit darker than I normally would use.  Trying to accurately determine the color after it has been applied while inside under artificial lighting is impossible so I went outside with my mirror and looked at the color in the light of day.  It was an overcast day and perfect for seeing colors as they really are.  The tint was good, but I could still see a tinge of orange where I had applied it a little thicker to cover my dark circles.  I have always had really dark circles under my eyes all my life (my brother too) so it is obviously a genetic thing and not due to being sick or tired.  Also, after wearing it for several hours I still saw some tiny creases where the make-up separated at the inner corners of my eyes near my nose.I will still use this stick, but honestly, I just can't see paying nearly 30 dollars for it.  Maybe $7 - 10, but no more.

I've been taking 5 mg of melatonin every night for several months now.  Ever since I went through the "CHANGE" my sleep patterns have been terribly wonky.  The "Move Free" delivers 6 mg (3 mg/pill) which is fine with me.  I am very active athletically and am always looking for things to help my joints, especially my knees.  I like how they combined the melatonin with the Glucosamine Chondroitin into one easy to take pill.  I take two pills about 30 minutes before bedtime and though I still wake up several times, my sleep is better and my knees feel fine in the morning.  Last night I played a ferocious 2 sets with my teenager and my knees feel great as I write this review.  I'm hesitant to give it 5 stars because I also take what is called, "Golden Paste" and it is a dream come true for arthritis sufferers though I do not have arthritis.  It helps with a lot of health problems and I take it as a preventative.

Made me poop waaaay too much.  This is mainly a laxative and it will make you lose weight by emptying your bowels of their contents.  I was unable to compete in a tennis match because I was scared to leave the house lest I needeth the toidy again.  I guess I could have worn a pair of "OOPS! I CR*PPED MY PANTS" but it would have been too noticeable.  This stuff is good if you are constipated and need some relief.

There's a lot of reviews already about this product.  I wavered for a good while about deciding if I wanted to accept this Cloudbook for review and now kind of wish I hadn't.  As far as I'm concerned, the Cloudbook is like a merging of a laptop and a chromebook with neither giving the features that are special to each one.  As far as it being a computer, it runs on Windows 10 of which I have great suspicions and doubts.  If you remember, I believe most everyone received an offer for a free download of Windows 10 as an upgrade from whatever Windows program they were currently using.  I have read from several sources that it was offered only as a way of installing NSA spyware on your computer.  We are being watched and monitored at every turn.  If you don't believe me, next time you are driving take a look at all the cameras on poles along the roads and highways and tell me we aren't being surveilled.  Smartphones, smart TV's, smart refrigerators, dryers and washing machines are simply ways of letting TPTB know what we are doing at all times.  How many loads of clothes you washed, what you are doing in your bedroom and on and on.  So, what does all this have to do with this little and cute computer?  It has Windows 10 installed.If you are o.k. with that then overall it's not a bad machine.  I really miss having a disk drive to load my own personal programs and don't like having to download stuff from the internet via the app store or some other internet source.  And since it is a computer but has very little space for storage, you have to have an anti-virus program.  It comes with one but it's only good for 30 days and you have to purchase it or get another one.  Most of your stuff will be stored in the Cloud (like a chromebook) unless you opt for a Sandisk or external hard drive.  And if you buy an external hard drive for more storage why not get a regular computer instead that has more bells and whistles and possibly a disk drive?It looks like a chromebook and I have had to put a label on it to distinguish it from mine and my kids chromebooks.  I'm having a hard time getting used to Windows 10 and it takes a long time to finally get on the internet.  I have taped a piece of paper over the camera lens staring me in the face - call me paranoid if you wish but I don't like people in my house uninvited. The "shift" key is way too small and I'm always missing it.As far as specs go they're listed on the main page but here they are again for your convenience:  11.6" HD Widescreen ComfyView LED-backlit Display (1366 x 768 resolution, 16:9 aspect ratio).  Intel Celeron N3050 Dual-Core Processor 1.6GHz with Intel Burst Technology up to 2.16GHz.  Windows 10  Intel HD Graphics  2GB of DDR3L Onboard Memory.  32GB Internal Storage  Secure Digital (SD) card reader.  802.11ac WiFi (Dual-Band 2.4GHz and 5GHz).  Bluetooth 4.0  Webcam (640 x 480)  High-definition audio support.  Two Built-in Stereo Speakers.  1 - USB 3.0 port  1 - USB 2.0 port  1 - HDMI Port with HDCP support.  Microsoft Office 365 Personal 1-Year Subscription (activation code included).  2-cell Li-polymer battery pack (4200mAh).  Up to 8 hours of battery life (Video Playback).  2.54 lbs. | 1.15kg (system unit only).If you are already using Windows 10 then it should be easy to navigate, but I feel as if I'm learning a whole new OS though I use Windows 8 on my other laptop.  It only detected two of my Bluetooth devices and I have several. If you want Word processing you must redeem your card number inside the box before a certain date or else it expires.  And it's all cloud based so your data is out there and not in your pc safe and sound.I will modify this review as needed, but I have not used this computer since a few days ago and probably will not be using it much at all.  I like my chromebook better for web surfing, and it doesn't require an anti-virus program because it's totally cloud based but I never use the cloud.  I store the stuff I want on my old desktop or other laptop.  And my chromebook has access to a word processing program without having to buy it.

As of this review this watch costs $29.99.  I have worn it for only a couple of days but I wore it continuously except to take it off at bedtime.  I found it to be comfortable and was not bothered by it.  I often have to take watches and bracelets off after a while because they begin to irritate me for whatever reasons, but this watch was easy to wear.  Though it says it can be adjusted  for size I can't figure out how to adjust it so if you have thick wrists it might not do.  I have slender wrists and the band gave me about 1/4th inch of play.  The instructions that come with the watch do not tell how to adjust the band and I think it's non-adjustable.  They do tell you how to set the date though this watch doesn't come with a date window.The watch itself is basically made out of green plastic.  It says it "rubberized" but if so, only minimally because I couldn't really detect any rubber.  The strap did not pinch my skin or snag any arm hairs.  The face is large and I could easily read the time without my glasses.  I didn't have to set the time because it came set already to my time zone.  It's not waterproof so I try not to get it wet.  It really looks just as pictured and is a nice deep olive green.  It's kind of an army-ish color and with some splashes of brown and beige it would be perfect camo.I like this watch so far but as of yet it's too early to tell how long it will last and when it will need a battery change.  If anything goes wrong I will update this review.

The first two ingredients are water and mineral oil.  Baby oil is mineral oil.  It is a very inexpensive oil and does not sink into your skin as a natural emollient would such as cocoa butter, shea butter or coconut oil.  It does contain a little glycerin and less jojoba seed oil, but it also includes alcohol, aluminum chlorohydrate and other chemicals.Personally, I would keep my money and buy something that delivered more natural (or preferably all natural) ingredients and no mineral oil.  But it does make your hands smoother for a while and has no smell that I can detect.  It's made in Switzerland but that doesn't do anything for me as far as making me think that it's a superior product.  It will help with dryness, and goes on easily and feels good to dry skin but overall, there's better products out there for less money.

This is by far the best beard trimmer/hair remover my husband has ever used, and he's had lots of them in the past.  When he saw this he groaned thinking, "not another one", but has since drastically changed his tune.  Since everyone has specified in detail just how well this little guy works I will spare myself the labor and allow the other reviews to cover that.  I will say that although this trimmer is a bit on the pricey side, it's actually worth it and I doubt you will be disappointed with it.

One of my niece's babies is now beginning to cut teeth and it does seem to be a bit unpleasant for him.  She's been using this teething gel by rubbing it on his gums and after about 10 or so minutes he quietens down and appears to no longer hurt.  She has to re-apply since he salivates and it wears off, but she can get about 30+ minutes or longer before he shows signs of teething pain again.  At night he sleeps longer since she rubs his gums with it before putting him in his crib.  So, as far as we can tell, this stuff does seem to help with that particular affliction.

This works o.k. for a fake tan, and does look like you've gotten some time in the sun, but it's a lot of work and time to apply. Mine came with a mitt for review purposes, but I understand that a mitt is not included when you buy the Xen-Tan. However, it wasn't all that easy to use and I think just using a plastic glove and a soft washcloth will do just as well.I applied this thoroughly over my freshly showered bod using small circular motions as instructed in the directions. That took a while and I was working up a sweat just doing that, which caused me to have to re-apply in some spots. I couldn't do my back but I was able to smear enough on it so it was actually a good indicator of how much Xen-Tan stayed on after showering later on. I noticed I did look noticeably darker after applying the Xen-Tan. I wore loose clothing for the rest of the day and actually did not shower again until the next morning so I certainly left it on for the minimum 3 hours before showering.When I got into the shower I saw the water run dark-ish down the drain and it had to be the Xen-Tan. I checked my back in the mirror and saw where some of the Xen-Tan had not washed off, but it was a lot lighter than when I initially applied it. I'm not really sure I'd want to spend $65.00 to work that hard, and not get much to show for it. I want to mention, that yesterday when I first applied the Xen-Tan, it felt sticky and I felt sticky for about an hour until it began to dry. Also, when I washed my hands any water that dribbled down my arms erased the Xen-Tan and I had to re-apply it. It doesn't tell you that water will erase the tan shortly after applying.  And be real careful with it on your feet because it will look like you just walked through red clay mud if you don't smear it around well.

My dogs really love this food.  I think it may be the ocean fish meal (2nd ingredient) that they crave more than the bison which is listed as the 1st ingredient.  But whatever, if it gets them to eat dry easily than it's all good to me.  I've fed them other Solid Gold dry dog food flavors and they like all of them.  It seems that they all contain natural ingredients such as meats, vegetables, fruits, vitamins and minerals and I can't find any long chemically named ingredients.  I don't know if the ingredients are non-GMO as it doesn't say that on the package so I'll assume that at least some of them are GMO products.My dogs are small but they don't have any problems crunching up and eating the large breed dry dog food.  If your dog has weak or bad teeth, I would get the smaller sized food though.  Overall, I think this is a good choice for dry dog food and as of this review it costs $13.99 for a 4 pound bag.

The first three ingredients are oatmeal, pearled barley and peas.  Ocean fish meal is not listed until ingredient #4.  I always want meat or fish to be the first ingredient.  That said, I still think this is a quality dog food at a reasonable price.  As of this review it costs $12.99 for a 4 pound bag.
