I blame Mrs. Philyodaddy, she's always wanting me to do stuff like visit museums or go to work.  Woman, I have been waiting to use this Euron Crow's Eye card for 3 rounds now!  Just let me Muster my forces!  Leave me alone!I do think this is the type of game that only gets better the more you play as everyone will understand it better.  One of our group (The Starks) spent 10 turns moving his forces back and forth between the Northern territories.  Have fun up there buddy, I've got a clear path to Kings Landing and I have Valyrian Steel in my hand.ANNYYYWAY, since this is in the "toys" category, I will address philyodaddy's favorite star ranking, Educational Value.  5 Stars.AGoT:TBG2E Teaches children (and grown children like me) important lessons like the geography of Westeros ("No, you dimwit, the Stoney Shore is MILES from the Stoney Sept.") as well as important social dynamics such as: how to stab your friends in the back, a useful talent in Corporate America, just ask the Zuckerberg.On a personal note, it is way too much of them to ask us to keep all of those little pieces in some kind of organized fashion for following playthroughs, I mean let's be real, if you're anything like philyodaddy, your method of cleaning up is throwing everything in the box, slamming the lid shut, clapping your hands together, and saying "All in a good day's work".  This is considerably more difficult when there are 689490349 pieces/cards/items included in the game.  The board is also the size of a 12-person dining room table.  So I hope you have one.My one complaint would be that even with 30 pages of instructions, we still don't know how a few things work.  Ports?  Ships?  Not a clue, we made the rules up as we went along.  Pretty sure if there was a professional AGoT:TBG2E society, they would shun the crap out of us.

Like many of the uncultured masses, I previously didn't put too much thought into the subject of ice trays. However, I have stepped up my ice tray game because of many broken promises over the years by inferior products. As philyodaddy fans are well aware I have had my ups and downs with the Arrow Plastic 00055 Ice Cube Trays (Pack of 2) so I purchased these badboys for a larger ice cube to throw in my Rubbermaid White Ice Cube Bin.  I'm sure this sounds like a joke, but amazon pro's can see all of the linked items are verified purchases. I wonder if that makes it better or worse? Anyway, I digress.I hate not having an ice maker, but these trays make it a tiny bit better. I have the standard 3 criteria ("3D" as tray-pro's call them) when reviewing an ice tray: Difficulty of Use, Durability, and Dimensions:Difficulty of use: 8.5/10 - The ice comes out without having to apply my super human wrist strength. Good for mere mortals. Hence the "Easy Release" moniker attached to this product line.Durability: 9/10 (subject to change of course) - I have yet to break one of these. The crappy ice trays always break. I honestly believe it is intentional to make us buy more of them.Dimensions: 7.69/10 - They are a little big for the ice chewers among us but they excel at keeping the drink at a delightfully cool temperature. Not the super jumbo size that all ice users loathe. Because they are a little larger girth than I prefer, I tend to combine some of these with the Arrow small guys (linked above) in my drinks so i can have the "best of both worlds" (like the fatally flawed R. Kelly and Jay Z Tour).This is the highest 3D score I have found in my foray into the ice tray world. 1 star is deducted because $8 for 2 puts the average cost at the top of my "maximum acceptable ice tray cost" range of $4/piece. $8 for crappy plastic is ridiculous. I can buy A LIVE LOBSTER for $8.4 Stars.

I was ecstatic when the lovely people at LifeCHARGE provided one of these bad boys for me to try out for my iPhone 5 with the purpose of reviewing. Shout out. Now if only I was provided with the iPhone 5 as well... I kid I kid. I am still pretty happy and use this every day. Previously I had carried (and tested) many external batteries and it was just a little annoying to carry around something extra.Let's get to the important things first: the color choices. Black and White are very early 2000's but gold (or champagne to philyodaddy) is clearly the color of NOW. I'd say this particular hue of yellowish is more of a Piper Heidsieck or maybe a single-vintage grower Champagne rather than a more tacky Veuve Clicquot or Cristal (poppin in my stretch Navigator). An understated, muted even, champagne color that contrasts superbly with my black selfie taker. A real classy look. Almost makes people stop focusing on my Mets pajama pants. Almost.Now that we've gotten the important stuff out of the way, I did some very in-depth testing. What I did was: I played the Notebook on full volume (to the thrill of Philyodaddy's neighbors) repeatedly until the phone's battery died (it was around the 42nd time that Ryan Gosling's chiseled features could be described as "smoldering") I used the LifeCHARGE MFI Approved Rechargeable Extended Battery Case for Apple iPhone 5/5s - Gold (hitherto: LMAREBCfAi5-G) to charge it back up. End result, the LMAREBCfAi5-G will give you about 1.238-1.373 extra charges of your iphone5, not sure about the iphone5s, because RESULTS MAY VARY.Cons, I'll get this out of the way quickly so I can make more jokes that only I find funny:1)It is a little bulky, sorry what did you want your magical device that charges2)You need to hold the charge button and charge the phone and battery pack separately. I would love if it automatically charged the phone and battery pack at the same time, but as BSB might say "aint nothing but a heartache"3) I now find the need to have my phone or battery charging at all times. I think I might be OCD but I want my phone and battery pack at 100%, because that's what I want.The cuatro) Doesn't work with some headphones without an extender. Oh shucks, just find headphones it does work with.I consulted noted phone-case expert Mrs. Nigels (of Assorted 27mm Super Bouncy Balls - 250 Count fame). She has a Mophie and she confirms that her experience both pros and cons are the same. She also thanked me again for filling her house with bouncy balls. Weird that both battery packs share the same negatives, I guess there is still room for another entrant into the subcategory.To pre-conclude, It is better than carrying around external battery packs, and its champagne color is super sexy, but there are still a few stars. I'd give it 4.3 stars, unfortunately rounding down to 4. Also if they could make one that prevents drunk-texting "What you up to?", that would be a swell enhancement.I'll end by demanding that Apple (and the Android producers) make their phones last longer. It is absolutely outrageous that devices like these are needed. I mean I know that the LifeCHARGE company is surely cheering for this never to come to pass, but c'mon. Instead of making Siri direct me to the nearest Rub and Tug, why don't you invent some new awesome batteries? Is that really too much to ask?

Don't know who this Reese guy is, but shout out to him.  Reese's really are the height of the candy industry.  Shame on you, wannabe's.  "If you come at the king, you best not miss" - Omar Little, The Wire.  "Reese's are the best" - Philyodaddy, reviewer.Reese's are the Honey Nut Cheerios Cereal, 12.25 Ounce (Pack of 4) of the Candy aisle.  Best in Class.  Pretty sure they are very healthy as I would like to eat several a day and don't have the diabetes yet.  If the packages include a calorie content sectsh, I certainly don't notice because I'm too busy devouring these morsels of heaven. 1.5 ounces of divinity right to the dome.Recommended way to consume: Dipped in Nutella.  Can they make a Nutella-filled reeses?  Wow, just give me the Nobel Candy prize, right now.Lastly, the full size cups (or even the super-large "Big Cup", which are also Philyodaddy-approved - please Reese's purists, don't nail me to the cross) are far superior to the little, dainty guys that come in the tin foil.  Don't bring that weak crap up in this.  You got the choc-pb ratio ALL WRONG.  I'll eat those little guys if I am stranded on a dessert island or stealing your kid's halloween candy, but otherwise: no way, no how.I swear I'm not fat.  By the way see what I did with "dessert island" - pretty clever, right?p.s.  As for all the people who wrote reviews of this product claiming it is super fresh, what in the world are you talking about?  It is a processed food.  Did you think that they just picked your pack of 36 right off the Chocolate Peanut Butter tree before hand-delivering it to you in a refrigerated container?  I want my steak dry-aged, my wine in a bottle, my Iphone made in China, and my g-damn Reese's from a warehouse in orange packaging.p.p.s.  I learned the following from Wikipedia while researching for this review. "They were created in 1928 by H. B. Reese, a former dairy farmer and shipping foreman for Milton S. Hershey."The more you know.

In a traditional case of the pot not being the same color as the kettle, I bought the "Matte Red" version of this bad boy.  #allredeverything It is a good tea kettle.  I rarely wash it.  Seriously, what is the point of washing it.  The only thing that ever goes inside of it is water and it is then boiled so as to remove any contaminates.  I ain't washing that crap.  The dishwasher is busy, sorry.Anyway, Primula engineers deserve kudos.  This is loud as f.  One of my least favorite things  in the world (this list appears to be getting long) is when Mrs. Philyodaddy just lets that beast go on for minutes.  She's filing the nails, she's reading the US weekly (Stars they're just like US they lay down the tracks in public restrooms!), she's playin the Candy Crush.  GET THE TEA KETTLE, WOMAN.  When I make my tea, I'm sprinting out my seat as soon as I see steam coming out, in anticipash of the noise.In terms of other features, not really sure what I can comment on.  It looks good, it holds 2.5 quarts (obviously, that is in the product description).One star deduction because the plastic handle is too hot to hold (It's gettin hot in herre) and I need to use a dishtowel.  Dishtowels are known receptacles for bacteria and non-soap hand washing.Edit: on my electric stove (I moved) - the handle is no longer 2 hot 2 touch... now it is great. Did have the problem on my gas stove though.

True story, I proposed at the beach and both my (now) wife and I were wearing Rainbow Sandals.  She Said Yes.  I didn't even need to go to Jared.  Mrs. Philyodaddy didn't see the proposal coming since I was wearing a t-shirt, cargo shorts, and Rainbow Sandals.  GOTCHA.Rainbow sandals are great.  The one obvious problem is that these things are absolutely awful to break in. Literally, it takes months, and I do know the definition of "literally".  Mrs. Philyodaddy made me throw away my 4-year old pair and buy a replacement, and my feet looked like size 13 swiss cheese for months. Thanks again.  But they were ready to go for the engagement!Once they are worn in they are wonderful and very comfortable.  Feel free to make major life decisions like marriage proposals.  And that's the bottom line.If demand gets high enough, I will post the picture of us so you can know I am not lying.  Philyodaddy only lies occasionally, and never in reviews.
I wore a shirt like this extensively when I was a Freshman and Sophomore in High School.  3 short years later, I lost my virginity.  Coincidence?  I think not.

The game is very fun on your first and second playthrough.  Soccer and Simulation is a winning combination.  However, upon subsequent playthroughs, like some other Kairosoft games, it gets a bit dull.  All of your players will be maxed out and the game gets kinda repetitive.  That being said you get a solid 20+ hours of play before that happens.  Now that is great value.Don't be expecting Football manager, it is a fun little soccer sim, it is more for Game Dev Story fans than for hardcore simulation players.

I'm 29.  I bought this for myself.  I have brought shame on my family.  I'm sorry, but I just can't help myself.  I need more of my favorite Mon Calamari super stud in my life.  IT'S A TRAP - ADMIRAL ACKBAR - Star Wars Tee Shirt Gildan Softstyle is my favorite shirt.  People love it.  Now people at work know how big a loser I am because they see my Admiral Ackbar Bobble Figure on my desk.  At my wedding, I came down the aisle to The Imperial March (true story).  Time to let my freak flag fly.Note - I rated this 5 stars for Educational Value because I believe it will help children understand the effect of colonization on modern racial demographics and integration.  That is all.It's a Trap.

I am giving this 5 stars because I love ASOIAF. I think these books are wonderful. However, why in the world would I want to have all 5 books as one file on my Kindle? It just doesn't make any sense. Oh great, I can read for 3 hours and make 1% progress! SWEEEEEETTT. It is the downside of e-books, they are completely unmanageable. The worst part was when I re-read them. For some reason, it bothered me even more. You can't find your place when you have 5000 pages in one stupid file. George, can I call you George, you really need to have more input on the electronic publishing. I can't imagine this was your choice. When the future books come out, I will be glad to get them separately.On the actual books, I love all 5 although of course AFFC is not as good. I'm not in the Dance with Dragons hating committee, so sue me. I liked it quite a bit. I discovered the series only when the TV show started. Again, go away haters, I still love the books just as much as everyone else. I'm sorry I didn't have the foresight to find this series when I had never heard of it.While I'm at it. Bran's storyline sucks. Aria is an annoying whiner. Daeny is great. And #teamdavos 4eva.Just stating facts.Can't wait for what's next. And GRRM - Let's Go Giants.

Honestly, who in the world doesn't love goldfish? They are a delicious snack. In the non-sweet snack category, I'd put them right up there in the pantheon with Combos (obviously Pepperoni Pizza as the best kind) and Doritos (preferably Cool Ranch, but I'll hear arguments for other flavors). I have heard rumors goldfish are slightly healthier than the two aforementioned tasty treats. Rumors are a tricky mistress. Hard to say.What more can you ask for when discussing a snack that is as American as Windows 95. Goldfish for everyone.  Whole Grain seems healthier, so I'm down.I paid $6.99, or even less with Subscribe and Save! At my local grocery store, they are like $8.99. Granted I live in New York City where a 3-pack of gum costs more than a 2 BR House in rural America, so take that as you will.

These ball pit balls are not joking around. There is a very good reason that they are number 1 in the category of "playground balls". I haven't figured out that reason yet, but I'm sure there is one. Maybe it is because they are "Phthalate Free". Notice I put quotes around it just like the product description does. Why the quotation marks? Did someone say they were "Phthalate Free"? Do they ALLEGE to be "Phtalate Free"? How can I trust that they are legitimately free of Phthalate with those quotation marks hanging around? Answer: I can't.Next question: WHAT IN THE WORLD IS PHTHALATE? Is that something I need to be scared of? I don't have children yet, but when I do, do I need to protect them from the evil dangers of Phthalate? I just spent 45 seconds internetting phthalate and I still don't understand what it is. It is spelled funny though. 4 consonants in a row! Unheard of! Ballsy.In conclusion, ball pits are fun and can be enjoyed by children of all ages. If you need some 6.5 cm balls, I recommend these. So do lots of other people, since they are number 1.

Frank's Red Hot is the standard bearer of the hot sauce world.  As I noted in my review of Huy Fong, Sriracha Hot Chili Sauce, 17 Ounce Bottle, Tobasco is yesterday's news.  Frank's is just a far superior product.  Tobasco is your grandfather's hot sauce, just because he Frankly didn't know better.  Not the grandfather you liked, the a-hole one.  I prefer Frank's along with Louisiana-based hot sauces like Crystal for my every day use.  AND I DO USE IT EVERY DAY.  I put hot sauce on everything, including but not limited to:RiceMeatFishPizzaPastaBoobs (just checking if you are still paying attention)Ethnic foodsChicken products - not limited to the wingsAssorted PoultryWild GameSandwichesMozz SticksMexican food - especially Trader Joe's Tamales which are f'ing delicious.  Don't hate the player.For those of you in the recipe game.  Here is the recipe for Buffalo Sauce for wings: 1 Bottle of Franks for 1 stick of Butter.  Heat on low.  Stir.  Boom.  Dunzo.It doesn't have the most kick in the world, but I ain't hatin, it just tastes good.In conclusion, thanks Frank, you did good.

Spoiler alert!!!! In a shocking twist, the main (title) character dies at the end of this film. UNEXPECTEDLY! Also, the North wins the Civil War! That one is probably not unexpected given their superior resources, man power, and the moral high ground (oops too political) but... Regardless, SPOILED!That is how you do a spoiler right? GOTCHA! He's alive the whole movie and then surprise! Totally spoiled it. Roasted.Other movies where someone dies:JFK (Director's Cut)Selenaand last but not least, a #tbt for the kids:The Passion Of The Christ Definitive Edition

Oh Sparty, I already miss you and it hasn't even been a year. This was a great show. It wasn't the best written or most realistic, it was just the most entertaining. There are men, There are great men, and there was Andy Whitfield. Liam McIntyre did a pretty good job in seasons 3 and 4, but when you're replacing a legend, what in the world are you to do?I have debated the realitisticness of this show with some of my friends (shoutout Langers 2003). Spoiler Alert- in the first season finale, AWhit jumps 20 feet straight up into the air. So, I'm not sure why they didn't let him take the weights off and really show off his high jump prowess. That being said, I was surprised how close to the history the plot line managed to keep while still being about blood, sex, and more sex. Gotta give them credit for that. Philyodaddy majored in history, so I would know.In all seriousness, I loved this show as much as I mourned Andy Whitfield's unfortunate passing. Even season 2 without the title character was excellent. Seasons 3 and 4 were a little worse, but oh well, what are you going to do? Godfather 3 wasn't as good as 1 or 2 either. Bring It On 2 (Bring it on Again) wasn't even good at all. So I heard. The Notebook 2 doesn't even exist.Oh and every female lead gets naked, so that's a good thing right? Mrs. Philyodaddy agrees in absentia.Sidenote- This was briefly on sale for $64.99, so I would not pay the current price of $105

Alexander Grechaninov was a major composer of the Russian silver age, and his best works qualify as ‚Äúgreat‚Äù, including some of his choral and chamber works. We certainly needed a complete cycle of his symphonies (I have a particular fondness for the exuberant fifth), and the Chandos one is certainly worth the investment for any fan of the Russian silver age. It is, however, hard to imagine a strong case being made for the first symphony apart from ‚Äúfor completeness sake‚Äù. Completed in 1895, it is a work heavily indebted to Rimsky-Korsakov and sounds a lot like Glazunov‚Äôs works from the same period. But it lacks the inventiveness, brilliance and melodic memorability of either of those composers, and although there are some pleasant things going on and the symphony never really gets ‚Äúboring‚Äù, there is nothing to remember it by once the moderately interesting scenery has passed you by. No complaints about the craftsmanship, but the scoring is hardly as brilliant as Rimsky or Glazunov either. The Russian State Symphony Orchestra plays well under Valeri Polyansky, but although it is not slow there is a certain lack of energy to the proceedings that I think is only partially the composer‚Äôs fault.Snowflakes (1910) is a collection of ten miniature poems about childhood. I admit that I expected some fantastic, phantasmagorical and wonderfully atmospheric fairy tale music in the manner of the Nutcracker or Liadov, and that seems to be what Grechaninov was aiming for as well ‚Äì but no, it doesn‚Äôt really work; after the opening number the music often turns banal and trite and the melodic material isn‚Äôt really memorable enough. Here, however, the performances are not free from blame. I know the opening song, Snowflakes (yes, it gave the title to the cycle) as a wonderfully crisp, mischievous and atmospheric solo song, but the choral-and-orchestral arrangement packs it all in a wet, woollen, grey cloth ‚Äì at least it does in the poorly balanced and woolly recorded sound here, and I suspect my disappointment in the rest of the cycle can at least to some extent be blamed on the same problem. But the singing is not great either, which is surprising from this source.And in the late Missa Sancti Spiritus (1940) the Russian State Symphonic Cappella certainly prove that they usually are excellent singers; it is very well performed. The mass dispenses with orchestra, and the result is a very devotional, rather low-key but emotionally charged setting. It is not great music ‚Äì not a patch on the best of Grechaninov‚Äôs other choral works ‚Äì but it is well written and beautiful enough. In sum I think this disc is mainly for completists; there are some good and enjoyable things here, but some serious drawbacks as well. Let me close, however, with a plea for an opportunity to hear one or more of Grechaninov‚Äôs operas. At least Dobrynya Nikitich was recorded on LP by Melodiya, but has not been officially reissued on cd, and there are at least two more (plus two ‚Äúchildren‚Äôs operas‚Äù).

Chandos‚Äôs Prokofiev series is amazingly comprehensive, and for much of it they employed the indefatigable Neeme J√§rvi. Now, J√§rvi‚Äôs unparalleled versatility and productivity are explained by something close to a one-size-fits-all approach to very diverse repertoire, but the Prokofiev symphony cycle he gave for Chandos is still possibly the best complete cycle in the catalogue (even though he cannot quite compete in some of the individual symphonies ‚Äì with Ancerl in no. 1 or Karajan in no. 5, for instance). How does he fare here? Well, the results are a bit variable, but it is never less than perfectly acceptable.The ballet The Prodigal Son was one of the works Prokofiev wrote during his stay in Paris and before his return to the Soviet Union, but it is written in a rather populist style, much simpler and straightforward than many of his earlier works (one imagines the story being an expression of the composer‚Äôs view of himself at the time: the artist tempted to forsake his homeland, but presently regrets it and hopes for forgiveness). It is nevertheless an inventive work, full of splendid ideas. J√§rvi and the Scottish National Orchestra are arguably best in the more tumultuous scenes, but they are really very good throughout, playing with plenty of spirit, panache and color ‚Äì this is the kind of work that really can take J√§rvi‚Äôs somewhat brazen, noisy and hard-pressed (though not necessarily particularly fast) approach; it is, after all, not a particularly subtle or multi-dimensional score.The other works are somewhat more harmonically complex ‚Äì not much so for the contemporaneous Divertissement, a fifteen-minute work in four movements, but at least the first movement contains the kind of machine-like pulse that you find in the earlier music. The second movement, a Nocturne, is an early example of his later style, however; the third is in the style of The Prodigal Son, and the fourth is also dance-like. It is a really rewarding and fun work, though I think the first two movements are the best; J√§rvi and his forces, however, are arguably most convincing in the last two, though this is once again an overall very fine performance. Where I have most doubts about the performances is probably in the Andante, an orchestration of a movement from his fourth piano sonata, which here sounds mostly ominous and one-dimensional (whether the orchestration really adds anything to the original anyways is an open question, though).The Symphonic Song dates from 1933 and is another stylistically transitory work. It is generally dark, troubled and dissonant, though a theme finally breaks free and the work ends in triumph. I have to admit, though, that I find the whole thing somewhat puzzling ‚Äì perhaps the somewhat noisy performance is partially to blame. Overall, the program may not be an essential one to anyone but already committed fans of the composer, but the Divertissement is certainly worth hearing, and The Prodigal Son is great fun as well. The sound is clear and spacious.

I was unfamiliar with the music of the Argentine composer Alberto Williams (1862-1952) before hearing this disc ‚Äì apparently there are some releases devoted to his piano works out there, but this seems to be the only disc devoted to any of his nine symphonies or major orchestral works. Both works on this disc belong to Williams‚Äôs late period ‚Äì in fact, the dates are 1937 and 1943, respectively, which means that he was 75 and 81 years old when he composed these works. I think it is worth pointing this out, since I suspect that many potential listeners would expect orchestral music composed by an Argentine composer born in 1862 to be essentially romantic. The truth, however, is that these are both clearly 20th century works, and if the basic language is romantic they often sound quite modern.Unfortunately they also strike me as rather bland; though not anachronistic the musical language isn‚Äôt particularly original, either; instead, Williams adopt a rather mainstream, cosmopolitan style ‚Äì there are plenty of hints toward his Argentine background, but they are overall rather subdued and polished off. The outer movements of the seventh symphony, Eterno Reposo, are dark and tragic but not particularly dramatic, and although the opening movement, La Pir√°mide, sounds ambitious and goal-directed at the outset, momentum quickly dissipates into aimless meanderings with some mildly interesting moments that ultimately fail to cohere. The second movement, Danzarinas De Am√≥n, sounds like its going for glitz but ends up with syrup, while the third movement, Tocadoras De Cr√≥talos, is more interesting ‚Äì at least it exhibits some vigor. The finale is moody and brooding ‚Äì at the outset it seems to aim for the dreamlike, but although it does achieve some atmosphere it never seems able to go anywhere; when it develops into something more dramatic and, ultimately, jubilant, that isn‚Äôt achieved by development but by simple juxtaposition. Overall, the symphony ‚Äì in fact, it sounds more like a suite ‚Äì is no more than moderately interesting.The Poema del Iguazu is a suite of musical images of the river Iguazu. It strikes me as more satisfying overall, perhaps because I didn‚Äôt expect any symphonic unity within or between the movements. The opening movement, Las Selvas Dialogan Con Las Cataratas is light and atmospheric with several good ideas and even a memorable theme or two. Barcarola Del Iguaz√∫ is nobly flowing, whereas La Luna Ilumina Las Cascadas is a slightly impressionistic nocturne, gentle but secretive but not very interesting ‚Äì one gets the feeling that Williams overall should have increased the speed, and no: I don‚Äôt think it is ultimately the performers‚Äô fault. The finale, La Garganta Del Diablo, supposedly depicts a great waterfall, but don‚Äôt get your hopes up: There is some noise and swagger but it doesn‚Äôt really make a particularly powerful impact. Overall, though, this is a pleasant and pleasing suite of what admittedly are rather insubstantial tone paintings.I do, however, suspect that the Orquesta Filarmonica de Gran Canaria under Adrian Leaper is partially to blame for my somewhat mixed reaction to the music. It does sound like Leaper knows what he is doing, and the playing is general decent, but I suspect much of this music requires somewhat fuller textures than the Gran Canaria players can give it. I also wonder whether they play it too safe ‚Äì the performances lack spirit and brilliance; they may be a bit too slow, but I am not sure a higher speed really is all I am asking for. The sound is fine, though, and those with a sense of adventure may certainly want to check this one out.

Max Bruch‚Äôs instrumental music beyond the ubiquitous first violin concerto is currently reasonably well represented on disc, but the main part of his compositional output consisted of a long series of secular oratorios and dramatic ballads for soloists, chorus and orchestra, only a couple of which are actually available on disc. Das Lied von der Glocke, after Schiller, is actually available in three recordings. I have not heard the others, and although I have heard good things about the CPO one I am not willing to believe that it could be much better than this Thorofon release, which is excellently performed with reasonably strong soloists and recorded in vivid sound. The music itself is a blast ‚Äì not particularly original, and perhaps not ultimately strikingly memorable, but hugely enjoyable, brilliantly scored, tuneful and with some beautiful meditative parts and marvelous (and marvelously developed) climaxes.The work was completed in 1878 and was apparently inspired by the bells of the Cologne Cathedral. Most of the work is actually rather reflective in character, as the Schiller poem would suggest ‚Äì the poem is a philosophical take on the episodes in a human life framed by an allegorical description of the creation of a new church bell ‚Äì but it builds up to a sustained, blazing climax; clearly inspired by Beethoven‚Äôs Ode to Joy, but not derivatively so. Of course, the message of domestic harmony in Schiller‚Äôs poem, of which Bruch makes much, will come across as pretty quaint to today‚Äôs listeners, especially as it is set to the tune of Holy Night, but whatever: It‚Äôs a glorious and very tuneful spectacle and can easily be enjoyed as such, and if you think this kind of romantic spectacle is for you, you will definitely appreciate Bruch‚Äôs Das Lied von der Glocke.The performances are overall excellent. The soloists are good ‚Äì none of them are perfect, but they clearly know how to work with each other and their ensemble work is magnificent. Still, it‚Äôs the Dresden State Opera Chorus who tends to steal the show ‚Äì this really is first-rate choral singing. The Dresden Philharmonic Orchestra is also very impressive under Hans-Christoph Rademann, and it‚Äôs all spaciously and vividly recorded (the climaxes are fortunately excellently captured). So, while it may not be a masterpiece this one still deserves a very, very strong recommendation. I would rate Das Lied von der Glocke above Moses and at least as equal to Damajanti and Arminius ‚Äì I haven‚Äôt heard Odysseus, but there is a recording of that one, and I hope I will get to hear both that one and some of the currently unrecorded ones, such as Achilleus or Das Feuerkreuz, at some point.

Plenty of famous conductors were also composers, and the fact that they made names for themselves as conductors of course makes it more likely that their compositional output is not completely forgotten but of interest to record companies, somewhat independently of concerns about quality. Hearing the music of these conductors is occasionally revelatory (Markevitch) and often eminently worthwhile (Furtw√§ngler); much of it is very much middle-of-the-road (Walter, Svetlanov, Dorati), however, and some of the music by these conductors turns out to be disappointing (Klemperer). At least a career as a conductor is a fairly reliable predictor of being a skilled orchestrator, but usually also favoring an eclectic style and a pretty conservative harmonic language, with Markevitch being the main exception.Rafael Kubelik‚Äôs music is indeed skillfully scored, eclectic and relatively conservative. Orphikon, a ‚ÄúMusic in Three Movements for Orchestra‚Äù, is quite ambitious in scope, however, and clocks in at approximately 35 minutes. It is darkly dramatic and often anguished in character, and influences are rather obvious ‚Äì a bit of Bartok and Shostakovich and some nods to Mahler, and I cannot help but hear the resemblance to the sound worlds of contemporaneous Czech composers like Vycpalek, Dobias and early Kabelac, perhaps in particular the latter. So, no ‚Äì not much of a discernible personal voice, but the work nevertheless manages to hold the listener‚Äôs attention (at least this listener‚Äôs attention) throughout. An enjoyable work ‚Äì though enjoyable in the manner that effectively written and scored brooding, gloomy, angst-ridden and tragically dramatic music can be enjoyable. Apparently the work is based on ‚Äúthe idea of integrating vertical and horizontal tone-relations through the existing principle of harmonics ‚Äì as determined by the inextinguishable laws of acoustics‚Äù. Yeah, whatever ‚Äì at least the overall structure of the work is somewhat unclear. Ideas are introduced and examined before being replaced by new ones rather than developed; but there are enough good (if not ultimately memorable) ideas and sufficient variety here for the result to be pretty effective nonetheless.The Cantata Without Words is written in the same style, but this time if employs a wordless chorus in addition to the orchestral forces, and the musical narrative is far more explicit. The chorus is imaginatively used and the whole thing is, once again, pretty enjoyable, though I do think that I did, in the end, find the ideas in Orphikon to be somewhat stronger in general. No matter, this is rather enjoyable music and of course the composer himself secures idiomatic and convincing performances from the Bavarian RSO & Chorus ‚Äì stronger on drama and blazing intensity than refinement, perhaps, but that is entirely appropriate for the music. The sound is a bit old and rough but not really any obstacle. Recommended to the adventurous, especially if you don‚Äôt expect any big revelations.

ASV has produced an eminently worthwhile series of Martucci‚Äôs orchestral works; the piano concertos and La canzona dei Ricordi are particularly worth checking out. Martucci did, as is well known, go against the grain among his Italian contemporaries by eschewing opera and focusing on instrumental music (and symphonic forms), but he also brought influences from German and French romanticism to Italy, and the piano music on this disc is written in a typical and unfortunately rather generic romantic style. There are influences of Liszt and the salon but few traces of a personal voice ‚Äì which you do, to an extent, find in some of his orchestral works. Fortunately much of the music is fast-paced and vivacious, and if it lacks depth ‚Äì which it consistently does ‚Äì much of it is at least moderately enjoyable, even if nothing sticks in the memory.The Prelude, Toccata and Gigue strikes me as perhaps the most enjoyable work of the program, but that might be just because it opens that program rather than because of any particular inherent merit. The three romances, on the other hand, are by some distance the weakest ‚Äì these are inconsequential salon works seeming to aim for sentimentality and nothing else. Francesco Caramiello‚Äôs playing is dutiful more than inspired ‚Äì at least he doesn‚Äôt overdo the music, but one sometimes gets the feeling that he doesn‚Äôt exactly believe in it either. Especially the slower works lack lyricism, but it is hard to completely blame the performer. The sound is good, though, and if you have a particular fascination for romantic piano music I suppose this might be worth checking out if you can find a cheap copy.

Joseph Marx (1882-1964) remained a resolutely late-Romantic composer throughout his career, and while he remained a respected teacher his own compositional style became more and more out of step with the times. At the time of his death his music disappeared more or less completely, but it has received renewed attention the last couple of decades. I have myself been very impressed by some of his works, but I have to admit that I am not entirely sure what to say about the music on this disc. The three tone poems comprising his Nature Trilogy are big, lush works containing some marvelous colors, scoring and orchestral effects, but are also rather diffuse and aimless (with one exception). The musical language is, as mentioned, late romantic but it seems to have borrowed quite a bit from Debussy; the music ebbs and flows and rummages, sometimes sounding a bit like Delius in his most ‚Äúacquired-taste‚Äù passages (and I am a committed fan of Delius), but there are few real themes and accordingly little real development. Perhaps that was the idea: the music is supposed to capture some moods and impressions of nature, not to tell a story. Perhaps Marx was more forward-looking than we give him credit for, and I am looking for some old-fashioned narrative structure that he has consciously chosen to eschew.In any case, the Symphonic Night Music seems to me to have at least the outlines of a discernible structure. It also contains plenty of lovely thing and is amazingly scored; but the enchanting details and shifting, opulent textures are primarily there to be savored for their own sake, it seems, and lovely as they are the work acquires something of an interminable character as it unfolds. The Idyll-Concertino is the shortest of the works and by some distance the most successful. It is, in fact, a marvelous work of gorgeous, hazy summer light and is able to capture the sense of temperature almost as well as Debussy‚Äôs Pr√©lude √† l'apr√®s-midi d'un faune. It also has some discernible themes to give it structure ‚Äì more similar to an architectural shape than the narrative structure of a story. In fact, after the Idyll-Concertino I thought for a moment that I had discovered a key to the music, but the Spring Music quickly lost me again. And once again, despite some lovely details and scoring it strikes me as mostly interminable wandering, even more aimlessly than the Symphonic Night Music.Four stars for the Symphonic Night Music (being generous), five for the Idyll-Concertino, three for Spring Music would be my verdict on the music. At least the Bochum Symphony Orchestra under Steven Sloane manages to realize the glittering colors and almost succulent textures of this music; indeed, the performances strike me as very admirable throughout, and the ASV sound is very good. To what extent they are perfect advocates for this music is harder to determine for sure, but I suspect the aimlessness that characterize at least the Spring Music is no fault of Sloane and the players. Overall, though, given the performances and the loveliness of the Idyll-Concertino I have to give this disc a fairly strong recommendation.

Franz Waxman is probably best known for his film music, though his concert work has received a bit of attention the last couple of decades; Eric Zeisl also made a career as a film composer, but recordings of his orchestral and chamber music have, to my ear, revealed him to be more than worthy of being compared to the greatest composers of the twentieth century. Both composers are stylistically associated with brilliant, essentially late-romantic splendor often reminiscent of film music ‚Äì which is unsurprising since these were among the composers establishing the sound of (Hollywood-style) film music. The disc at hand, however, finds them both in unusually reflective, dark, and powerfully poignant mode, far removed from the glitter, champagne and historical-epic qualities of the works with which most listeners would associate them.It is hard not to be affected by Waxman‚Äôs The Song of Terezin, composed in 1965 to texts drawn from poems written by children incarcerated in the Terezin concentration camp. Waxman sets the text with obvious consideration and sensitivity to the material, though there is a sense of anger running underneath and the score turns pretty dramatic at times. Scored for soprano, children‚Äôs choir, mixed choir and large orchestra, Waxman is also an exquisite colorist. Is it great music, though? See, that‚Äôs the rub ‚Äì like I said it is impossible not to be touched by this work, but I don‚Äôt really think Waxman‚Äôs music adds much to the poignancy of the poems. But then, maybe it wasn‚Äôt supposed to do so? I have to admit to having some trouble rating a work like this.Eric Zeisl‚Äôs Requiem Ebraico (Psalm 92) for choir, soloists and orchestra was written in 1944-45 in memory of the composer‚Äôs father. The music is more subdued than Waxman‚Äôs, but also somewhat more conservative, at least superficially so (there are, as always with Zeisl, some interesting and remarkable touches here and there). Though the text (sung in Hebrew) isn‚Äôt anywhere near as moving as Waxman‚Äôs poems, the music itself is to my ears more touching and more eloquent. It is probably not among Zeisl‚Äôs greatest works, but it is a touching one nonetheless. The performances are uniformly superb, at all levels, and the sound is very good. Overall, this is a highly recommendable disc, though I do perhaps ‚Äì I have to admit ‚Äì suspect that the contexts of these works, and the poems Waxman uses, have led to higher ratings for this disc than the music alone strictly speaking warrants. Still.

The music of Hermann Wolfgang von Waltershausen (1882-1954) isn‚Äôt often encountered these days. In fact, he seems to have lived a rather humble life and, although he apparently had some influence over the musical life in his native Munich, does not seem to have tried too hard to achieve much beyond that. His opera Oberst Chabert, completed in 1912, was nevertheless quite successful (so much so that there does, in fact, exist an alternative recording from 1956 with Julius Patzak among the cast, issued by Walhall ‚Äì I have not heard it) and certainly his greatest hit; it was even performed internationally but WWI but an effective stopper to any possibility it might have had for entering any kind of standard repertoire. You might have noticed that Waltershausen‚Äôs dates ‚Äú(1882-1954)‚Äù are also the dates of Walter Braunfels, another composer who continued to write in what is essentially a late-romantic style, but Waltershausen‚Äôs music is even more conservative and apparently remained that way throughout his career. Certainly the language of Oberst Chabert is heavily indebted to Wagner and Liszt, with a touch of Italian opera (Catalani and Puccini); much of it could pass for Richard Strauss, some of it as Franz Schmidt or Korngold, but it is also a more conservative overall than any of these latter three composers.The story is a relatively free adaptation of Balzac‚Äôs novel ‚Äì the characters‚Äô motivations are different and so are the outcomes. It is, in fact, a rather moving story in this adaptation (though it has become more standardly operatic), and at 100 minutes, it is also a relatively compact and dramatically effective one. Musically, Waltershausen doesn‚Äôt quite manage to achieve anything like the brilliance of Strauss or Korngold, but he is a skilled orchestrator with some fine, even memorable themes and some spectacularly good ideas. In fact, the quality of the music improves as things proceed ‚Äì in the first act, he seems mostly to present ideas and fragments that on their own sound disparate, and which together makes the act seem meandering and wayward without anything really memorable happening musically; but then things pick up as the ideas are developed and brought together, and much of the third act is magnificent ‚Äì not to mention the quintet at the end of the second act. It is, I suppose, a dangerous game, but if you feel like sampling this set before making a decision just listening from the beginning will not give you the right impression. I won‚Äôt say that it‚Äôs a masterpiece, but it is a very impressive work overall, and I would definitely like to hear more of Waltershausen‚Äôs output.The performances are generally very good ‚Äì at least Bo Skovhus is dependably excellent and dramatically hugely effective. Manuela Uhl is also very good ‚Äì she may score higher on drama than on sublime beauty of tone, but that‚Äôs also the right emphasis in a work like this. The rest of the cast is good if not outstanding and the orchestral performances by the Berlin Deutsche Oper Orchestra under Jacques Lacombe generally very effective ‚Äì clear textures and dramatic involvement, though not in the end ideally lush or opulent. That caveat is unfortunately exacerbated by the engineering; the sound is quite dry, which, although it keeps the textures clear, does to an extent undermine the kinds of effects I think the composer was often going for. We do get full texts and English translations and good notes, as usual with cpo. Overall, and despite a few shortcomings, a highly recommendable affair.

The Danish composer Hakon B√∏rresen (1876-1954) remained a staunch musical conservative throughout his life, and if you are looking for anything strikingly personal or (at all) forward-looking, this disc is probably not for you. These are Romantic, conservative, somewhat sturdy works; yet I found them absolutely lovable ‚Äì the ideas, while not exactly earworms, are strong, the colors glorious and B√∏rresen knew how to sustain momentum throughout ‚Äì these are, indeed, the kind of arch-romantic symphonies I am very happy actually exist.The second symphony (1904) is like so many other symphonies inspired by and subtitled ‚ÄúThe Sea‚Äù. Oh, well ‚Äì I don‚Äôt really hear that much seascape or vivid oceanic imagery here, but it doesn‚Äôt really matter. The style doesn‚Äôt venture that much beyond Schumann and perhaps Bruch and Reinecke, except for plenty of touches obviously indebted to Tchaikovsky; the robustly constructed and moderately dramatic first movement reminds me a bit of early Dvorak as well; the delightful second is a spirited and atmospheric Mendelssohnian scherzo; the third is perhaps the movement where the ghost of Tchaikovsky is most obvious (the overtures and symphonic poems more than the symphonies); and the fourth is a relatively gentle and wistful movement though not entirely without drama. These description doesn‚Äôt, however, capture how eminently enjoyable and satisfactory the whole affair actually is ‚Äì the third movement may meander a bit, but otherwise this is thoroughly recommendable for any lovers of romantic symphonism.The third symphony dates from 1927. It is hardly more modern in style, but the voice does seem a bit more personal nonetheless ‚Äì Dvorak and Tchaikovsky are audible influences but overall B√∏rresen manages to incorporate these influences seamlessly into something that is at least modestly individual. The first movement is also more complex than anything found in the second symphony (it is also almost as long as the other movements put together); though generally romantically tuneful, it also has more depth (and darkness) than anything else on this disc. The slow movement is by comparison modestly pleasant and the scherzo wistfully supple and touching. The last movement, too, is sparkling and spirited and mostly fun (enormously fun, in fact), though occasionally veering toward something resembling the depths of the first movement. It is an excellent work, and probably even more impressive than the second symphony (and, written 24 years after, even more completely out of touch with its times).In short, this is thoroughly enjoyable music, and I am very, very happy to have heard it. The players of the Radio-Sinfonie-Orchester Frankfurt at least sound like they enjoy themselves as well, and turn in spirited, colorful and warmly glowing performances under the direction of Ole Schmidt. I have not heard the alternative recording with Owain Arwel Hughes, but found little to complain about in the performances at hand. The sound is good. Pretty strongly recommended.Addendum: To say that many composers have found the connection between the symphony and the Ocean inspiring, would be an understatement. In addition to B√∏rresen‚Äôs second, ‚ÄòThe Sea‚Äô is the subtitle at least for Hanson‚Äôs seventh and Tuukkanen‚Äôs third. Rubinstein‚Äôs second is of course subtitled ‚ÄúOcean‚Äù, and Vaughan William‚Äôs first is ‚ÄúA Sea Symphony‚Äù. Alfv√©n‚Äôs fourth (‚ÄúFr√•n Havsbandet‚Äù) and Atterberg‚Äôs third (‚ÄúV√§stkustbilder‚Äù) have ocean-inspired titles, as does at least arguably Bantock‚Äôs ‚ÄúHebridean Symphony‚Äù and the title ‚ÄúSinfonia del mare‚Äù has been used by Malipiero, Nystroem and Nystedt. Montsalvatge wrote a Mediterranean Symphony, Langgaard‚Äôs fifteenth is titled ‚ÄúS√∏rstormen‚Äù (translated ‚ÄúStorm at Sea‚Äù) and more recently Williamson‚Äôs second (‚ÄúPilgrim p√• havet‚Äù) and Rasmussen‚Äôs first (‚ÄúOceanic Days‚Äù) have ocean-inspired titles, in addition to Dewey‚Äôs ‚Äúex Oceano‚Äù (on climate change). Moreover, at least Bax‚Äôs fourth and Braga Santos‚Äôs third were explicitly inspired by the sea. There are probably plenty of other examples of ocean-inspired symphonies, aren‚Äôt there?

I assume that the Paul Wittgenstein story is familiar enough: Wittgenstein ‚Äì brother of Ludwig and hailing from one of the wealthiest families in Europe ‚Äì lost his right arm in WW1, but decided to continue his career and commissioned concertos and music from Strauss, Britten, Prokofiev, Ravel, Korngold, Hindemith and others. Not a particularly sympathetic character, Wittgenstein insisted on lifetime exclusive performance rights (‚Äúyou don‚Äôt build a house just so that someone else can live in it. I commissioned and paid for the works, the whole idea was mine‚Äù) but still failed to perform many of the works he commissioned ostensibly because he didn‚Äôt like or understand them. Apparently he liked the works composed for him by Franz Schmidt very much, however, and Schmidt‚Äôs output for left hand was accordingly pretty substantial: In addition to the concerto and Concertante variations recorded here, there are three quintets (two with clarinet and string trio) and at least one solo piano work.Well, I don‚Äôt know for sure, but strongly suspect that Schmidt viewed these works as primarily or even purely sources of income. Schmidt‚Äôs best works are masterpieces, but the works here are not among them. That said, the craftsmanship is undeniable, and the Concertante Variations on the scherzo of Beethoven‚Äôs fifth violin sonata are unfailingly charming and delightful; nothing particularly exciting happens and it was evidently written to please Wittgenstein ‚Äì notice for instance how Schmidt carefully avoids letting the orchestra ever overshadow the soloist: It plays relatively quietly throughout and is evidently only there to provide some texture that a left-hand-alone score cannot. This is utility music, and it is hard not to notice the cynicism involved on the composer‚Äôs part to ‚Äì I speculate ‚Äì ensure that his customer (for whom it is hard to have much sympathy) would be satisfied. But as mentioned, it really is pleasant music, flowing nicely from one pretty moment to another completely without care or fear or a dark thought. It is actually worth hearing, though at 30 minutes obviously too long.The concerto is probably a different matter, unfortunately. Composed in 1934, its sound world is admittedly somewhat reminiscent of that of the fourth symphony, which immediately preceded it. But in terms of inspiration the fourth symphony is in a completely different league. The concerto, which goes on for 43 minutes, contains little that is at all memorable ‚Äì at least I could find little; others may disagree. It is heavy, cloudy, ruminating music that meanders around without ever really building up any drama or tension, and the main ideas are not only relatively weak but don‚Äôt ever really go anywhere. Now, I have certainly heard worse music than this, by all means, but for a composer of Schmidt‚Äôs reputation this is on the disappointing side.I suppose, though, that these works are must-haves for fans of the composer (and the variations are enjoyable enough to merit a listen even for the rest). In that respect it is good that they receive the advocacy they do. Markus Becker is a first-rate soloist here, with glitter, sparkle and enthusiasm in the variation and plenty of bravura in the concerto. He is finely supported by the NDR Radiophilharmonie, whose role is often subdued but no less important. The sound is good - the soloist may be somewhat too forwardly placed (I can see why they would do that way, but they exaggerated). I short, it is hard to imagine better advocacy or presentation of this music, but the music itself doesn‚Äôt really warrant an unreserved recommendation.

The Swedish composer Maurice Karkoff (1927-2013) was a productive composer, and I am just going to assume that the disc at hand paints a representative portrait. Apparently the critic Carl-Gunnar ≈hl√©n once wrote that Karkoff‚Äôs symphonies form a canon in the genre that is comparable to that of Allan Pettersson. That is exaggerating, but (at least one of) the two symphonies on this disc does make a case a composer who knew how to turn beautiful but often deeply introverted tone painting in an often uncompromisingly modern language into formally convincing structures. The title work, Sinfonia della vita, which was composed in 1993-94 and was the composer‚Äôs eleventh symphony, and is a case in point. The sound world of the work reminds one perhaps a little of Berg (or Fartein Valen), though it is more modern ‚Äì there is an undeniable romantic sensibility to the music, and a lyrical, melancholic strain running through the whole work. It is actually an impressive and appealing work; more so than the darker Dolorous Symphony (no. 9) for strings, which is dark and brooding and, I would say, sometimes dangerously close to self-parody (which may, perhaps, have been the point).‚ÄúSkuggspel, klara vatten‚Äù reveals a rather different side to the composer ‚Äì the lyrical, introverted character is still there, but these nine Chinese songs (from 1990) for voice and piano are based on Chinese music in melodic character and rhythm; they are, almost surprisingly, basically tonal and many of them almost shimmeringly beautiful. A similar inspiration from far Eastern sources characterize the older piano piece ‚ÄúVid gransen‚Äù (from Orientaliska bilder), but the expression seems less personal. The disc, however, opens with the song cycle ‚ÄúGl√ºhende R√§tsel‚Äù, a decision about which I have to say I have my misgivings; these uncompromising and, frankly, sometimes downright ugly pieces in a much less personal, more generic style inspired by contemporaneous avant-garde music.At his best, however, Karkoff‚Äôs music achieves a certain haunting, introverted beauty that is also quite personal; I recommend sampling Sinfonia della vita and ‚ÄúSkuggspel‚Äù for two very different examples. Still, I honestly think there is a fair bit of late twentieth century music to go through before this one. The performances are good enough, though I think the song-and-piano works would have benefited from a slightly mellower, more refined approach and the Helsingborg Symphony Orchestra under Tommy Andersson ‚Äì while overall good ‚Äì lacks the last ounce of brilliance and opulence, I think.

Yes, Boris Godunov is one of the greatest operas ever composed (it might, in fact, count as two or three operas given the various versions; all of them are great, though), and Khovanshchina is regularly performed. But Mussorgsky composed other operas as well ‚Äì or rather, he started a couple of other operas: like Khovanshchina, these operas were left unfinished and had to be put in working order by other hands, but have not received anything close to the same amount of attention. Salammbo and The Marriage are relatively early works (recordings exist) but Sorochintsi Fair, based on Gogol‚Äôs short story with the same name, was a project at least started when the composer was at the height of his powers. He completed some numbers (even some of the scoring), but much of the story was admittedly left without music, or just with scattered sketches. Among the things he did manage to do, was to incorporate the Night on the Bald Mountain music and a dream sequence not in the original story (and frankly rather bizarrely tagged onto it). At present the work exists in several completions, and it would have been interesting to compare them since anyone who embarks on the project of completing this work will have to do quite a bit of original work as well. The most famous version is Shebalin‚Äôs, and it is apparently the least interventionist one (I can‚Äôt help but think that I do hear some of Shebalin‚Äôs own voice here, though); one result of being non-interventionist is that the story itself doesn‚Äôt quite add up, but fair enough: I‚Äôve encountered worse in the realm of opera.Well, it is a work that any fan of the composer needs to hear. There are some delightful and fascinating things here, but I sometimes ‚Äì heresy, I know ‚Äì would have preferred a more interventionist approach from Shebalin. There are some very banal and clumsy parts here, too, though the juxtaposition of dark drama and almost vaudeville-like scenes seems to have been deliberate; it‚Äôs after all a comic opera, and one can only imagine the status it might have achieved had Mussorgsky managed to leave a complete or at least almost complete version. The appearance of a crude version of Night on the Bare Mountain is interesting ‚Äì it ends up sounding almost like a parody of itself, and the ending of that sequence is almost more effective than the ending of the work as we know it. The scoring is sometimes borderline amateurish (despite the often-made pleas for authenticity in performance versions of Mussorgsky‚Äôs orchestral works, I have to admit that I understand where Rimsky-Korsakov and his gang were coming from), but overall this is a fascinating and even fun work.Alternative recordings exist. I have not heard those (and as far as I know none of them use the exact same edition), but the one at hand is unfortunately no more than serviceable. The singing barely passes muster, and especially the female singers are problematic, even downright ugly. Partially this seems to be in virtue of conscious decisions, the idea being that these are comic characters in a comic opera and should therefore be sung like caricatures, but even it that (mistaken) decision had not been made, I doubt that Zalizniak‚Äôs Khivrya, for instance, would have been acceptable. Evgeny Brazhnik directs the Chorus and Orchestra of Ekaterinburg State Academic Opera and Ballet Theatre of Russia in a performance that similarly sounds as if it tries to underline the comic elements; it‚Äôs brash and forced and rushed (I suppose that‚Äôs one of the reasons why the Night on the Bald Mountain music comes across as something close to a parody) with little atmosphere and sense of majesty, and the orchestral players have serious troubles coping with the interpretative decisions.The sound quality is nothing to write home about either. The singers are far too forwardly placed (it actually varies a bit, but they are at least never integrated into the full sound picture), and the orchestra sounds hollow. Finally, there is the rather important matter of documentation. There is no libretto, only a summary ‚Äì but what we get is a summary of Gogol‚Äôs short story, not Mussorgsky‚Äôs adaptation. And that, of course, makes it well neigh impossible to figure out what is actually going on in the opera ‚Äì you easily figure out that it‚Äôs a comic opera, but it is impossible to determine what the jokes might be. So, in sum, this is a fascinating work well worth discovering, but the present release is, in the end, really no more than serviceable. The extent to which the other existing versions are superior is something I cannot say for sure, however.

Dvorak is usually not considered to have been a very idiomatic composer for the piano, though his best works, the Humoresques op. 101 and the Poetic Tone Pictures op. 85 belong among the greatest masterpieces ever written for the instruments. But the composer was not a virtuoso himself, and his music for the instrument are hardly virtuosic or dramatic (all of his piano works are miniatures), but they are often hauntingly beautiful, reflective and atmospheric ‚Äì and his famous melodic gift is as much on display in these works as it is in his more familiar works. Radoslav Kvapil has helpfully recorded all of it (he might have done it more than once, in fact), and if you just want to sample Dvorak‚Äôs piano output vol. 4 of this series is without the one to go for, though the present volume is an absolutely delightful follow-up.The main offerings are the six mazurkas op. 56 and the Suite op. 98. The latter is, of course, better known in its orchestral version as the ‚ÄúAmerican Suite‚Äù, though I suppose even in orchestral garb it remains among the composer‚Äôs less well-known works ‚Äì it is essentially light music, and the five movements are not linked together in any particular way; yet the music is gloriously atmospheric, sunny and reflective, both in the orchestral version and the original piano one. I am not sure either version is superior, but the piano version is definitely worth hearing. The mazurkas were composed a year after the first series of Slavonic dances, and these six pieces, too, testify to Dvorak‚Äôs seemingly unending supply of gorgeous melodic ideas. Though they do of course owe something to Chopin‚Äôs models, they are also instantly recognizable as Dvorak‚Äôs, and although the technical demands they put on the performer aren‚Äôt particularly daunting they come across as works that would deserve to be far better known.The other pieces on the disc are mostly minor works, but even the smallest trifle contains lovely elements entirely characteristic of the composer. In fact, the smallest of them, the F sharp major Humoresque (nothing to do with the G flat major one) composed in 1884 is, at 2‚Äô35, is a witty and disarmingly charming little gem. The poetic Impromptu, originally published in a humor magazine supplement is less memorable but contains some nice, characteristic touches. The Dumka and Furiant, though given the opus number ‚Äú12‚Äù, actually dates from 1884 as well and was also published in a magazine supplement. The Dumka is a more serious, solemn work the character of which is somewhat reminiscent of the contemporaneous Stabat Mater; the following Furiant is, as expected, as big of a contrast as one could imagine. Though perhaps not exactly among Dvorak's greatest masterpieces these are lovely works, very much worth hearing. Finally we get two small piano pieces dating from the time of the composition of the Humoresques, a lyrical Berceuse and a jolly Capriccio. These are admittedly merely chips from the composer‚Äôs work bench, but even so they have a touch of magic to them.An overall fascinating survey, then, and it should be mentioned that it covers Dvorak‚Äôs stylistic development from the national style of the Slavonic dances to the American or post-American style of his late works ‚Äì albeit in the form of lighter music. While the works here are not quite on the level of the op. 101 Humoresques or the Poetic tone pictures, there are still rewards aplenty, and Radoslav Kvapil plays it all superbly and idiomatically. The sound quality varies a bit (the recordings date from 1967 and 1970), with the Suite becoming a bit constricted. Still, this is an excellent disc, enthusiastically recommended, even if you should pick up vol. 4 first.

As you may already know, George Lloyd (1913-1998) was something of an outsider to the British (and international) musical establishment, as he continued to compose in an idiom that was almost defiantly diatonic and approachable and never afraid of neither heart-on-sleeve emotions or triumphant majesty. But the fact that his basic harmonic palette was rather conservative (even traditionally romantic) does not mean that the music itself is derivative or lack originality or personality ‚Äì quite the contrary. Combined with never-ending imagination and superb craftsmanship (he was, not the least, a wonderful orchestrator), Lloyd‚Äôs music did manage to secure him something of a fan base toward the end of his life, and some of his music comes pretty close to being genuine masterpieces.The seventh symphony might be a case in point. An ambitious work in three movements lasting almost 50 minutes in total, the work was written during 1957-59 and apparently orchestrated in 1974. It was influenced by the story of Proserpine, though one may well suspect a more personal story underneath; it is at least is a darker and more anguished work than most of his other symphonies. The lengthy but tautly constructed first movement builds darkly agitated dance-like material out of the mysterious material of the opening and works itself into a massive climax before receding back into mystery. The Largo movement is wistful, even sorrowful, but often strikingly, nobly beautiful.The opening of the finale, then, is an almost shocking contrast; as if the rug is suddenly pulled out under the world of the Largo. The thematic material is mercilessly destroyed, setting off a blistering build-up of anger and fury that culminates in a thunderous climax followed by a magically beautiful epilogue. It is a tremendous work, and it is ‚Äì as expected ‚Äì superbly performed here by the BBC Philharmonic under the composer himself, and they are recorded in warm, clear sound. Yes, the disc comes in at under 50 minutes of total playing time, but it is such a powerful work that one cannot really complain. Strongly recommended.

As you may already know if you are reading this, George Lloyd (1913-1998) was something of an outsider to the British (and international) musical establishment, writing in an idiom that is almost defiantly diatonic and approachable and never afraid of neither heart-on-sleeve emotions or triumphant majesty. But the fact that his basic harmonic palette was rather conservative (even traditionally romantic) does not mean that the music itself is derivative or lack originality or personality ‚Äì quite the contrary. Combined with never-ending imagination and superb craftsmanship (he was a wonderful orchestrator), Lloyd‚Äôs music has managed to secure a firm fan base, and though I don‚Äôt think ‚Äì as opposed to some ‚Äì that he is, ultimately, in the running for a position among the greatest British composers of the twentieth century, some of his symphonies are genuine masterpieces.The first and twelfth symphonies are probably not among those, however, and for those who are not already familiar with the music I would recommend starting somewhere else (the fourth symphony is a good bet). For those already attuned to the idiom, this is still a fascinating disc. Lloyd‚Äôs twelfth and final symphony does have a valedictory feel, but it is a warm and overall friendly farewell; final thoughts and remainders rather than something new and novel and important. Pairing it with the first symphony is a good idea, however: Though Lloyd‚Äôs idiom remained approachable and listener-friendly, it certainly evolved over the course of his career and the twelfth is definitely a more personal creation than the first, but the two works also retain a formal kinship (deliberately so): Both works consist of a theme and variations followed by a slow movement and an energetic finale (though the twelfth is over twice as long).Personally I found the first symphony endearing; true, the idiom owes a lot to, say, Vaughan Williams and Dyson and other composers of the turn-of-the-century British school(s), and there are some awkward transitions (it was written when the composer was 19), but it also has a kind of breezy boldness that puts to mind Bruckner‚Äôs first. Of course, the twelfth is in a different league with regard to formal security and the composer‚Äôs ability to utilize the full resources of the orchestra. It is also far more individual in character; yet overall I thought it missed the thematic strength of Lloyd‚Äôs best works and, indeed, even of its companion work. In any case the performances by the Albany Symphony Orchestra under the composer himself are first-rate and the sound is very good. Definitely worth adding to your collection, but newcomers to the composer should probably start elsewhere.

Back in the late 19th and early 20th century George Chadwick was one of the foremost representatives of American romanticism, but like all of them ‚Äì perhaps with the exception of MacDowell ‚Äì his name faded into obscurity where is languished until the last decade of the 20th century. His music is not particularly original ‚Äì that seems to have been part of the code for this group of composers (and which may have been part of what gave rise to the extreme originality of Ives and the American ultramodernists) - and it owes a lot to Liszt, Dvorak and possibly Chadwick‚Äôs own teachers, Rheinberger and Jadassohn. Though he may not have been a first-rate melodist, Chadwick‚Äôs scores are endlessly inventive, atmospheric and finely scored; they also requires a touch of fairy magic, full-blooded strings and dramatic momentum, which they rarely receive in sufficient degree in recordings. Jos√© Serebrier and the Czech State PO do seem to have many of the right ideas, but the playing isn‚Äôt quite as refined in the reflective movements or ferociously driven in the faster parts as the music needs, but the competition isn‚Äôt too fierce either.The Symphonic Sketches (1895-1905) consist of four movements with the kind of romantically picturesque titles that alone would explain why Chadwick‚Äôs music fell out of favor in the mid-twentieth century. Jubilee is an energetic and engaging movement written in mid-Dvorak style. Noel is unapologetically sentimental (tongue in cheek?), while Hobgoblin, though I see what the composer was going for, is not particularly successful. A Vagrom Ballad is endlessly inventive and attractive, however. The Melpomene overture is one of many Chadwick works on Greek themes, and while engaging and enjoyable while it lasts, it is frustratingly impossible to remember anything whatsoever of the music when it is over.Tam O‚ÄôShanter, however, is a riot. A phantasmagorical symphonic poem, it may be based on some pretty simple ideas, but it moves through a magnificent array of moods, atmospheres and nature painting, all the while generating more and more energy. It is definitely worth discovering, and although the playing tends to be a bit rough when the temperature is turned up, this is probably worth the price of the disc on its own. So, while not everything about this disc is ideal it deserves, in the end, a firm recommendation.

Most of the music of Jean Cras (1879-1932) is now available on disc, which is as it should be, I suppose. A dozen or so of the songs with orchestra recorded here are also available in their original versions for voice and piano; I haven‚Äôt heard those, but I would imagine that they have gained something (or at least been substantially transformed) from the composer‚Äôs very effective orchestration. Stylistically, Cras‚Äôs language is late romantic, owing something to Chausson and his friend Duparc, but there is also a Breton element that he shares with, say, Ropartz and certainly more than a touch of impressionism; the later works on this disc also seem to be a little more harmonically complex (Ravel, but also something slightly more acerbic), although the overall tone is still one of delectably atmospheric late romanticism ‚Äì but the program is variegated, and the atmosphere and sound world vary quite a bit between the collections of songs here.The opening set of four √âl√©gies was originally written for voice and orchestra, and are lush, opulent and shimmeringly beautiful, almost a bit over the top. A significant contrast, then, to the sparer, halflit and gloomier soundworld of the following three songs accompanied by string quartet, arrangements of relatively early songs ‚Äì effective enough, but best if not heard right after the √âl√©gies. L‚ÄôOffrande lyrique is a setting of six Tagore poems, originally with piano, and replaces the eternity-and-the-sea mood of the √âl√©gies with a somewhat more exotic, mysterious and introvert mood. The five songs comprising Fontaines also originated as piano-accompanied songs, but Cras seems to have had a field day scoring them ‚Äì this is imaginative and very effectively done. In the pleasant Image we return to string quartet accompaniment, and the final No√´ls, originally choral works, are full of na√Øve, pastoral, rustic charm, apparently set with no apparent intent of avoiding sentimentality, but the results are very charming.As pointed out by the other reviewer, the singing is somewhat variable. Philippe Do sounds better suited to opera than to song, and lacks warmth and the kind of intimate expressiveness with which the √âl√©gies should (to my ears) ideally be sung; it‚Äôs not bad - the phrasing is admirable and the diction good - it‚Äôs just not ideal. Lionel Peintre sounds like his songs suit him better and Ingrid Perruche is overall very good even if there is a certain lack of nuance in her characterizations. The Orchestre de Bretagne plays well and idiomatically under Claude Schnitzler, though the tone is perhaps not quite as rich as one might have ideally hoped for ‚Äì it is, however, probably as good as one could reasonably expect. The sound is a bit dry as well, but not really a problem. Overall, despite a few caveats regarding the performances and production this is a very recommendable release to anyone interested in French late romanticism.

Timpani has done a lot for the music of Joseph-Guy Ropartz (1864-1955) who otherwise seems to have managed to retain a toehold in the repertoire mostly through some chamber works, an EMI recording of his third symphony and a Naxos release of choral works. I am not sure his opera Les Pays is the ideal starting point for exploring his output, but it is an impressive work very much worth checking out. Stylistically, Ropartz‚Äôs music is late romantic with a touch of impressionist harmonies and a firm basis in Breton musical traditions ‚Äì if you have encountered the music of Lazzari, Cras or Ladmirault, you would have an idea (though the chance that you have encountered any of the music of those composers is, I suppose, lower than the chance that you‚Äôve encountered Ropartz‚Äôs); in this opera in particular I am also occasionally reminded of Chausson‚Äôs Le Roi Arthus (Les Pays actually strikes me frankly as more variegated and effective than Le Roi Arthus) and ‚Äì perhaps surprisingly ‚Äì the tone poems of Arnold Bax, which generally postdate Ropartz‚Äôs opera.Indeed, ‚ÄúLe Pays‚Äù (‚ÄúThe Country‚Äù), the title of the opera, refers to Brittany ‚Äì the story (Le Goffic‚Äôs ‚ÄúL‚ÄôIslandaise‚Äù, from a collection titled ‚ÄúPassions Celte‚Äù) follows Breton fishermen braving the stormy waters off the coast of Iceland and experience a shipwreck, whereupon the anti-hero Tual falls in love with a local girl, marries her and promises to stay; upon spring, however, he feels the call of his native land and set out to join his fellow Bretons to return ‚Äì the call is too strong for him to stay with his pregnant wife, and he sneaks away, which is not a good idea. The music is in a sense dramatic, but Ropartz tends to add a certain dreamy softness ‚Äì it‚Äôs deeply evocative, but even the dramatic Icelandic landscape and the drama of the story are shrouded in a haze of tragic mystique. Though the overall character of the work is lyric and tragic, it does move effectively forward; the drama is relatively lowkey but there is this sense of inevitability to the proceedings. Overall very convincing, but the work also contains plenty of individually striking things along the way, especially in some of the stirring, atmospheric orchestral passages. Indeed, it is really the orchestra more than what the characters sing that carry the story. To retain the essence and feel of the story Ropartz also decided to forego standard elements of French opera, including set pieces and even the chorus.As for the performances, Mireille Delunsch should be a reasonably familiar name, and she is a world-class singer who turns in an excellent performance here ‚Äì not only splendidly sung, but with an ability to draw intense sympathy for her character K√¶the. Gilles Ragon may be more famous for his work in music from earlier periods, but seems well adapted to Ropartz‚Äôs late romanticism and gives us a very convincing performance of the role of Tual. No complaints about Olivier Lallouette as J√∂rgen either (and yes, those are all the characters), and the Orchestre Philharmonique de Luxembourg plays generally very well under Jean-Yves Ossonce, though one could ‚Äì if one were churlish ‚Äì perhaps note that Ossonce tends to play things big and spacious and ask for a bit more intimacy. Is this set good enough for five stars? Just the effort of assembling a solid cast and orchestra to record an opera by Ropartz goes a long way. And when the results are as successful as they are (no complaints about the recorded sound either), and we ‚Äì importantly ‚Äì get a full libretto with English translation, the answer is surely "yes".

It never rains but it pours. Vytautas Bacevicius (1905-1970) was a Lithuanian composer who spent the last part of his career in the US. (He was also, it seems, the brother of Grazyna Bacewicz. Huh.) His music was for the most part ignored then, and it remained ignored until recently, when Toccata Classics issued two discs of his music and Naxos suddenly embarked on a series of his orchestral works. Well, it is not entirely undeserved ‚Äì Bacevicius has something of an individual style that, on the evidence of this disc, evolved quite a bit over his career yet retained certain signature traits. The music here is hard, belligerent, craggy and raucous, with the early works sounding a bit like a mix between Scriabin and Honegger (or perhaps rather Milhaud) and the later perhaps a bit like something in the direction of Var√©se.To start with the earliest work here, the one-movement Piano Concerto no. 1 (1929) is subtitled ‚ÄúSur les th√®mes lituaniens‚Äù though, apparently like other listeners, fail to hear much I recognize as folk music influences (perhaps it‚Äôs in part due to my unfamiliarity with Lithuanian folk music). It‚Äôs a short work (14 minutes) indebted to Scriabin but rather more modern, and, I have to admit, not really a work that sticks in the memory. The Po√®me √©lectrique from three years later shows a rather substantial stylistic and harmonic development. This is a work belonging to the ‚Äúfuturistic‚Äù machine music style exhibited by e.g. Honegger‚Äôs Pacific 231 or Prokofiev‚Äôs music of the time, and is one that sacrifices everything in favor of power and forward momentum ‚Äì ugly and colorful and dramatic, and quite spectacular if a bit superficial and not quite as memorable as the best works associated with that trend.Honegger is also brought to mind in the second symphony, composed in 1940 and given the subtitle ‚ÄúDella Guerra‚Äù.
