It‚Äôs a passionate if somewhat brutalistic work that rejects any kind of lyricism, with a first movement depicting the bombing of Poland, the second the sorrow and tragedy of war (rather impressive) and the third the battle for Europe. It‚Äôs not quite as forward-looking as the Po√®me √©lectrique, but quite effective and perhaps the strongest work on this disc overall. The sixth symphony, from 1960, is more harmonically advanced, containing little by way of melody (not that the earlier works focus much on melody either) and at least borders on rejecting tonality altogether, but it is a concentrated and overall well-constructed work. With Graphique, from 1964, we encounter an exploration of sonorities in a style closer to the avant-garde, at least something occasionally resembling late Var√©se; once again an overall moderately impressive work if not a masterpiece.The performances are certainly serviceable, if occasionally a bit rough and raw ‚Äì but then, this is music that requires raw power more than finesse or brilliance. The sound is a tad dry but at least allows you to hear all the details. A very recommendable release for those with a sense of adventure, certainly, though if I were to decide I think I would have recommended record companies to check out some other little-known Lithuanian composers from Bacevicius‚Äôs generation (Abelis Klenickis, Antanas Raciunas or Stasis Vainiunas, for instance) before launching competing series of Bacevicius‚Äôs works.

This is an excellent disc from one of the best mezzosopranos working during the last couple of decades. It does also, I suppose, present a nice survey of Tchaikovsky‚Äôs songs (of which there is quite a number, few of which are well-known) and includes at least the two most famous ones, ‚ÄúNone but the lonely heart‚Äù and ‚ÄúOnce Again, Alone‚Äù ‚Äì and the selection consists of songs from both early in his career (the 1869 set including ‚ÄúNone but the lonely heart‚Äù) and late ones. However, I would warn against listening through this disc in one go ‚Äì these songs are pretty much all rather dark and sad and slow, focusing on loneliness, regret, sorrow and longing. Taken a few at a time, on the other hand, virtually every single one comes across as a marvelous gem.That‚Äôs not the least because of the performances. Though most people will, I suppose, best know Olga Borodina from opera, these performances suggest that her talents are just as well if not even better suited to songs; it is hard not to be impressed vividness with which she characterizes the emotional contents of the songs, and the subtle variety in mood she finds across the songs here. Larissa Gergieva is the sister of Valery Gergiev, but as opposed to what you might expect from that, her performances are reflective and lyrical and occasionally almost reticent. In fact, Borodina and Gergieva take these songs pretty slowly but their artistry is definitely up to the challenge this presents.Indeed, Borodina and Gergieva have chosen an exceptionally dark and serious and emotionally replete approach to songs that are already as haunting and dark as any in the repertoire ‚Äì it‚Äôs pretty remarkable how well they bring the listener along and manage to avoid any sense of self-parody. And in the final three songs they go even further; in ‚ÄúNight‚Äù and ‚ÄúThe Sun Has Set‚Äù Borodina‚Äôs voice takes on even darker hues than before, and in the final, familiar ‚ÄúAgain, as before, alone‚Äù she sounds like death itself ‚Äì all light and hope is gone and one is left with such pain and horror that the result is almost unbearable; it‚Äôs the kind of thing that demands a long period of reflective silence after the end of the recital. A remarkable performance in a collection of remarkable performances. The sound quality is very good. Strongly recommended.

Rued Langgaard was, famously, a strange figure, and as a composer he is almost impossible to pigeon-hole. His famous ‚ÄúMusic of the Spheres‚Äù sounds almost like it belongs to the experimental avant-garde of the 60s (and was famously praised by Ligeti), and elsewhere in his oeuvre there is plenty of strikingly forward-looking music; at other times ‚Äì and sometimes in the same work ‚Äì much of the thematic material would have sounded conservative to Brahms or even Schumann. For the most part it's like late-romanticism refracted through madness, but although the music sounds deranged to the extent that one sometimes suspects that Langgaard was, indeed, crazy, there is a purpose to his solutions, and there is no doubting his technical skills.One thing that strikes one when listening to Langgaard‚Äôs music, including the three works here, is his special relationship with form. I don‚Äôt think one should listen to these symphonies as if they were through-composed, unified narratives; indeed, despite the essentially romantic character of these works, you won‚Äôt really find melodies in the traditional sense either ‚Äì at least not melodies that are developed in any ordinary sense. Instead, Langgaard uses building blocks identified by style or tone or a certain idea; whether these blocks then fit together in any ordinary manner seems to have been less of a concern.Another thing to keep in mind is that although these symphonies have (evocative?) titles ‚Äì as do the individual movements of no 4 ‚Äì it is unclear whether one should take them too seriously. Langgaard tended to add such titles to his works often long after the work was finished, and sometimes changed them later to something completely different. That said, the fourth symphony is titled ‚Äúfall of the leaves‚Äù, and it does indeed have a sort of autumnal quality (at least much of it does) ‚Äì a rather stormy, autumnal quality ‚Äì and certainly something very picturesque about the movements, though there is certainly a variety of moods expressed here. Overall, it must rank as one of the most immediately approachable of Langgaard‚Äôs symphonies, though not all of the movements are equally successful.The fifth has the subtitle ‚ÄúSteppelands‚Äù, though it is only the outer movements (which do evoke a feeling of a breeze or storm over a steppe landscape) that, to my ears, really fit that description. Overall, I don‚Äôt think this is one of Langgaard‚Äôs best works, however ‚Äì like many other of his symphonies there is little traditional development here rather than various episodes that only nominally fit together, but only a few of these episodes sound really inspired to me. The sixth symphony, however, is pretty remarkable. This work, like many of the composer‚Äôs, has a religious inspiration ‚Äì and a pretty apocalyptic one, at that (though the work is not really particularly dark). Given the title ‚ÄúThe Heaven Storming‚Äù, it is certainly a dramatic work, even though it eschews traditional symphonic development ‚Äì but as opposed to the other works, it is formally relatively tight; what underlies the proceedings is a sort of variation-form based on a theme played twice at the beginning, one idyllic and pastoral version and one rather ominous and ghostly one. Perhaps surprisingly, the tauter form of the work makes the work sound more modern than its two companions.I am not entirely sure I am completely sold on the performances. The Danish National Radio Symphony Orchestra certainly plays pretty excellently, and J√§rvi does succeed in whipping up plenty of drama and energy. But he also pushes the music quite hard, and I suspect there is more details in and variety between the movements in the sixth symphony than J√§rvi manages to bring out here (on the other hand, it is certainly stormy). Still, the fourth symphony manages to combine wistfulness and punch and I don‚Äôt think the feeling of waywardness in the fifth can be blamed on the conductor ‚Äì I haven‚Äôt heard the various alternatives available of these works, however. The Chandos sounds is very good, and overall this disc can be safely recommended to anyone with a sense of adventure.

Though it is billed as ‚Äúvol. 1‚Äù this disc really contains all of Bartok‚Äôs major works for violin and piano ‚Äì four major masterpieces, and in excellent performances and recording. The two rhapsodies are good and accessible examples of what Bartok did with (Hungarian) folk music, and although I must say that I prefer the orchestral versions, the violin-and-piano versions do reveal details and connections that one might otherwise miss, and do, I admit, allow for a kind of fierce abandon in the performances that is hard to accomplish with more than two players ‚Äì and Ehnes and Armstrong give you everything you‚Äôd want. What‚Äôs listed as ‚ÄúAlternative Ending‚Äù for part II of the first rhapsody is, in fact, the more familiar (and, honestly, effective) version.The two sonatas date from the early twenties, when Bartok‚Äôs style was at its wildest and perhaps most complex ‚Äì at least the two sonatas belong to his most harmonically and structurally complex works; they‚Äôre ‚Äì at least compared to the rhapsodies ‚Äì certainly not easy listening, but, boy, how one‚Äôs efforts and concentration are rewarded. I have no problem judging these two be among the greatest violin sonatas ever written. Though the music is tonal, both works are highly dissonant, powerful and even aggressive, but beyond that the two works are also pretty contrasted in character. The first is in a traditional three-movement form, with a ferocious and flickering first movement, a lyrical second movement and a barbaric third. The second is cast in one movement and is quite compact ‚Äì perhaps even structurally ‚Äúdense‚Äù ‚Äì but in two distinguishable section, the first one slow and the second faster. As a bonus we also get the pleasant, little and rather untypical AndanteNow, there are admittedly a number of first-rate recordings of the main works on this disc out there; yet I don‚Äôt think Ehnes and Armstrong (the piano usually plays an equal part in these works) need fear the competition overly much. I suppose one could say that they strike something of a middle ground between the more transparent and accessible approach of Tetzlaff and Andsnes, and the most fiery ones, such as the old and legendary performance of the second sonata by Szigeti and the composer himself. If so, the present performances do not feel at all like a compromise; this is wonderful, powerful, fierce but nuanced playing of the highest caliber. The sound is very good. Strongly recommended.

Franz Schmidt may have been an important symphonist (he was), but his first symphony is no masterpiece. An early work, it was completed when the composer was 22, and exhibits exuberance and, I suppose, youthful energy, and it is surely an assured work from a young composer. The language is even rather personal ‚Äì eclectic, to be sure, but it strikes me as an interesting and somewhat attempt to combine Schumann and Bruckner, with some clever and rather successful solutions. On the downside there are few really memorable things, especially beyond the first movement, and, more problematically, Schmidt‚Äôs narratives tend to get bogged down in some heavy fugal writing, in particular in the finale. It is certainly a work worth hearing, but it is more of an interesting and occasionally rewarding curiosity that puts Schmidt‚Äôs later development in context rather than a completely successful work in its own right.The indefatigable Neeme J√§rvi seems bent on recording everything, and he often secures first-rate performances for neglected or little-known repertoire. Sometimes, however, he seems to have too little time for preparation or thinking too deeply about the repertoire he records, and this recording strikes me, unfortunately, as a case in point. It‚Äôs not bad ‚Äì it never is with J√§rvi ‚Äì but it is also rather workmanlike, and the music is often too hard pressed, with too little attention to detail; the performance here seems to have the goal in sight from the very first bars, and takes the straightest path there without bothering too much about the subtleties or views along the way. That said, the Detroit Symphony Orchestra responds, in general, well, with plenty of punch and energy. Nonetheless, this strikes me as a serviceable performance rather than anything close to an ideal one. I have no idea what the point of the coupling might be: Four Interludes from Richard Strauss‚Äôs Intermezzo that makes less than perfect sense shorn of their context played with noise and superficiality, steeliness instead of opulence. The sound is decent, though.

Rimsky-Korsakov‚Äôs one-acter Kashchey the Immortal is, like several of his operas, based on a Russian fairytale. It was completed in 1902, around the time he lost his professorship at the Conservatory due to political activism, and a student performance of the work was followed by a political demonstration and, subsequently, a ban on performances of Rimsky‚Äôs music (quickly lifted due to political pressure). Well, like his other fairytale operas Khaschey does contain hints of social commentary, I guess, but it is certainly not as overt here as in some others. What is clear, is that Khaschey is otherwise crammed with action, and I imagine it may be dramatically pretty effective.Musically it shows, perhaps more than many of his other operas, an influence of Wagner. The whole score is based on a few leitmotifs for characters and emotions, but the score is rich and variegated with plenty of marvelous touches and clever solutions ‚Äì the blizzard scene being a notable example ‚Äì and Rimsky‚Äôs harmonic palette is, it seems, somewhat more advanced than in many of his other works. Of course, there is no time to dawdle ‚Äì despite all the details and twists everything has to fit in an hour ‚Äì and sometimes the scenes border on being too compressed (not usually a big problem in opera). One thing that is perhaps missing is any particularly memorable melodies ‚Äì still, the whole thing is a blast.As for the performances, I find Konstantin Pluzhnikov in the title role very impressive. He sings the role with a lighter touch and a bit of humor, which is entirely apt. Marina Shaguch sings beautifully ‚Äì perhaps some might say she is a bit too one-dimensional the fairy-tale princess she portrays, but contrast is effectively provided by the rich tone of Larissa Diadkova and the result is entirely convincing. There is perhaps a bit less contrast between Alexander Gergalov and Alexander Morozov, but that would also be the only criticism I could level against their impressive singing.As usual, Gergive pushes the Kirov Orchestra and chorus very hard, and the performance is perhaps stronger on white-hot intensity than fairytale atmosphere ‚Äì I don‚Äôt know how he compares with the other two recordings of the work, but it is a convincing interpretation in its own right (though I do think I would have chosen slightly more atmosphere over intensity if given the choice). The recording is excellent, at least. In sum, this is a fascinating, exciting score, and although I am perhaps not Gergiev‚Äôs biggest fan, with singing and advocacy like this it is hard to justify anything less than a top score for this one.

Elgar wrote quite a lot of music reflecting WW1, or for various occasional purposes related to the war, and Somm has usefully gathered together some really obscure and some slightly better known works on this disc. It is a must for committed fans of the composer, but not all of the works here are, shall we say, top-drawer Elgar. The aching, haunting Sospiri is the most familiar piece here, and an unqualified little masterpiece (and it is also rapturously played here by the BBC Concert Orchestra under John Wilson), and it is, honestly, in a different league compared to the rest of the program - something you will probably hear from the first note.That said, the symphonic poem Polonia is very fine work as well. A tribute to the people of Poland, Polonia mixes music by Chopin and Paderewski with patriotic themes, and although there is a bit of bombast here, surely, Elgar could do bombast pretty well without crossing the line to banality. It is also well played, though there is a celebrated Boult recording out there that, as far as I remember, is even more stirring. The other major work, The Sanguine Fan, was a ballet written for a charity concert and although it is perhaps not top-drawer Elgar either, it is enjoyable enough with enough variety, nuance and substance to sustain its duration.The three works for Belgium (inspired by the poems about the country‚Äôs suffering by Emile Cammaerts) are pretty vapid, however ‚Äì but then Elgar didn‚Äôt have the format, narration with orchestra, on his side. Carillon and Le Drapeau Belge are strictly for completists ‚Äì almost embarrassing, I would say. The gloomy Une Voix dans le D√©sert is hardly a great piece either, but at least Susan Gritton does her best to bring light and hope to the scene. Of the three small pieces, Carissima is a lighter, sepia-tinted, nostalgic and ‚Äì I suppose ‚Äì pretty little trifle, and Sursum corda (an 1894 work that doesn‚Äôt really have much to do with the war apart, perhaps, from the mood) is touching. Rosemary (a waltz) is very, very slight, however.In sum, then, this is, indeed, a very valuable collection, even if the musical quality is not consistently first-rate (or even second-rate). The performances are inspired, however, and the sound quality is good. Recommended, though perhaps mostly for already committed fans of the composer.

The more I hear of his music the more I become convinced that Erich Zeisl (1905-1959) is one of the most seriously neglected composers of the first half of the twentieth century. Zeisl was one of many Austrian Jews who left for America in the 1930s, and like his compatriot Korngold he ended up in Hollywood ‚Äì though his success there was definitely eclipsed by Korngold‚Äôs (and by Zeisl‚Äôs own pupil Jerry Goldsmith). Korngold may be an apt starting point for describing Zeisl‚Äôs musical style as well; it is rooted in romanticism, but there is less champagne and glitter than in Korngold‚Äôs music; it is in one sense more ‚Äúcivilized‚Äù, but at the same time more stylistically daring and unconventional. Korngold leavened with Hindemith, perhaps. Or perhaps Miklos Rozsa might be a better comparison, though Zeisl does ultimately not really sound anything like Rozsa. ‚ÄúEclectic‚Äù might be a fitting description as well, but if it is eclectic (and Pierrot in der Flasche certainly goes through a dizzying array of musical styles) the different influences are also melded together into a unified, personal style that is at the same time recognizable and novel.The piano concerto is a major find; marvelously inventive and finely constructed with a spacious, flowing and memorable opening movement, a wonderfully wistfully reflective second movement and a spectacularly enjoyable finale. Yes, much of it is borderline kitschy in the way Korngold‚Äôs music often is, but it never crosses that border and has a tinge of reflective dreaminess that Korngold does not ‚Äì and while the tonal language is rooted in romanticism it is certainly spiced up with some (slightly honed down) angularity and modern effects.Zeisl wrote a number of ballets and Pierrot in der Flasche is a relatively early one (from 1929, though the suite we get here was put together in 1935). It‚Äôs a phantasmagorical, hallucinatory riot. Stylewise it touches on pretty much everything imaginable ‚Äì the setting is modern and urban, illustrated by jazz and contemporary popular music influences, but it contains an extended fantasy setting involving all sorts of fantastic imagery, and in the music there is everything from fake orientalism, blues, Straussian schmaltz to Schrekerian hysteria and elements that don't really sound like anything I recognize, all ‚Äì amazingly ‚Äì put together in something that‚Äôs almost a coherent whole. In any case, it‚Äôs one of the most hilariously enjoyable things I have heard in a while.The performers sound like they agree. The Vienna Radio Symphony performs these works superbly under Johannes Wildner, with all the energy, color, opulence, feeling and imagination one could dream of, and Gottlieb Wallisch is a first-rate soloist in the concerto. The recording is amply spacious, rich and full but clear. Enthusiastically recommended.

Ernst Pepping (1901-1981) enjoyed a career as one of the most important composers of Protestant church music in the 20th century, and seems to have had quite an influence in his time, mostly through his choral and organ music. It is rarely heard these days, as far as I can tell, but cpo should be commended for this collection of his most significant orchestral works. Pepping‚Äôs three symphonies were composed between 1932 and 1944, which would be after he had set aside his earlier ‚Äúuncompromising dissonance‚Äù. And indeed, the style is rather toothless, though it may have appealed to authorities at the time; the second symphony was even recorded by the Berlin Philharmonic under Furtw√§ngler in 1943, a recording that has been intermittently available.The style of these works actually remind one a bit of social realist works; not so much in actual sound world as in the obvious attempt to be listener-friendly and avoid confrontation. All the works here are basically neo-classical and diatonic with just the occasional dissonance thrown in to spice things up. Given the composer‚Äôs background in choral music it is hardly surprising that the music relies a lot on counterpoint, but the textures never clog; the downside is that there is little drama or tension, but nor is there much sense of grandeur and ambition ‚Äì it is really all very nice, easily diverting music that chugs pleasantly along. But although there are few particularly memorable points of interest, there is exactly enough for the listener‚Äôs attention not to flag: these works are, indeed, enjoyable, clean, bright and variegated enough to sustain interest.More precisely, the first and third symphonies are both carefree and happy works; the second is darker. That doesn‚Äôt mean that it contains more drama, however; just that the atmosphere is gloomier and occasionally somewhat oppressive. And to be perfectly honest, I prefer Pepping in a happier mood ‚Äì though not by much, I would actually choose the third symphony as my favorite of the works here. The piano concerto from 1950 really is more of the same: cheerful (though somewhat introvert) and contrapuntal neo-classicism that plays around with its own material with just enough ingenuity to leave a positive overall impression.No masterpieces, then, and little to challenge the listener, yet it is enjoyable enough to merit a listen if you like, say, Hindemith or Blacher. The performances by the Nordwestdeutsche Philharmonie under Werner Andreas Albert appear to do the music justice (I haven‚Äôt actually heard the Furtw√§ngler recording of the second), and Volker Banfield provides as spirited a performance of the solo part in the concerto as it would be reasonable to hope for. In short, I would recommend this release (and look forward to cpo ‚Äì or anyone else ‚Äì exploring the music of, say, Hans Friedrich Micheelsen, Richard Mohaupt, Kurt Thomas or Johannes Driessler), but if you should miss it your life would probably not be very substantially poorer.

Both of Saint-Sa√´ns‚Äôs string quartets are late works (1899 and 1918, respectively), and probably not among his more familiar works (or even more familiar chamber works). To be honest, I don‚Äôt think the quartets are quite up there with some of his chamber works with piano; the piano seems to have allowed Saint-Sa√´ns let the music flow more freely ‚Äì both string quartets contain passages that sound a bit effortful compared to the composers output in general ‚Äì but that doesn‚Äôt mean that there are no musical rewards to be had here. In the e minor quartet I find the first two movements to be the strongest, being based on strong and interesting ideas and plenty of ingenuity; the slow movement strikes me as meandering and the finale a bit lacking in good ideas (though Saint-Sa√´ns could always rely on solid craftsmanship to drive his points home). It is still a rewarding work overall, by all means ‚Äì and quite a bit darker than one may have expected from the composer ‚Äì though not quite on the level of, say, the Franck quartet (of which I am occasionally reminded).The second quartet, in G major, was (apparently) written toward the end of World War I, when the composer was plagued by the effects of the war as well as anxiety about and (it seems) pessimism about the future. That seems to be why he chose to write the first movement in a very Mozartian style reminiscent of the music he wrote in his youth, and the second movement to be a sad response to the loss of that youth (though Saint-Sa√´ns seems, in that case, to have been unable to avoid a bit of self-aware humor). The third movement is primarily a bridge to a moderately effective but a bit nondescript finale. It is an occasionally fascinating work, but one does sometimes get the feeling that Saint-Sa√´ns was tired of it all, that he realized that his best music was behind him, leaving him to offer wry commentaries on his earlier successes.I have few complaints about the performances; the Miami quartet‚Äôs sound is vibrant and full-bodied and they make what sounds to me as the best possible cases for the Saint-Sa√´ns works. As for the companion work, Faur√©‚Äôs late, single quartet is a masterpiece, or at least a near-masterpiece (the piano quintets, cello sonatas and second violin sonata are probably even better) in his typical and utterly captivating late style. Here, however, I do feel that the Miami quartet perhaps lacks the last little ounce of dreamlike, wistful, autumnal magic I think can be realized in the work ‚Äì it‚Äôs a very good performance, to be sure, but my standards for what late Faur√© can sound like are pretty high. So to conclude, the disc contains two excellent performances of good but not great works, and one near-excellent performance of a marvelous work. The sound quality is superb, however.

I am not sure how popular Otto Nicolai‚Äôs ‚ÄúThe Merry Wives of Windsor‚Äù actually is anymore, at least outside of Germany (in fact, it seems that record companies have been more interested in exploring the rest of Nicolai‚Äôs output), but it is one of those classic operas that even if it (perhaps like Gustave Charpentier‚Äôs Louise or Flotow‚Äôs Martha) isn‚Äôt particularly frequently staged these days, still deserves a first-rate recording. In fact, it is probably safe to say that this opera is doomed and will never regain its previous status: It‚Äôs a singspiel, and that means that the story is carried by lots of spoken dialogue ‚Äì which is necessary for the drama but also makes some of the passages rather boring. The present version dutifully includes all the dialogue, but it‚Äôs relatively easy to skip if you want to (I suppose the ideal solution in my view is to print it in the booklet but not record it).The music, though, is delightful; from the still relatively familiar overture and all the way through, Nicolai‚Äôs score is brimful of ideas, excellent tunes and a joie-de-vivre surpassing almost anything else ‚Äì it really is a feast for anyone enjoying a sparkling, jolly and brilliant comedic opera. How actually funny it is may be a different matter, but Gottlob Frick certainly tries his best as Falstaff, turning in a performance so colorful and convincing that I imagine it would be hard for me to enjoy anyone else in the role (if I ever get the chance). EMI‚Äôs cast, however, is pretty much excellent throughout even if it is Frick who tends to steal the show.The Chor der Bayerischen Staatsoper M√ºnchen and the Bayerisches Staatsorchester turn in generally first-rate performances as well under the ever-dependable (inspired, actually) direction of Robert Heger, full of wit, sparkle and dramatic momentum. And though the recording dates from 1963 the sound is pretty excellent. The only minor drawback, I suppose, is that the libretto is given in German only ‚Äì there are extended synopses in English and French, but that‚Äôs not quite the same. Still, this is an extremely enjoyable affair, strongly recommended.

Brahms‚Äôs two late string quintets (the earlier piano quintet also started out as a string quintet) for 2 violins, 2 violas and cello are probably his best chamber works for strings alone, though they are not really that well served on disc. The first quintet was composed in 1882 and is cast in three movements, the first a generally gloriously joyous Allegro non troppo ma con brio, the second a deeply poignant slow movement with two livelier interludes and a wonderfully heartfelt ending and a dancing, songful and superbly crafted finale. The second quintet, composed in 1890, is in four movements; the first movement contains a particularly superb second subject; the slow movement is almost a self-standing work based on an initially ghostly motif for the viola that is masterly developed to a glorious conclusion; the third movement is a kind of yearning minuet and the finale again dance-like, though less outgoing than the finale of the earlier work.The performances here, though, are not unproblematic. There is already a debate over whether Trampler is playing in tune ‚Äì perhaps he is, and perhaps it is partially the use of vibrato that is putting me off, but the results don‚Äôt sound as beautifully textured as I think they could ‚Äì the wistfulness of the op. 111 third movement, for instance, is missing, and the second movement certainly is rather far from sublime ‚Äì as others have pointed out, the players don‚Äôt really achieve ‚Äúan ideal blend‚Äù. That said, the sound of the Juilliard Quartet is full-bloodied and they succeed rather well in the stormier passages. Perhaps it is just my awareness of the discussion that makes it sound to me as if Trampler is the main problem; perhaps it is just that the sound is less than ideal. Oh well, I shouldn‚Äôt exaggerate ‚Äì these are still very rewarding recordings, especially in the faster movements. As such, I am willing to recommend this release, though with some caveats.

Beyond his operas Richard Wagner did, in fact, write a number of orchestral works. Apart from the Siegfried-Idyll and the Wesendonck-lieder they are usually overlooked and of questionable quality with most (including some later works such as the Kaisermarch or the American Centennial March) being rather strikingly bad. The 14-minute fragment for the Beethoven-inspired Symphony in E major from 1834 (not the same as the slightly more familiar completed C major Symphony), is perhaps not strikingly bad, but far from distinguished in any sense and containing not the faintest trace of a promise of what was to come, and is hardly interesting enough musically to be of interest to many other than those with a special biographical interest in the composer.The models for the Overture to Das Liebesverbot (from the same year) are contemporary French and Italian comic opera ‚Äì again there is little trace of the mature dramatic work, but the overture is actually rather enjoyable on its own terms. The Faust Overture (1840-44) doesn‚Äôt actually contain any premonitions of the later works either ‚Äì illustrating instead how far Wagner had to go before reaching his famous later style. The work hasin fact managed to retain a toehold in the repertoire, but although it is vastly superior to earlier overtures such as Polonia and Rule Britannia, it is doubtful that it would have avoided sinking without a trace were it not composed by Wagner.The Faust-Overture is certainly not on the level of the more familiar overture to Rienzi that concludes this program and of course endlessly inferior to the Wesendonck-Lieder. What we get here, however, is not the Wesendonck-Lieder as you know them but ‚Äì and this is really poorly advertised ‚Äì the reorchestration for chamber forces by Hans Werner Henze. Though skillfully done, the character of the work becomes very different, with textures and colors and an austerity far closer to Webern than to the original work.Marjana Lipovsek sings them well, however, and she is sensitively accompanied by the Philadelphia Orchestra under Wolfgang Sawallisch, who is also appositively fiery in the Liebesverbot overture and the symphony. In Rienzi and Faust, however, they are arguably more splendidly stately than dramatic. All in all, this is an interesting program, but I do think it is primarily aimed at people with a particular interest in the composer rather than the general listener.

Antonio Bibalo's (1922-2008) main contributions were in opera, but this disc of instrumental works is ultimately rather fascinating. His style is rather difficult to pin down, but he studied with Elizabeth Lutyens and worked as a caf√© pianist in Norway (among a lot of other things) before his operatic breakthrough, and seems to have picked up influences everywhere ‚Äì perhaps the style is ultimately somewhat eclectic, but it is also rather personal. Though the works here are essentially tonal, they certainly owe a lot to twelve-tone music, even avant-garde experimental music, as well as jazz.Sinfonia Notturna, for instance, inhabits a sound world of tone clusters and play with sonorities, but the harmonic base is almost surprisingly traditional ‚Äì and although it seems to meander a bit (the work seeks to describe various aspects of the night, from the vastness of the night sky to peacefulness to misery to restless big-city nightlife to death) the result is never less than compelling and interesting. The performance by the Bergen Philharmonic Orchestra under Karsten Andersen appears to me to be very good; richly textured, colorful and with plenty of energy.Astrale for wind quintet is also inspired by the universe and the sky, though the inspiration sounds somewhat indirect and the result is certainly less striking than in the Sinfonia Notturna. Autunnale for flute, contrabassoon, vibraphone and piano sounds like a cross between serialism and smoky, jazzy salon music and should accordingly be rather dreary ‚Äì but the result is strangely compelling nonetheless. In the end, the Sinfonia Notturna is by far the most interesting item here, but the two chamber works are still rather compelling and they are excellently performed. An interesting and rewarding release, then, definitely worth hearing.

Tom√°s Bret√≥n (1850-1923) did, as so many Spanish composers of his generation, compose zarzuelas but he also endeavored to create a Spanish national opera, and La Dolores, from 1895, is one of the latter. Though a true, through-composed opera, it also exhibits a thoroughly Spanish character and contains some elements more familiar from the zarzuela ‚Äì which is mixed into what is otherwise a rather Italian style. The musical language is, in other words, eclectic rather than very original, but I suppose it works reasonably well, and the end results is a quite enjoyable piece of passionate melodrama that doesn‚Äôt quite manage to meld together into any particularly effective dramatic unity but contains enough excellent music to hold the listener's attention nonetheless.The performances are overall good. Elisabete Matos sings the main role with color and convincing technique, though her voice doesn‚Äôt have that lovable, seductive quality that one might have wanted from the role ‚Äì but that is, I assume, a churlish complaint (compare to the quality that most recorded operatic rarities get and this is quite splendid). Mario Lanza and Stefano Palatchi, the bass-baritones, are very fine (some apparently think Palatchi is too rough, but his performance sounds entirely suitable to the role for me), and Tito Beltran as Celemin is very good as well.But the prize must goes to Domingo, whose versatility is nothing less than astonishing (one more reason to count him as one of the absolutely greatest performing artists of the last 50 years). Well, maybe it‚Äôs just that I have grown to love that voice too much, but to my ears this is yet another superb performance and with a characterization entirely appropriate for the role. In any case, the Chor del Gran Teatro del Liceu, Cor Infantil del Conservatori de Badalona and the Orquestra Sinfonica di Barcelona i Nacional de Catalunya under Antoni Ros Marb√† support the soloists well without perhaps managing to bring out that last ounce of red-blooded ferocity I think the music sometimes needs. Oh, well ‚Äì though this is no masterpiece, it is a very enjoyable affair, and we should probably be grateful to have it in performances as (overall) convincing as these.

If you are looking for something very original, the music of Ferdinand Thieriot (1836-1919) may not be your first choice, but that‚Äôs virtually the only element missing from these works ‚Äì anyone who enjoys the chamber music of Brahms (a lifelong friend) or Rheinberger (Thieriot‚Äôs teacher) or even Dvorak would do well to give this a try. His music was well-received in its day, and the obscurity his music fell into after his death is probably explained partially by changing tastes, but also by the fact that his manuscripts were moved to St. Petersburg after WWII where they were left to gather dust.In any case the piano quintet (1869, revised 1894) is truly excellent, with particularly memorably, muscular and dramatic, Schumannesque-Brahmsian outer movements framing a beautiful, almost languid Adagio and a genial scherzo. It is a splendid work of such constant invention, good ideas and fluency that it deserves a place in the repertoire ‚Äì perhaps it could even be called a near-masterpiece? The Sextet comes without opus number and year of composition and may not quite reach the levels of the quintet ‚Äì it is still a lovely work of great charm and some wonderful ideas, though the ideas don‚Äôt develop quite as fluently as they do in the quintet. Between these works we get a set of variations for the unusual combination of two cellos and piano; if it doesn‚Äôt quite reach the depth of the quintet this is nevertheless not a lightweight work and is inventive and variegated enough to keep the listener‚Äôs attention throughout without much effort.The Hamburg Players turn in perfectly acceptable performances, though there are some imprecisions, rough edges and even some questionable intonation at times. They are not helped by a recording that to me sounds a bit too artificial, especially in the upper registers (I don‚Äôt really possess the vocabulary or technical insight to describe very accurately what I think is wrong but the results are at least not ideal). Still, I am very happy to have been given the opportunity to acquaint myself with Thieriot‚Äôs music; and wrote a lot ‚Äì especially chamber music (including four piano trios, thirteen string quartets, two octets and plenty of sonatas), but also five symphonies ‚Äì that I would like to have an opportunity to discover.

We are familiar with several Estonian contemporary composers, but the music of Ester M√§gi (b. 1922) is presumably mostly an unknown quantity in the West. One obvious reason is that her music has little to do with ‚Äúholy minimalism‚Äù, though it certainly owes a great deal to Estonian folk music ‚Äì Tubin, Sibelius and a bit of Bart√≥k (and a whiff of Shebalin and Myaskovsky, perhaps) are influences that come to mind, yet her language is individual and personal enough that no description of influences, it seems to me, will quite capture the sound. Compared to the European trends of the twentieth century, I suppose it is also rather conservative; tonal, certainly, though not afraid of unusual colors and textures.The opening Vesper (1990) is almost national romantic in character; an emotional (though not sentimental), reflective work of significant beauty. The piano concerto (an early work from 1952) is also pretty conservative, even romantic in character, but skillfully constructed and rather effective ‚Äì folksy and enjoyable. Bukoolika is a curious case. Dating from 1983, it is a series of pastoral scenes for orchestra, explicitly ‚Äúcow-pat‚Äù and superficially reminiscent of Delius, unapologetically describing cow bells, birdsong and so on. It is not an ironic work, yet the result is far from quaint-sounding either. (If Rautavaara can successfully get away with Cantus Arcticus, then why not?)The variations for piano, clarinet and chamber orchestra (1972) have sharper edges and more acute angles than the preceding works, with fiercely enjoyable results. Both this work and the Symphony (1968) suggests that M√§gi went through a slightly more modern-sounding phase in the 1960s and 70s, though the language is hardly uncompromisingly avant-garde (more like Bart√≥k). The Symphony is cast in three movements lasting no more than 14 minutes in total ‚Äì the first a forceful, angry allegro assai lasting for 2‚Äô30; the Andante is uneasy, while the finale is a relentlessly strident Presto culminating in a captivating epilogue. Though perhaps not a timeless masterpiece, it is an impressive work, well worth hearing. The performances are uniformly very good, and though the recorded sound varies a bit it is never less than adequate (clear but often a bit too in-your-face). Recommended.

A curate‚Äôs egg indeed. It is unfortunate that Hyperion has discontinued its magnificent series devoted to Granville Bantock‚Äôs orchestral music, but it means that fans of the composer will probably want to check out this disc, insofar as it contains two works ‚Äì the Old English Suite and the Russian Scenes ‚Äì not available from Hyperion, in addition to duplicating the Hebridean Symphony (in fairness, Leaper‚Äôs recording is two years older than Handley‚Äôs). On the other hand those two new works are not among Bantock‚Äôs greatest by any measure; indeed, I have to say that the Russian Scenes, at least, are primarily if not exclusively for the Bantock completist.The Old English Suite is not great music either, but at least it is pleasantly engaging. It consists of arrangements of Gibbons, Dowland, Bull, Farnaby and Byrd, dressed up in a wistfully colored, late-romantic garb. The quality of the music is a function of the quality of the originals, of course, and frankly I don‚Äôt know if Bantock‚Äôs arrangements add anything ‚Äì nor, emphatically, does the playing of the Czecho-Slovak State Philharmonic Orchestra under Adrian Leaper, which is just a bit too rough and hesitant to realize the kind of nostalgic gleam Bantock seems to have been going for. At least the results are more interesting than the Russian Scenes. Composed in 1899, they are obviously written by a non-Russian and in fact doesn‚Äôt sound particularly ‚ÄúRussian‚Äù at all ‚Äì not even picture-postcard Russian ‚Äì apart, if it counts, for a few rather Tchaikovsky-like gestures, at least not until the final movement. They are decidedly thin gruel on any terms, and once again the performances lack that last bit of flair and swagger and color that this music needs (in addition to being markedly rough around the edges).The performance of the Hebridean Symphony, however, is quite good ‚Äì not as sumptuous or polished as Handley, to be sure, but Leaper does have more bit and (arguably) dramatic power. In the end, though, I would probably go for Handley, however, for the additional glorious opulence and textural nuances, but partially also because of the superior sound on the Hyperion release (not that this Naxos release has particularly bad sound) ‚Äì and of course because of the couplings. This release, then, is of mostly specialist interest, though I cannot quite get myself to completely dismiss it.

I really want to, and think I should, like this music. I have enjoyed Chadwick‚Äôs symphonies, and his Liszt-Schumann-Dvorak-mix of a style should have suited the symphonic poem format rather well. Yet, there is something bland and thoroughly anonymous about this music, something almost insistently unmemorable about these scores ‚Äì there is plenty of beauty and style, but little sense of narrative structure and few examples of climaxes that have been built up over a long period of time, for instance; and whenever Chadwick seems to be onto something interesting the music tends to fizzle away into nothing. There is little fire, blood or atmosphere and it is ‚Äì as the topics of these tone poems may suggest ‚Äì as if he is trying to push an essentially late-romantic palette and style into an inoffensive, classically elegant shape.I may be wrong. If I am, it is because the performances here are thoroughly wrong-headed, which I suspect they may be (no one else seems to agree with me, though). Indeed, I often found myself imagining what the music would have sounded like if the Nashville Symphony Orchestra under Kenneth Schermerhorn had tried to go for some hell-for-leather fire in the more dramatic passages, perhaps some elfin, halflit woodland atmospheres in some of the more reflective passages, and generally more glitter, sparkle, mystery and swagger (the approach the Moscow Symphony Orchestra under Adriano took for George Templeton Strong‚Äôs music also for Naxos‚Äôs American Classics, for instance - I sort of imagine that Chadwick's music should inhabit something of the same sound world). I think this would have been eminently possible ‚Äì Serebrier is closer to that kind of approach in a recording of Melpomene for Reference, though still not quite where I think I can imagine this music should be (besides, Melpomene is among the weaker of the works here in any case) ‚Äì so I can only wonder what the music would have sounded like under such an approach.Compared to these admittedly imagined performances, Schermerhorn is workmanlike and dull. The Nashville players do get the notes right (probably not a mean feat), but there is no fire, imagination, atmosphere or spirit in the playing, no real sense of narrative structure ‚Äì no magic, really, and I do think this music needs it. Accordingly, I find it hard to pass any final verdict on the music itself. Euterpe, Aphrodite and Thalia strike me as probably the strongest; Melpomene is a tad non-descript, whereas I am unsure even a stronger performance would manage to make the elements of Angel of Death cohere. In short, I have some serious reservations about this disc, though I guess most of this music isn‚Äôt really readily available elsewhere either.

Some people might wonder: Given the popularity of Joaquin Rodrigo‚Äôs guitar concertos, why isn‚Äôt any of his other music more frequently heard? This disc does, I think, help answer that question, but raises a new one: Are Rodrigo‚Äôs guitar concertos really particularly good, or is it just that there isn‚Äôt really much serious competition in that genre? At least when Rodrigo turned to genres where comparisons with other composers are easier, he emerges as a composer rather far removed from the front rank; though the music on this disc is occasionally enjoyable and colorful, it is also as shallow as music gets and contains little that sticks in the memory.The ‚Äúmajor‚Äù works are the main problem. The symphonic poem Per la flor del Iliri blau (‚ÄúThe Flower of the Blue Lily‚Äù) was composed in 1934 based on a Valencian fable, and is a ramshackle, episodic and meandering work striving to achieve a sense of unity and narrative structure by little more than repetition. Accessible it is, to be sure, and one may even argue that even in this for the composer unusual format a certain distinctive voice is recognizable. But that‚Äôs not enough, and the result is overall pretty dull . A la busca del m√°s all√° (‚ÄúIn Search of What Lies Beyond‚Äù) is even less interesting. A NASA commission, Rodrigo evidently tried to create an atmosphere of wonder and mystery, and the harmonic palette is somewhat richer and more modern than in any other works of his I‚Äôve heard. But the effort fails miserably. This is inconsequential meandering evolving into sentimentalist banality; a really terrible work.The program as a whole is somewhat redeemed by the shorter works, which at the very least never tries to be anything but light music. The early Three Traditional Dance Airs are engaging and fun; Palillos y panderetas pretty slight but compelling enough (it was actually composed as recently as 1982), and the Two Spanish Dances featuring a virtuoso castanet part probably the highlight of the disc ‚Äì spirited and jolly and innocuous, rhythmically buoyant music in a national style (I‚Äôll refrain from commenting on the castanet part).The performances are decent enough if a bit rough ‚Äì I would perhaps have wished for a little bit more flair and sumptuousness from the Le√≥n Symphony Orchestra under Max Bragado, but I think the recording is at least equally to blame for the deficiencies in that department. Soundwise, this is really not one of Naxos‚Äôs better efforts; it is dry and lacks any hint of bloom or ambience. A bit of a pity, but given that the main items here aren‚Äôt better than they are I am unsure whether this disc would have merited more than a very guarded recommendation in any case ‚Äì I‚Äôll grudgingly give it three stars for the lighter music, but that‚Äôs pretty charitable.

Michael Colina is an American Grammy-award-winning composer with a background in jazz and television music; his ‚Äúclassical‚Äù music appears to stem primarily from the very early and most recent part of his career with a 25-year gap in the middle. Like the other reviewer here, I purchased the disc based on glowing reviews (in the IRR for my part), and I have to admit to being somewhat disappointed as well. Colina‚Äôs musical language is nothing if not approachable; colorful, texture-based, but anodyne and containing little that sticks in the memory ‚Äì ‚Äúelevator music‚Äù is descriptive, though I am willing to go for "superior elevator music".  All the music appears to be written as expressions of the composer‚Äôs emotional reactions to certain stories or images, with ‚Äì it seems to me ‚Äì little thought given to how to effectively translate that into self-standing works of music, and seems accordingly (to me) to be the kind of music that is most interesting to those who know Colina personally and are particularly interested in his personal emotional reactions to stuff. I‚Äôm not.Well, that might be a bit mean. Certainly his Baba Yaga, a fantasia for violin and orchestra, is inoffensive enough and eventful enough to be worth a listen. The work does bring to mind Russian romantic music ‚Äì it‚Äôs unabashedly tonal ‚Äì but contains some surprising and quirky twists and turns. On the downside, those unexpected twists and turns also make the music come across as pretty meandering ‚Äì certainly it lacks any strong, bearing ideas. At least it sounds nothing like Mussorgsky‚Äôs take (Colina appears to claim that he doesn‚Äôt even know it).If Baba Yaga is superficially entertaining enough to merit a listen, I can find little positive to say about The Unbearable Lightness of Being, a slow-moving tapestry of diffuse fog that is as boring as you could possibly imagine ‚Äì ‚Äúunbearable‚Äù is apt; of ‚Äúlightness‚Äù there is none. The tone poem Quinta del Sordo, however, is rather effective. Based on the ‚ÄúBlack Paintings‚Äù by Goya, it employs Spanish rhythms and color with a result that resembles the tone poems of Joaquin Rodrigo (not that composer‚Äôs best works, though). It is not very original, nor very profound, but is probably the work here I am most likely to return to.The flute concerto ‚ÄúIsles of Shoals‚Äù seems inspired by Ravel (mostly) and contains several fine things ‚Äì not the least a very effectively written solo part. It is an essentially light work with rather effective, colorful outer movements. The work as a whole, however, is ruined by the middle movement. Based on ‚ÄúSchafe k√∂nnen sicher weiden‚Äù it is certainly beautiful, but that‚Äôs because Bach‚Äôs original is beautiful; Colina‚Äôs adaptation only works to showcase his own lack of good ideas. Seriously, composers: You need to stop doing this kind of thing! The only thing you‚Äôll achieve is to assert your own inferiority as composers. (In fact, Colina draws on Saint-Sa√´ns in the third movement as well, but that attempt is less blatant and glaring and doesn‚Äôt to the same degree stand out like a sore thumb.)The performances are excellent, though. Lukasz Dlugosz and Anastasia Khitruk are splendid soloists (Khitruk‚Äôs tone is perhaps occasionally a little thin), and the London Symphony Orchestra sound rich and colorful under Ira Levin and Ransom Wilson. The sound quality is opulent and ambient ‚Äì perhaps a bit too processed, but certainly apt for this kind of music. Oh well, if you think this sounds as if it‚Äôd appeal to you, it very well might, but I cannot really say that I was more than moderately impressed.

To some ears this may sound as heresy, but I am very unsure what I really think of Liszt‚Äôs organ works. To me they sound suspiciously like what a first-rate composer for the piano may write when first getting hold of an organ (indeed) and, overwhelmed by the aural potentials momentarily forget most of what she or he knows about composition, melody, counterpoint and so on because he or she is caught up in exploring the sonorities ‚Äì ‚Äúhey, even a plain C major chord sounds majest; let‚Äôs hold it down for five seconds. Wow.‚Äù Whereas composers like Franck or Widor mastered the organ and its potential, the organ seems to have mastered Liszt. And he had access to (and conceived much of his organ music for) the largest organ in Germany at the time; I‚Äôm not sure that helped.That organ has been restored, and is the instrument used on the recording at hand, which should add a bit of interest to this release, both for organ aficionados and Liszt fans. And it does undeniably sound splendid; gloriously grand and colorful. The topic of the release is the connection between Liszt and Bach, and opens with Liszt's perhaps most famous organ work, the Pr√§ludium und Fuge √ºber das Thema B-A-C-H, which is overall excellently performed here, though Michael Sch√∂nheit is perhaps a bit short on drama. The other original Liszt work is the Weinen, Klagen, Sorgen, Zagen variations, which is a good example, I think, of the worry I expressed above ‚Äì though it sounds imposing in this version (performance and instrument), it is musically a relatively shallow affair.Liszt‚Äôs Bach transcriptions sound good primarily because of the originals. Somewhat interesting bonuses, however, are the original Bach works, the Passacaglia BWV 582 and the Weinen, Klagen, Sorgen, Zagen prelude, played following 19th century registration plans (by Liszt pupils or colleagues). They sound undeniably romantic ‚Äì stylistically really not such a far cry from Liszt‚Äôs own works, in fact, but better. Overall Sch√∂nheit‚Äôs performances are imposing if lacking a little bit in fire and drama. While I have some reservations about the music, I know that many others do not, and at least for them this should be a very interesting release.

The Canadian composer Murray Adaskin (1906-2002) was relatively productive, though he embarked on his career as a composer quite late in life, and most of his compositions date from after his retirement from his positions as conductor and later composer-in-residence at the Saskatoon Symphony Orchestra. Stylistically, his music is in particular inspired by Stravinsky and his teacher Milhaud, and although most of it is abstract, one can, according to Wikipedia ‚Äú[t]hrough his works, [‚Ä¶] feel the presence of landscapes, birdsongs and different local surrounding sounds.‚Äù Well, the landscape of Saskatchewan is, frankly, pretty boring, and so is, I have to admit, much of Adaskin‚Äôs music, at least if the set at hand is representative.Most of the works here are relatively diverting and light; joyful and jazzy ‚Äúwithout subterfuge‚Äù, as they say in the documentary on the second disc of the set (yes, there is one disc of works and a bonus disc with commentary and an interview ‚Äì as such the CBC series on Canadian composers is pretty valuable, even though not all of the music is). As such, the music can easily come to sound inconsequential, as it often does here ‚Äì the music often comes across as pointless, personal musings with no overall idea or shape; it‚Äôs short-breathed ‚Äì the ideas are introduced but rarely go anywhere and aren‚Äôt really strong enough to sustain any further development ‚Äì and anodyne. Yes, some of it is pleasant enough and perhaps worth a listen ‚Äì the Concerto for Bassoon and Orchestra, for instance, which is at least playful and nimble. The Divertimento for Orchestra preceding it is less so.Then there is a Suite for Orchestra, which seems most of all strikingly elusive, in the sense that it is almost impossible to remember anything of it after it is over, no matter how hard one tries. In Praise of Canadian Painting in the Thirties is the only non-abstract work on the disc, and probably the most compelling ‚Äì it may be an advantage to familiarize yourself with the works of the painters in question (Paraskeva Clark, Louis Muhlstock and Charles Comfort). It is not a masterpiece, but I have to admit that Adaskin to some extent manages to reflect some of the characteristics of these painters‚Äô styles in his music.The least interesting work on the disc is the final Divertimento no. 5 for percussion and orchestra. It‚Äôs grey and dull; a few uninteresting melodic fragments and contours filled in with some drum bumps here, tam-tams there, and a drumroll or two without any discernible structure or goal. It‚Äôs precisely as bad as such a work could be, which is pretty terrible. The performances, though, are good and the recorded sound generally very good. The music ranges from one-star works (Divertimento no. 5) to almost-four-stars (the Painting suite), but given the production values and the overall value of the whole series I am reluctant to give it less than three stars. But three stars is, frankly, on the generous side.

Eduard Napravnik (1839-1916) was a Czech-Russian composer and a central figure in Russian musical life, and, as a composer, he premiered a number of the most famous Russian works of the nineteenth century ‚Äì particularly operas. His own compositions are largely forgotten, but included four symphonies and four operas (his piano concerto and Fantasy on Russian themes have, appropriately, been recorded for Hyperion‚Äôs Romantic Piano Concerto series, but that‚Äôs about it), of which Dubrovsky is the only one to (barely) survive at the fringes of the repertoire in Russia. The libretto was written by Modest Tchaikovsky after Pushkin‚Äôs novel, though it plays down the social commentary in favor of the love story.A great opera it surely isn‚Äôt, and the musical language is far from original ‚Äì Tchaikovsky and Verdi with more than a bit of vaudeville thrown in just about sums it up. There are a few good arias, but they are separated by long stretches of pretty tedious note-spinning ‚Äì and every time the music seems on the verge of going somewhere, Napravnik reverts to inconsequential Verdi-pastiche, effectively undermining any sense of momentum. Still, I suppose the highlights might be interesting enough to warrant a listen. Or they would have been, if the presentation had been better.The male singers aren‚Äôt too bad; Kozlovsky in the title role is very good, and most of the others are far from bad. Vervitskaya is too shrill, however, but that may be partially the recording‚Äôs fault. The Bolshoi Theatre chorus and orchestra under Vassily Nebolsin may be ok, but who can tell? Whereas the voices are generally decently captured by the recording, the orchestra surely isn‚Äôt; it‚Äôs reduced to faint, tinny background ruminations in a distant hall. You can forget about notes and a libretto, and to add insult to injury, on my copy four tracks on the second disc wouldn‚Äôt play at all ‚Äì not that I really cared too much at that point given the quality of the tracks that did play. I haven‚Äôt heard the other versions (or releases of this version), but even with a better presentation I suspect this one is primarily for the specialist. I still hope that some record companies would make parts of the huge Melodiya catalogue of forgotten Russian operas available, however (operas by Aleksandrov, Arensky, Ernesaks, Gulak-Artemovsky, Magomaev, Morozov, Muradeli, Shebalin, Vlasov & Fere, or Zhiganov, to mention a few), but the presentation really needs to be better than this.

Zygmunt Krauze (b. 1938) was part of what one might perhaps call the golden age of Polish modernism, and although he is less well known than, say, Penderecki and Gorecki, the works on this disc reveals a personal voice characterized by a feeling of excitement in exploring unique sonorities and textures. Despite the use of avant-garde techniques, Krauze‚Äôs music remains relatively approachable, even though Krauze ideas about composition might easily be characterized as "novel" ‚Äì it feels more as extending the expressive range of conventional structures and forms than a radical break.Aus aller Welt stammende for ten string instruments dates from 1973, and is an example of ‚Äúmusic about music‚Äù. The basis for the work is four folk-like melodies; each instrument plays the same melody, but they have complete freedom in choice of tempo, dynamics, expression and articulation, and the result is a ‚Äúsoundscape‚Äù (for lack of a better word) in which different interpretations and explorations of the basic tune is melded together ‚Äì according to the composer, in ‚Äúunitary music‚Äù like this ‚Äú[t]he beginning of each composition immediately exposes the entire range of sounds and during the piece nothing new is introduced. There will be no surprises. [...] This music creates the space for a different way of being perceived.‚Äù Well, I suppose some listeners may be a bit put off by the resulting lack of contrast or dramatic impetus, but I have to admit that I found the results often rather mesmerizing.Tableau Vivant (1982) for chamber orchestra is a ‚Äúpiece about silence, fear, anger and obsessiveness.‚Äù The fifteen performers are divided into two groups in a dialogue about and formed by what sounds most like a slow march-like pulse deconstructed in various ways. I have to admit that the musings struck me as a bit inconsequential ‚Äì perhaps I am missing something. The Symphonie Parisienne (1986) strikes me as more successful. The work is based on a single motif that is relentlessly repeated in different scoring, and with different intensity and modes of expression, but the result is far more satisfying than it might sound from that description.Quatuor pour la naissance (1985) was apparently written as a response to the birth of his son, and though the emotions expressed are definitely conflicting, the overall mood is one of optimism and hope ‚Äì indeed, Krauze is intent of bending those conflicting emotions into a unified, homogenous sound where the contrasts are removed. Well, there may be something to the notion that great art is founded on suffering rather than contentment, and I cannot say I was particularly taken with this work ‚Äì yes, in one sense the attempt to create this homogenous sound world serves to bring attention to the contrasts, and the result is very far from a homogenous sound world, but I couldn‚Äôt really get myself to work up much enthusiasm for those contrasts.It is, admittedly, a bit tricky to pass any judgment on the performances, but the strongest works here do indeed come across as compelling, and they are recorded in nice, spacious sound. Not the most captivating disc of contemporary music to have come my way perhaps, but this is definitely worth exploring.

The titles of these works suggest that Peter Benoit (1834-1901) was a romantic through-and-through, with a penchant for the atmospheric and fairy-tale-like. What you get, however, is a pretty generic tonal language inspired by Schumann and Weber, with little by way of originality and disappointingly little tone-painting. These two concertos date from 1865, and were apparently Benoit‚Äôs last large-scale instrumental works ‚Äì the rest of his career would be primarily devoted to oratorios and large-scale cantatas. In fact, Benoit didn‚Äôt call them concertos, but Symphonic Tales, and although they follow the usual three-movement concerto form, they have the narrative structures of symphonic poems and, in the case of the piano concerto, a detailed program.The piano concerto opens with a Ballade, structured around two primary themes, one tragic and one noble, though the music is relatively non-descript and certainly evokes none of the ‚Äúsilvery sheen‚Äù or ‚Äúsoaring up in majestic height‚Äù mentioned by the booklet. More importantly, the themes are hardly memorable, and although the music is (barely) eventful and colorful enough to sustain the listener‚Äôs attention it doesn‚Äôt exactly invite repeated listening. The second movement, The Song of the Bard, at least exhibits some of the yearning, lamenting nostalgia it is supposed to, and the Fantastic Hunt in the Night is rather enjoyable, though desperately lacking the drama, urgency and spectacle of, say, Franck‚Äôs Le Chasseur maudit.Romantic, large-scale flute concertos are a rarity, which should secure at least some interest in Benoit‚Äôs concerto. Once again, the movements have programmatic titles, though there is a less explicit program. The opening movement, Will-o‚Äô-the-Wisps, is once again built around two themes, a capricious and nervous one and a more reflective one, and is appealing enough. The Melancholie movement is anodyne and the finale resembles the opening movement, though is less interesting. If flautists are looking for a first-rate romantic concerto for their instrument, this is not it. As a coupling we get the overture to Benoit's comic opera Le roi des Aulnes (The King of the Alders), first premiered in 1859. It is a spirited work, but totally lacking any distinctive or memorable features.The performances sound good enough; the soloists are actually impressive, especially Gaby van Riet in the flute concerto, and they are well supported by the Royal Flanders Philharmonic Orchestra under Fr√©d√©ric Devreese ‚Äì the orchestra could perhaps have benefited from a bit more rehearsal time to smooth out some rough edges, but I‚Äôve enjoyed far worse performances than this. The sound is fine. If this style of music appeals, then I suppose you could do worse than give this disc a try, but it is a far cry from being a mandatory release.

Like so many French composers of his generation Henri Tomasi (1901-1971) seems to be doomed to be remembered for a handful of wind concertos, in particular a decent but unexceptional trumpet concerto. The Requiem pour la paix, dedicated to ‚Äúthe martyrs of the resistance movement and all those who have died for France‚Äù, was begun in 1944, during Nazi occupation, and finished the following year. Being disillusioned by the war and rejecting all religious faith, Tomasi put the work aside, and it remained in obscurity until 1996. Stylistically it is tonal, airy, melodic, lyrical and touching ‚Äì Tomasi‚Äôs models seem to have been Debussy and Ravel, and although the music is ‚ÄúFrench‚Äù-sounding, there is really not much of the jaunty neo-classicism found in the music of many of his contemporaries.It is not, perhaps, as hauntingly memorable as the far more famous Durufl√© Requiem, but it is an impressive and memorable work, containing plenty of good ideas, sensitively colored and held together by a couple of recurring motifs and gestures. The moods shift between the reflectively serene and the defiant, with all sorts of shades in between. It is all captured here in vibrant, deeply committed performances; the choral contributions from Choeur R√©gional Provence-Alpes-CÙte d‚ÄôAzur and Choeur D√©partemental des Alpes-Maritimes are generally good; the soloists at least serviceable and occasionally very good, and I have few complaints about the Orchestra Philharmonique de Marseille under Michel Piquemal. A little bit more warmth and vibrancy might not have gone amiss, but it really is a minor complaint.As for the couplings, the Fanfares liturgiques are much more interesting than the title might suggest, with some nicely pointed, noble and imaginative touches, while Etre ou ne pas √™tre is brooding and rather non-descript. Once again I have few complaints about the performances, and the sound is generally good. Good notes as well, and although this is hardly a disc to change the world, it is definitely worth recommending. It would be good to hear more of Tomasi‚Äôs works that weren‚Äôt wind concertos or wind chamber music, such as one or more of his operas.

Given the legacy of Ignacy Jan Paderewski as a pianist and politician (as well as being the subject of a particularly famous example in academic philosophy of language), you‚Äôd think it‚Äôd be natural for a Polish record company to cover his output as a composer; it might pick people‚Äôs interest given the name alone. Fortunately, Paderewski was a really good composer as well ‚Äì not hugely original, perhaps, but the music is inventive, colorful, sporting strong themes and a decent sense of development and orchestration. Manru is his only opera, and is, essentially, a dramatic one with fairy-tale elements and lots of opportunities to paint vivid, atmospheric mountainscapes and nights by lakes. There are traces of Polish folk elements, I suppose, and also some gypsy-style music (part of the story), and much of it is glorious and beautiful ‚Äì not always dramatically taut, but Paderewski could pull some dramatic scenes with effective climaxes when he wanted to. Stylistically late-romantic ‚Äì Wagner and Tchaikovsky seem to be important role models ‚Äì there are also elements here that, I think, foreshadows Szymanowski. Highlights are probably the duet between Ulana and Manru in Act II and, frankly, most of Act III.The very best music tends to go to the character Ulana ‚Äì who really is, despite the title, the main character ‚Äì sung her by Ewa Czermak. It‚Äôs a role that requires a lot of emotion, fire and drama, and Czermak copes admirably ‚Äì her voice has the necessary power and volatility ‚Äì so much so, in fact, that she tends to overshadow the Manru of Taras Ivaniv, who sounds strained when they‚Äôre together; otherwise, Ivaniv singing is compelling. The smaller roles are somewhat variable, but generally more than acceptable and often good.I have certainly no complaints at all about the performances from the Chorus and Orchestra of the Lower Silesian Opera in Wroc≈Çaw under the sympathetic and convincing direction of Ewa Michnik ‚Äì in fact, this really is excellent playing (as is the violin solos, vivaciously and fiercely dispatched by Stanislaw Czermak ‚Äì the booklet doesn‚Äôt mention whether there is any relation to the soprano). And it is all recorded in very good sound. A drawback that should be mentioned concerns the booklet ‚Äì though information is given in Polish and English, the libretto is given in Polish only (though there is a track-indexed synopsis in English). So, is it a forgotten masterpiece? Perhaps not, but it is surely a deeply rewarding experience, and although five stars might be on the generous side I do wish to thank everyone involved for making this one available.

Heinrich Kaspar Schmid (1874-1953) is one of a substantial number of late-romantic composer cpo has done an admirable job of digging out of virtually complete obscurity. Schmid was an important organizer and academic, and his compositions ‚Äì at least the ones represented here ‚Äì exhibits an admirably sense of the craft. Though dating primarily from the later part of his career, these works are stylistically conservative and contain few elements that would be out of place in, say, Brahms (no post-romantic, expressive hysteria here, to be sure). They are also inspired by German (in particular, apparently, Bavarian) folk music and overall relatively lightly textured; contrapuntal, but never densely so, and Schmid certainly had a modest gift for melody, though few of the themes are particularly memorable. If I have a complaint - and I guess I do - it is that the music is too ‚Äúnice‚Äù and ‚Äúacademic‚Äù (in the negative sense) and light; there are no chances taken, and accordingly not that much to remember by which to remember this music.The possible exception is the trio for clarinet, viola and piano op. 114. It is a very compelling work, and the opening movement of the trio is the only movement on the disc that contains any real drama. It is followed by a splendid, almost Mendelssohnian, mystic, brief scherzo and a lovely if somewhat inconsequential slow movement. The finale is effective enough if essentially light music. ‚ÄúLight and charming‚Äù is an apt characterization also of the flute sonata op. 106; no profundity, in other words, but there is an appealing playfulness and variety of texture that nevertheless make it an attractive work overall.The two short works, an Allegretto for clarinet and piano and a Capriccio for flute and piano (both from an op. 34 set) contain little to write home about and the viola sonata op. 111 is, I have (and hate) to admit, a disappointment. Once again, Schmid is good at working with textures, but the work as a whole comes across as a meandering, rambling rant about nothing with some decently colorful metaphors thrown in. At least it is idiomatically written for the instrument ‚Äì sufficiently tailored to the specific sonorities of the viola to never sound like a transposed violin or cello sonata ‚Äì but that isn‚Äôt quite enough.Nor am I wholly satisfied by the performance; Nils M√∂nkemeyer‚Äôs playing is expressive and variegated enough, but intonation isn‚Äôt always spot-on, neither in the sonata nor in the trio. On the other hand, I might perhaps have wished for some more expressive nuances in Johannes Zurl‚Äôs clarinet playing (though Schmid doesn‚Äôt really encourage that, it seems). Pirmin Grehl‚Äôs flute parts are pretty good, on the other hand, and I don‚Äôt have any specific complaints about Nicholas Rimmer‚Äôs piano playing ‚Äì the piano is relegated to a distinctively supportive role in this music anyways. In short, this is a modestly interesting disc of some moderately interesting music; not enough to merit a full-scale revival, but I wouldn‚Äôt mind hearing Schmid‚Äôs d minor Symphony, apparently his most celebrated work.

These two symphonies by Rudolph Simonsen (1889-1947) have received some rather harsh criticism from certain quarters, so I wish to make a bit of a case for them. They are not forgotten masterpieces, by any means, but they are still overall rather interesting works that should appeal at least to those with a sense of adventure and an interest in the transitional period between late-romanticism and modernism. That said, the Overture in g minor that opens the program is probably unsalvageable ‚Äì it is a lengthy piece of generic Wagnerisms with little content, development or interest. But the symphonies are a different matter.It is, though, a bit unfortunate that the booklet note tries to compare them to Nielsen‚Äôs works from the same period ‚Äì there isn‚Äôt much of Nielsen here (though the first symphony may be inspired on an abstract level by Nielsen‚Äôs symphonies); on the other hand, I think I note some interesting and intriguing connections to the music of Rued Langgaard ‚Äì if Simonsen‚Äôs music fails to exhibit the same level of imagination and ear for sonorities as Langgaard, at least he seems to have something of the same focus; occasionally at the expense of continuity and narrative arches, but the colors and textures of Simonsen‚Äôs gnarly, gritty moving blocks of sound are fascinating enough in themselves, and Simonsen piles them on top of each other to achieve some relatively powerful climaxes, even if a convincing narrative thread isn't always sustained.The first symphony, ‚ÄúZion‚Äù, supposedly depicts the Jewish people‚Äôs struggles on their way to the promised land. The opening movement, ‚ÄúThe Struggle against Slavery‚Äù, is definitely filled with conflict and struggle, and is pretty effective as such. Unfortunately, the long Covenant movement ‚Äì at 19 minutes and divided into clearly delineated sections almost a symphony in itself ‚Äì strikes me as unsuccessful; it is a pretty glum affair (though the mood shifts to a lighter, more peaceful one about midway through) and, frankly, a pretty tedious one. What primarily makes the work worth hearing is the final movement, however: an effective, well-constructed Allegro con brio that builds up to a blazing conclusion that would probably have been more effective if the symphony as a whole had been stronger. Not a bad work, then, but the second movement could have needed some serious trimming.The second symphony, ‚ÄúHellas‚Äù, won a bronze medal at the 1928 Olympic Game (there were no gold or silver medals awarded) ‚Äì yes, that was back in days when various artistic genres were also part of the Olympics. It is a well-constructed work overall, though the themes are not particularly memorable (there are plenty of them, but I am not sure that makes up for it). Though lighter in spirit than the first, it often sounds a bit as if Simonsen was attempting to create a dramatic flow but succeeded only in building up pressure without any release. Oh, well, it is actually an interesting and enjoyable work nonetheless; the grinding, tempestuous first movement perhaps in particular.S√∏nderjylland's Symphony Orchestra at least gives all the works as good of a run for their money as one could have wished for under Israel Yinon ‚Äì any faults lie surely not with the performances. The sound quality is good as well and the liner notes mostly informative. Not a must-have, then, but I am glad to have heard these symphonies, and would probably extend a modest recommendation to anyone interested in music of the period with a sense of adventure.

One can perhaps imagine what challenges a woman composer like Louise Farrenc (1804-1875) must have faced as a professional composer of serious, large scale orchestral and chamber works in the Romantic era France, but Farrenc was, in fact, pretty successful. She was a recognized leading piano professor at the Paris Conservatoire, and her works, including her symphonies and large-scale chamber works, were performed and well received - she didn't write an opera, though, which in France of the time seems to have guaranteed being relegated to the second rank, regardless of the merits of the music itself. The two symphonies here are soundly crafted works with plenty of good ideas. Now, in her time Beethoven dominated what existed of a French symphonic scene, and Farrenc‚Äôs works are heavily indebted to Beethoven, as well as Haydn and Mozart, though there are romantic touches as well ‚Äì some passages remind me a little of Weber, others bear at least hints of an individual stamp.Both works are laid out in a similar manner. The outer movements are dramatic, bold and tempestuous ‚Äì very much reminiscent of Beethoven in style and execution, yet the thematic material is romantic - and extremely compelling.
