I find her less convincing in the slow movements; these are lyrical and often pretty, but a bit square and ‚Äì it seems to me ‚Äì uninspired; even the good ideas in the slow movement of the third symphony seem to me to be developed without much enthusiasm: I cannot help feeling, at least on occasion, that Farrenc put those movements there because she had to and would much rather get on with the action. As for the third movements, the Haydnesque, classical Minuetto in the first symphony is fine enough, but not as inspired as the sprightly, spirited, romantic scherzo of the third.They are both overall excellent works, though (my slight misgivings about the slow movements should be read as ‚Äúin comparison to the faster movements‚Äù ‚Äì they are still far above the average for composers of the period), and deserves more exposure than they have thus far been given. They are also really excellently performed by the North German Radio Symphony, Hannover under Johannes Goritzki ‚Äì alert, colorful, vigorous and with clear lines ‚Äì and although the recorded sound is a bit dull it is really not an impediment. Strongly recommended.

I had mixed hopes for this release, the final installment in Chandos‚Äôs series of Rubbra symphonies. Having been thoroughly impressed by nos. 2 and 6, and nos. 3 and 7, I found the disc containing nos. 4, 10 and 11 slightly tougher, no. 9 a fatally flawed near-masterpiece (yes ‚Äì Rubbra made one desperately wrong decision that almost ruined the whole work by giving the climax to a narrator), and no. 1 a bit of a disappointment. Well, whatever fears I might have had were quickly put to shame. The fifth and eighth symphonies are absolute masterpieces, among the truly great works of the twentieth century, and this is a magnificent release ‚Äì probably the one I would recommend as a starting point for anyone thus far unacquainted with this fabulous composer.Now, Rubbra‚Äôs symphonies are surely not about surface spectacle and don‚Äôt really give up their goods that easily. They are understated, to a large extent distanced and reflective, and don‚Äôt really contain much by way of drama in the traditional sense. But Rubbra was a masterly musical architect and his melodies, though perhaps not (usually) instantly memorable, are often haunting and tend to flow beautifully toward understated but nevertheless powerful climaxes. It is also the kind of music that requires first-rate performances and a conductor with a clear vision and deep understanding. Fortunately, that‚Äôs precisely what it gets in this series, and as on previous volumes the playing here is little short of amazing.The eighth symphony is apparently sometimes viewed as a somewhat problematic work. It is certainly introverted, poetic and ‚Äúspiritual‚Äù (if that‚Äôs an apt characterization of music at all) ‚Äì indeed, it was dedicated to Teilhard de Chardin. Cast in three movements, the outer movements are generally mellow ‚Äì shimmering and beautiful though not without incident ‚Äì and enclose a superb, dance-like though still reflective central Allegretto con brio. The opening movement is among the best the composer ever wrote (though it requires some concentration on the part of the listener) whereas the final lento is stunningly beautiful ‚Äì even transcendent. A small drawback, perhaps, is that its climactic theme is the sunrise theme from Janacek‚Äôs Cunning Little Vixen. No matter ‚Äì it is magnificently employed for very different purposes here.The fifth is the composer‚Äôs best known work and for good reason ‚Äì though perhaps not ultimately superior to his other symphonies (though it is absolutely marvelous) it is probably his most user-friendly work. The outer movements, for instance, are more obviously dramatic than in his other works, though the structure at least in each individual movement is as clean and compelling as ever; in addition, the finale is less ambiguously optimistic than in his other symphonies (perhaps except the eighth, though here the optimism is of a more reflective kind). The second movement is ebullient, spirited and buoyant (and almost Sibelian), whereas the slow movement is pensive and dark ‚Äì arguably the weak link in this symphony but still powerful stuff.In between we get an Ode to the Queen, a cycle of three songs composed for the Coronation year. It is much more extrovert and joyous than most of the composer‚Äôs works, but does overall not hold a candle to the symphonies in terms of quality ‚Äì as such it feels quite out of place here. But no matter; it is excellently done and I have few complaints about Susan Bickley‚Äôs singing (yes, it‚Äôs hard to hear precisely what she‚Äôs singing, but if you read the texts you realize that you don‚Äôt really want to know). And the two surrounding masterpieces simply must be heard. Very strongly recommended.

Howard Ferguson (1908-1999) may have been one of the most important composers to come out of Northern Ireland, but his music isn‚Äôt particularly well known. Ferguson‚Äôs output wasn‚Äôt large, and he stopped composing altogether in the late 50s, ostensibly because he felt like he was starting to repeat himself, but surely also because his unapologetically tuneful, atmospheric, haunting music was rather far out of line with the prevailing trends. Stylistically Ferguson‚Äôs own work belongs to the sound world of post-romanticism; there are touches of Vaughan Williams, to be sure, and passages reminiscent of the music of Herbert Howells or his friend Gerald Finzi. While not hugely original, it is finely constructed and imaginative, with enough personal touches to give it an identifiable, individual voice.I don‚Äôt think the decision to start the program on this disc with the Overture for an Occasion was the best possible idea ‚Äì it is without doubt the weakest work here, and is really a pretty anodyne and unmemorable piece of bluster and pomp (the occasion was the coronation of Queen Elizabeth). The Partita is an earlier but better work, characterized by a fine balance between evocative, wistful romanticism and classical elegance. That said, I do think the movements all tend to go on for just a little bit longer than the material warrants ‚Äì at a total of 25 minutes a bit more substance would have been welcome. The Two ballads op.1 for baritone and orchestra are often haunting and impressively sensitively scored for a composer in his early twenties, but hardly masterpieces.But none of my criticisms of the works mentioned matter in the grand scale of things. The main work here is Ferguson‚Äôs large-scale setting of the late-medieval poem The Dream of the Rook for soprano, chorus and orchestra ‚Äì his last completed work and, I think, at least arguably a genuine masterpiece. It is a wonderfully atmospheric, warmly scored work in the English choral tradition ‚Äì Howells, Vaughan Williams and Finzi spring to mind ‚Äì but so full of magical touches that it surpasses most other works in that tradition. Captivating throughout, it rises to an absolutely glorious climactic chorus (‚ÄúBut the Lord arose‚Äù), and though most of the work is somewhat restrained there is not a passage that is less than deeply impressive.Everything is given committed performances and the sound is spectacular. Although not all the music here is first-rate, given the quality of the Dream of the Rood I cannot justify giving the disc anything less than five stars. Strongly recommended.

This disc was recorded as a centenary tribute to Sir Thomas Armstrong (1898-1994), a distinguished academic and Principal of London‚Äôs Royal Academy of Music, and that‚Äôs what it sounds like. What I mean is that although the performances sound generally well-prepared and idiomatic, the music is primarily of specialist interest, perhaps primarily to the many whose lives seem to have been touched by Thomas Armstrong. That is not to say that the music is bad, at least not in general, but there are definitely no revelations here.The earliest work, A passer-by, is actually rather fine. Subtitled ‚ÄúA Rhapsody for baritone solo, chorus and orchestra‚Äù, this is a 14-minute setting of Robert Bridge‚Äôs poem from 1922, rather anonymous in style but exhibiting some nice Delian touches that will probably appeal to many of those who like British music from the period. Much the same can be said for the closing work, Friends departed, from 1928 ‚Äì it is more personal in style, to be sure, and more tautly constructed, but still a somewhat anonymous work with some nice touches.The rest is less interesting. The six part-songs are, I suppose, decent enough if you like this kind of thing, but there is nothing memorable about them either, and the London Philharmonic Choir sounds somewhat uninspired (which is understandable). The little Sinfonietta is eminently forgettable, but where things really go bad is in brief the piano quintet, which must surely contain one of the most badly conceived openings in the chamber music literature (seriously), and continues with some meandering string pads accompanied by an ‚Ä¶ ululating, grating piano part. It is not helped by the rather poor balance between instruments exhibited here, but nothing would really have helped this one. It is fortunately short.Apart from some uncertainties and moments of uninspired singing from the chorus the performances are good and the sound is generally fine (apart from the balance in the piano quintet). In sum, then, the disc is worth hearing for A passer-by and Friends departed, which ‚Äì despite lacking any truly individual voice ‚Äì are atmospheric and beautiful enough. The rest was really not necessary.

Aleksander Kopylov (1854-1911) is not among the composers usually mentioned among the Russian Silver Age of composers, and perhaps his music doesn‚Äôt quite exhibit the imagination, color and melodic memorability of Glazunov or Liadov, but I think I dare guarantee that if you like the music of those composers you‚Äôll enjoy this one. Yes, stylistically the music belongs to the school of the composers mentioned and owes a lot to the Mighty Five, in particular Borodin, but is none the worse for that.The relatively ambitious Symphony in c minor is a product of the patronage of Mitrofan Belyayev and was dedicated to Liadov. It opens, rather surprisingly, with a 20-minute Andante movement that contains enough incident and good ideas to sustain its length, even if the structure is perhaps not ideally taut ‚Äì and if the orchestration isn‚Äôt as ingenious as that of Rimsky-Korsakov, Kopylov clearly knew a trick or two. The comparatively very brief Scherzo movement is excellent, though the following, second andante movement perhaps a bit too uneventful and untroubled ‚Äì and the main theme not sufficiently distinctive ‚Äì for its 11 minutes, but the majestic, glittering finale is impressive enough. All in all, perhaps not quite a first-rate symphony, but a very enjoyable one and certainly worth hearing.The two shorter works are great fun. The Scherzo is dance-like and vivacious with some good ideas and tunes, whereas the Overture is ‚Äì though rather typical of the time and tradition ‚Äì atmospheric and enjoyable. Everything is played with spirit and panache, and the recording is good. A very worthwhile addition to the catalogue, then, guaranteed to please ‚Äì as mentioned ‚Äì anyone who likes the music of the Russian Silver Age. Apparently Kopylov was, in his time, particularly recognized for his chamber music, especially his four string quartets, which it would be interesting to hear. Or perhaps someone would have a look at, say, the Ukrainian Symphony by Mykhailo Kalachevsky (once recorded on LP by Melodiya) or the music of Georgi Conus (brother of the Julius Conus of the relatively famous violin concerto).

The ASV cycle of Rimsky-Korsakov orchestral works provides a nice survey, and the performances are certainly colorful and dramatic (sometimes borderline breathless) even if they may lack the last touch of both finesse and magic (J√§rvi, Svetlanov and Ansermet, say, are probably preferable in the end, though less comprehensive). In any case, this ‚Äì at least the best of them ‚Äì are works that anyone with even a moderate interest in colorful, atmospheric, romantic music need to know, and the ASV performances, divided between Yondani Butt and Loris Tjeknavorian do the music justice.The disc at hand, with the Philharmonia Orchestra conducted by Yondani Butt, opens with the relatively familiar overture to The Tsar‚Äôs Bride, a splendidly invigorating curtain raiser, though I suppose Gergiev‚Äôs performance as part of the eminently worthwhile complete opera is a tad more exhilarating than this one. As for the Fantasia on Serbian Themes, this is an early work and is somewhat more loosely structured than Rimsky‚Äôs later works ‚Äì yet the atmosphere is certainly there, and the work as a whole is a memorable experience.The first symphony is also a (very) early work (though it was later revised), and is hardly a masterpiece. Stylistically it sounds like a very Russian-nationalistic version of Schumann, and though the thematic material is perhaps not the strongest it does have plenty of character. The performance here is also very good, especially in the best movement, the finale, which really comes to life under the baton of Yondani Butt ‚Äì the ending is truly fiery. But whatever its qualities the first symphony is nothing compared to the second. Rimsky-Korsakov‚Äôs second symphony, Antar, might be a bit more of a symphonic suite than a symphony in character, but it really is, in my mind, one of the greatest symphonic works ever written; its glorious themes really sound like nothing else, and they‚Äôre developed with such magic and imagination that you will (or at least I am) be utterly captivated from the first second to the last. And it really is a one-off ‚Äì nothing else in Rimsky‚Äôs output, nor in anyone else‚Äôs, really sounds anything like that second symphony. That said, I think there is a bit more variety, a bit more magic, to the work than is captured by the performance at hand, despite plenty of color and atmosphere; sometimes I think Butt pushes it just a bit too hard, with the result that the music becomes just a bit breathless.The sound is large but clear and not overly reverberant. Though perhaps not a first choice in the second symphony (albeit arguably in the first), this is an overall very fine disc, well worth acquiring ‚Äì the competition is strong in the main works, but the Serbian Fantasia is at least a very worthwhile rarity that might make this a tempting acquisition even if you need at least to hear some of the alternatives mentioned above in the second symphony as well.

Harald Genzmer (1909-2007) is actually pretty well-represented on disc, though those discs might be rather difficult to get hold of at a reasonable prize, and the disc at hand is, I admit, my first and only exposure to his music. And though the music is hardly revolutionary it did make me want to hear more. According to himself, his music ‚Äúshould appeal to performers by being practicable and to listeners by being intelligible,‚Äù which it certainly is, and his declared influences are Rudi Stephan, Richard Strauss and Max Reger. The most obvious influence, however, is Hindemith, and although he lived and worked through most of the major developments of the 20th century, he stuck with his ideals.The music is generally melodic (though not afraid of dissonance) and polyphonic in the manner of Hindemith, yet ‚Äì despite the obvious influence ‚Äì you‚Äôd never mistake Genzmer‚Äôs music for that of the older composer; Genzmer‚Äôs melodic material, his textures and atmospheres are his own, sometimes rooted in German folk music, sometimes ‚Äì perhaps surprisingly ‚Äì suggesting the open-air, blue-sky soundscapes of Carl Nielsen. British commentators sometimes suggest Malcolm Arnold as a comparison, and although Genzmer‚Äôs music doesn‚Äôt really sound anything like Arnold‚Äôs, I sort of see why one might be struck by the comparison, especially with regard to the shifts between darkness and playfulness (though with less sarcasm) in Genzmer‚Äôs music.The 1954 flute concerto is perhaps the work where the Nielsen associations are the strongest. It is a playful, quirky work, though the finale is quite aggressive, at least until the mischievous wink at the end. Andrea Lieberknecht gives a delightful performance of the solo part. Oliver Triendl‚Äôs playing of the second piano concertino with strings (1963) comes across as perhaps slightly more workmanlike, but that might be because the content is slightly more ‚Ä¶ dour, for lack of a better word ‚Äì it is still an interesting and ultimately rewarding work. The viola concerto from 1968 is more restrained and inward-looking, but contains its share of (well-planned) blooming outbursts and small, humorous anecdotes. Lars Anders Tomter gives a very fine rendition of the solo part. Throughout the Rundfunk-Sinfonieorchester Saarbr√ºcken with Werner Andreas Albert provides solid though somewhat unexceptional support and the sound is, if a little gray, fine enough. All in all a rewarding if not ultimately revelatory release, recommended to any fan of tonal 20th century music, especially fans of Hindemith (though, again, Genzmer‚Äôs style is distinctive enough never to sound derivative).

Faur√©‚Äôs second opera, P√©n√©lope (yes, he wrote two, though Prom√©th√©e is hardly ever heard and doesn‚Äôt seem to have received a complete recording) is a late work (1913), but although his late chamber music has established themselves pretty firmly in the repertoire, P√©n√©lope has not fared so well, despite being described by e.g. Copland as one of the best operas written since Wagner. One of the reasons may be that the music is, overall, ‚Äúdistinctly non-theatrical‚Äù ‚Äì indeed, the musical style is distinctly written in the flowing, ever-changing and dreamy style of his late chamber works ‚Äì no big arias or easy excerpts here ‚Äì and Faur√© seems to have deliberately avoided much in terms of stage action until the very end (a pity, then, that the libretto is otherwise rather uninteresting). That said, the work does employ leitmotifs, and the two main roles may perhaps require something of a Wagnerian quality ‚Äì apart from that, the music ha preciously little to do with Wagner. Oh, well ‚Äì it is a beautiful, powerful score, and if it is hard to imagine it working very well on stage that matters little when listening to an audio-only set like this.The warmly lyrical rather than dramatic music requires a bit expressive shading and tenderness from the singers, and Jessye Norman in the title role succeeds marvelously, with radiant, warm singing that is especially impressive in the upper register. Equally impressive, however, is her expressive range and thoughtful characterization - some has said that she's a bit emotionally distant but if that's so, isn't that a very valid interpretation of the character? Alain Vanzo is perhaps less convincing in terms of convincing characterization, but at least his singing is beautiful. As a matter of fact, it is hard to find a weak link in the cast (at least among the more major characters). The orchestral playing is first-rate as well, and although the sound is a bit cavernous it certainly does little to ruin the experience. Which is, of course, fortunate given the absence of much serious competition in this work. Strongly recommended.

Joseph Marx‚Äôs style remained thoroughly committed to romanticism long after it went out of fashion, but although his style is conservative and romantic it really sounds like no one else‚Äôs. There is certainly a bit of Reger in it, but also arguably some Italian influences (Martucci and Respighi, though none of the relatively early works on this disc are likely to have been actually influenced by the latter composer). The music is melodic, and if I were to give a brief description of Marx‚Äôs sound world ‚Äì both in the works here and elsewhere ‚Äì his themes and melodic material seem to be in the style of typical (yet often memorable) salon music; but what he does with that material has surely nothing to do with salon music; rather, he puts it to service in convincing large-scale structures and the results are, somehow, as passionate, powerful and profound and as far removed from ‚Äúlight music‚Äù as the music of Brahms or Mahler. You wouldn‚Äôt think it‚Äôd work, but it does.The three works for piano quartet here were all written in 1911 and are all single-movement works; large-scale, ambitious and symphonic in nature if not actually in form (the sonata-form reminiscences are at least hard to discern). The opening Rhapsody is, at 28 minutes, arguably on the long side, but so filled with incident and glorious melodic ideas that I, for one, won‚Äôt complain. It is also, if not exactly formally taut, at least a structurally convincing work in four relatively clearly separate sections. The 17-minute Scherzo is perhaps somewhat less memorable but still a major work well worth investigating for any fan of late-romantic chamber music ‚Äì it is invigorating, fresh and sunny but not without depth.The masterpiece, however, is the Ballade, which at 17‚Äô32 doesn‚Äôt feel a moment too long. It opens with a lengthy theme in the solo cello (reminiscent, I think, of Bach‚Äôs cello suites, which the composer may or may not have known), which launches an expansive fugue with plenty of textural variation and plays with lights and shadows. It really is a wonderful work with touches of impressionism and some truly memorable themes. As a first approximation, one may perhaps imagine a more transparently textured version of Reger, but the thematic material is really nothing like Reger's.In short, this is splendid music, with the best (in particular the Ballade) being at least almost worthy of the designation ‚Äúlost masterpiece‚Äù. The performances are convincing if perhaps lacking the last touch of brilliance and the sound is good. The presentation is good as well, and overall I would rate this as something of a major discovery. Strongly recommended.

Tilo Medek (1940-2006) belonged, at least earlier in his career, to what one might perhaps call the ‚Äúlast generation of tonal composer‚Äù ‚Äì meaning that, like the very different musical languages of, say, Treibmann or Sallinen, Medek‚Äôs music is rooted in tonality, but there is nothing ‚Äúneo‚Äù about the language, and it is not really derivative or unoriginal either; rather, the music stands on (rather than breaks with) and develops further the ideas of composers like Hindemith, Shostakovich or Stravinsky. Thus, in his ambitious, four-movement cello concerto (1978) you can hear plenty of things that will remind you of Hindemith, Stravinsky and Mahler, though Medek also seems to be very much aware of the allusions and associations, playing around with them, using them to underline main lines of argument, and taking the associations in unusual directions.That said, the cello concerto is no mere game, but a substantial and very worthwhile addition to the repertoire. The four movements are equipped with literary titles and do sound as if they (as the booklet also points out) are poised between absolute music and program music. Yes, the music is abstract, but there is a clear narrative structure to the music and the conversations between the soloists and various orchestral instruments, all painted on a large canvas that do present you with a unified, clearly structured point. Is it a great work? Well, though the composer manages to keep it together, and although almost every twist and idea is interesting, one does feel that the work would have benefited from some more self-control; it is, in the final verdict, longer than the material can justify.The two remaining works are, I think, among the strongest contributions to the solo cello repertoire I have heard in a while. Stele is a memorial for Bernd Alois Zimmermann and seems on the surface to be written in a slightly less compromising musical language; yet it is a deeply captivating work in which the music both manages to flow freely and ingeniously while also conveying a sense of depth and struggle. Schattenspiele consists of five short, remarkable pieces that do, indeed, suggest an intricate play with shadows and echoes of the music just presented.The cello soloist, Guido Schiefen, is superb in those solo pieces. He is also good in the solo part of the concerto, where the live recording gives the playing an extra dimension of danger and energy, I suppose. The problem is that there are some passages where the performances seem on the verge of falling together ‚Äì particularly in the playing of the Royal Philharmonic Orchestra under Israel Yinon; for the most part they acquit themselves very well, but the music sounds like it sometimes proved a tough challenge and occasionally too much of a challenge. Oh well, this is overall very good performances of some fascinating music, well worth investigating.

CPO has certainly done the music of Felix Weingartner a service, and the present disc concludes their cycle of his symphonies with the ambitious, choral seventh, completed in 1942, the year of the composer's death. Those who know any of the previous releases in the series know what to expect ‚Äì Weingartner‚Äôs sound world is that of a polished, post-Wagnerian late-romanticism without any sharp edges; warm, superbly scored and a bit anonymous. Clearly inspired by Beethoven‚Äôs ninth ‚Äì almost too obviously so at times ‚Äì the seventh symphony is, unfortunately, far from Weingartner‚Äôs best; if you follow this series you‚Äôll probably want it, but this is, honestly, pretty thin gruel, and newcomers are advised to start with an earlier work, perhaps preferably the second.The opening movement starts off in a rather Brucknerian vein, which then gives way to a fugato that sounds like it was fun to write but which makes for a less rewarding listening experience. While the first movement is instrumental, the second sets a poem by Friedrich Hebbel ‚Äì Weingartner doesn‚Äôt really seem to care whether the music reflects the meaning of the poem, however, and frankly: Though Weingartner was very skilled orchestrator, writing for voices seems to find him a bit at loss. The instrumental scherzo sounds overall decent, though, and the trio melody is beautiful.The meat of the work, though, is the finale, which lasts more than half an hour. How, you may ask, can anyone but a Bruckner or perhaps a Mahler create a coherent symphonic movement of that length? Well, that‚Äôs the rub. Weingartner certainly doesn‚Äôt, and there is plenty of meandering going on ‚Äì in particular, he spends an awful lot of time in moving between the main elements. Even his choice of text is strange ‚Äì there are two poems, one by Carmen Studen (his wife) and the other by H√∂lderlin, and I, for one, have no idea what the connection may be. At least the ending, when it comes, is very effective with its return to the opening of the first movement, bringing the whole thing to a rather glorious culmination.You may have come to expect exemplary performances by the Basel Symphony Orchestra under Marko Letonja ‚Äì they have certainly done well for themselves in the earlier issues in this series. Here, however, lack of preparation shines through, and in particular the scherzo movement contains some rough and tentative passages. The singers are somewhat variable as well ‚Äì though Rolf Romei and Maya Boog deliver plenty of fine singing in the finale (though also here they are a bit variable), the soloists seem disinterested in the second movement ‚Äì perhaps a result of the clumsiness of the vocal writing. The choir is no more than adequate, though the recording, at least, is good. A curate‚Äôs egg ‚Äì primarily for the specialist.

Wow! Those dedicated crate diggers at Soundway have really outdone themselves with this excellent collection of music from Colombia. Even if you have any of the excellent compilations of cumbia music from Colombia's renowned Disco Fuentes label, the music on this CD will be a very pleasant and welcome addition to your collection.The main style featured on this CD is called Champeta, described in the liner notes as  "a re-invention of afro music in Colombia, mixed with Caribbean psychedelia, afro roots and elements of cumbia and other styles native to the Caribbean coast." There has long been an African influence in the music of Colombia, thanks in part to the slave trade the came to that country's coast 500 years ago. In addition to that, during the 1970s music from the Congo, Kenya, and South African became very popular in Colombia, further contributing to the melting pot of sounds.The result is an infectious and lively blend of rhythms and vivacious singing. These musicians and singers are holding nothing back! Listen to this CD a few times and I swear you will be singing "Palenque, Palenque!" at the top of your lungs ... and maybe doing a dance on the counter top too. Honestly,  this is extremely additive music, the sort of stuff that can Iiven up any party and bring a big smile to your face, even if you don't understand the lyrics.This CD comes with a 36-page booklet that includes a very fascinating history of Champeta and Colombian music from this era written by Lucas Silva. The track listings include songwriter credits, original issue date and original album name, plus song times. Another outstanding compilation from Soundway. Dig in and have a party!

I grew up during the "golden age" of Southern Rock in the 1970s, and I still love listening to groups such as the Marshall Tucker Band, the Outlaws, Wet Willie, Atlanta Rhythm Section, Lynyrd Skynyrd, and many others. Great music that hasn't lost any of its vitality. But for some reason, I missed out on Cowboy during those years .Granted, they only released two albums in the early '70s, but I'm still puzzled why I never heard them until now. Well, this was a belated discovery, but a very welcome one. Add this album, and the other Cowboy release "5'll Getcha Ten" the ranks of classic southern rock records.Actually, the sound of this album isn't so much rock, but more country and folk. Soothing acoustic guitar playing and ringing harmonies are the hallmarks of Tommy Talton and Scott Boyer, the two leaders of Cowboy. If I had to compare them to anyone of that era, I'd say their sound was closer to that of a band like Poco. More on the mellow side, but pleasingly so.This CD reissue comes with a 12-page booklet that includes an essay about the band and these recordings written by Scott Schinder, as well as lyrics to all of the songs. The only thing missing is the song times. That slight aside, this is a fabulous album, one of those "growers" that will hook you in the end!

I bought the two other compilations of songs the Dave Hamilton produced, also reissued by BGP, and I totally loved them. Hamilton was a VERY prolific writer and producer, but never got the props or publicity that his fantastic music deserved. As the back cover says, "In Dave Hamilton's studio in Detroit the '70s arrived with a funky beat and a sense of experimentation. The results are a wild mixture of lo-fi funk and soul."As I write this, there is one other review posted on this page, giving this CD only 1 star, citing the "hideous" sound of the remastering. I realize that some people are pickier about sound quality and that not everyone hears things the same way, and perhaps I have a higher tolerance for "lo-fi" recordings, but I don't find anything on this collection annoying or difficult to listen to whatsoever. I think giving this outstanding collection of music only 1 star is the real travesty.But I digress. There are plenty of rare and obscure soul treats on this generous 22-track CD. Amazon's main product review, and the liner notes, city artists such as Curtis Mayfield, the Temptations, and Funkadelic as having influenced some of these songs. I'd also add the Meters, Isaac Hayes, and female singers such as Bettye LaVette and Candi Staton in some cases too. Some of the tracks here are instrumentals, or vocal versions of songs that WERE instrumentals on the previous Dave Hamilton collections. From what the liner notes say, Hamilton's studio was "open at all times" and he recorded a "vast quantity" of instrumentals, some of which were created as backing tracks. But you can count on one thing: all of these tracks, whether instrumental or with vocals, have an infectious, vibrant, and funky edge.One of Hamilton's biggest discoveries was O.C. Tolbert (also the subject of a separate CD collection by Kent, "Black Diamond" that is well worth seeking out), and his has two wonderful songs on this CD, including one track, "Love Bandit," that was recently discovered after having been mis-labeled as being by another singer. Another highlight on this CD is the funky anti-drug tune "You Fool You" by Prophet & His Disciples. Actually, that song takes up two tracks as a Part 1 and a Part 2. Then there is the Bolton Brothers, the Barrino Brothers, Little Ann, Chico & Buddy, another version of Billy Garner's "Brand New Girl" and so much more. Really, I can't recommend this, as well as the other Dave Hamilton collections, highly enough. This may be "messy" and "lo-fi" but it's got funk and feel and good vibes galore. For me, that's what really counts.This CD comes with a 12-page booklet with liner notes by Dean Rudland and some Black & White photos of Hamilton and a few of the recording artists. Fans of late 1960s and early 1970s soul music will find a lot of wonderful discoveries here.

This 1975 album still holds up as one of the very best ones that Robert Palmer recorded, but it doesn't seem to get the praise it deserves, sandwiched between his amazing debut solo effort, "Sneaking Sally Through the Alley" and his more popular MTV-hyped albums and singles in the 1980s.Palmer does a superb job of covering songs by Toots & the Maytals (the title track), the Lowell George/Little Feat gem "Trouble", and Allen Toussaint's "River Boat." But perhaps the best material on here are Palmer originals such as "Give Me an Inch", "Back in My Arms", and "Fine Time." Honestly, not a dud in the bunch. This is terrific album from start to finish.And how 'bout those talented backing musicians? Who are they? Well, that brings up my next point. The only reason I'm deducting this a star is the almost total lack of information and liner notes on this Island CD reissue. This is one of those cheap versions with no booklet or details about the recordings, so lacking in info that might as well be a CD-R. The fact that all of the members of Little Feat, including Lowell George, played on this album is not even mentioned. A shameful omission to an otherwise splendid recording. At least Amazon is selling this for a very low price.

I've only recently discovered the music of jazz organist Charles Earland, but I'm hooked! Almost on a whim I tried "Black Talk!" and totally loved its addictive soul-jazz grooves. That led to getting "Intensity" and then his live album. Once again, very hot stuff. They don't call him "The Mighty Burner" for nothing! Then I saw this 1974 album with Freddie Hubbard and Joe Henderson, two jazz legends in their own right, and I just had to get it CD too. And I'm happy I did; this is another keeper!As you tell by the other glowing reviews, this is indeed a fantastic album, but one where Earland shares the spotlight with his horn-playing buddies. In fact, listening to much of this album, you'd be hard-pressed to call it a Charles Earland solo album with so much great horn playing, not only Joe Henderson on tenor sax and Freddie Hubbard on trumpet and flugelhorn, but another jazz vet, Eddie Henderson, pops up to play trumpet on four tracks. But rest assured that Earland is still playing up a storm on organ, particularly on "Warp Factor 9", "Van Jay" and the album's stunning closing song, "Never Ending Melody." I'm a big fan of jazz organ and I think Earland was one of the most underrated masters of the instrument, but man, you gotta love the horns on this album too, and the way they mix with Earland's organ and the rhythm section is frequently spectacular. This is total jazz paradise!While Earland doesn't hog the show, it remains his album because he wrote almost all of the songs. Except for an excellent version of Hubbard's classic "Red Clay" and a cool Joe Henderson song, "No Me Esqueca," the rest of the songs were written by Earland. Yes, he's also an underrated songwriter too. If you're a fan of any of these master musicians --- and let's not forget the amazing Harvey Mason on drums too --- you need to check out this masterful album.

Here is another wonderful musical discovery, unearthed and reissued by the reliable Analog Africa label. Amazon's product review says that this band is from South Africa, but that's not the case. They were from Zimbabwe (or Rhodesia, as it was known back in those days), but were certainly known to music lovers in that region back in the mid to late 1970s. In fact, South African music legend West Nkosi produced many of the songs on this collection.There are plenty of joyous, seductively slinky rhythms that abound in these songs. The Green Arrows fused a bit of that South African township jive sound with a grittier, funkier edge. Of one song on this collection, the liner notes praise the "gutsy, psychedelic, zim-hoedown style which became the band's signature. It was around that time that the music of the Green Arrows was dubbed 'Waka Waka' by the fans, due to Stanley's guitar sound." I have no idea what a "zim-hoedown" is or was, but Stanley Manatsa (his brother Zexie was the band's bass player and lead singer) did indeed use some creative "fuzz" effects for his distinctive guitar sound.This compilation is divided into two parts, the first 10 tracks taken from the "Chipo Chiroowa" album recorded in 1974-75, and the other 10 tracks are dubbed the "Waka Waka Selection" from 1976-79. Needless to say, this is lively, powerful music with danceable rhythms galore. The CD come with an informative 24-page booklet with liner notes by Samy Ben Redjeb, plus some cool old photos of the band members. This was a talented band that should have been much better known. Sadly, however, that was the case with so many great African artists in the 1970s. In any case, this is a very worthwhile purchase that should excite fans of this golden era of African music.

This CD is another very strong addition to the "Backbeats" series, this time focusing on songs from the famous Philadelphia International label. The front cover hails this is "Sophisicated 80s Philly Soul", but this collection actually includes 9 tracks from the 1970s, plus of the material culled from the '80s, 6 tracks are from 1980.As the other reviewer noted, these selections are not the hit singles from that label. You can find those great but well-played songs elsewhere, but this compilation serves more as "re-introduction" to the forgotten album tracks by the label's more prominent names, and perhaps a few songs by singers you might not have heard before such as Anthony White, Dee Dee Sharp Gamble, and one of the label's more prolific songwriters, Bunny Sigler. I love this idea of putting lesser known and rare tracks on these "Backbeats" CDs, and this one has plenty of wonderful new discoveries. I was particularly struck by "Start the Fire" by Jean Carn, 'You're My Sweetness" by Billy Paul (you can't go wrong with any of his fine albums), "Set a Little Trap" by Phyllis Hyman, an "Easy, Easy, Got to Take It Easy" by Teddy Pendergrass. If you love that classic Philadelphia International '70s soul sound, you'll find a lot to like on this 74-minute CD.My only complaint, and it's a minor one, lies with the information in the CD booklet. The song credits list the songwriter and song times, plus the year the song was released. That's all appreciate, But for every song it notes that it is the "album version" and not a single edit ... but they don't tell you which album the song originally came from! Other than that annoying omission, this is a fine collection of delicious soul music. Dig in and enjoy!

I've never visited the Ivory Coast, or any country in Africa, but Carol Spindel's evocative descriptions of life in the village where she spent a year with her husband in the early 1980s, doing agricultural research, makes me feel like I'd been along for the adventure. And that's the highest praise I can give this compelling book. Her sense of place, and the way she portrays the villagers and their simple yet fascinating lifestyle, is very well done.Spindel has an empathetic feel for these villagers, but she's also not shy about discussing some aspects of this very different culture that trouble her or are problematic for one reason or another. She also pulls no punches when describing her reservations about one particularly shady character who is helping her husband conduct research in the area. You can't help rooting for Spindel as she makes a concerted effort to learn to speak the local language, and become more aware of the local traditions, dos and don'ts. By the end of the book she has become accepted by this group of villagers, many of whom were either scared of her initially, or who didn't know what to make of the idea of her and her husband living among them.In the book's introduction Spindel acknowledges that she is "not a scholar, attempting to analyze and explain. Many aspects of life in Kalikaha are never discussed, and many others are treated superficially." But her honest attempts at observing, understanding, and helping the people she met during her stay are nothing more than a resounding success.I'm sure that anyone who has visited to this part of Africa will find this book to be an interesting read, but even if you're like me and have never visited this part of the world, this book sheds light on a fascinating way of life, and helps us to better understand the whole concept of understanding one another and bridging cultures.

I don't feel that I need to offer a lengthy discourse on the greatness of Richard Thompson. Since most people reading this are already familiar with his music It would be like preaching to the choir, right? But I'll just say that I've been listening to Richard Thompson since the late 1970s and own a few dozen of his albums, and consider him one of music's greatest treasures. And to the point: This new album ranks with the best of his many fine albums.Also no need to give a track-by-track breakdown, but there are MANY fine moments on this album (the first disc produced by Jeff Tweedy, and the second disc --- more of an EP --- produced by RT himself) that will please longtime fans of this amazing artist. Yes, he's a talented guitar player with a very distinctive style, but I've always been more impressed with his songwriting chops. This guy can write some killer songs, and there are plenty to savor here. Listening to this new set of songs, there is a familiarity to the tone and the texture of the music, yet nothing feels regurgitated or forced. Thompson remains energized and inspired and still has plenty of new ideas. Long may he play!

No two ways about it; this set is a vintage reggae goldmine! Two CDs packed with seductive, delightful reggae music, mostly from 1968-1972. As the liner notes say, "In 1967 Joe Gibbs became one of the new generation of Jamaican music producers who began to challenge the dancehall supremacy of long-established pioneers like Sir Coxesone, Duke Reid, Prince Buster, et al." On this collection reggae fans will find plenty of familiar names and a few no-names, performing intoxicating original tunes alongside many covers of popular R&B and pop songs of the era. ... but it's all uniformly fantastic!Like the reviewer on this page Comment Man said, I also have a burgeoning collection of reggae albums, including a few dozen compilations, and I too was pleased that there were only a couple of songs on this collection that I'd heard before. So, I think it's a safe bet that even the diehard reggae lover will find many new discoveries on this collection. But don't go thinking that this is just a bunch of obscure reggae songs that were thrown together to fill two discs. No, man, this is reggae gold, all very high quality songs that rank with the best of the stuff that labels like Trojan and Treasure Isle put out. Really, it's that special.The CDs come with a 12-page booklet with a short essay about Joe Gibbs and his musical contributions, plus commentary on each track. There are songwriting credits but no specific recording dates listed for each track, and songs times are not listed. But whatever details that are lacking in the credits is more than made up for by the sheer quality of the music. Listen and smile!

I've only recently -- admittedly, very belatedly --- heard this 1993 album by Al Stewart and I'm very pleased with it. I can't believe that one reviewer called this "Uneven and Inconsistent". To my ears that's far from the case. This is a consistently good album, with several excellent songs that that would qualify for another "Best Of" collection. Al Stewart has released many fine albums over the course of his career and "Famous Last Words" is yet another winner.If you're already an Al Stewart fan, you pretty much know what to expect and he doesn't deviate much from his usual musical template on this album. Those distinctive vocals and well-crafted songs with intelligent lyrics, all backed by Al's impeccable guitar playing and a host of other skilled musicians (including album co-producer Peter White on guitar and keyboards). The end result is a very satisfying and comforting listening experience.  Other reviewers have proclaimed the 8-minute "Trains" as one of the album's best songs, and I can only agree. A fine tune that sounds even better with each listen. Other favorites include "Peter On the White Sea", "Charlotte Corday" (co-written with Tori Amos"), and "Don't Forget Me". The CD's booklet includes lyrics to all of the songs.Don't be concerned that there weren't any "hits" from this album. Even back in the '90s when this was first released, radio had become a non-factor. The core concern is always the quality of the music, and on that note Al Stewart delivered another strong album. Al Stewart fans, don't sleep on "Famous Last Words"; this one is a keeper!

This is a great collection of songs by a woefully underrated American band. But ... as I write this review, Amazon is selling this collection as a CD-R version, and for nearly 14 dollars!!! Sorry, but that borders on criminal. Why sell a CD-R for so much money? And why isn't the official Rhino Records version still being sold? Yeah, you can dig up copies from secondhand dealers, but "Best of" collections like this one should not be sold as those rip-off CD-Rs.As for the music, this collection includes all their biggest hits and brings back some great memories from the 1960 (Does anyone remember the appearance of the "Beau Brummel-stones" on the Flintstones TV show?!), and more importantly some catchy tunes that stick in your head. But man, not a CD-R!

If you are on this page, most probably you are already a fan of Durutti Column and that "band's" creator, Vini Reilly. That being the case, I'm probably preaching to the choir, but just to assure you; this is a fabulous album. Actually, it's a two-for-one package, combining the never-before-released "Short Stories For Pauline" album (recorded back in 1983) along with a live concert recording from Brussels in 1981.Many of the diehard Durutti Column fans might already be familiar with some of this material: 9 of the tracks from "Short Stories For Pauline" were included on the "Lips That Would Kiss" compilation that came out in 1991, although several of those songs have entirely different titles! One track on this album, "Duet," was used by Tony Wilson of Factory Record to "expand" an entire orchestral album by the Durutti Column, that being "Without Mercy." To further confuse matters, "Duet" was re-titled "La Douleur" on "Lips That Would Kiss" and according to the liner notes it was also released as "Nighttime Estoril" and "A Little Mercy". In any case, it's one of Vini's greatest compositions, dubbed "a poignant instrumental for piano and violin" in the liner notes. That violin part was played by Blaine Reininger from Tuxedomoon. Known more for his distinctive guitar style, Vini also is an outstanding piano player, and he shows his versatility on this track and others.This CD comes with a 12-page booklet with an essay about the recordings and this period of the Durutti Column's history. As to who wrote the liner notes, it doesn't say! Also, at the end of the live CD (an open-air performance at Place de la Monnaie that featured Vini on guitar and vocals with Bruce Mitchell on drums) there is an interesting/amusing interview with Vini Reilly.Not much more to say about this fine package. If you are a Durutti Column this one is a must have!

I noticed this book on the shelves many, many times, never bothering to read the blurb on the back cover or finding out what it was all about, before a friend recommended it to me. I am a frequent visitor to Myanmar (Burma) and absolutely love the country, the culture and the people. Finding out that this story takes place in that country's Shan State, an area that is especially dear to me, caused me to get even more excited about reading this novel. Long story short: I found this to be an incredibly captivating, inspiring, and beautiful novel, the sort of book that you wholeheartedly want to recommend to other reading friends.You can read the synopsis of the story elsewhere on this page, but I found this to be much more than a "love story." It also had elements of a riveting mystery, making it quite the page-turner, the reader wanting to find out what happened to Tin Win and Mi Mi. The author's writing style (or at least the style of the translator) is straightforward and uncluttered, yet also very evocative and descriptive. He does a fantastic job of capturing the feel and color of the Shan State town of Kalaw, plus describing the slow pace and unique way of life of the Burmese; in the towns, the teashops, and the monasteries. Like Tin Win, I can close my eyes and hear the myriad sounds and feel the presence of these special people.As much as I loved this novel, there were aspects of the story that required the reader to suspend belief, or accept some things with a grain of salt. But that's the magic and madness of fiction; it doesn't all have to make sense. But speaking of sense, the author's use of "sense", in the case of a describing how a blind character uses his other senses (the "hearing heartbeats" in the book's title), is particularly effective. To call it enchanting and magical would not be an understatement. This is one very special and moving novel.Because I love the setting of this novel so much, I may be biased in my reaction to the story, but honestly I think this is the sort of book that will appeal to a wide range of readers, regardless of their knowledge of anything Burmese.

I absolutely love this album, but wasn't going to even bother writing a review, seeing that over 700 reviews had already been posted on this page! But hey, why not join the JT party, right? And this new album is indeed like going to a reunion of good friends and sharing good times.Many others have remarked about how strong this album is, and how it brings back memories of JT's great early 1970s albums, and I can only agree with those opinions. It's certainly not an exaggeration: It's as if James Taylor has been drinking from the musical fountain of youth, sounding as youthful and buoyant as he did back in the day, on albums like "Mud Slide Slim" and "Sweet Baby James."I won't bore you with a song-by-song breakdown of the tracks on this album. Suffice to say that these new tunes sparkle and shine, supported by strong melodies, Taylor's ageless vocals, and some impressive lyrical depth. If you've been a James Taylor fan over the years (decades!) then I think it's safe to say that you will be very satisfied with this excellent new album. I only hope it won't take another decade-plus for him to release some more new material. This one is sheer musical bliss!

I've been a Yo La Tengo fan for many years --- oops, I think "decades" would be more accurate at this point! --- and their "Fakebook" album of mostly acoustic cover tunes remains one of my very favorites, one of those recordings that is so amazing and so life-affirming that it would qualify as one of my Desert Island Discs.That love of "Fakebook" perhaps explains why I'm not quite as enthusiastic about this new Yo La Tengo album --- one that many are calling "Fakebook 2" ---- as I would be normally. Not to say that I don't like it; that's far from the case. I would wholeheartedly agree with reviewer Charlie Quaker who called this album "a quiet little gem." Indeed, this album is packed with sweet, wonderful songs, most of them cover versions (you can read about the who-what-when in other reviews), plus a couple of new Yo La Tengo  songs and a few re-makes of their older recordings. It's all good to great, but for me it's just not quite as magical or powerful as "Fakebook" was, and still is. But I applaud Ira Kaplan and his Yo La Tengo band members for at least attempting to recapture that acoustic magic. They came close to hitting it out of the park , but it only ended up being a ground rule double (sorry, I had to put in a baseball reference for Ira's benefit!).The CD doesn't come with a booklet or any liner notes to speak of, but the digi-pack folds out to reveal a listing of each track that informs the listener who did the original version, or which Yo La Tengo album the previous version came from. Once again, this might not be a classic, but it's still a mighty fine album; tastefully chosen tunes, performed with love and passion and harmony. And for me, that works very well.

I had never heard of this guy before buying the CD, but I had read some favorable reviews, plus seeing that the CD was reissued by the dependable Light in the Attic label made me feel like that this was a safe bet. Well, I have to admit that I'm not as knocked out as I had hoped. It's a decent album, with a couple of very good songs, but for the most part I didn't hear much that made a strong impression.This album was recorded in 1972 and obviously didn't make a big splash at the time, so after this one lone album, Bob Frank left the music business for a few decades until recent interest in his music helped to get back in the studio and make some new albums again. The main Amazon review tosses out a few names for comparison, and I certainly do hear a hint of Dylan in some of these songs, but also a bit of artists such as John Prine, Kris Kristofferson, and even Jesse Winchester. Plus, he's in the same ballpark as another neglected Memphis musician, Sid Selvidge.Perhaps one reason that I wasn't that thrilled with the album was Bob Frank's vocals. On many of these songs he uses an affected vocal style, as if he's trying to sound like some revered old bluesman. But alas, he was just a young musician from Memphis playing some fairly interesting folk-blues songs. Again, not bad stuff at all, but this album doesn't strike me as any sort of lost classic. And be forewarned about the length: the album only clocks in at 28 minutes and for some reason Light in the Attic did not add (or did not locate) any bonus material. The CD does, however, come with a very informative 24-page booklet that includes an interview with Bob Frank about his early days in the music business and comments on each track by Bob Frank.

If someone had told me that this CD was intended as a "Best Of" Roy Ayers collection, I wouldn't have blinked or doubted it at all. This assemblage of "unreleased recordings" truly shines, offering the same delightfully addictive mix of soul and jazz grooves that Roy's better-known songs all were known for having. The period when these songs were recorded, from 1976 to 1981, was obviously a fertile one for Roy Ayers, and even unreleased "scraps" like these are of high quality.The only disappointing thing about the CD is the packaging. As another reviewer noted, Roy's liner notes --- basically, his comments on each of the album's songs --- are not much more than rambling gibberish, reading more like something an obsessed, and very young, fan would have written. Hey, at least he seems to remember most of the people that played on each track! In fact, after he's finished with his meandering memories of each song, there is a full listing of all the musicians and singers who appeared on each track, as well as songwriting credits. Missing, however, are the recording dates for the songs as well as the absence of song times.But hey, I'm nit-picking at this point. The music is what counts and there are plenty of great tunes on here --- over 75 minutes of music --- that burst with that distinctive Roy Ayers musical magic; pulsating vibes and generous grooves that will put the listener in a blissful orbit! If you're a Roy Ayers fan, don't miss this collection!

The title of this compilation, "The Down Home Soul of Z.Z. Hill" is slightly misleading. When I think of "down home soul" of think of the gritty and soulful tunes recorded by southern R&B masters such as Otis Redding, Percy Sledge, George Jackson, and Wilson Pickett. It's not that Z.Z. Hill doesn't belong in that select company --- he was certainly a master in his own right --- but these early recordings that he made (except for two later tracks, these songs were all recorded from 1964 to 1967) show a smoother and slicker side of Z.Z. Hill. Part of the reason for that is that arrangements of the songs, produced and arranged by Maxwell Davis and his orchestra.I may be a bit harsh in giving this collection only 3 stars, but it just didn't move me, or soothe me, or impress me as much as the other albums that I have by Z.Z. Hill, particularly his excellent 1971 album, "The Brand New Z.Z. Hill" (produced by Swamp Dogg) or the fine 2-CD collection of his "United Artists Recordings" that spanned the years 1972-75. The early recordings on this CD are also a far cry from the acclaimed early 1980s blues albums that he made for the Malaco label, just before he tragically passed away in 1984.My misgivings about this album aside, there are some great tracks on here, songs that allow Z.Z. Hill to show off his earthy, buoyant vocal style. The songs that are strongest, in my opinion, are the ones recorded in 1967, such as "You Can't Hide a Heartache, a cover of Sam Cooke's "Nothing Can Change This Love" and a very bluesy version of the Jimmy Hughes gem "Steal Away." One song that Hill wrote himself from that year, "You Don't Love Me" also shows his soulful, grittier side.In later interviews, Z.Z. Hill said he was "uncomfortable" with some of the earlier recordings, and yet he told another interviewer that "the records were great." Mixed feelings perhaps, which is sort of the way I feel about this album. As a vocalist, Hill shines throughout these recordings, but some of the weaker material, plus the slicker string arrangements combine to dampen my enthusiasm.This CD was compiled by Kent Records and distributed by Ace, but the booklet and liner notes fall a bit beneath their usual excellent standards. The CD comes with a thin 4-page booklet that has an essay about Z.Z. Hill written by Cliff White. That gives you a good background about Hill's entire recording career, but it doesn't really go into a lot of detail about these particular recordings.

The reviewers that praised these two soundtrack albums as "masterpieces" and even "superior" to Isaac's famous "Shaft" score are both right; these are indeed outstanding albums, either as soundtracks to the films or as stand-alone works. Pure soul-jazz bliss!I had heard a few songs off these albums in the past, thanks to a "Hits" collection that I have by Isaac Hayes, plus the fabulous "Pursuit of the Pimpmobile" which is on a couple of compilation albums that I have. But most of the music on these albums was totally new to my ears. And what a delight it was do discover these two 1970s soundtrack gems, both of them released in 1974. The result is less of a typical "Blaxploitation" sound --- one that Isaac and other musicians pioneered that decade -- that you would associate with soundtracks of the era, but more of a varied and complex musical palette, mixing soul and funk with atmospheric and jazzy instrumentals, plus a few mellow vocal tracks. Singing or arranging, Isaac Hayes shows his mastery throughout these recordings.The first soundtrack, "Tough Guys" was a single album when first released, while "Truck Turner" was a double-album set. One this 2-CD reissue, the first disc (which includes songs of both soundtracks) runs 52 minutes, while disc two (all "Truck Turner") is 55 minutes. One reviewer mentioned the better packaging on the Ace reissue, and I'd be curious what extras that version had. I have the Stax/Fantasy CD version that includes only a thin insert that lists the tracks and recording dates, but doesn't have any booklet or essays about the recordings. The only details (if you even can call them that) are the credits that say that Isaac Hayes supplied the vocals "with Rhythm by The Movement and Strings by the Memphis Symphony Orchestra." And that's it for any information.That lack of detail in the liner notes is slightly disappointing, seeing as how tremendous both of these albums are. Nevertheless, Amazon is currently selling this 2-CD set for a very reasonable price, so if you're an Isaac Hayes fan, or anyone who loves 1970s soul, this set is a must have, two of Isaac's underrated masterpieces!

I had only heard 2 songs by the Notations, but they were great ones, so when I saw that they now had a full-length CD available, I didn't hesitate to order it. This one certainly met my expectations. This is sweet Chicago soul, very reminiscent of the music made by Curtis Mayfield and the Impressions. In fact, the Notations cover a Mayfield song on this collection ("I've Been Trying") and after meeting the famous man himself, they wrote another song ("Superpeople") specifically for him. Disappointingly, "Superpeople" is not on this collection, but it apparently was "rediscovered" on the Northern Soul circuit in recent years and has helped to create a renewed awareness of this fine group.The Notations got their start after soul legend Syl Johnson signed them to the Twinight label that he was also recording for at the time (early 1970s), I first heard their song "I Can't Stop" on Numero Group's excellent 2-CD collection of Twinight songs "Eccentric Soul: Twinight's Lunar Rotation." The other tune I heard, "I'm Still Here" was on the Kent collection "More Perfect Harmony: Sweet Soul Groups". Both of those captivating songs are also on this collection, which also has been reissued by the Numero Group, another indication that you are getting some high quality music.One of the more distinctive aspects of the Notations was the vocals by singer Cliff Curry. When he hit certain notes there would be this cute little yelp, almost like someone had stepped on his foot! A bit unusual, but endearingly so. It turns out that his "yelp" had come from an attempt to challenge Syl Johnson's suggestion that he try something "original" when recording the song. Curry is quoted in the liner notes as saying he "hated that for a long time" but eventually came around to the realization that "Sly knew what he was talking about" and ended up liking it. And for good reason; this is a terrific tune.In addition to that song and the Mayfield cover, there are plenty of other tunes on this collection that offer ample evidence that the Notations were a supremely talented vocal group, one that could have gained wider national notice if only they had gotten the exposure and the breaks, Another song of interest is "Young Girl," the last track on this CD. This was a Curry-penned song that had touches of Drifters-like doo-wop. If the recording sounds rough, there is a reason for that: it was recovered from a nearly-lost cassette tape. But even the lack of fidelity doesn't diminish the power of this great song.After some other label moves and a brief move to the big time with a single for Mercury, the Notations kept on keeping on, despite the lack of any major commercial breakthrough. A shame, because they certainly had the talent. Nevertheless, the band has persevered and from what the liner notes say, they are still performing today, even though original member LaSalle Matthews died in 2002.The CD comes with a 12-page booklet with a history of the group written by Ryan Boyle. Another very interesting, and soul satisfying reissue from the Numero Group. If you are a fan of 1970s soul vocal groups, don't miss this one!

Admittedly, I'm VERY late in discovering this band, but oh what a joy they are to hear! I first heard their recent "Shattered" album earlier this year and was very impressed. Memorable songs with hooks, a passionate singer, and a tight band. Wanting to hear more by this talented and energetic band, I decided to get this 2002 release, Yow! Once again I'm smitten and knocked out. Now this is rock and roll!First impressions: they sound like Paul Westerberg and the Replacements teaming up with David Johansen (early solo albums, without the New York Dolls), and having Booker T. play the organ. In other words, crunchy, melodic rock with grit, grooves, soul and passion. I'm stumped that I never hard of this band until recently, but delighted and excited to have finally discovered Reigning Sound.My rock and roll has been satisfied, but I need to hear more by Reigning Sound: two albums down and more to go!

This is a fantastic collection of female soul singers (along with a few duets with some fellows!) that were produced, mentored and nourished by James Brown. Most of the material spans the years 1960 to 1974, with one track from  1975 and another from 1977 tacked on for good measure. For certain, J.B. fans will find a lot to like on this 2-CD set, but by no means is the appeal limited to diehard James Brown fans. This is simply great soul music, ranging from early 1960s sweet soul ballads to early 1970s funk groovers.Most J.B. fans have heard some of these songs before, particularly the hit singles by Lyn  Collins and Marva Whitney. Both singers have a lot of material on these two discs, but another of the more impressive singers is Vicki Anderson. Some of her songs, such as "The Message From the Soul Sisters (Parts 1 & 2)" and "You're Welcome, Stop on By" (this is a Bobby Womack song, and this version is a duet with Bobby Byrd) are absolute gems. Another very cool Vicki Anderson cut is "Don't Throw Your Love in the Garbage Can," Written by the legendary Clarence Reid (also known as Blowfly) and soul diva Betty Wright, this song was recorded at T.K. Studios in Miami and also features the underrated Little Beaver on guitar.Many of these tracks feature members of the JBs, ace musicians such as Bootsy Collins (and his brother Catfish), Fred Wesley, Bobby Byrd, Maceo Parker, and of course James Brown himself. A few other 1970s cuts include appearance by jazz legends such as the Brecker Brothers, Jon Faddis, Joe Farrell, and  Cornell Dupress. Needless to say, ALL of these tracks -- with the JBs or others --- sizzle and satisfy.The CD set also comes with a very informative 24-page booklet that includes a complete lineup of musicians on each track, songwriting credits, song times, and original recording date. A very well-done package of vintage soul and funk music, with a definite J.B. touch.

If you are an Elvis Costello fan, I'd venture to say that this endearingly oddball compilation of singles, covers, outtakes, and previously unreleased material is a must have for your collection. Released in 1987 by Demon Records, most of this material was recorded from the early to mid 1980s, a fertile musical period for Mr. Costello. As others have noted, while these songs didn't make the cut on any of his studio albums, they are still of high quality.The album leads off with "Seven Day Weekend," a fun duet with Jimmy Cliff. It's a good tune, but there are better ones that follow. Another duet, "The People's Limousine" with T-Bone Burnett, is much more interesting, and the cover of Burt Bacharach's "Baby It's You" with Nick Lowe also sparkles. Three other cover tunes are also worth noting: a lively version of Smokey Robinson's "Head to Toe", a beautiful version of Richard Thompson's "Withered and Died", and a particularly creative take on Yoko Ono's "Walking on Thin Ice", perhaps the best cover of a Yoko Ono song I've ever heard (granted, there aren't that many out there!).Costello also re-invents himself with very interesting alternate versions of "American Without Tears" and a total revamping of "Big Sister." I could go on and on, listing yet more memorable songs on here, but hopefully you get the gist of this album. It's similar to "Taking Liberties," the other 1980s collection of Costello B-sides and rarities, but it's a strong collection and highlights some true nuggets from this period of Costello's career, a time when he was clicking on all cylinders and could virtually do no wrong. Ah, I miss those days. Very delightful compilation.

My entire knowledge of Brewer & Shipley was having heard "One Toke Over the Line" on the radio back in the 1970s. Great tune, but I had no inkling that they had recording plenty of other albums, including this gem of an album a few years previous to their big hit. But after reading so many glowing reviews for this CD reissue, I was intrigued enough to order it from Amazon. Excellent decision; this album is wonderful!All of the rave reviews are certainly justified. This truly is a magical gem of an album, packed with melodic, echanting and radiant tunes, combining what could be called orchestral pop with some more folk-sounding arrangements. The result is simply beautiful. And the more I hear this album, the more I am also struck by the passion and power of the lyrics.Calling this album unheralded and underrated would be an understatement. This truly is a magnificent collection of songs. Thanks to the other reviewers who shared their love for this album. I feel lucky to have belatedly discovered this beauty.

If you have any of the other excellent "Nigeria Special" compilations from Soundway, you know what to expect: plenty of lively and propulsive songs with plenty of rhythm happening. In the liner notes, the compilers pledge to bring us listeners "some of the more obscure and unheard names and recordings from what was undoubtedly a time brimming with sonic treasures." And rest assured there are plenty of such musical jewels waiting your discovery on this CD.The compilation starts with an early, fairly rare, version of "Who're You" by Fela Kuti from 1971, a song that he re-recorded for his Fela's "London Scene" album. Most of the reviewers on this page have dismissed this song somewhat, but I think it's an exciting, vibrant tune with some intense rhythms and wild organ playing. Among the other songs that impress me on this CD are the intense "Mind Your Business" by Saxon Lee & the Shadows International, the jazz-infused instrumental "Gboymojo" by Segun Bucknor's Revolution,  "Hankuri" by Madman Jaga, and the slightly psychedelic "trance-like" feel of "Ariwo Yaa" by Bob Ohiri & His Uhuru Sounds. Another one of my favorite Nigerian musicians, Orlando Julius, contributes "Afro-Blues", a percolating instrumental propelled by "raw organ stabs and Orlando's sweet saxophone". Interestingly. the last track on this collection, the pleasing "Ole" is by the Black Santiagos, a band from Benin, but included here because the record was pressed and released in Nigeria.As you would expect from Soundway, the CD comes with a 20-page booklet that includes a short essay about this period of Nigerian music, written by album compiler Miles Cleret, and capsule summaries of each track. The songs span the years 1971-78. Another very welcome release from Soundway that should please fans of 1970s Nigerian music.

As usual, the musical archeologists at the Numero Group have unearthed another treasure chest of obscure soul treats, this time from the San Antonio, Texas-based Dynamic label. The music on this collection is culled from the years 1965-1968 when the Dynamic label, headed by local businessman and music fan Abe Epstein, was putting out records galore, and good ones they were!The first track on this collection, "Hey It's Love" by the Commands is enough to turn your head around right off the bat; a "commanding" song indeed! The lead singer, from what I can gather by the liner notes, was Dan Henderson, accurately described as having a "mesmerizing alto." I'm scratching my head, trying to think of who his voice reminds me of, but it's a distinctive, tuneful one that draws every ounce of emotion out of the song. A pure soul treat. The Commands were one of the groups that could have/should have been a much bigger name, if only they had received the right breaks and a bit of luck. They have a total of 6 songs on this CD, including another fantastic tune, "No Time For You," which was later covered by the O'Jays. The members of the Commands were also in the Air Force and most of their "tours" during that time were appearances at other Air Force bases! After losing some of their original members, Henderson kept the Commands going. A new record was scheduled with RCA, only to have that deal apart. The liner notes tell us that "following a horrific 1969 break-in at Henderson's home, the singer left San Antonio and was never heard from again. A true loss for soul music. This guy had an amazing voice!The second track on the album, "Give Your Love To Me" by Little Jr. Jesse & the Teardrops, is another incredibly catchy tune, but more pop than soul, sporting some quasi-surf guitar licks. Another group that caught my ear was the Webs. Briefly signed to Atlantic, they have 3 songs on this CD, including the wonderful "Don't Ever Hurt Me". Another armed forces-related group on the label was Doc & Sal, two singers stationed in the Navy. They have 4 songs on this collection, including the lovely "Laughing to Keep From Crying."The liner notes estimate that Abe Epstein (who passed away in 2012) recorded close to a thousand tracks for the Dynamic label, along with two earlier record companies. The cream of that crop is planned for an additional release on Numero. Meanwhile, soul fans can enjoy these melodic and memorable soul treats. The CD comes with a 24-page booklet with exhaustive details about the label and these artists.

I'm no expert on the subject of Amelia Earhart, nor have I read any of the many books written about her, save for an old copy of Fred Goerner's "The Search for Amelia Earhart" that I read when I was in high school back in the mid 1970s. I've always been interested in the "mystery" of what happened to Earhart and navigator Fred Noonan during their attempted flight around the world in 1937, so I looked forward to reading this author's account of "Finding Amelia".At first, I was a bit skeptical of how good this book would be.The cover art looked cheaply done and I wasn't familiar with the publisher. Would this be a legitimate investigative book or some sensational mumbo-jumbo? Well, to put it briefly, it WAS a worthwhile read, both well-written and well-researched. In fact, it's so full of facts and figures and details, that I think most casual readers with no deep interest in the subject might have a hard time wading through these detailed chapters. So many dates and time zones and degree lines and positions and people; this plethora of names and numbers will spin your head around. For me, it was all hard to keep track of and understandable at times.Nevertheless, the author does a good job of keeping the story flowing, describing both the events leading up to that final flight, the communications ---or lack of --- between Earhart and those on the ground, and the frantic search for her and Noonan afterwards. The author also offers plenty of interesting and enlightening facts about Earhart and her skills --- or again, the lack of them --- that help to dispel the idea that she was an ace pilot.The biggest disappointment for me was the lack of any satisfying ending or conclusion. Of course, due to the fact that we still don't know what happened to Earhart or her plane, even after all these years, that's a difficult task. But on the back cover it tells us that the author is "an internationally recognized authority on the Earhart disappearance and has led 8 archaeological search expeditions to the Pacific," so with that in mind, I would expect some sort of "expert" analysis or educated guesses as to what he think happened. But we never get that in this book. Instead, the author gives us a 1-page epilogue in the form of a short telegram sent in 1940. This is supposed to shed some light on the mystery? Sorry, but I feel cheated.

I'm always on the lookout for obscure soul and funk albums from the 1960s and 1970s and this one caught my eye while surfing on Amazon late one night recently. The reviews were mostly positive and the fact that the always reliable Eddie Landsberg recommended this CD made the purchase a no-brainer for me. I'm delighted to say that the music more than met my expectations; this is hot stuff indeed!The Counts were a band from Detroit and previously known as the Fabulous Counts in the late 1960s. In those early days they had a minor hit with their instrumental "Jan Jan". That song is not on this album (there is a separate CD for The Fabulous Counts), but the songs that are on "What's Up Front That Counts", originally released in 1971, are mighty tasty in their own right. Both the instrumentals and vocal cuts exude a vibrant funky soul vibe. At times they sound to me like a cross between early Tower of Power and early-1970s Temptations, gritty and powerful, horns blasting and guitars wah-wah-ing away. Other tracks sound vaguely like The Meters or even the underrated Rasputin's Stash (another must-buy band, also recommended by Eddie).This is a relatively short album, with only 34 minutes of music, but pleasing minutes they are! The only reason I didn't give this 5 stars was due to the drab CD packaging. This CD was reissued by Westbound in 2005, but they offer you nothing in the way of a booklet or any liner notes. The inside insert lists songwriting credits, and song times are listed on the back cover, but there isn't a list of the band members nor any information about these recordings. A real shame, because this was obviously a talented band with some cool tunes, and I would have liked more background information on them (I only learned about their previous incarnation as the Fabulous Counts from other sources). Those complaints aside, this is a very good album that fans of 1970s funky soul will surely appreciate.

Orleans was a band that had a few hit singles --- "Still The One" being the one that most everyone has heard --- during their relatively brief recording career, but they deserve much more recognition and respect from critics than they've received. I think that this single disc compilation from Rhino of their "best" tunes is the best one that's available.Orleans tends to get pigeonholed as a "soft rock" or "pop" group, but they showed a musical versatility that belied such simple generalizations.
