I like this paragraph in the liner notes that sums up their sound: "Good-time party band of serious-minded songwriting vehicle? Purveyors of uplifting love songs or messengers of politically-charged rock broadsides? R&B/reggae groove-meisters or harmonizing folkies? All of the above could be applied to Orleans."Indeed, this band really WAS able to play with chameleon-like dexterity, blending sounds and shifting musical focus when they wanted. Perhaps those traits didn't endear them to critics, but as you can say from the many reviews on this page, the fans loved their music. One of their earliest songs, "Half Moon" was also recorded by Janis Joplin, and later by Chaka Khan and Rufus. That song showed the funkier side of the band, but as the liner notes indicated, they could play some tenderly beautiful ballads, uptempo rockers, or even songs with a reggae rhythm. Lead singer John Hall wrote many of these songs with his wife Johanna, some of which touched on environmental issues. You could say that Hall was one of the first artists to express concern about climate change in a song, using "Cold Spell" as an example.This CD comes with a 16-page booklet with a history of the band and comments from some of the band members, who later regrouped and recorded new songs in the late 1980s and early 1990s (none of which are included on this collection).One side note: Reading the reviews for this CD, many people have compared the music of Orleans to that of other 1970s bands such as Firefall, Ambrosia, Player, and even Poco. One fan went so far as to rate Orleans behind Ambrosia, but ahead of Poco and Firefall. I'd put it the other way around. As much as I like Orleans, I don't think they are/were quite in the same league as a pioneering band like Poco. But I certainly would rank Orleans ahead of the other bunch of "soft rock" 1970s acts. They really did have many good songs, with hooks, harmonies, and lyrical substance.

I have several other so-called "Hillbilly" compilations and enjoy them thoroughly. There is something that is so pure and fun about this style of country music. This 2-CD set is no exception; it's packed with fun and funny hillbilly tunes, or "good old-fashioned mountain music" as the liner notes call it.If you're like me and already have similar collections of hillbilly music, you may have heard a few of these songs already, perhaps the tracks by Merle Travis, Hank Williams, Bob Wills, Spade Cooley, and Red Foley. But there are a whole bunch of songs that I had NOT heard before, thus making this set a very satisfying purchase. And the fact that Amazon is selling is so cheap is an added bonus.These songs swing and sway with unbridled energy, plus the lyrical content (providing that's it's not one of the fantastic instrumentals) can be a bit risque, if not just darn funny. Honestly, these songs will make you smile big time! CD 1 clocks in at 65 minutes, while CD 2 offers 63 minutes. The oldest song on here is from 1936 and the most recent is from 1960, but the vast majority of the tracks are from the mid-1940s to the mid-1950s.The CD comes with a thin 4-page insert that has brief liner notes about some of the artists represented, but is by no means comprehensive. At the bottom of one page is a listing (in very tiny print) of the release dates for each track, along with songwriter credits. Not a fantastic package in that respect, but the lively and vivacious songs more than make up for the lack of information about the artists.

All in all, I found this compilation to be very satisfying, another fascinating addition to the Backbeats series that has exposed me to some new sounds. The front cover hypes this is "Soulful Jazz Licks From the 70s", and that's true for the most part, but to be a stickler for details, there ARE three tracks from 1980 included here also.Most of these tracks are extended instrumentals, the highlights including Reuben Wilson's steaming cover of the War classic "The Cisco Kid", Funk Inc. (billed as Funk Incorporated on this CD) offering a wicked version of Curtis Mayfield's "Give Me Your Love", Jimmy McGriff's "Red Beans", and the Gamble & Huff Orchestra's take on "Is It Something I Said," which as you would expect is is a Gamble & Huff song. Two other cover versions are also memorable: "Lionel Hampton's take on the Buddy Miles classic "Them Changes" and someone named Hysear Down Walker with an enchanting version of "Killing Me Softly." Of the handful of tracks with vocals, my favorite is Lou Rawls singing "Trade Winds." Anything that man sings is gold and this song is no exception.The tracks on this collection are licensed from four labels: Philadelphia International, Brunswick, Groove Merchant, and Fantasy. It's a nice batch of tunes that flows very well, and with nearly 76 minutes of music you get your money's worth. That said, I certainly agree with some of the criticisms of this package by reviewer ziontrain. Yes, like other volumes in this Backbeats series, they waste too much page space giving you a needless rundown on status of the series and a fairly generic overview of the jazz and R&B scene of this period. Like ziontrain, I would have been very interested in reading more about these tracks and some of the lesser known artists on this collection, such as Hysear Don Walker and Mike Longo. Then again, Backbeats is a budget reissue label so I don't expect exhaustive liner notes like I'd get with a compilation from Kent or Ace Records.The meager liner notes aside, the music on this collection is actually quite good, and I daresay there will be a few pleasant discoveries awaiting anyone who enjoys the late 1970s and early 1980s period of soul-jazz fusion. Good grooves galore await you!

I heard a track from Tame Impala's previous album, "Lonerism" but wasn't overly impressed so I never bought the whole CD. But after reading some reviews of this new one, I decided to take a chance, especially after seeing it in stock at a local CD shop. The verdict: I'm favorably blown away by this album. It's definitely one of my Top 10 favorite albums this year.Not having heard the band's previous albums, I can't offer any comparisons or make a guess as to how they/he have progressed or matured as a songwriter or performer. All I can tell you is that these songs abound with hooks and good grooves and lovely harmonies. These songs float and soar and lift the spirits. Some definite synth-pop magic at work on this album. I'll throw a curveball in the way of comparison and say that some of these songs remind me of New Musik's wonderful "Straight Lines" album from the early 1980s, albeit with a more modern production touch.This album was definitely not what I expected, and perhaps that helps to make me love it even more. Shimmering would be my one word to describe these songs. I'm so impressed by this album that I'm going to go back and give "Lonerism" a try too.

I'm delighted that I stumbled upon the listing for this CD --- an album I had never heard of by a band I had never heard of before! --- but more importantly I'm delighted by the excellent music. As others have described it, this is classic roots-rock reggae spiced by sparkling harmonies and a rock-solid cast of musicians. The liner notes call this album "a definitive high point in Jamaican close harmony singing" and that's very true.  Most of the lead vocals are by Roy Cousins and Errol Wilson, but reading the credits reveals that a grand total of 8 men sing the lead on these songs, in addition the MANY who are singing harmony. Let's just say: these guys could sing!This album was first released in 1977 on the small Wambesi label, so perhaps that explains why many reggae fans outside of Jamaica have never heard this group's music. But that lack of attention does not mean that this is a minor, insignicant recording. Far from it; this is first-rate stuff indeed. These songs are full of those lilting, uplifting reggae rhythms. and songs with sweet singing and lyrical depth. The cast of supporting musicians includes reggae royalty such as Aston 'Family Man' Barrett, Robbie Shakespeare, Ernest Ranglin, Earl 'Chinna' Smith, Ansel Collins, Tommy McCook, and others, plus harmony vocals from members of the Meditations and the Heptones.The first paragraph of the liner notes succinctly sums up this band: "The Royals seem to have remained as the last great unsung Jamaican vocal group from reggae's 'Golden Age' in the '60s and '70s, and their work is still relatively unknown outside of a small coterie of serious reggae students despite their having made some of the most sublime and enduring music of the genre."This CD includes an 8-page booklet with an essay about the band and these recordings written by Harry Hawke. This CD is a welcome discovery for anyone who loves the classic sound of 1970s reggae.

I've enjoyed many of G.M. Ford's books, both the Frank Corso series and the Leo Waterman series. Ford is both a talented writer and a deft storyteller. This novel, however, was the weakest one that I've read by him. I may be a bit too harsh in giving it only 2 stars, but the story had so many flaws and lack of focus that I almost didn't even finish reading it.One of the main problems with the novel is that the protagonist, Frank Corso, plays a relatively minor role in the story. Instead, we are forced to follow the violent actions of two prisoners, a female TV news reporter who is battling marital turbulence, and a dysfunctional company trying to operate the correctional facility. It wasn't until the final 100 or so pages that I finally find myself becoming interested in what was happening. There are a few saving graces to this book. Ford demonstrates his writing talent with several poignant and powerful passages, and I liked the way he highlights the for-profit-blight that is the state of the US prison system. I'm not that squeamish when it comes to reading about violence, but also thought that parts of this book were too over-the-top in describing the ways that various characters were killed. I really don't think it added to the suspense factor or made things any more realistic, just disturbing.If you haven't read any of the books in the Frank Corso series, I would NOT recommend that you start with this one. A very disappointing entry in what is normally a well-done series.

Harvey Mandel is one of those names that I knew, mainly as for his guitar-for-hire appearances on other artists' albums, but I had never actually heard anything he had recorded before I ordered this CD. I wasn't sure if this was the best one to get. A couple of his studio albums have received rave reviews, but in the end, I wanted to hear some sort of retrospective, a "Best Of" as this CD is titled, so this was the one I picked. All I can say is: WOW! These are masterful instrumentals! Mandel is indeed an amazing guitarist, one with flash and style, but also one that uses those talents to create some very listenable and engaging songs.I would concur with Steven's recommendation that fans of Joe Satriani and Eric Johnson might like this album. Mandel is most definitely someone that fans of hot-shot guitar players will appreciate. But he's not a one-trick pony, either in the way he plays the instrument or the type of music that he records. As other reviews have noted, he fuses blues with rock and jazz, plus adds some funky and soulful touches too. You can hear clear jazz-rock fusion on some cuts, uptempo blues on others, and some get-down boogie at other times. This guy has the flair and the touch and the just the right feel to make it all work.While the music is superb, the packaging of the CD is somewhat of a letdown. The liner notes offer a brief history of Mandel's recording career, with a few quotes from his old keyboard partner Barry Goldberg, but no comments from Mandel himself. The booklet that comes with the CD (just a thin 4-page insert) does not have any songwriting credits, no recording dates, no song times, no list of which albums the tracks originally were on, and no lineup of the musicians who play with Mandel on these songs. Very disappointing not to have more details about these recordings. My copy of this CD was put out by Fuel in 2011.

Amazon's main product review says that anyone wanting to hear Kottke's music for the first time should start with his acclaimed "Six and Twelve String Guitar" album. Well ... I'm not so sure about that. As fantastic as that album is --- and it DOES rank as a classic --- I think this 2-CD retrospective of his work on the Takoma, Capitol, and Chyrsalis labels offers a fuller and better balanced overview of his music, showcasing not only his dazzling instrumental guitar virtuosity but Kottke's "other" side too, that being his songs with vocals. Kottke is obviously a great guitarist, but also a great singer and songwriter.As other reviewers have noted, Kottke has frequently been compared to John Fahey for his impressive guitar skills, but like someone else noted, I think Kottle's work is more listenable and entertaining. Yes, he dazzles on the strings, but he also is astute enough to know when to slow down and caress a song, offering sweet, lovely tunes, and at other times charming and quirky ones. And if you've ever had the pleasure of seeing this man in concert, you will also know that he is a charming and funny fellow too, the consummate entertainer.So yeah, if you are looking for a place to start your Kottke collection, this 2-CD is an excellent place to begin. It cuts off in the early 1980s, before he started recording for the Private Music label, so you miss some of songs from that period (and there are plenty of good ones on those albums too!), but for a satisfying sampling of his earlier years, some would say his prime time, this collection is wonderful.

Seemingly an odd idea for an album --- covers of "English Rebel Songs" dating back to 1381 --- works smashingly in the hands, and vocal chords of Chumbawamba. Protest songs were never so beautifully sung!If you are already a Chumbawamba fan, you will definitely want to hear this one, but be forewarned; it doesn't sound like anything else the group has ever done. Not only due to the theme of the songs --- although this band has certainly never shied away from political or social issues in the past --- but because it's mostly an acapella album and lacks the "normal" instrumentation that the band uses. A bare bones approach, but one that actually fits with the tone of these folk songs of struggle and rebellion.This collection of songs was originally recorded by the band in 1988. To quote the liner notes, the members of the band "were determined to stir up a rout in our tiny anarcho-punk community by swapping guitars and drums for acapella singing .... fifteen years later, we felt we'd learned enough about our voices to try again, updating and rearranging the songs against the backdrop of US/British warmongering. The songs were discovered in songbooks and in folk clubs and on cassette tapes, chopped and changed and bludgeoned into shape with utmost respect for the original tunes."That respect and sincerity comes shining through in these brilliantly performed songs. And the voices; oh, those voices. Mesmerizing and lovely only begins to tell the tale as the harmonies soar and float. Listen and learn and appreciate what this band has done. This truly represents a milestone in their recording career. Maybe not their most catchy batch of tunes, and it's relatively short at 31 minutes, but this ranks as one of their most important albums.If you are not a Chumbawamba fan, this would probably not be the best able with which to start in journey in discovery one of music's most versatile --- and vital --- bands. Then again, this collection of songs is so thought-provoking and passionate, that the more people that hear it the better.

I knew the name Luther Allison, but until recently had never heard anything by this legendary guitarist. A friend let me borrow his copy of this CD recently, but it took a while to finally get around to playing it. Looking at the track listing, my first thoughts were: ugh ... another guy playing boring old blues standards. Not sure if this is something I'm going to like very much.Well, after the first time through this CD, I liked it very much indeed. In fact, I was riveted. Not only was Allison obviously a gifted guitar slinger, I really liked his interpretations and new takes on these tried and tested --- and often tired --- old blues tunes. Yeah, we've heard some of these songs many times already by dozens of other acts, but Allison puts a fresh, imaginative spin on these dusty old tunes. Plus, the originals of his on this album also sparkle. I especially love the two extended jams; the 7:26 title cut and the sprawling 10:44 opus, "It's Been a Long Time." Whew, this guy is beyond impressive. But as hot as Allison's guitar playing is, he's backed by a very tight band. I especially like the piano playing of Paul White. Never heard of this guy before, but he can pound those keys!Since playing this one to death, I've bugged my friend to lend me more of Luther Allison albums, and it that doesn't work, well, there is always the Amazon site to place yet another order. Right now they are selling this CD for an insanely low price, so if you're sitting on the fence and love electric blues guitar, don't delay on getting this one. It's a total gem.

One of the (many) 5-star reviews for this novel used the word "riveting" to describe the story, and that's the exact word I was going to use, expect in a negative sense: this one was far from riveting! And that's disappointing because I have always found the other books in this series by Silva to be very engrossing, entertaining, and yes, riveting. Not so this time around.Silva definitely has his formula down pat and anyone who has read other books in this series pretty much knows what to expect. That's comforting on one level, but it's also a bit predictable and wearisome. The same characters are doing the same things and saying the same things, and we're reading the same stuff, with slight variations, over and over again.That's not so say that this book is a disaster. Silva is far too good a writer --- but perhaps more accurately, a very good storyteller --- to write a book that is going to put you to sleep. But for the first time ever reading one of these Gabriel Allon tales, I have to say that there were a few lackluster chapters and a general lack of tension and suspense.Like other reviewers, I will no doubt want to read the next book in the series, but I'm hoping that Silva will make an effort to break out of his predictable formula and give us a few surprises. At this point, this series needs a tune-up.

Perhaps you need not to have been a devotee of the author's famous Creation Records label to appreciate this books, but I think it's safe to say that your enjoyment of this tome would benefit from having heard and enjoyed some of the bands that Alan McGee signed and managed, acts such as Primal Scream, Oasis, My Bloody Valentine, the Jesus and Mary Chain, and the Libertines.Creation Records was indeed an influential and exciting label and in addition to some of the well-known acts, the label released great records by terrific lesser-known bands too, including Biff Bang Pow, a band that McGee himself was a member of. This book is more than a tell-all tale of the bands that McGee signed or hung out with, but it also delves into his own turbulent journey in life, one that was dominated for many years by excessive drug use. McGee pulls no punches when it comes to those decadent days, but I found the endless drug-fueled tales a bit tedious after a few chapters. Okay, you were a mess; we get it. Much more interesting to me was reading about dealing with, and recording with, bands such as House of Love, Ride, and the prolific, underrated genius Ed Ball.While some passages of the book are entertaining, informative, or just plain funny, other parts meander and drift, or are just confusingly presented. McGee is a colorful character with plenty of wild tales to tell, but he's not much of a writer and the book suffers from weak prose, lack of continuity, and his use of too much Scottish slang. There were times I would stop in the middle of a paragraph, wondering what --- or who --- he was rambling on about. Where were the editors? On one hand, you could call McGee's writing style refreshing and true to his maverick spirit, but on the other hand reading such gibberish can be maddening for the reader.All in all, though, this was a fun read, and a book that will be of interest to anyone who was immersed in the "indie" music scene of the 1980s and 1990s.

Okay, I'm a bit late in discovering the music of Jesse Malin --- this is the first album that I've heard by him --- but I'm so blown away by this CD that I've already ordered another one by him, and I'm sure that will be one of many. This is one of those instantly likable albums, so good that you want to tell all your kindred musical pals. This guy is the real deal!Seeing as how this is my introduction to Malin and his music, I obviously can't compare this new effort to his past albums. I've read through the older reviews and seen him compared to everyone from Springsteen to Dylan, but I don't hear those two artists much in these songs. Okay, maybe there's an ever-so-slight Springsteen touch in the songwriting, but if I were forced to compare him to anyone I'd offer up a mix of Paul Westerberg, Ryan Adams, and a quality throwback such as Garland Jeffreys. In other words; this guy can write some excellent songs, ones with both acute hooks and meaningful lyrics.The CD version of this album comes with a 16-page booklet that includes lyrics to all of the songs and a full lineup of all the musicians who play on each track. Sign me up: I want to hear more by this guy!

Now here is a "Soul Shop" that is worth paying a visit. The photo on the cover did indeed come from a real shop that was run by Bill Curtis of the Fatback Band, offering the "Best Bands for Hire" in various musical styles. And that's the beauty of this compilation of Curtis and Fatback-related music; there is a pleasing diversity of soul music styles to be found.The songs on here were recorded from 1967 to 1971 and aren't nearly as funky as the stuff that Fatback would do later in the '70s. That said, the 3 tracks featuring Johnny King and the Fatback Band are pretty funky in their own right, sounding like a cross between Sly & the Family Stone and Eddie Kendricks. The second track on here is a wicked instrumental titled "The Cat Walk" by Gerry & Paul and the Soul Emissaries. It's hailed in the liner notes as "a classic dance record" of the Northern Soul scene. I can hear why. Very infectious tune.And there are plenty of more gems on here, including the 4 sultry soul tunes by Mary Davis, and 4 tracks by The Four Puzzles (sometimes simply called The Puzzles). Those Puzzle tracks were written by members of the Diplomats, or just by that band's main member, Samuel Culley. The Diplomats don't have any songs on this CD, but they DO have a very good career retrospective released by Kent/Ace, and of further interest is the other band they formed, Skull Snaps. Essential soul music, as is this collection.This CD comes with an 8-page booklet with an essay about Bill Curtis and his soul shop and these unfairly neglected recording artists, written by noted soul authority Ady Croasdell. . If you are a fan of late '60s and early 70s soul music, by all means check this one out. The CD is a little short on songs, with only 43 minutes of music, but it's of high quality.

I'm surprised that there aren't more reviews for this excellent album, the debut by Songhoy Blues. Confusingly, Amazon has separate listings for the import and domestic versions of this album, both of which have identical track listings. In any case, this is a very impressive album by a band that was "born of violence and displacement," having to flee their native Mali due to the conflict with Islamist extremists. The final straw for guitarist Garba Toure was when he was threatened with a few lashes and a smashed instrument if local rebels saw him carrying his guitar around town again. Time to hit the road!Together with two other guys also with the last name of Toure (none of them related) and a drummer, they formed Songhoy Blues. Although these guys come from the Songhoy tribe in Mali, their music reminds me a lot of that Tinariwen, who hail from a Touareg tribe in the same country. Both groups weave atmospheric strands of blues together with western sounds to create fascinating music. Songhoy Blues have more rock influences in their songs --- or at least the liner notes tell us they listened to many western bands growing up --- and yet the music sounds closer in spirit to what legends like Ali Farke Toure or even Amadou and Mariam have recorded. The liner notes call the music of Songhoy Blues "a modern amplified spirit, built on traditions centuries old." Indeed, there is a certain "timeless" quality to this mesmerizing pieces, songs with layers and vibrant rhythms that lodge in your consciousness with each repeated listen.This CD comes with an 8-page booklet that has an essay about the band written by Andy Morgan. In addition to the four regular band members there are several other guest musicians on this album, including Damon Albarn from Blur who sings on one track. A very impressive band from Mali!

This is another marvelous vintage soul treat, rediscovered and reissued by the Numero Group label. If you've heard the "Eccentric Soul: The Capsoul Label" compilation from Numero, then you HAVE heard this talented group; they had 3 songs on that collection.The Four Mints did indeed record for the Capsoul label, but only released five singles in their recording career. The label deemed that enough material for a full album, thus they put out "Gently Down Your Stream" in 1973, the band's --- and the label's --- one and only LP! For this CD reissue, those diligent crate-diggers at Numero found "one brilliant song saved from the cutting room floor" along with some rehearsal versions of two songs from the album, taken from the archives of one of Capsoul's main songwriters. It's not a long album in terms of minutes, but the quality of the material is strong.If you are a fan of 1960s and 1970s soul music and haven't heard the Four Mints before, you are in for a real treat.  This Columbus, Ohio group had a sweet soul sound that reminds me of classic soul acts such as The Impressions and the Miracles, with a bit of Chi-Lites in the mix too. In other words; these guys could sing!The CD comes with an 8-page booklet that includes a short history of the group and a lineup of the members and musicians who played on these songs. Like other CD reissues from Numero, you also get a cute little "collector's card" (baseball card size) of one of the artists on the label. Another very satisfying reissue from Numero Group that will surely satisfy soul fans.

This is an amazing live album that unfortunately, due to almost non-existent distribution, has never been heard by those who would most it appreciate it, especially the diehard Dwight Twilley fans out there. If you can find a secondhand copy online from Amazon or any other dealers, snag it; this one is terrific!The one reviewer who hailed this album as one of the best of the 1970s is not exaggerating or smoking something funny; this really IS a masterpiece of a show, capturing a talented young band in all its sweat and glory in a special moment in time. One thing that struck me listening to this CD was how much FUN the band is having. Instead of going through the motions as some band do, Twilley, Seymour and band sound like they are playing for the sheer thrill of it. Not just posturing, but living it; playing rock and roll with passion and flair.And obviously the audience at the Agora is loving the show too and feeding off the band's energy, which in turn then doubles back and pumps up the band yet even more. Really, this show overflows with energy, and the sound quality of the radio broadcast is surprisingly good too; clear and punchy.I understand the reaction by the reviewer who complained about the CD version of this recording being not much more than a CD-R. I also detest buying a CD online and later discovering that it's only a cheap CD-R. For certain, the lack of credits and liner notes is a big disappointment --- this great band and this great performance deserve better treatment --- but the Agora show is so intense and so magical that I can almost forgive the packaging slight. The bottom line is the music, and this delivers big time.The CD contains 45 minutes of music. Here is the full track listing:1. Shakin‚Äô In the Brown Grass2. Just Like the Sun3. Chance to Get Away4. Could Be Love5. Trying to Find My Baby6. Betsy Sue7. I‚Äôm On Fire8. Twilley Don‚Äôt Mind9. Here She Comes10. Sky Writer11. TV12. Rock and Roll 4713. England

I remember seeing this album in the record bins a few decades ago, but I until I recently bought this CD reissue I'd never heard it before. And that should rank as a BIG act of neglect, seeing as how I was a big fan of Pure Prairie League, and Craig Fuller was the lead singer on that band's first two albums. In any case, I'm very happy to have finally heard this little gem of an album. Maybe it's not quite a 5-star effort, but it's a consistently pleasing one. No duds to be found whatsoever.After leaving Pure Prairie League, Fuller joined forces with Eric Kaz and some other veteran musicians to form sort of a B-League supergroup called American Flyer. They made two albums (which are currently out of print; maybe Real Gone Music can reissue those also!) with that band and then recorded this one as a duo. As soon as the first song, "Feel That Way Again" comes wafting through the speakers, the delight begins, hearing that distinctive and comforting voice of Craig Fuller once again. That opening track is only one of many fine moments on this album, radiant songs such as "Cry Like a Rainstorm" (many of you may have heard Linda Ronstadt cover this song), "Til You Come Back" and "Annabella".It's still mystifying why this fine album didn't make more of a splash when it was first released in 1978 on the Columbia label. One theory, according to Fuller, was that the label was totally enamored with another record that came out at the same time --- the first Toto album --- and gave most of their attention to that one, virtually ignoring the Fuller/Kaz album. All these years later, however, I dare say that this group of songs has held up MUCH better than those on that Toto album. If you enjoyed Craig Fuller's recordings with Pure Prairie League, or even more recent efforts with the revamped Little Feat, check out this album too. Some mighty fine songs on here!This CD reissue comes with a 12-page booklet, reproducing the original back cover of the album (that has a list --- in fine print --- of the many musicians who play on this album), plus new liner notes by Ed Osborne. Oddly, no song times are listed, but they do furnish songwriting credits.

As I write this, I'm shocked to see that there are no other reviews for this excellent compilation. C'mon, folks, did these rhythms! This is another exhilarating collection, an unearthing of buried musical African treasures from the crate-digging folks at Soundway Records. If you enjoyed any of the "Nigeria 70" collections, or Afro-Beat in general, this is another fine CD to add to your collection.Billed as "Psychedelic Afro-Rock & Fuzz Funk in 1970s Nigeria," this collection delivers as billed. As the liner notes explain, "At the beginning of the 1970s the rise of afro-centric consciousness started making bands fuse African elements into what had been throughout the 60s mere imitations of western groups." Of course Fela Kuti was making musical waves around this same time, but there were plenty of other lesser-known bands in Nigeria making equally inspired, albeit "weird sounding" music too, thus this compilation.The last song on here, "Chant to Mother Earth" by BLO, is perhaps the strangest and yet most enchanting of all the tracks. It sounds almost like a fusion of Santana and Jimi Hendrix mixed with Peter Green-era Fleetwood Mac. Haunting, atmospheric, and very powerful. The rest of the tracks are also very good, combining those promised funk and rock strains, some with a pleasing slinky groove. A few of the cuts also sound to me like they were inspired by those class soul-jazz records that the Blue Note label was putting out in the early 1970s; an intoxicating mix of horns, guitar, drums, and very funky organ playing. Hot and hotter! My favorites among the lesser-known acts include the tracks by The Elcados, Mono Mono, the Funkees (who also have a great CD of their own that's been reissued), and Joe King Kologbo & His Black Sound.The CD comes with a 24 page booklet that includes sleeve notes by album compiler Miles Claret, plus capsule summaries of each track. This is one of 3 CDs in the "Nigeria Rock Special" series and they are all highly recommended!

The blurb on the cover, saying: "Were Armistead Maupin to write Tales of the City and set it in Boston, he would have penned The Men From the Boys", caught my eye and motivated me to buy this book at a secondhand shop recently. It took me a while to get through it; one of those books that you start, put down, pick up again, repeat, until finally something clicks and you feel compelled to finish the damn thing! But in the end, I finished it and liked it quite a bit.Okay, perhaps this isn't a gay classic, and it's certainly not in the same league as the "Tales of the City" novels, but I found this to be a very well written and thought-provoking novel. As far as comparing it to Maupin's books, it wasn't nearly as funny or charming, and the characters not as remotely endearing. In fact, I found it hard to generate much love for any of the characters in this novel, although by the end of the final chapter I thing I finally came around to getting a better feel for them and at least empathizing with their tangled relationships and mindsets.The highest praise that I can give this novel is that the story felt very real. Yes, the plot --- if you want to call it that --- was thin, but in many ways it simply reflected the real way that gay men lived their lives. While I may not have liked all of the characters or the way they sometimes treated one another, much of it was painfully close to the truth in regards to gay life, especially as it was in the 1990s when this book was written and published. Because of that timeline, one might complain that the novel is "dated," but I actually enjoyed going back to that time, in all its glory and horror.Another way to gauge whether or not I liked this book was the final question: would I read another novel by this author? And the answer is a definitive yes. Mann impressed me as a very talented writer and I'd like to read other books, novels or not, that he has written.

As the "Simply Great" review says, this is indeed a magnificent compilation of Nigerian "Afro-Beat" music from the 1970s, sure to please anyone that has enjoyed the "Nigeria 70" collections, or most anything from this era, including the main practitioner of the sound, Fela Kuti."Afro Baby" might sound like an odd, if not questionable title for a compilation like this, but as the liner notes explain, the term "Afro Baby" was a nickname in Nigeria for those people that represented the trends and lifestyles of the time. "Afro", we are told, was more than just a sound of the time, but a state of mind that became associated with rebellion. In an essay by Benson Idonije that's included in the liner notes, he explains that "Afro Baby" also referred to people who were found to be smart or crafty in their dealings with other people, and it's in that context that the term is used in the song that's the title track to this CD, played by Stephen Olisa (misspelled as "Osita" on the back cover) Amaechi & His Afro-Rhythm Skies. This song, says the liner notes, is a perfect example of how musicians traced the highlife sounds of the 1960s to the Afro-Beat grooves of the 1970s.In addition to that track, and songs by familiar names from the era such as Fela, Orlando Julius, and Tunji Oyelana, there are some dynamite numbers by Bola Johnson, the Mebusas, Thony Shorby Nwenyi, and more. These songs invariably catch your attention and kick you upside the head --- and the booty --- thanks to a poly-rhythmic stew of guitars, horns, percussion, and some funky organ playing. Whew, this is hot stuff!This CD comes with a 16-page booklet that includes essays about this music by album compiler Miles Cleret and "A Nigerian Perspective" by Benson Idoniji, as well as capsule summaries of each track. An outstanding collection of 1970s Nigerian music.

These are pretty standard silpats.  These are great for anything gluten-free, because they don't stick.  I've been using silpats for years on my cooking blog, glutenfreedirtcheap.com, and that's why I can't wholeheartedly recommend these; the are a lot thinner than some others sold on amazon- if you're looking for a silpat that won't flail around under something heavy, look elsewhere.If you're trying to use these in a toaster oven, though, there is one major advantage to the thinness of these: they can be folded in half to fit in a standard toaster oven. For that use, I would recommend them.

I fed this to my corgi/chihuahua mix. She seems to like the taste, and it doesn't create digestive issues. It also doesn't seem to aggravate her allergies. I don't notice a change in her weight.Unfortunately, it also contains a large amount of cellulose.  Cellulose can cause a strong colitis reaction in any creature predisposed towards it. (Google: Science Daily colitis cellulose.)  Recommended, if your dog doesn't tend towards digestive issues.

My boyfriend tested this:  it's not an improvement over less expensive models.What's Bad:1.)  It causes irritation. He doesn't have particularly sensitive skin, and he owns two other Phillips Norelco shavers, specifically Arcitecs--and he says they don't hurt.2.)  The charger base is huge. It's about five inches wide, six inches deep including the power cable, and ten inches tall. You'll need a large bathroom counter or shelf to accommodate this.3.)  The included trimmer is a separate unit that has to be swapped with the shaver heads and stored separately. (Although it does fit in the travel case, with the shaver.)4.)  The included cleaner smells like toilet bowl cleaner. It's really objectionable.5.)  The included cleaner made the chemically sensitive people in our house sneeze--reading the instruction manual, unfortunately, there doesn't seem to be an unscented version.6.)  This is harder  to clean, than other Phillips models. You have to forcibly take the shaving head apart, so that hair gets everywhere.What's Good:1.) The travel case has a slightly hard shell, and it's reasonably protective.2.) It gives a close shave.3.) This is good for travel. You can just plug the unit into the charger cord, without taking along the huge cleaning base.This is just o.k. The cheaper Phillips models are better.

I was really excited to try this product--turmeric is really helpful for those with inflammatory disorders. Unfortunately, this is not a good idea for anyone with a tendency towards colitis, because the supplement is in cellulose capsules. If you Google, "cellulose colitis Science Daily", you'll find the 2015 studies which show a strong  colitis reaction in response to methylcellulose. It's unfortunate, because these are gluten-free, and would be a really good anti-inflammatory, otherwise.

This absorbs almost instantly. If you have low Vitamin D, this can help a lot of aches and pains caused by low Vitamin D. This is truly gluten free--I have fast reacting celiac, and I've been taking it for a week with no ill effects.One caveat: this is a tiny bit laxative. A non-soybean-oil source (which this is not), might be a better idea.

Much of this is trademark Mieville--fantastical, consistent alternate realities.  In that sense, this is exactly what you're expecting when you read Mieville's work.  (And the plot twists are amazing, and unbelievably unexpected.)  Mieville also writes so well, that there are moments of being transported, even in the context of, say, reading a film treatment about zombies.  Like almost everything he's ever published, this is very, very good.However, it's understandable that a lot of this hasn't been published before:  much of this is horror, which is not what I would expect when reading Mieville.  It's horror that is so well written, that in at least one story, I kept thinking I was reading Kaitelyn Kiernan, not Mieville. But, if horror isn't your thing, I can only recommend this for Mieville completists. (Which most of his fans probably are.) Recommended.

For reference, I've never used a pair of noise-blocking earphones, regularly, because I could not find any that worked with my normal-but-small ears. As a result, I've tried several pairs over the last few years.  These will probably be the first pair I've tried that I can actually use.Physical Comfort:  these are the most comfortable HD in-ear-earphones I have ever worn. I have tiny ears, and the smallest version of this fits well; I had not been able to find noise-blocking earphones that were comfortable, prior to trying these.  (I've tried at least four others, without success.)  Also, some noise-blocking earphones cause vertigo, and these do not cause any inner-ear problems.Sound Quality:  the headphone sound is really clear, almost sweet; the dynamic range that is almost a little too good--testing these with Carmina Burana, the quietest parts were a little difficult to hear, and the loudest parts were blowing out my eardrums. The sound is clear; these make it easy to hear vocal pronunciations in foreign languages.Noise Blocking:  these have some noise blocking, but it only blocks about 50% of ambient sound.  The noise blocking abilities of these is about average, for HD in-ear headphones.Overall: Recommended, and very good for small ears.

This is kind of a rough read.  The beginning of the story follows a female soldier being tortured by a terrifying adversary, who does something to her, in the course of an interrogation.  And then she wakes up somewhere else.You'll be tempted to put the story down at the beginning, but, it gets better. This is a gritty, classic sci-fi tale that reminded me of Neal Asher. (I have a hard time sitting through some of Asher's gore.)  Without giving anything away, the harder parts of this story make the ending all the more worth it. If you like the emotional aspects of Reynold's work, you'll love this, too.

This version of Ensure has a lot of extra added protein; it's really yummy version of this particular drink; it tastes like a real milkshake, without having an off or chemical aftertaste.  It's a tiny bit chalky, but not noticeably so.  The mouth feel is good, and this staves off hunger for a long time--probably because of the added grams of protein. It's also gluten and lactose free.However, for me personally, this caused a lot of abdominal pain, not like being glutened, but like actual food poisoning (I'm gluten, but not lactose intolerant.)  So, I started reading ingredients:  this has a lot of cellulose in it.  If you google, "cellulose colitis Science Daily," you'll find the study published in Nature in February of this year, which shows that there is a strong relationship between eating cellulose and having colitis, and it's a very marked reaction if you have any tendency towards getting colitis.So, I'd recommend this for the taste and the protein, but not for anyone with Crohn's IBD, Celiac, Gluten-intolerance or Ulcerative Colitis.

If you've had the round air-filters before, this may be a significant improvement.  Both quieter and easier to place in a room, there is a noticeable difference in allergens in the air when this is turned on, placed parallel to a wall.  (I turned this on its highest setting in an 800 square foot room; I was congested from summer allergies when I went to sleep, and able to breathe much better, four hours later.)Even better than its performance, is the lack of noise this makes during operation. From across a room, it sounds like the steam setting on a dishwasher, when this is on its highest setting. On its lowest setting, it's quiet enough to set next to a bed--but it's not noticeably effective on its lowest setting.The entire unit is about a foot and a half high, and about five inches wide.  It's small enough to fit under one edge of a table, so it's out of the way.  Out of the box, this requires opening the cover and inserting two air filters, and then it is ready to go. This can be used on its side, but I think it gets better air circulation positioned vertically.  It's impressive.One caveat: this not effective enough at the lowest setting, and too loud at that setting, to be useful in a smaller bedroom. Recommended for placement in any room where noise is not as important; and for larger rooms where this can be placed across a room from the user.

This is a very sturdy, well thought out backseat car cover. For reference, the front and back fit over the standard backseat size of a Toyota Prius.  There are spaces for the seatbelts to go through, so if you're using this with a backseat carseat, for either a dog or a child, it should work.I have used it to haul large potted plants, and it protects the back seat from dirt and water.  The attached pockets, attached on  one side are useful for storing other small items.  This does have one serious downside, though: because it's black, it gets hot.  It's not so hot that I wouldn't recommend it, at all--it doesn't burn hands when you touch it, if it's been in the car for several hours--but if a dog were sitting in this, it would be fairly uncomfortable unless you really have the AC on high.  Recommended, but not necessarily for summer months.

This is a nice tent, but it takes thirty minutes to assemble, with two people working in good weather, in good lighting. It packs up really, really small, and it's lightweight. For the size and weight, it might be worth it.When this first showed up on my doorstep, I thought it was something else.  This is only slightly larger and more heavy than a package of printer paper.  It's perfect for longer backpacking trips, as long as you're not going ultra-lightweight, and you're not planning on breaking the tent down every morning.The tent comes in a bag with mesh sides, so it can dry out, a little, when you pack it up.What's in the bag:Four parcels--1.) It has a separate waterproof nylon bag that contains four tiny guylines (little ropes that anchor the tent supports to hold them vertical) and ten ground stakes.2.)  A nylon bag for tent poles. (12 by 3, and several ounces in weight.)3.) The actual tent.4.)  The rainfly. (Tent cover.)5.) Ribbons (not cords, ribbons) that tie the rainfly and tent--and they are almost too short. It took two of us to tie the tent parcels back together.6.)  Instructions. There is a single legal-sized instruction sheet. You should probably already be familiar with tents before reading the instructions.  If not, you'll have to learn some new words:  "tent fly" (the rain cover), "guy cords" (the tent stake ropes), "ridge pole" (tent support).This does not include a footprint (another new word), which is a sheet of nylon to protect the tent and keep it dry.The materials are pretty standard, and the construction is solid. The tent has two doors, which is a nice feature. The interior tent height is comfortable. The tent body is entirely mesh, which might work well in a hot climate; this is pretty roomy for a two-person tent; it has small interior pockets and hooks for gear lofts; the tent has windows on the sides that could be used for star watching. However, I can only give this three and a half stars to four stars--it takes thirty minutes to assemble, if you have two people working on it.This would be good for camping in hot, wide open, star-heavy country; in rainy or colder climates, the fact that it takes so long to assemble might make you be pretty unhappy, while you are assembling your tent in the cold or rain.For reference, I put this together with a family member--who then showed me a much older  off-brand tent with fewer stakes, that he has had for fifteen years--his old tent took five minutes.  Because this particular tent is complicated and has a lot of parts, it takes quite a while to set up.  Recommended, but just barely.

This is only for vehicle use. That's not clear from the manufacturer's description.It's easy to install, if you don't mind reading the instructions:  it has to be powered by your car battery while in use, so you can't charge other electronics, etc.It also has a sticker on the box that talks about professional installation; professional installation isn't necessary. This is configured a lot like a CB radio antenna setup.Beyond that, I couldn't say.  I called Verizon, and spent twenty minutes on the phone with a service representative in June of 2015--the service rep said, "This is not a device we service. I can't give you permission to use it."So, having said that, the only advice I can give is to ask your service provider first.  Otherwise, this could be a very expensive mistake.

Following the story of a near-future assassin who wakes up with his memory wiped after every kill, you'll start reading this, thinking it's one sort of book, and then it becomes something entirely different.  When the plot shifts, it becomes an alternate-history earth, story.  If that's not your thing (I stopped reading both Connie Willis', "The Dog at Nighttime," and Gene Wolfe's, "The Long Earth), keep going.  This is an incredible book.Reminiscent of Ian Banks', "Use of Weapons," the author's writing is amazing because it describes almost continuous action, very coherently. It also manages a neat set of moral conundrums, without creating anything maudlin. This author does foreshadowing, depth, angst, and all the emotional twists that make up science fiction worth reading. Very Recommended.

These are like sponges, but in an almost-paper towel-like thickness. They work like paper towels--which means no paper waste.  Wet, they're flexible. Dry, they're like large flat sponges. They can be machine or hand washed and take about twelve hours to dry.  While they don't pick up quite as much as paper towels, for jobs that will require multiple passes, these can save a lot of paper waste.Also, because they're flexible, they work better than sponges at getting into nooks and crannies.I tested them cleaning out an old pantry that had dust, dirt, plant food, and, and moldy bags scattered in it. These picked up most of the debris, with no problems, and washed out with dish soap, in about five hand-wash rinses.They don't pick up everything--I followed with a paper towel, and still came away with a little more wet dirt. (If I were going to pick up really nasty stuff, I'd use a paper towel, first, to avoid putting the worst messes through the washing machine or into the water table.)After testing these on a pantry, I accidentally spilled baking soda on a greasy, 1950's linoleum floor. I decided to pick the baking soda up and clean the grease off the floor at the same time.  The sponge worked beautifully, cleaning the floor to a high shine, but the sponge itself came away black.  After washing the sponge in a machine washer on hot, there were still faint grease stains.  Also, the baking soda seemed to have started to tear apart the finish of the sponge, a little.These will hold up to even really greasy, abrasive jobs, better than a paper towel. If I were going to commit to these instead of paper towels, I'd buy several. Recommended.

Reminiscent of cold iced coffee chilling in the refrigerator, windows open to a summer breeze on windows covered by lace curtains, and the sound of Southern blues somewhere in the distance, these are perfect for hot summer nights with a breeze.The overall quality is the kind of thing you'd expect in a 1950's Austin bungalow, which is where I hung these; the edges are raw machine scallops; the lace is clearly synthetic. If you're looking for period-perfect early 1960-'s to '70's Southern curtains, which are somewhat cheaper construction, these are perfect; for recreating a certain era, I couldn't have found a better pair if I'd looked for a long time.Machine lace like this was designed to allow breezes in, without allowing people to see into a house with open windows at night.  While these aren't as fancy or well made as the best machine-made lace, these work very well for that purpose--they're opaque enough to provide privacy at night, while allowing light in during the day. Covered in a diffuse rose-and-leaf-pattern, the lace is consistently stitched and pretty. These are a good example of a good pair of lower-end machine lace curtains.If you're looking for machine lace reminiscent of a certain era, these are recommended.

This looks like interspecies-fantasy-magic of the Maguire/Andrews/Briggs-type. It is not.  Switching back and forth between the thirteenth century and modern-day, the story follows a twenty-first century author and her boyfriend, as they move into a picturesque old house in the Welsh highlands.  The 13th century storyline includes Merlin, a bit of torture porn, a bit of real porn, servants, adultery, and a vulnerable heroine. The writing is better than that found in most romance novels, so if you're into that kind of thing, it's worth picking up--and if you don't like sexual situations involving coercion and fear, it's not.

Narrated by a girl waking up in what seems like a coffin, this is a story about a bunch of teenagers who find themselves in a room full of dust and individual medical bays, and then they find themselves in some kind of huge building.  It's science fiction, so you know there is some kind of adventure ahead--and the author has asked us to write spoiler-free reviews, so I'm going to talk about the writing from here.Reminiscent of the work of Greg Bear, and plotted a little like a made-for-tv movie, this author writes well enough that I actually finished the book, which is definitely not something I always do. This isn't absolutely fantastic writing so much as it's really fantastic plotting.  As far as the overall story arc, this book is really, really good.I'm also tempted to write something like, "Tensely plotted, tight, and spine-tingling, this is a real page turner."  And, it is.Although the author tries to delve into Big Ideas, ultimately, the third act devolves a little into a B-movie. Despite that, the overall story is compelling enough, that this is a good escapist rainy-afternoon Saturday afternoon read you won't want to put down.  Appropriate for older teens. Some violence.
These are very pretty, but very shiny curtains. If you're looking for something that is sort of bland, these are not it. They're almost glassy, they're so reflective.

A couple of years ago, it became impossible to find imodium that didn't contain lactose--as most of the generics do--when McNeil stopped selling imodium in the U.S.  This works as well as the McNeil product; with the caveat that you have to take it about thirty minutes before you'd have to take the McNeil U.S. imodium. I'm so grateful that this is available anywhere.
This is a very flattering professional piece. Machine washable, and light weight, it's a good addition to a summer professional wardrobe.

These are beautiful plants--but they look like poison oak. If you're in Texas, people will rip these out, thinking they're dangerous weeds. It's a shame--these make really pretty creepers. They just don't work in the Southwest.
Love these. The fabric is great, and although they're a little small for the size, they're flattering. This is like the very old Coldwater Creek Pants.

I love these:  they are a worthy heir to Coldwater Creek, since it went bankrupt--with one exception.  You have to reinforce the crotch seams; this is really stretchy fabric, but the seams are not. The fabric is good enough that it's worth the extra twenty minutes with a needle and thread to avoid any embarrassing tears.

I used this to wrap really heavy diplomas in glass, in the middle of the night. The individual bubbles don't pop easily--the psychotic home contractor we were trying not to wake never heard a thing from our bubble wrap. He didn't even wake up until we started to change the locks.

Having just moved out of a house that had a fancy built in microwave, I was a little afraid to try to find a replacement. I mean, who really cooks in a microwave?  You need, "reheat," for nachos, a "baked potato," button, and the high setting to make water for tea.  This does all that, well. It's large enough for a regular smaller dinner plate, and it's sturdy and not scary. This is an excellent microwave for the price.

Fabulously well-constructed, this can be stored on its side in the refrigerator--it's that carefully made. And, the carafe itself is beautiful, thick plastic that doesn't take on stains. The only part I have some doubt about is the interior sieve, which is actually made of a fine plastic fabric mesh, not metal, so it's not clear how well it will hold up over time.Easy to clean, the carafe is wide enough that you can wash it with your bare hands if you have small hands, and leave it out in a dish drainer to air dry away any anaerobic bacteria. In short, it's great.One caveat:  you can't use this for espresso grind, or you'll be watching little espresso particles diffuse into your coffee. This needs medium grind or larger.

This is a really good dish draining mat if you're using a square drainer--for a standard dish drainer, you'd need two.  Much better looking in person, this is a thick, hefty drain mat. Reminiscent of modern rubber art, it's a nice addition to the kitchen. Recommended.

This is a sturdy, well-constructed dish tub. However, it's not deep enough to wash many dishes at once; it's about the depth of a standard butter-knife blade.  If you're planning on washing more than dishes for two or three people from a single meal, you'll need a bigger tub.  The drain is ingenious, though, and if you're a multiple-rinse hand-washer, this will get the job done faster. Recommended, with reservations.

Third Edit:After sending me a malfunctioning unit the first time, causing proxy server problems with the software associated with this, and generally being frustrating, Brother seems bent on digging themselves in deeper.  I got my replacement unit on a Thursday, and sent it back on a Saturday.  I have a UPS tracking number that says Brother has the unit, but Brother is now dunning me for a unit they have had for five days, according to UPS.Brother has had their nonfunctioning first unit back, five days ago, but they are sending me harassing emails. I'm not impressed. I'm leaving two stars, so I have one more to take off if they do anything else wrong.  Pass on this, and save yourself the annoyance.Second Edit:The scanner works well.  It dates each scan, and saves as a PDF.  The printer for black and white is lightning fast for individual pages.--and it's very clear printing. Like most modern printers, the top edge is about 1/20th of an inch off, but it's within acceptable parameters for professional printing.Pros:  You can set this up if your laptop does not have an external CD rom drive,and you're using a USB cord, instead of connecting wirelessly--most laptops without external CD ROM drives (It's the $350 Dell, British knockoff special) will require both USB ports; that means disconnecting the CD rom drive to plug in the printer; it works, even without the CD ROM drive attached. Very nice.Cons:  See belowFirst Edit:The setup will mess up a Chrome browser, as well. I can't even begin to tell you how frustrating this machine is.  I've had so many issues with it, that it's infuriating beyond belief.  (I agreed to participate in a Brother product study? It did something to my Windows proxy settings.)Maybe this is o.k. if you don't agree to participate in their study or update software (both use the proxy server).  Also, it doesn't print completely straight. So far, it works--after hours and hours of redoing my laptop.  (At one point in my life, I was a software developer; you shouldn't have to be that to fix whatever the setup for this does to your computer.)Recommended for the cheaper ink, and the fact that it does work at all. It's a huge effort to get it working, between the setup disk interfering with the formatting of your proxy server, and the fact that some of these units don't work at all. This is an exercise in frustration. I hope that they get the bugs worked out.First Review: This is a massive machine. It is a team lift-item. (It only weighs about 37 pounds, but it's so large it's difficult to move.) I spent about 30 minutes trying to clear jams, watching youtube videos about how to clear jams, and  I kept trying to clear a code that showed up on the machine, specifically, "Unable to initialize 8f."  I opened and closed all of the compartments and got ink all over my fingers. When the printer tried to work, it made a screeching noise, when it moved at all.  Supposedly that code means there is a clog somewhere. (Yes. The printer carriage does not work.)In addition, one of the hinges was not properly attached, and the scanner cover was not glued on all the way through the top of the scanner.So, I called Brother Customer Service; they were patient.  They put me on hold after telling me that the serial number on the back didn't exist  After another couple of minutes, they came back on the line and said, "This is a new item. We don't have it in our systems, so it does exist, but I can't help you with it. They then, "passed me up the chain," to try to get it to work.  I never got through to anyone who could get it to work after half an hour of trying to get it to work myself, and then twenty minutes on the phone with customer service, and then the call dropped.  There may be units like this that work on the first try--but I didn't get one.  This unit is too heavy and too expensive to take the risk that it is defective.  The scanner surface, hinges, and printer carriage were not in working order.  As of this writing, my saintly boyfriend has agreed to help me move the printer to the post office in the back of his hatchback, and Brother has told me they will replace it. (After hours of very patient, non-native speaking call reps that, based on their accents, speak Thai and French, or possibly Cantonese and French.)I've been continuing to try to get this to work.  I'm impressed with Brother customer service. They keep calling me back, even though I'm in a Verizon dead spot and my phone keeps dropping the call. The Brother company has said, through tech reps that are in New Jersey (another unmistakeable accent) that they will replace the unit. Stay tuned.
